document.body:
111-12008 Oral Health Annual Evidence Update - Introduction

back to contents

  Introduction & Editorial

 

Oral Health Evidence Update
by Professor Barbara Chadwick, Clinical Lead Oral Health Specialist Library


I am pleased to introduce the results of our 2007 Annual Evidence Update. This is an opportunity to present those interested in evidence-based oral health with a general overview of new knowledge across a range of topics.

 

It’s interesting to see that half of the 64 systematic reviews we identified conclude that there simply isn’t enough high quality evidence to make a clear clinical decision. A typical example is Schwarz and Larson's review of prophylactic use of antibiotics after tooth extraction and implant placement. They identified only 13 studies that met their inclusion criteria and concluded that “Overall [the] body of literature was limited and of poor quality.”

 

Part of the work of the OHSL is to ensure that these uncertainties are captured for a new Database of Uncertainties about the Effects of Treatments. DUETS aims to publish uncertainties that cannot currently be answered by referring to reliable up-to-date systematic reviews of existing research evidence as a means of prioritising new research in the UK.

 

Periodontal disease continues to be a fertile area for systematic reviewers. Among the topics considered in 2007 were stress and psychological factors as possible risk factors for periodontal disease (Peruzzo et al) and periodontitis as a factor in the prevalence and incidence of Coronary Heart Disease (CHD) (Bahekar et al), and in preterm low birth weight (Vergnes et al). The results are interesting and point to potential associations, but all the authors highlight the need for large scale, well designed trials to confirm this.

 

Equally a review considering a possible relationship between dental amalgam and multiple sclerosis (Aminzadeh and Etminan) identifies the need for additional research to definitively rule out any association.

 

When asked to identify particular issues, bisphosphonate-induced osteonecrosis of the jaw (ONJ) comes up regularly. Following Woo et al’s 2006 systematic review, 2007 saw a new review looking at the incidence of osteonecrosis in osteoporosis patients receiving oral bisphosphonates (Panzanias et al). This indicated that prevalence of ONJ was low in comparison with the number of prescriptions. More important though is how we identify and manage both at-risk patients and those who have developed ONJ. Library staff are in the process of developing a critically appraised resource, as part of which they identified an evidence-based guideline: Bisphosphonate-associated osteonecrosis of the jaw: report of a task force of the American Society for Bone and Mineral Research. They also found a very clear piece of patient information on ONJ produced by Cancer Research UK.

Systematic reviews are defined as the pinnacle of evidence. However, they are only as good as the methodology employed. The Library has a policy of critically appraising all non-core content and the process provided an opportunity to look in depth at the methodological quality of 2007 Oral Health systematic reviews. Initial results indicate that search methods are a particular area of concern. The methods used in the majority of reviews were unlikely to identify all relevant studies; a failure that potentially compromises their findings.

 

Finally, I would like to express my thanks to those involved in developing this Annual Evidence Update. The Editorial Board volunteered their time to provide a clinical perspective on the critical appraisals. I would also like to thank Fiona Morgan and Ruth Turley, Information Specialists on the OHSL team who have been responsible for searching and critically appraising the literature and who have done much of the work to pull the update together. 

 

 
Barbara Chadwick is Professor of Paediatric Dentistry and Student Affairs Tutor at Cardiff University School of Dentistry.

 

]]>

document.body:
111-12008 Oral Health Annual Evidence Update - Methodology

back to contents

   Methodology

 

An electronic search for systematic reviews was conducted in the following databases: AMED, ASSIA, CINAHL, Medline, Medline in Process, Embase and PsycINFO using the search strategy outlined in our Quality Policy¹. In addition, we hand searched or scanned the electronic tables of contents of thirteen oral health journals:

• Angle Orthodontist
• British Dental Journal
• Clinical Oral Implants Research
• European Archives of Paediatric Dentistry
• International Journal of Oral & Maxillofacial Implants
• International Journal of Oral & Maxillofacial Surgery
• Journal of Clinical Periodontology
• Journal of Dental Research
• Journal of Dentistry
• Journal of Oral & Maxillofacial Surgery
• Journal of Prosthetic Dentistry
• Journal of the American Dental Association
• Oral Surgery, Oral Medicine, Oral Pathology, Oral Radiology, and Endodontics

 

The electronic search identified 1494 papers of which 239 were reviewed in full text. Hand searching identified an additional 25 reviews for potential inclusion – most as a result of two journal supplements not being indexed.

 

In addition to 16 Cochrane reviews added as core Library content, a total of 55 systematic reviews were identified as meeting the inclusion criteria (see Quality Policy).  52 papers were critically appraised by OHSL staff and reviewed by the Editorial Board and three were identified as new additions to the DARE database. Seven papers were excluded at critical appraisal stage because of substantive methodological issues; giving a final total, including Cochrane reviews, of 64 systematic reviews for 2007.

In addition to systematic reviews, OHSL staff worked with the National Library of Guidelines to identify the latest guidelines meeting their selection criteria. 14 relevant guidelines were identified.

¹ New systematic reviews identified in the Cochrane Library, DARE, HTA or NEED are considered to be core content and are added on a quarterly or monthly basis as they become available. To ensure we capture content added in this way, we also search our Library.

]]>

document.title: 2009 Annual Evidence Update on Antenatal and Pregnancy Care - Dental treatment during pregnancy
document.topics: <![CDATA[ SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORAL DISORDERS,ORAL HEALTH,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,PERIODONTOLOGY,ASSOCIATED CONDITIONS,TREATMENT & MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body:
111-12009 Annual Evidence Update on Antenatal and Pregnancy Care - Dental treatment during pregnancy

There has been a considerable volume of research into the question of whether periodontal disease in pregnant women is associated with adverse pregnancy outcomes – particularly pre-term birth (PTB) and low birth weight (LBW). Seven systematic reviews looking at associations between periodontal health and pregnancy were published between 2002 and 2008. All found some evidence for a link, but include the caveat that larger, high quality studies are required to confirm the connection between periodontal disease and adverse pregnancy outcomes.

The most recent review [Polyzos et al 2009] raises the key question as to whether periodontal disease treatment with scaling and/or root planing during pregnancy may reduce these adverse outcomes. It concludes that there is some evidence in favour of treating periodontal disease during pregnancy. 

Periodontal disease is an infection of the tissue supporting the teeth that affects up to 40 per cent of adults. According to the British Dental Health Foundation, hormone changes during pregnancy make women more open to oral health problems such as gum disease. Maternal periodontal disease is associated with increased risks of PTB and LBW. In the UK there is no guidance in this area, although common practice is to undertake scaling and root planing during pregnancy but restrict anti-microbials use to acute infections only, limit the amount of radiographs and not undertake surgery until after the birth.

The mechanisms by which surgical treatment of periodontal disease might reduce PTB rate remain unknown. However, the authors suggest the benefit is likely to be related to the decline of oral cavity pathogen concentration and the consequent reduction of transportation of organisms to the amniotic fluid and chorionic membranes. In addition, a reduction in circulating inflammatory mediators produced in the oral crevice (and subsequently into the systemic circulation) of women with periodontal disease might result from surgical treatment leading to reduced exposure of genital tract tissues to these mediators. Finally, the local inflammatory response in the crevice may lead to a systemic inflammatory immune response increasing the sensitivity of immune cells in the amnion (or other genital tract tissues) to an inflammatory stimulus such as ascending bacteria from the lower to the upper genital tract; therefore, surgical treatment of periodontal disease could be beneficial simply by reducing the periodontal driver of the systemic response.

Dr Catriona Murray, academic clinical fellow in obstetrics and gynaecology at The John Radcliffe Hospital, Oxford comments: "Interestingly, the risk of pre-eclampsia, (a pregnancy related disease whose pathophysiology is thought to be related to a systemic inflammatory response), was shown to be increased in women with periodontal disease [Conde-Agudelo et al. 2008]). However, the effect of treatment of the periodontal disease was not evaluated in that meta-analysis. It should be noted that in the subgroup analysis no reduction in PTB was seen for those with more severe periodontal disease and consideration must be given to the potential dangers of bacteraemia associated with the procedure."

Professor Barbara Chadwick, Clinical Lead for NHS Evidence – oral health, adds, "This metaanalysis suggests that there is an association between periodontal disease and increased risk of PTB and LBW but the largest randomized trial included in the review did not find periodontal treatment during pregnancy to be beneficial. Weaknesses in the designs of included studies limit the conclusions that can be drawn and, frustratingly, it is not possible to make firm clinical recommendations for dental care.

"The generally cautious approach to managing pregnant patients that many dentists follow remains appropriate. However, several large randomised controlled trials are underway to test the hypothesis that periodontal treatment can reduce rates of these adverse pregnancy outcomes. If results from these trials agree with this metaanalysis, periodontal assessment and therapy could become a standard part of antenatal care."

 

_________________________________________________________


Polyzos NP, Polyzos IP, Mauri D, Tzioras S, Tsappi M, Cortinovis I, Casazza G. Effect of periodontal disease treatment during pregnancy on preterm birth incidence: a metaanalysis of randomized trials. American Journal of Obstetrics and Gynecolology 2009; 200(3):225-32.

Conde-Agudelo A, Villar J, Lindheimer M. Maternal infection and risk of preeclampsia: Systematic review and metaanalysis. American Journal of Obstretics and Gynecology, 2008; 198 (1): 7-22.

Vergnes JN, Sixou M. Preterm low birth weight and maternal periodontal status: a meta-analysis. American Journal of Obstetrics & Gynecology 2007; 196: 135e1-135e7.

Xiong X, Buekens P, Vastardis S, Yu SM. Periodontal disease and pregnancy outcomes: state-of-the-science. Obstetrical and Gynecological Survey 2007; 62(9):605-15.

Xiong X, Buekens P, Fraser WD, Beck J, Offenbacher S. Periodontal disease and adverse pregnancy outcomes: a systematic review. British Journal of Obstetrics and Gynaecology 2006; 113 (2): 135–143.

Khader YS, Ta'ani Q, Periodontal diseases and the risk of preterm birth and low birth weight: a meta-analysis, Journal of Periodontology 2005; 76(2): 161-5.

Scannapieco FA, Bush RB, Paju S. Periodontal disease as a risk factor for adverse pregnancy outcomes. A systematic review. Annals of Perodontology 2003; 8(1): 70-78.

Madianos PN, Bobetis GA, Kinane DF.Is periodontisis associated with an increased risk of coronary heart disease and preterm and/or low birth weight births? Journal of Clinical Periodontology 2002; 29 (Suppl. 3): 22-36. 


 

]]>

document.body:
111-12009 Oral Cancer Annual Evidence Update - Commentary

 

 

 

Dr David I Conway
Clinical Senior Lecturer in Dental Public Health, University of Glasgow Dental School;
Honorary Consultant in Dental Public Health, NHS National Services Scotland, Information Services Division

 


 

 

 

As we enter Mouth Cancer Awareness Week [1] it is a good opportunity to reflect on the body of literature published in the past 12 months. This research has aimed to further our understanding of the aetiology of oral cancer and to inform the development of evidence based practice to better treat and manage patients with the disease.

The need for reflection seems to be greater than ever – with the spotlight on oral cancer as it regularly hits the headlines in the UK. “Alarming rise in oral cancer rates among forty somethings” [2] and “Drink blamed for oral cancer rise” [3] were typical stories which focused on the increasing rates of the disease in young people, and on the role of excessive alcohol consumption in oral cancer risk. Their source was the Cancer Research UK publication of epidemiological statistics for oral cancer incidence [4].

However, behind these eye-catching headlines, a detailed interrogation of the data reveal that the facts remain: oral cancer is a disease primarily of older adults (the median age is 65), is more common among men (males : females ratio is 2 : 1 – albeit this ratio has been converging) and is increasing among those living in our most deprived communities (in Scotland by 2002, incidence rates were 2.5 times higher among those in the most compared to least deprived areas) [5].

In the UK there were 5,325 new cases and 1,841 deaths in 2007 from oral cancer in the UK [3]. Globally head and neck cancers are among the most common in the world accounting for over 550,000 new cases and over 300,000 deaths per year [6] – with the greatest burden falling upon low- and medium-income countries [6]. Survival for patients with head and neck cancer is poor and there has been limited improvement in the last three decades [7].

This commentary sets out to identify and review all systematic reviews published in the past year which included oral cancer as a focus, to critically appraise them, and to interpret the evidence. The broad areas of oral cancer research included here fall into the following categories and will be considered in turn:
• risk factors
• prevention
• diagnosis and referral
• treatment and management 
• clinical guidelines

I must acknowledge the support I received from the NHS Evidence - oral health team, who identified and critically appraised all the reviews included in this commentary.


Newly published evidence in 2009

There were 15 systematic reviews and 2 clinical guidelines related to oral cancer, published in the year November 2008 to October 2009 – they are summarised in Table 1 and Table 2 respectively.

 

Table 1: Systematic reviews in oral cancer in 2009

 Paper   Research Area  Study Type  Quality Assessment
Lee et al, 2009 [8] Risk
associated with smokeless tobacco 		Meta-analysis of 98 studies (8 cohort, 90 case control)
 Weak data, methodological flaws in review and authors have significant competing interests
Smith et al, 2009  [12] Risk
biomarkers in dysplasia

Systematic review and meta-analysis of 13 observational studies  

 Well conducted review but included studies were of poor quality
Zhou et al, 2009 [13] Risk
genetic risk factor 		Systematic review and meta-analysis of 8 case control studies (1326 cases and 3,130 controls) Poor quality studies and review had methodological flaws
Zhuo et al, 2009 [14]  Risk
genetic risk factor		 Systematic review and meta-analysis of 27 case control studies Review has methodological flaws; lack of information on potential confounders
Kim 2009 [16] Prevention
garlic 		Narrative systematic review, includes 1 case control study relevant to oral cancer Poorly conducted review with weak data
Boehm et al, 2009 [17] Prevention
green tea		 Systematic review  includes I prospective cohort study relevant to oral cancer  Cochrane review conducted using a high quality methodology. Limited data of medium quality 
Gómez et al, 2009 [19]

Diagnosis and referral diagnostic delay

 Systematic review and meta-analysis of 9 retrospective cross-sectional studies Significant flaws in review methodology and limited quality data
Goy et al, 2009 [20] Diagnosis and referral
diagnostic delay		 Narrative systematic review of 27 studies; study type not defined Review of limited methodological quality. Significant clinical heterogeneity
Huang et al, 2009 [21] Diagnosis and referral
tumour thickness and cervical lymph involvement		 Systematic review of 16 studies; study type unclear. Pooled data for total of 1136 patients Review has some methodological flaws. Studies had limited sample size
Bohlius et al, 2009 [22]Treatment and management
erythropoietin 		Treatment and management
erythropoietin darbopoietin		 Narrative systematic review. 3 RCTs included patients with head and neck cancer only Cochrane review using appropriate methodology. Sequence generation unclear in all three studies, allocation concealment unclear in one study
Kassab et al, 2009 [23] Treatment and management
homeopathic medicines for adverse effects		 Narrative systematic review.  2 RCTs included patients with head and neck cancer Cochrane review conducted using a high quality methodology. Sequence generation and allocation concealment unclear in studies
Kedge 2009 [24] Treatment and management
moist desquamation in radiotherapy		 Narrative systematic review of 9 RCTs and 1 CCT  Well conducted review, limited by having one author. Overall study quality poor
Lambin et al, 2009 [25] Treatment and management
erythropoietin		 Systematic review and meta-analysis of 5 RCTs of patients with head and neck cance Cochrane review using appropriate methodology. Only one study showed no risk of bias
LeBon et al, 2009 [26] Treatment and management
topical opioids in palliative care		 Systematic review of 6 RCTs and 13 case reports Review has some methodological flaws.
Studies of low to medium quality
Stableforth et al, 2009 [27] Treatment and management
Immunonutrition 		 Systematic review of 10 RCTs  Some elements of review methodology unclear. Included studies inadequately powered.

 

Table 2: Clinical guidelines in oral cancer in 2009

NICE Guideline [28 Cetuximab for the treatment of recurrent and/or metastatic squamous cell cancer of the head and neck Clinical Guideline Appropriate high quality methodology
NHS Clinical Knowledge Summary [29] Head/neck cancer - suspected Evidence based practice review Appropriate high quality methodology

 

Risk associated with smokeless tobacco
 
Lee et al’s [8] systematic review and meta-analysis investigating the relationship between smokeless tobacco and all cancer is a follow-up from their 2007 review which focussed entirely on oral cancer [9]. Their new study found an additional three studies on the risk in oral cancer. They found similar results in both reviews with a significant increased risk for oral cancer associated for past smokeless tobacco use in the USA but not for Scandinavian snuff.  

The authors declare competing interests in the form of consultancy work for “a number of tobacco, pharmaceutical and chemical companies”. Without doubting the scientific ethics of the individual authors – it is disappointing that doubts around the motivation and purpose of this research inevitably appear at the back of one’s mind while reading this review. There is a well documented significant debate on whether tobacco funded research is ethical and should be published in the scientific literature at all [10, 11]. However, on the plus side for this review – the authors‘ conflicts of interest are up front, declared and not hidden.

Key message: There is a lower risk of oral cancer associated with smokeless compared to smoking tobacco. As this risk still remains and is significant, it would be difficult to justify advising use of smokeless tobacco as a strategy in smoking cessation. 

 

Biomarkers in dysplasia of the oral cavity

Smith et al [12] undertook a well-conducted systematic review into biomarkers for oral cancer. There were methodological limitations in their review primarily associated with limitations in the underlying studies – including wide study heterogeneity, small sample sizes and design of the studies included in the review. Therefore, the results need to be interpreted with caution. The main findings were the identification of a range of pathological and genetic biomarkers in oral dysplasia that are associated with progression to oral cancer.

Key message: There is potential to identify biomarkers to help predict oral cancer progression risk in patients with oral dysplastic lesions. This in turn could change clinical practice in terms of targeting of treatment and follow-up. More and better research is required to hone these findings.

 

Genetic risk factors of oral cancer

Zhou et al [13] identified the Arg194Trp polymorphism in the X-ray repair cross-complementing group 1 gene as a potential risk factor of oral cancer in a meta-analysis of 8 case-control studies. The search and quality assessment within the review was limited. The risk of oral cancer among Asians associated with this gene was quantified as a 35% increased risk. This gene has been described as potentially modifying the effects of smoking and betel quid chewing.

The same group also undertook a further meta-analysis investigating CYP1A1 and GSTM1 polymorphisms - Zhou et al [14]. Both genotypes were not significant in Asian or white populations

Key message: Identification of genetic markers in the future could inform risk assessment and treatment planning. We remain a while away from definitive applications in practice.


Further research on risk factors for oral cancer

Large international consortia are increasingly coming together to undertake pooled analysis. In relation to epidemiological research - the International Head and Neck Cancer Epidemiology (INHANCE) consortium, established in 2004 to contribute elucidating the aetiology of head and neck cancer by providing opportunities for pooled analyses of individual patient data on head and neck cancer on a very large scale (with 33 studies pooling data on nearly 25,000 cases and over 33,000 controls) [15]. This is the way forward with regard to elucidating better understanding of risk factors for oral cancer.

 

Prevention of oral cancer

Kim conducted a very interesting review into the association with garlic intake and reduced cancer risk [16]. In relation to cancer in general there was limited evidence to support the role of garlic in cancer prevention. But one case-control study reported a near 40% reduced cancer risk associated with high consumption of garlic. 

Green tea was the focus of a high quality Cochrane review by Boehm and colleagues [17]. They found insufficient evidence to give any firm recommendations regarding green tea for cancer risk or indeed prevention in general or oral cancer in particular.

In terms of diet and oral cancer risk, with the exception of the well known risk associated with alcohol consumption, there is only reasonable evidence (from systematic reviews) to support the role of fresh fruit and vegetables in reducing oral cancer risk [18].

Key message: Prevention strategies in terms of behavioural risk factors need to continue to focus on reducing smoking and alcohol consumption, and increasing fruit and vegetable consumption.

[Those who enjoy green tea and garlic should continue to do so!]

 

Diagnosis and referral

Diagnosis delay was investigated in a meta-analysis by Gómez et al [19]. Viewing the results with caution, primarily due to the limitations of the original research included in the review –delay in diagnosis was broadly associated with more advanced stage disease compared to patients with no delay. More research is clearly required in this area, including prospective studies with strict methodology. Both patient and service side factors need to be considered – often delay is put down to patients’ not seeking care, when there may be barriers to this care and delays associated with identification and referral that need to be better understood and ultimately improved.

Goy et al undertook a similar systematic review for head and neck cancer – including oral cancer [20]. While the review was well conducted, it suffered from the very mixed nature (high heterogeneity) of the studies included. This review found no evidence to support the relationship between patient delay and tumour stage at diagnosis. This is counterintuitive, but perhaps suggests that it doesn’t matter how late the diagnosis is – getting any stage of diagnosis of oral cancer is too late. Further work is also required to investigate diagnosis delay related to staging and to prognosis.
 
Key message: Services need to be oriented to and focus on early diagnosis, but further research is required to understand how to improve this. 

Huang et al in their meta-analysis confirmed a strong association between tumour thickness and cervical lymph-node involvement [21]. While the meta-analysis was not of the highest quality, the strength of association would seem to over-ride this concern.

Key message: Tumour thickness is a valid predictor in planning neck treatment. 
The optimal cut-off point for tumour thickness is 4mm - with oral tumours thicker than this requiring a prophylactic neck dissection.


Reviews on treatment

Bohlius et al [22] undertook a Cochrane review including analysis of individual patient data to investigate erythropoietin or darbepoetin treatment in cancer patients. The review followed robust Cochrane methodology and included only three head and neck cancer trials (out of 53 cancer trials in the whole review). Erythropoietin or darbepoetin treatment worsened survival overall (there was no specific oral or head and neck analysis). For those patients undergoing chemotherapy, the worsening was less pronounced.

Lambin and colleagues [25] undertook a Cochrane review specifically into the use of erythropoietin as an adjuvant treatment with (chemo) radiation therapy for head and neck cancer. Interestingly, by contrast to Bohlius, they identified five trials, they did however agree that erythropoietin with radiotherapy had worse outcomes than radiotherapy alone.

Key message: There is not enough evidence to support the use of erythropoietin treatment in head and neck cancer patients undergoing radiotherapy and limited evidence even as an adjuvent to chemotherapy.  


Kassab et al [23] undertook their Cochrane review into the controversial area of homeopathic medicines and their potential role in limiting adverse effects from cancer treatments. Robust methodology found some preliminary data in support of the efficacy of topical calendula for prophylaxis of acute dermatitis during radiotherapy and Traumeel S mouthwash in the treatment of chemotherapy-induced stomatitis.

The area of homeopathic medicines is controversial and it can only become more credible if further and more robust randomised control trials are undertaken. Thus far, there have been limited randomised control trials in this area.

Key message: More research is required into homeopathic medicines in managing adverse effects in cancer treatments.


There was a systematic review investigating the effectiveness and acceptability of interventions for moist desquamation in radiotherapy patients by Kedge [24]. Moist desquamation is a nasty side-effect of radiotherapy where the skin thins and weeps as it loses its epithelial integrity. In a very well conducted systematic review, including one head and neck cancer trial amongst the 10 included, a mixed picture of evidence was found regarding the use of hydrogels and hydrocolloid dressings – but they sometimes improved patient comfort (although not other aspects of the condition – such as duration). There was no evidence to support other interventions for moist desquamation.
 
Key message: Hydrogels and hydrocolloid dressings can improve patient comfort in those with moist desquamation following radiotherapy.


LeBon and co-workers in a thorough systematic review found some evidence to support the use of topical opioids in the palliative care for cancer patients [26]. The review included only one head and neck trial (out of the 6 RCTs and 13 case reports identified in the review). However there is limited evidence to transfer this to clinical practice in terms of ideal opioid, starting dose, interval of administration, methods of titration, or carrier, nor which wounds are suitable for this treatment.

Key message: There is not enough evidence to support the use of topical opioids in head and neck cancer patients. 


Stableforth et al [27] undertook a systematic review into the role of immunonutrition in patients undergoing surgery for head and neck cancer. The review had limited methodology providing evidence mostly from small trials with incomplete reporting. The pooled estimates showed a reduction in length of hospital stay with perioperative immunonutrition – but the mechanism was unclear.

Key message: Further research in the form of adequately powered trials need to be undertaken to substantiate the benefits of immunotherapy in patients undergoing surgery for head and neck cancer (although the evidence is beginning to look promising).

 

Guidelines published in 2009

In the past year, two relevant clinical guidelines have also been published. There was a NICE Guideline on Cetuximab for the treatment of recurrent and/or metastatic squamous cell cancer of the head and neck [28]. NICE concluded that cetuximab, given in combination with platinum-based chemotherapy for the treatment of recurrent and/or metastatic squamous cell carcinoma of the head and neck, could not be recommended as a cost-effective use of NHS resources. The NICE Committee noted that some people may be currently receiving cetuximab in combination with platinum-based chemotherapy for this indication and recommended that these people should have the option to continue treatment until they and their clinician consider it appropriate to stop.

NICE decisions on the cost-effectiveness of medication often receive adverse publicity. In this current economic climate, decisions around cost-effectiveness are ever more important as the health service has tighter financial constraints. But, to some degree, it was always thus – there is always a finite level of resource and decisions to fund one treatment (particularly costly and not fully clinically proven treatments) have an opportunity cost and impact on funding other areas of the health care.

A Clinical Knowledge Summary on what health care practitioners should do if head and neck cancer is suspected was also published in this past year [29]. All of the general recommendations were considered at the lowest level (D) evidence – which indicates that they are based primarily from evidence from expert committee reports, opinions and/or clinical experience of respected authorities. This highlights the need for more research into head and neck/oral cancer.

Key message: A patient who presents with symptoms suggestive of head and neck or thyroid cancer should be referred to an appropriate specialist or the neck lump clinic, depending on local arrangements

Any patient with persistent symptoms or signs related to the oral cavity in whom a definitive diagnosis of a benign lesion cannot be made, should be referred or followed up until the symptoms and signs disappear. If the symptoms and signs have not disappeared after six weeks, an urgent referral should be made.

Primary health professionals should advise all patients, including those with dentures, to have regular dental checkups.

 

Finally, in relation to the evidence for the primary treatment and management of oral cancer, the Cochrane Systematic Reviews on Oral Cancer (CSROC) group [30] are working on systematically reviewing the evidence in relation to oral cancer treatment and management. While the review into surgical treatment has already been published [31], the work continues in relation to chemotherapy, radiotherapy, and immunotherapy/biotherapy [32].


References

1 Mouth Cancer Awareness Week [website] http://rdoc.org.uk/ [accessed November, 2009].

2 Cancer Research UK Alarming rise in oral cancer rates among fortysomethings Press Release Tuesday 11 August 2009. London: Cancer Research UK, 2009. http://info.cancerresearchuk.org/news/archive/pressrelease/2009-08-11-alarming-rise-in-oral-cancer-rates-among-fortysomethings [accessed November, 2009].

3 BBC Online. Drink blamed for oral cancer rise. London: BBC News. http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/8193639.stm [accessed November, 2009]

4 Cancer Research UK Oral Cancer – UK Incidence Statistics. London: Cancer Research UK, 2009.
http://info.cancerresearchuk.org/cancerstats/types/oral/incidence/index.htm#age [accessed November, 2009].

5 Conway DI, Brewster DH, McKinney PA, Stark J, McMahon AD, Macpherson LMD. Widening socio-economic inequalities in oral cancer incidence in Scotland, 1976-2002. British Journal of Cancer 2007; 96: 818-820.

6 Ferlay J, Bray F, Pisani P, Parkin DM, GLOBOCAN 2002 cancer incidence, mortality and prevalence worldwide IARC CancerBase No. 5, version 2.0, Lyon: IARC Press, 2004. 

7 Karim-Kos HE, de VE, Soerjomataram I, Lemmens V, Siesling S, Coebergh JW. , Recent trends of cancer in Europe: a combined approach of incidence, survival and mortality for 17 cancer sites since the 1990s, European Journal of Cancer 2008; 44: 1345-1389.

8 Lee PN, Hamling J. Systematic review of the relation between smokeless tobacco and cancer in Europe and North America. BMC Medicine 2009; 7: 36.

9 Weitkunat R, Sanders E, Lee PN. Meta-analysis of the relation between European and American smokeless tobacco and oral cancer. BMC Public Health 2007; 7: 334.
 
10 King J, Yamey G, Smith R. For and against: Why journals should not publish articles funded by the tobacco industry: For and Against. BMJ 2000; 321:1074.

11 Chapman S. Research from tobacco industry affiliated authors: need for particular vigilance. Tobacco Control 2005; 14: 217-219.

12 Smith J, Rattay T, McConkey C, Helliwell T, Mehanna H, Smith J, et al. Biomarkers in dysplasia of the oral cavity: a systematic review. Oral Oncology 2009; 45: 647-53.

13 Zhou C, Zhou Y, Li J et al. The Arg194Trp polymorphism in the X-ray repair cross-complementing group 1 gene as a potential risk factor of oral cancer: a meta-analysis. Tohoku Journal of Experimental Medicine 2009; 219: 43-51.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: 2009 Oral Cancer Annual Evidence Update - Methods
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,ORAL CANCER]]>
document.body:
111-12009 Oral Cancer Annual Evidence Update - Methods

back to contents

Methods

 

Search strategy

The following search strategy was developed in Medline and adapted to the remaining databases.

1     mouth neoplasms.ti,ab. or exp Mouth Neoplasms
2     "head and neck neoplasms"/
3     exp mouth neoplasms/
4     ((cancer$ or tumour$ or tumor$ or neoplas$ or malignan$ or carcinoma$ or metatasta$) adj5 (oral$ or intra-oral$ or gingiva$ or oropharyn$ or mouth$ or tongue$ or cheek or cheeks or gum or gums or palatal or palate or intraoral or (head adj neck))).ti,ab.
5     or/1-4
6     meta-analysis.pt,sh.
7     (meta-anal: or metaanal:).tw.
8     (quantitativ: review or quantitativ: overview:).tw.
9     (systematic: review: or systematic: overview:).tw.
10     (methodologic: review: or methodologic: overview:).tw.
11     (integrative research review: or research integration:).tw.
12     quantitativ: synthes:.tw.
13     or/6-12
14     (medline or medlars).tw,sh. or embase.tw.
15     (scisearch or psychinfo or psycinfo).tw.
16     (psychlit or psyclit).tw.
17     (hand search: or manual search:).tw.
18     (electronic database: or bibliographic database:).tw.
19     (pooling or pooled analys: or mantel haenszel).tw.
20     (peto or der simonian or dersimonian or fixed effect:).tw.
21     or/14-20
22     review.pt,sh. or review:.tw. or overview:.tw.
23     21 and 22
24     13 or 23
25     5 and 24
26     limit 25 to (english language and yr="2000 - 2007")

 

Sources

We searched the following electronic sources for systematic reviews, meta-analyses and guidelines published in English between November 2008 and October 2009.

  • Amed
  • ASSIA
  • CINAHL
  • Embase
  • Medline
  • Medline-in-Process
  • PsycINFO
  • Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews
  • DARE
  • NHS EED
  • HTA
  • National Library for Guidelines and National Library for Public Health
  • NHS Evidence - oral health, cancer and ENT/audiology specialist collections

We hand searched or scanned the electronic tables of contents of eight journals: 

  • British Dental Journal
  • International Journal of Oral & Maxillofacial Implants
  • International Journal of Oral & Maxillofacial Surgery 
  • Journal of Dental Research
  • Journal of Dentistry
  • Journal of Oral & Maxillofacial Surgery
  • Journal of the American Dental Association
  • Oral Surgery, Oral Medicine, Oral Pathology, Oral Radiology, and Endodontics

In addition, NHS Choices, the British Dental Health Foundation and cancer charity websites were searched for patient information,

 

Inclusion Criteria

To be included in the collection, a systematic review had to meet the following criteria:

  • Search strategy includes at least one electronic database
  • Inclusion and exclusion criteria detailed 
  • Included studies have been quality assessed 
  • Results of the included studies are reported

 

Results

The search strategy identified 370 potentially relevant systematic reviews. After scanning the titles and abstracts, 242 duplicate references and clearly irrelevant records were removed. 128 papers were reviewed in full-text, of which 15 systematic reviews met the collection’s inclusion criteria. Two new guidelines were also identified.

 

Critical appraisal

Journal-published systematic reviews which are not appraised by the Database for Reviews and Dissemination were critically appraised by Information Specialists from the NHS Evidence - oral health using internationally recognised methods and a critical summary written. The critical appraisal, summary and paper of each included review has been checked by a clinician for accuracy and contextual issues.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: 2009 Oral Health Annual Evidence Update - Introduction
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY]]>
document.body:
111-12009 Oral Health Annual Evidence Update - Introduction

back to contents

  Introduction & Editorial

 

Oral Health Evidence Update
by Professor Barbara Chadwick, Clinical Lead Oral Health Specialist Library


Once again I am pleased to introduce the results of our latest Annual Evidence Update and to present the best of the newly published evidence across the range of oral health topics.

 

The number of systematic reviews published in 2008 that meet our inclusion criteria is almost 50 percent higher than in 2007 (90 versus 64). Unfortunately, it has not brought with it an increase in certainty. Once again, many of the new systematic reviews we identified concluded that there wasn’t enough high quality evidence to make a clear clinical decision.

 

These uncertainties are being fed into NHS Evidence - UK Duets (a Database of Uncertainties about the Effects of Treatments); thereby helping to identify areas where more research is needed and providing the information from which priorities can be determined.

 

Looking at the various topics, periodontal disease and dental caries again provide the biggest crop of systematic reviews. In the case of periodontal disease, reviews developed for the 6th European Workshop on Periodontology added significantly to the overall total.

 

The impact of periodontal disease on general health continues to be an area of interest. In 2008 reviewers looked at cardiovascular disease,1-2 diabetes3 and the risk of preeclampsia4. The current update is also notable for having a number of reviews published on very similar topics.

 

Systematic reviews are defined as the gold standard of evidence. However, they are only as good as the methodology they use. The NHS Evidence - oral health collection has a policy of critically appraising all non-core content and once again we have taken the opportunity to look in depth at the methodological quality of oral health systematic reviews. We presented results of our last update at the 2008 Cochrane Collaboration meeting in Freiburg5 and hope to publish an extended analysis incorporating the results from this Update. Search methods continue to be a concern. Yet again the methods used in the majority of reviews were unlikely to identify all relevant studies; thereby potentially compromising review findings. 

 

Finally, I would like to express my thanks to those involved in developing this Annual Evidence Update. The Editorial Board volunteer their time to provide a clinical perspective on the critical appraisals. Fiona Morgan and Ruth Turley, Information Specialists for NHS Evidence - oral health are responsible for searching and critically appraising the literature and have done a considerable amount of work in pulling this update together. 

 


Barbara Chadwick is Professor of Paediatric Dentistry and Student Affairs Tutor at Cardiff University School of Dentistry.

 

___________________________________________________________

1 Humphrey LL, Fu R, Buckley DI, Freeman M, Helfand M. Periodontal disease and coronary heart disease incidence: A systematic review and meta-analysis. Journal of General Internal Medicine, 2008; 23 (12): 2079-86.

2 Paraskevas S, Huizinga JD, Loos BG, et al. A systematic review and meta-analyses on C-reactive protein in relation to periodontitis. Journal of Clinical Periodontology, 2008; 35: 277-290.

3 Darre L, Vergnes JN, Gourdy P, Sixou M. Efficacy of periodontal treatment on glycaemic control in diabetic patients: A meta-analysis of international studies. Diabetes and Metabolism, 2008; 34(5): 497-506.

4 Conde-Agudelo A, Villar J, Lindheimer M. Maternal infection and risk of preeclampsia: Systematic review and metaanalysis. American Journal of Obstretics and Gynecology, 2008; 198 (1): 7-22.

5 Morgan FM, Turley RL, Chadwick BL. Could do better? Search methods in recent oral health systematic reviews. Abstracts of the 16th Cochrane Colloquium. German Journal for Evidence and Quality in Health Care 2008; 102 (suppl.VI): 62
 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: 2009 Oral Health Annual Evidence Update - Methodology
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY]]>
document.body:
111-12009 Oral Health Annual Evidence Update - Methodology

back to contents

   Methodology

 

An electronic search for systematic reviews was conducted in the following databases: AMED, ASSIA, CINAHL, Medline, Medline in Process, Embase and PsycINFO using the search strategy outlined in our Quality Policy¹. In addition, we hand searched or scanned the electronic tables of contents of thirteen oral health journals:

• Angle Orthodontist
• British Dental Journal
• Clinical Oral Implants Research
• European Archives of Paediatric Dentistry
• International Journal of Oral & Maxillofacial Implants
• International Journal of Oral & Maxillofacial Surgery
• Journal of Clinical Periodontology
• Journal of Dental Research
• Journal of Dentistry
• Journal of Oral & Maxillofacial Surgery
• Journal of Prosthetic Dentistry
• Journal of the American Dental Association
• Oral Surgery, Oral Medicine, Oral Pathology, Oral Radiology, and Endodontics

For guidelines, we worked with the NHS Evidence - national library of guidelines to identify the latest guidelines meeting their selection criteria.

 

 

The electronic search identified 1238 papers of which 241 were reviewed in full text. Hand searching identified an additional 12 reviews for potential inclusion.

A total of 80 systematic reviews were identified as meeting the inclusion criteria (see Quality Policy).  These papers were critically appraised by specialist collection staff and reviewed by the Editorial Board. Nine papers were excluded at critical appraisal stage because of substantive methodological issues; giving a total of 71 papers. Finally, we searched this specialist collection for newly added core content. Nine Cochrane systematic reviews were identified, plus a further nine reviews from the DARE, HTA and NHS EED databases and finally, one review from NHS Evidence - ENT and audiology. These gave a final total of 90 systematic reviews for 2008.

 

 

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: 2010 Oral Health Annual Evidence Update - Commentary
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY]]>
document.body:
111-12010 Oral Health Annual Evidence Update - Commentary

Back to Contents

 

     John Stanfield Dental Hygienist and Editor Team in Practice

 

 

What's new for Dental Care Professionals?

 

In looking at the papers published in 2009 I originally identified 48 which on first glance would possibly be of interest to the Dental Care Professional (DCP).  My task was then to look at each of the papers in more depth and decide which of these provided information that we can use in practice.  Many of the papers did not identify anything new but instead pointed the way for areas of further study to refine our understanding.  In many instances more robust RCTs and standardisation of methodology were required.

 

Therefore I have attempted to select those studies which show some clear outcomes and that will be of immediate use to the DCP in the clinical environment. The lack of robust RCTs is probably an indicator of the costs and time involved in conducting such studies, however they do need to be done if we are to get realistic data that can stand up to scrutiny.

 

Bisphosphonate-related Osteonecrosis of the Jaw (BRONJ)

 

Although still a rare occurrence, the effects of BRONJ can be devastating particularly since in many cases it is due to the side effects of treating other equally devastating diseases.  Mauri et al looked at the meta analysis of the incidence of BRONJ and the adjunctive use of bisphosphonates in breast cancer treatments, finding that the incidence was rare (0.24%).  Madrid and Sanz evaluated the impact of placing dental implants in patients on bisphosphonate treatments.  Their systematic review concluded that there was a consensus that patients on IV bisphosphonates were contra-indicated whilst those on oral bisphosphonates for less than 4 years are not contra-indicated.  This has been backed up by the work of Khan et al (26) in their systematic review, which found that there was insufficient evidence to confirm a causal link between BRONJ and low dose oral bisphosphonates.  They did however emphasize the need for good oral hygiene and conservative surgical intervention.

 

Smoking Cessation

 

The meta analysis by Myung et al supports the use of web and computer-based smoking cessation programmes. Although their use may be limited to those who may be computer literate, this is becoming much more commonplace.  The literature shows there was a 1.5 times cessation rate compared to the control groups.  Moore et al (34) have shown in their systematic review that the use of Nicotine Replacement Therapy to be safe and effective.  Perhaps the combined use of complementary methods could increase the cessation rates even further?

 

Anti-coagulants and Dental Surgery

 

Nematullah et al have, through their meta analysis of 5 trials totalling 533 patients, determined that continuing patients on their regular dose of anti-coagulant therapy does not seem to confer a greater risk of bleeding.  This is compared to the risk caused by the discontinuation or modification of their therapy.

 

Fissure Sealant

 

Yengopal et al have been able to show via a meta analysis that both glass ionomers and resin-based fissure sealants have an equal beneficial effect in the prevention of dental caries.  The authors do however acknowledge that further high quality RCT are needed to look at a comparison between high viscosity GIC based fissure sealant and the resin-based fissure sealant material.

 

 

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: 2010 Oral Health Annual Evidence Update - Introduction
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY]]>
document.body:
111-12010 Oral Health Annual Evidence Update - Introduction

back to contents

  Introduction

 

Oral Health Evidence Update
by Professor Barbara Chadwick, Clinical Lead NHS Evidence - Oral Health


Once again I am pleased to introduce the results of our latest Annual Evidence Update which presents the best of the newly published evidence across the range of oral health topics.

 

We have seen an exponential increase in the number of systematic reviews published over the last few years. In 2009, we identified 150 reviews that met our inclusion criteria. This compares with 90 in 2008 and 64 in 2007.  However, it is not matched by an increase in certainty. Once again, many of the systematic reviews we identified concluded there wasn’t enough high quality evidence to make a clear clinical decision.

 

These uncertainties are being fed into NHS Evidence - UK Duets (Database of Uncertainties about the Effects of Treatments); thereby helping to identify areas where more research is needed and providing the information from which priorities can be determined.

 

We're very aware of the need to address the needs of all oral health professionals. So, as part of this Update we asked John Stanfield to look at the evidence and identify what he thought would be most useful to Dental Care Professionals. His commentary makes very interesting reading.

 

John's is intended to be the first in a series of commentaries looking at the latest evidence in a variety of areas. The first two will focus on periodontal disease and dental implants - both areas where a considerable amount of research is published. 

 

Systematic reviews are considered to be the gold standard of evidence. However, they are only as good as the methodology they use. The NHS Evidence - oral health collection has a policy of critically appraising all non-core content and once again we have taken the opportunity to look in depth at the methodological quality of the systematic reviews we include. We now have data for three years and hope to publish this in the next few months.

 

Once again, search methods are a particular concern. The methods used in many reviews were unlikely to identify all relevant studies; thereby potentially compromising review findings. 

 

Finally, I would like to express my thanks to those involved in developing this Annual Evidence Update, particularly to the clinicians who volunteered their time to provide a clinical perspective on the critical appraisals. Fiona Morgan and Ruth Turley, Information Specialists for NHS Evidence - oral health are responsible for searching and critically appraising the literature and have done a considerable amount of work in pulling this update together. 

 


Barbara Chadwick is Professor of Paediatric Dentistry and Student Affairs Tutor at Cardiff University School of Dentistry.

 

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: 2010 Oral Health Annual Evidence Update - Methodology
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY]]>
document.body:
111-12010 Oral Health Annual Evidence Update - Methodology

back to contents

   Methodology

 

An electronic search for systematic reviews was conducted in the following databases: AMED, ASSIA, CINAHL, Medline, Medline in Process, Embase and PsycINFO using the search strategy outlined in our Quality Policy¹. In addition, we hand searched or scanned the electronic tables of contents of thirteen oral health journals:

• Angle Orthodontist
• British Dental Journal
• Clinical Oral Implants Research
• European Archives of Paediatric Dentistry
• International Journal of Oral & Maxillofacial Implants
• International Journal of Oral & Maxillofacial Surgery
• Journal of Clinical Periodontology
• Journal of Dental Research
• Journal of Dentistry
• Journal of Oral & Maxillofacial Surgery
• Journal of Prosthetic Dentistry
• Journal of the American Dental Association
• Oral Surgery, Oral Medicine, Oral Pathology, Oral Radiology, and Endodontics

For guidelines, we worked with the NHS Evidence - national library of guidelines to identify the latest guidelines meeting their selection criteria.

 

 

 

The electronic search identified 1578 papers of which 201 were reviewed in full text. Hand searching identified an additional 6 reviews for potential inclusion.

A total of 91 journal-published systematic reviews were identified as meeting the inclusion criteria (see Quality Policy). They were critically appraised by specialist collection staff and reviewed by clinicians. Four papers were excluded at critical appraisal stage because of substantive methodological issues; giving a total of 87 papers. Nine papers of these papers had also been identified by NHS Evidence - ENT and audiology and were appraised by staff from that collection. Finally, we searched this specialist collection for newly added core content. 37 Cochrane systematic reviews were identified, plus a further 26 reviews from the DARE, HTA and NHS EED databases. These gave a final total of 150 systematic reviews for 2009.

 

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: 2010 Special Care Dentistry Annual Evidence Update - Introduction
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,SPECIAL CARE DENTISTRY]]>
document.body:
111-12010 Special Care Dentistry Annual Evidence Update - Introduction

 

back to contents

 

INTRODUCTION: Professor Barbara Chadwick, Clinical Lead NHS Evidence - oral health

Welcome to our latest annual evidence update on special care dentistry which provides an update of new information published over the past twelve months. This evidence update is timed to coincide with the Winter meetings of the British Society for Disability and Oral Health and of the British Society of Gerodontology and we thank them for their help and advice over the past year.

 

In our 2010 update, NHS Evidence - oral health has identified and critically appraised new systematic reviews published between November 2009 and to October 2010. We have also worked with the National Library of Guidelines to identify the latest guidelines meeting their inclusion criteria.  The Update has been divided into the following categories:

 

  • Commissioning
  • Bleeding disorders
  • Cancer patients
  • Cardiovascular conditions
  • Immunocompromised patients
  • Learning disabilities
  • Mental illness  [no new evidence identified]
  • Older people
  • Physical disabilities  [no new evidence identified]
  • Prison populations

In each category, new evidence is presented first, followed by the results of previous AEUs in this area. 

 

We have also used the opportunity afforded by the update to identify treatment-based clinical uncertainties in this area. These have been entered into DUETs (the Database of Uncertainties about the Effects of Treatment). DUETs captures uncertainties that cannot currently be answered by reliable up-to-date systematic reviews of existing research evidence. The captured uncertainties provide a means of prioritising new research in the UK.

 

Finally, I would like to express my thanks to those involved in developing this Annual Evidence Update. I would like to thank the Editorial Board members who volunteered their time to provide a clinical perspective on the critical appraisals. I would also like to thank Fiona Morgan and Ruth Turley, Information Specialists on the NHS Evidence - oral health team who have been responsible for searching and critically appraising the literature and who have done much of the work to pull the update together.

 

Barbara Chadwick is Professor of Paediatric Dentistry and Student Affairs Tutor at Cardiff University School of Dentistry.

]]>

document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,SPECIAL CARE DENTISTRY]]>
document.body:
111-12010 Special Care Dentistry Annual Evidence Update - Methodology

back to contents

Methodology

 

An update search to identify the most recent systematic reviews was conducted in the following databases: AMED, ASSIA, CINAHL, Medline, Medline in Process, Embase and PsycINFO using the search strategy outlined in our Quality Policy.

We hand searched or scanned the electronic tables of contents of thirteen oral health journals:
• British Dental Journal
• Clinical Oral Implants Research
• Gerodontology
• International Journal of Oral & Maxillofacial Implants
• International Journal of Oral & Maxillofacial Surgery
• Journal of Clinical Periodontology
• Journal of Dental Research
• Journal of Dentistry
• Journal of Disability and Oral Health
• Journal of Oral & Maxillofacial Surgery
• Journal of Prosthetic Dentistry
• Journal of the American Dental Association
• Oral Surgery, Oral Medicine, Oral Pathology, Oral Radiology, and Endodontics

For guidelines, NHS Evidence – oral health staff worked with the National Library of Guidelines to identify the latest guidelines meeting their selection criteria.

In addition we searched the following Specialist Collections for relevant content:

• cancer
• cardiovascular
• later Life
• learning disabilities
• mental health
• musculoskeletal
• neurological conditions
• oral health
• palliative and supportive care
• National Library of Public Health
• surgery, anaesthesia, perioperative and critical care


11 new systematic reviews were added to the Collection and one existing review was updated. Two new guidelines were identified.

 

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: A comprehensive and critical review of dental implant prognosis in periodontally compromised partially edentulous patients
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,PERIODONTOLOGY,RESTORATIVE DENTISTRY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: No statistically significant differences in both short-term and long-term implant survival exist between patients with a history of chronic periodontitis and periodontally healthy individuals. As the selected publications exhibited considerable discrepancies, more studies,uniformly designed, preferably longitudinal, prospective and controlled, would be important.

Methods: A systematic review of 15 longitudinal studies to clarify the outcome of implant treatment in periodontally-compromised, partially edentulous patients. Literature search to August 2006. 

Quality of review: A moderate quality systematic review. Just two databases were searched (PubMed and Cochrane oral health register), but this was supplemented by handsearching several journals and reference list checking. The search was restricted to published papers in the English language, which may have introduced publication and language bias. No formal method for assessing the quality of included papers is reported, although the quality of individual studies is presented in Tables 1 and 2 and in the discussion.

Long term is defined as = 5 years which for periodontal patients is somewhat short. Only four studies looked at a period of  = 10 years.  The definition of ‘periodontally compromised’ patients is not particularly objective as an inclusion criterion. Many of the included studies had disparate subgroups such as smokers and graft patients. These subgroups and their effect on the results and on periodontal status did not appear to be accounted for.

Results:  Patients with a history of chronic periodontitis may exhibit significantly greater long-term probing pocket depth,peri-implant marginal bone loss and incidence of peri-implantitis compared with periodontally healthy subjects. Even though the short-term implant prognosis for patients treated for aggressive periodontitis is acceptable, on a long-term basis the matter is open to question. Alterations in clinical parameters around implants and teeth in aggressive periodontitis patients may not follow the same pattern, in contrast to what has been reported for chronic periodontitis patients.

Citation: Karoussis IK, Kotsovilis S, Fourmousis I. A comprehensive and critical review of dental implant prognosis in periodontally compromised partially edentulous patients. Clinical Oral Implants Research 2007; 18(6): 669-79. 

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: A double-blind placebo-controlled comparison of tramadol/acetaminophen and tramadol in patients with postoperative dental pain.
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORAL SURGERY,IMPACTED THIRD MOLARS,POSTOPERATIVE PAIN RELIEF]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors conclusions: This study established the superiority of tramadol/acetaminophen (APAP) 75mg/650mg over tramadol 100mg in the treatment of acute pain following surgery.

Methods: A double-blind placebo controlled randomised controlled trial of 456 patients with moderate-to-severe pain within 5 hours post extraction of at least two impacted third molars (mean age 21.8 years, 64% female). Patients were allocated to receive placebo, tramadol 100mg, or tramadol/APAP 75mg/650mg to control the pain after surgery. Pain relief and adverse reactions were followed for 6 hours.

Quality of Study: This was a double blinded trial with concealment of allocation. The number of participants completing the study was high (441 patients – 96.7%).

Results:  Tramadol/APAP was superior to tramadol (P < 0.001) or placebo (P < 0.001) on all efficacy measures: total pain relief (PAR) over 6 h (7.4, 2.5, and 1.5, respectively, on a scale of 0-24); sum of pain intensity differences (PIDs) (3.1, 0.6, and 0.1, respectively, on a scale of -6 to 18); and sum of PAR and PID (10.5, 3.1, and 1.6, respectively, on a scale of -6 to 42). Median times to onset of perceptible and meaningful PAR were 37.6 and 126.5 min, respectively, for the tramadol/APAP group (P < 0.001) for each, compared with tramadol and placebo arms).

The most common adverse events with active treatment were nausea, dizziness, and vomiting; these events occurred more frequently in the tramadol group than in the tramadol/APAP group.

Citation: Fricke Jr. James, Hewitt David J, Jordan Donna M, A double-blind placebo-controlled comparison of tramadol/acetaminophen and tramadol in patients with postoperative dental pain. Pain. 2004; 109: 250 -257

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: A double-blind, single-dose comparison of the analgesic efficacy of tramadol/acetaminophen combination tablets, hydrocodone/acetaminophen combination tablets, and placebo after oral surgery.
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORAL SURGERY,IMPACTED THIRD MOLARS,POSTOPERATIVE PAIN RELIEF]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' Conclusions: T/APAP tablets (tramadol/acetaminophen) provided effective, rapid (< or = 34 minutes), dose-dependent analgesia for the treatment of postoperative dental pain. Two T/APAP tablets provided analgesia comparable to that provided by HC/APAP (hydrocodone bitartrate/acetaminophen) with better tolerability.

Method: A single-centre, double-blind, placebo- and active-controlled study in 185 adults with at least moderate pain 5 hours after extraction of 2 or more impacted third molars. Patients were allocated to receive 1 or 2 T/APAP tablets, 1 HC/APAP tablet, or placebo.

Quality of study: Although measures of precision (confidence intervals) were not reported, primary outcome data are reported in tables rather than in graphs.

Results: T/APAP 75/650 mg and HC/APAP were statistically superior to placebo on the primary efficacy measures of TOTPAR, SPID, and SPRID (p  1 tablet > placebo) was seen for TOTPAR, SPID, and SPRID (all, p). The median time to onset of pain relief was approximately 34.0 minutes with 2 T/APAP tablets and 25.4 minutes with HC/APAP. Although the median time to onset of pain relief was shorter with HC/APAP, two T/APAP tablets had comparable efficacy to HC/APAP. The median time to remedication with a supplemental analgesic agent was 169.0 minutes in the T/APAP 75/650 mg group and 204.0 minutes in the HC/APAP group. However, the duration of pain relief, was not significantly different between these 2 groups. The overall incidence of adverse events (AEs) was lower with T/APAP (0% treatment-related AEs) than with HC/APAP (4%) or placebo (10%). The incidence of nausea (18% T/APAP, 36% HC/APAP) and vomiting (12% T/APAP, 30% HC/APAP) was approximately 50% lower with 2 T/APAP tablets than with HC/APAP (P < 0.05).

Full Citation: Fricke JR Jr, Karim R, Jordan D, Rosenthal N. A double-blind, single-dose comparison of the analgesic efficacy of tramadol/ acetaminophen combination tablets, hydrocodone/acetaminophen combination tablets, and placebo after oral surgery. Clinical Therapeutics. 2002;24(6):953-68.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. Full text online access is available to NHS staff in England via ATHENS passwords. To apply for an ATHENS password and access this resource and many others please go to the ATHENS registration page .

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: A meta-analysis of alcohol consumption and the risk of 15 diseases
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ALCOHOL,RECENT ADDITIONS,RISK FACTORS,PANCREATITIS,CANCER,COLON & RECTUM,DISEASE PREVENTION,ALCOHOLIC LIVER DISEASE,ALCOHOLIC CIRRHOSIS,SMALL INTESTINE,CHRONIC PANCREATITIS,LIVER,OESOPHAGUS,CANCER,STOMACH,ULCERS,DUODENAL ULCERS,GASTRIC ULCERS,PANCREAS,GASTROENTEROLOGY & LIVER DISEASES,OUTCOMES,CANCER,BREAST CANCER,ORAL CANCER,OESOPHAGEAL CANCER,LIVER CANCER,THROAT CANCER,CIRCULATORY DISEASES,STROKE & TIA,CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASES,HYPERTENSION,ORAL HEALTH DISORDERS,LIVER DISORDERS,INJURIES,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORAL CANCER,DENTAL PUBLIC HEALTH,ORAL PATHOLOGY,ORAL DISORDERS,ORAL HEALTH,PUBLIC HEALTH,DETERMINANTS,SOCIAL DETERMINANTS,LIFESTYLE,INDIVIDUAL BEHAVIOUR,ALCOHOL CONSUMPTION,RESEARCH METHODS,METHODS,CANCER,CIRRHOSIS,ALCOHOLIC,ANALYSIS & RESEARCH]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

Authors' conclusions: Some of the findings from this meta-analysis are innovative and of specific relevance, including the absence of a threshold effect for any of the seven cancer sites considered from both model-based and point-based relative risk, and the apparently stronger association for oral and pharyngeal as compared to esophageal or laryngeal cancer across subsequent levels of alcohol drinking.

Methods: Systematic review of 99 case-control and 57 cohort studies investigating the association between alcohol consumption and the risk of 15 diseases (including cancer of the oral cavity). Literature search 1966-1998.

Quality of review: Several databases were searched and key journals hand-searched in attempting to find relevant literature. However, studies may have been missed as unpublished research was not sought and it is unclear whether non-English language papers were included. As the literature search was conducted in 1998, this review does not reflect recent findings. Although the inclusion criteria for eligible studies is reported, the authors then selected high quality papers from this group for inclusion in the meta-analysis. The score required for inclusion is not stated.  There are very limited data on the results of included studies or on the presence of heterogeneity. The references for included studies are not provided.

Results: Strong trends in risk were observed for cancers of the oral cavity, esophagus and larynx, hypertension, liver cirrhosis, chronic pancreatitis, and injuries and violence.  The results for cancer of the oral cavity varied with the amount of alcohol consumption. For 25g/day relative risk (RR) was 1.86 (95%CI 1.76-1.96), 0g/day RR 3.11 (2.85-3.39) and 100g/day RR 6.45 (5.76-7.24).

Citation: Corrao G, Bagnardi V, Zambon A, Vecchia CL. A meta-analysis of alcohol consumption and the risk of 15 diseases. Preventive Medicine. 2004; 38: 613-619

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: A meta-analysis of six-month studies of antiplaque and antigingivitis agents
document.publisher: Journal of the American Medical Association
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PREVENTION,OUTCOMES,ORAL HEALTH DISORDERS,ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,CAUSES & PREVENTION,DENTAL PUBLIC HEALTH,DENTAL CARIES,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PUBLIC HEALTH,RESEARCH METHODS,ANALYSIS,METHODS,ANALYSIS & RESEARCH,DENTAL HEALTH]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Author's conclusions: The studies in this systematic review provide strong evidence of the antiplaque, antigingivitis effects of multiple agents. These results support the use of these agents as part of a typical oral hygiene regimen.

Methods: A systematic review and meta-analysis of 50 randomised controlled trials to evaluate the efficacy of antigingivitis and antiplaque products in six month trials. Search dates not provided.

Quality of review: The review is hindered by a limited search strategy and poor reporting of the results. Medline was the only electronic database searched using basic search terms, although manufacturers were contacted for unpublished research and the reference lists of papers initially identified were checked. Searching additional databases using a wider range of terms, handsearching journals and contacting experts may have identified additional papers.

While no formal method is reported for appraising the validity of included studies, details were abstracted for several quality aspects including sample size, blinding and randomisation.

Results are not clearly presented, with most results described in the text. The forest plots in Tables 1 and 2 for anti-gingivitis effects do not report the exact value of pooled results and not all the comparisons are presented in the narrative.

Note: Of the 50 included studies, 13 were provided by manufacturers. The review was part supported by a grant from Pfizer Inc and the electronic version of the paper is sponsored by Oropharma Inc, manufacturer of an antibiotic used in the treatment of periodontal disease.

Results: Seventeen studies support the antiplaque, antigingivitis effects of dentifrices containing 0.30 percent triclosan, 2.0 percent Gantrez copolymer. There was no evidence of efficacy for triclosan products containing either soluble pyrophosphate or zinc citrate. Dentifrices with stannous fluoride had statistically significant, but marginally clinically significant, evidence of an antiplaque effect; however, there was both a statistically and clinically significant antigingivitis effect. The largest body of studies (21 studies) supported the efficacy of mouthrinses with essential oils. A smaller body of studies (seven) supported a strong antiplaque, antigingivitis effect of mouthrinses with 0.12 percent chlorhexidine. Results for mouthrinses with cetylpyridinium chloride varied and depended on the product’s formula.

Citation: Gunsolley JC. A meta-analysis of six-month studies of antiplaque and antigingivitis agents. Journal of the American Dental Association 2006; 137(12): 1649-1657

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: A meta-analysis of the efficacy of over-the-counter nicotine replacement
document.topics: <![CDATA[ SMOKING CESSATION,POPULATION BASED & PREVENTATIVE SERVICES,DENTAL PUBLIC HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORAL HEALTH,PUBLIC HEALTH,MANAGEMENT & INTERVENTIONS,HEALTHCARE & HEALTH SERVICES,MEDICINES,PHARMACIES,SERVICES,ANALYSIS,IMPACT ASSESSMENT,METHODS,ANALYSIS & RESEARCH]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Over the counter (OTC) nicotine replacement therapy (NRT) is pharmacologically efficacious and produces modest quit rates similar to those seen in real world prescription practice.

Methods: A meta-analysis of 4 randomised controlled trials of over-the-counter nicotine replacement therapy (OTC NRT) versus placebo, and 4 trials (2 randomised and 2 non-randomised trials) of OTC versus prescribed NRT. Literature search dates not reported.

Quality of study: It is unclear whether non-English language trials were sought. A formal method of assessing the validity of included studies is not reported, however, the methodological issues of the included studies are discussed in detail.

Results: One OTC NRT versus OTC placebo nicotine gum study was excluded due to small sample size and different setting. The four remaining studies were randomised trials of nicotine versus placebo patch with ORs of 2.1–3.2. These outcomes were homogenous and when combined resulted in an OR favouring NRT of 2.5 (95% confidence interval (CI) 1.8 to 3.6).

Among the two randomised and two non-randomised trials of OTC NRT versus prescription NRT, one small study had an OR of 0.3, two others had ORs of 1.0 and 1.4, and a fourth study had an OR of 3.6. These results were not homogenous; however, when combined via a random effects model the estimated OR was not less than 1.0—that is, OR 1.4 (95% CI 0.6 to 3.3).

The long term (that is, greater than six months) quit rates for OTC NRT was 1% and 6% in two studies and 8–11% in five other studies. These results were not homogenous; however, when combined the estimated OR was 7% (95% CI 4% to 11%).

Citation: Hughes JR, Shiffman S, Callas P, Zhang J. A meta-analysis of the efficacy of over-the-counter nicotine replacement. Tobacco Control 2003; 12: 21-27.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. Full text online access is available to NHS staff in England via ATHENS passwords. To apply for an ATHENS password and access this resource and many others please go to the ATHENS registration page .

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: A partially blinded randomised controlled trial of patient-maintained propofol sedation and operator controlled midazolam sedation in third molar extractions
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,DENTAL ANXIETY,ORAL SURGERY,IMPACTED THIRD MOLARS,SEDATION]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' Conclusions: Propofol sedation offered superior anxiolysis, quicker recovery, less amnesia and less depression of simple psycho-motar function.

Method: A partially blinded randomised controlled trial of 110 patients (mean age of 28 years old) referred to a sedation unit at the University of Glasgow Dental School for removal of third molars with intravenous conscious sedation. Patients were allocated to operator-controlled sedation with midazolam or patient maintained sedation with propofol.

Quality Assessment: This is a reasonably well conducted trial. Randomisation was performed by an independent statistician using a block randomisation system and all patients completed the study. The recovery staff were blinded to the sedation technique although patients and surgeons were not.

Results: State anxiety was reduced to a greater extent in the propofol group (mean difference 10 (SD 4)mm; p=0.010). Propofol patients recovered quicker (mean difference 7 (SD 1.4) min: p=0.001). Propofol patients had a smaller reduction in arterial oxygen saturation (mean difference 0.8 (SD 0.3)%; p=0.030), and a reduced increase in heart rate (mean difference 9 (SD 2)beats.min-1; p=0.001).

Citation: Leitch JA, Anderson K, Gambhir S et al. A partially blinded randomised controlled trial of patient-maintained propofol sedation and operator controlled midazolam sedation in third molar extractions. Anaesthesia 2004; 59(9):8 53-60.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. Full text online access is available to NHS staff in England via ATHENS passwords. To apply for an ATHENS password and access this resource and many others please go to the ATHENS registration page .

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.
