document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: A review of feeding interventions for infants with cleft palate
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,DENTO-FACIAL ANOMALIES]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors conclusions: There is a need for ongoing scientific evaluation of feeding interventions used with infants who have cleft palate. A number of factors, including the heterogeneity of samples studied, lack of replication of trials, and small sample sizes, affected the type and strength of evidence underpinning specific feeding interventions.

Methods: A systematic review of 55 papers including 2 RCTs and 3 inteventional studies without randomisation. Literature search date not reported.

Quality of review: Although several databases were searched and selected journals handsearched, it is possible that studies were missed and bias introduced as only published studies in the English language were included.  Of the 55 included studies, five were intervention studies.  The remainder were non-data-driven reports of expert opinion.

Results: Fifty-five articles published between 1955 and 2002 were reviewed. There are currently no completed systematic reviews relevant to this body of literature (level I evidence). Two well-designed randomized controlled trials (level II evidence) were found. These were considered to provide the strongest evidence for feeding intervention techniques. These articles described a combination of interventions, including early feeding and nutrition education, as well as assisted feeding methods for infants with isolated cleft conditions. Three examples of level III.3 evidence were also found. Fifty (91%) of 55 articles reviewed were non–data-driven reports of expert opinion.

Citation: Reid J. A review of feeding interventions for infants with cleft palate. Cleft Palate-Craniofacial Journal. 2004; 41(3): 268-278

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: A review of functional outcomes related to prosthetic treatment after maxillary and mandibular reconstruction in patients with head and neck cancer
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,ORAL CANCER,ENT AND AUDIOLOGY,NOSE & SINUS DISORDERS,LARYNX & PHARYNX DISORDERS,NEOPLASMS,MALIGNANT,NEOPLASMS,MALIGNANT,CONDITIONS,TREATMENT & MANAGEMENT,THERAPEUTIC INTERVENTIONS,NON-DRUG TREATMENTS,OTHER,SURGERY,HEAD & NECK CANCER]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors’ conclusions: The limitations of the reviewed literature lead to the view that, at present, it is not possible to draw firm comparative conclusions between the prosthetic treatment s considered in reconstruction of the maxilla and mandible.

Methods: A narrative systematic review of 49 studies (study types unclear) to consider functional outcomes across categores of prosthetic treatment after microvascular reconstruction of the maxilla and/or mandible. Database search dates 19900 to 2006.

Quality of review: The results of this review are limited by the low quality of the included information and the lack of comparable measurements.

The authors searched a good range of databases, albeit with somewhat limited search terms and supplemented that search by reference checking. However, restricting the search to published studies in the English language may have introduced bias. Appropriate procedures were used to minimise error and bias in the final stages of study selection and in the data extraction process, which included validity assessment of the included papers. Following assessment, studies were allocated a level of evidence. No study was allocated a high level and virtually all were rated as low level evidence.

Results: Twelve papers reported on function after maxillary reconstruction, with the majority of papers reporting on outcomes for 1 to 6 subjects. Thirty-nine papers reported on function after mandibular reconstruction. Speech outcomes were satisfactory across all groups. Swallowing reports indicated that many patients who received either type of prosthetic rehabilitation resumed a normal diet, whereas those without prosthetic rehabilitation were often restricted to liquid diets or feeding tubes. Patients without prosthetic rehabilitation reportedly had poor masticatory ability, whereas conventional prosthetic treatment allowed some recovery of mastication and implant-retained prosthetic treatment resulted in the most favorable masticatory outcomes. Quality-of-life outcomes were similar across all patients.

Citation: Tang JA, Rieger JM, Wolfaardt JF. A review of functional outcomes related to prosthetic treatment after maxillary and mandibular reconstruction in patients with head and neck cancer. International Journal of Prosthodontics, 2008; 21 (4): 337-354

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: A review of the effectiveness of oral health promotion activities among elderly people
document.topics: <![CDATA[ OUTCOMES,ORAL HEALTH DISORDERS,ADULTS,POPULATION BASED & PREVENTATIVE SERVICES,HEALTH PROTECTION,MONTHLY ADDITIONS,OLDER PEOPLE,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORAL HEALTH,PUBLIC HEALTH,MANAGEMENT & INTERVENTIONS,SERVICES,OLDER PEOPLE,SPECIAL CARE DENTISTRY,GROUPS,AGE GROUPS,POPULATIONS,2009 DECEMBER]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors’ conclusions: In the last 10 years, increasing attention has been paid to oral health promotion activities among the elderly population and high quality evidence has emerged. However, there is a need for even higher-quality research to provide more definitive guidelines on oral health promotion practices for elderly people

Methods: a narrative systematic review of seventeen studies (13 RCTs, 3 quasi-experimental, 1 pre-post study) to determine the effectiveness of oral health promotion studies conducted among elderly people. Database search dates: 1997-2007.

Quality of review: It is possible that relevant studies were missed. Whilst the authors searched several databases (Medline/PubMed, Web of Science, Central), the search terms used were limited and inclusion was limited to published studies in English. Reference list checking and searching grey literature sources may have identified additional papers.

The processes used to select, quality assess and data extract included studies are not described and the introduction of error and bias in these processes cannot be excluded. The authors used a 21 point checklist detailed in Kay and Locker: Effectiveness of Oral Health Promotion, HEA 1997

Results: The use of fluoride, antimicrobial agents and health-care provide educational interventions all appear to have a role in preventing coronal and/or root caries. The atraumatic dental restorative procedure is a feasible option in the management of caries among elderly people but its efficacy requires further investigation.

The majority of the effective papers related to oral health promotion activities aimed at improving plaque levels, gingival health and oral hygiene. The use of powered toothbrushes, antimicrobial agents and comprehensive oral health promotion regimes are likely to benefit periodontal health. However, whether oral health promotion can improve and sustain periodontal status requires investigation through further high quality studies. Definite periodontal outcome measures, such as pocket depth and clinical attachment levels, need to be included as outcome measures.

It does appear that allied health-care personal have a role in improving oral health behaviour including dental attendance and studies support the notion of multi-sector involvement within health promotion. However, there is a need for studies of longer duration to determine whether changes in oral health behaviour are merely transient or are actually sustained following these interventions.

Citation: McGrath C, Zhang W, Lo EC. A review of the effectiveness of oral health promotion activities among elderly people. Gerodontology 2009; 26(2):85-96.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. Full text online access is available to NHS staff in England via ATHENS passwords. To apply for an ATHENS password and access this resource and many others please go to the ATHENS registration page .

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: A review of the effects of stannous fluoride on gingivitis
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,PERIODONTOLOGY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors conclusions: The use of stannous fluoride dentifrices results in gingivitis and plaque reduction when compared with a conventional dentifrice. The precise magnitude of this effect was difficult to assess because of a high level of heterogeneity in study outcomes.

Methods: A systematic review of 36 studies (35 RCTs and 1 CCT) to evaluate the effect of different formulations of stannous fluoride on the parameters of gingivitis.

Quality of review: It is likely that the search strategy did not identify all relevant papers.  Only Medline and the Cochrane Clinical Trials Register were searched and reference lists of reviews checked.  Journals were not hand searched.  Non-English language papers were excluded and unpublished research was not sought which may have introduced language and publication biases. The quality of the included studies was independently assessed by two reviewers.  There was significant heterogeneity in the end results of the included studies and the authors indicate that the results should be viewed with some caution.

Results: For stannous flouride dentifrices, a statistically significant reduction in gingivitis was noted in comparison with control (weighted mean difference (WMD) of 0.15 (gingival index) and 0.21 (gingivitis severity index) (test for heterogeneity p<0.00001, I2=91.1% and p=0.03, I2=80.1%, respectively)). With regard to plaque reduction inconsistent results existed. On using the plaque index no differences were found, whereas meta-analysis of the Turesky index provided a WMD of 0.31 (p=0.01, test for heterogeneity p<0.0001, I2=91.7%). There was insufficient data for a meta-analysis for stannous flouride mouth rinse and dentifrice/mouthrinse formulations.  Eight studies provided information on dental staining using a variety of indices.  Regardless of the index used, there was a statistically significant increase in staining prevalence in comparison with NaF (sodium fluoride) formulations.

Citation: Paraskevas S, van der Weijden GA. A review of the effects of stannous fluoride on gingivitis. Journal of Clinical Periodontology 2006; 33: 1–13

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: A review of the literature on osteonecrosis of the jaw in patients with osteoporosis treated with oral bisphosphonates: prevalence, risk factors, and clinical characteristics
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORAL DISORDERS,ORAL SURGERY,DENTO-FACIAL ANOMALIES,OLDER PEOPLE,OSTEONECROSIS OF THE JAW,SPECIAL CARE DENTISTRY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: The relative prevalence of osteonecrosis of the jaw (ONJ) in patients treated for osteoporosis was low vs the number of prescriptions. Age >or=60 years, female sex, and previous invasive dental treatment were the most common characteristics of those who developed ONJ. However, it is not possible to draw further conclusions about the potential association between oral bisphosphonate use and ONJ in the identified studies because of incomplete reporting and the presence of confounding factors.

Methods: A narrative systematic review of 11 studies (8 case reports and 3 retrospective studies. The review aimed to elucidate the relationship between bisphosphonate use and the development of ONJ in patients receiving oral bisphosphonates for the treatment of osteoporosis.  Literature search 1966-2006.

Quality of review: A reasonable attempt was made to identify relevant literature by searching several databases, some relevant organisation websites and conference abstracts and by reference list checking. However, the search was restricted to published research in the English language, which may have introduced publication and language bias. The results of the review are limited by the low level of evidence (mostly case series or reports) and poor quality of included studies. It appears that randomised controlled trials were not eligible for inclusion on the assumption that they did not report prevalence of osteonecrosis of the jaw. However, the accuracy of this assumption could not have been verified by the authors without checking potentially relevant RCTs in full text.

The review was funded by pharmaceutical company Roche Laboratories.

Results: 11 publications reporting 26 cases of ONJ in osteoporosis patients were included in the review. The most commonly affected site was the mandible (16 patients), followed by the maxilla (6 patients). Among the 23 patients whose age was reported, 18 (78%) were aged >or=60 years. Among the 23 patients whose sex was reported, only 3 (13%) were men. Of 15 patients with a history of invasive dental treatment, 12 (80%) had undergone dental surgery or experienced dental trauma at the site of ONJ. Among the 10 patients for whom treatment duration was reported, no clear relationship between the duration of bisphosphonate treatment and the development of ONJ was observed.

Citation: Pazianas M, Miller P, Blumentals WA, Bernal M, Kothawala P. A review of the literature on osteonecrosis of the jaw in patients with osteoporosis treated with oral bisphosphonates: prevalence, risk factors, and clinical characteristics. Clinical Therepeutics 2007; 29(8):1548-58.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance.  You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: A systematic overview of radiation therapy effects in head and neck cancer
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORAL CANCER,ORAL RADIOLOGY,ENT AND AUDIOLOGY,NOSE & SINUS DISORDERS,LARYNX & PHARYNX DISORDERS,SALIVARY GLAND DISORDERS,NEOPLASMS,MALIGNANT,XEROSTOMIA,NEOPLASMS,MALIGNANT,NEOPLASMS,MALIGNANT,CONDITIONS,TREATMENT & MANAGEMENT,RADIOTHERAPY,CHEMOTHERAPY,HEAD & NECK CANCER]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Methods: A systematic review of 39 randomised controlled trials and 1 meta-analysis investigating radiation therapy for head and neck cancer. The review is compared to similar systematic review conducted in 1996 by the Swedish Council of Technology Assessment in Health Care.

Quality of review: Key papers may have been missed as only two databases were searched.  There was no hand-searching, reference list checking or search for unpublished studies. It is unclear whether the search included non-English language papers.  The review has limited inclusion criteria and, whilst the quality of each included study is reported,  the method of critical appraisal used is not provided.

Authors Conclusions and Results:

General, non-nasopharynx

Substantial evidence indicates that the tumour effect of radiotherapy can be increased by the concomitant administration of chemotherapeutic agents, particularly cisplatin and 5-fluorouracil.

There is moderate evidence of a survival benefit of radiation combined with concomitant chemotherapy compared to radiation alone. However, the results are equivocal.

There is substantial evidence in published studies for an increased frequency of severe acute side effects as a result of concomitant chemotherapy and radiotherapy.

There are very few studies that allow any estimates of the risk for serious late side effects. There is a weak indication of an increased risk for serious fibrosis.

The general quality of studies and the lack of information on serious side effects indicate a need for large, well-designed clinical studies with a reasonable follow-up.

Hypoxic cell sensitizers

Most reported trials reject the usefulness of nitroimidazole derivatives for sensitization of hypoxic tumour cells. There is some evidence that patients with tumours in the pharynx and larynx may benefit from sensitization by nimorazole.

Prophylactic treatment of side effects

There is weak evidence that local antibiotics have a clinically significant effect in preventing acute radiotherapy side effects.

There is insufficient evidence that radioprotective agents offer clinically significant protection of parotid glands (one study in two publications). There is insufficient evidence that radioprotective agents do not spare tumour tissue.

Since the previous report no randomized studies comparing the effectiveness of external beam radiotherapy and brachytherapy have been performed. Both methods are well established and have independently proved to be effective in the treatment of certain head and neck cancers. No conclusion can be drawn regarding their relative effectiveness.

Since the previous report no data to guide the use of intraoperative radiotherapy have been identified.

Citation: Zackrisson B, Mercke C, Strander H, Wennerberg J, Cavallin-Stahl E. A systematic overview of radiation therapy effects in head and neck cancer. Acta Oncologica 2003; 42(5-6): 443-61

Access: Available to the general public.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: A systematic review and meta-analyses on C-reactive protein in relation to periodontitis
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,PERIODONTOLOGY,ASSOCIATED CONDITIONS]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: This systematic review provides evidence that periodontitis elicits a mild acute-phase response with elevation of CRP levels compared with healthy controls. Periodontal treatment results in lowered CRP levels; however, the treatment studies available are scarce. Further research should investigate whether the changes in cellular and molecular markers in peripheral blood in periodontitis are indeed causally related to cardiovascular events and whether periodontal therapy and maintenance of periodontal health will reduce the risk for such events.

Methods: A systematic review and meta-analysis of 18 studies (10 studies included in the meta-analysis) to review the evidence for the contention that CRP is elevated in periodontitis and to determine whether periodontal therapy lowers CRP levels. Database search dates: 1965 to 1 June 2007.

Quality of review: The results of the review are limited by the quality of the included papers.

The authors searched two databases using an adequate search strategy, supplemented by reference list checking. However, the search was restricted to published studies in English which may have introduced bias. Searching additional sources without restrictions may have identified additional papers. Appropriate procedures were used to minimise error and bias in study selection, data extraction and quality assessment. The authors used checklists to determine study validity and examine risk of bias.

Note: the authors searched for cross-sectional studies which can identify associations but which cannot prove causal links. Prospective cohort studies are required to determine causality. Few of the included studies report controlling for socio-economic status: a significant confounder vs CRP levels – as the authors indicate.

Results: The majority of the studies showed that CRP levels are higher in patients than in controls. Often, studies showed that patients had CRP levels >2.1 mg/l. A meta-analysis of 10 cross-sectional studies showed that the weighted mean difference (WMD) of CRP between patients and controls was 1.56 mg/l (p<0.00001). Evidence from available treatment studies (n=6) showed lower levels of CRP after periodontal therapy. Eligible treatment studies in a meta-analysis demonstrated a WMD of reductions of CRP after therapy of 0.50 mg/L (95% CI 0.08–0.93) (p=0.02).

Citation: Paraskevas S, Huizinga JD, Loos BG, et al. A systematic review and meta-analyses on C-reactive protein in relation to periodontitis. Journal of Clinical Periodontology, 2008; 35: 277-290

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance.  You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: A systematic review and meta-analysis of the role of positron emission tomography in the follow up of head and neck squamous cell carcinoma following radiotherapy or chemoradiotherapy
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,ORAL CANCER,ENT AND AUDIOLOGY,NOSE & SINUS DISORDERS,LARYNX & PHARYNX DISORDERS,SALIVARY GLAND DISORDERS,NEOPLASMS,MALIGNANT,NEOPLASMS,MALIGNANT,NEOPLASMS,MALIGNANT,CONDITIONS,TREATMENT & MANAGEMENT,THERAPEUTIC INTERVENTIONS,NON-DRUG TREATMENTS,RADIOTHERAPY,HEAD & NECK CANCER]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Positron emission tomography (PET) is highly accurate in this role. However it is less sensitive early after treatment and has poor anatomical detail. PET may reduce the requirement for check endoscopies and planned neck dissections. A protocol for its use in post-treatment surveillance is proposed.

Methods: A systematic review and meta-analysis of 27 studies to examine the effectiveness of positron emission tomography (PET) in the detection of recurrent or persistent head and neck squamous cell carcinoma after radiotherapy or chemoradiotherapy. Literature search to October 2007.

Quality of review: It is unlikely that the search identified all existing studies. The authors searched a limited range of databases using limited terms and checked the reference lists of included papers. Restricting the search to published papers in English may have introduced publication and language biases.

The authors assessed the quality of included studies using QUADAS – the Quality Assessment of Diagnostic Accuracy tool. However, as they state the tool does not weight data for meta-analysis. There was considerable heterogeneity between the included studies and it is open to question whether the authors should have conducted a meta-analysis. They state that the degree of heterogeneity may limit the applicability of the results.

Results: The pooled sensitivity and specificity of PET for detecting residual or recurrent head and neck squamous cell carcinoma were 94% [95% confidence interval (CI), 87–97%] and 82% (95% CI, 76–86%) respectively. Positive and negative predictive values were 75% (95% CI, 68–82%), and 95% (95% CI, 92–97%) respectively. Sensitivity was greater for scans performed 10 weeks or more after treatment.

Citation: Isles MG, McConkey C, Mehanna HM. A systematic review and meta-analysis of the role of positron emission tomography in the follow up of head and neck squamous cell carcinoma following radiotherapy or chemoradiotherapy. Clinical Otolaryngology 2008; 33(3): 210-22.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: A systematic review and meta-analysis on the effect of implant length on the survival of rough-surface dental implants
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,RESTORATIVE DENTISTRY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors’ conclusions: Within the limitations of this systematic review, the placement of short rough-surface implants is not a less efficacious treatment modality compared to the placement of conventional rough-surface implants for the replacement of missing teeth in either totally or partially edentulous patients.

Methods: A systematic review to examine whether there is a significant difference in survival between short and conventional rough-surface dental implants placed in totally or partially edentulous patients. 37 papers reporting 22 patient cohorts were selected. Literature search to August 2007.

Quality: Seven journals were hand searched over several years and two bibliographic databases were searched for irrelevant studies, though only using narrow search terms. A good attempt was made to identify unpublished research, limiting the risk of publication bias. However, only English language papers were sought which may have introduced language bias. It is possible that more recent studies have been published in this area as the literature search was approximately two years old at the time of publication. Reliable methods were used to select and quality appraise included papers.

Results: Meta-analysis revealed no statistically significant difference in survival between short and conventional rough surface implants placed in totally or edentulous patients.

Citation: Kotsovilis S, Fourmousis I, Karoussis IK, Bamia C. A systematic review and meta-analysis on the effect of implant length on the survival of rough-surface dental implants. Journal of Periodontology 2009; 80(11):1700-18.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: A systematic review concerning early orthodontic treatment of unilateral posterior crossbite
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORTHODONTICS,DENTO-FACIAL ANOMALIES,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORAL DISORDERS,ORAL HEALTH]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors conclusions: There is no scientific evidence available to show which of the treatment modalities, grinding, Quad-helix (QH), expansion plates, or rapid maxillary expansion is the most effective. To obtain reliable scientific evidence, better-controlled RCTs with sufficient sample sizes are needed to determine which treatment is the most effective for early correction of unilateral posterior crossbite. Future studies should also include assessments of long-term stability as well as analysis of costs and side effects of the intervention.

Methods: A systematic review of 2 randomised controlled and 10 non-randomised clinical trials to assess the orthodontic treatment effects on unilateral posterior crossbite in the primary and early mixed dentition. Treatments included Quad-helix, rapid maxillary expansion, expansion plates and grinding. The main outcomes measured were success rate, expansion obtained molars/ cuspid and expansion remained molars/ cuspids (mm). Literature search from January 1966 to October 2002.

Quality of Study: Non-English lanugage papers were included, however, only Medline was searched for literature and unpublished research was not sought. Two independent reviewers assessed the quality of the studies.

Results: Most of the studies have serious problems of lack of power because of small sample size, bias and confounding variables, lack of method error analysis, blinding in measurements and deficient or lack of statistical methods. The success rate was reported to be 100% or close to 100% for treatment with Quad-helix and rapid maxillary expansion. For expansion plates, the success rate reported was between 51% and 100% and for grinding, between 27% and 90%. Spontaneous correction was found to occur between 16% and 50% in the untreated control groups.

Citation: Petren S, Bondemark L, Soderfeldt B. A systematic review concerning early orthodontic treatment of unilateral posterior crossbite. Angle Orthodontist. 2003; 73(5): 588-596.

Access: Available to the general public. 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: A systematic review of bisphosphonate osteonecrosis (BON) in cancer
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,DENTO-FACIAL ANOMALIES,ORAL CANCER,ORAL CARE FOR CANCER PATIENTS,SPECIAL CARE DENTISTRY,CANCER PATIENTS,OSTEONECROSIS OF THE JAW]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: High-quality studies are needed to accurately characterize the prevalence of bisphosphonate osteonecrosis (BON), and to determine effective treatment protocols.

Methods: A narrative systematic review 28 studies (mix of intervention and observational studies) examining the prevalence of BON in the cancer population, prevention and treatment protocols, and quality of life issues. Database search dates: October 2003 to December 2008.

Quality of review: Overall a reasonably well-conducted systematic review. The authors searched two electronic databases using a highly sensitive search strategy. However, it is possible that potentially relevant studies were missed as no other sources were searched and inclusion was restricted to published studies in the English language. Appropriate processes were used to minimise error and bias in selecting, data extracting and quality assessing included studies. A range of questions designed to identify potential bias in different study types were incorporated into the data extraction form. Only limited information is provided on the included studies. It is not clear if studies could be combined which gives concern to using an overall prevalence score.

Results: A total of 28 publications fulfilled inclusion criteria, but only 22 were used for prevalence analysis. No randomized controlled clinical trials, meta-analysis, or quality of life papers were found that contained information regarding either prevalence or treatment protocols for the management of BON. The overall weighted prevalence of BON included a sample of 39,124 patients with a mean weighted prevalence of 6.1%. The weighted prevalence was 13.3% for studies with documented follow-up with a sample size of 927 individuals. The weighted prevalence in studies with undocumented follow-up was 0.7% in a sample of 8,829 chart reviews. Epidemiological studies evaluated a total of 29,368 individual records, and the weighted BON prevalence was 1.2%.

Citation: Migliorati CAW, Woo SB, Hewson I, Barasch A, Elting LS, Spijkervet FK et al. A systematic review of bisphosphonate osteonecrosis (BON) in cancer. Supportive Care in Cancer 2010;18(8):1099-106.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

 

Note: additional details about the methodology are provided in: Brennan MT, Elting LS, Spijkervet FK. Systematic reviews of oral complications from cancer therapies, Oral Care Study Group, MASCC/ISOO: methodology and quality of the literature. Supportive Care in Cancer 2010 Aug;18(8):979-84.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: A systematic review of cardiovascular effects of epinephrine on hypertensive dental patients
document.publisher: Oral Surgery, Oral Medicine, Oral Pathology, Oral Radiology, and Endodontics
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORAL SURGERY,SPECIAL CARE DENTISTRY,CARDIOVASCULAR CONDITIONS]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Although the increased risk for adverse events among uncontrolled hypertensive patients was found to be low and the reported occurrence of adverse events in hypertensive patients associated with the use of epinephrine in local anesthetics was minimal, the quantity and quality of the pertinent literature is problematic.  

Methods: A systematic review of 6 studies on epinephrine-containing local anaesthetic solutions in hypertensive patients receiving dental treatment. Studies on epinephrine-impregnated gingival retraction cords were also sought, however, the literature identified did not meet the review inclusion criteria. Literature search to March 2001.

Quality of study: Key papers may have been missed and publication bias introduced as unpublished research was not sought. Also, it is unclear whether non-English language publications were sought. The authors do not state how the validity of included studies was assessed and there is no clear indication of the type of studies included.

Results: Use of epinephrine in uncontrolled hypertensive patients was associated with small, nonsignificant increases in systolic and diastolic blood pressure. No adverse outcomes were reported. Only one study examined effects of epinephrine on controlled hypertensive patients, in whom additional risks due to interactions with antihypertensive medication are possible. Available studies did not address effects of gingival retraction cord on hypertensive patients.

Citation: Bader JD, Bonito AJ, Shugars DA. A systematic review of cardiovascular effects of epinephrine on hypertensive dental patients. Oral Surgery, Oral Medicine, Oral Pathology, Oral Radiolology and Endodontics. 2002; 93: 647-653.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: A systematic review of cephalometric facial soft tissue changes with the Activator and Bionator appliances in Class II division 1 subjects
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORTHODONTICS]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Based on the available evidence, a significant amount of controversy regarding the soft tissue changes produced by the Activator and the Bionator exists. Soft tissue changes that were reported as being statistically significant were of questionable clinical significance. Long-term, double-blinded, prospective randomized clinical trials are needed to confirm the findings. Three-dimensional quantification is also required to overcome current limitations in our understanding of the soft tissue changes obtained with the use of removable functional appliances.

Methods: A systematic review of 11 studies (1 RCT, 10 CCTs) to evaluate, through lateral cephalograms, facial soft tissue changes after the use of the Activator and Bionator appliances in Class II division 1 malocclusion subjects. Literature search to January 2006. 

Quality of review:  Overall a reasonably well-conducted systematic review. A number of databases were searched without language restrictions and reference lists of selected studies checked, although using a wider range of search terms may have identified further papers. Unpublished research does not appear to have been sought, which may have introduced publication bias. Selection of included studies was conducted in duplicate by two independent reviewers, and studies were quality assessed using a pre-defined criteria.

Results: Five articles using the Activator and six using the Bionator fulfilled the selection criteria and quantified facial soft tissue changes. An individual analysis of these articles was undertaken and some methodological flaws were identified.

Citation: Flores-Mir C and Major PW. A systematic review of cephalometric facial soft tissue changes with the Activator and Bionator appliances in Class II division 1 subjects. European Journal of Orthodontics 2006; 28(6):586-593.

Access: The full text of this paper is available to the general public.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: A systematic review of clinical efficacy of adjunctive antibiotics in the treatment of smokers with periodontitis
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,PERIODONTOLOGY,TREATMENT & MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: The evidence for an additional benefit of adjunctive antibiotic therapy in smokers with chronic periodontitis is insufficient and inconclusive. Additional well-designed RCTs are required to assess the effect of antibiotics in conjunction with periodontal treatments in smokers.

Methods: A narrative systematic review of five randomised controlled trials to determine whether adjunctive antimicrobials improves the clinical outcome of non-surgical therapy (scaling and root planing) or surgical therapy in the treatment of periodontitis in smokers. Database search dates: inception to 2009 inclusive.

Quality of review: The authors searched a range of databases (PubMed, Embase, Scopus, Central) supplemented by reference list checking, handsearching key journals and contacting experts and companies involved in this area of research. However, inclusion was restricted to peer-reviewed publications in English. Appropriate methods were used to minimise the introduction of error and bias in study selection, quality assessment and data extraction. The authors assessed risk of bias and concluded that it was high in all studies raising questions about the validity of the results.

Results: Little evidence was found that supported the use of antibiotic therapy in conjunction with surgical periodontal therapy in smokers. With respect to non-surgical therapy, consistent improvements in clinical attachment level (CAL) gain and probing depth (PD) reduction was reported after the use of a 250-mg azithromycin tablet in one study. Adjunctive doxycycline gel and minocycline microspheres statistically improved CAL gain (in one RCT) and PD reduction (in one RCT), respectively. However, the risk of bias in all studies was estimated as high.

Citation: Angaji M, Gelskey S, Nogueira-Filho G, Brothwell D, Angaji M, Gelskey S, et al. A systematic review of clinical efficacy of adjunctive antibiotics in the treatment of smokers with periodontitis. Journal of Periodontology 2010 Nov;81(11):1518-28.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: A systematic review of clinical trials of aligning archwires
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORTHODONTICS]]>
document.body:
This This record is a critical summaty produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: There is insufficient data in the identified studies to make clear recommendations regarding the most effective archwire for alignment. Recommendations on future study design have been made.

Methods: A narrative systematic review of four randomised controlled trials to identify the efficacy of archwires used in the alignment stage of orthodontic treatment. Literature search to July 2008.

Quality of review: A reasonable attempt was made to identify relevant studies by searching several bibliographic databases and checking the reference lists of articles. There were no language restrictions, and it appears that unpublished/ongoing research was sought via clinical trials registers (mRCT). Further papers may have been identified by using broader search terms in the databases, handsearching journals and contacting experts.

Two independent reviewers selected, data extracted and quality assessed papers, minimising the potential for bias and inaccuracy. The quality scoring system does not seem to consider whether certain quality criteria are more or less important than others. Furthermore the minimum score required for a paper to be deemed sufficient quality is subjectively chosen.

Results: Seven studies were identified as meeting selection criteria. Four studies were deemed after quality assessment, to have a low risk of bias and data was extracted from these. No two studies shared a common methodology or common reporting outcome. Meta-analysis was therefore not possible.

Citation: Riley M, Bearn DR. A systematic review of clinical trials of aligning archwires. Journal of Orthodontics 2009; 36: 42-51

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: A systematic review of complication risks for HIV positive patients undergoing invasive dental procedures
document.publisher: Journal of the American Dental Association
document.topics: <![CDATA[ SPECIAL CARE DENTISTRY,IMMUNOCOMPROMISED PATIENTS,ENDODONTICS,ORAL SURGERY,PERIODONTOLOGY,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORAL HEALTH]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Limited published scientific evidence is available to guide clinicians in regard to possible increased risks of invasive oral procedures associated with the HIV status of the patient.

Methods: A systematic review of 5 cohort studies (3 retrospective and 2 prospective). Literature search April 2000.

Quality of study: Publication and language bias may have been introduced as it is unclear whether unpublished and non-English literature was sought.

Results: The authors found no studies involving orthognathic surgery, periodontal therapy, dental implants, prophylaxis, or scaling and root planing, and only one study reporting few immediate endodontic therapeutic complications. Thus, the evidence is insufficient with respect to any additional risk associated with these procedures among people with HIV/AIDS. Because of the few studies, low overall complication rates and variability in results from different analytic approaches, the authors consider the evidence to be too poor to rule in or out a meaningful relationship between HIV status and complications from tooth extractions. 

Citation: Patton LL, Shugars DA, Bonito AJJ. A Systematic Review of Complication Risks for HIV-Positive Patients Undergoing Invasive Dental Procedures.  Journal of the American Dental Association. 2002; 133:195-203. 

Access: Full-text online access is freely available to this paper.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: A systematic review of definitions of periodontitis and methods that have been used to identify this disease
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,PERIODONTOLOGY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: This review has confirmed previous work which has suggested that epidemiological studies of periodontal diseases are complicated by the diversity of methodologies and definitions used. The studies that were reviewed utilized a minimum diagnostic threshold defining periodontitis, at a given site in terms of clinical attachment loss (CAL) of 2 mm and pocket probing depth (PPD) of 3 mm.

Methods: A systematic review of 15 studies to critically analyse the definitions of periodontitis and the methods that have been used to identify and measure the disease. Database search dates to August 2006.

Quality of review: A well-conducted systematic review. The authors searched a range of published and unpublished sources without language restrictions, supplemented by reference list checking. Appropriate methods were used to minimise the introduction of error and bias in study selection and data extraction. Included studies were assessed for risk of bias.

Results: The survey revealed heterogeneity between the studies in the measurement tools used, particularly the types of probes and the sites and areas of the mouth that were assessed. There was also heterogeneity in the use of CAL and  PPD as criteria for periodontitis. In the 15 studies, the threshold for a diagnosis of periodontitis when CAL was the criterion ranged from 2 to > or =6 mm and when PPD was used, from 3 to > or =6 mm.

Citation: Savage A, Eaton KA, Moles DR, Needleman I. A systematic review of definitions of periodontitis and methods that have been used to identify this disease. Journal of Clinical Periodontology 2009 Jun;36(6):458-67.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: A systematic review of dental disease in patients undergoing cancer therapy
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORAL CANCER,ORAL CARE FOR CANCER PATIENTS,SPECIAL CARE DENTISTRY,CANCER PATIENTS]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions:

  1. Patients who were post-radiotherapy had the highest DMFT compared to those who were post-chemotherapy and healthy controls. 
  2. Patients who were post-antineoplastic therapy had higher PI and GI than healthy patients.
  3. The use of fluoride products and chlorhexidine rinses are beneficial in patients who are post-radiotherapy. 
  4. Conventional glass ionomer restorations performed more poorly than resin-modified glass ionomer, composite resin, and amalgam restorations in patients who were post-radiotherapy.  
  5. There continues to be lack of clinical studies on the extent and severity of dental disease that is associated with infectious complications during cancer therapy.

Methods: A narrative systematic review of 64 papers (46 observational and 18 intervention studies) to determine the impact of cancer therapies on teeth and periodontum. Database search dates: 1990-2008 inclusive.

Quality of review: Overall a reasonably well-conducted systematic review. The authors searched two electronic databases using a highly sensitive search strategy. However, it is possible that potentially relevant studies were missed as no other sources were searched and inclusion was restricted to published studies in the English language. Appropriate processes used to minimise error and bias in selecting, data extracting and quality assessing included studies. A range of questions designed to identify potential bias in different study types were incorporated into the data extraction form. Only limited information is provided on the included studies. It is not clear if studies could be combined which gives concern to using an overall prevalence score.

Results: The weighted overall prevalence of dental caries was 28.1%. The overall DMFT for patients who were post-antineoplastic therapy was 9.19 (SD, 7.98; n=457). The overall plaque index for patients who were post-antineoplastic therapy was 1.38 (SD, 0.25; n=189). The gingival index for patients who were post-chemotherapy was 1.02 (SD, 0.15; n=162). The weighted prevalence of dental infections/abscess during chemotherapy was reported in three studies and was 5.8%.

Citation: Hong CH, Napenas JJ, Hodgson BD, Stokman MA, Mathers-Stauffer V, Elting LS, et al. A systematic review of dental disease in patients undergoing cancer therapy. Supportive Care in Cancer 2010 Aug;18(8):1007-21

Access: Full-text online access is freely available

Note: additional details about the methodology are provided in:
Brennan MT, Elting LS, Spijkervet FK. Systematic reviews of oral complications from cancer therapies, Oral Care Study Group, MASCC/ISOO: methodology and quality of the literature. Supportive Care in Cancer 2010 Aug;18(8):979-84

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: A systematic review of dental recall intervals and incidence of dental caries
document.publisher: Journal of the American Dental Association
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,DENTAL CARIES,DENTAL PUBLIC HEALTH,CAUSES & PREVENTION]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

NOTE: NICE Guidance is available on this topic. [view]

 

Authors' conclusions: The evidence for using a one-recall-interval-fits-all protocol to reduce caries incidence is weak. Studies that address the impact of recall interval on caries incidence are methodologically weak. The evidence is not strong enough to support using any specific one-recall-interval-fits-all protocol for all patients.

Methods: A narrative systematic review of seven papers/six studies (1 RCT, 2 CCTs, 2 retrospective and 1 cross sectional) to determine whether there is evidence to support a "one-recall-interval-fits-all" protocol, such as a six-month recall interval on caries incidence.

Quality of review: It is possible that potentially relevant studies were missed as the authors only searched PubMed supplemented by reference list checking. The search terms used were restrictive and inclusion was further limited to published English language studies. No information is provided on the processes used to select and data extract included studies and the introduction of error and bias cannot be ruled out. The authors used a 1998 checklist that scored quality out of 27. Overall quality was low with significant issues identified in all studies.

Results: The randomized controlled trial showed no significant differences in oral health between patients recalled every 12 months and those recalled every 24 months. The investigators of one nonrandomized controlled trial reported that a two- to three-month recall interval significantly reduced the incidence and recurrence of caries. The investigators of an additional longitudinal non-randomized controlled study that compared three-, six- and 12-month recall intervals reported caries increments of 4.4, 4.0 and 4.9, respectively. The results of two retrospective studies showed that a specific recall interval did not alter caries incidence significantly. The results from a cross-sectional study suggested that a six-month recall interval was associated with more restored teeth but less active caries.

Citation: Patel S, Bay RC, Glick M. A systematic review of dental recall intervals and incidence of dental caries. Journal of the American Dental Association 2010 May;141(5):527-39.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal for the first 12 months after publication. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: A systematic review of graft materials and biological agents for periodontal intraosseous defects
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,PERIODONTOLOGY,TREATMENT & MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Overall the use grafting biomaterials or biological agents was more effective than open flap debridement (OFD) in increasing attachment levels in intraosseous defects, but the significant unexplained heterogeneity among studies means that the results shouls be interpreted with caution.  

Methods: A systematic review of 26 randomised controlled trials of at least 6 month duration (24 included in the meta-analysis). Main outcome measures were clinical attachment levels (CAL), change in probing pocket depth (PPD) and extent of intraosseous defect fill. Literature search performed up to and including June 2001.

Quality of study: Key papers may have been missed as only English language papers were included. Limited attempts were made to explore potential causes of heterogeneity.

Results: The difference in CAL change between test and control groups varied from -1.45 mm to 1.40 mm with respect to different biomaterials/biological agents.

Meta-analysis showed that CAL change significantly improved after treatment for coralline calcium carbonate (weighted mean difference 0.90 mm; 95% CI: 0.53-1.27), bioactive glass (weighted mean difference 1.04 mm; 95% CI: 0.31-1.76), hydroxyapatite (weighted mean difference 1.40 mm, 95% CI 0.64-2.16), and enamel matrix proteins (weighted mean difference 1.33 mm, 95% CI 0.78-1.88). However, heterogeneity in results between studies was highly statistically significant for most of biomaterials/biologicals and could not be fully explained.

Citation: Trombelli L, Heitz-Mayfield L, Needleman I, Moles D, Scabbia A. A systematic review of graft materials and biological agents for periodontal intraosseous defects. Journal of Clinical Periodontology. 2002; 29 (Suppl. 3): 117-135.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: A systematic review of guided tissue regeneration for periodontal furcation defects
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,PERIODONTOLOGY,TREATMENT & MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Overall, guided tissue regeneration (GTR) was consistently more effective than open flap debridement (OFD) in reducing open horizontal furcation depths, horizontal and vertical attachment levels and pocket depths for mandibular or maxillary class II furcation defects. However, these improvements were modest, variable and there was only a limited number of studies available to appraise the effects, thus limiting general conclusions about the clinical benefit of GTR. Future studies should aim to identify factors associated with achieving consistent and more pronounced benefits over open flap debridement.

Methods: A systematic review of 16 randomised controlled trials in patients with chronic adult periodontitis (CAP) or periodontitis with furcation involvement. Literature search to April 2001.

Quality of study: Generally this is a well conducted review, which used bibliographic databases, handsearching and contacting experts to identify published and unpublished literature. However only English language papers were included. Quality of included studies was assessed by two independent reviewers.

Results: For the primary outcome, reduction in horizontal furcation depth assessed during re-entry, the weighted mean difference between GTR and control was 1.51 mm (95% CI [0.39–2.62], chi-square for heterogeneity 67.6 (df = 3), P < 0.001) in mandibular class II furcations, 1.05 mm (95% CI [0.46–1.64, chi-square for heterogeneity 34.9 (df = 3), P < 0.001) in maxillary class II furcations, and 0.87 mm (95% CI [-0.08–1.82], chi-square for heterogeneity 0.1 (df = 4), P = 0.991) in studies that had combined mandibular and maxillary class II furcations. For the secondary outcomes, GTR treatment led to significantly better results than open flap debridement. No meta-analysis could be performed for frequency of furcation closure because of sparse data.

Citation: Jepsen S, Eberhard J, Herrera D, Needleman I. A systematic review of guided tissue regeneration for periodontal furcation defects. Journal of Clinical Periodontology 2002; 29 (Suppl 3): 103-116.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: A systematic review of guided tissue regeneration for periodontal infrabony defects
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,PERIODONTOLOGY,TREATMENT & MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Overall, guided tissue regeneration (GTR) was more effective than open flap debridement (OFD) in improving attachment levels. However, there was marked variability between studies and general conclusions about the clinical benefit of GTR are limited by this heterogeneity. Future studies should aim to identify factors associated with achieving consistent benefits over open flap debridement. Open flap surgery should remain the control comparison in these studies. 

Methods: A systematic review of 11 randomised controlled trials in adult patients with chronic periodontitis to evaluate the efficacy of guided tissue regeneration vs open flap debridement for infrabony defects. Literature search to October 2000.

Quality of study: This is a well-conducted review, which used bibliographic databases, hand-searching and contacting experts to locate the published and unpublished literature with no language restrictions. Quality of included papers were assessed by two independent reviewers.

Results: For attachment level change, the weighted mean difference between GTR alone and open flap debridementwas 1.11 mm (95% CI: 0.63–1.59), chi-square for heterogeneity 31.4 (9 df ), P < 0.001) and for GTR + bone substitutes was 1.25 mm (95% CI: 0.89–1.61, chi-square for heterogeneity 0.01 (1 df), P = 0.91). The number of sites needed to treat (NNT) for GTR to achieve one extra site gaining 2 mm or more attachment over open flap debridement was 8 (95% CI: 4–33). Heterogeneity between studies was highly statistically significant for all principal comparisons and could not be explained satisfactorily by sensitivity analyses.

Citation: Needleman I, Tucker R, Giedrys-Leeper E, Worthington H. A systematic review of guided tissue regeneration for periodontal infrabony defects. Journal of Periodontal Research. 2002; 37(5): 380-388.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: A systematic review of marginal soft tissue at implants subjected to immediate loading or immediate restoration.
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,PERIODONTOLOGY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Within the limits of the evaluated data it can be cautiously concluded that once immediately loaded or restored implants integrate successfully, they appear to show a soft-tissue reaction with regard to periodontal as well as morphologic aspects comparable with those of conventionally loaded implants. However, follow-up periods are generally short, number of patients and/or implants per study are few, and most studies present only limited data on peri-implant soft-tissue evaluation. More accurate long-term studies with a stronger study design  reporting more detailed on treatment and follow-up protocols are required to allow for proper comparisons and conclusions.

Methods: A systematic review of 17 studies (2 RCTs, 4 CCTs and 11 prospective case series) to evaluate marginal soft-tissue aspects at implants subjected to immediate loading or immediate restoration. Literature search 1966-2004.

Quality of study: It is likely that the search strategy did not identify all relevant papers as only one database (Medline) was searched.  Although this was supplemented by a review of reference lists and journal hand searching, the decision to exclude non-English language papers and unpublished data may have introduced language and publication biases. No formal quality appraisal of the included papers was included, although there is some discussion of quality issues.  The authors indicate that the short follow-up periods, small study numbers and limited evaluative data make it difficult to arrive at clear conclusions.

Results:  The total number of patients treated within the 17 studies was 432 including a total 706 implants studied. Overall, the articles reported on many different procedures and follow-up times, time points and evaluated soft-tissue parameters varied considerably between the different articles.

Citation: Glauser R, Zembic A, Hämmerle CHF. A systematic review of marginal soft tissue at implants subjected to immediate loading or immediate restoration. Clinical Oral Implants Research 2006. 17 (s2): 82–92.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: A systematic review of measures of effectiveness in screening for oral cancer and precancer.
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,ORAL CANCER,PREVENTION,SCREENING]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: There is insufficient available data to make an unequivocal determination as to the effectiveness of the oral cancer screening programmes at the present time. However, a recent further report on the Indian study published after completion of the review, provides some evidence that screening for oral cancer may be effective at least in developing countries with a high incidence of the disease.  

Methods: A systematic review of 28 studies to establish the effectiveness of screening for oral cancer and precancer.

Quality of study: A wide-ranging database search was conducted.  However the comprehensiveness of the data identified may have been limited by a decision not to search for unpublished materials and to exclude non-English language papers. The authors provided only limited information on the quality of the included studies or on the levels of evidence included.

Results: The studies included showed substantial heterogeneity in objectives and study design, location and setting, numbers and characteristics of participants, screening personnel, methods of recruitment and types of data collected. Only one study, from the Indian sub-continent, reported a randomised controlled trial; interim results showed 14.9% of intervention subjects died after 3 years compared with 56.3% of non-intervention controls. The review overall produced no evidence in favour of or against the potential benefits associated with an oral cancer screening programme.

Citation: Downer MC, Moles DR, Palmer S, Speight PM. A systematic review of measures of effectiveness in screening for oral cancer and precancer. Oral Oncology 2006; 42(6): 551-560

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: A systematic review of oral fungal infections in patients receiving cancer therapy
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORAL CANCER,ORAL CARE FOR CANCER PATIENTS,SPECIAL CARE DENTISTRY,CANCER PATIENTS]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: There is an increased risk of clinically significant oral fungal infection during cancer therapy. Systemic antifungals are effective in the prevention of clinical oral fungal infection in patients receiving cancer therapy. Currently available topical antifungal agents are less efficacious, suggesting a need for better topical agents

Methods: A narrative systematic review of 64 papers (46 observational and 18 intervention studies) to determine the impact of cancer therapies on teeth and periodontum. Database search dates: 1990-2008 inclusive.

Quality of review: Overall a reasonably well-conducted systematic review. The authors searched two electronic databases using a highly sensitive search strategy. However, it is possible that potentially relevant studies were missed as no other sources were searched and inclusion was restricted to published studies in the English language. Appropriate processes were used to minimise error and bias in selecting, data extracting and quality assessing included studies. A range of questions designed to identify potential bias in different study types were incorporated into the data extraction form. Only limited information is provided on the included studies. It is not clear if studies could be combined which gives concern to using an overall prevalence score.

Results: For all cancer treatments, the weighted prevalence of clinical oral fungal infection was found to be 7.5% pre-treatment, 39.1% during treatment, and 32.6% after the end of cancer therapy. Head and neck radiotherapy and chemotherapy were each independently associated with a significantly increased risk for oral fungal infection. For all cancer treatments, the prevalence of oral colonization with fungal organisms was 48.2% before treatment, 72.2% during treatment, and 70.1% after treatment. The prophylactic use of fluconazole during cancer therapy resulted in a prevalence of clinical fungal infection of 1.9%. No information specific to oral fungal infections was found on quality of life or cost of care.

Citation: Lalla RV, Latortue MC, Hong CH, Ariyawardana A, mato-Palumbo S, Fischer DJ, et al. A systematic review of oral fungal infections in patients receiving cancer therapy. Supportive Care in Cancer 2010;18(8):985-92.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

 

Note: additional details about the methodology are provided in:

Brennan MT, Elting LS, Spijkervet FK. Systematic reviews of oral complications from cancer therapies, Oral Care Study Group, MASCC/ISOO: methodology and quality of the literature. Supportive Care in Cancer 2010 Aug;18(8):979-84

 

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: A systematic review of oral health assessment by nurses and carers for residents with dementia in residential care facilities
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,SPECIAL CARE DENTISTRY,OLDER PEOPLE]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: To date, the most comprehensive, validated and reliable assessment screening tool for use by nurses and carers with cognitively impaired institutionalized residents is the Brief Oral Health Status Examination. Other less comprehensive oral assessment tools that are useful for nurses and carers of institutionalized dementia populations include the Index of Activities of Daily Oral Hygiene and the Mucosal Plaque Score. These review findings presented evidence to support the use of oral assessment screening tools by nurses and carers for cognitively impaired residents living in residential aged care facilities. Few validated and reliable tools have been published for use by carers in the cognitively impaired residential care population, and continued evolution of oral assessment screening tools needs to embrace the complete spectrum of residents' levels of cognitive impairment.

NOTE: For full details and a critical appraisal of this review go to:  Pearson A, Chalmers J. Oral Oral hygiene care for adults with dementia in residential aged care facilities. JBI Reports 2004; 2(3): 65-113

A Best Practice information sheet for healthcare professionals has been produced based on the full systematic review and is freely available.

Citation:  Chalmers J, Pearson A. A systematic review of oral health assessment by nurses and caers for residents with dementia in residential care facilities. Special Care in Dentistry 2005; 25(5): 227-232.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: A systematic review of orofacial pain in patients receiving cancer therapy
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORAL CANCER,ORO-FACIAL PAIN,ORAL CARE FOR CANCER PATIENTS,SPECIAL CARE DENTISTRY,CANCER PATIENTS]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: This systematic review identified the presence of pain before cancer therapy, likely attributable to the cancer; an increase in pain during therapy and the common persistence of pain following cancer treatment. Continuing research should use validated tools to prospectively assess orofacial pain, its causes and pathophysiology, and its effect on quality of life and economic impact. Clinical trials of pain management in this setting are also warranted.

Methods: A narrative systematic review of 39 papers (33 observational studies and 6 clinical trials) to evaluate the literature related to orofacial pain in head and neck cancer patients (excluding mucositis-related pain). Database search dates 1990-2008 inclusive.

Quality of review: Overall a reasonably well-conducted systematic review. The authors searched two electronic databases using a highly sensitive search strategy. However, it is possible that potentially relevant studies were missed as no other sources were searched and inclusion was restricted to published studies in the English language. Appropriate processes used to minimise error and bias in selecting, data extracting and quality assessing included studies. A range of questions designed to identify potential bias in different study types were incorporated into the data extraction form. Very limited information is provided on the included studies. There seemed to be significant heterogeneity between studies and it unclear how valid an overall prevalence score can be.

Results: 34 of the 39 studies reported pain in patients with head and neck cancer. Pain is common in this patient population and is reported by approximately half of patients prior to cancer therapy, 81% during therapy, 70% at the end of therapy, and by 36% at 6 months after treatment. Pain is experienced beyond the 6-month period by approximately one third of patients and is typically more severe than pre-treatment cancer-induced pain.

Citation: Epstein JB, Hong C, Logan RM, Barasch A, Gordon SM, Oberlee-Edwards L, et al. A systematic review of orofacial pain in patients receiving cancer therapy. Supportive Care in Cancer 2010;18(8):1023-31

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

 

 

Note:

Additional details about the methodology are provided in: Brennan MT, Elting LS, Spijkervet FK. Systematic reviews of oral complications from cancer therapies, Oral Care Study Group, MASCC/ISOO: methodology and quality of the literature. Supportive Care in Cancer 2010 Aug;18(8):979-84

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: A systematic review of powered vs manual toothbrushes in periodontal cause-related therapy
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,PERIODONTOLOGY,PREVENTION]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: The use of power-driven toothbrushes (PDT), especially counter-rotational and oscillating rotating brushes, can be beneficial in reducing the levels of gingival bleeding or inflammation. There is a need for methodological homogeneity in future studies in this field to enable quantitative analysis of their results.

Methods: A systematic review of 21 randomised controlled trials in patients aged 15 or more years presenting with gingivitis/periodontitis. Main outcome measures were reduction of the gingivitis - ie, reduction of gingival bleeding or inflammation. Literature search to June 2001.

Quality of study: Key papers may have been missed as non-English publications were not included, it is unclear whether a thorough search for unpublished research was performed.

Results: The heterogeneity of the data prevented a quantitative analysis. A higher efficacy in the reduction of gingival bleeding or inflammation in the power-driven toothbrushs (PDT) patients was detected in 10 studies. This effect appears to be related to the capacity to reduce plaque, and is more evident in counter-rotational and oscillating-rotating brushes.

No solid evidence was found for a higher efficacy of sonic brushes. In short-term studies with prophylaxis after initial examination, independently of the type of PDT tested, no significant differences were found.

Citation: Sicilia A, Arregui I, Gallego M, Cabezas B, Cuesta S. A systematic review of powered vs. manual toothbrushes in periodontal cause-related therapy. Journal of Clinical Periodontology. 2002; 29 (S3): 39-54.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: A systematic review of professional mechanical plaque removal for prevention of periodontal diseases
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: There appears to be little value in providing professional mechanical plaque removal (PMPR) without oral hygiene instruction (OHI). In fact, repeated OHI might have a similar effect as PMPR. Some forms of PMPR might achieve greater patient satisfaction. There is little difference in beneficial or adverse effects of different methods of PMPR.

Methods: A systematic review of 32 studies (24 RCTs and 8 CCTs). Search dates 1950 to October 2004.

Quality of review: A reasonable attempt was made to identify relevant evidence by searching several databases using a detailed search strategy of indexed terms and keywords. However, only published papers in the English language were included so key papers may have been missed and bias introduced. Selection, data extraction and quality assessment of the included papers were all conducted independently by two reviewers. The studies differed in their characteristics and the authors appropriately did not combine their results in a meta-analysis.

Results: Evidence exists that PMPR in adults, particularly in combination with OHI, may be more effective than no treatment judged by surrogate measures. The evidence for a benefit of PMPR+OHI over OHI alone is less clear. The optimum frequency of PMPR has not been investigated although more frequent PMPR is associated with improved markers of health. The strength of evidence for these results ranges from weak to moderate due to risk of bias, inconsistent results, lack of appropriate statistics and small sample size.

Citation: Needleman I, Suvan J, Moles DR, Pimlott J. A systematic review of professional mechanical plaque removal for prevention of periodontal diseases. Journal of Clinical Periodontology 2005; 32 (Supplement 6): 229-282

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. 

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.
