document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: A systematic review of public water fluoridation
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ENVIRONMENTAL,ENVIRONMENT,OUTCOMES,ORAL HEALTH DISORDERS,ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,CAUSES & PREVENTION,DENTAL PUBLIC HEALTH,DENTAL CARIES,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,DETERMINANTS,PUBLIC HEALTH,METHODS,RESEARCH METHODS,ANALYSIS & RESEARCH,DENTAL HEALTH]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: The review identified that the quality of research into the efficacy and safety of water fluoridation is low, however the results of studies included in the review show dental caries to be lower in fluoridated areas and a strong association between water fluoride concentration and the proportion of the population with dental fluorosis. No clear evidence of other negative effects of water fluoridation was found. The review concludes that the evidence of a reduction in caries should be considered together with the increased prevalence of dental fluorosis.

Methods: A systematic review of 214 studies including 45 controlled before-after studies, 102 cross sectional studies, 47 ecological studies, 13 cohort (retrospective or prospective) studies, and seven case-control studies.

Quality of study: This is a well-conducted review which used bibliographic databases, hand-searching and contacting of experts to locate published and unpublished literature in any language. Quality assessment and data extraction of included studies was performed by two independent reviewers.

Results: Water fluoridation was associated with an increased proportion of children without caries and a reduction in the number of teeth affected by caries. The range (median) of mean differences in the proportion of children without caries was -5.0% to 64% (14.6%). The range of mean change in decayed, missing and filled primary/permanent teeth was 0.5 to 4.5 (2.25) teeth.

The review estimates that a median of six people would need to receive fluoridated water for one extra person to be free from caries (interquartile range of the distribution of number needed to treat was 4 to 9 people)

The pooled estimated of the prevalence of fluorosis at a water fluoride concentration of 1.0ppm was 48% (95% CI 40% to 57%) and for fluorosis of aesthetic concern 12.5% (7.0% to 21.5%). There was however, considerable heterogeneity between results of individual studies.

From these results it is estimated that six people (95%CI 4 to 21) would have to be exposed to water fluoride concentrations of 1.0 ppm for one additional person to develop fluorosis of any degree, compared with a theoretical low fluoride concentration of 0.4ppm.Of these, about one quarter will have fluorosis.

There was no clear evidence of other adverse effects (e.g. cancer, bone fracture, dementia, Downs syndrome) resulting from water fluoridation.

Citation: McDonagh M, Whiting P, Wilson P et al. Systematic review of water fluoridation. British Medical Journal. 2000: 321; 855-859.

Full report - McDonagh M, Whiting P, Bradley M. Fluoridation of Drinking Water: a Systematic Review of its Efficacy and Safety Centre for Reviews and Dissemination. University of York 2000. (Report 18).

Access: Available to the general public

 

ADDITIONAL INFORMATION 

In a statement released on 23 October 2003 the Centre for Reviews and Dissemination said:

"In 1999, the Department of Health Commissioned CRD to conduct a systematic review (Fluoridation of Drinking Water: a Systematic Review of its Efficacy and Safety) into the efficacy and safety of the fluoridation of drinking water. The review specifically looked at the effects on dental caries/decay, social inequalities and any harmful effects. The review was published on the CRD Fluoridation website and in the BMJ in October 2000.

"We are concerned about the continuing misinterpretations of the evidence and think it is important that decision makers are aware of what the review really found. As such, we urge interested parties to read the review conclusions in full at http://www.york.ac.uk/inst/crd/pdf/summary.pdf.

"We were unable to discover any reliable good-quality evidence in the fluoridation literature world-wide.

"What evidence we found suggested that water fluoridation was likely to have a beneficial effect, but that the range could be anywhere from a substantial benefit to a slight disbenefit to children's teeth.

"This beneficial effect comes at the expense of an increase in the prevalence of fluorosis (mottled teeth). The quality of this evidence was poor.

"An association with water fluoride and other adverse effects such as cancer, bone fracture and Down's syndrome was not found. However, we felt that not enough was known because the quality of the evidence was poor.

"The evidence about reducing inequalities in dental health was of poor quality, contradictory and unreliable." 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: A systematic review of selected caries prevention and management methods
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,DENTAL CARIES,DENTAL PUBLIC HEALTH,CAUSES & PREVENTION,TREATMENT & MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: The strength of the evidence for preventing carious lesions in caries active individuals was judged to be fair for fluoride varnishes and insufficient for all other methods.

Methods: A systematic review of 22 intervention studies evaluating preventive interventions among caries-active or high caries risk subjects. There were four main groups of interventions; those based on fluorides, chlorhexidine, combinations involving chlorhexidine and fluoride or sealants, and other agents. Study types unknown.  

Quality of study: The review was limited by a lack of available high quality studies or trials involving adult subjects and primary teeth. The variety in experimental protocols among many set studies made comparisons difficult and unreliable.

It is possible the review may have missed relevant studies during the literature search. Unpublished research was not sought, and there was no reference list follow-up. The criteria for judging the quality of the evidence was vague.

Results: Among the 22 studies addressing the prevention of carious lesions in caries-active or high risk individuals, the strength of the evidence was judged to be fair for fluoride varnishes, and insufficient for all other methods. Among the seven studies addressing the management of non-cavitated carious lesions, the strength of the evidence for efficacy was judged to be insufficient for all methods.

The results do not indicate that the preventive and management methods reviewed are not efficacious; rather, they demonstrate that not enough is known to determine the efficacy of the methods.

Citation: Bader JD, Shugars DA, Bonito AJ. A systematic review of selected caries prevention and management methods. Community Dentistry and Oral Epidemiology 2001; 29: 399-411.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: A systematic review of single-tooth restorations supported by implants
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORAL SURGERY,RESTORATIVE DENTISTRY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Single-tooth implants show an acceptable short-term survival of 4 years, but crown complications are common.

Methods: A systematic review to examine the failures of single tooth restoration (STR) supporting implants, and complications with the STR. 10 studies met the authors' inclusion criteria, although one was later excluded because of a lack of statistical homogeneity for the outcomes after 2 years follow-up. The remaining 9 studies represented 459 single-tooth implants. The search was conducted in April 1998 and searched for papers from 1990 onwards.

Quality of study: It is likely that key papers have been missed in this review. Only Medline was searched for studies, and there was no reference list follow-up, or handsearching. Unpublished research was not sought which may have introduced publication bias. There are little data available on the results of the included research, and on the study designs.

Results: A three-step inclusion/exclusion procedure was applied to identify papers that represented: good scientific practice (GSP), reported results of all patients, implants and crowns for more than 2 years, and had sufficient data to generate life-table analyses. The outcomes were 'implant failure' and crown completion'.

9 studies survived. These data showed an overall mean GSP of 0.37 with a predicted 4 year implant survival of 97% ± 1% (n=459 single tooth implants), and an uncomplicated crown maintenance of 83% (n=240 single tooth restorations).

Citation: Creugers NH, Kreulen CM, Snoeck PA et al. A systematic review of single-tooth restorations supported by implants. Journal of Dentistry. 2000 28 209-217.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: A systematic review of stress and psychological factors as possible risk factors for periodontal disease
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,PERIODONTOLOGY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Within the limitations of this systematic review, the majority of studies showed a positive relationship between stress/psychological factors and periodontal disease. However, in the future, well-designed and more representative studies should be considered to confirm these factors as a risk for periodontal disease.

Methods: A narrative systematic review of 14 studies (7 case control, 6 cross sectional and one prospective clinical trial) to explore whether there is enough evidence to consider stress and psychological factors as risk factors for periodontal disease. Literature search from 1 January 1990 to 1 April 2006.

Quality of review: The review addressed a clearly focused question. The authors limited bias by selecting, data extracting and quality appraising included studies independently in duplicate. However it is possible that the search strategy missed key papers. Only two databases were searched (Medline and the Cochrane Oral Health Group trials register) using basic search terms supplemented by checking reference lists for extra papers. The search was restricted to published studies in English which may have introduced language and publication bias. Searching additional databases, handsearching journals and grey literature sources may have identified further papers. The number of citations generated by the search is not reported.

Results:  57.1% found a positive outcome between psychosocial factors/stress and periodontal disease, 28.5% observed a positive outcome for some characteristics and a negative outcome for others, and 14.2% found a negative outcome.

Citation: Peruzzo DC, Benatti BB, Ambrosano GMB, Nogueira-Filho GR, Sallum EA, Casati MZ, Nociti Jr FH. A systematic review of stress and psychological factors as possible risk factors for periodontal disease. Journal of Periodontology 2007; 78(8): 1491-1504. 

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance.  You can find your local library via the My Library home page. 

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: A systematic review of the 5-year survival and complication rates of implant-supported single crowns
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORAL SURGERY,PERIODONTOLOGY,RESTORATIVE DENTISTRY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: After an observation period of 5 years, high survival rates for implants and implant-supported single crowns (SCs) can be expected. However, biological and particularly technical complications are frequent.

Methods: A systematic review and meta-analysis of 26 cohort studies to assess the 5-year survival of implant-supported single crowns (SCs) and to describe the incidence of biological and technical complications. Literature search 1966 - July 2006.

Quality of review: Only one database was searched (Medline) which was supplemented with hand searching a wide range of key journals and checking reference lists of related reviews. Key papers may still have been missed however and bias introduced as only English and German language papers were included and unpublished research was not sought. Sound methods were used in selecting included papers independently in duplicate, which reduces potential error and bias. No formal method for assessing the validity of included studies was reported, however the inclusion criteria addressed some quality aspects. Although the authors tested for heterogeneity, they do not report whether or not it was present, and it is unclear whether a random effects model was used in all analyses or only for the ones stated. Information on the design of studies included is also limited, other than that they were prospective or retrospective.

Results: Survival of implants supporting SCs was 96.8% [95% confidence interval (CI): 95.9-97.6%] after 5 years. The survival rate of SCs supported by implants was 94.5% (95% CI: 92.5-95.9%) after 5 years of function. The survival rate of metal-ceramic crowns, 95.4% (95% CI: 93.6-96.7%), was significantly (P=0.005) higher than the survival rate, 91.2% (95% CI: 86.8-94.2%), of all-ceramic crowns. Peri-implantitis and soft tissue complications occurred adjacent to 9.7% of the SCs and 6.3% of the implants had bone loss exceeding 2 mm over the 5-year observation period. The cumulative incidence of implant fractures after 5 years was 0.14%. After 5 years, the cumulative incidence of screw or abutment loosening was 12.7% and 0.35% for screw or abutment fracture. For supra-structure-related complications, the cumulative incidence of ceramic or veneer fractures was 4.5%.

Citation: Jung RE, Pjetursson BE, Glauser R, Zembic A, Zwahlen M, Lang NP. A systematic review of the 5-year survival and complication rates of implant-supported single crowns. Clinical Oral Implants Research 2008; 19(2):119-30

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page. 

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

 

____________________________________________________________

See also:

ADA Critical Summary: Moderately favorable survival rate for implant-supported single crowns. Shapiro L.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: A systematic review of the consequences of premature birth on palatal morphology, dental occlusion, tooth-crown dimensions, and tooth maturity and eruption
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,DENTO-FACIAL ANOMALIES]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors conclusions: Scientific evidence was found for altered palatal morphology in the short term among the premature children, and oral intubation was a contributing factor to the alterations. If corrected age was considered for the premature children, no delay in dental development and eruption was found compared with normally born children. Thus, the early birth of premature children must be taken in account when planning for orthodontic treatment.

Because of the contradictory results and lack of longitudinal studies, the scientific evidence was too weak to answer the questions whether premature birth causes permanent alteration of palatal morphology, alteration of dental occlusion, and altered tooth-crown dimensions. To answer these questions and obtain reliable scientific evidence whether premature children are at risk for malocclusions from possible alterations of palatal morphology such as asymmetry and high arched palates, further well-designed controlled studies as well as longitudinal studies are needed.

Methods: Systeamtic review of 12 cross-sectional and 1 longitudinal studies to explore whether prematurity results in alteration of palatal morphology, dental occlusion, tooth-crown dimensions and tooth maturation. Literature search to database covering the period from January 1966 to November 2002.

Quality of review: Key papers may have been missed and publication bias introduced as the only database searched was Medline and only research published in English was included.  Screening of papers for relevance, data extraction and critical appraisal was conducted by two reviewers independently.

Results: Of the 5 studies concerning palatal morphlogy and crosesbite, 4 found a positive correlation between altered palatal moprphology and oral intubation, whereas one did not.

All 5 studies concerning tooth maturation/development demonstrated a delay in toothmaturation/development and eruption among the premature children. When corrected age was considered however, no delay was found.

Three cross-sectional studies concerned tooth-crown dimensions and had contrdictory results. 

Citation: Paulsson L, Bondemark L, Soderfeldt B. A systematic review of the consequences of premature birth on palatal morphology, dental occlusion, tooth-crown dimensions, and tooth maturity and eruption. Angle Orthodontist 2004; 74(2): 269-279

Access: Available to the general public.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: A systematic review of the effect of anti-infective therapy in the treatment of perio-implantitis
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORAL SURGERY,PERIODONTOLOGY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors conclusions: There are to date no data available to support specific treatment protocols. It is suggested that  randomised human controlled clinical trials for the treatment of peri-implantitis be initiated. 

Methods: A systematic review of 6 human experimental and observational studies and of 15 animal experimental studies. Literature search to January 2002.

Quality of study: Generally this is a well-conducted review, which used bibliographic databases, handsearching and contacting experts to locate published and unpublished literature in any language. Quality of included studies was assessed by two independent reviewers.

Results: A multitude of treatment regimens, including anti-infective therapy, were reported in the included studies. The antibiotic regimens varied between studies. No standardised medication protocol was used. Type of antibiotic, dosage, duration and time for initiation of antibiotic treatment were different for all studies but details were not always reported.

A non-medicated control group was reported in one animal experiment only. The outcomes following anti-infective treatment of peri-implantitis are highly variable and the evidence for a consistent and clinically relevant advantage of using antibiotics can be questioned in this context.

Citation: Klinge B, Gustafsson A, Berglundh T. A systematic review of the effect of anti-infective therapy in the treatment of peri-implantitis. Journal of Clinical Periodontology. 2002. 29 (Suppl 3): 213-225.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: A systematic review of the effect of surgical debridement vs non-surgical debridement for the treatment of chronic periodontitis
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,PERIODONTOLOGY,TREATMENT & MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Both scaling and root planing alone and scaling and root planing combined with flap procedure are effective methods for the treatment of chronic periodontitis in terms of attachment level gain and reduction in gingival inflammation. In the treatment of deep pockets open flap debridement results in greater probing pocket depth reduction (PPD) and clinical attachment gain.

Methods: A systematic review of 6 split-mouth randomised controlled trials in adult patients (n=235) with chronic periodontitis to evaluate the effectiveness of open flap debridement (OFD) vs scaling and root planing (SRP) for the treatment of chronic periodontal disease. Literature search 1965 - April 2001.    

Quality of study: Key papers may have been missed and bias introduced as only Engish language papers were included, and it is unclear whether unpublished research was sought. The evidence is limited by the small number of studies and participants, as acknowledged by the authors.

Results: There was considerable variation in study design and reporting, and the quality assessment revealed deficiencies regarding key components of study quality.

Meta-analysis evaluation of the studies indicated that 12 months following treatment, surgical therapy resulted in 0.6 mm more PPD reduction (WMD 0.58 mm; 95% CI 0.38, 0.79) and 0.2 mm more CAL gain (WMD 0.19 mm; 95% CI 0.04, 0.35) than non-surgical therapy in deep pockets (>6 mm). In 4–6 mm pockets scaling and root planing resulted in 0.4 mm more attachment gain (WMD -0.37 mm; 95% CI -0.49, -0.26) and 0.4 mm less probing depth reduction (WMD 0.35 mm; 95% CI 0.23, 0.47) than surgical therapy. In shallow pockets (1–3 mm) non-surgical therapy resulted in 0.5 mm less attachment loss (WMD -0.51 mm; 95% CI -0.74, -0.29) than surgical therapy.

Citation: Heitz-Mayfield LJ, Trombelli L, Heitz F, Needleman I, Moles D. A systematic review of the effect of surgical debridement vs non-surgical debridement for the treatment of chronic periodontitis. Journal of Clinical Periodontology. 2002; 29(Suppl 3): 92-102.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: A systematic review of the effectiveness of anticalculus dentifrices
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,DENTAL CARIES,DENTAL PUBLIC HEALTH,CAUSES & PREVENTION]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors conclusions: Anticalculus dentifrices containing pyrophosphates, zinc compounds and/or co-polymers were effective in significantly reducing calculus scores.

Methods: Systematic review of 31 randomised controlled trials comparing one or more active agents with a placebo dentrifice. The main outcome measured was Calculus using the Voipe-Manhold Index (VMI). 

Quality of review: This is a well-conducted systematic review.  A thorough search was conducted to identify relevant published and unpublished research.  Selection and quality of included studies was jointly assessed by two reviewers according to pre-defined criteria. The authors statistically tested for publication bias and heterogeneity.  Results suggested the presence of publication bias and significant heterogeneity was detected between the included studies.

Results: Random effect model for 3-month studies showed an effect size of -0.6 for all comparisons. The effect sizes varied from -0.3 for dentifrices with zinc chloride 0.5% to -1.1 for pyrophosphate 1.3% and copolymer 1.5% dentifrices. Meta-analysis of all the studies with 6-month follow-up gave an effect size of -1.1 (-1.5 to -0.8) and for 12-month follow-up the effect size was -13.6 (-21.4 to -5.8).

Citation: Netuveli GS, Sheiham A. A systematic review of the effectiveness of anticalculus dentifrices. Oral Health and Preventive Dentistry. 2004; 2: 49-58

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: A systematic review of the effectiveness of exercise, manual therapy, electrotherapy, relaxation training, and biofeedback in the management of temporomandibular disorder
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,DENTO-FACIAL ANOMALIES]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

Authors' conclusions: These recommendations should be viewed cautiously. Consensus on defining temporomandibular joint disorder, inclusion and exclusion criteria, and use of reliable and valid outcome measures would yield more rigorous research.

Methods: A systematic review of 30 studies examining the effectiveness of various physical therapy interventions for temporomandibular disorder.

Quality of review: A reasonable attempt was made to locate all the relevant literature with searches in several databases (Medline, CINAHL and Cochrane Clinical Trial Register), supplemented by a review of reference lists.  However, unpublished research was not sought and the search was restricted to English language papers.  Consequently, as the authors indicate, the review may have been subject to publication and language bias. An extensive quality appraisal process was undertaken to review the validity of the included studies.  The majority of this was undertaken by a single reviewer, and the authors highlight the possibility of selection and evaluation bias.   Overall the quality of the 30 included studies was low (5 average and 25 weak) and the authors rightly advise that the results should be viewed with caution.

Results: The following recommendations arose from the 30 studies: (1) active exercises and manual mobilizations may be effective; (2) postural training may be used in combination with other interventions, as independent effects of postural training are unknown; (3) mid-laser therapy may be more effective than other electrotherapy modalities; (4) programs involving relaxation techniques and biofeedback, electromyography training, and proprioceptive re-education may be more effective than placebo treatment or occlusal splints; and (5) combinations of active exercises, manual therapy, postural correction, and relaxation techniques may be effective.

Citation: Medlicott MS, Harris SR. A systematic review of the effectiveness of exercise, manual therapy, electrotherapy, relaxation training, and biofeedback in the management of temporomandibular disorder. Physical Therapy 2006;86:955–973.

 Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: A systematic review of the effectiveness of physical therapy interventions for temporomandibular disorders.
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,DENTO-FACIAL ANOMALIES]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors conclusions: Most of the studies included in this review were of very poor methodological quality; therefore, the findings should be interpreted with caution.

Methods: A systematic review of twelve randomised controlled trials to assess the evidence for the effectiveness of physical therapy interventions in the management of temporomandibular disorders. 

Quality of review: An excellent attempt was made to find all relevant research.  A wide range of databases was examined for papers in all languages, reference lists were searched and experts contacted.  The authors also searched for unpublished data. Eligible papers were critically appraised by two reviewers independently and study information is clearly reported.  Quality of the included studies was low in most cases and the authors indicate that review findings should be viewed with caution. 

Results:  12 studies met all selection criteria for nclusion in the review.  Four studies addressed the use of therapeutic exercise interventions, two studies examined the use of acupuncture, and six studies examined electrophysical modalities. Two studies provided evidence in support of postural exercises to reduce pain and to improve function and oral opening. One study provided evidence for the use of manual therapy in combination with active exercises to reduce pain and to improve oral opening. One study provided evidence in support of acupuncture to reduce pain when compared with no treatment; however, in another study no significant differences in pain outcomes were found between acupuncture and sham acupuncture. Significant improvements in oral opening were found with muscular awareness relaxation therapy, biofeedback training, and low-level laser therapy treatment.

Citation: McNeely ML, Armijo Olivo S, Magee DJ. A Systematic Review of the Effectiveness of Physical Therapy Interventions for Temporomandibular Disorders. Physical Therapy 2006; 86(5): 710-725.

Access: Full-text online access of this article is available.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: A systematic review of the effects of bone-borne surgical assisted rapid maxillary expansion
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORTHODONTICS]]>
document.body:
This is a provisional record for information. The review has been identified as potentially meeting our quality criteria. It will be critically appraised and a quality statement provided as soon as possible.
_____________________________________________________

 

Introduction: A systematic literature review was conducted to find out if bone-borne maxillary expansion with corticotomies is an effective and secure orthodontic/orthopaedic treatment modality, eliminating orthodontic and periodontal side effects of tooth-borne maxillary expansion with corticotomies.

Material and Methods: Randomized controlled trials (RCT), controlled clinical trials (CCT) and case series with a sample size >or=5 were electronically searched in PubMED, MEDLINE, EMBASE Excerpta Medica, CINAHL, Biological Abstracts and CENTRAL till June 2008. Data were extracted by 2 observers.

Results: Ten studies fulfilled the inclusion criteria, of which 9 were prospective and 1 was a retrospective case series.

Conclusion: No RCT's or CCT's were published on bone-borne surgically assisted rapid maxillary expansion (SARME). For expected advantages compared to tooth-borne SARME, only weak evidence was found for less buccal tipping of the teeth used as anchor teeth in tooth-borne expansion. The heterogeneity of the retrieved publications and the wide variety of outcome variables posed serious restrictions on the review of the literature in a quantitative systematic manner. There is a need for well designed clinical trials research on the effects of tooth-borne and bone-borne SARME 

Citation: Verstraaten J, Kuijpers-Jagtman AM, Mommaerts MY, Berge SJ, Nada RM, Schols JG et al. A systematic review of the effects of bone-borne surgical assisted rapid maxillary expansion. Journal of Cranio-Maxillo-Facial Surgery 2010; 38(3):166-174

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: A systematic review of the incidence of biological and technical complications in implant dentistry reported in prospective longitudinal studies of at least 5 years
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORAL SURGERY,PERIODONTOLOGY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Data on the incidence of biological and technical complications may be underestimated and should be interpreted with caution. 

Methods: A systematic review and meta-analyses of 51 studies. The majority were longitudinal cohort studies, and in a few cases controlled clinical trials and randomised controlled trials. Literature search date was 2001, no date limits reported.

Quality of study: Unpublished literature was not sought and only English language publications were included. There is only limited information on how the papers were assessed for quality and the types of studies included. It was unclear if they were similar enough to be combined in meta-analysis.

Results: Implant loss was described in about 100% of studies, while biological complications were considered in only 40-60%, and technical complications in 60-80% of the studies. Meta analysis indicated that implant loss prior to functional loading occurs in about 2.5% of all implants placed in implant therapy including more than one implant and when routine procedures are used. Implant loss during function occurs in about 2-3% of implants supporting fixed reconstructions, while in overdenture therapy >5% of the implants can be expected to be lost during a 5-year period.

41% of included studies reported data on the incidence of persisting sensory disturbance >1 year following implant surgery, but also on the absence or a low incidence (1-2%) of this complication beyond this interval.

There is limited information regarding the occurrence of peri-implantitis and implants exhibiting bone loss >or=2.5 mm. Implant fracture is a rare complication and occurs in <1% of all implants. The incidence of technical complications related to implant components and suprastructures, and of soft tissue complications was higher in overdentures than in fixed reconstructions.

Citation: Berglundh T, Persson L, Klinge B. A systematic review of the incidence of biological and technical complications in implant dentistry reported in prospective longitudinal studies of at least 5 years. Journal of Clinical Periodontology 2002; 29(Suppl. 3):197-212

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: A systematic review of the preventive effect of oral hygiene on pneumonia and respiratory tract infection in elderly people in hospitals and nursing homes: Effect estimates and methodological quality of randomized controlled trials
document.publisher: Journal of the American Geriatrics Society
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Within the limitations of this study, it can be concluded that available results from RCTs provide strong evidence that mechanical oral hygiene decreases mortality risk from pneumonia and seems to have a clinically relevant preventive effect on nonfatal pneumonia in dependent elderly individuals. These data show that providing mechanical oral hygiene may prevent approximately one in 10 cases of death from pneumonia in dependent elderly people and indicate a largely similar effect for prevention of pneumonia. Future research in this area should be focused on high-quality RCTs with appropriate sample size calculations.

Methods: A narrative systematic review of 15 papers (5 RCTs, 3 case control, 3 cross-sectional, 2 cohort studies and a systematic review) to investigate the preventive effect of oral hygiene on pneumonia and respiratory tracts infection in elderly people in hospitals and nursing homes. Search dates: 1996 to November 2007. Note: whilst 15 papers met the inclusion criteria, the review focuses on five papers reporting the results of four randomised controlled trials.

Quality of review: As the authors indicate, the results of this review should be viewed with caution because of the methodological flaws identified in included studies.

Several databases (Medline, Central and NHS Economic Evaluations Database) were searched for papers in a range of European languages and this was supplemented by reference list checking. However, it is likely that potentially relevant papers were missed as the search terms used were limited and only published papers were sought.

The authors identified 15 papers as meeting their inclusion criteria. However, the analysis is based on the five papers reporting on randomised controlled trials; two of which were different reports of the same study. They note that their findings “are largely consistent with a previous systematic review” – not entirely surprising given that the four studies on which they based their analysis were captured in that review. The authors appropriately decided not to conduct a meta-analysis given the significant clinical heterogeneity between studies. Although the inclusion criteria defines elderly people as 65 or older, the one study in a hospital population (the other three are in nursing home residents) includes surgical patients with a mean age of <65.

No information is provided on the processes used to select, data extract and quality assess included papers and the introduction of error and bias cannot be excluded. Study quality was assessed using the Jadad Scale and was generally medium to low with significant methodological flaws identified. The authors note that none of the included studies include a power calculation.

Results: The RCTs revealed positive preventive effects of oral hygiene on pneumonia and respiratory tract infection in hospitalized elderly people and elderly nursing home residents, with absolute risk reductions from 6.6% to 11.7% and NNTs from 8.6 to 15.3 individuals. The non-RCT studies contributed to inconclusive evidence on the association and correlation between oral hygiene and pneumonia or respiratory tract infection in elderly people. 

Citation: Sjogren P, Nilsson E, Forsell M, et al. A systematic review of the preventive effect of oral hygiene on pneumonia and respiratory tract infection in elderly people in hospitals and nursing homes: Effect estimates and methodological quality of randomized controlled trials. Journal of the American Geriatrics Society, 2008; 56 (11): 2124-2130

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. Full text online access is available to NHS staff in England via ATHENS passwords. To apply for an ATHENS password and access this resource and many others please go to the ATHENS registration page. 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: A systematic review of the relationship between overjet size and traumatic dental injuries
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,DENTAL INJURIES,ORTHODONTICS]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Children with an overjet larger than 3mm are approximately twice as much at risk of injury to anterior teeth than children with an overjet smaller than 3mm. This risk is less for boys than for girls.

Methods: A systematic review of 11 studies (longitudinal, case-control and cross-sectional studies) to aggregate information on the risk of injury to anterior teeth in relation to different degrees of overjet, to develop a checklist to use to assess the publications methodology, and combine the results of the studies in a meta-analysis.

Quality of review: The interpretation of the results should be viewed with caution. The homogeneity test showed the studies were heterogeneous, as were studies in two subgroups, yet the reviewers still pooled the odds ratios together. It may have been useful to perform meta-regression. One paper was also excluded since its OR differed considerably from other studies.

Although it can be deduced that case-control, cross sectional and longitudinal studies were included in the review, this is not clearly displayed. Key papers may not have been identified in the search strategy as unpublished papers were not sought.

Results: From the results it can be concluded that children with an overjet larger than 3mm are approximately twice as much at risk of traumatic dental injury than 3mm. For the 10 studies, the pooled Odds Ratio (OR) of overjet group 3mm or less versus 3mm or more, was 2.30 (CI 2.03-2.50).

The effect of overjet on the risk of dental injury is less for boys than for girls in the same overjet group.In addition risk of injury to anterior teeth tends to increase with increasing overjet size. Furthermore the pooled OR does not seem to be affected by the quality of the studies. Pooled OR for sub-group analysis were as follows:
2.16 (CI = 1.91-2.44) for studies using children of ages 6-18 yrs
2.17 (CI = 1.81-2.59) aged 6-18 yrs, internal validity score >19
2.17 (CI = 1.87-2.51) aged 6-18 yrs, methodological score >41
2.90 (CI= 2.33-3.76) aged 6-18 years, female
1.77 (CI = 1.41-2.20) aged 6-18 years, male

An OR of 2 was assumed to be clinically relevant (according to Pullinger et al, 1993).

Citation: Nguyen QV, Bezemer PD, Habets L et al. A systematic review of the relationship between overjet size and traumatic dental injuries. European Journal of Orthodontics 1999; 21: 503-515.

Access: Full text of this paper is freely available.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: A systematic review of the role of immunonutrition in patients undergoing surgery for head and neck cancer
document.publisher: International Journal of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORAL CANCER,ORAL SURGERY,ENT AND AUDIOLOGY,LARYNX & PHARYNX DISORDERS,NEOPLASMS,MALIGNANT,CONDITIONS,TREATMENT & MANAGEMENT,THERAPEUTIC INTERVENTIONS,NON-DRUG TREATMENTS,OTHER,SURGERY,HEAD & NECK CANCER]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors’ conclusions: There is a discrepancy between the use of dietary interventions and the strength of evidence for their benefit. Whilst perioperative immunonutrition is associated with reduced length of hospital stay; the mechanism is unclear as other outcomes were not improved. Trials were small with incomplete reporting of outcomes. An adequately powered trial is required to substantiate benefit.

Methods: A systematic review and meta-analysis of ten randomised controlled trials comparing perioperative standard polymeric nutrition or no nutritional supplementation with immunonutrition in the treatment of head and neck cancer. Database search dates not stated.

Quality of review: The authors made a reasonable attempt to identify the available literature, searching several databases, albeit with limited search terms, supplemented by reference list checking and contacting manufacturers to identify unpublished studies. It is not clear whether there were any language restrictions.

It is unclear how study selection and quality assessment was conducted. However, an appropriate process was used to minimise error and bias in data extraction.  The authors assessed key quality elements: allocation concealment, use of ITT analysis and blinding of participants and assessors. They also comment on small sample sizes with consequent inadequate powering of studies.

Results: Pooled estimates showed a reduction in length of hospital stay by 3.5 days (95% CI 0.7 to 6.3 day, P < 0.01). No reductions in clinical complications were seen.

Citation: Stableforth W, Thomas S, Lewis S. A systematic review of the role of immunonutrition in patients undergoing surgery for head and neck cancer. International Journal of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery 2009; 38(2):103-110.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance.  You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: A systematic review of the success of sinus floor elevation and survival of implants inserted in combination with sinus floor elevation. Part I: Lateral approach
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PERIODONTOLOGY,RESTORATIVE DENTISTRY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: The present systematic review revealed several shortcomings in the clinical studies reporting on sinus floor elevation. Many of the studies on the survival of implants placed in sinus grafted sites failed to report the original residual bone height at the site of presumptive implant placement and on graft failures. There is also a lack of RCTs with sufficient statistical power comparing various grafting materials. Hence, it appears appropriate to make the following recommendations: Only studies with rough-surface implants should be included in future analyses, as the use of machined surface implants tended to skew the survival rates due to low survival rates in sinus grafted sites. Long-term cohort studies on implants should be prospective, have complete follow-up information preferentially with similar lengths of follow-up for all patients. This, in turn, means that data on well-defined time periods should be reported for the entire cohort, especially for the different years after installation.

Methods: A systematic review and meta-analysis of 19 cohort studies (9 prospective and 10 retrospective to assess the survival rate of implants placed in the sites with transalveolar sinus floor augmentation and to evaluate the incidence of surgical and post-operative complications related to this procedure. Database search dates 1965 to November 2007.

Quality of review: The results of this systematic review should be viewed with caution. As the authors indicate, there are limited data available; none of it of high quality.

It is likely that the authors missed potentially relevant papers. Only one database was searched using restrictive search terms and supplemented by reference list checking, It is unclear whether papers in all languages were included. Searching additional databases with a sensitive search strategy, contacting experts and reviewing grey literature sources may well have identified additional papers. Appropriate procedures were used to minimise error and bias in study selection and data extraction. Whilst a formal quality appraisal process was not conducted, some quality elements were considered as part the inclusion criteria.

Results:

  • Based on implant-based analysis, the estimated annual implant failure rate was 3.5% (95% CI: 2.5%– 4.9%). This translated into a 3-year implant survival of 90.1% (95% CI: 86.4%–92.8%) based on implant level.
  • However, when failure rates was analyzed based on subject level, the estimated annual failure was 6.04% (95% CI: 3.87%–9.43%) translating into 16.6% (95% CI: 10.9%–24.6%) of the subjects experiencing implant loss over 3 years.
  • The annual failure rate of machined surface implants (6.9%) was significantly (po0.0001) higher than that for rough surface implants (1.2%).
  • The annual failure rate was significantly higher (4.0% versus 0.7%) (p50.001) when no membrane was used to cover the lateral window after the grafting procedure.
  • In rough surface implants the 3-year survival rates ranged between 96.3% and 99.8% depending on the grafting material used.
    • The lowest annual failure rate (0.1%) of rough surface implants was observed using autogenous particulated bone graft.
    • The annual failure rates of rough surface implants were similar using bone substitutes (1.1%) and combinations of autogenous bone and bone substitutes (1.1%).
  • Perforation of the sinus membrane occurring in 19.5% of the procedures was the most frequently reported complication. The mean incidence of post-operative graft infection was 2.9%. Graft loss resulting in inability of implant placement was reported in 1.9% of cases.

Citation: Pjetursson BE, Tan WC, Zwahlen M, Lang NP.  A systematic review of the success of sinus floorelevation and survival of implants inserted in combination with sinus floor elevation. Part I: Lateral approach. Journal of Clinical Periodontology 2008; 35(8 Suppl):216-40.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance.  You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: A systematic review of the success of sinus floor elevation and survival of implants inserted in combination with sinus floor elevation. Part II: Transalveolar technique
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PERIODONTOLOGY,RESTORATIVE DENTISTRY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: The present systematic review revealed several shortcomings in the clinical studies. Many of the studies on the survival of implants placed in sinusgrafted sites failed to report the original residual bone height and graft failures, if any. There is a need for a long-term clinical trial (=5 years) of implants inserted in combination with transalveolar sinus floor elevation. Furthermore, the question of whether different surgical techniques, implant types and grafting materials would improve the outcomes remains open, and future research is needed. RCTs with sufficient statistical power comparing transalveolar sinus floor elevations with and without grafting materials would be of great value.

Methods: A systematic review and meta-analysis of 19 cohort studies (9 prospective and 10 retrospective to assess the survival rate of implants placed in the sites with transalveolar sinus floor augmentation and to evaluate the incidence of surgical and post-operative complications related to this procedure. Database search dates 1965 to November 2007.

Quality of review: The results of this systematic review should be viewed with caution. As the authors indicate, there are limited data available; none of it of high quality.

It is likely that the authors missed potentially relevant papers. Only one database was searched using restrictive search terms and supplemented by reference list checking, It is unclear whether papers in all languages were included. Searching additional databases with a sensitive search strategy, contacting experts and reviewing grey literature sources may well have identified additional papers. Appropriate procedures were used to minimise error and bias in study selection and data extraction. Whilst a formal quality appraisal process was not conducted, some quality elements were considered as part the inclusion criteria.

Results: 

  • The estimated annual implant failure rate was 2.5% (95% CI: 1.4– 4.5%). This translated into a 3-year implant survival of 92.8% (95% CI: 87.4–96.0%).
  • The survival rate appeared to decrease with decreasing residual bone height.
  • Analysis on the subject-level revealed an estimated annual failure of 3.71% (95% CI: 1.21–11.38%), translating to 10.5% (95% CI: 3.6– 28.9%) of the subjects experiencing implant loss over 3 years.
  • Perforation of the sinus membrane occurring in 3.8% of the procedures was the most frequently reported complication. The mean incidence of post-operative graft infection was 0.8%.

Citation: Tan WC, Lang NP, Zwahlen M, et al. A systematic review of the success of sinus floor elevation and survival of implants inserted in combination with sinus floor elevation Part II: Transalveolar technique. Journal of Clinical Periodontology, 2008; 35 (s8): 241-254

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance.  You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: A systematic review of the survival and complication rates of all-ceramic and metal-ceramic reconstructions after an observation period of at least 3 years. Part I: single crowns
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,RESTORATIVE DENTISTRY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: All-ceramic crowns, when used for anterior teeth, showed survival rates at 5 years comparable to those seen for metal–ceramic crowns.

When used for posterior teeth, the survival rates at 5 years of densely sintered alumina crowns (94.9%) and reinforced glass–ceramic crowns (93.7%) were similar to those obtained for metal–ceramic crowns. Furthermore, lower survival rates of 90.4% and 84.4% can be expected for InCeram crowns and glass–ceramic crowns when utilized for premolars and molars.

Methods: A systematic review of 34 cohort studies (13 retrospective and 21 prospective) to assess the 5-year survival rates of all-ceramic single crowns and to compare it with the survival rates of metal–ceramic crowns and to describe the incidence of biological and technical complications. Literature review 1966 to November 2006.

Quality of review: The search may have missed key papers. Just two databases and reference list. Additional databases, handsearching key journals and contacting experts may have identified further papers. Unpublished literature was not sought which may have introduced publication bias, and it appears that only papers written in English, French or German were considered.

No formal method for assessing the quality of included studies is reported, however the inclusion criteria addressed aspects of quality such as criteria for length of follow-up and some methodological details of included studies were collected during data extraction.

It is not clear whether study selection, data extraction and quality assessment of included studies was performed in duplicate, which is a method used to help limit potential bias.

Results: In meta-analysis, the 5-year survival of all-ceramic crowns was estimated at 93.3% (95% confidence interval (CI): 91.1%–95%) and 95.6% (95% CI: 92.4%–97.5%) for metal–ceramic crowns.

All-ceramic crowns were also analyzed according to the material utilized. Densely sintered alumina (Procera®technique) crowns showed the highest 5-year survival rate of 96.4%, followed by reinforced glass–ceramic crowns (Empress®technique) and InCeram-crowns with survival rates of 95.4% and 94.5%, respectively. A significantly lower survival rate of 87.5% was calculated for glass–ceramic crowns after 5 years.

All-ceramic crowns were also grouped and analyzed regarding the position in the mouth. All four types of all-ceramic crowns showed lower survival rates when seated on posterior teeth. Moreover, for glass–ceramic crowns (84.4%) and InCeram-crowns (90.4%), this difference reached statistical significance (P=0.009, P=0.028).

Citation: Pjetursson BE, Sailer I, Zwahlen M, Hämmerle CHF. A systematic review of the survival and complication rates of all-ceramic and metal-ceramic reconstructions after an observation period of at least 3 years. Part I: single crowns. Clinical Oral Implants Research 2007; 18 (s3): 73–83.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance.  You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: A systematic review of the survival and complication rates of all-ceramic and metal-ceramic reconstructions after an observation period of at least 3 years. Part II: fixed dental prostheses.
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,RESTORATIVE DENTISTRY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

Authors' conclusions: For all-ceramic FDPs, significantly lower survival rates were seen at 5 years compared with metal–ceramic FDPs. The most frequent reason for failure of FDPs made out of glass-ceramics or glass-infiltrated ceramics was fracture of the reconstruction (framework and veneering ceramic). However, when zirconia was used as framework material, the reasons for failure were primarily biological and technical complications other than framework fracture.

Method: A systematic review of 8 prospective and 1 retrospective cohort studies to assess the 5-year survival rates and incidences of complications of all-ceramic fixed dental prostheses (FDPs) and to compare them with those of metal–ceramic FDPs.

Quality of review: The search may have missed key papers. Onlytwo databases were searched supplemented by reference list checking. Additional databases, handsearching key journals and contacting experts may have identified further papers. Unpublished literature was not sought which may have introduced publication bias, and it appears that only papers written in English, French or German were considered.

No formal method for assessing the quality of included studies is reported, however the inclusion criteria addressed aspects of quality such as criteria for length of follow-up and some methodological details of included studies were collected during data extraction.

It is unclear whether appropriate methods were used to minimise the introduction of error and bias during study selection, data extraction and quality assessment of included studies.

Results: In Poisson regression meta-analysis, the 5-year survival of metal–ceramic FDPs was significantly (P<0.0001) higher with 94.4% [95 confidence interval (CI): 91.1–96.5%] than the survival of all-ceramic FDPs, being 88.6% (95 CI: 78.3–94.2%). The frequencies of material fractures (framework and veneering material) were significantly (P<0.0001) higher for all-ceramic FDPs (6.5% and 13.6%) compared with those of metal–ceramic FDPs (1.6% and 2.9%). Other technical complications like loss of retention and biological complications like caries and loss of pulp vitality were similar for the two types of reconstructions over the 5-year observation period.

Citation: Sailer I, Pjetursson BE, Zwahlen M, Hämmerle CHF. A systematic review of the survival and complication rates of all-ceramic and metal-ceramic reconstructions after an observation period of at least 3 years. Part II: fixed dental prostheses. Clinical Oral Implants Research 2007; 18 (s3): 86–96.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: A systematic review of the survival and complication rates of fixed partial dentures (FPDs) after an observation period of at least 5 years. I. Implant-supported FPDs
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,RESTORATIVE DENTISTRY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors conclusions: Despite a high survival of fixed partial dentures (FPDs), biological and technical complications are frequent. This, in turn, means that substantial amounts of chair time have to be accepted by the clinician following the incorporation of implant-supported FPDs. More studies with follow-up times of 10 and more years are needed as only few studies have described the long-term outcomes.

Methods: A systematic review of 21 prospective and retrospective cohort studies examining the survival of implant supported FPDs with a mean follow-up of 5 years or more. Literature search to April 1966 to April 2004.

Quality of review: Key papers may have been missed and publication bias introduced as the only database searched was Medline and incusion was restricted to published research in English. There was no formal method for critically appraising the included studies, however the inclusion criteria addressed aspects of methodological quality (eg a minimum of five years clinically assessed follow-up was required).

Results: The search provided 3844 titles and 560 abstracts. Full-text analysis was performed for 176 articles resulting in 21 studies that met the inclusion criteria. Meta-analysis of these studies indicated an estimated survival of implants in implant-supported fixed partial dentures (FPDs) of 95.4% (95 percent confidence interval (95% CI): 93.9–96.5%) after 5 and 92.8% (95% CI: 90–94.8%) after 10 years. The survival rate of FPDs supported by implants was 95% (95% CI: 92.2–96.8%) after 5 and 86.7% (95% CI: 82.8–89.8%) after 10 years of function. Only 61.3% (95% CI: 55.3–66.8%) of the patients were free of any complications after 5 years. Peri-implantitis and soft tissue complications occurred in 8.6% (95% CI: 5.1–14.1%) of FPDs after 5 years. Technical complications included implant fractures, connection-related and suprastructure-related complications. The cumulative incidence of implant fractures after 5 years was 0.4% (95% CI: 0.1–1.2%). After 5 years, the cumulative incidence of connection-related complications (screw loosening or fracture) was 7.3% and 14% for suprastructure-related complications (veneer and framework fracture).

Citation: Pjetursson BE, Tan K, Lang NP, Bragger U, Egger M, Zwahlen M. A systematic review of thr survival and complication rates of fixed partial denture (FPDs) after an observation period of at least 5 years. I. Implant-supported FPDs. Clinical Oral Implants Research. 2004; 15(6): 625-642.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: A systematic review of the survival and complication rates of fixed partial dentures (FPDs) after an observation period of at least 5 years. II. Combined tooth-implant-supported FPDs
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PERIODONTOLOGY,RESTORATIVE DENTISTRY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors conclusions: Survival rates of both implants and reconstructions in combined tooth–implant-supported fixed partial dentures (FPDs) were lower than those reported for solely implant-supported FPDs (Pjetursson et al. 2004). Hence, planning of prosthetic rehabilitation may preferentially include solely implant-supported FPDs. However, anatomical aspects, patient centered issues and risk assessments of the residual dentition may still justify combined tooth–implant-supported reconstructions.

It was evident from the present search that tooth–implant-supported FPDs have not been studied to any great extent and hence, there is a definitive need for more longitudinal studies examining these reconstructions.

Methods: Systematic review of 13 cohort studies (9 prospective and 4 retrospective) comparing tooth-implant reconstructions with solely implant-supported constructions. The follow-up period for the studies was at least 5 years. Literature search dates 1966 to April 2004.

Quality of the review: Key papers may have been missed and publication bias introduced as the only database searched was Medline and inclusion was restricted to published papers in the English language. There was no formal method for critically appraising the included studies, however the inclusion criteria addressed aspects of methodological quality (eg a minimum of five years clinically assessed follow up was required).

Results: Meta-analysis indicated an estimated survival of implants in combined tooth–implant-supported fixed partial dentures (FPDs) of 90.1% (95% CI 82.4–94.5%) after 5 and 82.1% (95% CI 55.8–93.6%) after 10 years. The survival rate of FPDs was 94.1% (95% CI 90.2–96.5%) after 5 and 77.8% (95% CI 66.4–85.7%) after 10 years of function. There was no significant difference in survival of tooth and implant abutments in combined tooth–implant FPDs.

After an observation period of 5 years, 3.2% (95% CI 1.5–7.2%) of the abutment teeth and 3.4% (95% CI 2.2–5.3%) of the functionally loaded implants were lost. After 10 years, the corresponding proportions were 10.6% (95% CI 3.5–23.1%) for the abutment teeth and 15.6% (95% CI 6.5–29.5%) for the implants. After a 5 year observation period, intrusion was detected in 5.2% (95% CI 2–13.3%) of the abutment teeth. Intrusion of abutment teeth were almost exclusively detected among non-rigid connections.

Citation: Lang NP, Pjetursson BE, Tan K, Bragger U, Egger M, Zwahlen M. A systematic review of the survival and complication rates of fixed partial dentures (FPDs) after an observation period of at least 5 years. II. Combined tooth-implant-supported FPDs. Clinical Oral Implants Research. 2004; 15(6): 643-653.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: A systematic review of the survival and complication rates of fixed partial dentures (FPDs) after an observation period of at least 5 years. III. Conventional FPDs
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,RESTORATIVE DENTISTRY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors conclusions: The pooled failure rates of fixed partial dentures (FPDs) requiring intervention but leaving FPD in situ were lower than that of FPDs remaining totally intact during the observation period. Caries and loss of abutment vitality were the most common biological complications, while loss of retention of the FPD was the most common technical complication. Fracture of abutment teeth and material complications occured less frequently.

Methods: Systematic review of 19 prospective and retrospective cohort studies to determine the long-term success/survival of FPDs and complication rates. Literature search 1966 to March 2004.

Quality of research: Key papers may have been missed and bias introduced as the search was limited to published studies in the English language listed in Medline, plus reference lists of included studies.  There was no formal method for critically appraising included studies, although the inclusion criteria addressed aspects of methodological quality (eg a minimum of 5 years clinically assessed follow-up was required). 

Results: The 10-year probability of survival for fixed partial dentures was 89.1% (95% confidence interval (CI): 81–93.8%) while the probability of success was 71.1% (95% CI: 47.7–85.2%). The 10-year risk for caries and periodontitis leading to FPD loss was 2.6% and 0.7%, respectively. The 10-year risk for loss of retention was 6.4%, for abutment fracture 2.1% and for material fractures 3.2%.

Citation: Tan K, Pjetursson BE, Lang NP, Chan ESY. A systematic review of the survival and complication rates of fixed partial dentures (FPDs) after an observation period of at least 5 years. III. Conventional FPDs. Clinical Oral Implants Research. 2004; 15 (6): 654-666.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: A systematic review of the survival and complication rates of fixed partial dentures (FPDs) after an observation period of at least 5 years. IV. Cantilever or extension FPDs
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PERIODONTOLOGY,RESTORATIVE DENTISTRY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors conclusions: This systematic review on cantilever fixed partial dentures indicated that survival and success rates of cantilever fixed partial dentures were lower than those of conventional end-abutment supported fixed partial dentures (FPDs) described in a review by Tan et al (2004) and biological and technical complications were frequent.

Methods: Systematic review of 13 cohort studies ( 10 prospective and 3 retrospective) examining survival of FPDs with and without cantilever extensions. Literature search dates 1966 to April 2004.

Quality of review: Key papers may have been missed and publication bias introduced as the only database searched was Medline and papers were limited to research published in the English language.  There was no formal method for critically appraising the included studies, however the inclusion criteria addressed aspects of methodological quality (eg a minimum of five years clinically assessed follow-up was required).

Results: Meta-analysis resulted in an estimated survival rate of cantilever fixed partial dentures (FPDs) of 81.8% (95% CI 78.2–84.9%) and success rate (free of all complications) of 63% (95% CI 54.7–70.2%) after 10 years. The most common biological complication was loss of pulp vitality (32.6%) followed by caries at abutment teeth (9.1%).

After a 10-year observation period 2.6% of the FPDs were lost as a result of dental caries and 1% due to recurrent periodontitis. The most frequent technical complication was loss of retention (16.1%) followed by material fractures (5.9%). The cumulative incidence of fractures of abutment teeth was 2.9% and 2.4% of the FPDs were lost as a result of abutment tooth fracture after an observation period of 10 years.

Citation: Pjetursson BE, Tan K, Lang NP, Bragger U, Egger M, Zwahlen. A systematic review of the survival and complication rates of fixed partial dentures (FPDs) after an observation period of at least five years. IV. Cantilever or extension FPDs. Clinical Oral Implants Research. 2004; 15 (6): 667-676

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: A systematic review of the survival of implants in bone sites augmented with barrier membranes (guided bone regeneration) in partially edentulous patients
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PERIODONTOLOGY,RESTORATIVE DENTISTRY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: The survival rate of implants placed into sites with augmented bone using barrier membranes (guided bone regeneration) are similar to those generally reported for implants placed conventionally into sites without the need for bone augmentation. 

Methods: A systematic review of 11 studies (2 controlled trials and 9 case series and cross sectional studies) in patients with at least 12-month results following prosthetic reconstruction of titanium implants in bone regenerated with or without membrane supporting materials.  Literature search from 1990 to May 2001.

Quality of study: Medline was the only database used to locate the research, however several journals were also hand-searched and reference lists of relevant papers checked. It is unclear if unpublished or non-English language literature was sought. 

Results: Considering data from all included studies, the survival rate of implants placed into sites with regenerated/augmented bone using barrier membranes varied between 79% and 100% with the majority of studies indicating more than 90% after at least one year of function. No significant differences were found in the two controlled trials between implants in regenerated compared to implants in non-regenerated bone.

Citation: Hammerle CH, Jung RE, Feloutzis A. A systematic review of the survival of implants in bone sites augmented with barrier membranes (guided bone regeneration) in partially edentulous patients. Journal of Clinical Periodontology. 2002; 29 Suppl 3:226-231.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: A systematic review of viral infections associated with oral involvement in cancer patients: a spotlight on Herpesviridea
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORAL CANCER,ORAL CARE FOR CANCER PATIENTS,SPECIAL CARE DENTISTRY,CANCER PATIENTS]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Acyclovir and valacyclovir are equally effective in preventing oral HSV infection. Neutropenic patients, who were primarily treated for hematological malignancies in the studies reviewed, are at a greater risk for viral infection.

Methods: A narrative systematic review of 23 studies (14 observational and 9 intervention studies) to determine the prevalence of and interventions for oral viral infections.  Database search dates: 1989 to 2007.

Quality of review: Overall a reasonably well-conducted systematic review. The authors searched two electronic databases using a highly sensitive search strategy. However, it is possible that potentially relevant studies were missed as no other sources were searched and inclusion was restricted to published studies in the English language. Appropriate processes were used to minimise error and bias in selecting, data extracting and quality assessing included studies. A range of questions designed to identify potential bias in different study types were incorporated into the data extraction form. Only limited information is provided on the included studies. It is not clear if studies could be combined which gives concern to using an overall prevalence score.

Results: Prevalence of oral herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection in neutropenic patients was higher than in patients treated with radiotherapy for head and neck cancer (49.8% vs. 0%, respectively). In patients treated with radiochemotherapy for head and neck cancer, the prevalence of oral HSV infection increases up to 43.2% (CI, 0–100%). Prevalence of HSV infection was higher when oral ulcers existed. Information about other oral viral infections is sparse. There was a significant benefit of using acyclovir to prevent HSV oral infection (at 800 mg/day). Various dosing protocols of valacyclovir achieved prevention of HSV reactivation (500 or 1,000 mg/day). The prevalence of HSV reactivation was similar for acyclovir and valacyclovir. No information about impact on QOL and economic burden was available.

Citation: Elad S, Zadik Y, Hewson I, Hovan A, Correa ME, Logan R, et al. A systematic review of viral infections associated with oral involvement in cancer patients: a spotlight on Herpesviridea. Supportive Care in Cancer 2010 Aug;18(8):993-1006.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

 

Note: additional details about the methodology are provided in:

Brennan MT, Elting LS, Spijkervet FK. Systematic reviews of oral complications from cancer therapies, Oral Care Study Group, MASCC/ISOO: methodology and quality of the literature. Supportive Care in Cancer 2010 Aug;18(8):979-84
