document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: A systematic review on the clinical efficacy of subginigval debridement in the treatment of chronic periodontitis
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,PERIODONTOLOGY,TREATMENT & MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Subgingival debridement (SDG), in conjunction with supragingival plaque control, is an effective treatment in reducing probing pocket depth and improving the clinical attachment level, and more effective than supragingival plaque control alone.   

Methods: A systematic review of 11 non-randomised trials and 18 longitudinal studies in patients with chronic untreated periodontitis. The review evaluates the effectiveness of sub-gingival debridement on change in probing attachment level (main outcome), pocket depth and bleeding on probing. Databases were searched up to 2001.

Quality of study: Inclusion criteria were amended in the light of studies identified. The literature search was not comprehensive and restricted to English language articles.  Heterogeneity was not assessed formally.

Results: Four of the 10 controlled studies provide a definite ‘yes’ that SGD is effective with regard to clinical outcomes. In the study where subgingival debridement was not supported by oral hygiene instruction, the paper provided a definitive 'no'. The weighted mean of attachment gain of SGD in pockets initially >or=5 mm was 0.64 mm as compared with 0.37 mm for supragingival plaque control only (SPC).

The reduction of pocket depth was 0.59 mm and 1.18 mm for SPC and SGD, respectively. Of the 18 papers that provided only information on the effect of treatment as compared with the baseline values, eight showed SGD to be beneficial with regard to clinical attachment level change while the remaining 10 provided no such an analysis. The weighted mean of this effect was a 0.74-mm gain of attachment as a result of treatment in pockets initially >or= 4 mm.  

Citation: Van der Weijden GA, Timmerman MF. A systematic review on the clinical efficacy of subgingival debridement in the treatment of chronic periodontitis. Journal of Clinical Periodontology. 2002; 29 (Suppl 3):55-71.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: A systematic review on the effect of systematic antimicrobials as an adjunct to scaling and root planing in periodontitis patients
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,PERIODONTOLOGY,TREATMENT & MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors conclusions: Systemic antimicrobials in conjunction with scale and root planing (SRP), can offer an additional benefit over SRP alone in the treatment of periodontitis, in terms of CAL and PPD change, and reduced risk of additional CAL loss. However, differences in study methodology and lack of data precluded an adequate and complete pooling of data for a more comprehensive analyses. It was difficult to establish definitive conclusions, although patients with deep pockets, progressive or ‘active’ disease, or specific microbiological profile, can benefit more from this adjunctive therapy. 

Methods: A systematic review of 25 randomised controlled trials in patients with aggressive and chronic periodontitis. Literature search to April 2001.

Quality of study: Unpublished research was not sought and onlu English language papers were included. As acknowledged by the authors the review was limited due to a lack of data and differences among studies.

Results: Quality assessment showed that randomization and allocation concealment methods were seldom reported and blindness was usually not defined clearly. In general, selected studies showed high variability and lack of relevant information for an adequate assessment.

Overall, SRP plus systemic antimicrobial groups demonstrated better results in CAL and PPD change than SRP alone or with placebo groups. Only limited meta-analyses could be performed, due to the difficulties in pooling the studies and the lack of appropriate data. This analysis showed a statistically significant additional benefit for spiramycin (PPD change 0.407 95%CI 0.081 - 0.733 p= 0.014) and amoxicillin/metronidazole (CAL change 0.450 95%CI 0.192 - 0.709, p= 0.001) in deep pockets.

Citation: Herrera D, Sanz M, Jepsen S, Needleman I, Roldan S. A systematic review on the effect of systemic antimicrobials as an adjunct to scaling and root planing in periodontitis patients. Journal of Clinical Periodontology 2002; 29 (Suppl 3): 136-159.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page. 

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: A systematic review on the effects of subgingival chlorhexidine gel administration in the treatment of chronic periodontitis
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,PERIODONTOLOGY,TREATMENT & MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: The limited data currently available on the effects of subgingival chlorhexidine gel application do not justify its use in the treatment of chronic periodontitis.

Methods: A systematic review of 8 randomised controlled trials  examining the use of chlorhexidine gels as a single measure of treatment and as an adjunct to scaling and root planing. Literature search up to January 2005.

Quality of review:  The limited search strategy may have failed to identify relevant studies.  Medline and Cochrane databases were searched, supplemented by journal handsearching and reference list review, but it is not clear that unpublished trials were sought.  The validity of the included papers was assessed.  Studies were of  variable quality and limited sample size and the authors rightly indicate that the data do not support gel usage.

Results: Eight studies were finally selected. Due to considerable heterogeneity in study design and outcome variables measured a qualitative data analysis was performed. There is evidence that subgingival chlorhexidine gel administration as a monotherapy temporarily reduces bleeding tendency on probing; a clinical effect coinciding with relevant microbiological changes described in all but one study. To what extent chemical effects contribute to these changes appears to be related to the frequency of gel administration. There seem to be little to no data indicating that the treatment outcome of scaling and root planning will benefit from the adjunctive subgingival administration of a CHX gel.

Citation: Sabzevar MM, Cosyn J. A Systematic Review on the Effects of Subgingival Chlorhexidine Gel Administration in the Treatment of Chronic Periodontitis. Journal of Periodontology 2005; 76(11): 1805-1813

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: A systematic review on the effects of the chlorhexidine chip when used as an adjunct to scaling and root planing in the treatment of chronic periodontitis
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,PERIODONTOLOGY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: The clinical and microbiological data currently available on the chlorhexidine chip are limited and conflicting. More research is needed to elucidate the additional value of the chlorhexidine chip when used as an adjunct to scaling and root planning. 

Methods: A systematic review of five randomised controlled trials to review the evidence for the use of the chlorhexidine chip as an adjunct to scaling and root planing in the treatment of chronic periodontitis.

Quality of study: A limited database search was conducted in Medline and Central,  supplemented by hand searching of three journals and a review of references from selected studies.  Unpublished research does not appear to have been sought and non-English language papers were excluded; this may have introduced publication and language biases. The authors conducted a quality appraisal of the five selected RCTs and found methodological problems with four of them.  This, combined with considerable heterogeneity in study design made the results ambiguous.

Results: Multicenter studies have indicated significantly high pocket reductions and clinical attachments gains following a combination of mechanical debridement and repeated chlorhexidine chip administration in comparison to scaling and root planning alone. However, some recent studies failed to confirm the additional value of the chlorhexidine chip. A number of interstudy disparities with respect to methodological quality and study design may account for this lack of accordance. 

Citation: Cosyn J, Wyn I.  A systematic review on the effects of the chlorhexidine chip when used as an adjunct to scaling and root planing in the treatment of chronic periodontitis. Journal of Periodontology 2006; 77 (2): 257-64

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: A systematic review on the use of residual probing depth, bleeding on probing and furcation status following initial periodontal therapy to predict further attachment and tooth loss
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,PERIODONTOLOGY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Patient-based data from one study suggest that  (RPD) are predictive of further periodontal disease progression. Further research via multicentre randomised controlled trials is needed.

Methods: A systematic review of 13 prospective longitudinal studies in patients aged at least 20 years with chronic periodontitis in natural teeth untreated within the preceding year. Search dates were not reported.

Quality of study: Non English language papers were not included in this review. A clear formal method of assessing the validity of the included studies was not reported, however the inclusion criteria do address some methodological quality aspects. Results are based on only one small study.

Results: Only one publication utilised data based on patients as unit of observation. This study included 16 subjects over 42 months and suggested that residual probing depths are predictive of further disease progression whereas persisting bleeding on probing are not. An additional critical review of 12 selected publications preiously excluded as they did not present patient-based data was performed and selected information presented in the article.

Citation: Renvert S, Persson GR. A systematic review on the use of residual probing depth, bleeding on probing and furcation status following initial periodontal therapy to predict further attachment and tooth loss. Journal of Clinical Periodontology 2002; 29 Suppl 3:82-89.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: A systematic review to investigate the effectiveness and acceptability of interventions for moist desquamation in radiotherapy patients
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORAL CANCER,TREATMENT & MANAGEMENT,ORAL CARE FOR CANCER PATIENTS,SPECIAL CARE DENTISTRY,CANCER PATIENTS]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Author’s conclusions: Despite being recommended by many guidelines (College of Radiographers Summary of Intervention for Acute Radiotherapy Induced Skin Reactions in Cancer Patients (London, 2001); NHS Quality Improvement Scotland Best Practice Statement: Skincare of Patients Receiving Radiotherapy (Edinburgh, 2004)); there is mixed evidence concerning the use of hydrogels and hydrocolloid dressings. However, improved patient comfort was sometimes seen, which is arguably equally important. There was limited evidence to support other interventions. Further research is urgently needed.

Quality of review: Overall a well-conducted systematic review, however, as the author states, the generalisability of most included studies is limited by small samples, strict selection criteria, single centre locations and restricted patient groups,

An extensive electronic search of 24 sources was conducted for published and unpublished literature in all languages. The search was supplemented by hand searching, reference list checking and contacting experts and manufacturers.

The review was conducted by a single author and consequently it is possible that bias and error were introduced in selecting, quality assessing and data extracting studies. The CASP checklist was used to quality assess included studies. Study quality was mixed.

Methods: A systematic review of ten studies (9 RCTs and 1 CCT) to evaluate treatments for moist desquamation in radiotherapy patients. Database search dates not stated.

Results: There is limited and often conflicting evidence to support the use of any intervention for moist desquamation. No convincing evidence for any intervention was found.

Citation: Kedge EM. A systematic review to investigate the effectiveness and acceptability of interventions for moist desquamation in radiotherapy patients. Radiography 2009; 15(3): 247-257.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Absence of carious lesions at margins of glass-ionomer and amalgam restorations: a meta- analysis
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,DENTAL CARIES,RESTORATIVE DENTISTRY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors’ conclusions: Carious lesions at margins of single-surface glass ionomer cement (GIC) restorations are less common than with amalgam fillings after 6 years in permanent teeth. No difference was observed in primary teeth. More trials are needed in order to confirm these results.

Methods: A systematic review and meta-analysis of four randomised and two quasi-randomised controlled trials. The review aimed to compare the absence of carious lesions at margins of GIC and amalgam restorations. Literature search to January 2008.

Quality of review: The results should be viewed with caution, as the review is limited by the low number and poor quality of the randomised controlled trials identified. It is difficult to judge whether the literature search was comprehensive. Although a number of databases were searched, the search appears to have been restricted to these databases and search terms are not provided. Unpublished research was not sought and this  may have introduced publication bias.

The results of trials were pooled based on their clinical homogeneity: i.e. by type of dentition (primary or permanent), cavity type (single or multiple surfaces) and years of follow-up period. This resulted in a small number of studies in each pooled analysis.  For example the authors conclude that absence of carious lesions at margins of single-surface GIC restorations is higher than on amalgam fillings of permanent teeth after six years. However this result is based on a meta-analysis of just two studies. Furthermore these studies are shown to be statistically heterogeneous, (p = 0.08,  the authors set the level at p<0.1). The presence of heterogeneity and its impact is not discussed by the authors, but it does suggest a random effects model might have been more appropriate for the meta-analysis, or that the studies should not have been combined.

The authors critically appraised included studies and set study quality criteria for excluding papers, yet it appears they did not fully comply with this criteria. For example, studies were to be excluded if they used insufficient random allocation of study subjects. However table 3 (quality assessment of accepted studies) shows that the allocation was judged to be unclear in three studies and inadequate in two (allocation by toss of a coin or alteration).

Results: Significantly less carious lesions were observed on single-surface GIC restorations in permanent teeth after 6 years as compared to restorations with amalgam (OR 2.64 - CI 95% 1.39 - 5.03, p= 0.003). No studies investigating multiple-surface restorations on permanent teeth were identified. Studies investigating carious lesions at margins of restorations in primary teeth showed no difference between both materials after 3 and 8 years.

Citation: Mickenautsch S, Yengopal V, Leal SC, Oliveira LB, Bezerra AC, Bönecker M. Absence of carious lesions at margins of glass-ionomer and amalgam restorations: a meta- analysis. European Journal of Paediatric Dentistry 2009;10(1): 41-6.

Access: Full text of this paper is freely available.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Abutment screw loosening in single-implant restorations: A systematic review
document.publisher: International Journal of Oral and Maxillofacial Implants
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PERIODONTOLOGY,RESTORATIVE DENTISTRY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: The results show that abutment screw loosening is a rare event in single-implant restorations regardless of the geometry of implant-abutment connection, provided that proper anti-rotational features and torque are employed.

Methods: A systematic review of 27 studies to ascertain the incidence of abutment screw loosening in single-implant restorations with different implant-abutment connection geometries. Database search dates not stated.

Quality of review: The authors searched three databases supplemented by hand searching five key journals and reference list checking.  However it is possible that relevant studies were missed and bias introduced as the search terms used were very restrictive and inclusion was limited to published studies in the English language. Appropriate procedures were used to minimise error and bias in study selection and data extraction. The authors appear to have limited quality assessment to assigning levels of evidence (generally low); however the inclusion criteria did include some quality elements: study numbers, drop-out rates and a minimum follow-up period. That follow up period was 3 years and it is noteworthy that extending the minimum follow-up period to five years would have excluded 17 of the 29 included studies. The authors recognise this in their discussion and comment that “the results do not provide safe conclusions regarding the long-term stability of various implant-abutment connections.

Results: Three-year complication-free rates (survival proportions) were calculated with the aid of a survival function, assuming constant failure rates. The external-connection group comprised 12 studies following 586 single-implant restorations for a mean follow-up time that ranged from 3 to 5 years. The estimated percent of complication-free single-implant restorations after 3 years was 97.3% (95% CI: 95.6-98.3). The internal connection group comprised 15 studies following 1,113 single-implant restorations for a mean follow-up time that ranged from 3 to 10 years. The estimated percentage of complication-free single-implant restorations after 3 years was 97.6% (95% CI: 96.5-98.3).

Citation: Theoharidou A, Petridis HP, Tzannas K, et al. Abutment screw loosening in single-implant restorations: A systematic review. International Journal of Oral and Maxillofacial Implants, 2008; 23 (4): 681-690

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance.  You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Accuracy of computer programs in predicting orthognathic surgery hard tissue response
document.publisher: Journal of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,DENTO-FACIAL ANOMALIES,ORAL SURGERY,ORTHODONTICS]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors’ conclusions: Computer programs cannot consistently predict the skeletal changes occurring after orthognathic surgery but their results may be considered inside a clinically acceptable range. The last-minute changes by the surgeons have not been considered so far. No software program was shown to be superior in prediction accuracy compared with its competitor.

Methods: A systematic review of nine (6 retrospective and 3 prospective) uncontrolled studies. The review sought to investigate the accuracy of computer programs in predicting skeletal changes after orthognathic surgery. Literature search to June 2008.

Quality of review:  A good attempt was made to identify relevant studies, via a range of bibliographic databases, journal handsearching and reference list checking. Unpublished research was not included, which may have introduced publication bias.

Two independent reviewers selected papers in duplicate and quality was assessed using a predefined checklist, though it is unclear whether this was also conducted in duplicate. It should also be noted that the studies were a relatively low level of evidence (most were retrospective uncontrolled studies).

Results: As expected, no dental changes occurred but the computer programs were unable to precisely predict all the skeletal changes. Most of the prediction inaccuracies were within 2 mm or 2 degrees, which can be partially attributed to measurement errors in cephalometric tracing

Citation: Kaipatur N, Al-Thomali Y, Flores-Mir. Accuracy of computer programs in predicting orthognathic surgery hard tissue response. Journal of Oral Maxillofacial Surgery 2009; 67:1628-1639

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Accuracy of computer programs in predicting orthognathic surgery soft tissue response
document.publisher: Journal of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,DENTO-FACIAL ANOMALIES,ORAL SURGERY,ORTHODONTICS]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors’ conclusions: The most significant area of error in prediction through the available computer prediction programs was the lower lip area. Although the individual errors are almost always minimal (<2 mm), the composite addition of these minimal errors could have clinical implications.

Methods: A systematic review of seven retrospective studies examining the accuracy of computer programs in predicting soft tissue response subsequent to skeletal changes after orthognathic surgery. Literature search to to August/September 2007.

Quality of review:  A good attempt was made to identify relevant studies, via a range of bibliographic databases, journal handsearching and reference list checking. Unpublished research was not included, which may have introduced publication bias.

Two independent reviewers selected papers in duplicate and quality was assessed using a predefined checklist, though it is unclear whether this was also conducted in duplicate. It should also be noted that the studies were a relatively low level of evidence (retrospective studies).

Results: All 7 studies in general showed accurate prediction outcomes (<2 mm) when compared with actual results in both horizontal and vertical directions. Only for a few specific cephalometric points was the difference larger than 2 mm (2.2 for pogonion vertically, 2.2 and 2.9 for lower lip vertically, 3.8 for stomion inferior horizontally, 2 and 2.1 for stomion inferior vertically, 2.6 for stomion superior horizontally, 2.1 for pronasale vertically).

Citation: Kaipatur N, Flores-Mir. Accuracy of computer programs in predicting orthognathic surgery soft tissue response. Journal of Oral Maxillofacial Surgery 2009; 67:751-759

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Accuracy of real-time polymerase chain reaction versus anaerobic culture in detection of Aggregatibacter actinomycetemcomitans and Porphyromonas gingivalis: a meta-analysis
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,PERIODONTOLOGY,DIAGNOSIS]]>
document.body:
This is a provisional record for information. The review has been identified as potentially meeting the Oral Health Specialist Library quality criteria. It will be critically appraised and a quality statement provided as soon as possible.
_____________________________________________________

Authors' conclusions: This review showed a high diagnostic accuracy of real-time polymerase chain reaction (PCR) in detecting A. actinomycetemcomitans and P. gingivalis compared to the culture technique. However, the choice of the microbiologic test is determined by several factors, including diagnostic accuracy, cost, availability, and the need for an antibiotic susceptibility test.

Methods: A systematic review and meta-analysis of five studies to determine the diagnostic accuracy of real-time PCR aimed at detecting Aggregatibacter actinomycetemcomitans (previously Actinobacillus actinomycetemcomitans) and Porphyromonas gingivalis. Literature search to 1 November 2007.

Results: Meta-analyses examined the areasunder summary receiver operator characteristic curves (SROCs), and diagnostic odds ratios (DORs) were calculated to evaluate the test accuracy. The areas under SROCs for real-time PCR in identifying A. actinomycetemcomitans and P. gingivalis were 95.9% and 99.5%, respectively. The DORs in detecting A.actinomycetemcomitans and P. gingivalis were 18.5 (95% confidence interval [CI]: 2.25 to 152.02) and 40.47 (95% CI: 1.99 to 822.26), respectively.

Citation: Atieh MA. Accuracy of real-time polymerase chain reaction versus anaerobic culture in detection of Aggregatibacter actinomycetemcomitans and Porphyromonas  gingivalis: a meta-analysis. Journal of Periodontology 2008;79(9):1620-9.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Acellular dermal matrix for mucogingival surgery: A meta-analysis
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,PERIODONTOLOGY,TREATMENT & MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: It is difficult to draw anything other than tentative conclusions from this meta-analysis of acellular dermal matrix (ADM) for mucogingival surgery, primarily because of the weakness in the design and reporting of existing trials.

Methods: A systematic review and meta-analysis of eight RCTs. Four studies compared ADM versus a connective tissue graft for root coverage procedures, two compared ADM versus coronally advanced flap (CAF) for root coverage procedures, and two studies compared ADM to free gingival graft in augmentation of keratinized tissue. Literature search from January 1990 to October 2004.

Quality of Review: A reasonable attempt was made to identify relevant research through database and hand searching.  However, it is possible that key papers may have been missed as unpublished and non-English language papers were not sought.  Two reviewers independently selected papers and assessed the quality of included studies.  The authors appropriately state that the review was limited by design quality and by the levels of heterogeneity and highlight the need for further, high quality RCTs.

Results: There were no statistically significant differences between groups for any of the outcomes measured (recession coverage, keratinized tissue formation, probing depths, and clinical attachment levels). The majority of the analyses demonstrated moderate to high levels of heterogeneity. 

Considering the heterogeneity values found among the studies, certain trends could be found:

  1. Three out of four studies favored the ADM-RC group for recession coverage
  2. A connective tissue graft tended to increase keratinized tissue compared to ADM (0.52-mm difference; P = 0.11)
  3. There were trends of increased clinical attachment gains comparing ADM to CAF procedures (0.56-mm difference; P = 0.16)

Citation: Gapski R, Parks CA, Wang H-L,A cellular dermal matrix for mucogingival surgery: A meta-analysis, Journal of Periodontology, 2005; 76(1): 1814-1822

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Actions that can make anticoagulant therapy safer: Alert and other information
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORAL SURGERY]]>
document.body:
This Patient Safety Alert advises healthcare organisations to take steps to manage the risks associated with the prescribing, dispensing and administering of anticoagulants.

Anticoagulants are one of the classes of medicines most frequently identified as causing preventable harm and admission to hospital.

Healthcare organisations in England and Wales should:

  1. Ensure staff are properly trained.
  2. Review and/or update written procedures and clinical protocols to ensure they reflect safe practice.
  3. Audit anticoagulant services using BSH/NPSA safety indicators as part of the annual medicines management audit programme. 
  4. Ensure that patients prescribed anticoagulants receive appropriate information. 
  5. Promote safe practice for prescribers and pharmacists to check that patients’ blood clotting (International Normalised Ratio, INR) is monitored regularly and that the INR level is safe before issuing or dispensing repeat prescriptions for oral anticoagulants.
  6. Promote safe practice for prescribers co-prescribing one or more clinically significant interacting medicines for patients already on oral anticoagulants: arrange for additional INR blood tests and inform the anticoagulant service that an interacting medicine has been prescribed.
  7. Ensure dental practitioners manage patients on anticoagulants according to evidence-based therapeutic guidelines. 
  8. Amend local policies to standardise the range of anticoagulant products used, incorporating characteristics which promote safer use.
  9. Promote the use of written safe practice procedures for the administration of anticoagulants in social care settings.


Resources include:

  • Patient Safety Alert
  • Template service audit form
  • Information for community pharmacists, GPs and social care providers
  • Poster for dental practices on how to manage patients who are taking warfarin and undergoing dental treatment
  • British Society of Haemotology Standards for anticoagulants
  • Risk assessment reports

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Acupuncture in the treatment of painful dysfunction of the temporomandibular joint -- a review of the literature.
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,ORO-FACIAL PAIN]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions:  Acupuncture appears to be a suitable complementary treatment method in the management of craniomandibular dysfunction. However, its significance has to be further evaluated in future studies.

Methods:  A systematic review of six randomised controlled trials to determine the efficacy of acupuncture in the treatment of craniomandibular dysfunction.

Quality of study: It is likely that all relevant papers were not identified.  Only Medline, PubMed and the Cochrane Library were searched using a limited search strategy. It is unclear whether reference lists were checked or whether non-English language papers were considered. Unpublished research does not appear to have been sought, and this may have introduced publication bias. Variations between the studies were too great to allow data synthesis.  Limited statistical information is provided, making it difficult to review results. As the authors state, all included studies shared methodological shortcomings and the results should therefore be viewed with caution.

Results:  All studies share methodological shortcomings, including a lack of detailed descriptions of the randomization procedures, point selection, possible dropouts and undesirable events as well as attempts to identify a possible placebo effect of the acupuncture. Only 1 study investigated long-term results. Although based on the improvement of subjective and objective criteria, all studies consider acupuncture as an effective treatment for painful dysfunction of the temporomandibular joint, the good results achieved must be interpreted with caution because of the methodological shortcomings identified.

Citation:  Fink M, Rosted P, Bernateck , Stiesch-Scholz M, Karstd M. Forsch Komplementärmed 2006;13:109-115

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Adjunctive techniques for oral cancer examination and lesion diagnosis. A systematic review of the literature
document.publisher: Journal of the American Dental Association
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,ORAL CANCER,DIAGNOSIS & REFERRAL]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: There is evidence that toluidine blue (TB) is effective as a diagnostic adjunct for use in high-risk populations and suspicious mucosal lesions. OralCDx is useful in assessment of dysplastic changes in clinically suspicious lesions; however, there are insufficient data meeting the inclusion criteria to assess usefulness in innocuous mucosal lesions. Overall, there is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of visually based examination adjuncts.

Methods: a systematic review of 23 studies (study design not reported) to evaluate the effectiveness of adjunctive techniques  (toluidine blue, ViziLite Plus with TBlue, ViziLite, Microlux DL, Orascoptic DK, VELscope and OralCDx brush biopsy that may facilitate the early detection of oral premalignant and malignant lesions (OPML). Literature search from 1 January 1966 to 17 February 2008.

Quality of review: A moderate quality systematic review which may be limited by the search strategy employed. Although three databases were searched; broader search terms, checking reference lists of studies, handsearching key journals and contacting experts/organisations may have identified additional research. Further key papers may have been missed and bias introduced as only English language studies were included. Unpublished research does not appear to have been sought which may have introduced publication bias.

Included papers were quality assessed in duplicate and the characteristics and results of the studies are clearly displayed in the appendix.

Results: The largest evidence base was for TB. A limited number of studies was available for ViziLite, ViziLite Plus with TBlue and OralCDx. Studies of VELscope have been conducted primarily to assess the margins of lesions in known OPML. The authors identified no studies of Microlux DL or Orascoptic DK. 

Citation: Patton LL, Epstein JB, Kerr AR. Adjunctive techniques for oral cancer examination and lesion diagnosis: a systematic review of the literature. Journal of the American Dental Association 2008; 139(7): 896-905.

Access: The full text of this paper is freely available.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Aetiology of molar–incisor hypomineralization: a critical review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PAEDIATRIC DENTISTRY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors's conclusions: There is currently insufficient evidence in the literature to establish aetiological factor/s relevant for molar–incisor hypomineralization (MIH). Improvements in study design, as well as standardization of diagnostic and examination protocols, would improve the level and strength of evidence.

Methods: A narrative systematic review of 53 studies (42 cohort, 5 case control, 5 cross-sectional and 1 case series) to assess the strength of evidence for the aetiology of MIH, often as approximated by demarcated defects. Literature search dates unclear.

Quality of review:  As the authors note, the conclusions of this review are limited by the quality and availability of the evidence. The authors made a fair effort to identify published literature through electronic databases (Medline, Embase and Cochrane Library) using comprehensive search terms. However, no other sources were searched and inclusion was restricted to English language studies which may have introduced bias. Appropriate methods were used to minimise error and bias in study selection and quality assessment. The method used to data extract study data is unclear. Only 17 of the included papers were graded as being of low to moderate risk of bias.

Results: The level of evidence provided by the majority of papers was low and most did not specifically investigate MIH. There was moderate evidence that polychlorinated biphenyl/dioxin exposure is involved in the aetiology of MIH; weak evidence for the role of nutrition, birth and neonatal factors, and acute or chronic childhood illness/treatment; and very weak evidence to implicate fluoride or breastfeeding.

Citation: Crombie F, Manton D, Kirkpatrick N. Aetiology of molar–incisor hypomineralization: a critical review. International Journal of Paediatric Dentistry 2009; 19(2) 73-83.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Alterations of temporomandibular disorders before and after orthognathic surgery
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,DENTO-FACIAL ANOMALIES,ORAL SURGERY,ORTHODONTICS]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: To obtain reliable scientific evidence, additional well-controlled and well-designed studies are needed to determine how and if orthognathic surgery alters signs and symptoms of temporomandibular disorders (TMD).

Methods: A narrative systematic review of three controlled clinical trials. Literature search: January 1966 to April 2006.

Quality of review: The methods used to select, data extract and quality appraise included articles were thorough. However, it is possible that the search missed key papers. Only two databases were searched, and additional methods to identify papers such as reference list checking, hand-searching, contacting experts and examining grey literature sources were not used. Whilst there was no language restriction, the search was limited to published research. This may have introduced publication bias.

Results: The search strategy resulted in 467 articles, of which 3 met the inclusion criteria. Because of few studies with unambiguous results and heterogeneity in study design, the scientific evidence was insufficient to evaluate the effects that orthognathic surgery had on TMD. Moreover, the studies had problems with inadequate selection description, confounding factors, and lack of method error analysis.

Citation: Abrahamsson C, Ekberg E, Henrikson T, Bondemark L. Alterations of temporomandibular disorders before and after orthognathic surgery. The Angle Orthodontist 2007; 77(4): 729–734.

Access: Available to the general public.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Alveolar bone dimensional changes of post-extraction sockets in humans: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORAL SURGERY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors’ conclusions:  During the post-extraction healing period, the weighted mean changes as based on the data derived from the individual selected studies, show the clinical loss in width to be greater than the loss in height, assessed both clinically as well as radiographically.

Methods: A systematic review of 6 RCTs, four CCTs, 1 case series and one prospective clinical trial. (Five of the included studies had a spilt mouth design.) Databases searched from 1965 to March 2009.

Quality of review: A reasonable attempt was made to identify all relevant papers, using comprehensive search terms in two databases and reference list checking. However, additional papers studies may have been identified from further bibliographic databases, handsearching key journals, website searches and contacting key experts. The studies are limited to published, English language papers which may have introduced publication and language bias.

As recognised by the authors, the weighted mean differences should be viewed cautiously due to the large degree of clinical heterogeneity between studies.

Results: The reduction in width of the alveolar ridges was 3.87 mm (95%CI 4.059 to 3.673). The mean clinical mid-buccal height loss was 1.67 mm (95%CI 1.91 to 1.428). The mean crestal height change as assessed on the radiographs was 1.53 mm (95%CI 1.696 to 1.364). Socket fill in height as measured relative to the original socket floor was on an average 2.57 mm. (2.446 to 2.707)

Citation: Van der Weijden F, Dell’Acqua F, Slot DE. Alveolar bone dimensional changes of post-extraction sockets in humans: a systematic review. Journal of Clinical Periodontology 2009: 36; 1048-1058.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: An epidemiologic review of smokeless tobacco health effects and harm reduction potential
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,DENTAL PUBLIC HEALTH,ENT AND AUDIOLOGY,CONDITIONS,HEAD & NECK CANCER]]>
document.body:
This is a provisional record for information. The review has been identified as potentially meeting our quality criteria. It will be critically appraised and a quality statement provided as soon as possible.

 

Aims: A systematic review of the epidemiologic literature on the health effects of smokeless tobacco (ST) and its relevance to the harm reduction model for smoking was undertaken.

Methods: Published epidemiologic studies, from the US and European countries, meeting defined inclusion criteria and assessing the health effects of smokeless tobacco products were examined.

Results: ST use showed evidence of a slightly increased risk for all-cause mortality. Little evidence was found to support a causal relationship between ST use and risk of oral, pancreatic or lung cancer. ST use was not associated with an increased risk of cardiovascular disease or stroke incidence, but evidence suggested ST use was associated with increased mortality from these diseases. Clinical trials evaluating the effectiveness of ST products in smoking cessation have been sparse, and no standardized method for measuring ST dependence has been used, limiting the assessment of their relationship to ST use. Several studies have examined if ST use increases the risk of smoking initiation, but few have modeled this complex behavior appropriately.

Conclusions: Overall, epidemiologic studies have not shown strong evidence of elevated tobacco-related disease risks with ST use. More research is necessary to assess the smoking behavioral consequences of ST use prior to its consideration as a harm reduction tool 

Citation: Colilla SA. An epidemiologic review of smokeless tobacco health effects and harm reduction potential. Regulatory Toxicology & Pharmacology 2010; 56(2):197-211. 

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: An evidence-based assessment of the clinical guidelines for replanted avulsed teeth. Part 1: timing of pulp extirpation
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ENDODONTICS,ORAL SURGERY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

NOTE: this review and its companion relate to guidelines published by the International Association of Dental Traumatology:

  • Guidelines for the evaluation and management of traumatic dental injuries
  • Guidelines for the management of traumatic dental injuries. II. Avulsion of permanent teeth

These guidelines are only available to members of the association. 

 

Authors' conclusions: There is clinical evidence for an association between pulp extirpation (PE) performed after 14 days following replantation and the development of inflammatory resorption. This investigation supports the current clinical guidelines for PE within 10 to 14 days of replantation.

Methods: A systematic review and meta-analysis of six studies (three retrospective audit and three prospective cohort) pooling 236 replanted avulsed teeth. Database search dates not stated.

Quality of review: The conclusions of this review are limited by the small sample sizes of included studies. As the authors themselves admit, it is possible that potentially relevant papers were missed. Although they searched several electronic databases, the search terms were restrictive, no additional sources were searched and only English language papers were included. Little information is provided on the methods used to select, quality assess and data extract included papers and the introduction of error and bias in these processes cannot be excluded. The authors developed their own quality appraisal checklist based on several others. Overall study quality was limited.

Results: Meta-analyses found a statistically significant association between PE performed after 14 days and the development of inflammatory resorption [common odds ratio (COR) = 0.37, standard error (se) = 0.50, 95% confidence interval (CI): 0.14–0.98]. Pulp extirpation within 10 days of replantation was not significantly associated with a decreased likelihood of developing inflammatory resorption. There were no statistically significant differences in PE times for functional healing, acceptable healing without progressive resorption, or the development of replacement resorption.

Citation: Hinckfuss SE, Messer LB. An evidence-based assessment of the clinical guidelines for replanted avulsed teeth. Part I: timing of pulp extirpation. Dental Traumatology. 2009 Feb; 25(1):32-42.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: An evidence-based assessment of the clinical guidelines for replanted avulsed teeth. Part II: prescription of systemic antibiotics
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,DENTAL INJURIES,ENDODONTICS]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

NOTE: this review and its companion relate to guidelines published by the International Association of Dental Traumatology:

  • Guidelines for the evaluation and management of traumatic dental injuries
  • Guidelines for the management of traumatic dental injuries. II. Avulsion of permanent teeth

These guidelines are only available to members of the association

 

Authors' conclusions: The evidence for an association between prescribing systemic antibiotic therapy (SAT) and an increased likelihood of acceptable periodontal healing outcome is inconclusive. This investigation of antibiotic use as defined in the clinical guidelines indicates there is inconclusive clinical evidence from studies of replanted avulsed human teeth to either contradict or support the guideline. Pending future research to the contrary, dentists are recommended to follow current guidelines in prescribing SAT when replanting avulsed teeth.

Methods: A systematic review and meta-analysis of three studies (two retrospective audit and one prospective cohort) pooling 326 replanted avulsed teeth. Database search dates not stated.

Quality of review: The conclusions of this review are limited by the small sample sizes of included studies. As the authors note, it is possible that potentially relevant papers were missed. Although they searched several electronic databases, the search terms were restrictive, no additional sources were searched and only English language papers were included. Little information is provided on the methods used to select, quality assess and data extract included papers and the introduction of error and bias in these processes cannot be excluded. The authors developed their own quality appraisal checklist based on several others. Overall study quality was limited.

Results: Meta-analyses found no statistically significant difference between prescribing or not prescribing antibiotics for acceptable periodontal healing without progressive root resorption (common odds ratio = 0.90, SE = 0.29, 95% confidence intervals = 0.51–1.58). 

Citation: Hinckfuss SE, Messer LB. An evidence-based assessment of the clinical guidelines for replanted avulsed teeth. Part II: prescription of systemic antibiotics. Dental Traumatology 2009 Apr;25(2):158-64.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: An investigation of the nature of research into dental health in prisons: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ OUTCOMES,INDIVIDUAL BEHAVIOUR,DISADVANTAGED GROUPS,ORAL HEALTH DISORDERS,MONTHLY ADDITIONS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORAL HEALTH,DETERMINANTS,PUBLIC HEALTH,HYGIENE,BUILDINGS,PRISONS,SPECIAL CARE DENTISTRY,SETTINGS,POPULATIONS,GROUPS,MAY 2010,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,DENTAL DECAY,DENTAL CARIES,ORAL HYGIENE,DENTAL HEALTH]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Though the institutions and inmates studied differ in many ways, there is a general trend from the published research that oral health is poorer in institutionalised populations than non-institutionalised matched individuals, and that dental health is perceived as less important than other aspects of health.

Methods: A narrative systematic review of 21 studies (17 cross-sectional, 3 retrospective chart reviews, 1 qualitative) to identify the nature and quality of oral health research carried out in prisons, correctional institutions and detention facilities worldwide.

Quality of review: The authors searched multiple databases using a comprehensive search strategy, supplemented by reference list checking. It is not clear whether there was any language restriction, but only published papers were included. Additional search methods aimed at identifying grey literature may have yielded additional studies.

Appropriate procedures were used to minimise error and bias in study selection, data extraction and quality assessment. Whilst the authors do not provide much detail on quality assessment they state that data extraction included identification of potential sources of bias and attempts to control for confounding.

Results: The primary focus of the papers identified was the oral health status of inmates, assessed by clinical examinations of decayed, missing and filled teeth (DMFT) and periodontal status, plus self-report measures of oral health behaviours and service utilisation. Attempts were made to reduce sources of bias by selecting random samples of inmates, standardising measurement techniques and addressing potential confounding effects. Few studies considered the potential impact of socio-economic status on disease levels. In some studies the oral health of inmate populations was compared to that of non-institutionalised individuals. Studies report high prevalence of oral disease, though precise levels differ according to the composition of the samples.

Citation: Walsh T, Tickle M, Milsom K. An investigation of the nature of research into dental health in prisons: a systematic review. British Dental Journal, 2008; 204: 683-689.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: An overview of oral health promotion in adolescents
document.topics: <![CDATA[ OUTCOMES,YOUNG PEOPLE,ORAL HEALTH DISORDERS,HEALTH PROTECTION,POPULATION BASED & PREVENTATIVE SERVICES,MONTHLY ADDITIONS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,DENTAL PUBLIC HEALTH,ORAL HEALTH,PUBLIC HEALTH,MANAGEMENT & INTERVENTIONS,SERVICES,GROUPS,AGE GROUPS,POPULATIONS,2009 DECEMBER]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: The majority of the studies targeting oral health promotion towards adolescents reported only short-term and varying effects of oral health-related behaviour. The present knowledge suggests that a relapse of adolescent oral health-related behaviour in time should be expected in the absence of a subsequent reinforcement. As there was a lack of diversity in methods employed to motivate adolescents to adhere to oral hygiene regimens, it cannot be inferred which intervention is the best to promote oral health to this cohort. The main challenge for future research in oral health promotion is not only to find the effective ways to change an individual’s behaviour, but also to achieve sustained improvements in it that translate to improved oral health. Therefore, alternative approaches for oral health promotion in adolescents should be explored.

Methods: A narrative systematic review of 31 studies (study types unclear) to determine the effectiveness of different strategies used to promote oral health in adolescents. Database search date: 1967 to September 2007.

Quality of review: It is likely that relevant studies were missed as only Medline was searched using a limited search strategy, supplemented by reference list checking. Restricting the search to published English language studies may have introduced additional bias. No information is provided on the processes used to select and data extract studies and the introduction of error and bias cannot be excluded. Whilst no formal method was used to assess the quality of included studies, some key quality elements (follow-up period, sample size, validity of outcome measures) were considered. The authors comment on the age of most of the included studies; the majority of which were conducted before 1990.

Results: All studies evaluating knowledge showed cognitive gains. Only slight or no improvement in attitude was reported. The average improvement in oral hygiene was 30–50%. A wide range 0–50% of the effects on gingival health was presented. However, the relapse in oral hygiene status towards baseline values was also observed. Only studies employing professionally applied preventive measures in conjunction with educational activities reported significantly lower caries incidence

Citation: Brukiene V, Aleksejuniene J. An overview of oral health promotion in adolescents. International Journal of Paediatric Dentistry. 2009; 19(3):163-71.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Ante's (1926) law revisited: a systematic review on survival rates and complications of fixed dental prostheses (FDPs) on severely reduced periodontal tissue support
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,PERIODONTOLOGY,RESTORATIVE DENTISTRY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: (i) masticatory function could be established and maintained in subjects receiving FDPs on abutment teeth with severely reduced but healthy periodontal tissue support and (ii) FDPs survival rates compared favourably with those of FDPs incorporated in subjects without severely periodontally compromised dentitions.

Methods: A systematic review of six retrospective studies to determine the impact of severely reduced, but healthy periodontal tissue support on the survival rate and complications of FDPs after a mean follow-up time of at least 5 years. Literature search 1966 to September 2006.

Quality of review: It is possible that the search strategy missed key papers. Only one database was searched (Medline) using basic search terms, journals hand-searched and reference lists checked for extra papers. The search was restricted to published English-language studies which may have introduced language and publication biases. Additional databases, grey literature sources and contacting experts may have identified further key articles.

Results: A total of 579 FDPs were incorporated and followed up to 25 years. Meta-analysis yielded an estimated FDP survival rate of 96.4% [95% confidence interval (95% CI): 94.6–97.6%] after five and of 92.9% (95% CI: 89.5–95.3%) after 10 years, respectively. After 10 years, the estimated rate of abutment teeth without endodontic complications amounted to 93% (95% CI: 62.6–98.9%). The 10-year estimated rate of caries-free abutment teeth was 98.1% (95% CI: 88.2–99.7%). FDPs without loss of retention were estimated to occur in 95.4% (95% CI: 92.6–97.2%) of cases after 10 years.

Citation: Lulic M, Brägger U, Lang, NP, Zwahlen M, SAlvi GE. Ante's (1926) law revisited: a systematic review on survival rates and complications of fixed dental prostheses (FDPs) on severely reduced periodontal tissue support. Clinical Oral Implants Research 2007; 18 (s3): 63–72.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Antibiotic prophylaxis and postoperative complications after tooth extraction and implant placement: a review of the literature
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORAL INFECTIONS,ORAL MEDICINE,ORAL SURGERY,PERIODONTOLOGY,RESTORATIVE DENTISTRY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: With the recent improvements in the current standards of antibiotic prophylaxis in dentistry, further monitoring of antibiotic use among dental practitioners as well as continuing education for practitioners concerning the public health risks related to the over-prescription of antibiotics are needed.

Methods: Systematic review to assess the evidence regarding the use of preoperative antibiotic prophylaxis among children and adults undergoing dental extraction or implant placement. 8 RCTs, 2 retrospective studies, 2 correlational, and 1 non-randomized trial were included. Literature search 31 Dec 1997 to 30 June 2007.

Quality of review: A good range of databases was searched, but the way in which the search terms were combined were restrictive, potentially missing key papers. Other methods such as handsearching, reference list checking or contacting experts may have identified further papers. Furthermore it is possible that publication and language bias was introduced as only published papers written in English were included. Selection and critical appraisal of included studies was performed in duplicate by independent reviewers, although information regarding the inclusion critieria is limited.

Results: Overall, the body of literature was limited and of poor quality. In general, sample sizes were small and provided insufficient statistical power to avoid type II, or false-negative errors. In some studies no comparison group was included and/or it was difficult to determine the extent to which the intervention had actually been implemented.

Citation: Schwartz AB, Larson EL. Antibiotic prophylaxis and postoperative complications after tooth extraction and implant placement: a review of the literature. Journal of Dentistry 2007; 35: 881-888

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Are mutans streptococci detected in preschool children a reliable predictive factor for dental caries risk? A systematic review.
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,DENTAL CARIES,PAEDIATRIC DENTISTRY,CAUSES & PREVENTION]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors conclusions:  Presence of mutans streptococci, both in plaque or saliva of young caries-free children, appears to be associated with a considerable increase in caries risk. Lack of adjustment for potential confounders in the original studies, however, limits the extent to which interpretations for practice can be made.

Methods:  A systematic review of nine studies to assess the association of mutans streptococci detected in 2- to 5-year old preschool children and the subsequent development of caries.  Literature search to end 2003.

Quality of review: A reasonable attempt was made to find all relevant research.  The authors searched a number of databases without language restrictions; albeit with narrow search terms.  They also checked reference lists and contacted test manufacturers regarding new research. The validity of included studies was assessed independently by two reviewers and found to be problematic.  Combined with the relatively low number of included studies and small sample sizes, the authors rightly conclude that the results should be viewed with caution.

Results:  Results of plaque and saliva testing were pooled separately using a fixed effects model. Methodological quality of reports was low. Out of 9 studies included, data from 3 reports on plaque test assessment alone (n = 300) and from 4 reports on saliva test assessment alone (n = 451) were available for pooled analysis. The pooled risk ratio (95% CI) was 3.85 (2.48-5.96) in studies using plaque tests and 2.11 (1.47-3.02) in those using saliva testing.

Citation:  Thenish NL, Bachmann LM, Imfeld T, Leisebach Minder T.  Are mutans streptococci detected in preschool children a reliable predictive factor for dental caries risk? A systematic review. Caries Research 2006; 40: 366-374.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Are psycho-social and behavioural factors related to health related-quality of life in patients with head and neck cancer?
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,ORAL CANCER,ENT AND AUDIOLOGY,NOSE & SINUS DISORDERS,LARYNX & PHARYNX DISORDERS,SALIVARY GLAND DISORDERS,NEOPLASMS,BENIGN,MALIGNANT,NEOPLASMS,BENIGN,MALIGNANT,NEOPLASMS,BENIGN,MALIGNANT,CONDITIONS,TREATMENT & MANAGEMENT,ADJUNCTIVE THERAPY,HEAD & NECK CANCER]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Further research is needed to investigate other psychological factors which may influence aspects of health related-quality of life (HR-QoL). By understanding the relationship between HR-QoL and potentially modifiable variables, interventions can be designed with the aim of improving a patient’s long-term well-being.

Methods: Systematic review of 6 case control and 10 prospective studies to identify the psycho-social or behvioural factors associated with HR-QoL and the relationship between depresive symptoms and HR-QoL.

Quality of Review: Although non-English papers were not included, a good attempt was made to locate relevant published and unpublished research.  The authors searched 10 databases, checked reference lists of included papers, contacted experts and handsearched recent journals.  The authors assessed the validity of the included studies.

Results: Five main factors were associated with varying degrees with HR-QoL, personality, social support, satisfaction with consultation and information, behavioural factors, such as consuming alcohol and smoking, and depressive symptoms.

Citation: Llewellyn CD, McGurk M, Weinman J. Are psycho-social and behavioural factors related to health related-quality of life in patients with head and neck cancer? A systematic review. Oral Oncology 2005; 14(5): 440-54

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Assessment of characteristic features and dental anomalies accompanying tooth transposition: a meta-analysis
document.publisher: American Journal of Orthodontics and Dentofacial Orthopedics
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,DENTO-FACIAL ANOMALIES]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors’ conclusions: Tooth transposition is an isolated phenomenon rather than a syndrome. It occasionally can be accompanied by other characteristic features and dental anomalies, but without distinct associations. The heterogeneity of the original samples and the few studies that remained for evaluation after application of the exclusion criteria do not allow more definitive conclusions to be drawn. More high-quality studies on tooth transposition are needed to produce strong evidence based conclusions.

Methods: A meta-analysis to investigate possible characteristic features and dental anomalies that accompany tooth transposition. Five studies were eligible for inclusion. Meta-analysis was performed by determining the marginal mean proportions and the 95% confidence intervals estimated by the random-effect model. Literature search to October 2008.

Quality of review:  The results of the review should be viewed with caution given the poor quality of evidence available.  The authors made a good attempt to identify relevant published and unpublished studies; searching a broad range of bibliographic databases, research registers and websites, supplemented by hand searching and contacting experts.

There is some ambiguity about the inclusion criteria. Studies were to be excluded if they had a small sample size, but an adequate sample size is not defined. Although the authors state they did not impose language restrictions, papers had to have an abstract in English and four papers were excluded because they were “undetermined language”. The flow diagram indicates that 10 papers were excluded on the basis of “syndromic patients”, though the reasoning for this is unclear. This is potentially important as the authors’ concluded that tooth transposition is an isolated phenomenon rather than a syndrome.

Results: The lack of high-validity studies of the characteristic features and dental anomalies of tooth transposition was noted. The analysis of the data of the studies showed that tooth transposition seems to occur more often unilaterally than bilaterally, with maxillary prevalence and no sex preference, and it is significantly unrelated to dental anomalies, such as congenitally missing teeth, peg-shaped or hypoplastic teeth, or impacted teeth. There might be an association with overretained deciduous teeth.

Citation: Papadopoulos MA, Chatzoudi M, Karagiannis V. Assessment of characteristic features and dental anomalies accompanying tooth transposition: a meta-analysis. American Journal of  Orthodontics and Dentofacial Orthopedics 2009 ;136(3):308.e1-10

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Assessment of endpoints in studies on peri-implantitis treatment--A systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,PERIODONTOLOGY,TREATMENT & MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body:
This is a provisional record for information. The review has been identified as potentially meeting our quality criteria. It will be critically appraised and a quality statement provided as soon as possible.

 

Background: Endpoints are normally used to assess the efficacy of clinical treatment. In studies of peri-implantitis therapy, "true" endpoints are preferred to "surrogate", because they can capture a substantial proportion of the effect of treatment on an outcome of interest, for example implant failure.Objective To assess the type of endpoints reported in the literature on peri-implantitis therapy, and their frequency of use.

Materials and methods: An extensive literature search was conducted (Pubmed, Cochrane, and Lilacs databases up to and including October 2009) to retrieve randomised controlled trials and non-randomised studies. Grey literature and major dental journals were also searched for potential studies. A variable was regarded as an endpoint only when it was clearly stated as the objective of an investigation.

Results: Fourteen studies are included in this review. Data on implant failure are presented solely as a consequence of peri-implantitis therapy, and not as an objective of an investigation. No true endpoint was described in any study on peri-implantitis. Mean pocket probing depth at implant, mean clinical attachment level at implant, and mean bleeding on probing (after pocket depth assessment) at implant were the three surrogate endpoints cited most often in the studies. More than 20 different clinical endpoints were described in the studies selected.

Conclusions: Reports did not reveal whether or not the therapy for peri-implantitis is useful for reducing the risk of implant failure. A consensus should be reached among dental researchers to standardise surrogate endpoints, and efforts should be made to validate these endpoints 

Citation: Faggion Jr CM, Listl S, Tu YK. Assessment of endpoints in studies on peri-implantitis treatment - A systematic review. Journal of Dentistry 2010; 38(6):443-450.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.
