document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Association between fruit and vegetable consumption and oral cancer: a meta-analysis of observational studies.
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,ORAL CANCER,PREVENTION,NUTRITION]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions:  The consumption of fruit and vegetables is associated with a reduced risk of oral cancer.  Prospective studies, which are less prone to bias, are needed to confirm this result.

Methods:  A systematic review of sixteen studies ( 15 case control and 1 cohort) to determine quantitative conclusions about the contribution of fruit and vegetable intake to the occurance of oral cancer.  Literature search to September 2005.

Quality of study: It is likely that the search strategy did not identify all relevant papers.  Only Medline was searched, using limited search terms.  This was supplemented by checking reference lists from retrieved publications and recent review articles.  It is not clear whether non-English language papers were included or unpublished data sought.  The methodological quality of the included studies was independently assessed by two reviewers. There was considerable heterogeneity between the studies and the authors discuss a number of biases and confounders that may have had an impact on study results.  Consequently, they advise that the results of this study should be viewed with caution.

Results:  The combined adjusted odds ratio (OR) estimates showed that each portion of fruit consumed per day significantly reduced the risk of oral cancer by 49% (OR: 0.51; 95% CI: 0.40, 0.65). For vegetable consumption, the meta-analysis showed a significant reduction in the overall risk of oral cancer of 50% (OR: 0.50; 95% CI: 0.38, 0.65). The multivariate meta-regression showed that the lower risk of oral cancer associated with fruit consumption was significantly influenced by the type of fruit consumed and by the time interval of dietary recall.

Citation: Pavia M, Pileggi C, Nobile CG, Angelillo IF. Association between fruit and vegetable consumption and oral cancer: a meta-analysis of observational studies. American Journal of Clinical Nutrition 2006; 83(5): 1126-32

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. 

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Association between maternal infections and preeclampsia: a systematic review of epidemiologic studies
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,PERIODONTOLOGY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors’ conclusions: Endothelial dysfunction and excessive inflammation are consistent characteristics of preeclampsia. The exact cause of inflammation is not completely understood. However, infection is known to stimulate the immune system and may provide a biologically plausible explanation for preeclampsia-related inflammation. The concept that infection may trigger preeclampsia would provide insight into the pathophysiology of this maternal syndrome. Furthermore, it would suggest public health measures that might reduce the incidence of a disease that causes major maternal morbidity and perinatal mortality.

Methods: A systematic review and meta-analysis of 16 observational studies (6 prospective, 8 case control and 2 retrospective) to examine the strength of an association between maternal infection and preeclampsia. Database search dates: 1964 to August 2006.

Quality of review: The results of the study are limited by the quality of the included studies. As the authors note, they could not “discount the possibility that unmeasured infection-related risk factors may have confounded the relationship between infection and preeclampsia in some studies”. Most of the studies did not evaluate all potential confounding factors.

The authors searched three databases supplemented by reference list checking. The search was restricted to peer-reviewed published studies in English, German and Spanish. Tests indicated no significant evidence of publication bias.

The method used to select studies is unclear and data extraction was conducted by one author. The introduction of error and bias into these processes cannot be excluded. No formal process was used to assess the quality of included papers. However, the authors discuss the limitations of the included papers in some detail.

Results:  Combined results for the 16 studies yielded an OR of 2.1 (95% CI 1.6–2.7). Separate pooled estimates for prospective (OR 2.3, 95% CI 1.7–3.0), case control and retrospective studies combined (OR 2.0, 95% CI 1.4–2.9) yielded similar results. Heterogeneity was significant across overall pooled estimates, case control and retrospective studies (Qdf=20 of 45.7, P = .001; Qdf=10 of 38.7, P < .005, respectively), but not prospective studies (Qdf=9 of 6.5 P = .69).

Citation: Rustveld LO, Kelsey SF, Sharma R. Association between maternal infections and preeclampsia: a systematic review of epidemiologic studies. Maternal and Child Health Journal 2008 Mar;12(2):223-42.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. Full text online access is available to NHS staff in England via ATHENS passwords. To apply for an ATHENS password and access this resource and many others please go to the ATHENS registration page .

 

NOTE:

We have included this review because periodontal disease was the infectious agent studied in several of the studies. However, there is no separate analysis of an association between periodontal disease and preeclampsia.  Two other systematic reviews have considered this possible association in more detail:

Conde-Agudelo A, Villar J, Lindheimer M. Maternal infection and risk of preeclampsia: Systematic review and metaanalysis. American Journal of Obstretics and Gynecology, 2008; 198 (1): 7-22.

Xiong X, Buekens P, Vastardis S, Yu SM. Periodontal disease and pregnancy outcomes: state-of-the-science. Obstetrical and Gynecological Survey 2007; 62(9):605-15.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Association between pacifier use and breast-feeding, sudden infant death syndrome, infection and dental malocclusion
document.publisher: International Journal of Evidence Based Healthcare
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,DENTO-FACIAL ANOMALIES,ORTHODONTICS]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: No conclusions can be drawn regarding an association between pacifier use and dental malocclusion, due to the lack of epidemiological studies. This was also the case for the association between pacifier use and infection.

The evidence for a relationship between pacifier use and Sudden Infant Death Syndrome (SIDS) is consistent. For breast feeding, research shows that pacifier use in infancy is associated with a shorter duration and non- exclusivity.

Methods: Narrative systematic review to examine the evidence of adverse and/or positive outcomes of pacifier use in infancy and childhood in relation to each of the following:

  • breast feeding
  • sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS)
  • infection
  • dental malocclusion.

No studies met the inclusion criteria for dental malocclusion. Included studies were: 2 RCTs and 8 cohort studies (breast feeding outcomes), 6 case control studies (SIDS outcome) and 4 cohort studies (infection outcomes). Literature search from January 1960 to October 2003.

Quality of review: A well conducted narrative systematic review. The review addressed a clearly focused issue and a good attempt was made to identify all relevant published and unpublished literature. Searching methods included 15 databases, citation searching, key websites, government documents, books and reports, handsearching, and contacting experts. To minimise bias, study selection, data extraction and quality assessment were performed in duplicate by independent reviewers. However, it is possible that language bias was introduced as the review was restricted to English, German or Spanish studies.

Results: Five cohort studies and one case-control study focused on the relationship between pacifier use and dental malocclusion. Not one of these studies reported a measure of association, such as an estimate of relative risk. It was therefore not possible to include these studies in the final review.

Please see the executive summary for further details on the breast feeding, SIDS and infection outcomes.

Citation: Callaghan A, Kendall G, Lock C et al. Association between pacifier use and breast-feeding, sudden infant death syndrome, infection and dental malocclusion. International Journal of Evidence Based Healthcare 2005; 3: 147-167

Access: The executive summary is freely available to view online. However, full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Association of malocclusion and functional occlusion with temporomandibular disorders (TMD) in adults: a systematic review of population-based studies
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORO-FACIAL PAIN,ORTHODONTICS]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors conclusions: Few associations were established between malocclusion or functional occlusion and signs and symptoms of TMD. In view of the small number of randomized studies and their methodologic quality, these results should be verified through further valid representative studies.

Methods: Systematic review of 4 population-based epidemiological studies in adults 20 years or older, to establish whether or not associations exist between different types of malocclusions, as well as factors of functional occlusion (eg, occlusal interferences, nonworking-side occlusal contacts) and temporomandibular disorders (TMD). Literature search 1966 to February 2002. 

Quality of review:  A reasonable attempt was made to identify the relevant literature. Medline and Embase databases were searched without restriction and selected journals and reference lists were handsearched for additional papers in either English or German.  Unpublished research was not sought and this may have introduced publication bias.  The methodological quality of included papers was assessed by two independent reviewers using pre-defined methodology.  The selection process is unclear.  The authors indicate that they examined 74 papers in full-text.  Of these twenty two are described in the review: four population-based epidemiological studies fulfilled the exclusion criteria; 18 studies were excluded.

Results: The average total methodologic score achieved was 43 out of a possible 100 points. Few associations were reported between malocclusion and parameters of functional occlusion and clinical as well as subjective TMD, and these associations were not uniform. No particular morphologic or functional occlusal factor became apparent. Additionally, the occlusal factors found were partly protective for TMD, ie, subjects with these occlusal parameters showed fewer signs and symptoms of TMD (angle Class II malocclusion, deep bite, anterior crossbite).

A positive relationship was only described in two cases—between the number of rotated lateral teeth and subjective symptoms of dysfunction, and between excessive abrasions and clinical dysfunction. In neither case, however, was the strength of the correlation given.

Citation: Gesch D, Bernhardt O, Kirbschus A. Association of malocclusion and functional occlusion with temporomandibular disorders (TMD) in adults: a systematic review of population-based studies. Quintessence International. 2004; 35 (3): 211-221.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Association of some specific nutrient deficiencies with periodontal disease in elderly people: A systematic literature review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,PERIODONTOLOGY,ASSOCIATED CONDITIONS,SPECIAL CARE DENTISTRY,OLDER PEOPLE]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors’ conclusions: There is no evidence of an association of vitamin B complex, vitamin C, vitamin D, calcium, and magnesium deficiencies with periodontal disease in non-institutionalized elderly people. To produce conclusive evidence on the subject of this systematic literature review, longitudinal cohort studies and follow-up randomized controlled trials are needed.

Methods: A narrative systematic review of 8 cross-sectional studies to consider whether there is an association between nutritional deficiencies (vitamin B complex, vitamin C, vitamin D, calcium and magnesium) and periodontal disease in older people (aged 50+). Database search dates: January 1990 to May 2007).

Quality of review: The review has a number of limitations. It is possible that key papers have been missed as only peer-reviewed published studies written in English or Dutch have been included. Whilst a range of databases were searched, the terms used were restrictive and only 38 potentially relevant publications were identified. Using more comprehensive search terms, hand searching journals, contacting experts and searching websites and other grey literature sources, may have identified further relevant studies.

There is a lack of clarity around the inclusion and exclusion critieria. The authors do not discuss why they excluded malnourished groups, nor do they consider how mineral deficiencies were measured. Additionally, it appears that Pussinen et al (Table 1) was included despite its periodontal disease outcome measure being serology, rather than CAL or PPD; the defined outcome measures.

Appropriate methods were used to minimise error and bias in selecting and data extracting studies. The quality of included studies was assessed; focusing on the elements of study design likely to introduce bias.

The authors’ conclusions were appropriate given that the only cross-sectional studies were identified. Longitudinal studies, which could have indicated causality, did not appear to be available.  As the authors note, there is a need for additional studies in this area. Only two papers actually focus on the population of interest (adults aged 50+); the other six covering a wide range of population ages. Additionally, six of the eight included papers were reporting data from the same cross-sectional survey (the US National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey).

Results: None of the studies meeting the selection criteria included institutionalized elderly people. In the studies on non-institutionalized elderly people, no significant or consistent association was found between vitamin B complex, vitamin C, vitamin D, calcium, and magnesium dietary intakes and serum levels and periodontal disease. Although in those studies decreased dietary vitamin C intake was found to be associated with increased risk of periodontal disease, no conclusive evidence could be demonstrated.

Citation: van der Putten G, Vanobbergen J, De Visschere L, Schols J, de Baat C. Association of some specific nutrient deficiencies with periodontal disease in elderly people: A systematic literature review. Nutrition 2009: 25 (7): 717-722

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. Full text online access is available to NHS staff in England via ATHENS passwords. To apply for an ATHENS password and access this resource and many others please go to the ATHENS registration page .

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Associations between periodontal disease and risk for atherosclerosis, cardiovascular disease and stroke. A systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,PERIODONTOLOGY,ASSOCIATED CONDITIONS]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors conclusions: Periodontal disease may be modestly associated with atherosclerosis, myocardial infarction and cardiovascular disease. Additional large-scale longitudinal epidemiologic and intervention studies are necessary to validate this association and to determine causality.

Methods: A systematic review of 31 studies (case-controls cross-sectional and longitudinal studies) to assess the association between chronic inflammatory periodontal disease and atherosclerosis. Literature search 1966 to March 2002.

Quality of the review: Key papers may have been missed and bias introduced as it is unclear whether unpublished or non-English language studies were sought. Two independent reviewers selected the studies and extracted data. Papers were assigned a rank according to the type and quality of the study.  However, it is not reported how the judgements of quality were made.  The potential for confounding factors suggests that the findings should be treated with caution.

Results: Of the initial 1,526 studies identified, were included in the analysis. Taken together, most of the literature supports a modest association between periodontal disease and atherosclerosis. However, data reported in several studies do not show this association.

The absence of a standard definition and measures for periodontal disease complicates interpretation of results, as do potential confounding risk factors common to both conditions.

Citation: Scannapieco FA, Bush RB, Paju, S. Associations between periodontal disease and risk for atherosclerosis, cardiovascular disease, and stroke. A systematic review. Annals of Periodontology. 2003; 8(1): 38-53.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Associations between periodontal disease and risk for nosocomial bacterial pneumonia and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. A systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,PERIODONTOLOGY,ASSOCIATED CONDITIONS]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Oral colonization by respiratory pathogens, fostered by poor oral hygiene and periodontal diseases, appears to be associated with nosocomial pneumonia. Additional large-scale randomised controlled trials are warranted to provide the medical community with further evidence to institute effective oral hygiene procedures in high-risk patients to prevent nosocomial pneumonia.

Methods: A systematic review examining whether periodontal diseases or other indicators of poor oral health influence the initiation/progression of pneumonia or other lung diseases. 9 randomised controlled trials (study population 1,759) and 11 case-control and cohort studies (study population 1,413). Study populations included patients with any form of pneumonia or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and periodontal disease. Literature search 1966 to March 2002.

Quality of Review:  The search strategy was limited and it is likely that relevant studies were missed.  Only Medline and the Cochrane Clinical Trials Register were searched using narrow search terms.  The authors do not report any additional searching or whether non-English language papers were included so it is possible that publication and language biases were introduced.  Two reviewers independently selected the studies according to agreed inclusion criteria and extracted data.  Although included studies were graded, it is unclear whether the quality of included studies was appraised or whether only randomised controlled trials were included.  

Results: A variety of oral interventions improving oral hygiene through mechanical and/or topical chemical disinfection or antibiotics reduced the incidence of nosocomial pneumonia by an average of 40%.

Several studies demonstrated a potential association between periodontal disease and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

Citation: Scannapieco FA, Bush RB, Paju S. Associations between periodontal disease and risk for nosocomial bacterial pneumonia and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. A systematic review. Annals of Periodontology. 2003; 8(1): 54-69.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Bahind the headlines - Clean teeth 'reduce heart risk'
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,DENTAL PUBLIC HEALTH]]>
document.body:
Brushing your teeth twice a day could save you from a heart attack”, the Daily Mail has reported.

Its story is based on a study from Scotland, which looked at the potential association between how often people brushed their teeth and their risk of cardiovascular disease. It found that people who never or rarely brushed their teeth were 70% more likely to get cardiovascular disease than those who brushed their teeth twice a day. People with poor oral hygiene also had higher blood levels of specific chemical marker of inflammation, which is thought to increase the risk of developing heart disease.

What does NHS Choices make of this study?

This type of research cannot prove that poor oral hygiene causes cardiovascular disease as it may simply be that people who follow a healthy lifestyle also brush their teeth more. Equally, the results of this analysis were adjusted to account for this likelihood. The study is in line with other research suggesting a link between periodontal (gum) disease, inflammation and cardiovascular disease. Overall, this study does suggest that brushing may reduce the risk of cardiovascular disease in addition to the clear benefits of preventing tooth decay and keeping gums healthy.

See the entire NHS Choices commentary on this news item.

 

Citation of original study

de Oliveira C, Watt R, Hamer M. Toothbrushing, inflammation, and risk of cardiovascular disease: results from Scottish Health Survey. BMJ 2010;340:c2451

 

'Behind the headlines' provides an unbiased and evidence-based analysis of health stories that make the news. The service is intended for both the public and health professionals and endeavours to:

  • explain the facts behind the headlines and give a better understanding of the science that makes the news
  • provide an authoritative resource for GPs which they can rely on when talking to patients
  • and become a trusted resource for journalists and others involved in the dissemination of health news
]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Behind the Headlines - Red wine and tooth decay
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,DENTAL CARIES,CAUSES & PREVENTION]]>
document.description: "Red wine can care for our teeth, the Daily Express reported. The newspaper says that "a daily glass could help keep teeth healthy and reduce the need for fillings.
document.body:
“Red wine can care for our teeth”, the Daily Express reported. The newspaper says that “a daily glass could help keep teeth healthy and reduce the need for fillings.”

This news report is based on a laboratory study investigating the effects that red wine (stripped of its alcohol) had on one type of bacteria that causes tooth decay. The results suggest that chemicals in red wine can stop bacteria sticking to extracted teeth in a petri dish, but this does not necessarily mean that drinking red wine will reduce the risk of cavities. It is possible that other components in the wine, such as sugars and acids, could counteract the effects, or that the wine does not remain in the mouth long enough.

 

What does NHS Choices make of this study?

Although this study can illustrate the effects of de-alcoholised red wine in the laboratory, laboratory conditions may not accurately reflect what really happens in the mouth. Therefore, this study does not necessarily prove that drinking red wine prevents tooth decay.

See the entire NHS Choices commentary  on this news item.

 

Citation of original study

Daglia M, Stauder M, Papetti A, et al. Isolation of red wine components with anti-adhesion and anti-biofilm activity against Streptococcus mutans.
Food Chemistry 2009; 119: 1182-1188

 

'Behind the headlines' provides an unbiased and evidence-based analysis of health stories that make the news. The service is intended for both the public and health professionals and endeavours to:

  • explain the facts behind the headlines and give a better understanding of the science that makes the news
  • provide an authoritative resource for GPs which they can rely on when talking to patients
  • and become a trusted resource for journalists and others involved in the dissemination of health news
]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Behind the Headlines - Rise in mouth cancer linked to STIs
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,ORAL CANCER,RISK FACTORS,HUMAN PAPILLOMAVIRUS]]>
document.body:
The Daily Telegraph reported that a “rise in mouth cancer may be due to sexually transmitted infection”. The newspaper said that there has been a 50% increase in the number of mouth cancers in the last 20 years, and the increase appears to be in those cases related to the human papilloma virus (HPV).

The story is based on an editorial in the British Medical Journal by cancer specialists, which highlighted an increase in the numbers of a specific type of throat cancer in the UK. The specialists also discussed studies from other countries that show an increase in the proportion of HPV-related throat cancers.

The editorial reported on a very small number of studies, but it shows that there may be a need to investigate the incidence of HPV-related throat cancers in the UK, to track these cases and to see if HPV-related cancers should be treated differently to non-HPV-related throat cancers. There is insufficient evidence at the moment to suggest that the HPV vaccination, currently available for teenage girls, should also be given to boys.

What does NHS Choices make of this study?

The authors have highlighted the increasing incidence of oropharyngeal cancers in men in the UK. They have associated this with an increase in the proportion of HPV-related cancers based on studies in Sweden and the US.

Further research is needed to assess whether the increase in oropharyngeal cancers in British men reflects an increase in HPV-related or non-HPV-related cancers. As HPV-related and non-HPV-related throat cancers have a different prognosis for survival, further research may look at whether different treatments can have different effects on these two throat cancer subtypes.

There is insufficient evidence at present to suggest that the HPV vaccination currently given to teenage girls should also be given to boys.


 

See the entire NHS Choices commentary on this news item.

Citation of original study

Mehanna H, Jones TM, Gregoire V, Ang KK. Oropharyngeal carcinoma related to human papillomavirus. British Medical Journal 2010

'Behind the headlines' provides an unbiased and evidence-based analysis of health stories that make the news. The service is intended for both the public and health professionals and endeavours to:

  • explain the facts behind the headlines and give a better understanding of the science that makes the news
  • provide an authoritative resource for GPs which they can rely on when talking to patients
  • and become a trusted resource for journalists and others involved in the dissemination of health news

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Behind the headlines: Acupuncture 'eases dentist fear'
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,DENTAL ANXIETY]]>
document.description: Acupuncture can help cure patients of a fear of the dentist's drill,” according to The Daily Telegraph.
document.body:
“Acupuncture can help cure patients of a fear of the dentist's drill,” according to The Daily Telegraph. It says that research shows that just one five-minute session of acupuncture can reduce anxiety and enable people who have previously avoided the dentist to have treatment.

This study looked at 20 people whose fear of the dentist had previously hampered or prevented the completion of their dental treatment. It found that their pretreatment level of anxiety reduced after acupuncture and they were all able to receive their dental treatment. However, this study did not compare people receiving acupuncture with people receiving no anxiety treatment. This means we cannot rule out the possibility that their fear naturally reduced over time. Also, the dental procedures performed in this study were minor (cleaning or examination), and this study cannot tell us whether acupuncture would provide anxiety relief for major procedures such as drilling.

What does NHS Choices make of this study?

NHS Choices highlights a number of points to note when interpreting this study including

  • the lack of a control group
  • small number recruited from those who agreed to accupuncture
  • individuals in the study only received minor dental procedures
  • there was no comparison with other approaches to reducing fear
  • the study was unblinded

They conclude: "Overall, the study suggests that using a brief acupuncture session for reducing anxiety in people afraid of the dentist could be worth further investigation, but larger, blinded, randomised controlled studies will be needed to confirm its effects."

See the entire NHS Choices commentary on this news item.

Citation of original study

Rosted P, Bundgaard M, Gordon S, Lynge Pedersen AM. Acupuncture in the management of anxiety related to dental treatment: a case series. Acupuncture in Medicine 2010;28:3-5 [Abstract]

'Behind the headlines' provides an unbiased and evidence-based analysis of health stories that make the news. The service is intended for both the public and health professionals and endeavours to:

  • explain the facts behind the headlines and give a better understanding of the science that makes the news
  • provide an authoritative resource for GPs which they can rely on when talking to patients
  • and become a trusted resource for journalists and others involved in the dissemination of health news

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Biofeedback, acupuncture and transcutaneous electric nerve stimulation in the management of temperomandibular disorders: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,ORO-FACIAL PAIN]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: An analysis of the degree of evidence of the results revealed no evidence for the efficacy of biofeedback, acupuncture or transcutaneous electric nerve stimulation in the management of temporomandibular disorders.

Methods: Systematic review of 7 controlled clinical trials to assess the efficacy of biofeedback, acupuncture and transcutaneous electric nerve stimulation in the management of temporomandibular disorders. Literature search to May 2002.

Quality of Review: Generally a well conducted systematic review. Several databases were searched and reference lists of included papers checked for further relevant papers.  However, the search was restricted to English language studies and unpublished research was not sought.  Consequently relevant papers may have been missed and language and publication biases introduced. The validity of the included studies was assessed using a pre-defined criteria list. 

Results: Seven controlled clinical trials met the criteria for inclusion. The patients included in the studies ranged from 19–100. Three studies assessed the efficacy of biofeedback, three studies assessed the efficacy of acupuncture and one study assessed the efficacy of transcutaneous electric nerve stimulation. All the studies were of low quality with contradicotry outcomes. 

Citation: Jedel E, Carlsson J. Biofeedback, acupuncture and transcutaneous electric nerve stimulation in the management of temperomandibular disorders: a systematic review. Physical Therapy Reviews. 2003; 8(4): 217-223

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Biomarkers in dysplasia of the oral cavity: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,ORAL CANCER,RISK FACTORS]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors’ conclusions: Many methodological limitations have been identified by this review and we recommend the results are interpreted with caution. Research into this field should concentrate on longitudinal design, with pooling of data from multiple centres to achieve larger cohorts. We recommend standardisation of definitions to allow appropriate comparisons to be made.

Methods: A systematic review and meta-analysis of 13 observational studies to examine the evidence for the effectiveness of biomarkers and genetic abnormalities in predicting progression to cancer in patients with oral dysplasia. Database search dates: inception to November 2007.

Quality of review: Overall a well-conducted systematic review. As the authors indicate, their conclusions should be interpreted with caution, given the methodological limitations of included studies.

The authors made a reasonable attempt to identify available literature, searching a wide range of electronic databases (Cochrane Library, Embase, Medline, AMED, CINAHL and Kings Fund), albeit with limited search terms. They also conducted an internet search, checked reference lists and contacted experts. However, as they concede, restricting inclusion to published English language studies may have introduced bias.

Appropriate methods were used to minimise error and bias in study selection, quality assessment and data extraction. The quality of included studies was assessed using the Newcastle-Ottowa Scale – a validated checklist for observational studies. The authors highlight the limited quality of included studies – generally small scale, single centre, retrospective observational studies.

Results: The evidence consists mainly of small, single centre, retrospective studies. In oral dysplasia, loss of heterozygosity (LOH), particularly at the 3p ± 9p loci, increases the risk of progression to cancer (RR 17.60 (2.77, 108.37) p < 0.001), as does survivin (RR 30 (4.25, 197.73), p  0.001), matrix metalloproteinase (MMP 9), (RR 19.00 (1.56, 209.38) p = 0.02) and DNA content (RR 12.00 (1.17, 82.10) p = 0.03). Other markers identified by this review including p53, p73, MMP 1 and 2 and cathepsin L mRNA, did not predict progression. LOH, survivin, MMP 9 and DNA content are potential markers for increased risk of progression from oral dysplasia to cancer

Citation: Smith J, Rattay T, McConkey C, Helliwell T, Mehanna H, Smith J, et al. Biomarkers in dysplasia of the oral cavity: a systematic review. Oral Oncology 2009;45(8):647-53.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Bisphosphonate associated osteonecrosis of the jaw
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORAL SURGERY,SPECIAL CARE DENTISTRY,CANCER PATIENTS]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Currently, there is insufficient evidence to confirm a causal link between low-dose BP use in the osteoporosis patient population and ONJ. We concluded BP associated ONJ is associated with high-dose BP therapy primarily in the oncology patient population. Prevention and treatment strategies are currently based on expert opinion and focus on maintaining good oral hygiene and conservative surgical intervention.

Methods: A narrative systematic review of 92 studies of the incidence, risk factors, diagnosis, prevention and treatment of BP associated ONJ.  [34 reviews, 18 case series, 16 case reports, 10 editorials, 2 prospective observational studies, 2 surveys, 8 comments and letters to editorial and 2 clinical guidelines were included.] Database search dates from inception to January 2008.

Quality of review: The authors appear to have made a good attempt to identify published and unpublished studies, although only English language studies were included, which may have introduced bias. Appropriate methods were used to minimise error and bias in selecting and data extracting included studies. However, the review is it is limited by the quality of the available data and by unclear reporting of the results of included studies. The latter may have resulted from the very broad scope of the review and its inclusion criteria. For example, reviews were also included which may have resulted in the duplication of results. This does not appear to have been addressed by the authors.

The authors appropriately conclude that there is insufficient evidence to confirm a causal link for low-dose BP, but do confirm an association with high-dose BP therapy in the oncology patient population. This may not be appropriate given the authors’ acknowledgement that the evaluation of risk factors for ONJ in the studies identified is limited to descriptive analyses and the absolute and relative importance of the risk factors in bisphosphonate associated ONJ remains unknown. 

No formal method of assessing the validity included studies is reported, although the results are considered in light of the quality of the evidence.

Results:  The results showed that the diagnosis is made clinically. Prospective data evaluating incidence and etiologic factors are very limited. In oncology patients receiving high-dose intravenous BP, ONJ appears to be dependent on the dose and duration of therapy, with an estimated incidence of 1%-12% at 36 months of exposure. In osteoporosis patients, it is rate, with an estimated incidence <1 case per 100,000 person years of exposure. The incidence of ONJ in the general population is not known.

Citation: Khan AA, Sándor GK, Dore E, et al. Bisphosphonate associated osteonecrosis of the jaw. Journal of Rheumatology. 2009;36(3):478-90.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Bisphosphonates and jaw osteonecrosis
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORAL DISORDERS,DENTO-FACIAL ANOMALIES,ORAL SURGERY,SPECIAL CARE DENTISTRY,OLDER PEOPLE,CANCER PATIENTS,OSTEONECROSIS OF THE JAW]]>
document.body:
111-1Bisphosphonates and jaw osteonecrosis

The July 2006 issue of Bandolier includes a discussion of the evidence for bisphosphonate-induced osteonecrosis of the jaw. The discussion centres on a systematic review published in the Annals of Internal Medicine.

 

It concludes:

The bulk of the reported cases are in patients being treated for cancer, where bisphosphonates reduce bone pain, and significantly reduce bone problems. There are clear risk factors, and newer guidance places great emphasis on oral examinations before starting treatment with bisphosphonates in cancer patients, and maintaining good oral health.

Cancer patients receive high doses of bisphosphonates intravenously. Osteoporosis patients receive much lower doses orally. Here the risk is much lower...

...Given the millions of people taking oral bisphosphonates, the risk is negligible. Maintaining good oral health in older people still makes sense, as does exchange of information on drugs by dentists and patients.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Bisphosphonates and osteonecrosis of the jaw
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL SURGERY,DENTO-FACIAL ANOMALIES,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORAL HEALTH,CANCER PATIENTS,OSTEONECROSIS OF THE JAW,OLDER PEOPLE,SPECIAL CARE DENTISTRY]]>
document.body:
111-1Bisphosphonates and osteonecrosis of the jaw

back to contents

 

Definition: bisphosphonate-associated osteonecrosis of the jaw: an area of exposed bone in the maxillofacial region that did not heal with 8 weeks after identification by a healthcare provider, in a patient who was receiving or had been exposed to a bisphosphonate and had not had radiation therapy to the craniofacial region. (American Society for Bone and Mineral Research)

 
 30 September 2009: The European Medicines Agency has completed a review on the risk of osteonecrosis of the jaw associated with the use of bisphosphonates. The Agency’s Committee for Medicinal Products for Human Use (CHMP) concluded that there is an increased risk of osteonecrosis of the jaw in patients using these medicines. [More]

 

The following guidelines and systematic reviews have been identified through a systematic search of the literature as the best available evidence-based resources on the topic of bisphosphonates and osteonecrosis of the jaw. Guidelines are identified in association with the National Library for Guidelines and meet their inclusion criteria. The systematic reviews listed below have been critically appraised in accordance with our Quality Policy.

 

The reference materials and patient information included have been developed by government agencies, medical associations and charities. 

 

Guidelines

Canadian consensus practice guidelines for bisphosphonate associated osteonerosis of the jaw: Canadian Association of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgeons. (2008) [view]

Bisphosphonate-associated osteonecrosis of the jaw: report of a task force of the American Society for Bone and Mineral Research. (2007) [view]

American Society of Clinical Oncology clinical practice guideline update on the role of bisphosphonates in multiple myeloma (2007) [view]

Cancer Care Ontario: The role of bisphosphonates in the management of skeletal complications for patients with multiple myeloma: a clinical practice guideline (2007) [view]

Mayo Clinic consensus statement for the use of bisphosphonates in multiple myeloma (2006) [view]

 

Systematic reviews

Osteonecrosis of the jaw and use of bisphosphonates in adjuvant breast cancer treatment: a meta-analysis (2009) [view]

Bisphosphonate associated osteonecrosis of the jaw (2009) [view]

What impact do systemically administrated bisphosphonates have on oral implant therapy? A systematic review (2009)  [view]

A review of the literature on osteonecrosis of the jaw in patients with osteoporosis treated with oral bisphosphonates: prevalence, risk factors, and clinical characteristics (2007) [view]

Narrative [corrected] review: bisphosphonates and osteonecrosis of the jaws (2006) [view]

Bisphosphonates and osteonecrosis of the jaw: cause and effect or a post hoc fallacy? (2006) [view]

 

Reference material:

MHRA:

  • Bisphosphonates and osteonecrosis of the jaw (2007) [view]
  • Osteonecrosis of the jaw with bisphosphonates (2006) [view]

FDA: Osteonecrosis of the jaw: important drug precaution (2005) [view]

Bandolier: Bisphosphonates and jaw necrosis (2006) [view]

 

Patient information

Cancer Research UK: About bisphosphonates and jaw problems [view]

American Dental Association:

  • Bisphosphonate medications and your oral health [view]
  • Osteoporosis medications and the risk of developing jaw complications [view]

American Academy of Oral Medicine: Bisphosphonate therapy and the oral cavity [view]

British Osteoporosis Foundation: Osteonecrosis of the Jaw (ONJ) [view]

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Bisphosphonates and osteonecrosis of the jaw: cause and effect or a post hoc fallacy?
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,DENTO-FACIAL ANOMALIES,ORAL SURGERY,SPECIAL CARE DENTISTRY,CANCER PATIENTS,OLDER PEOPLE,OSTEONECROSIS OF THE JAW]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Although not enough evidence is available to prove a causal link between bisphosphonates (BPs) and osteonecrosis of the jaw (ONJ), it seems that under specific circumstances local defences can become overwhelmed resulting in ONJ.

Methods: A systematic review of 22 retrospective studies (225 patients) to review the evidence for arelationship between use of bisphosphonates and the development of osteonecrosis of the jaw and to explore potential mechanisms of action based on the known effects of a particular BP. Literature search to July 2005.

Quality of review: The review is limited by the poor quality and level of evidence available. Furthermore, Several databases were searched along with key websites, conference proceedings and reference lists of included papers. However, there is no information on the number of citations identified, which languages were considered and whether unpublished research was included. No formal method of assessing the validity of included studies is reported, however some aspects of quality are discussed in the review section. Note: the prevalence estimate reported in the abstract is based on one study (in multiple myeloma patients) that reported this information.

Results: The prevalence of ONJ was estimated at 1.5%. The involved BPs were pamidronate, zoledronic acid, alendronate and risedronate, all potent
nitrogen-containing agents. The most common symptom was pain (81.7%), although 12.2% of cases were asymptomatic. In 69.3% of patients ONJ was preceded by a dental extraction. At the time of diagnosis, 74.5% of patients were receiving chemotherapy and in 38.2% of cases corticosteroids were administered. Although various conservative and surgical treatment modalities were reported, residual sites of ONJ persisted in 72.5% of cases.

Citation: Van den Wyngaert T, Huizing MT, Vermorken JB. Bisphosphonates and osteonecrosis of the jaw: cause and effect or a post hoc fallacy? Annals of Oncology 2006; 17(8): 1197-204.

Access: Full-text online access to this article is freely available.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Bone augmentation procedures in implant dentistry
document.publisher: International Journal of Oral and Maxillofacial Implants
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORAL SURGERY,RESTORATIVE DENTISTRY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: A wide range of surgical procedures were identified. However, it was difficult to demonstrate that one surgical procedure offered better outcomes than another. Moreover, it is not yet known if some surgical procedures, eg, reconstruction of atrophic edentulous mandibles with onlay autogenous bone grafts or maxillary sinus grafting procedures in case of limited/moderate sinus pneumatization, improve long-term implant survival. Every surgical procedure presents advantages and disadvantages. Priority should be given to those procedures which are simpler and less invasive, involve less risk of complications, and reach their goals within the shortest time frame. The main limit encountered in this literature review was the overall poor methodological quality of the published articles. Larger well-designed long-term trials are needed.

Methods: A narrative systematic review of four studies (1 prospective, 3 retrospective) to evaluate (1) the success of different surgical techniques for the reconstruction of edentulous deficient alveolar ridges and (2) the survival/success rates of implants placed in the augmented areas. Database search dates: 1975 to January 2008.

Quality of review: As the authors note, the conclusions are limited by the results of the included studies, the vast majority of which were retrospective. It is possible that potentially relevant studies were missed as only Medline was searched, supplemented by reference list checking and hand-searching key journals. The search was further restricted to published studies in English which may have introduced additional bias. The methods used to select and data extract studies is unclear and the introduction of error and bias cannot be excluded. Although the authors do not appear to have conducted a formal appraisal of included studies, they comment on the poor quality of included studies throughout the review.

Citation: Chiapasco M, Casentini P, Zaniboni M. Bone augmentation procedures in implant dentistry. International Journal of Oral and Maxillofacial Implants 2009;24 Suppl:237-59. 

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Botulinum toxin in the management of sialorrhoea: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,ENT AND AUDIOLOGY,SALIVARY GLAND DISORDERS,SIALORRHOEA,CONDITIONS,THERAPEUTIC INTERVENTIONS,NON-DRUG TREATMENTS,OTHER]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors’ conclusions: Minor side effects were reported in one of the RCTs but overall botulinum toxin (BTX) appears to be a safe, minimally invasive and effective means in the treatment of sialorrhoea (drooling) with the potential to become the treatment of choice. However, further randomised controlled trials are required to more fully evaluate this new modality of treatment.

Methods: A systematic review of six studies (including two RCTs) to identify the evidence for the use of BTX in the treatment of drooling. Literature search January 1997 to December 2005.

Quality of review: The results of this review should be viewed with caution. The review is poorly reported and the search was unlikely to identify all relevant papers. Whilst three databases were searched, it does not appear that reference lists were checked, journals handsearched or experts contacted. The authors state that they restricted the search to published papers in the English language, which may have introduced publication and language biases.

Only limited information is provided on inclusion criteria, which do not define the population of interest or outcome measures. The number of studies identified and excluded are not reported. No formal method of assessing the validity of included papers is reported, although the quality of the research is discussed.

Results: Two RCTs demonstrated the effectiveness of BTX in the management of sialorrhoea. There was no clear evidence for one antigenic type of botulinum toxin over another and minimal evidence for the optimal dose of botulinum toxin for each antigenic type. No advantage was conferred in using ultrasound guidance in injecting the glands. Neither of the RCTs nor any of the other four controlled studies identified directly compared submandibular versus parotid injection or directly compared botulinum toxin against surgery. 

Citation: Lim M, Mace A, Reza Nouraei SA, Sandhu G.  Botulinum toxin in the management of sialorrhoea: a systematic review. Clinical Otolaryngology 2006; 31(4): 267–272.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Can subepithelial connective tissue grafts be considered the gold standard procedure in the treatment of Miller Class I and II recession-type defects?
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,PERIODONTOLOGY,RESTORATIVE DENTISTRY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors’ conclusions:

  • The results of this systematic review show that subepithelial connective tissue grafts provide significant root coverage, clinical attachment and keratinized tissue gain. Overall comparisons allow us to consider it as the ‘gold standard’ procedure in the treatment of recession-type defects. However, further comparisons between SCTG and CAF are necessary to confirm this condition.
  • All other tested procedures produced favourable improvements in gingival recession, clinical attachment level and width of keratinized tissues, as well.
  • There was a marked variation in the percentages of mean root coverage and complete root coverage between studies and procedures. Overall, SCTG showed the best results.
  • There are few data regarding patient evaluation outcomes such as changes in aesthetic condition, preference to a specific procedure and discomfort levels.
  • Improvements in clinical outcomes by means of creeping attachment or root conditioning agents were not evident.
  • There are few data from randomized controlled trials with > 12 months’ follow-up.

Methods: A narrative systematic review of 23 RCTs to determine whether subepithelial connective tissue grafts (SCTG) can be considered the gold standard procedure in the treatment of recession-type defects? Literature search to December 2007.

Quality of review: Overall a good quality systematic review. The authors searched a range of databases using adequate search terms and supplemented this with hand searching several journals. However, it is possible that studies were missed as the authors restricted their search to published studies in the English language. Appropriate procedures were used to minimise error and bias in study selection, data extraction and quality assessment. The authors used Cochrane methods to assess validity (randomisation, adequate allocation concealment; outcome assessors blinded to treatment outcome and completeness of follow-up).

Citation: Chambrone L, Chambrone D, Pustiglioni FE, Chambrone LA, Lima LA. Can subepithelial connective tissue grafts be considered the gold standard procedure in the treatment of Miller Class I and II recession-type defects? Journal of Dentistry, 2008; 36 (9): 659-671

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Caries prevalence in children with cleft lip and palate--a systematic review of of case-control studies
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,DENTAL CARIES,DENTO-FACIAL ANOMALIES,PREVALENCE]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: This systematic review of literature was unable to find firm evidence for the assumption that cleft lip and palate (CLP) children have an increased prevalence of dental caries.

Methods: A systematic review of 6 cross-sectional case control studies to examine the evidence of an increased prevalence dental caries in children with CLP. Literature search to May 2006. 

Quality of review: Whilst the authors employed sound methods for selecting, data extracting and quality appraising studies, the search strategy was unlikely to find all key papers. Only one database (PubMed) was searched, there was no reference list checking, handsearching or use of grey literature sources, and experts were not contacted. Furthermore, unpublished research was not sought which may have introduced publication bias.

Results: Significantly more caries in CLP children were reported in two of the four studies in the permanent dentition and in three out of four publications dealing with primary teeth. None of the articles were, however, assessed with the highest grade 'A' and the level of evidence was therefore based on three papers graded 'B'. There was a tendency
towards higher caries scores in preschool children, but as conflicting results were revealed, the evidence that children with CLP exhibit more caries than noncleft controls was inconclusive.

Citation: Hasslöf P, Twetman S. Caries prevalence in children with cleft lip and palate--a systematic review of case-control studies. International Journal of Paediatric Dentistry. 2007; 17(5): 313-9.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Caries preventive effect of casein phosphopeptide-amorphous calcium phosphate (CPP-ACP): a meta-analysis
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,DENTAL CARIES,CAUSES & PREVENTION]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Within the limitations of this review, the results of the clinical in situ trials indicate a short-term remineralization effect of casein phosphopeptide-amorphous calcium phosphate (CPP-ACP).Additionally, the promising in vivo RCT results suggest a caries-preventing effect for long-term clinical CPP-ACP use. Further randomized control trials are needed in order to confirm these initial results in vivo.

Methods: A systematic review and metanalysis of 11 RCTs and 1 systematic review to determine whether the introduction of CPP-ACP into the oral environment provides any caries-preventive benefit superior to that of comparator or placebo. [5 in situ RCTs contributed to the meta-analysis]. Database search dates: inception to 31 August 2008.

Quality of review: The results of this review should be considered with caution for a number of reasons. 8 of the 11 included randomised trials were conducted by scientists who hold the patent for this product. In addition, the authors conducted a sub-group analysis of five studies despite tests confirming the presence of considerable heterogeneity (p<0.00001). All five meta-analysed studies were conducted in situ and the results may not be an accurate reflection of effectiveness in the general population.

It is possible that the authors did not identify all relevant studies. Whilst they searched several electronic sources, the choices of database were unconventional, the search terms were restrictive and inclusion was limited to published papers in the English language. Appropriate methods were used to minimise the introduction of error and bias in the selection, quality assessment and data extraction of included papers. The authors considered risk of bias in the included papers by assessing randomisation, allocation concealment, blinded outcome assessment and completeness of follow-up.

Results: Five in situ randomized control trials (RCT) could be pooled for meta-analyses. During the short-term (7-21 days) in situ trials, participants wore appliances containing enamel slabs that were analyzed in the laboratory after exposure to CPP-ACP. The pooled in situ results showed a weighted mean difference (WMD) of the percentage remineralization scores in favor of chewing gum with 18.8 mg CPP-ACP as compared to chewing gum without CPP-ACP (WMD -8.01; 95% CI: -10.54 to -5.48; p = 0.00001), as well as compared to no intervention (WMD -13.56; 95% CI: -16.49 to -10.62; p = 0.00001). A significant higher remineralization effect was also observed after exposure to 10.0 mg CPP-ACP (-7.75; 95% CI: -9.84 to -5.66; p = 0.00001). One long-term in vivo RCT (24 months) with a large sample size (n = 2720) found that the odds of a tooth surface's progressing to caries was 18% less in subjects who chewed sugar-free gum containing 54 mg CPP-ACP than in control subjects who chewed gum without CPP-ACP (p = 0.03).

Citation: Yengopal V, Mickenautsch S. Caries preventive effect of casein phosphopeptide-amorphous calcium phosphate (CPP-ACP): a meta-analysis. Acta Odontologica Scandinavica 2009; 67(6): 321-332.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Caries-preventive effect of fissure sealants: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,DENTAL CARIES,DENTAL PUBLIC HEALTH,CAUSES & PREVENTION]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors conclusions: The review suggests limited evidence that fissure sealing of 1st permanent molars with resin-based materials has a caries-preventive effect. The evidence is incomplete for permanent 2nd molars, premolars and primary molars and for glass ionomer cements. Overall, there remains a need for further trials of high quality, particularly in child populations with a low and a high caries risk, respectively.

Methods: Systematic review of 13 studies (1 randomised and 12 controlled clinical trials) using resin-based or glass ionomer sealant materials. Literature search

Quality of review:  A reasonable attempt was made to identify the literature: several databases were searched, reference lists of included studies checked and experts contacted.  Studies in a range of languages were included, although unpublished trials were excluded. Two reviewers independently assessed for relevance and quality using the data extraction form. There was significant heterogeneity (p<0.001) between the studies included in the meta-analysis for overall risk reduction.  The review was also limited by the poor quality of the included trials.

Results: The results showed that most studies were performed during the 1970s and a single application had been utilized. The relative caries risk reduction pooled estimate of resin-based sealants on permanent 1st molars was 33% (relative risk = 0.67; CI = 0.55-0.83). The effect depended on retention of the sealant.

Citation: Mejare I, Lingstrom P, Petersson LG, et al. Caries-preventive effect of fissure sealants: a systematic review. Acta Odontologica Scandinavica. 2003; 61(6): 321-330.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Caries-preventive effect of glass ionomer and resin-based fissure sealants on permanent teeth: a meta analysis
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,DENTAL CARIES,CAUSES & PREVENTION]]>
document.body:
This is a provisional record for information. The review has been identified as potentially meeting our quality criteria. It will be critically appraised and a quality statement provided as soon as possible.
_____________________________________________________

 

Authors' conclusions: This systematic review with meta-analysis found no evidence that either material was superior to the other in the prevention of dental caries. Thus, both materials appear equally suitable for clinical application as a fissure sealant material

Methods: A systematic review of 8 RCTs and 3 systematic reviews with meta-analysis of 6 studies to review the relative efficacy of glass ionomer cement (GIC) vs resin-based fissure sealants in caries prevention. Database search to January 2008.

Results: The pooled odds ratio for the six studies was 0.96, 95% CI 0.62-1.49, indicating no difference in the caries-preventive effect of GIC and resin-based fissure sealant material.

Citation: Yengopal V, Mickenautsch S, Bezerra AC, Leal SC. Caries-preventive effect of glass ionomer and resin-based fissure sealants on permanent teeth: a meta analysis. Journal of Oral Science 2009; 51(3):373-82.

Access: Full text of this review is freely available.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Caries-preventive effect of resin-based and glass ionomer sealants over time: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,DENTAL CARIES,CAUSES & PREVENTION]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: There is no evidence that either resin-based or glass ionomer sealant material is superior to the other in preventing dentine lesion deveopment in pits and fissures over time.

Methods: A PubMed/Medline literature review supplemented by papers identified in an earlier Cochrane review of the effects of two types of sealant material.

Quality of review: This review should be viewed with caution, as methodological flaws may have introduced bias and led to key papers being missed. It is likely that the search strategy missed key papers. Only Medline and PubMed were searched and reference lists checked. Whilst eligible papers were also identified from an earlier Cochrane review (which used a more exhaustive search strategy) the searches were conducted in 2002 predating this review’s search date by two years. Contacting experts, searching additional databases and websites and hand-searching may have identified further papers. Moreover, only published papers in the English language were included which may have introduced publication and language biases. Although selection bias was minimised by two authors independently selecting papers in duplicate, the quality of included studies does not appear to have been considered thoroughly. Only limited quality inclusion criteria were set to select randomised studies with at least one year follow-up. No formal methods of reporting the validity of the studies is reported, and the quality of individual studies is not discussed.

Results: There was no consistent pattern observed with respect to the caries-preventive effect of either resin-based or glass ionomer sealants. Therefore, it was impossible to calculate an overall attributable risk.

Citation: Beiruti N, Frencken JE, van 't Hof MA, van Palenstein Helderman WH. Caries-preventive effect of resin-based and glass ionomer sealants over time: a systematic review. Community Dentistry and Oral Epidemiology, 2006; 34(6): 403–409.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Cephalometric facial soft tissue changes with the twin block appliance in Class II division 1 malocclusion patients. A systematic review.
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORTHODONTICS]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Three-dimensional quantification of the soft tissue changes is required to overcome current limitations in our understanding of the soft tissue changes obtained after the use of the twin block appliance in Class II division 1 malocclusion patients.

Methods: A systematic review of two randomised controlled trials to evaluate facial soft tissuer changes after the use of the twin block appliance in Class II division 1 malocclusion patients. Literature search to October 2005. 

Quality of review: The review is limited by the lack of available controlled studies in this area. Whilst a number of databases were searched, further papers could potentially have been identified using a wider range of search terms, handsearching journals, contacting experts, and seeking unpublished research through grey literature sources.

Results: Two articles fulfilled the selection criteria and quantified facial soft tissue changes. Although some statistically significant changes in the soft tissue profile were found, the magnitude of the changes may not be perceived as clinically significant. Changes produced in the upper lip seem to be controversial, although the study with sounder methodological quality did not report significant changes. No change in the anteroposterior position of the lower lip and the soft tissue menton or improvement of the facial convexity was found.

Citation: Flores-Mir C, Major PW. Cephalometric facial soft tissue changes with the twin block appliance in Class II division 1 malocclusion patients. A systematic review. Angle Orthodontist 2006 76(5): 876-81.

Access: Available to the general public.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Characteristics of TMD headache: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,DENTO-FACIAL ANOMALIES]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Despite methodological problems such as low subject numbers and poorly documented sampling methods and inclusion criteria, the literature showed that TMD-related headache has identifiable diagnostic characteristics. This information could be used to develop guidelines to assist the identification of headaches which emanate from the temporomandibular structures. Greater scrutiny of the sample to ensure homogeneity of the headache types would assist future research.

Methods: A narrative systematic review of 15 studies (study types unclear) to identify the diagnostic criteria that confirm temporomandibular involvement in headache presentations. Database search 1966 to September 2007.

Quality of review: The authors made a reasonable attempt to find potentially relevant studies. They searched two databases (PubMed and CInahl) using what appears to be a good search strategy and checked the reference lists of included papers. However, studies may have been missed as the search was restricted to published papers in the English language. Searching additional databases, hand searching key journals and contacting experts may have identified additional studies.

The quality of the included studies was assessed using a specially designed checklist which included questions around sample characteristics, recruitment and whether inc/excl criteria were stated.

Results: Temporomandibular-related headache often presents unilaterally, in the pre-auricular region, temple and retro-orbital regions of the head. Other characteristics include tenderness of the masticatory muscle and reduced jaw opening with some mandibular deviation.

Citation: Zito G, Morris ME, Selvaratnam P. Characteristics of TMD headache: a systematic review. Physical Therapy Reviews, 2008; 13 (5): 324-332

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Chewing gum health risk
document.topics: <![CDATA[ DENTAL PUBLIC HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORAL HEALTH]]>
document.body:
111-1Chewing gum health risk

A sweetener used in sugar-free chewing gum, some toothpastes and thousands of other products could be a severe health risk,” the Daily Mail reported on 11 January1. It says that the sweetener, Sorbitol, can trigger severe weight loss, abdominal pain and diarrhoea.

The news article relates to a recent report in the BMJ2 which highlights the cases of two patients who had chronic diarrhoea and suffered severe weight loss (up to a fifth of their body weight), the cause of which was traced back to excessive intake of sorbitol through their use of chewing gum.

A full report and analysis of the evidence is available from the NHS Choices Behind the Headlines service.

 

______________________________________________________

1 Sweetener in chewing gum can damage your health. Daily Mail, January, 11 2008

2 Pirlich M, Bauditz J, Norman K, et al. Severe weight loss caused by chewing gum. BMJ 2008; 336: 96-97

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Chlorhexidine varnish for preventing dental caries in children, adolescents and young adults: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,DENTAL CARIES,DENTAL PUBLIC HEALTH,PAEDIATRIC DENTISTRY,CAUSES & PREVENTION]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: It is tentatively concluded that chlorhexidine (CHX) varnish has a moderate caries-inhibiting effect when applied every 3-4 months. However, this effect seems to have diminished by around 2 years after the last application. There is no evidence for a caries-inhibiting effect of CHX varnish with longer intervals between applications.

Methods: Systematic review to determine the caries-inhibiting effect of CHX varnished on the permanent dentition of children, adolescents and young adults. 10 randomised or quasi-randomised controlled trials were included in which the prevented fraction and 95% confidence intervals could be calculated. Literature search to August 2005.  

Quality of review: The review addressed a clearly focused research question. The search may have missed studies as only English language literature was included and it is unclear whether unpublished studies were sought. Supplementing the database searches and reference list checking with wider search terms website searches, handsearching journals and contacting experts may have identified further papers. No formal method for appraising the validity of included studies was reported, however data on some quality aspects were collected and discussed.

Results: This systematic review did not result in a meta-analysis as an overall prevented fraction could not be computed because of the large variation of outcome results. The variation could not be explained by the time between evaluation and last application but might be explained by application frequency.

Citation: Zhang Q, van Palenstein-Helderman WH, van't Hof MA, Truin G-J. Chlorhexidine varnish for preventing dental caries in children, adolescents and young adults: a systematic review. European Journal of Oral Sciences 2006; 114: 449-455.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Clinical efficacy of casein derivatives: a systematic review of the literature
document.publisher: Journal of the American Dental Association
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,DENTAL CARIES,CAUSES & PREVENTION]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: The quantity and quality of clinical trial evidence are insufficient to make conclusions regarding the long-term effectiveness of casein derivatives, specifically CPP-ACP, in preventing caries in vivo and treating dentin hypersensitivity or dry mouth.

Methods: A systematic review of 12 studies (10 RCTs, 1 uncontrolled and 1 survey) to determine the clinical efficacy of casein derivatives (specifically casein phosphopeptide-amorphous calcium phosphate [CPP-ACP] complex) used in dentistry. Database search dates: inception to 2007.

Quality of review: It is likely that the search methodology missed potentially relevant papers. Whilst the authors searched a wide range of sources, the search strategy used was limited and only English language papers were selected. Using a wider range of terms without language restrictions, hand-searching journals and contacting experts may have identified additional papers. Although the inclusion/exclusion criteria state that only randomised and quasi-randomised studies were to be included, the authors included an uncontrolled cohort study and a follow-up survey.
The quality of the included papers was assessed independently by two reviewers and they identified issues with the data: six of the twelve included studies were conducted using an in situ model by the team who patented the CPP-ACP complex. These all indicated significant positive results for caries prevention. The four independent studies were conducted used a variety of methods and may not be directly comparable. They did not find the same levels of significance.

Results: Nine studies focused on caries prevention, of which seven showed that CPP-ACP (as found in sugar-free pellet or slab chewing gum, lozenges, milk or mouthrinse) was effective in preventing dental caries by remineralizing subsurface carious lesions in situ in a dose-response fashion. One was a clinical trial with conflicting results regarding the effect of CPP-ACP on the regression of white-spot lesions; one was a survey of the relief of dry-mouth symptoms; and one was an uncontrolled clinical study that showed the lack of effectiveness and lack of short-term therapeutic effect in treating dentin hypersensitivity.

Citation: Azarpazhooh A, Limeback H. Clinical efficacy of casein derivatives: a systematic review of the literature. Journal of the American Dental Association 2008; 139(7):915-24.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.
