document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Clinical outcomes of GBR procedures to correct peri-implant dehiscences and fenestrations: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORAL SURGERY,RESTORATIVE DENTISTRY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Despite the favorable results obtained, it was difficult to draw a significant conclusion as far as the more reliable grafting material and membrane barrier for the correction of dehiscence/fenestration defects are concerned, due to the limited sample of patients and the wide variety of grafting materials and membranes, used alone or in combination. Moreover, due to the lack of randomized clinical trials, it was impossible to demonstrate that such augmentation procedures are actually needed to allow the long-term survival of implants.

Methods: A narrative systematic review of seven papers (study types unclear) to analyze the clinical outcomes of endosseous implants following guided bone regeneration (GBR) procedures to correct dehiscence/fenestration defects associated with implant placement. Database search dates: 1986 to 2008 inclusive.

Quality of review: As the authors noted, the poor methodological quality of the included studies limits the conclusions that can be drawn.

It is possible that potentially relevant studies were missed as the authors searched only one database (PubMed) supplemented by reference list checking and hand-searching key journals. The restrictive search terms used and limiting inclusion to published studies in English may have introduced bias. Appropriate methods were used to minimise error and bias in study selection. No information is provided on data extraction methods and it does not appear that the authors formally assessed the quality of included papers; although quality elements are considered.

Results: A total of 238 patients received 374 implants. Defects were treated with resorbable or non-resorbable membranes, in association with or without graft materials. Patients were followed for 1-10 years after the start of prosthetic loading. In the postoperative period, 20% of the non-resorbable membranes and 5% of the resorbable ones underwent exposure/infection. However, in the majority of cases, a complete or an almost complete coverage of the initial defect was obtained. The overall survival rate of implants, irrespective of the type of membrane and grafting materials, was 95.7% (range: 84.7-100%). No significant modifications of probing depth and/or variation of clinical attachment level around implants were observed during the follow-up period.

Citation: Chiapasco M, Zaniboni M. Clinical outcomes of GBR procedures to correct peri-implant dehiscences and fenestrations: a systematic review. Clinical Oral Implants Research. 2009 Sep;20 Suppl 4:113-23.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Clinical outcomes of implants following lateral bone augmentation: systematic assessment of available options (barrier membranes, bone grafts, split osteotomy)
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PERIODONTOLOGY,RESTORATIVE DENTISTRY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Within the limits of the review there was evidence that the evaluated augmentation techniques result in similar implant survival between augmented and pristine sites. The small number of retrieved studies fulfilling the inclusion criteria limited the conclusions regarding the success of the augmentation and its effect on the survival of the implants. Properly designed randomized controlled clinical trials on this topic are needed.

Methods: A narrative systematic review of four prospective longitudinal studies (3 CCTs, 1 cohort) to compare the clinical outcomes related to implants following lateral augmentation procedures (guided bone regeneration (GBR), bone grafts, split osteotomy) with implants placed in pristine sites. Database search to end Novemeber 2007.

Quality of review: As the authors state, the review is limited by the quality of the included studies. Two databases were searched using an adequate search strategy, supplemented by reference list checking. Searching additional databases, hand-searching key journals and contacting experts may have identified additional relevant studies. There were some language restrictions. Appropriate procedures were used to minimise error and bias in study selection, data extraction and quality assessment. Most studies were found to be of high risk of bias.

Results: Three studies compared implants placed with simultaneous GBR or with a bone substitute and one with autogenous bone graft as a staged procedure. The implant survival at the augmented sites irrespective of the procedure used varied from 91.7% to 100% and from 93.2% to 100% at the control sites for a period between 12 and 59.1 months.

Citation: Donos M, Mardas N, Chadha V. Clinical outcomes of implants following lateral bone augmentation: systematic assessment of available options (barrier membranes, bone grafts, split osteotomy). Journal of Clinical Periodontology, 2008; 35 (Suppl. 8): 173-202

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance.  You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Clinical performance of CEREC ceramic inlays: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,DENTAL CARIES,RESTORATIVE DENTISTRY,TREATMENT & MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Machinable ceramics, as used by the CEREC system provide a useful restoration with a high success rate.

Method: A systematic review of 15 studies to identify the clinical performance of intra-coronal CEREC restorations luted with an adhesive composite technique. The focus of the review is to establish the survival rate of these restorations and to identify the factors that may cause them to fail. Literature was sought from 1986 to 1997.

Quality of study: There is very little information provided on the search strategy and quality assessment of the included studies. The authors do not state what and how many databases were searched, whether they included non-English papers, if unpublished research was sought, and how may people appraised the included trials. There is also little information on the designs of the included designs. It is also difficult to determine how the mean survival rate has been determined.

Results: Machinable ceramics are color stable and wear at a clinically acceptable rate. Wear of the luting composite on occlusal surfaces leads to the phenomenon of submargination. Ceramic fracture, wear at the interface and post-operative hypersensitivity remain a problem which require further investigation.

The data available establishes ceramic intra-coronal restorations machined by the CEREC system as a clinically successful restorative method with a mean survival rate of 97.4% over a period of 4.2 years. The review also highlights the reasons and the rates of failure for this type of restoration. The predominant reasons for failures are fracture of the ceramic, fracture of the supporting tooth, postoperative hypersensitivity and wear of the interface lute.

Citation: Martin N, Jednakiewicz NM. Clinical performance of CEREC ceramic inlays: a systematic review. Dental Materials 1999; 15: 54-61.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Combining paracetamol (acetaminophen) with nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs: a qualitative systematic review of analgesic efficacy for acute postoperative pain
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORO-FACIAL PAIN,ORAL SURGERY]]>
document.body:
This is a provisional record for information. The review has been identified as potentially meeting our quality criteria. It will be critically appraised and a quality statement provided as soon as possible.
_____________________________________________________

 

Background: There has been a trend over recent years for combining a nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drug (NSAID) with paracetamol (acetaminophen) for pain management. However, therapeutic superiority of the combination of paracetamol and an NSAID over either drug alone remains controversial. We evaluated the efficacy of the combination of paracetamol and an NSAID versus either drug alone in various acute pain models.

Methods: A systematic literature search of Medline, Embase, Cumulative Index to Nursing and Allied Health Literature, and PubMed covering the period from January 1988 to June 2009 was performed to identify randomized controlled trials in humans that specifically compared combinations of paracetamol with various NSAIDs versus at least 1 of these constituent drugs. Identified studies were stratified into 2 groups: paracetamol/NSAID combinations versus paracetamol or NSAIDs. We analyzed pain intensity scores and supplemental analgesic requirements as primary outcome measures. In addition, each study was graded for quality using a validated scale.

Results: Twenty-one human studies enrolling 1909 patients were analyzed. The NSAIDs used were ibuprofen (n = 6), diclofenac (n = 8), ketoprofen (n = 3), ketorolac (n = 1), aspirin (n = 1), tenoxicam (n = 1), and rofecoxib (n = 1). The combination of paracetamol and NSAID was more effective than paracetamol or NSAID alone in 85% and 64% of relevant studies, respectively. The pain intensity and analgesic supplementation was 35.0% +/- 10.9% and 38.8% +/- 13.1% lesser, respectively, in the positive studies for the combination versus paracetamol group, and 37.7% +/- 26.6% and 31.3% +/- 13.4% lesser, respectively, in the positive studies for the combination versus the NSAID group. No statistical difference in median quality scores was found between experimental groups.

Conclusion: Current evidence suggests that a combination of paracetamol and an NSAID may offer superior analgesia compared with either drug alone 

Citation: Ong CK, Seymour RA, Lirk P, Merry AF. Combining paracetamol (acetaminophen) with nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs: a qualitative systematic review of analgesic efficacy for acute postoperative pain. Anesthesia and  Analgesia 2010; 110(4):1170-1179  

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

 

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Comparative effect of paracetamol, NSAIDs or their combination in postoperative pain management: a qualitative review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORO-FACIAL PAIN,ORAL SURGERY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Paracetamol is a viable alternative to non-special anti inflamatory drugs (NSAIDs), especially because of the low incidence of adverse effects, and should be the preferred choice in high risk patients. It may be appropriate to combine paracetamol with NSAIDs, but future studies are required.

Methods: A systematic review of 41 double-blind randomised controlled trials (including 16 trials on dental postoperative  pain). Main outcome measures were standard pain measures such as visual analogue scales amd objective and behavioural scores. Literature search 1966 to January 2001. 

Quality of review: Key papers may have been missed and publication bias introduced, as only English-language publications were included, and unpublished research was not sought. The methods used to select the studies and extract data were not described.

Results: Non steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) were clearly more effective in dental surgery, whereas the efficacy of NSAIDs and paracetamol seemed without substantial differences in major and orthopaedic surgery; although firm conclusions could not be drawn becouse the number of studies was limited. The addition of an NSAID to paracetamol may confer additional analgesic efficacy compared with paracetamol alone, and the limited data available also suggest that paracetamol may enhance analgesia when added to an NSAID, compared with NSAIDs alone. Future studies are required, especially after major surgery, with specific focus on a potential increase in side-effects from their combined use.

Citation: Hyllestad M,  Jones S, Pedersen JL, Kehlet H. Comparative effect of paracetamol, NSAIDs or their combination in effective pain management: a qualitative review. British Journal of Anaesthesia. 2002; 88(2): 199-214.

Access: The full text of this paper is freely available.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Comparing efficacy and safety of four intravenous sedation regiments in dental outpatients.
document.publisher: Journal of the American Dental Association
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,DENTAL ANXIETY,ORAL SURGERY,IMPACTED THIRD MOLARS,SEDATION]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: The results of this large-scale study provide assurance to both the public and the dental profession of the safety of parenteral sedation with these drugs and combinations of these drugs when titrated slowly in the recommended doses by appropriately trained dentists.

Methods: A multicentre double-blind randomised controlled trial of 997 patients requiring removal of two to four third molars with parenteal sedation. Patients were allocated to receive:

  • midazolam - administed to a clinical endpoint of conscious sedation (mean dose, 8.6 mgs),
  • midazolam plus additional midazolam - as needed suring the procedure (mean total dose 12.2mg).
  • midazolam and fetanyl - 1.4micrograms/kilogram fetanyl plus midazolam to achieve the same endpoint of conscious sedation (mean dose, 5.7mg)
  • midazolam, fetanyl and methohexital - midazolam mean dose 5.8mg and methohexital as needed during the procedure (mean dose 61.0mg).
  • Placebo

Quality of study: This is a large-scale trial conducted at 5 sites in the US, with each site enrolling approximately 200 patients. Both patients and the study investigators were blinded to the intervention. Patients were followed-up over 24 hours, however it is unclear whether all of them completed follow-up.

Results: Each drug regimen reduced anxiety during surgery in comparison with placebo, with the combination of midazolam, fentanyl and methohexital resulting in significantly less anxiety in comparison with the other treatment groups (p<0.05).

Pain reports by patients during surgery also were reduced significantly by the combination of fentanyl, midazolam and methohexital (p<0.05)

Patients global evaluations of the efficacy of sedation ranked midazolam with supplemental midazolam and the combination of fenyl midazolam and methohexital as significantly more efficacious than the other two drug regimens.

The authors noticed respiratory depression in patients in the two opioid-treated groups, but no other physiological changes were detected.

Citation: Dionne RA, Yagiela JA, Moore PA, Gonty A, Zuniga J, Beirne OR. Comparing efficacy and safety of four intravenous sedation regimens in dental  outpatients. Journal of the American Dental Association 2001; 132(6): 740-51.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Comparison of implant survival following sinus floor augmentation procedures with implants placed in pristine posterior maxillary bone: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORAL SURGERY,RESTORATIVE DENTISTRY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Implant survival appears to show greater variability in grafted sinuses than in the posterior maxilla. However, prospective studies with larger patient numbers and control of confounding factors are urgently needed to provide definitive data on this important procedure.

The objective of this study was to systematically review implant survival following sinus augmentation procedures compared with conventional implant placement in the posterior maxilla.

Methods: A systematic review of 5 clinical trials to compare implant survival procedures with conventional implant placement in the posterior maxilla. Literature search to April 2004.

Quality of Review: A good attempt was made identify all relevant papers. Several databases were searched, selected journals were handsearched and reference lists of included papers were checked.  There were no language restrictions, although it is unclear whether unpublished research was sought.  Two reviewers independently screened papers for relevance and reviewed the validity of the included studies.  The review is limited only by the quality of the included data.

Results: Heterogeneity of the selected papers prevented meta-analysis. Implant survival ranged from 73% to 100% for non-augmented sinuses and from 36% to 100% for augmented sinuses in patient-based data. From implant-based data, survival varied between 75% and 100% for both non-augmented and augmented areas.

Citation: Graziani F, Donos N, Needleman I, Gabriele M, Tonetti M. Comparison of implant survival following sinus floor augmentation procedures with implants placed in pristine posterior maxillary bone: a systematic review. Clinical Oral Implants Research, 2004; 15(6): 677-682.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Correlation between socioeconomic indicators and traumatic dental injuries: a qualitative critical literature review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,DENTAL INJURIES,PAEDIATRIC DENTISTRY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors’ conclusions: There is no consensus in the literature regarding the association between the occurrence of traumatic injury in permanent teeth and socioeconomic indicators and the majority of the studies analyzed found no such association. It is suggested that the association between traumatic dental injuries and socioeconomic factors may be related to the indicators used, considering differences in their individual components.

The heterogeneity of the methodologies and the small number of published articles hinders the comparison of the studies. Consequently, it is essential to standardize methodologies for the classification of traumatic dental injuries and socioeconomic indicators in order to achieve a better comparison of results. Socioeconomic indicators with a greater number of individual components need to be developed in order to enable the obtainment of results that are closer to the reality of the population.

Methods: A narrative systematic review of 9 observational studies (8 cross-sectional and 1 cohort) to evaluate the potential correlation between socioeconomic indicators and traumatic dental injury in children.  Database search dates: inception to April 2008.

Quality of review: The results of this review should be viewed with caution. Eight of the nine included studies were cross-sectional; such studies can only indicate a potential association, not a causal link. In addition, a wide range of social indicators were used.

The authors searched a good range of databases without language restrictions, supplemented by reference list checking. However, it is possible that potentially relevant studies were missed as the search terms used were restrictive. Appropriate processes were used to minimise the introduction of error and bias in study selection, quality assessment and data extraction. To be included, studies had to meet a range of quality criteria.

Results: 7 studies were from Brazil and 2 from Thailand. Statistically significant associations between permanent tooth injuries and high economic status were found in four studies.

Citation: Bendo CB, Scarpelli AC, Vale MP, Araújo Zarzar PM. Correlation between socioeconomic indicators and traumatic dental injuries: a qualitative critical literature review. Dental Traumatology 2009 Aug;25(4):420-5.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Corticosteroids reduce postoperative morbidity after third molar surgery: a systematic review and meta-analysis
document.publisher: Journal of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORAL SURGERY,IMPACTED THIRD MOLARS,POSTOPERATIVE PAIN RELIEF]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: The results of this meta-analysis suggest that the perioperative administration of corticosteroids (CS) for patients undergoing third molar (M3) removal has a mild to moderate effect in reducing inflammatory symptoms up to 7 days post-surgery. Specifically, the findings of this study suggest that perioperative administration of CS reduces early and late edema and trismus compared with controls after M3 surgery. Due to the limited number of pain trials, power in that meta-analysis was limited. The lack of an ability to perform proper stratified analyses in this study highlights the need for new prospective large scale investigations to adequately assess the optimal type and dose of CS, as well as the proper time to administer CS for M3 surgery. Furthermore, the different anti-inflammatory effects of CS and NSAIDs in M3 surgery should be further investigated in a large prospective design.

Methods: A systematic review and meta-analysis of 12 studies (11 RCTs and 1 CCT) to determine whether peri-operative corticosteroid administration for patients undergoing third molar removal, decreases postoperative edema, trismus, and pain in the early (1-3 days) and late (>3 days) postoperative periods when compared with saline or similar control. Database search 1966 to February 2007 inclusive.

Quality of review: A well-conducted systematic review limited by the quality of the included studies. The authors searched several databases, supplemented by a range of ‘snowballing’ techniques (reference list checking, e-journal searching, reviewing abstracts and contacting experts in the field); although limiting inclusion to English language studies may have introduced bias. The process used to select included studies is unclear, but appropriate procedures were used to minimise error and bias in data extraction and quality assessment. Although the authors did not score the quality of the included papers, small sample sizes and a lack of information in most regarding methods of randomisation and allocation concealment indicate the overall quality was limited.

Results: Subjects receiving CS had significantly less edema during both early (SMD, 1.4; 95% confidence interval [CI], 0.6, 2.2; P = .001) and late (SMD, 1.1; 95% CI, 0.1, 2.0; P = .03) time periods after surgery and less trismus than controls during the early and late postoperative periods (early WMD, 4.1 mm; 95% CI, 2.8 mm, 5.5 mm; P = .001; late WMD, 2.7 mm; 95% CI, 0.8 mm, 4.6 mm; P   .005). Average pain levels were not significantly different between the 2 groups (early WMD, 0.4 visual analog scale [VAS]; 95% CI, -0.04 VAS, 0.9 VAS; P = .07; late WMD, 0.5 VAS; 95% CI, -0.6 VAS, 1.5 VAS; P=.4)

Citation: Markiewicz R, Brady MF, Ding EL, et al. Corticosteroids reduce postoperative morbidity after third molar surgery: a systematic review and meta-analysis. Journal of of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery, 2008; 66 (9): 1881-1894.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Could do better? Search methods in recent oral health systematic reviews
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,EVIDENCE BASED HEALTHCARE RESOURCES]]>
document.body:
111-1Could do better? Search methods in recent oral health systematic reviews

 

The Oral Health Specialist Library team presented a poster at the 2008 Cochrane Colloquium in Freiburg. The poster extracted results from the Library's Oral Health Annual Evidence Update; looking at aspects of methodological quality in 2007 systematic reviews.

 

The poster focused on search methods - systematic reviews are only as good as their search methodologies allow - and concluded: 

  • The quality of search methods in journal systematic reviews is considerably lower than that used in the vast majority of Cochrane reviews.
  • It appears likely that the search methods employed in most journal systematic reviews are unlikely to identify all relevant research.
  • Authors of systematic reviews must devote more attention to developing comprehensive search strategies
  • Arguably the inclusion of an information specialist in the review team would benefit this process.

 

 

 


]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Critical factors for the success of orthodontic mini-implants: a systematic review
document.publisher: American Journal of Orthodontics and Dentofacial Orthopedics
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORTHODONTICS]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: The following conclusions should be considered with caution because only a secondary level of evidence was found:

  1. For self-tapping mini-implants, the diamewter and the length of the implant should be 0.2 to 0.5mm larger than the width and the depth of the bone hole for optimal placement torque.
  2. For mini-implants, healing time is unnecessary.
  3. The selection of tooth-bearing mini-implant size depends on the bone available.

Methods: A systematic review of 16 RCTs to consider factors that affect mini-implants as direct and indirect orthodontic anchorage. Database search dates: 1966 to June 2007.

Quality of review: The article lacks clarity on the outcomes of interest, and whether the review’s primary aim is to assess the effectiveness of mini-implant loading, the factors that that might influence success, or both. Whilst a number of sources of information have been searched, including bibliographic databases and hand searching journals, the search terms used in the databases do not appear to be fully reported. Studies written in any language were considered, however unpublished research was not sought which may have introduced publication bias. Appropriate methods were used to select and data extract included studies.

Citation: Chen Y, Kyung HM, Zhao WT, Yu WJ. Critical factors for the success of orthodontic mini-implants: a systematic review. American Journal of Orthodontics and Dentofacial Orthopedics. 2009 Mar; 135(3):284-91.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Current ceramic materials and systems with clinical recommendations: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,RESTORATIVE DENTISTRY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Within the scope of this systematic review, there is no evidence to support the universal application of a single ceramic material and system for all clinical situations. Additional longitudinal clinical studies are required to advance the development of ceramic materials and systems.

Methods: A review of the literature (19 prospective and four restrospective clinical trials) to determine the efficacy of treatment with all-ceramic restorations. Literature search 1996-2006.

Quality of research: The results should be viewed with caution as there are failings in the methodology and reporting of this review.  Key papers are likely to have been missed as only Medline and PubMed databases were searched, supplemented by handsearching of two journals. Other methods such as website searching, reference list checking and personal contacts were not employed. Additionally, the search was restricted to published papers in the English language which may have introduced publication and language bias.

No formal method is described for assessing the quality of included studies, although some inclusion criteria related to quality were set: 2 year minimum follow-up period along with reporting of complications, study type setting and sample size. The number of included studies is also unclear: the text states 23 papers were reviewed whilst it is appears from table II and III that 24 papers were included.

Results: The literature demonstrates that multiple all-ceramic materials and systems are currently available for clinical use, and there is not a single universal material or system for all clinical situations. The successful application is dependent upon the clinician to match the materials, manufacturing techniques, and cementation or bonding procedures, with the individual clinical situation.

Citation: Conrad HJ, Seong WJ, Pesun IJ. Current ceramic materials and systems with clinical recommendations: a systematic review.Journal of Prosthetic Dentistry 2007; 98(5): 389-404.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: CYP1A1 and GSTM1 polymorphisms and oral cancer risk: association studies via evidence-based meta-analyses
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,ORAL CANCER,RISK FACTORS]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: The data suggest that variant genotypes of CYP1A1 might not be risk factors for oral cancer, whereas GSTM1 null genotype significantly increases susceptibility to oral cancer in Asians but not Caucasians.

Methods: A systematic review and meta-analysis of 27 case control studies to assess the possible associations of oral cancer risk with CYP1A1 genetic variation and GSTM1 null genotype respectively. Database search dates: to January 2008.

Quality of review: The results of this review should be viewed with caution.

It is likely that potentially relevant studies were missed. The search was restricted to three general medical databases (Medline, Embase and CNKI) using limited search terms. Searching genetics databases, supplemented by reference list checking, hand searching key journals and consulting experts may have identified additional research.

It is unclear how study selection was conducted. However, an appropriate process was used to minimise error and bias in data extraction. No formal quality assessment was undertaken, but the authors do discuss some quality issues including sample size and the risk of various biases. Whilst the lack of information on socio-economic status in some studies is highlighted, sensitivity analyses do not appear to have been conducted for this or for other key confounders such as tobacco and alcohol usage. The only sub-group analyses reported were those for Asians and Caucasians.

Results: For CYP1A1 MspI polymorphism, the overall odds ratio (OR) for the combined type B and C versus type A genotypes was non significant [OR 1.48 (95% CI = 0.97-2.27)] as were those for sub-group analyses of Asians [OR 1.80 (95% CI = 0.97-3.32)]and Caucasians [OR 1.17 (95% CI = 0.71-1.93)]. For CYP1A1 exon7 polymorphism, the overall odds ratio for the combined Ile/Val versus Ile/Ile genotypes was also non significant [OR 1.30 (95% CI = 0.88-1.92)] as were those for sub-group analyses of Asians [OR 1.69 (95% CI = 0.77-3.73)]and Caucasians [OR 1.08 (95% CI = 0.72-1.61)]. For For GSTM1 polymorphism, the overall odds ratio (OR) for the GSTM1 null geneotype versus the GSTM1 present genotype  WAS significant overall [OR 1.32 (95% CI = 1.08-1.61)] as was that for the sub-group analysis of Asians [OR 1.39 (95% CI = 1,07-1.81)]. However analyses in Caucasion Europeans and Americans were non significant [OR 1.02 (95% CI = 0.83-1.26) and OR 1.24 (95% CI = 0.61-2.50) respectively]

Citation: Zhuo W, Wang Y, Zhuo X, Zhu Y, Wang W, Zhu B, Li D, Chen Z. CYP1A1 and GSTM1 polymorphisms and oral cancer risk: association studies via evidence-based meta-analyses. Cancer Investigation 2009;27(1):86-95.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance.  You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

 

_____________________________________________________________________ 

See also:
Varela-Lema L, Taioli E, Ruano-Ravina A et al. Meta-analysis and pooled analysis of GSTM1 and CYP1A1 polymorphisms and oral and pharyngeal cancers: a HuGE-GSEC review. Genetics in Medicine 2008; 10(6): 369-84.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Dental amalgam and multiple sclerosis: a systematic review and meta-analysis
document.topics: <![CDATA[ OUTCOMES,MULTIPLE SCLEROSIS,NEUROLOGICAL DISEASES & DISORDERS,ORAL HEALTH DISORDERS,TREATMENT & MANAGEMENT,RESTORATIVE DENTISTRY,DENTAL CARIES,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,PUBLIC HEALTH,METHODS,RESEARCH METHODS,ANALYSIS & RESEARCH]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Future studies that take into consideration the amalgam restoration size and surface area along with the duration of exposure are needed in order to definitively rule out any link between amalgam and multiple sclerosis (MS).

Methods: A systematic review and meta-analysis of 8 studies (4 observational, 3 case-control and one cohort) to explore and quantify the association between amalgam restorations and MS. Literature search 1966 to April 2006.

Quality of review: Although three databases were searched and reference lists scanned, key studies may have been missed as it appears only basic search terms were used. In addition, the search was restricted to published research in the English language which may have introduced publication and language bias. Two reviewers independently assessed the quality of the included studies although the methods are not reported. There was considerable heterogeneity between the studies. However, the authors did take this into account; using a random effects model when pooling results.

Results: The pooled OR for the risk of MS among amalgam users was consistent, with a slight, nonstatistically significant increase between amalgam use and risk of MS.

Citation: Aminzadah KK and Etminan ME. Dental amalgam and multiple sclerosis: a systematic review and meta-analysis. Journal of Public Health Dentistry 2007; 67(1): 64-66

Access: This paper is available to the general public.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Dental and skeletal changes following surgically assisted rapid maxillary expansion.
document.publisher: International Journal of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,DENTO-FACIAL ANOMALIES,ORAL SURGERY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions:  The conclusions should be considered with caution because only a secondary level of evidence was found.

Methods:  A systematic review of 12 retrospective studies to evaluate skeletal and dental changes after surgically assisted rapid maxillary expansion.

Quality of review: A wide-range of electronic databases were searched and reference lists of included studies were checked. It does not appear that there were any language restrictions. There was no search for unpublished studies which may have introduced publication bias. The quality of the included studies was assessed using a 20 point scoring system. All were retrospective studies with significant methodological flaws (minimum and maximum scores of 1 and 7 respectively) and the authors rightly state that the results should be viewed with caution.  

Results:  All included studies had methodological flaws. Expansion was greater at the molars and diminished progressively to the anterior part of the dental arch in all the evaluation periods. Vertical and sagittal skeletal changes were nil or not clinically significant. The nasal portion of the maxillary complex showed an increase in dimensions thereby improving nasal patency. An overall dental relapse of 0.5–1 mm is reported after 1 year of orthodontic treatment.

Citation:  Lagravere MO, Major PW, Flores-Mir, C.  International Journal of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery 2006; 35: 481-487.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Dental arch space changes following premature loss of primary first molars: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PAEDIATRIC DENTISTRY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Sample sizes and methodological quality of the included studies is limited. All three studies challenged the need for space maintainers after premature loss of primary first molars because their results did not show a clinically significant loss of arch perimeter or arch width. Nevertheless, in cases with incisor and/or lip protrusion or a severe predisposition to arch length deficiency prior to any tooth loss, the amount of loss identified could have treatment implications.

Methods: A systematic review of three longitudinal studies to consider the implications of premature loss of primary molars for treatment planning. Database search dates: inception to July/August 2007.

Quality of review: Given the limitations of the included studies, the results of this review should be viewed with caution. It appears that study quality was low with small sample sizes, no examiner blinding, a lack of information about baseline comparability of groups and a failure to consider confounders.
 
The authors searched a range of databases, supplemented by reference list checking. It appears that the search was restricted to published studies in English, Spanish or Portuguese. If this is the case, then bias may have been introduced. Appropriate procedures were used to minimise error and bias in study selection, however the process used for data extraction and quality assessment is not stated. The authors provide details of a 15 point checklist used to consider study quality.

Results: A reported immediate space loss of 1.5mm per arch side in the mandible and 1mm in the maxilla - when normal growth changes were considered – was found.

Citation: Tunison W, Flores-Mir C, ElBadrawy H, et al. Dental arch space changes following premature loss of primary first molars: a systematic review. Pediatric Dentistry, 2008; 30 (4): 297-302

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Dental fear in adults: a meta-analysis of behavioural interventions
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,DENTAL ANXIETY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Despite extensive heterogeneity, changes in self-reported anxiety represent medium to large effect sizes. Patients signing up for a behavioral intervention for dental fear can be expected to report a significant reduction in their fear, and this effect generally seems to be lasting. Mean long-term attendance (>4 years after treatment) is 77%.

Methods: Systematic review of 38 papers (including 16 randomised controlled trials) examining the efects of behavioural interventions in adults with documented high dental fear or avoidance.

Quality of Review: Only the PubMed and Psychlit databases were searched and the limited search strategy may have failed to identify relevant studies.  Reference lists of included studies were checked but no handsearching was conducted. Two cited unpublished theses were included, but it is not clear whether a thorough search was conducted for unpublished literature, nor whether non-English language papers were sought.  No formal method is reported of assessing the quality of included studies, however, data were collected on variables that affect validity, including attition, sample size and randomisation. There was significant heterogeneity in the meta-analyses conducted, suggesting that it may have been inappropriate to pool the studies statistically. 

Results: The calculated effect sizes (ESs) for self-reported anxiety after intervention indicate positive changes in 36 of the 38 studies and no changes in two. The overall ES = 1.8 (95% CI 1.6, 1.8).

The percent of subjects with post-treatment dental visits in the first 6 months post-treatment varied between 50 and 100%. The overall ES for attendance at dental visits, weighted by sample size, is 1.4 (95% CI 1.3, 1.6). The homogeneity analysis indicates that the studies cannot be adequately described in one ES. The reported percentage of subjects with a dental visit between 6 months and 4 years post-treatment varied from 48 to 100%. The overall weighted ES for visiting the dentist, adjusted for drop-outs in the studies, is 1.2 (95% CI 0.99, 1.4).

Citation: Kvale G, Berggren U, Milgrom P. Dental fear in adults: a meta-analysis of behavioural interventions. Community Dentistry and Oral Epidemiology, 2004; 32(4): 250-264

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Dental flossing and interproximal caries: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ OUTCOMES,INDIVIDUAL BEHAVIOUR,ORAL HEALTH DISORDERS,DENTAL CARIES,DENTAL PUBLIC HEALTH,PAEDIATRIC DENTISTRY,CAUSES & PREVENTION,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,DETERMINANTS,PUBLIC HEALTH,HYGIENE,RESEARCH METHODS,METHODS,ANALYSIS & RESEARCH,DENTAL HEALTH,DENTAL CARIES,DENTAL DECAY,ORAL HYGIENE]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions:  Professional flossing in children with low fluoride exposures is highly effective in reducing interproximal caries risk. These findings should be extrapolated to more typical floss-users with care, since self-flossing has failed to show an effect.

Methods:  A systematic review of six randomised controlled trials to assess the effect of flossing on interproximal caries.  Literature search to end 2004.

Quality of study:  The search strategy encompassed several databases (Medline, Central, Web of Science and the controlled trials database). In addition, reference lists were consulted and investigators contacted to obtain unpublished literature.  It is not clear whether non-English language papers were considered. The authors highlight a number of weaknesses in this systematic review.  Some of these relate to the review protocol, others are due to the size, quality and design of the included studies.  They describe the evidence as “challenging to interpret” and “low level” because of inconsistent results across trials, the difficulty in extrapolating some results and the below average quality of some included trials. 

Results:  Professional flossing performed on school days for 1.7 years on predominantly primary teeth in children was associated with a 40% caries risk reduction (relative risk, 0.60; 95% confidence interval, 0.48–0.76; p= 0.001). Both three-monthly professional flossing for 3 years (relative risk, 0.93; 95% confidence interval, 0.73–1.19; p= 0.32) and self-performed flossing in young adolescents for 2 years (relative risk, 1.01; 95% confidence interval, 0.85–1.20; p= 0.93) did not reduce caries risk.

Citation:  Hujoel P, Cunha-Cruz J, Banting D, Loesche W. Dental flossing and interproximal caries: a systematic review. Journal of Dental Research. 2006; 85(4): 298-305.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. Full text online access is available to NHS staff in England via ATHENS passwords. To apply for an ATHENS password and access this resource and many others please go to the ATHENS registration page. 

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Dental management of patients using antithrombotic drugs: critical appraisal of existing guidelines
document.publisher: Oral Surgery, Oral Medicine, Oral Pathology, Oral Radiology, and Endodontics
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,SPECIAL CARE DENTISTRY,CARDIOVASCULAR CONDITIONS,ANTICOAGULATION]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors conclusions: Two evidence-based clinical practice guidelines, satisfactorily fulfilling the criteria of the AGREE instrument. Both were published in 2007. They advise to not routinely discontinue antiplatelet and anticoagulation medication before dental surgery. The majority of the recommendations, however, were not sufficiently linked to levels of evidence

Methods: A narrative systematic review of 4 guidelines available for management of dental invasive procedures in patients on antithrombotic drugs. Database search dates: inception to October 2007.

Quality of review: Several databases were searched (Medline, CINAHL, Science Citation Index), supplemented by searching a range of guideline producers and several guideline-specific databases. Searching Embase – a key source for pharmacological information – may have yielded additional results. The process used to select guidelines is not described, although the authors assessed the quality of included guidelines independently in duplicate using the Agree instrument.

However, they failed to identify the UK guidance published by the British Committee for Standards in Haematology in March 2007: Guidelines for the management of patients on oral anticoagulants requiring dental surgery. This guidance is used by the National Patient Safety Agency in the development of advice issued at the same time: Actions that can make anticoagulant therapy safer: Alert and other information.

Citation: van Diermen D, Aartman I,  Baart J, Hoogstraten J, van der Waal I. Dental management of patients using antithrombotic drugs: critical appraisal of existing guidelines. Oral Surgery, Oral Medicine, Oral Pathology, Oral Radiology, and Endodontology 2009; 107(5): 616-624

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Dental surgery for patients on anticoagulant therapy with warfarin: a systematic review and meta-analysis
document.publisher: Journal of the Canadian Dental Association
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,SPECIAL CARE DENTISTRY,CARDIOVASCULAR CONDITIONS,ANTICOAGULATION]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Continuing the regular dose of warfarin therapy does not seem to confer an increased risk of bleeding compared with discontinuing or modifying the warfarin dose for patients undergoing minor dental procedures.

Methods: A narrative systematic review of five randomised controlled trials to evaluate the effect of continuing warfarin therapy on the bleeding risk of patients undergoing elective dental surgical procedures. Database search: 1990 to June 2008.

Quality of review: The review is limited by the poor quality of the included studies. In looking for guidance on clinical management of anticoagulated patients, the following sources are recommended:

  • British Committee for Standards in Haematology: Guidelines for the management of patients on oral anticoagulants requiring dental surgery.
  • National Patient Safety Agency: Actions that can make anticoagulant therapy safer: Alert and other information

A reasonable attempt was made to identify relevant studies. Three databases were searched (Medline. Embase and Central), experts were contacted and conference abstracts and references of included papers were checked. Appropriate methods were used to minimise error and bias in selecting, critically appraising and data extracting included studies. As the authors note, four of the five studies were conducted in hospital (one study did not specify setting) and consequently generalisability to the dental practice is limited.

Results: Compared with interrupting warfarin therapy (either partial or complete), perioperative continuation of warfarin with patients’ usual dose was not associated with an increased risk for clinically significant nonmajor bleeding (relative risk [RR], 0.71; 95% confidence interval [CI]: 0.39–1.28; p = 0.65; I2 = 0%) or an increased risk for minor bleeding (RR, 1.19; 95% CI: 0.90–1.58; p = 0.22; I2 = 0%).

Citation: Nematullah A, Alabousi A, Blanas N, Douketis JD, Sutherland SE. Dental surgery for patients on anticoagulant therapy with warfarin: a systematic review and meta-analysis. Journal of the Canadian Dental Association 2009; 75(1):41.

Access: Full-text is freely available to the public

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Dentomaxillofacial variability of cleidocranial dysplasia: clinicoradiological presentation and systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,DENTO-FACIAL ANOMALIES]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: The diagnosis of cleidocranial dysplasia (CCD) can be difficult when typical features are not clearly expressed. Since the multiple case studies concentrated on specific clinical aspects, an overall ranking including all associated findings was not possible. Owing to their prevalence, we recommend referencing to the described list of clinical signs as major symptoms for the pathognomy in CCD, since they are infrequent in other conditions and in the general population. To categorize the expression of CCD, more interdisciplinary studies are necessary. Nevertheless, a subjective classification is possible according to the related restrictions in the patients’ quality of life.

Methods: A systematic review to determine the clinical and radiological presentation of CCD in the authors patient group and to compare them with other reported cases by a systematic review of the literature. 40 single case presentations and 17 multiple case studies were included. Data for 283 patients with CCD were available, including the authors own patient cohort of 24 individuals. Literature search dates not reported.

Quality of review: Selected journals were hand searched, reference lists checked and non-English language publications included. However, PubMed was the only database searched and it does not appear that unpublished literature was sought. Consequently studies may have been missed.

No appraisal of the studies is reported, however critical appraisal of case reports and case series may not be applicable.

Results: Dental signs such as supernumerary teeth and eruption failure were expressed in over 93.5%. Skeletal symptoms such as hypoplastic maxilla and the clavicular sign were exhibited in over 84.3%. The prevalence of spontaneous mutations differs slightly when comparing the single case studies (72.0%) with our patient data (58.3%). The fraction of spontaneous mutations in multiple case studies was 5.0%.

Citation: Golan I, Baumert U, Hrala BP, Mubig D. Dentomaxillofacial variability of cleidocranial dysplasia: clinicoradiological presentation and systematic review. Dentomaxillofacial Radiology 2003; 32(6): 347-354.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Diagnosing abuse: a systematic review of torn frenum and other intra-oral injuries
document.topics: <![CDATA[ DETERMINANTS,OUTCOMES,AGE GROUPS,CHILDREN,ORAL HEALTH DISORDERS,ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,PAEDIATRIC DENTISTRY,DENTAL INJURIES,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PUBLIC HEALTH,SOCIAL DETERMINANTS,MONTHLY ADDITIONS,POPULATIONS,GROUPS,ABUSE,2009 SEPTEMBER]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Current literature does not support the diagnosis of abuse based on a torn labial frenum in isolation. The intra-oral hard and soft tissue should be examined in all suspected abuse cases, and a dental opinion sought where abnormalities are found.

Methods: A systematic review of 18 case series or studies and one case control study representing 591 children. The review aimed to examine the evidence for whether a torn labial frenum is pathognomic of abuse, and to define other intra-oral injuries found in physical abuse. Literature search from 1950 to June 2006.

Quality of review: A well conducted review, which used an exhaustive search strategy to identify all relevant evidence. A range of biomedical, health, child, social care and grey literature databases were searched using comprehensive search terms. There were no language restrictions and unpublished research was sought. To minimise bias, included studies were critically appraised in duplicate by two independent reviewers, with a third reviewer arbitrating any disputes.

Results: There were no comparative studies of accidental and abusive torn labial frenum to enable a probability of abuse to be determined. Nine studies documented abusive torn labial frena in 27 children, 22 were less than five years old and 24 fatally abused. Only a direct blow to the face was substantiated as a mechanism of injury. Two studies noted accidentally torn labial frena, both from intubation. Abusive intra-oral injuries were widely distributed to the lips, gums, tongue and palate and included fractures, intrusion and extraction of the dentition, bites and contusions.

Citation: McGuire S, Hunter B, Hunter L, Sibert JR, Mann M, Kemp AM. Diagnosing abuse: a systematic review of torn frenum and other intra-oral injuries. Archives of Disease in Childhood 2007; 92: 1113-1117.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Diagnostic accuracy of panoramic radiography in determining relationship between inferior alveolar nerve and mandibular third molar
document.publisher: Journal of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORAL SURGERY,IMPACTED THIRD MOLARS]]>
document.body:
This is a provisional record for information. The review has been identified as potentially meeting our quality criteria. It will be critically appraised and a quality statement provided as soon as possible.

 

Purpose: The aim of this review was to determine the diagnostic accuracy of panoramic radiographic markers in the detection of the relationship between the mandibular canal and third molar roots.

Materials and Methods: A literature search of electronic databases, Cochrane Oral Health Group's Trials Register, National Research Register, conference proceedings, and abstracts was performed to identify studies that had investigated the diagnostic accuracy of the 3 panoramic radiographic markers (ie, darkening of the root, interruption of the radiopaque borders, and diversion of the mandibular canal). RevMan, version 5.0, and Meta-DiSc software programs were used for the pooled analyses and the construction of a summary receiver operating characteristic curve.

Results: A total of 5 studies were included, involving 894 observations. The overall pooled sensitivity and specificity for darkening of the root was calculated as 51.2% (95% confidence interval [CI] 42% to 60%) and 89% (95% CI 87% to 90%), respectively. The interruption of radiopaque borders showed a pooled sensitivity of 53.5% (95% CI 78.1% to 81.8%) and a pooled specificity of 80% (95% CI 78.1% to 81.8%). The diversion of the canal criterion had a pooled sensitivity of 29.4% (95% CI 21.8% to 38.1%) and a pooled specificity of 94.7% (95% CI 93.6% to 95.7%). The area under the receiver operating characteristic curve was 70% to 77%.

Conclusions: The results of this meta-analysis suggest a reasonable diagnostic accuracy for panoramic radiography in the preoperative evaluation of the relationship between third molars and the canal. Additional studies are needed to examine a more accurate, accessible, and cost-effective initial radiographic technique before third molar surgery 

Citation: Atieh MA. Diagnostic accuracy of panoramic radiography in determining relationship between inferior alveolar nerve and mandibular third molar. Journal of Oral & Maxillofacial Surgery 2010; 68(1):74-82 

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Diagnostic delay and disease stage in head and neck cancer: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,ORAL CANCER,ENT AND AUDIOLOGY,CONDITIONS,DIAGNOSIS & REFERRAL,HEAD & NECK CANCER]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Possible explanations for the lack of an observed relationship between patient delay and stage include: inaccurate measurement of delay, lack of sensitivity of disease stage to delay-related disease progression, and variation in tumor aggressiveness, which could lead to variation in symptom progression rates. Better evidence is needed about the relationship between diagnostic delay and disease progression and/or disease outcomes. If demonstrated and validated, such associations would provide a much stronger argument than description of delay alone for education programs around symptom recognition and for more active screening of high-risk individuals.

Methods: A narrative systematic review of 27 studies to examine the evidence for an association between patient and/or provider-related diagnostic delay and late stage at diagnosis.

Quality of review: This review is limited by considerable clinical heterogeneity between the included studies; notably in the number of sites included, the variety of types of delay and the ways in which delay was measured.

The authors searched three databases (Medline, Embase and Biosis) and supplementing their search with reference list checking. However, it is likely that studies were missed and bias introduced as the search terms used were extremely limited and the search was restricted to published studies in the English language. No information is provided on the processes used to select and data extract included papers. Whilst no formal quality assessment process is described, several elements were identified in the inclusion criteria including study design and sample size.

Results: Most studies detect no relationship between diagnostic delay and stage at diagnosis. Where studies identified a relationship it varied in direction and magnitude, with no consistent positive association in any of the head and neck cancer sites.

Citation: Goy J, Hall SF, Feldman-Stewart D, Groome PA. Diagnostic delay and disease stage in head and neck cancer: a systematic review. Laryngoscope 2009; 119(5):889-98.

Access: Full-text online access to this article requires subscription to the journal.  NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Directions to Primary Care Trusts concerning the exercise of Dental Public Health functions 2008
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,DENTAL PUBLIC HEALTH]]>
document.body:
Directions have been made on implementation of The Functions of Primary Care Trusts (Dental Public Health) (England) Regulations 2006. The functions are to provide oral health programmes and undertake oral health surveys. PCTs will need to have regard to Delivering Better Oral Health An evidence-based toolkit for prevention published in September 2007 in developing oral health programmes and the guidance issued in January 2007 Dental screening (Inspection) in schools and consent for undertaking screening and epidemiological surveys in undertaking oral health surveys. PCTs will also need to  make appropriate staff available in exercising the function to undertake oral health surveys in accordance with the national programme and protocols.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Do bone grafts or barrier membranes provide additional treatment effects for infrabony lesions treated with enamel matrix derivatives? A network meta-analysis of randomized-controlled trials
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,PERIODONTOLOGY,TREATMENT & MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body:
This is a provisional record for information. The review has been identified as potentially meeting our quality criteria. It will be critically appraised and a quality statement provided as soon as possible.

 

Background/aim: Network meta-analyses of randomized-controlled trials were undertaken to investigate whether enamel matrix derivatives (EMD) in conjunction with other regenerative materials yield better treatment outcomes than EMD alone in the treatment of infrabony defects > or =3 mm.

Material and Methods: A literature search was conducted using the Medline, EMBASE, LILACS and CENTRAL databases up to and including December 2008. Treatment outcomes were changes in probing pocket depth (PPD), clinical attachment level (CAL) and infrabony defect depth. Different types of bone grafts (or barrier membranes) were first treated as a group and then separately.

Results: Twenty-eight studies were included in the review. EMD plus bone grafts and EMD plus membranes attained 0.24 mm [95% high probability density (HPD) intervals: -0.38, 0.65] and 0.07 mm (95% HPD intervals: -1.26, 1.04) more PPD reduction than EMD alone, respectively. For CAL gain, EMD plus bone grafts and EMD plus membranes attained 0.46 mm (95% HPD intervals: -0.17, 0.83) and 0.15 mm (95% HPD intervals: -1.37, 0.30), respectively. When different types of bone grafts and barrier membranes were treated separately, EMD with bovine bone grafts showed greater treatment effects.

Conclusion: There was little evidence to support the additional benefits of EMD in conjunction with other regenerative materials 

Citation: Tu YK, Woolston A, Faggion CM, Jr., Tu YK, Woolston A, Faggion CMJ. Do bone grafts or barrier membranes provide additional treatment effects for infrabony lesions treated with enamel matrix derivatives? A network meta-analysis of randomized-controlled trials. Journal of Clinical Periodontology 2010; 37(1):59-79

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Do stress-related psychosocial factors contribute to cancer incidence and survival?
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,ORAL CANCER,ENT AND AUDIOLOGY,CONDITIONS,RISK FACTORS,PROGNOSIS,HEAD & NECK CANCER]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: The analyses suggest that stress-related psychosocial factors have an adverse effect on cancer incidence and survival, although there is evidence of publication bias and results should be interpreted with caution.

Methods: A systematic review and meta-analysis of 162 prospective studies to investigate the association between stress-related psychosocial factors and cancer outcomes. Literature search to October 2007. [Note: results reported are based on a sub group analysis of three of the 11 studies in head and neck cancer.]

Quality of review: A moderate quality systematic review and meta-analysis. A reasonable attempt was made to identify published research by searching four databases and checking reference lists from relevant reviews and articles. Non-English language and unpublished research was not sought however, which may have introduced language and publication bias.

The characteristics and results of individual studies are not presented, but this may have been due to the large number of studies included (126).
Whilst the review overall suffers from publication bias, there was no evidence of publication bias for the result regarding head and neck cancer, but this still should be viewed cautiously given that it is based on only three papers.

Results: Psychosocial factors are associated with poorer survival in patients with head and neck cancer: hazard ratio 1.58 (CI: 1.22-2.03; p<0.001).

Citation: Chida Y, Hamer M, Wardle J, Steptoe A. Do stress-related psychosocial factors contribute to cancer incidence and survival? Nature Clinical Practice Oncology 2008; 5(8): 466-75.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Does black tea prevent tooth decay?
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,DENTAL CARIES,DENTAL PUBLIC HEALTH,CAUSES & PREVENTION]]>
document.body:
111-1Does black tea prevent tooth decay?

A news item in the Daily Express on 9 December 2008 reported "a daily cup of black tea can help prevent tooth decay"

 

 

 

 

 

Where does the evidence come from?

A study conducted by US-based researchers at Temple University School of Dentistry, Philadelphia. Results of the study were published in General Dentistry.

Citation: Bassiouny MA, Kuroda S and Yang J. Topographic and radiographic profile assessment of dental erosion-Part III: Effect of green and black tea on human dentition. General Dentistry 56(5) 2008; 451-461 [full text]

 

What were the authors' objectives?

To compare green and black tea to soda and orange juice in terms of their erosive effect.

 
What was the nature of the evidence?

A laboratory study of the effects of green tea, black tea, orange juice and cola, plus an active and a passive control fluid (acetic acid 5% and water respectively) on 36 sound human teeth for a period of 20 weeks.

What were the findings? 

The erosive effects of green and black tea were “relatively harmless” and “closely resembled” the tap water used as a control. Orange juice and cola both “exhibited “significant erosion”.

 

What were the authors' conclusions?

"The results of this study clearly identified the differences in terms of the tested fluids’ erosive potential and offered conclusive evidence of brewed green and black tea’s minimal erosive action on the human dentition compared with soda and orange juice. In view of the countless systemic and dental health benefits of brewed tea and its minimal potential for erosion of human enamel, this beverage should be encouraged as a substitute for acidic drinks."

 

How reliable are the conclusions?

As the authors state in the discussion, this was an ""an accelerated controlled laboratory test" and "did not seek to duplicate the complex clinical situation but to provide an accurate comparison among the beverages tested with respect to their effect on human dentition." The process used to measure enamel erosion by the various drinks did not represent a real life situation, and caution should be used in extrapolating the results of an in vitro study to a clinical setting.

 

How accurately did the media report the studies findings?

The authors cite several laboratory studies suggesting tea has an anticariogenic effect to support their contention that there are "dental health benefits", but the study itself only compares the relative erosive effects of tea vs cola or orange juice. To extrapolate from this that drinking a cup of black tea a day can prevent tooth decay is inaccurate.

It is interesting to note that a press release about this study issued by the Academy of General Dentistry, quotes the lead author as stating that green tea "is superior over black due to its natural flavinoids (plant nutrients) and antioxidants"; a conclusion not highlighted in the paper.


Links to the relevant, available news articles:

A black tea a day can stop tooth decay, The Daily Express, 9 December 2008

 

Other library items of interest:

Do herbal teas damage teeth?

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Does dietary counseling improve quality of life in cancer patients? A systematic review and meta-analysis
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORAL CANCER,ENT AND AUDIOLOGY,CONDITIONS,TREATMENT & MANAGEMENT,THERAPEUTIC INTERVENTIONS,NON-DRUG TREATMENTS,OTHER,SPECIAL CARE DENTISTRY,CANCER PATIENTS,HEAD & NECK CANCER]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Dietary counseling does not appear to improve quality of life (QOL) significantly in patients with cancer. However,an observed trend toward benefit underscores the need for further study.

Methods: A systematic review and meta-analysis of five randomised controlled trials.  3 RCTs considered head and neck cancer (results are not separated according to site). Literature search dates not provided.

Quality of review: The review lacks sufficient details to assess the quality of the searching for the systematic review. Whilst a number of databases are searched, the strategy, search terms and included languages are not reported. Furthermore unpublished research does not appear to have been sought which may have introduced publication bias.

In the discussion, the authors rightly state that results should be viewed with caution due to the small number of trials included and the substantial heterogeneity detected.

Results: The standardised mean difference in QoL scores among patients who received dietary counseling was 0.56 (95% CI: -0.01-1.14; P=0.06).

Citation: Halfdanarson TR, Thordardottir E, West CP, Jatoi A. Does dietary counseling improve quality of life in cancer patients? A systematic review and meta-analysis. Journal of Supportive Oncology. 2008; 6(5): 234-7.

Access: Full text freely available.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Does oral health promotion influence the oral hygiene and gingival health of patients undergoing fixed appliance orthodontic treatment? A systematic literature review.
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,ORTHODONTICS,TREATMENT & MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy. 

 

Authors’ conclusions: An oral health promotion programme for patients undergoing fixed appliance orthodontic treatment produces a short term reduction (up to 5 months) in plaque and improvement in gingival health. No particular OHP method produces a greater short term benefit to periodontal health during fixed appliance orthodontic treatment. Further studies using appropriate methods and in particular longer follow up periods are required.

Methods: A narrative systematic review of six studies (4 RCTs, 2 CCTs) to determine whether oral health promotion influences the oral hygiene and gingival health of patients undergoing fixed orthodontic treatments. Database search 1966 to May 2005.

Quality of review: A reasonable attempt was made to find potentially relevant studies. Several databases and Google Scholar were searched, reference lists checked and key journals hand-searched without language restrictions. Study selection methods are not detailed. However, appropriate procedures were used to minimise error and bias in data extraction and quality assessment. Studies were assessed for risk of bias. No data are provided for individual study ratings.

Results:  Positive effects on plaque and/or gingival health were produced in four of the included trials. In the other two studies (both RCTs), OHP resulted in no difference being detected in dental plaque levels and/or gingival bleeding. None of the studies detected a negative effect of orthodontic OHP on gingival health. In the short term (up to 5 months), significant reductions in plaque levels can be expected when an OHP programme is instituted for patients undergoing fixed appliance treatment (P < 0.05).21–23,25 It was not possible to determine if an educational intervention was superior to an environmental change in improving oral hygiene. Advice on smoking cessation did not form part of any of the OHP programmes.

Citation: Gray D, McIntyre G. Does oral health promotion influence the oral hygiene and gingival health of patients undergoing fixed appliance orthodontic treatment? A systematic literature review. Journal of Orthodontics, 2008; 35; 262-269

Access: The full text of this paper is freely available.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Does the presence of antagonist remaining teeth affect implant overdenture success? A systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,RESTORATIVE DENTISTRY]]>
document.body:
This is a provisional record for information. The review has been identified as potentially meeting our quality criteria. It will be critically appraised and a quality statement provided as soon as possible.

 

Introduction/Aims: Many patients who need implant overdentures are not completely edentulous; they still have antagonist natural teeth or implant fixed prostheses. In such cases, however, little is known about whether existing natural teeth affect the success of implant overdentures positively or act as a complicating factor. This systematic review attempts to clarify the correlation between existing remaining teeth and the survival/success rate of maxillary and mandibular implant overdentures.

Methods: An assessment of available relevant articles published in English from 1990 to 2009 was performed using an online database and a manual search in libraries.

Results: Although the opposing natural dentition was not sufficiently described in the literature, 10 articles about the mandible and 10 articles about the maxilla were selected. As there was no controlled study on the natural teeth opposing implant overdentures, this review could not reach a clear conclusion.

Conclusion: The review did reveal a remarkably high success/survival rate for mandibular implant overdentures; maxillary implant overdentures showed a lower rate. The presence of antagonist teeth hardly seems to be a risk factor for success for mandibular implant overdentures. For maxillary implant overdentures, the existence of antagonist teeth might act negatively for implant survival, but they are certainly not a contraindication. Although a few articles stated this relationship, we could not find an apparent correlation between the remaining antagonist teeth and the success of the implant overdentures. A detailed description of the opposing dentate status and results of randomized controlled clinical trials would be required to characterize this evidence-based implant overdenture treatment.

Citation: Ohkubo C, Baek KW. Does the presence of antagonist remaining teeth affect implant overdenture success? A systematic review. Journal of Oral Rehabilitation 2010; 37(4):306-312

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.
