document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Does tooth brushing influence the development and progression of non-inflammatory gingival recession? A systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,PERIODONTOLOGY,TREATMENT & MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: The data to support or refute the association between tooth brushing and gingival recession are inconclusive.

Methods: A systematic review of 18 studies (1 RCT, 1 cohort and 16 cross-sectional) to evaluate the effect of tooth brushing on the initiation and progression of non-inflammatory gingival recession. Literature search January 1966 to July 2005.

Quality of review: A well conducted systematic review, using a thorough search strategy to identify relevant literature. Six databases were searched with a comprehensive list of search terms (Medline, Embase, Web of Knowledge, Cochrane Central, Current Contents and Google Scholar), and supplemented with reference list checking, handsearching journals and contacting journal editors. To minimize bias, selection of papers was conducted independently by three reviewers and included papers were quality assessed in duplicate by two independent reviewers.

The review was supported by a research grant from Philips Oral Healthcare, who funded the primary researcher’s post. However, the authors do not consider there was a direct conflict of interest with this collaboration, particularly as commercially sponsored investigations with the primary aim of comparing the efficacy of different toothbrushes were excluded from the review.

Results: The full texts of 29 papers were read and 18 texts were eligible for inclusion. One abstract from EuroPerio 5 reported a randomized-controlled clinical trial [Level I evidence] in which the authors concluded that the toothbrushes significantly reduced recessions on buccal tooth surfaces over 18 months. Of the remaining 17 observational studies, two concluded that there appeared to be no relationship between tooth brushing frequency and gingival recession. Eight studies reported a positive association between tooth brushing frequency and recession. Other potential risk factors were duration of tooth brushing, brushing force, frequency of changing the toothbrush, brush (bristle) hardness and tooth brushing technique. None of the observational studies satisfied all the specified criteria for quality appraisal and a valid appraisal of the quality of the randomized-controlled trial was not possible.

Citation: Rajapakse PS, McCracken GI, Gwynnett W, Steen ND, Guentsch A, Heasman PA. Does tooth brushing influence the development and progression of non-inflammatory gingival recession? A systematic review. Journal of Clinical Periodontology 2007; 34(12): 1046–1061.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance.  You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Durability of amalgam in the restoration of class II cavities in primary molars:a systematic review of the literature
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,DENTAL CARIES,PAEDIATRIC DENTISTRY,RESTORATIVE DENTISTRY,TREATMENT & MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Amalgam remains an appropriate choice of material for the restoration of the primary dentition. However, factors other than durability are increasingly influencing its use in clinical practice.

Methods: A sytematic review of 24 papers looking at the durability of amalgam when used to restore interproximal (class II) cavities in primary molars. Literature search 1966- 2006.

Quality of review:  The review is limited by the lack of a thorough attempt to identify all relevant literature. Only Medline and Embase were searched. Extra databases, reference list checking, handsearching, grey literature sources and contacting experts may have located additional key studies. Furthermore, unpublished and non-English language papers were not included which may have introduced publication and language bias. Heterogeneity between studies or whether it is possible to combine study results is not addressed by the authors.

Results: No study achieved a Grade A; four studies rated Grade B1 and thirteen B2. Seven studies were rated Grade C. Results are reported on 17 studies (15 RCTs and 2 clinical trials) that were quality graded B and above. A wide range of failure rates for amalgam were reported from 0 – 58%. However, in the context of a controlled clinical environmentin a developed country the failure rate varied between 0 and 22%.

Citation: Kilpatrick NM, Neumann A. Durability of amalgam in the restoration of class II cavities in primary molars: a systematic review of the literature. European Archives of Paediatric Dentistry 2007; 8(1): 5-13.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance.  You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Early orthodontic treatment of skeletal open-bite malocclusion: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,DENTO-FACIAL ANOMALIES,ORTHODONTICS]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Most of the studies had serious problems of lack of power because of small sample size, bias and confounding variables, lack of method error analysis, blinding in measurements, and deficient or lack of statistical method. Thus, the quality level of the studies was not sufficient enough to draw any evidence-based conclusions.

Methods: Systematic review of 7 clinical trials examining the relationship between early orthodontic treatment and skeletal open bite. Literature search January 1966 to July 2004

Quality of review: It is likely that relevant studies have been missed due the limited search strategy: only PubMed and the Cochrane Clinical Trials Register were searched using narrow search terms.  There was no hand searching or reference list checking reported, and it is unclear whether non-English language papers were considered.  Unpublished research does not appear to have been sought, which may have introduced publication bias.  Table 1 describing the design of the studies is not very comprehensible, which leads to some confusion on the overall design of the included studies.  The authors rightly acknowledge that the poor quality of the included studies, did not allow them to draw adequate conclusions.

Results: Two controlled clinical trials of early anterior open bite indicated the effectiveness of treatment in the mixed dentition with headgears or functional appliances (or both).

Citation: Cozza P, Mucedero M, Baccetti T, Franchi L. Early orthodontic treatment of skeletal open-bite malocclusion: A systematic review. Angle Orthodontist 2005; 75: 707-713

Access: Full text freely available to the general public.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Economic evaluation of dental caries prevention: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ECONOMICS,ECONOMICS,OUTCOMES,ORAL HEALTH DISORDERS,POPULATION BASED & PREVENTATIVE SERVICES,COSTING,COSTS,ORAL DISORDERS,ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,DENTAL PUBLIC HEALTH,DENTAL CARIES,CAUSES & PREVENTION,DETERMINANTS,PUBLIC HEALTH,MANAGEMENT & INTERVENTIONS,SERVICES,ANALYSIS,METHODS,RESEARCH METHODS,ANALYSIS & RESEARCH,DENTAL CARIES,DENTAL DECAY,DENTAL HEALTH]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors conclusions: The scarcity of well-conducted studies, as well as contradictory evidence in the reviewed articles, makes it difficult to judge the health-economic effect of the studied caries-prevention methods.

Methods: Systematic review of economic evaluations of cares prevention. 17 studies were included (4 randomised controlled and 2 controlled clinical trials, and 7 cohort, 1 cross-sectional and 3 case-control studies).

Quality of review:  The search may have missed key papers as only one database (Medline) was searched.  The search was conducted across a range of European languages and reference lists of included papers were checked.  However there was no search for unpublished material.  The inclusion criteria for population (eg age, high risk) and types of eligible caries prevention methods are not clearly defined. The quality of the included studies was independently appraised by two reviewers.

Results: There were 17 original studies including an economic evaluation. The reviewed studies show that there are contradictory results from studies on fissure sealant (low evidence values), fluoride rinsing (low and moderate evidence values), fluoride tablets (low evidence values), fluoride varnish (low evidence values) and from preventive programmes (low evidence values). There was only one study of chlorhexidine in caries prevention on primary teeth, which makes it impossible to draw conclusions.

Citation: Kallestal C, Norlund A, Soder B, et al. Economic evaluation of dental caries prevention: a systematic review, Acta Odontologica Scandinavica. 2003;61(6):341-6.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Effect estimates and methodological quality of randomized controlled trials about prevention of alveolar osteitis following tooth extraction: a systematic review
document.publisher: Oral Surgery, Oral Medicine, Oral Pathology, Oral Radiology, and Endodontics
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORAL SURGERY,IMPACTED THIRD MOLARS]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Local treatment with tetracycline, and also 0.12% chlorhexidine rinsing preoperatively and 7 days postoperatively, seem to have significant and clinically relevant preventive effect on alveolar osteitis (AO) following surgical removal of lower third molars.

Methods: A systematic review of 32 randomised controlled trials looking at the prevention of alveolar osteitis. Dates of literature search not reported.

Quality of review: A moderate quality narrative systematic review. Quality appraisal and data extraction of included studies was completed in duplicate. However, the search strategy may not have been sufficient to identify all relevant articles. Only two databases were searched plus reference list checking. Handsearching, contacting experts or grey literature searches were not conducted. Unpublished research was not sought which may have introduced publication bias. 

Results: There was a wide variation in the design and quality of the RCTs (N = 32). The greatest risk reduction for AO was seen for local treatment with tetracycline (ARR, 12%-31%). For a majority of the preventive interventions, the evidence was absent or inconclusive.

Citation: Hedström L, Sjögren P. Effect estimates and methodological quality of randomized controlled trials about prevention of alveolar osteitis following tooth extraction: a systematic review. Oral Surgery Oral Medicine Oral Pathology Oral Radiology and Endodontology. 2007; 103(1): 8-15.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Effect of combined caries-preventive methods: a systematic review of controlled clinical trials
document.topics: <![CDATA[ OUTCOMES,ORAL HEALTH DISORDERS,CAUSES & PREVENTION,DENTAL CARIES,DENTAL PUBLIC HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,PUBLIC HEALTH,RESEARCH METHODS,METHODS,ANALYSIS & RESEARCH,DENTAL HEALTH,DENTAL DECAY,DENTAL CARIES]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: This systematic review provides moderate scientific evidence that combinations of treatments involving fluoride have a preventive effect on caries in children and adolescents. However, for elderly patients the scientific evidence for the caries-preventive effect of different combinations of treatments was found to be incomplete. No conclusion could be drawn regarding the evidence for combinations of treatments being effective for groups at high caries risk, as the results from the identified clinical studies were conflicting.

Methods: Systematic review of 24 controlled studies (including 8 randomised controlled trials) to evaluate the caries-preventive effect of combined caries-preventive methods, defined as two or more different interventions in combination, each expected to prevent dental caries.

Quality of review:  Relevant papers may have been missed as only one electronic database (Medline) was searched.   Reference lists of included studies were scanned for additional papers, but unpublished research was not sought.  The quality of the included papers was assessed independently by two reviewers and graded according to a pre-determined scale. 

Results: Of the 14 studies included concerning treatment for children and adolescents 7 studies of high-value or moderate-value evidence showed a statistically signficiant beneficial effect on caries increment. 3 further studies supported these results although these were graded as limited-value evidence.

Citation: Axelsson S, Soder B, Nordenram G, et al. Effect of combined caries-preventive methods: a systematic review of combined clinical trials. Acta Odontologica Scandinavica. 2004; 62(3): 163-169.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Effect of Herbst treatment on temporomandibular joint morphology: a systematic literature review
document.publisher: American Journal of Orthodontics and Dentofacial Orthopedics
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,DENTO-FACIAL ANOMALIES,ORTHODONTICS]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Prospective controlled studies using serial magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and tomography are required to establish the effect of Herbst treatment on temporomandibular jount (TMJ)morphology.

Method: A systematic review of 5 ‘internal controls’ studies of Herbst treatment of Class II patients using magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), computerized tomography scans, or tomograph. TMJ morphology was assessed with special reference to glenoid fossa remodeling, condylar remodeling, condylar position, and articular disc position. Literature search to 2001. 

Quality of study: The literature search is restricted to English language articles and the authors do not state whether unpublished research was sought. The evidence is limited by the small number of studies and methodological deficiencies, as acknowledged by the authors.

Results: All studies used internal controls with pre-treatment and post-treatment imaging. Four studies used MRI, and 1 used tomograms. The 4 MRI studies used overlapping patient samples and were not considered as independent evidence. The MRI studies did not provide conclusive evidence of osseous remodelling or condyle position change. The tomography study demonstrated minor condyle position change relative to the glenoid fossa.

Citation: Popowich K, Nebbe B, Major PW.  Effect of Herbst treatment on temporomandibular joint morphology: a systematic literature review.  American Journal of Orthodontics and Dentofacial Orthopedics 2003; 123(4):388-94.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Effect of loading time on the success of complete mandibular titanium implant retained overdentures: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,RESTORATIVE DENTISTRY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: No deleterious effects up to 24 months have been shown from immediate or early loading. Conventional loading after a 3-month healing period has not been proven to be the only acceptable protocol for mandibular IOD, but further long-term studies are needed to confirm this.

Methods: A systematic review of nine prospective comparative studies (5 RCTs, 4 CCTs) to compare the effect of timing of loading initiation on the success of mandibular IOD. Literature search from database inception to 1 September 2005.

Quality of review: The review has a well-defined research question and inclusion criteria. However results are limited by the search strategy which may not have been sufficient to identify all relevant articles. While Medline was searched using comprehensive search terms and were journals handsearched; additional databases, reference list checking, contacting experts and website searches may have identified further papers. The search was restricted to published papers in the English language, which may have introduced publication and language bias. There is also limited information on the statistical methods used to combine data for effect of indices by mode of loading.

Results: Three immediate loading trials showed an increase in the amount of marginal bone loss over time, while the majority of early and conventionally loaded implants exhibited a decrease in the amount of bone loss in the second year compared with the first 12-month period. Probing depth at 24 months showed a significant difference between early and conventional loading; SMD 0.5 (95% confidence interval 0.03, 0.97). No other statistically significant differences were found between either immediate or early and conventional loading for any indices.

Citation: Kawai Y, Taylor JA. Effect of loading time on the success of complete mandibular titanium implant retained overdentures: a systematic review. Clinical Oral Implants Research 2007; 18 (4): 399–408.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Effect of maxillary sinus augmentation on the survival of endosseous dental implants. A systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PERIODONTOLOGY,RESTORATIVE DENTISTRY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Insufficient data were present to statistically evaluate the effects of smoking, residual crestal bone height, screw versus press-fit implant design, or the effect of implant surface micromorphology other than machined versus rough surfaces.

There are insufficient data to recommend the use of platelet-rich plasma in sinus graft surgery.

Methods: Systematic review to determine the efficacy of sinus augmentation procedure compared to various surgical techniques. 43 studies were included (3 randomised controlled clinical trials 5 controlled trials, 12 case series, and 23 retrospective analyses). 34 were lateral window interventions, 5 were osteotome interventions, 2 were localised management of the sinus floor, and 2 involved the crestal core technique. Literature search to Apirl 2003.

Quality of review: A reasonable attempt was made to identify all relevant literature. Several databases were searched, selected journals handsearched and reference lists of included studies checked. Authors were also contacted to identify unpublished research, however only English language papers were included which may have introduced bias.  Four reviewers independently assessed the quality of the included studies.

Results:  Meta-regression was performed to determine the effect of the variables of block versus particulate grafting techniques, implant surface, graft material, and the use of a membrane over the lateral window. The survival rate of implants placed in sinuses augmented with the lateral window technique varied between 61.7% and 100%, with an average survival rate of 91.8%.

For lateral window technique:

  • Implant survival rates reported in this systematic review compare favorably to reported survival rates for implants placed in the non-grafted posterior maxilla.
  • Rough-surfaced implants have a higher survival rate than machine-surfaced implants when placed in grafted sinuses.
  • Implants placed in sinuses augmented with particulate grafts show a higher survival rate than those placed in sinuses augmented with block grafts.
  • Implant survival rates were higher when a membrane was placed over the lateral window.
  • The utilization of grafts consisting of 100% autogenous bone or the inclusion of autogenous bone as a component of a composite graft did not affect implant survival.
  • There was no statistical difference between the covariates of simultaneous versus delayed implant placement, types of rough-surfaced implants, length of follow-up, year of publication, and the evidence level of the study.

Citation: Wallace SS, Froum SJ. Effect of maxillary sinus augmentation on the survival of endosseous dental implants. A systematic review. Annals of Periodontology. 2003; 8(1): 328-343

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Effect of periodontal disease treatment during pregnancy on preterm birth incidence: a metaanalysis of randomized trials
document.publisher: American Journal of Obstetrics and Gynecology
document.topics: <![CDATA[ OUTCOMES,PUBLIC HEALTH,POPULATIONS,GROUPS,INFECTIOUS DISEASES,PERIODONTOLOGY,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORAL HEALTH,INFECTIONS,MONTHLY ADDITIONS,ORAL HEALTH DISORDERS,WOMEN,POPULATION GROUPS,MOUTH AND GUM INFECTIONS,PREGNANT WOMEN,ADULTS,ADDED 2009,2009 AUGUST,SEPT 09]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors’ conclusions: If ongoing large and well-designed randomized trials support our results, we might need to reassess current practice or at least be cautious prior to rejecting treatment of periodontal disease with scaling and/or root planing during pregnancy.

Methods: A systematic review and meta-analysis of seven randomised controlled trials (total 2663 participants) to determine the effect of treatment for periodontal disease during pregnancy. Database search dates inception to January 2008.

Quality of review: The authors searched several databases (Medline, Central and Web of Science) without language restrictions. Whilst the search terms were somewhat restrictive, the database search was supplemented by checking reference lists of included papers and hand searching three journals. The process used for study selection, quality assessment and data extraction are unclear and the introduction of bias cannot be excluded. The quality of the included studies was limited with a high risk of bias in at least three studies. Only two studies had adequate randomisation, allocation concealment and blinding. Neither of these studies (which also had the largest sample size) showed statistically significant results.

Results: Treatment resulted in significantly lower PTB (odds ratio [OR], 0.55; 95% confidence interval [CI], 0.35-0.86; P = .008) and borderline significantly lower LBW (OR, 0.48; 95% CI, 0.23-1.00; P = .049). Note: the overall result for LBW touches the line of no effect.  No difference was found for spontaneous abortion/stillbirth (OR, 0.73; 95% CI, 0.41-1.31; P = .292). Subgroup analysis suggested significant effect of treatment in the absence of history of PTB or LBW (OR, 0.48; 95% CI, 0.29-0.77; P = .003) and less severe periodontal disease as defined by probing depth (OR, 0.49; 95% CI, 0.28-0.87; P = .014) or bleeding on probing site (OR, 0.37; 95% CI, 0.14-0.95; P = .04).

Citation: Polyzos NP, Polyzos IP, Mauri D, Tzioras S, Tsappi M, Cortinovis I, Casazza G. Effect of periodontal disease treatment during pregnancy on preterm birth incidence: a metaanalysis of randomized trials. American Journal of Obstetrics and Gynecolology 2009; 200(3):225-32.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Effect of periodontal treatment on serum c-reactive protein levels: a systematic review and meta-analysis
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,PERIODONTOLOGY,TREATMENT & MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions:  Although there is currently a large body of evidence to indicate that serum CRP levels are elevated in patients with chronic periodontal disease, further investigation is needed to support periodontal treatment intervention as a means of controlling systemic inflammation in the general population. Based on the findings of this review, it is highly unlikely that CRP levels can be modulated by a single episode of non-surgical periodontal treatment in patients with severe periodontal disease.

Methods:  A systematic review and meta-analysis of randomised controlled trials and single-cohort studies to examine the effect of periodontal treatment on systemic C-reactive protein (CRP) levels.

Quality of study: It is possible that the search strategy did not identify all relevant papers.  Only Medline and the CCTR were searched using narrow search terms, together with reference lists from selected papers.  Non-English language papers were not sought and it is unclear whether unpublished research was sought, which may have introduced language and publication biases. The authors conducted a formal quality assessment on the three RCTs, however there was limited assessment of the seven cohort studies.  All included studies had small sample sizes and there were additional methodological issues identified with two of the three RCTs.  The authors correctly indicate the need for further, high quality research in this area.

Results:  The meta-analysis of the RCTs showed that there is no statistically significant difference in serum CRP levels between the two arms. Similarly, results from the single-cohort studies showed that the difference on serum CRP levels was not significantly different before and after treatment.

Citation:  Ioannidou E, Malekzadeh T, Dongari-Bagtzoglou A.  Effect of periodontal treatment on serum c-reactive protein levels: a systematic review and meta-analysis. J Periodontol 2006; 77:1635-1642

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Effectiveness and safety of nicotine replacement therapy assisted reduction to stop smoking: systematic review and meta-analysis
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,DENTAL PUBLIC HEALTH]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: This review found evidence that nicotine assisted reduction to stop programmes can be effective in achieving sustained abstinence from smoking of six months. There was no evidence of an increase in life threatening problems, and nicotine replacement therapy was well tolerated, with almost no difference in discontinuation because of side effects in those receiving nicotine replacement therapy compared with those receiving placebo. Nausea was significantly more common with nicotine replacement therapy than with placebo, but only one in 30 users became nauseous because of treatment. The results imply that compared with placebo twice the number of smokers sustained six months’ abstinence as a result of nicotine replacement therapy. This equates to about an additional 3% of all smokers quitting who would otherwise not have done so. This is a similar effect size to treating smokers who are motivated to quit, where 4-5% might be expected to abstain for six months owing to use of nicotine replacement therapy. Most of the evidence, however, comes from trials with regular behavioural support and monitoring and it is unclear whether using nicotine replacement therapy without regular contact would be as effective.

Methods: A systematic review and meta-analysis of seven placebo-controlled RCTs (2767 smokers) to determine the effectiveness and safety of nicotine replacement therapy assisted reduction to stop smoking. Database search dates: 1992 to November 2007.

Quality of review: A well conducted systematic review which updates the results of a Health Technology Assessment on this topic conducted by the authors. The authors searched a wide range of databases (Cochrane Library Medline, Embase, CINAHL, PsycINFO, Science Citation Index) using a comprehensive search strategy without language restrictions. The electronic search was supplemented by contacting experts, authors and NRT manufacturers.

Appropriate methods were used to limit error and bias in study selection, data extraction and quality assessment. All seven included studies were found to be of high quality.

Results: 6.75% of smokers receiving nicotine replacement therapy attained sustained abstinence for six months, twice the rate of those receiving placebo (relative risk (fixed effects) 2.06, 95% confidence interval 1.34 to 3.15; (random effects) 1.99, 1.01 to 3.91; five trials). The number needed to treat was 29. All other cessation and reduction outcomes were significantly more likely in smokers given nicotine replacement therapy than those given placebo. There were no statistically significant differences in adverse events (death, odds ratio 1.00, 95% confidence interval 0.25 to 4.02; serious adverse events, 1.16, 0.79 to 1.50; and discontinuation because of adverse events, 1.25, 0.64 to 2.51) except nausea, which was more common with nicotine replacement therapy (8.7% v 5.3%; odds ratio 1.69, 95% confidence interval 1.21 to 2.36).

Citation: Moore D, Aveyard P, Connock M, Wang D, Fry-Smith A, Barton P. Effectiveness and safety of nicotine replacement therapy assisted reduction to stop smoking: systematic review and meta-analysis. BMJ. 2009; 338(23):b1024.

Access: Full text is freely available.

Note: This review is an updated extension and summary of a Health Technology Assessment on this topic conducted by the authors: 'Cut down to quit' with nicotine replacement therapies in smoking cessation.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Effectiveness of antibiotic prophylaxis in third molar surgery: a meta-analysis of randomized controlled clinical trials
document.publisher: Journal of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORAL SURGERY,IMPACTED THIRD MOLARS]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Systemic antibiotics given before the surgery were effective in reducing the frequencies of alveolar osteitis (AO) and wound infection after third molar surgery.

Methods: Systematic review and meta-analysis of 20 randomised controlled trials to examine the effectiveness of antibiotic prophylaxis in third molar surgery in terms of alveolar osteitis and surgical wound infection. Literature search dates not reported.

Quality of review: Generally a well-conducted systematic review employing a good search strategy for both published and unpublished research, without language restrictions. A test for publication bias was conducted (none detected) and studies were statistically homogeneous. Data extraction and quality assessment was performed for the included studies but it is not reported whether this was performed in duplicate by independent reviewers (a method used to limit potential bias).

Results: A total of 2,932 patients randomized in 16 clinical trials reported AO as an outcome. AO occurred in 84 of 1,350 patients in the treatment group, a frequency of 6.2%; and in 228 of 1,582 patients in the control group, a frequency of 14.4%. Systemic antibiotic therapy was effective in reducing the risk of AO (odds ratio [OR] 2.175) with an NNT of 13. A total of 2,396 patients randomized in 12 clinical trials reported wound infection as an outcome. Wound infection occurred in 44 of 1,110 patients in the treatment group, a frequency of 4%; and in 78 of 1,286 patients in the control group, a frequency of 6.1%. Systemic antibiotic therapy was effective in reducing the risk of wound infection (OR 1.794) with an NnT of 25. Antibiotics reduced the risk of AO and wound infection only when first dose was given before surgery.

Citation: Ren Y, Malmstrom HS. Effectiveness of Antibiotic Prophylaxis in Third Molar Surgery: A Meta-Analysis of Randomized Controlled Clinical Trials. Journal of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery 2007; 65(10): 1909-1921.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance.  You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Effectiveness of fluoride in preventing caries in adults
document.topics: <![CDATA[ OUTCOMES,ORAL HEALTH DISORDERS,ADULTS,POPULATION BASED & PREVENTATIVE SERVICES,HEALTH PROTECTION,ORAL DISORDERS,ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,CAUSES & PREVENTION,DENTAL PUBLIC HEALTH,DENTAL CARIES,PUBLIC HEALTH,MANAGEMENT & INTERVENTIONS,SERVICES,RESEARCH METHODS,METHODS,ANALYSIS & RESEARCH,POPULATIONS,AGE GROUPS,GROUPS,DENTAL HEALTH,DENTAL CARIES,DENTAL DECAY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: The findings suggest that fluoride prevents caries among adults of all ages.

Methods: a systematic review and meta-analysis of 19 studies (10 RCTs, 8 cross-sectional, 1 CCT and 1 prospective cohort) to examine the effectiveness of self- and professionally applied fluoride and water fluoridation among adults. Literature search from database inception to 2004.

Quality of review: The results should be viewed with caution. The search strategy is poor and insufficient detail is provided on the results of individual studies, the statistical methods used and the rationale for the varying subgroup analyses conducted. The review also included several cross-sectional studies (8 out of the 20 studies) which do not allow a causal link between exposure and caries to be determined. In addition one of the included studies (Rickles and Becks, 1951) had a split mouth design  which is inappropriate for fluoride because of wash over.

Despite also seeking unpublished research by contacting experts, it is likely that key papers have been missed as only three databases were searched (Medline, Embase and Central) using very limited search terms, plus reference list checking. Only English language studies were included which may have introduced language bias. Furthermore the searches were conducted in 2004, with over a two year gap in the literature covered to when the review was published in 2007. It is worth noting that the date of the most recent study identified was 1998. Update searches, additional databases, comprehensive search terms, website searching and handsearching journals may have identified additional papers.

The results of individual studies are shown in forest plots but the actual values of are not reported. Several sub-group analyses are conducted in the results section without a rationale for doing so. For example, there were 18 studies examining any fluoride in any ages and coronal caries, but the difference in annual coronal caries increment was calculated for 11 studies, whilst the result reported in the abstract is based on the 6 studies published during/after 1980.

Results: Among studies published during/after 1980, any fluoride (self- and professionally applied or water fluoridation) annually averted 0.29 (95%CI: 0.16–0.42) carious coronal and 0.22 (95%CI: 0.08–0.37) carious root surfaces. The prevented fraction for water fluoridation was 27% (95%CI: 19%–34%).

Citation: Griffin SO, Regnier E, Griffin PM, Huntley V. Effectiveness of fluoride in preventing caries in adults. Journal of Dental Research 2007; 86(5): 410-415

Access: Full-text online access of this paper is freely available.Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. Full text online access is available to NHS staff in England via ATHENS passwords. To apply for an ATHENS password and access this resource and many others please go to the ATHENS registration page. 

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Effectiveness of manual therapies: the UK evidence report
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,DENTO-FACIAL ANOMALIES]]>
document.body:
This is a provisional record for information. The review has been identified as potentially meeting our quality criteria. It will be critically appraised and a quality statement provided as soon as possible.

 

Background: The purpose of this report is to provide a succinct but comprehensive summary of the scientific evidence regarding the effectiveness of manual treatment for the management of a variety of musculoskeletal and non-musculoskeletal conditions.

Methods: The conclusions are based on the results of systematic reviews of randomized clinical trials (RCTs), widely accepted and primarily UK and United States evidence-based clinical guidelines, plus the results of all RCTs not yet included in the first three categories. The strength/quality of the evidence regarding effectiveness was based on an adapted version of the grading system developed by the US Preventive Services Task Force and a study risk of bias assessment tool for the recent RCTs.

Results: By September 2009, 26 categories of conditions were located containing RCT evidence for the use of manual therapy: 13 musculoskeletal conditions, four types of chronic headache and nine non-musculoskeletal conditions. We identified 49 recent relevant systematic reviews and 16 evidence-based clinical guidelines plus an additional 46 RCTs not yet included in systematic reviews and guidelines.Additionally, brief references are made to other effective non-pharmacological, non-invasive physical treatments.

Conclusions: Spinal manipulation/mobilization is effective in adults for: acute, subacute, and chronic low back pain; migraine and cervicogenic headache; cervicogenic dizziness; manipulation/mobilization is effective for several extremity joint conditions; and thoracic manipulation/mobilization is effective for acute/subacute neck pain. The evidence is inconclusive for cervical manipulation/mobilization alone for neck pain of any duration, and for manipulation/mobilization for mid back pain, sciatica, tension-type headache, coccydynia, temporomandibular joint disorders, fibromyalgia, premenstrual syndrome, and pneumonia in older adults. Spinal manipulation is not effective for asthma and dysmenorrhea when compared to sham manipulation, or for Stage 1 hypertension when added to an antihypertensive diet. In children, the evidence is inconclusive regarding the effectiveness for otitis media and enuresis, and it is not effective for infantile colic and asthma when compared to sham manipulation.Massage is effective in adults for chronic low back pain and chronic neck pain. The evidence is inconclusive for knee osteoarthritis, fibromyalgia, myofascial pain syndrome, migraine headache, and premenstrual syndrome. In children, the evidence is inconclusive for asthma and infantile colic 

Citation: Bronfort G, Haas M, Evans R, Leininger B, Triano J, Bronfort G et al. Effectiveness of manual therapies: the UK evidence report. Chiropractic & Osteopathy 2010; 18:3 

Access: Full-text of this document is freely available.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Effectiveness of topical administration of opioids in palliative care: a systematic review
document.publisher: Journal of Pain and Symptom Management
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORAL CANCER,TREATMENT & MANAGEMENT,ORAL CARE FOR CANCER PATIENTS,SPECIAL CARE DENTISTRY,CANCER PATIENTS]]>
document.body:
Authors’ conclusions: this review concludes that there is support for the use of topical opioids, but does not permit us to make clear recommendations for clinical practice in terms of the ideal opioid, the starting dose, interval of administration, methods of titration, or carrier, nor are we able to identify which wounds are most suitable for this treatment. Despite clear clinical benefits described in small RCTs, there is a deficiency of higher-quality evidence on the role of topical opioids, and more robust primary studies are required to inform practice recommendations. N-of-1 trials should be encouraged for specific clinical circumstances.

Methods: A narrative systematic review of 19 studies (6 RCTs and 13 case reports) to examine whether topical opioids are effective in controlling pain in palliative care settings. Literature search dates not provided.

Quality of review: The authors searched a wide range of databases (Medline, Embase, CINAHL, CancerLit, www.controlledtrials.com and Evidence-based Medicine Reviews) supplemented by reference list checking and hand searching. However the search terms used were limited and may not have identified all relevant papers. Whilst grey literature sources were searched, inclusion was limited to published studies in English and German languages which may have introduced bias.

No information is provided on the process used to select studies for inclusion, but data extraction was conducted by two reviewers. The quality of the six RCTs was assessed using the Jadad scale and was found to be limited in three studies (lack of blinding and small sample sizes were mentioned). Only limited information is provided on the quality and the results of included studies.

Results: Five opioids were investigated [diamorphine, morphine (sulfate and hydrochloride), methadone,oxycodone, and meperidine (pethidine)]. The ulcers treated included both malignant and nonmalignant wounds, as well as oropharyngeal mucositis. Opioids were applied every two to three hours in trials on mouthwashes, and one to six times daily to skin wounds. Eighteen studies favoured topical opioids in pain relief, as evidenced by reductions in post-treatment pain scores, but time to onset and duration of analgesia varied widely.

Citation: LeBon B, Zeppetella G, Higginson IJ. Effectiveness of topical administration of opioids in palliative care: a systematic review. Journal of Pain and Symptom Management 2009; 37(5):913-7.

Access: Full-text online access to this article requires subscription to the journal.  NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Effects of 0.2% chlorhexidine gluconate and amoxicillin plus clavanic acid on the prevention of alveolar osteitis following mandibular third molar extractions
document.publisher: Oral Surgery, Oral Medicine, Oral Pathology, Oral Radiology, and Endodontics
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORAL SURGERY,IMPACTED THIRD MOLARS,PROPHYLACTIC REMOVAL]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusion: It would be more beneficial to use chlorhexidine solution with a beta-lactamase inhibitor-containing antibiotic (amoxicillin plus clavulanic acid) to enhance its effectiveness for the prevention of alveolar osteitis.

Method: A randomised controlled trial of 177 patients (53.7% female, mean age 24 years) to evaluate the use of 0.2% chlorhexidine plus amoxicillin clavulanic acid combination as a prophylactic therapy for the prevention of alveolar osteitis after mandibular third molar extractions. Patients were allocated to receive 0.22% chlorhexidine gluconate alone, 2% chlorhexidine plus amoxicillin clavulanic acid combination or 0.09% sterile saline solution. All patients were recalled for the diagnosis of alveolar osteitis on the third and seventh postoperative days. Adverse reactions to chlorhexidine were also assessed.

Quality of study: Concealment of treatment allocation is not indicated. There is no information on the flow of participants during the trial period (dropouts, if any) and therefore it cannot be assumed that an intention-to-treat analysis was carried out. Although the use of placebo and blinding of surgeons (outcome assessors) is reported, the difference in the length of prescribed treatments makes the possibility of blinding unclear. Baseline characteristics are reported in the same table as the main outcome data and measures of dispersion and precision are not presented.

Results: When patients in the antibiotic group (amoxicillin plus clavulanic acid) were compared with those in the other two groups a significant reduction in alveolar osteitis was noted (p <0.05). An alteration in taste, the bad taste of the solution, and staining of dentures and oral tissues were the major complaints about chlorhexidine.

Citation:  Delilbasi C, Saracoglu U, Keskin A. Effects of 0.2% chlorhexidine gluconate and amoxicillin plus clavulanic acid on the prevention of alveolar osteitis following mandibular third molar extractions. Oral Surgery Oral Medicine Oral Pathology Oral Radiology and Endodontics 2002; 94(3): 301-304.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Effects of antioxidant supplements on cancer prevention: Meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,ORAL CANCER,PREVENTION]]>
document.body:
This is a provisional record for information. The review has been identified as potentially meeting our quality criteria. It will be critically appraised and a quality statement provided as soon as possible.

 

Background: This meta-analysis aimed to investigate the effect of antioxidant supplements on the primary and secondary prevention of cancer as reported by randomized controlled trials.

Methods: We searched Medline (PubMed), Excerpta Medica database, and the Cochrane Review in October 2007. Results: Among 3327 articles searched, 31 articles on 22 randomized controlled trials, which included 161 045 total subjects, 88 610 in antioxidant supplement groups and 72 435 in placebo or no-intervention groups, were included in the final analyses.

Results: In a fixed-effects meta-analysis of all 22 trials, antioxidant supplements were found to have no preventive effect on cancer [relative risk (RR) 0.99; 95% confidence interval (CI) 0.96-1.03). Similar findings were observed in 12 studies on primary prevention trials (RR 1.00; 95% CI 0.97-1.04) and in nine studies on secondary prevention trials (RR 0.97; 95% CI 0.83-1.13). Further, subgroup analyses revealed no preventive effect on cancer according to type of antioxidant, type of cancer, or the methodological quality of the studies. On the other hand, the use of antioxidant supplements significantly increased the risk of bladder cancer (RR 1.52; 95% CI 1.06-2.17) in a subgroup meta-analysis of four trials.

Conclusions: The meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials indicated that there is no clinical evidence to support an overall primary and secondary preventive effect of antioxidant supplements on cancer. The effects of antioxidant supplements on human health, particularly in relation to cancer, should not be overemphasized because the use of those might be harmful for some cancer 

Citation: Myung S-KK. Effects of antioxidant supplements on cancer prevention: Meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials. Annals of Oncology 2010; 21(1):166-179.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Effects of different implant surfaces and designs on marginal bone-level alterations: a review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,RESTORATIVE DENTISTRY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions:

  1. Controlled prospective studies evaluating the effect of implant surface and designs on marginal bone level (MBL) changes =3 years are few.
  2. As revealed from such studies, there is no evidence that modified surfaces are superior to non-modified implant surfaces in marginal bone preservation.
  3. One study reported on significantly improved MBL preservation for implants with a conical and micro-threaded marginal collar than implants with a cylindrical and non-threaded marginal portion after 3 years in function. The interpretation of the results from this study is difficult due to the presence of two differences in design and the absence of differences in MBL changes during the third year of function.
  4. Comparisons between implants of different systems involve evaluations of combinations of surface and designs. No implant system was found to be superior in marginal bone preservation.

Methods: A narrative systematic review of 10 studies (8 RCTs, 2 CCTs) to evaluate the effect of different implant surfaces and designs on MBL alterations.

Quality of review: As the authors indicate, there are limited clinical data on this topic. It is likely that relevant studies were missed as the authors only searched one database (PubMed) using restrictive search terms and supplemented by reference list checking. Further restricting the search to published papers in the English language may have introduced additional  bias.

No information is provided on the processes used to select and data extract included studies and the risk of error and bias being introduced cannot be excluded. Although the authors do not report using a formal process to assess the quality of included studies, they consider several quality elements including sample size, loss to follow-up, study length and appropriateness of controls.

Results: there is no evidence that modified surfaces are superior to non-modified implant surfaces in marginal bone preservation.

Citation: Abrahamsson I, Berglundh T. Effects of different implant surfaces and designs on marginal bone-level alterations: a review. Clinical Oral Implants Research 2009; 20 Suppl 4:207-15.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Effects of lip bumpers on mandibular arch dimensions
document.publisher: American Journal of Orthodontics and Dentofacial Orthopedics
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORTHODONTICS]]>
document.body:
This This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.  

 

Authors' conclusions: Our results showed increases in arch imensions that included an increase in arch length. This was attributed to incisor proclination, distalization, and distal tipping of the molars. There were also increases in arch width and intercanine and deciduous intermolar or premolar distances. The long-term stability of the effects of the lip bumper (LB) need to be elucidated.

Methods: A narrative systematic review of 1 RCT to examine the effects of lip bumper therapy on mandibular arch dimensions. Database search dates: December 1968 to January 2007.

Quality of review:  Several databases were searched, journals handsearched and reference lists checked for further studies. However, only English-language published studies were sought, which may have introduced language and publication bias. No formal method for assessing the quality of included studies is reported, although the authors do address key methodological factors in their selection criteria. Each study had to have a suitable sample size and control group, report the sexes and ages of the subjects, use study cases and lateral cephalometrics and confirm reliability through error measurement. Ultimately, the results of the review are limited by the lack of good quality research in this area.

Please note the discussion section of this review includes the results of some of the fifteen studies that were excluded due to methodological errors.

Results: Increases in arch dimensions that included an increase in arch length. This was attributed to incisor proclination, distalization, and distal tipping of the molars. There were also increases in arch width and intercanine and deciduous intermolar or premolar distances.

Citation: Hashish DI, Mostafa YA. Effect of lip bumpers on mandibular arch dimensions. American Journal of Orthodontics and Dentofacial Orthopedics 2009 Jan;135(1):106-9.

Access:  Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Effects of programs for prevention of early childhood caries
document.topics: <![CDATA[ OUTCOMES,ORAL HEALTH DISORDERS,CHILDREN,PRIMARY CARE SERVICES,POPULATION BASED & PREVENTATIVE SERVICES,ORAL DISORDERS,ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,DENTAL CARIES,PAEDIATRIC DENTISTRY,CAUSES & PREVENTION,PUBLIC HEALTH,MANAGEMENT & INTERVENTIONS,SERVICES,POPULATIONS,GROUPS,AGE GROUPS,DENTAL HEALTH,DENTAL DECAY,DENTAL CARIES]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Conclusive evidence regarding the best intervention to prevent early childhood caries could not be drawn due to the flawed design of some papers. However, fluoride-based interventions appear to be effective in young children. More studies are required to determine the best method of delivery.

Methods: A narrative systematic review of seven randomised controlled trials. Literature search 1966-2003.

Quality of review: A reasonably well conducted review. A good attempt was made to identify all relevant articles by searching a number of databases, grey literature sources, reference list checking and handsearching. Two independent reviewers assessed study quality. The authors appropriately did not pool results statistically as there was considerable heterogeneity between the studies.

Results: The initial search produced 916 citations, 19 of which met the inclusion criteria. The quality of the articles was assessed independently by the reviewers based on randomized selection and double blinding. The 7 articles included in the actual review evaluated the effects of dental health education, prenatal fluoride administration, topical fluoride application, preventive dental programs, and use of fluoridated toothpaste. Meta-analysis was not possible because of differences in the types of intervention among the studies.

Citation: Ammari JB, Baqain ZH, Ashley PF. Effects of programs for prevention of early childhood caries: a systematic review. Medical Practice and Principles 2007; 16(6) 437-442

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance.  You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Efficacy and safety of biodegradable osteofixation devices in oral and maxilliofacial surgery: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,DENTO-FACIAL ANOMALIES,DENTAL INJURIES,ORAL SURGERY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: No firm conclusions can be drawn regarding the fixation of traumatically fractured bone segments, due to the lack of controlled clinical trials. Regarding the fixation of bone segments in orthognathic surgery, only a few controlled clinical studies are available. There does not appear to be a significant short-term difference between titanium and biodegradable fixation systems regarding stability and morbidity. However, definite conclusions, especially with respect to the long-term performance of biodegradable fixation devices used in maxillofacial surgery, cannot be drawn.

Methods: A systematic review of the literature (3 RCTs and 2 CCTs) to determine the clinical efficacy and safety of biodegradable devices compared with titanium devices in oral and maxillofacial surgery. Literature search from inception to 2005.

Quality of review: A well conducted narrative systematic review. The search included three databases, reference list checking and contacting experts. There were no age or language restrictions. Two reviewers independently assessed the quality of the included studies. Appropriately, given the heterogeneity between studies, no meta-analysis was conducted.

Results: The study selection procedure revealed four methodologically ‘acceptable’ articles. Owing to the different outcome measures used in the studies, it was impossible to perform a meta-analysis. Therefore, the major effects regarding the stability and morbidity of fracture fixation using titanium and biodegradable fixation systems were qualitatively described.

Citation: Buijs GJ, Stegenga B, Bos RRM. Efficacy and safety of biodegradable osteofixation devices in oral and maxillofacial surgery: a systematic review. Journal of Dental Research 2006; 85(11):980-989.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. Full text online access is available to NHS staff in England via ATHENS passwords. To apply for an ATHENS password and access this resource and many others please go to the ATHENS registration page. 

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Efficacy and safety of the use of autologous plasma rich in platelets for tissue regeneration: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,ORAL SURGERY,PERIODONTOLOGY,TREATMENT & MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors’ conclusions: Autologous plasma rich in platelets (PRP) improves the gingival recession but not the clinical attachment level in chronic periodontitis. In the complete healing process of chronic skin ulcers, the results are inconclusive. There are little data about PRP safety. There are several methodologic limitations and, consequently, future research should focus on strong and well-designed RCTs that assess the efficacy and safety of PRP.

Methods: A systematic review and meta-analysis of twenty RCTs (11 of oral and maxillofacial surgery, 7 of chronic skin ulcers, and 2 of surgery wounds). Database search to 2006.

Quality of review: A well conducted systematic review limited by quality of the included studies. The authors searched a wide range of databases without language restrictions, supplemented by reference list checking. Appropriate processes were used to minimise error and bias in selecting, data extracting and quality assessing included studies. The Jadad scale was used to assess quality which was judged to be medium or low in most studies.

Results: Two RCTs of surgical wounds (38 patients) showed no difference between treatment groups. Four RCTs evaluated the depth reduction in gingival recession in chronic periodontitis; the SMD was 0.54 (95% confidence interval [CI], 0.16 to 0.92) mm, favorable to PRP. Three RCTs evaluated the clinical attachment level in chronic periodontitis; the SMD was 0.33 (95% CI, -0.71 to 1.37) mm. Six RCTs assessed the complete skin epithelialization in wound ulcers; the RR was 1.40 (95% CI, 0.85 to 2.31). Only 6 RCTs reported adverse effects and none showed a causal relation with the PRP application.

Citation: Martínez-Zapata MJ, Martí-Carvajal A, Solà I, Bolibar I, Angel Expósito J, Rodriguez L, García J. Efficacy and safety of the use of autologous plasma rich in platelets for tissue regeneration: a systematic review. Transfusion 2009 Jan;49(1):44-56.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Efficacy of chemical root surface modifiers in the treatment of periodontal disease. A systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,PERIODONTOLOGY,TREATMENT & MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Evidence to date suggests that the use of citric acid, tetracycline, or ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA) to modify the root surface provides no benefit of clinical significance to regeneration in patients with chronic periodontitis.

The best method for ascertaining the clinical efficacy of acid-treated root regeneration would be to conduct a randomised clinical trial with sufficient statistical power that is supported by quantitative histological evaluation.

The majority of the studies that evaluated the regenerative potential of root surface modifiers were observational in nature; therefore, the value of conclusions reached in this manuscript must be carefully considered.

Methods: Systematic review to assess the efficacy of root surface biomodification through the use of citric acid, tetracycline, or ethof ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA). 22 quasi-experimental studies, 7 case control studies and 5 case reports incorporating a total patient population of 575 were included. Literature search to September 2002. 

Quality of review: It is difficult to determine whether the search strategy was thorough; despite searches in several databases and on the internet and handsearching.  It is unclear whether unpublished research or non-English language papers were sought. Studies were quality graded independently by two reviewers.

Results:  26 studies were analysed for citric acid, 5 for tetracycline, and 3 for EDTA treatment.

Four of 8 human histological studies reported regeneration with the use of citric acid. Only 1 of 18 clinical studies reported attachment gain. 

Of the 5 studies examined using tetracycline, 1 histological study and 1 clinical study reported attachment gain.

No regeneration was reported in the 3 studies evaluating the use of ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA).

Meta-analysis performed on 28 clinical trials did not show any significant effects of acid root treatment on attachment level gains or probing depth.

Citation: Mariotti A. Efficacy of chemical root surface modifiers in the treatment of periodontal disease. A systematic review. Annals of Periodontology. 2003; 8(1): 205-226

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Efficacy of clinical methods to assess jawbone tissue prior to and during endosseous dental implant placement: a systematic literature review
document.publisher: International Journal of Oral and Maxillofacial Implants
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ENDODONTICS,ORAL SURGERY,RESTORATIVE DENTISTRY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: The evidence for the efficacy of clinical methods to assess jawbone tissue prior to and during endosseous dental implant placement is sparse. This emphasises the need for studies that incorporate accepted methodological criteria for diagnostic efficacy.

Methods: A systematic review of seven diagnostic studies to evaluate the diagnostic accuracy of clinical methods to assess bone density, quantity or quality prior to and during dental implant placement. Literature search to September 2005.

Quality of review: Whilst, the potential for bias was limited by selecting, data extracting and quality assessing papers in duplicate by independent reviewers, the review should be viewed with caution as the search was insufficient to identify relevant literature and there were inaccuracies in reporting.

The only database searched was PubMed using a complex but very restrictive search strategy which may have excluded potentially relevant articles. The database search was supplemented by reference list checking, but additional databases, handsearching key journals and contacting experts may have identified further papers. Limiting inclusion to papers with an abstract may well have resulted in the exclusion of relevant papers. In addition, the search was restricted to published papers in the English language which may have introduced language and publication bias.

Results: In one study, no method was presented as the test method. In six studies, the results of the test method were compared to those of a reference method. However, only one study presented the results in terms of percentage of correct diagnoses. In that study, the use of periapical radiography together with reference images yielded correct assessment of the trabecular pattern of the mandible in 3 categories in 58% of the sites. The kappa index of interobserver agreement was 0.35 and intraobserver agreement was 0.67. Corresponding kappa values for 4 classes of bone quality presented by Lekholm and Zarb were 0.33 and 0.43, respectively. No study examined the accuracy of the method originally described by Lekholm and Zarb.

Citation: Ribeiro-Rotta RF, Lindh C, Rohlin M. Efficacy of clinical methods to assess jawbone tissue prior to and during endosseous dental implant placement: a systematic literature review.International Journal of Oral and Maxillofacial Implants 2007; 22(2): 289-300.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance.  You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Efficacy of dental prophylaxis (rubber cup) for the prevention of caries and gingivitis: a systematic review of literature
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,DENTAL CARIES,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,CAUSES & PREVENTION,PREVENTION]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Prophylaxis before professionally applied topical fluoride (PATF) does not improve caries prevention in children. This finding cannot be generalised to adolescents and adults due to a lack of such studies in these populations. Furthermore, dental prophylaxis provided at four monthly or six monthly intervals has been shown to have no therapeutic benefit in the prevention of gingivitis in adults. This review highlights the need for additional research on the therapeutic benefits of prophylaxis. It is therefore recommended that:

  • For the prevention of caries in children: dental prophylaxis need not be provided either at a recall visit or before the application of topical fluorides.
  • For the prevention of gingivitis in the general population: dental prophylaxis (rubber cup) at recall appointments (of intervals of four or six months) is not effective for the prevention or treatment of gingivitis.

Methods: A narrative systematic review of six studies (3 RCTs, 3 CCTs) to assess the efficacy of routine dental prophylaxis applied before professionally applied topical fluoride (PATF) or at a regular recall visit in the prevention of caries or gingivitis. Database search dates: 1966 to Feb 2009.

Quality of review: The results and conclusions are limited by the small number of included studies. The authors searched a wide range of databases, supplemented by reference list checking. However, it is possible that potentially relevant studies were missed and bias introduced as the search terms were restrictive and the search was limited to published studies in the English language.

The authors used appropriate methods to select included papers, however those used to quality assess and data extract papers are unclear and the introduction of error and bias cannot be excluded.

Results: There was a unanimous agreement in four studies that a dental prophylaxis is not warranted before a PATF for caries prevention in children. A generalisation on dental prophylaxis before PATF cannot be applied to adolescents and adults. Available evidence (two other studies) fails to demonstrate any benefit in the prevention of gingivitis from further dental prophylaxis at interval used for recall examinations.

Citation: Azarpazhooh A, Main PA. Efficacy of dental prophylaxis (rubber cup) for the prevention of caries and gingivitis: a systematic review of literature. British Dental Journal 2009; 207(7):E14; discussion 328-9.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Efficacy of homeopathic therapy in cancer treatment
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,ORAL CANCER]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions:  There is insufficient evidence to support clinical efficacy of homeopathic therapy in cancer care.

Methods: A systematic review of five randomised and one controlled clinical trial to evaluate the clinical efficacy of homeopathic therapy in cancer care.

Quality of review: A reasonable attempt was made to locate all the relevant literature, with electronic searching across a wide range of databases.  However, this does not appear to have been supplemented by reference list follow-up, journal hand searching or personal contacts, making it possible that relevant studies were missed.  It is not clear that attempts were made to identify unpublished data or whether non-English language papers were considered, which may have introduced publication and language bias. The quality of the included studies was independently assessed by two reviewers using pre-defined criteria (Jadad score).  The authors note that even high scoring trials had methodological flaws (eg small sample sizes) and recognise that results should be treated with caution because of the lack of and sometimes the poor quality of the primary data.

Results: Five of the six included studies reported positive results but only two, related to reduction of symptoms, were statistically significant.  Both studies had limited numbers.

Citation:  Milazzo S, Russell N, Ernst E. Efficacy of homeopathic therapy in cancer treatment European Journal of Cancer 2006; 42: 282-289.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.
