document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Efficacy of periodontal treatment on glycaemic control in diabetic patients: A meta-analysis of international studies
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,TREATMENT & MANAGEMENT,ASSOCIATED CONDITIONS]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: The present meta-analysis represents the best information available to date that addresses this issue, and suggests that periodontal treatment could improve glycaemic control. Nevertheless, these results need to be viewed with caution because of a lack of robustness, and deficiencies in the design of some of the studies included. A randomized controlled trial with sufficient statistical power would help to confirm the results of this meta-analysis.

Methods: A systematic review of 25 intervention studies (9 CCTs and 16 uncontrolled studies) to investigate the effect of periodontal therapy on glycaemic control in people with diabetes. A meta-analysis was conducted of the 9 controlled studies. Database search dates: Jan 1976 – Dec 2007.

Quality of review: As the authors indicate, this review is limited by the poor quality of the included studies; characterised by small samples sizes and, in most instances, a lack of examiner blinding.

The authors have made a good attempt to identify potentially relevant studies. They searched a range of databases without language restrictions, reviewed the reference lists of included studies and looked for unpublished trials. Appropriate procedures were used to minimise error and bias in study selection, data extraction and quality assessment. Several methods were used to critically appraise the included studies. The authors identify 25 studies of which 9 were controlled trials. The meta-analysis was based on data only from the controlled trials. The purpose of including the 16 uncontrolled studies in the review is not clear as only limited reference is made to their results in the narrative.

Results: The standardized mean difference in HbA(1c) with the treatment of periodontal disease was 0.46 (95% CI: 0.11, 0.82). These findings suggest that periodontal treatment could lead to a significant 0.79% (95% CI: 0.19, 1.40) reduction in HbA(1c) level. Note: One study significantly deviated from the overall effect. Without this study the overall SMD decreased to a non-significant value of 0.27 (95% CI: -0-01-0.60).

Citation: Darre L, Vergnes JN, Gourdy P, Sixou M. Efficacy of periodontal treatment on glycaemic control in diabetic patients: A meta-analysis of international studies. Diabetes and Metabolism, 2008; 34(5): 497-506.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

________________________________________________

See also:

Matthews J, Jokstad A, Clarkson J. Weak evidence suggests scaling and root planing may help people With diabetes improve glycemic control. Journal of the American Dental Association 2009; 140: 1144-1145.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Emergency management of acute apical periodontitis in adults
document.publisher: Canadian Collaboration on Clinical Practice Guidelines in Dentistry
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,ENDODONTICS,PERIODONTOLOGY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Aims: This guideline is intended to aid clinicians in ensuring pain relief for patients with acute apical periodontitis (AAP). The recommendations in this guideline do not apply to patients with swelling , periapical radiolucency and systemic changes.

Recommendations: The recommendations are summarised below:

  • Non-surgical endodontic therapy (root canal) should be started on the affected tooth as soon as possible.
  • Patients should be given the appropriate dose of analgesics (NSAIDs if not contraindicated) pre-operatively, or immediately post-operatively. This should be continued as needed to control pain.
  • In the event endodontic therapy cannot be started immediately, appropriate analgesics should be prescribed.
  • For some patients, extraction may be an alternative to endodontic therapy.
  • If the tooth is in hyper-occlusion, the occlusion should be relieved if possible.
  • Non-surgical endodontic therapy (root canal) should be started on the affected tooth as soon as possible
  • Antibiotic therapy is not indicated for this condition.
  • Bony trephination is not indicated for this condition.

Methodology and Development Process: Evidence based guideline using a systematic review and appraisal of the evidence. Levels of evidence and the strength of the recommendations were graded. Development was carried out by a multidisciplinary team consisting of a Methodology Resource Group and a Clinical Advisory Group. 

Publication history information: This guideline was approved in October 2002, aiming to evaluate new evidence every 5 years.

Access: The Canadian Collaboration on Clinical Practice Guidelines in Dentistry (CCCD) website and guidelines are no longer available. The full-text of the systematic review which underpinned the guidelines is available to the general public.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Emergency management of acute apical periodontitis in the permanent dentition: a systematic review of the literature
document.publisher: Journal of the Canadian Dental Association
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,PERIODONTOLOGY,TREATMENT & MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: In the management of pain associated with acute apical periodontitis, there is strong evidence to support the use of systemic NSAIDs in conjunction with nonsurgical endodontics. The use of antibiotics is not recommended.

Method: A systematic review of 15 randomised controlled trials of patients presenting with acute apical periodontitis (AAP) from nonvital pulp in the permanent dentition. 8 studies contributed to a meta-analysis for intensity of pain, and 5 trials for mean pain relief. Subgroup analysis was then performed for individual interventions. Databases sought from their inception to 2001.

Quality of review: Unpublished research was not sought and only English and French language studies were included. There was significant heterogeneity in the meta-analysis for mean pain relief and intensity of pain. The results of the subgroup meta-analysis for individual interventions should be viewed with caution as they are based on a small number of trials with a limited number of participants.

Results: Sub-group meta-analysis showed that pre-emptive analgesics (nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDS)) in conjunction with pulpectomy provided a significant benefit of mean pain relief (weighted mean difference -11.70, 95% CI -22.84 to -0.56). Three interventions did not show significant benefit: systemic antibiotics, intracanal treatment with a steroid-antibiotic combination, and trephination through attached gingiva.

Citation: Sutherland S, Matthews DC. Emergency management of acute apical periodontitis in the permanent dentition: a systematic review of the literature. Journal of the Canadian Dental Association 2003; 69(3). 160-160L.

Access: Full-text freely available to the public

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Emerging risk factors for coronary heart disease: a summary of systematic reviews conducted for the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,ASSOCIATED CONDITIONS]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors’ conclusions: We did not find any direct evidence that periodontal examination would be useful for reclassifying persons classed as intermediate-risk by the Framingham risk score.
The weight of currently existing evidence suggests that there may be an important link between periodontal disease and CHD. Additional longitudinal studies with standardized measures of periodontal disease and careful adjustment for socioeconomic status as well as for traditional CHD risk factors would be useful.

Methods: A systematic review and meta-analysis of 76 prospective cohort studies. The review identified 8 papers from 7 cohorts that were relevant to periodontal disease. Database search 1966-2006 inclusive.

Quality of review: It is possible that potentially relevant papers were missed as the authors searched only one electronic database (PubMed), using very limited terms, supplemented by reference list checking. The search was further limited to English language published studies. No information is provided on the methods used to select, data extract and critically appraise included studies and the introduction of error and bias cannot be excluded. The authors used the US Preventive Services Task Force criteria to critically appraise included papers. Five were considered good quality and three were deemed fair quality

The authors note several issues including: Lack of reliability in assessment of PD. Mix of measures and self report. Also that periodontal examination requires skill with dental instruments and x-rays and the wide range of possible measures. Lack of evidence in intermediate-risk populations; particularly in ethnic groups.

Results: Follow-up ranged between 5 and 21 years. Periodontal disease was defined (and diagnosed) differently among the studies. Some studies employed dental examinations and radiographs and others relied on self report. Cardiovascular and CHD outcomes also were defined differently among the studies. Three studies were rated good quality and five were fair quality. Periodontal disease based on either self report or dental examinations was evaluated in 6 studies. Five studies showed increased risk of CHD in association with baseline periodontal disease and two showed no association, although one study found an increased risk that was not statistically significant (RR 1.5) among women. When these studies were combined in meta-analysis, the summary estimate of risk ratio was 1.24 (95% CI 1.01-1.51) for any CHD or CVD event. In subgroup analyses, the association with CHD was increased with female gender, longer follow-up times, and in studies based on dental exam rather than self-report. Gingivitis as a measure of periodontal disease was evaluated in 2 studies and both showed or suggested elevated rates of CHD death among individuals with baseline gingivitis. When combined in meta-analysis the summary estimate was 1.35 (95% CI 0.79-2.30). Bone loss was an important risk factor for subsequent CHD with 2 studies showing statistically significant relative risks from 1.36-1.90. Four studies found that tooth loss made an independent contribution to the prediction of CHD events; one fair quality study suggested increased risk but was not statistically significant. When these 4 studies were combined in meta-analysis, the summary estimate for all CHD/CVD events was 1.41 (95% CI 1.22-1.63) indicating a 41% increased risk of CHD or CVD events among individuals with 0-10 teeth at baseline.

Citation: Helfand M, Buckley DI, Freeman M, Fu R, Rogers K, Fleming C, Humphrey LL. Emerging risk factors for coronary heart disease: a summary of systematic reviews conducted for the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force. Ann Intern Med. 2009 Oct 6;151(7):496-507.

Full report: AHRQ Evidence Synthesis Number 73: Screening for Intermediate Risk Factors for Coronary Heart Disease: Systematic Evidence Synthesis. October 2009

Access: Full text of summary paper and AHRQ report both freely available.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: European review of bisphosphonates and risk of jaw osteonecrosis
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,DENTO-FACIAL ANOMALIES,SPECIAL CARE DENTISTRY,CANCER PATIENTS,OLDER PEOPLE,OSTEONECROSIS OF THE JAW]]>
document.body:
The European Medicines Agency’s Committee for Medicinal Products for Human Use (CHMP) has completed a review on the risk of jaw osteonecrosis linked to use of bisphosphonates.

The aims of the review were to determine:

  • The criteria that define osteonecrosis of the jaw related to bisphosphonates 
  • How bisphosphonates may cause osteonecrosis of the jaw
  • Whether the risk of osteonecrosis of the jaw is greater with some bisphosphonates or for some groups of patients
  • The measures that could be taken to minimise this risk

 

The CHMP concluded that “there is an increased risk of osteonecrosis of the jaw in patients using these medicines. However, further studies should be carried out to better identify the factors that increase the risk and the measures needed to minimise it.” In the meantime, the following recommendations have been reiterated:

  • Before taking any decisions concerning treatment with bisphosphonates, prescribers should take the risks and benefits for each individual patient into account.
  • Prescribers should ensure that patients with cancer go to their dentist for a check-up and find out if they need any dental treatment before they start taking a bisphosphonate. They should also ensure that patients who do not have cancer go to their dentist for a check-up if their dental health is poor.
  • During treatment with bisphosphonates, patients should maintain good oral hygiene, go for routine dental check-ups and report any symptoms in the mouth such as loose teeth, pain or swelling.
  • Dentists should be aware of the risks in patients taking bisphosphonates and should keep dental treatment as conservative and preservative as possible.
  • It is essential that prescribers, dentists and patients work together to manage the risk of osteonecrosis of the jaw.

 

The European Medicines Agency, together with regulatory authorities in Member States, will keep this issue under close review. Further information can be found in the question-and-answer document at the link above.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Evaluation of formocresol versus ferric sulphate primary molar pulpotomy: a systematic review and meta-analysis
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,DENTAL CARIES,ENDODONTICS,TREATMENT & MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' Conclusions: In primary molar teeth with exposure of vital pulps by caries or trauma, pulpotomies performed with either formocresol or ferric sulphate have similar clinical and radiographic success. Ferric sulphate may be recommended as a suitable replacement for formocresol.

Methods: A systematic review of 11 studies (4 RCTs, 4 CCTs and 3 retrospective studies) to evaluate the effects of formocresol and ferric sulphate when used as medicaments in pulpotomized primary molar teeth. Six clinical trials were included in the meta-analysis. Literature search from database inception to May 2006.

Quality of review: A range of databases were searched for relevant literature (Medline, Embase, Cochrane Library, and SCIsearch). However, additional techniques such as contacting experts, handsearching and grey literature sources may have identified additional papers. It is not reported whether the search was restricted to English language or published research only. Potential bias was reduced by data extracting and appraising included studies in duplicate by two reviewers independently.

Results: Eleven clinical studies comprising four randomized-clinical trials (RCTs), four controlled clinical trials (CCTs) and three retrospective studies were included. The results of the meta-analysis of six prospective clinical trials suggested that the two popular pulpotomy medicaments were not significantly different in terms of clinical outcomes, radiographic findings, prevalence of apical and furcal destruction, internal root resorption or pulp canal obliteration. The relative risk (RR) value and 95% CI for those parameters were 0.72 (0.43–1.23), 0.87 (0.59–1.30), 0.67 (0.27–1.66), 1.77 (0.56–5.58) and 1.41 (0.63–3.15), respectively. The overall clinical and radiographic success rates based on the data of treatments with ferric sulphate from the 11 studies included ranged from 78% to 100% (mean 91.6 ± 8.15%) and from 42% to 97% (mean 73.5 ± 18.40%), respectively.

Citation: Peng L, Ye L, Guo X, Tan H, Zhou X, Wang C, Li R. Evaluation of formocresol versus ferric sulphate primary molar pulpotomy: a systematic review and meta-analysis. International Endodontic Journal 2007; 40(10): 751–757.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance.  You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Evaluation of the effectiveness of a pre-brushing rinse in plaque removal: a meta-analysis.
document.topics: <![CDATA[ OUTCOMES,ORAL HEALTH DISORDERS,ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,CAUSES & PREVENTION,DENTAL CARIES,DENTAL PUBLIC HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PUBLIC HEALTH,METHODS,RESEARCH METHODS,ANALYSIS & RESEARCH,DENTAL DECAY,DENTAL HEALTH]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Although PLAX use appears to offer some benefit in plaque and gingivitis reduction, the clinical magnitude of the difference and the benefit on oral health are likely to be small.

Methods: A systematic review of 19 randomised controlled trials to assess the efectiveness of the pre-brushing rinse PLAX on existing plaque and gingivitis. Papars published by December 2000 were sought.  

Quality of review: Key papers may have been missed during the literature search of this review as only English-language studies have been included and unpublished research has not been sought.  This may have also introduced publication bias. 

The included trials were heterogeneous and varied in type of control group, duration of the trials, and whether plaque was measured on all the teeth or the 6 Ramfjord teeth. The authors state though that sensitivity analyses to see whether the study characteristics had any relationship to the measured effect of PLAX, did not substantially modify the outcome.

Results: In "1 day" studies, PLAX significantly reduced plaque after rinsing (difference=0.143; 95% CI= 0.02 - 0.27; p=0.022) whereas no significant reduction was observed in post-brushing measures.

In "longitudinal" studies, plaque was significantly reduced at 1-2 weeks (difference= 0.168; 95% CI=0.09-0.24; p<0.0001) 3-4 weeks (difference=0.179; 95% CI=0.01-0.35 p=0.043) 12 weeks (difference= 0.288; 95%CI= 0.21-0.37; p<0.0001) and 24 weeks (difference= 0.257; 95%CI =0.22-0.29; p<0.0001) follow-up.

Citation: Angelillo IF, Nobile CGA, Pavia MEvaluation of the effectiveness of pre-brushing rinse in plaque removal: a meta-analysis. Journal of Clinical Periodontology 2002; 29: 301-309.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Evidence-based clinical recommendations regarding screening for oral squamous cell carcinomas
document.publisher: Journal of the American Dental Association
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,ORAL CANCER,PREVENTION,SCREENING]]>
document.body:
This is a provisional record for information. The review has been identified as potentially meeting our quality criteria. It will be critically appraised and a quality statement provided as soon as possible.

 

Background: This article presents evidence-based clinical recommendations developed by a panel convened by the American Dental Association Council on Scientific Affairs. This report addresses the potential benefits and potential risks of screening for oral squamous cell carcinomas and the use of adjunctive screening aids to visualize and detect potentially malignant and malignant oral lesions.

Tyes of studies reviewed: The panel members conducted a systematic search of MEDLINE, identifying 332 systematic reviews and 1,499 recent clinical studies. They selected five systematic reviews and four clinical studies to use as a basis for developing recommendations.

Results: The panel concluded that screening by means of visual and tactile examination to detect potentially malignant and malignant lesions may result in detection of oral cancers at early stages of development, but that there is insufficient evidence to determine if screening alters disease-specific mortality in asymptomatic people seeking dental care.

Clinical implications: The panel suggested that clinicians remain alert for signs of potentially malignant lesions or early-stage cancers while performing routine visual and tactile examinations in all patients, but particularly in those who use tobacco or who consume alcohol heavily. Additional research regarding oral cancer screening and the use of adjuncts is needed 

Citation: Rethman MP, Carpenter W, Cohen EE, Epstein J, Evans CA, Flaitz CM et al. Evidence-based clinical recommendations regarding screening for oral squamous cell carcinomas. Journal of the American Dental Association 2010; 141(5):509-520. 

Access: Full-text online access to this paper is freely available.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Evidence-based mucogingival therapy. Part 1: A critical review of the literature on root coverage procedures
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,PERIODONTOLOGY,TREATMENT & MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

  

Authors' conclusions: A standard format with minimum requirements for data collection and presentation should be established and imposed by international journals in order to provide readers and researchers with more useful information on the surgical coverage of exposed root surfaces. 

Methods: A systematic review of published case series, controlled studies, and randomised trials on surgical root coverage for treating gingival recessions. The study aimed to identify updated minimum standards for data presentation. Searches were conducted for articles published from 1970 to 2000.

Quality of review: This is a qualitative/descriptive review of the evidence. The inclusion criteria were not defined in terms of specific outcomes and participants, although outcome data are described in the tables. The literature search centres mainly on journal handsearch and reference search, although it is supplemented by a single database search.

Results: The overall clinical outcomes of different techniques appear to be satisfactory, but the published evidence is of little help in deciding which procedure is best suited for each clinical situation.

Only a more homogeneous way of collecting and reporting clinical data and especially outcome measures will allow for an effective reanalysis which could help in everyday clinical decision making.

Citation: Pagliaro U, Nieri M, Franceschi D, Clauser C, Pini-Prato G. Evidence-based mucogingival therapy. Part 1: A critical review of the literature on root coverage procedures. Journal of Periodontology 2003; 74(5): 709-40.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Facial aesthetics: is botulinum toxin treatment effective and safe? A systematic review of randomised controlled trials
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,AESTHETICS,ENT AND AUDIOLOGY,CONDITIONS,THERAPEUTIC INTERVENTIONS,NON-DRUG TREATMENTS,OTHER]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: The use of botulinum toxin type A (BTA) in non-surgical facial cosmetic procedures produces high rates of improvement with rapid onset and long duration of action (longer than four months for some patients) when compared to placebo. The effects of BTA were sustained for longer at rest than at maximum muscle contraction. The incidence of adverse effects associated with BTA is similar to placebo, with the exception of blepharoptosis which is reported to be 0-5.4% after treatment of labellar lines.

Methods: A narrative systematic review of 11 randomised controlled trials to review the efficacy of BTA in facial aesthetics and to determine whether there are any adverse effects associated with the procedure. Database search: 1977 to January 2009.

Quality of review: A reasonable quality systematic review. The authors searched a good range of databases (Medline, Embase, Central and CINAHL), supplemented by reference list checking and hand searching. However, studies may have been missed as the search terms used were limited and the search was restricted to published studies. It is unclear whether there were any language restrictions.

Whilst the process used to select studies is unclear, the authors used appropriate methods to minimise error and bias in study selection and quality assessment. Overall study quality was good, however, follow-up times were short term (4-24 weeks) and the authors highlight the need for studies to assess the effects of repeated usage.

Results: The use of BTA showed improvements in facial wrinkles over placebo, with a peak effect reported at around one month and the effects lasting between 4-6 months. No studies reported any severe adverse effects. The incidence of blepharoptosis in glabellar lines treated with BTA was reported to be between 0-5.4%, and may be related to the technique of injection into the muscles. The incidence of other side-effects such as headache, pain at injection site and mild bruising was similar in both the BTA and placebo groups.

Citation: Gadhia K, Walmsley AD. Facial aesthetics: is botulinum toxin treatment effective and safe? A systematic review of randomised controlled trials. British Dental Journal 2009; 207(5):E9; discussion 216-7. 

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Factors influencing efficiency of sliding mechanics to close extraction space: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORTHODONTICS]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors’ conclusions: The results of clinical research support laboratory results that nickel-titanium coil springs produce a more consistent force and a faster rate of closure when compared with active ligatures as a method of force delivery to close extraction space along a continuous arch wire; however, elastomeric chain produces similar rates of closure when compared with nickel-titanium springs. Clinical and laboratory research suggest little advantage of 200 g nickel-titanium springs over 150g springs. More clinical research is needed in many areas. It would seem prudent to direct  energy at well-designed randomized prospective trials identifying variables that are clinically relevant in space closure using straight wire mechanics. 

Methods: A systematic review of 10 prospective clinical trials (including 9 CCTs) to determine the strength of clinical evidence concerning the influence of various factors on the efficiency (rate of tooth movement) of closing extraction spaces using sliding mechanics. Database search dates: 1966 to 2006 inclusive.

Quality of review: The limits of the search methodology make it likely that that relevant studies were missed. Only two databases were searched using a limited search strategy, supplemented by hand searching five orthodontic specialist journals. It appears that the search was restricted to published papers in the English language which may have introduced bias. Using a wider range of terms without language restrictions, reference list checking and contacting experts may have identified additional papers. Whilst the authors do not discuss the use of a formal quality appraisal process, they do provide data on a number of quality-related issues including sample size, method of randomisation, whether a power analysis was conducted, and if the study was blinded. 

Results:

  • Elastomeric powerchain produces similar rates of retraction as 150 and 200 g nickel-titanium springs;
  • nickel-titanium springs of 150 and 200 g are more effective at closing space than active ligatures;
  • nickel-titanium springs of 200 and 150 g are equally effective in space closure;
  • arch wire size might have no effect on the rate of closure, but larger sizes control tipping better; 
  • frictional differences of arch wire type might not be the major factor in rate of closure. 

Citation: Barlow M, Kula K. Factors influencing efficiency of sliding mechanics to close extraction space: a systematic review. Orthodontics and Craniofacial Research 2008; 11(2):65-73.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page. 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Flapless surgery and its effect on dental implant outcomes
document.publisher: International Journal of Oral and Maxillofacial Implants
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORAL SURGERY,RESTORATIVE DENTISTRY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Flapless surgery appears to be a plausible treatment modality for implant placement, demonstrating both efficacy and clinical effectiveness. However, these data are derived from short-term studies with a mean interval of 19 months. The available short-term data demonstrate that flapless surgery, initially recommended for novice surgeons, actually requires more experience and presurgical planning than was originally assumed. Furthermore, this technique is often more demanding than the conventional surgical approach. Therefore, the use of flapless implant placement as a "routine" procedure in daily practice is not recommended.

Methods: A systematic review of 16 studies (9 prospective and 7 retrospective) to consider the efficacy and effectiveness of flapless surgery for endosseous dental implants. Database search dates: 1966 to August 2008.

Quality of review:  The results of this review are limited by several factors.  It is likely that potentially relevant studies were missed and bias introduced. The author searched only one electronic database, supplemented by hand searching key journals. Database search terms were highly restrictive and the search was further limited to published studies in English. As there is only one author the introduction of error and bias in study selection and data extraction cannot be excluded. Whilst the quality of included studies is not assessed, certain quality elements (sample size, follow-up period and drop-out rates) are identified. There is considerable inter-study heterogeneity in terms of outcomes, loading protocols and follow-up periods. As the author states, “more studies with similar loading protocols that objectively compare conventional surgery with a flapless approach are needed.”

Results: The available data on flapless technique indicate high implant survival overall. Prospective cohort studies demonstrated approximately 98.6% (95% CI: 97.6 to 99.6) survival, suggesting clinical efficacy, while the retrospective studies or case series demonstrated 95.9% (95% CI: 94.8 to 97.0) survival, suggesting effective treatment. Six studies reported mean radiographic alveolar bone loss ranging from 0.7 to 2.6 mm after 1 year of implant placement. Intraoperative complications were reported in four studies, and these included perforation of the buccal or lingual bony plate. Overall, the incidence of intraoperative complications was 3.8% of reported surgical procedures.

Citation: Brodala N. Flapless surgery and its effect on dental implant outcomes. International Journal of Oral and Maxillofacial Implants 2009;24 Suppl:118-25.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Fluoride interventions for root caries: a review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ OUTCOMES,ORAL HEALTH DISORDERS,MONTHLY ADDITIONS,DENTAL CARIES,TREATMENT & MANAGEMENT,ORAL DISORDERS,ORAL HEALTH,PUBLIC HEALTH,DENTAL CARIES,DENTAL DECAY,DENTAL HEALTH,2009 NOVEMBER]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Additional fluoride appears to be a preventive and therapeutic treatment for root caries.

Methods: A systematic review of six studies (5 RCTs and one uncontrolled trial) to examine the effectiveness of specific fluoride treatments on root caries activity in adults. Literature search to April 2005. 

Quality of review: Whilst the review employed reliable methods for selecting, quality assessing and data extracting, the search may have missed key papers. Only two databases (Medline and the Cochrane oral health register) were searched, and there was no reference list checking, handsearching, or contacting experts. Furthermore the search was restricted to published papers in the English language, which may have introduced language and publication bias.

Results: Out of 348 titles and abstracts, six papers fulfilled the selection criteria and were processed for data extraction. The highest level of evidence was presented in the two papers using a double-blind controlled randomised clinical trial (Wallace et al, 1993; Baysan et al, 2001). Both these studies indicate that the increased application of fluoride in the form of a high concentration dentifrice or additional mouthwash had a positive effect on the root caries incidence/severity.

Citation: Heijnsbroek M, Paraskevas S, Van der Weijden GA. Fluoride interventions for root caries: a review. Oral Health and Preventive Dentistry 2007;5(2):145-52.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Fluoride supplements, dental caries and fluorosis: a systematic review
document.publisher: Journal of the American Dental Association
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,DENTAL CARIES,CAUSES & PREVENTION]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

 

Authors' conclusions: There is weak and inconsistent evidence that the use of fluoride supplements prevents dental caries in primary teeth. There is evidence that such supplements prevent caries in permanent teeth. Mild-to-moderate dental fluorosis is a significant side effect.

Methods: A systematic review of twelve studies(twenty papers) to examine evidence regarding the effectiveness of fluoride supplements in preventing caries and five to consider their association with dental fluorosis. The review was commissioned by the American Dental Association. Database search: inception to June 2006.

Quality of review: The results are limited by the quality of the included studies.

The authors searched a range of databases supplemented by reference list checking. Only published studies in English were included, which may have introduced bias. The processes used for study selection and data extraction are unclear. However, an appropriate procedure was used to minimise error and bias in quality assessment. The authors quality assessed studies that evaluated the effectiveness of fluoride supplements and found seven to have a high and five to have a moderate risk of bias. No assessment was made of the studies looking at associations with dental fluorosis.

Results: Eleven papers from seven studies evaluated dosage schedules similar to that recommended by the American Dental Association. One study with a high risk of bias looked at the primary teeth of children during the first three years of life. It reported a 47.2 percent reduction in dental caries. Investigators in one trial involving 3- to 6-year-old children found a 43 percent difference, and another trial of children in this age group did not find a significant benefit. Researchers in several studies involving older children detected a significant reduction in caries increments in permanent teeth with the use of fluoride supplements. Seven studies (15 papers) had withdrawal rates of 30 percent or higher. All five included studies that evaluated the association between use of fluoride supplements and dental fluorosis found that use of the supplements increased the risk of mild-to-moderate fluorosis.

Citation: Ismail AI, Hasson H. Fluoride supplements, dental caries and fluorosis: a systematic review. American Dental Association, 2008; 139: 1457-1468

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Fluoride varnish in the prevention of dental caries in children and adolescents: a systematic review.
document.publisher: Journal of the Canadian Dental Association
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,DENTAL CARIES,CAUSES & PREVENTION,TREATMENT & MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: The following recommendations were developed on the basis of the evidence: 1. For high-risk populations (e.g., people with low socioeconomic status, new immigrants and refugees, First Nations and Inuit children and adolescents), fluoride varnish should be applied twice a year, unless the individual has no risk of caries, as indicated by past and current caries history. This schedule of application would permit sealants to be checked biannually to ensure retention. 2. Single-dose packages of fluoride varnish should be used for children; the varnish in such packages should be stirred vigorously before application, to ensure that any precipitated fluoride is redissolved. 3. There is good evidence of the complementary efficacy of preventive strategies such as sealants and varnish, as well as toothbrushing and nutritional counselling; oral healthcare programs should therefore include as many complementary strategies as possible.

Methods: A narrative systematic review of seven studies (5 RTCs and 2 CCTs) to consider the use of fluoride varnish for the prevention of dental caries among high-risk children and adolescents. Literature search from 2000 to 2007.

Quality of review: The results should be viewed with caution as most of  the included studies appear to be of poor quality. It is likely that the search methodology missed potentially relevant papers. Whilst the authors searched a wide range of sources, the search terms used were highly specific and only published papers in the English language were selected. Searching without language restrictions, hand-searching journals and contacting experts may have identified additional papers. This review is designed to provide more up-to-date evidence than that made available in a series of four Cochrane reviews published between 2002 and 2004 and the authors of this review might have found it helpful to take advantage of the more sensitive search strategy used in the Cochrane reviews.  The authors scored the quality of included papers using a checklist. One paper was excluded on this basis.

Citation: Azarpazhooh A, Main PA. Fluoride varnish in the prevention of dental caries in children and adolescents: a systematic review. Journal of the Canadian Dental Association 2008;74(1):73-9.

Access: Full text freely available.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Formation of a hard tissue barrier after pulp cappings in humans. A systematic review.
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ENDODONTICS]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Insufficient evidence grade does not necessarily imply that there is no effect of a pulp capping procedure or that it should not be used. Rather, the insufficient evidence underpins the need for high-quality studies.

Methods: A systematic review of 21 studies (4 RCTs, 9 CCTs and 8 Case Series) to evaluate the evidence on the formation of a hard tissue barrier after pulp capping in humans.  Literature search 1966-2004 inclusive.

Quality of review: It is likely that the search strategy did not identify all the relevant papers.  Only PubMed and the Cochrane Clinical Trial Register were searched using very narrow search terms and papers without abstracts were excluded.  Reference lists of identified studies were reviewed, but there was no search for unpublished studies and the search was limited to English language papers.  The latter restrictions point to the possible introduction of publication and language biases. The authors independently assessed the methodological quality and validity of the included studies and designated their quality as high, moderate or low. None of the 21 included studies was considered to be high quality and only one was deemed moderate. As the authors indicate, the quality of the included studies makes it difficult to offer any evidence-based conclusions.

Results:  Evidence levels were poor (one study had moderate and twenty had a low level of evidence) and there was heterogeneity between the studies. The majority of studies on pulp capping using calcium hydroxide based materials reported formation of hard tissue bridging, studies on other pulp capping materials such as bonding agents presented inferior results.

Citation: Olsson H, Petersson K, Rohlin M. Formation of a hard tissue barrier after pulp cappings in humans. A systematic review. International Endodontic Journal 2006; 39(6): 429–442.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Full-mouth treatment versus quadrant root surface debridement in the treatment of chronic periodontitis: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,PERIODONTOLOGY,TREATMENT & MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: The review suggests that mechanical or non-surgical periodontal treatment is effective but showed no difference in the periodontal clinical outcome measures between full mouth debridment and quadrant scaling and root planing (Q). The data suggested that less treatment time may be needed for full-mouth debridement therapy compared to conventional quadrant scaling and planing. Limited data from studies conducted in the 1990s showed advantages for the full mouth disinfection approach, when considering strict use of chlorhexidine compared to quadrant scaling and planing. However, this is still inconclusive and further studies are required in this field.

Methods: A systematic review and meta-analysis of seven randomised controlled trials to determine the relative efficacy of full-mouth debridement and/or disinfection versus quadrant-wise debridement. Database search to end 2007.

Quality of review: A Cochrane Review on the same topic by Eberhard et al1 was published in January 2008. Although the two reviews do not have an identical list of included studies, the same conclusions were reached. The search methodology used in this review is less comprehensive: limited to two databases plus reference lists of identified studies and restricted to published studies in English. However, the same potentially relevant studies appear to have been identified. Appropriate procedures were used to minimise error and bias in study selection, data extraction and quality assessment. The included papers were quality assessed for risk of bias.

Results: All the randomised controlled trials included in the review failed to show any statistically significant differences between the full mouth debridement and quadrant scaling and planing approaches.

Citation: Farman M, Joshi RI. Full mouth treatment versus quadrant root surface debridement in the treatment of chronic periodontitis: a systematic review. British Dental Journal, 2008; 205; 1-11.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

__________________________________________________________

1 Eberhard J, Jepsen S, Jervøe-Storm PM, Needleman I, Worthington HV. Full-mouth disinfection for the treatment of adult chronic periodontitis. Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews 2008, Issue 1. Art. No.: CD004622. DOI: 10.1002/14651858.CD004622.pub2.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Functional outcomes after organ preservation treatment in head and neck cancer: a critical review of the literature.
document.publisher: International Journal of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORAL CANCER,ORAL RADIOLOGY,ORAL SURGERY,ENT AND AUDIOLOGY,NOSE & SINUS DISORDERS,LARYNX & PHARYNX DISORDERS,SALIVARY GLAND DISORDERS,NEOPLASMS,BENIGN,MALIGNANT,NEOPLASMS,BENIGN,MALIGNANT,NEOPLASMS,BENIGN,MALIGNANT,CONDITIONS,TREATMENT & MANAGEMENT,THERAPEUTIC INTERVENTIONS,NON-DRUG TREATMENTS,SURGERY,RADIOTHERAPY,HEAD & NECK CANCER]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: The results suggest that organ preservation does not translate into function preservation for all patients with head and neck cancer.

Methods:  A systematic review of 50 studies (including two randomised controlled trials).  The review aimed to determine functional outcomes after organ preservation and to assess the impact of such treatment on speech, swallowing and quality of life in patients with head and neck cancer. Database search dates: 1990-2005.

Quality of review: The search strategy included a wide range of databases supplemented by searches of reference lists of included studies and relevant reviews.  Non-English language papers were not considered and it does not appear that unpublished research was sought suggesting the possibility that language and publication biases may have been introduced. The internal and external validity of the 50 included studies were independently assessed by two reviewers. The reporting of individual study design and results is limited. 

Results: The majority of reports suggested that organ preservation techniques have the potential to result in swallowing disorders, often related to dysmotility of the oropharyngeal and laryngeal structures, and resulting in frequent episodes of aspiration. This may lead to the need for enteral feeding in the short term for some patients while, in others, this need is life long. Speech does not appear to be affected to the same degree as swallowing.

Citation: Rieger JM, Zalmanowitz JG, Wolfaardt JF. Functional Outcomes after organ preservation treatment in head and neck cancer: a critical review of the literature. International Journal of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery 2006; 35: 581-587

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Functional outcomes and rehabilitation strategies in patients treated with chemoradiotherapy for advanced head and neck cancer: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,ORAL CANCER,ENT AND AUDIOLOGY,CONDITIONS,TREATMENT & MANAGEMENT,RADIOTHERAPY,CHEMOTHERAPY,THERAPEUTIC INTERVENTIONS,DRUG TREATMENTS,NON-DRUG TREATMENTS,CHEMOTHERAPY,RADIOTHERAPY,HEAD & NECK CANCER]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: The most common abnormalities at baseline included reduced posterior motion of the base of tongue, delay in the swallow reXex, decreased epiglottic movement, decreased laryngeal elevation, and bolus residue in the vallecula or posterior pharyngeal wall after the completion of the swallow. The same swallowing abnormalities occurred after CRT, but in higher frequencies and in greater severity. Even 1-year posttreatment, swallowing abnormalities still existed. Tumors in the nasopharynx were associated with trismus and reduced oral tongue control. Oropharynx tumors exhibited a high frequency of reduced tongue base retraction and reduced tongue strength and patients with lesions in the larynx most frequently exhibit reduced tongue base retraction, reduced anterior posterior tongue movement, delayed pharyngeal swallow, reduced laryngeal elevation, and reduced cricopharyngeal opening. In addition, CRT seems to increase the aspiration rate, and neck dissections seem to worsen laryngeal elevation.

Most of the reviewed studies were not designed to examine the eVects of swallowing therapy. Only two papers mentioned rehabilitation options, but specific information was lacking.

Methods: A narrative systematic review of 15 prospective and retrospective studies to to assess the effects of the disease and of CRT on functions such as swallowing, mouth opening, nutrition, pain and quality of life in patients with head and neck cancer and to identify techniques or strategies known to alleviate or rehabilitate the loss of function(s) associated with CRT. Database search: January 1997 to August 2007.

Quality of review: The results of this systematic review are limited by quality of the included studies. The authors searched two databases (PubMed and Cochrane) with limited terms, supplemented by checking reference lists of included papers. The search was restricted to published papers in English, Dutch and German. Given the limits of the search strategy, the possibility that relevant studies were missed cannot be excluded. Appropriate methods were used to minimise error and bias in the selection, data extraction and quality assessment of included studies.

Citation: van der Molen L, van Rossum MA, Burkhead LM, Smeele LE, Hilgers FJ. Functional outcomes and rehabilitation strategies in patients treated with chemoradiotherapy for advanced head and neck cancer: a systematic review. European Archives of Oto-Rhino-Laryngology 2009 Jun;266(6):889-900.

Access: Full text of the paper is freely available.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Garlic intake and cancer risk: an analysis using the Food and Drug Administration's evidence-based review system for the scientific evaluation of health claims
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,ORAL CANCER,RISK FACTORS]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: There was no credible evidence to support a relation between garlic intake and a reduced risk of gastric, breast, lung, or endometrial cancer. Very limited evidence supported a relation between garlic consumption and reduced risk of colon, prostate, esophageal, larynx, oral, ovarian, or renal cell cancers. [Note: results reported in the review indicate that evidence for risk reduction in colon and prostate cancer is limited and contradictory]

Methods: A narrative systematic review of 19 controlled studies (2 intervention, 4 cohort, 9 case control, 4 case cohort) to evaluate the scientific evidence for garlic intake reducing the risk for different types of cancer. Literature search dates: 1955-2007.

Quality of review: The results of this review should be viewed with caution. It is likely that potentially relevant studies were missed as the search was restricted to published papers in English and Korean identified from two electronic databases (Medline and Embase) using limited search terms. The search was supplemented only by references obtained from two colorectal cancer systematic reviews. Additional reference list checking, consulting experts, searching grey literature sources and including studies in other languages may have identified additional studies. It is notable that the authors do not reference an earlier high quality AHRQ systematic review on this topic: Mulrow et al, Garlic: effects on cardiovascular risks and disease, protective effects against cancer, and clinical adverse effects. 

The authors do not describe the processes used to select, data extract and quality assess included studies and the introduction of error and bias cannot be excluded. Quality assessment included placebo control for intervention studies, plus appropriate outcomes (no surrogate end points), population sampling and treatment of confounders, Only studies judged to be of high or moderate methodological quality were included.

Note: although it utilises data from Caucasian as well as Asian populations, the review was developed for use in a Korean setting. 

Results: There is no credible evidence to support the use of garlic for cancer risk reduction in gastric, rectal, breast, lung or endometrial cancers. Of nine studies looking at an association between garlic consumption and reduced colon cancer risk, one prospective cohort study (distal colon cancer) and two case-control studies reported a reduction in risk with garlic intake. Of four studies in prostate cancer two case control and one prospective cohort study found no association, whilst one case control study found a reduction in risk.

One case control study reported that a high use of garlic was positively associated with a reduction of cancer in the following subjects: 395 patients (1066 controls) with esophageal cancer [OR: 0.43; 95% CI: 0.28, 0.67], 527 patients (1297 controls) with larynx cancer [OR: 0.56; 95% CI: 0.38, 0.827], 749 patients (1772 controls) with oral cancer [OR: 0.61; 95% CI: 0.44, 0.85], 1031 patients (2411 controls) with ovarian cancer  [OR: 0.78; 95% CI: 0.62, 0.98] and 767 patients (1534 controls) [OR: 0.69; 95% CI: 0.53, 0.92].

Citation: Kim JY, Kwon O. Garlic intake and cancer risk: an analysis using the Food and Drug Administration's evidence-based review system for the scientific evaluation of health claims. American Journal of Clinical Nutrition 2009; 89(1):257-64.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Guided tissue regeneration for the treatment of periodontal intrabony and furcation defects. A systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,PERIODONTOLOGY,TREATMENT & MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Overall, guided tissue regeneration (GTR) is consistently more effective than open flap debridement (OFD) in the gain of clinical attachment and probing depth reduction in the treatment of intrabony and furcation defects.

Methods: Systematic review of 85 randomised and 4 cohort studies assessing the effect of physical barriers compared with surgcal controls or clinical, radiographic, adverse, and patient-centred outcomes. Literature search to January 2002.

Quality of review: A good attempt was made to identify all relevant papers.  Several databases were searched, selected journals were handsearched and reference lists of included papers were checked.  In addition, unpublished research was sought by contacting two manufacturers of GTR devices.  It is unclear whether there were any language restrictions.  The authors assessed and ranked the methodological quality of the included studies.

Results: For the primary outcome variables, in both intrabony-defect and furcation-defect studies, GTR was favored over OFD therapies (p<0.0001). 

No differences were detected among barrier types, but barrier types could explain some heterogeneity in the results. Augmentation of the GTR barrier with a particulate graft enhanced vertical probing depth (p<0.05), vertical probing attachment level and horizontal open probing attachment, but none of the intrabony outcomes.

Citation: Murphy KG, Gunsolley JC. Guided tissue regeneration for the treatment of periodontal intrabony and furcation defects. A systematic review. Annals of Periodontology. 2003 8 (1) 266-302.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Hard palate repair timing and facial growth in cleft lip and palate: A systematic review.
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,DENTO-FACIAL ANOMALIES,ORAL SURGERY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: The review highlights the importance of further research. Prospective well-designed, controlled studies, especially targeting long term results, are required to elucidate the effect of timing of hard palate repair on facial growth in patients with cleft lip and palate.

Methods: A systematic review of fifteen non-randomised retrospective studies to evaluate the effect of timing of hard palate repair on facial growth in patients with cleft lip and palate.

Quality of review: As the authors indicate, it is likely that the search strategy did not identify all relevant papers.  Only one database was searched (Medline) using narrow search terms. The search was supplemented by searching reference lists of relevant papers and hand searching two key journals.  However, limiting the search to published English language papers may have introduced publication and language biases. The authors reviewed the methodology of the included papers using a checklist from Greenhalgh’s How to read a paper.  All but four of the 15 included studies had multiple methodological flaws and there was significant heterogeneity between the studies.  Consequently, the evidence was inconclusive.

Results: Methodological deficiencies and heterogeneity of the studies prevented major conclusions.

Citation: Liao Y-F, Mars M. Hard palate repair timing and facial growth in cleft lip and palate: A systematic review. Cleft Palate-Craniofacial Journal 2006; 43 (5)563-570. 

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. Full text online access is available to NHS staff in England via ATHENS passwords. To apply for an ATHENS password and access this resource and many others please go to the ATHENS registration page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Healing of oral lichenoid lesions after replacing amalgam restorations. A systematic review
document.publisher: Oral Surgery, Oral Medicine, Oral Pathology, Oral Radiology, and Endodontics
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORAL INFECTIONS,ORAL PATHOLOGY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Protocols must be standardised to obtain valid results. The replacement of amalgam restorations can result in the resolution or improvement of oral lichenoid lesions (OLLs). Patch testing seems to be of limited value. The topographic relationship between an OLL and an amalgam restoration is a useful—but not conclusive—marker.

Methods: Systematic review of 14 cohort and 5 case-controlled trials. The study population consisted of 1158 patients (27% male and 73% female; age range, 23-79 years).

Quality of review: A well conducted systematic review of 19 studies (14 cohort and 5 case control).  Several databases were searched from 1966 to 2000.  Reference lists of included studies were also checked and experts contacted.  Resource limitations restricted papers to the English language which may have led to relevant papers being missed.  Two reviewers independently screened papers for relevance, then data extracted and critically appraised the included studies.  Because of the heterogeneity of the included studies there was no pooling of data. 

Results: From 16% to 91% of patients had positive patch test results for at least 1 mercury compound. Of 1158 patients, 636 had to have their restorations replaced. The follow-up period ranged from 2 months to 91/ 2 years. Complete healing ranged from 37.5% to 100%. The greatest improvements were seen in lesions in close contact with amalgam.

Citation: Issa Y, Brunton PA, Glenny AM, Duxbury AJ. Healing of lichenoid lesions after replacing amalgam restorations: a systematic review. Oral Surgery, Oral Medicine, Oral Pathology, Oral Radiology and Endodontology. 2004; 98(5): 553-565.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.title: Health action planning and health facilitation for people with learning disabilities: good practice guidance
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,SPECIAL CARE DENTISTRY,LEARNING DISABILITIES]]>
document.body:
The Department of Health has published guidance on health facilitation and health action planning for people with learning disabilities.

The document aims to describe and clarify good practice and to support localities to make progress on this and on reducing health inequalities experienced by people with learning disabilities. It builds on previous DH guidance and reflects the learning that has taken place since 2002 along with key recommendations of relevant recent reports and research.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Health effects associated with smokeless tobacco: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ RISK FACTORS,TOBACCO,OUTCOMES,ORAL HEALTH DISORDERS,ORAL DISORDERS,ORAL HEALTH,ORAL CANCER,PUBLIC HEALTH,DETERMINANTS,LIFESTYLE,SOCIAL DETERMINANTS,TOBACCO USE,INDIVIDUAL BEHAVIOUR,ANALYSIS & RESEARCH]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Chewing betel quid and tobacco is associated with a substantial risk of oral cancers in India. Most recent studies from the US and Scandinavia are not statistically significant, but moderate positive associations cannot be ruled out due to lack of power. Further rigorous studies with adequate sample sizes are required.

Methods: Systematic review of 95 observational studies of smokeless tobacco (ST) use, with a sample size of 500 people or more. 46 studies investigated ST use and oral and pharyngeal cancers. Literature search dates not reported.

Quality of review: This review employed a good search strategy using a several bibliographic databases and detailed search terms.  Websites were also searched, reference lists of included papers were checked for further relevant papers and experts contacted.  The search included foreign language papers, although none met the inclusion criteria.  The quality of the included papers was independently assessed by two authors.  The review is limited by the quality of those papers.

Results: Many of the studies lacked sufficient power to estimate precise risks, mainly due to the small number of ST users. Studies were often not designed to investigate ST use, and many also had major methodological limitations including poor control for cigarette smoking and imprecise measurements of exposure.

Studies in India showed a substantial risk of oral or oropharyngeal cancers associated with chewing betel quid and tobacco. Studies from other regions and of other cancer types were not consistent. Few studies have adequately considered the non-cancer health effects of ST use.

Citation: Critchley JA, Unal B. Health effects associated with smokeless tobacco: a systematic review. Thorax 2003; 58: 435-443

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. Full text online access is available to NHS staff in England via ATHENS passwords. To find out how to get an ATHENS password and access this resource and many others please refer to "Athens Registrations"  at http://www.library.nhs.uk/athens/

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Hemostatic mouthwashes in anticoagulated patients undergoing dental extraction
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORAL SURGERY,SPECIAL CARE DENTISTRY,BLEEDING DISORDERS,CARDIOVASCULAR CONDITIONS,ANTICOAGULATION]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Findings in recent studies indicate that dental extractions in anticoagulated patients can be performed without temporary discontinuation of oral anticoagulant therapy with the use of hemostatic mouthwashes to control localized bleeding. This practice should be more widely adopted due to minimized bleeding and thromboembolic risks.

Methods: Systematic review of eight clinical trials (six randomised) to evaluate  the efficacy and safety of local acting hemostatic agents in patients undergoing dental extractions and taking oral anticoagulants. Literature search to July 2006.

Quality of review: This review should be viewed with caution. The methods used are poorly reported and there is only limited information regarding inclusion criteria. It is likely that the search strategy was insufficient to identify all relevant studies. Only published papers in the English language were included which may have introduced publication and language bias. No formal method for assessing the quality of included papers is reported, however some quality aspects of studies are discussed in the results.

Results: Eight studies evaluated tranexamic acid; one assessed epsilon aminocaproic acid. All studies were reviewed for efficacy and safety of hemostatic mouthwashes and intensity of continued anticoagulation therapy. The studies enrolled populations that varied in the indications for oral anticoagulation (OA), target INR ranges, and oral surgeries performed. Patients receiving uninterrupted OA and using hemostatic mouthwashes had no greater and, in some cases, lesser bleeding incidence compared with various other treatment groups (including interrupted OA, uninterrupted OA, autologous fibrin glue with uninterrupted OA, and reduced OA with heparin bridge). No severe adverse effects were reported. No studies assessed the risk of thromboembolism between the different treatment strategies.

Citation: Patatanian E, Fugate, SE. Hemostatic mouthwashes in anticoagulated patients undergoing dental extraction. Annals of Pharmacotherapy 2006; 40(12): 2205-2210

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance.  You can find your local library via the My Library home page.  

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: How long do routine dental restorations last - a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,DENTAL CARIES,RESTORATIVE DENTISTRY,TREATMENT & MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: The review suggests 50% of all restorations are expected to last between 10 and 20 years. However a formal statistical analysis could not be explored due to the lack of comparative, high quality studies.

Methods: A systematic review of eight studies (1 non-randomised controlled trial, 1 prospective longitudinal study and 6 retrospective longitudinal studies) on the longevity of routine dental restorations in permanent posterior teeth.

Quality of review: The review is limited by ther design of the included studies. There is a need for definitive comparative studies of the longevity of routine dental restorations, of sound design and adequate power, using standardised assessments and appropriate methods of analysis.

Results: Eight of 58 relevant research reports were categorised, according to agreed criteria, as being of satisfactory validity and quality They suggested that 50% of all restorations last 10 to 20 years, although both higher and lower median survival times were reported. However variability was substantial. Restoration type, materials, the patient the operator, the practice environment and type of care system appeared to influence longevity.

Citation: Downer MC, Azli NA, Bedi R, et al. How long do routine dental restorations last: a systematic review. British Dental Journal 1999; 187(8): 432-439.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: HPV in oral squamous cell carcinoma vs head and neck squamous cell carcinoma
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,ORAL CANCER,ENT AND AUDIOLOGY,NOSE & SINUS DISORDERS,LARYNX & PHARYNX DISORDERS,NEOPLASMS,BENIGN,MALIGNANT,NEOPLASMS,BENIGN,MALIGNANT,CONDITIONS,RISK FACTORS,HEAD & NECK CANCER]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: These findings support the assumption that a correct distinction of head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC) by site, together with the use of more sensitive HPV DNA detection methods, should be considered as essential prerogatives in designing future investigations into viral prevalence in head and neck tumors.

Methods: A meta-analysis of 62 studies to verify whether two variables (specification of tumour site and method of HPV DNA identification) influence the datum on HPV assay. Literature search January 1988 to January 2007.

Quality of review: It is likely that the search was insufficient to identify all relevant research in this area. Only Medline databases were searched and supplemented with reference list checking. The full search strategy, search results and included languages are not reported. Furthermore unpublished research does not appear to have been sought which may have introduced publication bias (this was suggested by the funnel plot).

Whilst the results of individual studies are displayed, results for two studies are not shown. Significant heterogeneity was detected and therefore a random effects model used. No formal method of critically appraising studies is reported, however the quality of included studies is described in the discussion.

Results: The pooled prevalence of HPV DNA in the overall samples (Sigma: 4852) was 34.5%, in OSCC it was 38.1% and in the not site-specific HNSCC was 24.1%. With regard to the detection method, PCR-based studies reported a higher prevalence rate than ISH-based rates (34.8, versus 32.9%) especially in the OSCC subgroup (OSCC PCR based: 39.9%)

Citation: Termine N, Panzarella V, Falaschini S et al. HPV in oral squamous cell carcinoma vs head and neck squamous cell carcinoma biopsies: a meta-analysis (1988-2007). Annals of Oncology 2008; 19(10):1681-90.

Access: Full text access to this paper is freely available.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Human papillomavirus and head and neck cancer: a systematic review and meta-analysis
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,ORAL CANCER,ENT AND AUDIOLOGY,NOSE & SINUS DISORDERS,LARYNX & PHARYNX DISORDERS,NEOPLASMS,MALIGNANT,NEOPLASMS,MALIGNANT,CONDITIONS,RISK FACTORS,HUMAN PAPILLOMAVIRUS,HEAD & NECK CANCER]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors’ conclusions: The association between human papillomavirus 16 (HPV16) and head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC) in specific sites suggests the strongest and most consistent association is with tonsil cancer, and the magnitude of this association is consistent with an infectious aetiology. However, the method of viral detection may be an important source of heterogeneity. Resolution of this issue will require further studies using both methods, examining associations separately in different sites.

Methods:  A systematic review of 20 case control studies investigating HPV16 exposure in head and neck cancer. Literature search from database inception to February 2004.

Quality of review: Whilst the authors searched several databases and checked reference lists for further studies it is unclear whether unpublished or non-English language papers were sought. Therefore publication and language biases may have been introduced.  No formal method of critical appraisal of included studies has been reported, although the authors did extract data on sample size and discuss the presence of selection bias and studies which adjusted for confounders. 

Results: The association between HPV16 and cancer was strongest for tonsil (OR: 15.1, 95% CI: 6.8-33.7), intermediate for oropharynx (OR: 4.3, 95% CI: 2.1-8.9) and weakest for oral (OR: 2.0, 95% CI: 1.2-3.4) and larynx (OR: 2.0, 95% CI: 1.0-4.2). To investigate heterogeneity, further stratification by method of HPV16 detection, suggested that variation in the magnitude of the HPV-cancer association with cancer site was restricted to studies using ELISA: among studies using PCR, the magnitude of the summary odds ratios was similar across the four sites.

Citation: Hobbs CGL, Sterne JAC, Bailey M, Heyderman RS, Birchall MA, Thomas SJ. Human papillomavirus and head and neck cancer: a systematic review and meta-analysis. Clinical Otolaryngology 2006; 31 (4), 259–266.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance.  You can find your local library via the My Library home page.
