document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Human papillomavirus types in head and neck squamous cell carcinomas worldwide: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,ORAL CANCER,ENT AND AUDIOLOGY,CONDITIONS,RISK FACTORS,HUMAN PAPILLOMAVIRUS,HEAD & NECK CANCER]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: The high HPV16 prevalence and the lack of HPV18 in oropharyngeal compared with other head and neck squamous cell carcinomas (HNSCCs) may point to specific virus-tissue interactions. Small sample size and publication bias complicate the assessment of the prevalence of HPV in head and neck sites beyond the oropharynx.

Methods: A systematic review of 60 observational studies (study types unclear) to determine the worldwide prevalence and type distribution of HPV in tumour biopsies of head HNSCCs. Database search to February 2004.

Quality of review: The results of this study should be viewed with some caution. It is likely that potentially relevant studies were missed as the search was limited to published studies identified from a single database (PubMed) using restrictive search terms. It is unclear whether there were any language restrictions. Whilst data extraction was appropriately conducted - independently in duplicate - no information is provided on how studies were selected. Consequently the introduction of error and bias at this stage cannot be excluded. It does not appear that the authors used any formal process to assess the quality of included studies, although they discuss several issues that limit the review: small sample sizes (<100 cases), the possibility of selection bias, a lack of consideration of confounders and the limited number of studies with a cancer-free control group.

Results: In the 5,046 HNSCC cancer specimens, the overall HPV prevalence was 25.9% [95% confidence interval (95% CI), 24.7-27.2]. HPV prevalence was  significantly higher in oropharyngeal SCCs (35.6% of 969; 95% CI, 32.6-38.7) than oral SCCs (23.5% of 2,642; 95% CI, 21.9-25.1) or laryngeal SCCs (24.0% of 1,435; 95% CI, 21.8-26.3). HPV16 accounted for a larger majority of HPV-positive oropharyngeal SCCs (86.7%; 95% CI, 82.6-90.1) compared with HPV-positive oral SCCs (68.2%; 95% CI, 64.4-71.9) and laryngeal SCCs (69.2%; 95% CI, 64.0-74.0). Conversely, HPV18 was rare in HPVpositive oropharyngeal SCCs (2.8%; 95% CI, 1.3-5.3) compared with other head and neck sites [34.1% (95% CI, 30.4-38.0) of oral SCCs and 17.0% (95% CI, 13.0-21.6) of laryngeal SCCs]. Aside from HPV16 and HPV18, other oncogenic HPVs were rarely detected in HNSCC. Tumor site–specific HPV prevalence was higher among studies from North America compared with Europe and Asia.

Citation: Kreimer AR, Clifford GM, Boyle P, Franceschi S. Human papillomavirus types in head and neck squamous cell carcinomas worldwide: a systematic review. Cancer Epidemiology, Biomarkers and Prevention 2005 Feb;14(2):467-75

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.


 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Hyperfractionated or accelerated radiotherapy in head and neck cancer: a meta-analysis.
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORAL CANCER,ORAL RADIOLOGY,ENT AND AUDIOLOGY,NOSE & SINUS DISORDERS,LARYNX & PHARYNX DISORDERS,NEOPLASMS,MALIGNANT,NEOPLASMS,MALIGNANT,CONDITIONS,TREATMENT & MANAGEMENT,RADIOTHERAPY,THERAPEUTIC INTERVENTIONS,NON-DRUG TREATMENTS,RADIOTHERAPY,HEAD & NECK CANCER]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions:  Altered fractionated radiotherapy improves survival in patients with head and neck squamous cell carcinoma. Comparison of the different types of altered radiotherapy suggests that hyperfractionation has the greatest benefit.

Methods:  A systematic review and meta-analysis of 15 randomised controlled trials with 6515 patients to assess whether unconventional factionated radiotherapy in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma can improve survival.

Quality of review: A good attempt was made to identify published and unpublished research. The authors conducted a search of Medline and Embase and supplemented this by searching abstracts, reference lists, a clinical trial register and by contacting experts. Missing data was obtained for patients who had been excluded from published analyses. However, only English language papers were included and this may have introduced a language bias. Whilst no formal method of quality appraisal was reported, the authors state that they followed the methods outlined in a Cochrane Library protocol on this topic (Pignon 2000) – checking data consistency, randomisation procedures and follow up. The authors report that data from one study (212 patients) was lost but don’t provide any further detail. The review was sponsored by Sanofi-Aventis, which could be a potential conflict of interest. However, the authors state that the sponsors had no role in study design, data collection, data analysis, interpretation or writing of the report.

Results:  There was a significant survival benefit with altered fractionated radiotherapy, corresponding to an absolute benefit of 3·4% at 5 years (hazard ratio 0·92, 95% CI 0·86–0·97; p=0·003). The benefit was significantly higher with hyperfractionated radiotherapy (8% at 5 years) than with accelerated radiotherapy (2% with accelerated fractionation without total dose reduction and 1·7% with total dose reduction at 5 years, p=0·02). There was a benefit on locoregional control in favour of altered fractionation versus conventional radiotherapy (6·4% at 5 years; p<0·0001), which was particularly efficient in reducing local failure, whereas the benefit on nodal control was less pronounced. The benefit was significantly higher in the youngest patients (hazard ratio 0·78 [0·65–0·94] for under 50 year olds, 0·95 [0·83–1·09] for 51–60 year olds, 0·92 [0·81–1·06] for 61–70 year olds, and 1·08 [0·89–1·30] for over 70 year olds; test for trends p=0·007).

Citation:  Bourhis J Overgaard J, Audry H et al. Hyperfractionated or accelerated radiotherapy in head and neck cancer: a meta-analysis.  Lancet 2006; 368(9538): 843-854

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. Full text online access is available to NHS staff in England via ATHENS passwords. To apply for an ATHENS password and access this resource and many others please go to the ATHENS registration page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Hyposalivation, xerostomia and the complete denture: A systematic review
document.publisher: Journal of the American Dental Association
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,RESTORATIVE DENTISTRY,ENT AND AUDIOLOGY,SALIVARY GLAND DISORDERS,XEROSTOMIA,SIALORRHOEA,CONDITIONS,THERAPEUTIC INTERVENTIONS,NON-DRUG TREATMENTS,OTHER]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Prospective clinical studies are needed to establish a framework for evidence-based treatment of denture-wearing patients experiencing dry mouth.

Methods: A systematic review to determine the treatment effects of hyposalivation on denture retention. Database search dates: 1950 to September 2007.

Quality of the review: The review is limited by a lack of methodologically acceptable studies. Whilst the authors identified 11 papers, none were of a sufficient quality and they correctly concluded that additional research is required

It is likely that potentially relevant papers were missed. Although the authors searched a range of databases, they used very limited search terms and restricted the results to English-only studies. Expanding the search to encompass reference list checking, hand searching key journals, contacting experts and looking for grey literature may also have identified additional papers.

Results: No high quality studies were identified.

Citation: Turner M, Jahangiri L, Ship JA. Hyposalivation, xerostomia and the complete denture: A systematic review. Journal of the American Dental Association, 2008; 139: 146-150

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Immediate knowledge increase from an oral cancer information leaflet in patients attending a primary health care facility: a randomised controlled trial
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORAL CANCER,DENTAL PUBLIC HEALTH,PREVENTION,RISK FACTORS]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors conclusions: Immediate knowledge gain from a simple patient information leaflet (PIL) about oral cancer was found and independent of the primary care facility, where the PIL was distributed.

Methods: Randomised controlled trial of 800 participants from 14 general practices (8 dental and 6 medical) in the North West of England. Patients were allocated to the experimental group (PIL provided, and returned prior to completion of questionnaire) or control (no PIL). Both groups completed a self-reported questionnaire assessing knowledge of oral cancer.

Quality of study: The study was conducted in a large patient group.  However, it only measures short-term effects.  It does not measure knowledge prior to the leaflet being provided, although there is a control group.  The method of randomisation is unclear and there are more women in the PIL group.

Results: The results showed that patients who had read the oral cancer PIL demonstrated a significant increase in knowledge regardless of clinical setting - knowledge levels of oral cancer were greater by 5 points in those who received the leaflet (F[1,739]=246.24, p<0.0001). Those who responded in dental surgeries indicated approximately one extra correct knowledge item compared to those in medical settings (p<0.05).

Patients who were provided with the leaflet showed improvements in selecting the correct signs and risk factors associated with disease.

Citation: Humphris GM, Ireland RS, Field EA. Immediate knowledge increase from an oral cancer information leaflet in patients attending a primary health care facility: a randomised controlled trial. Oral Oncology 2001; 37: 99-102

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Immediate loading with single implant crowns: a systematic review and meta-analysis
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,RESTORATIVE DENTISTRY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Although the findings of this systematic review and meta-analysis are clearly not robust enough to guide clinical practice, they do demonstrate better outcomes with a conventional loading  protocol for single implant crowns. Immediately loaded implants carry a higher risk of failure. Further adequately powered clinical trials are needed. Caution with immediate loading of implants with crowns as a standard of care for single tooth replacement is recommended.

Methods: A systematic review and meta-analysis of 5 studies (248 implants) to compare immediate to conventional loading of single implant crowns. Literature search dates: 1969 to 1 November 2007.

Quality of review: As the authors state, the review is limited by the quality of the included studies. It is possible that potentially relevant studies were missed. The authors searched two databases (Medline and Central), supplemented by reference list checking and hand-searching nine key journals. However, the search terms used were restrictive, and, as the authors themselves note, not searching Embase and limiting the search to published papers in the English language may have introduced bias.

An appropriate method was used to select studies for inclusion, although that used for data extraction is not stated. Whilst the authors did not use a formal method to assess the quality of included studies, they do consider quality aspects including sample size, follow-up and allocation concealment.

Results: Immediate loading of single implant crowns was associated with a significantly higher risk of implant failure (relative risk: 5.07, 95% CI: 2.00 to 12.84, P < .001). Pooling of randomized controlled trials showed similar results, although the difference was not statistically significant. Immediate nonocclusal loading was also associated with worse outcomes when compared to conventional loading (relative risk: 4.76, 95% CI: 1.74 to 13.02, P = .002).

Citation: Atieh MA, Atieh AH, Payne AG, Duncan WJ. Immediate loading with single implant crowns: a systematic review and meta-analysis. International Journal of Prosthodontics 2009; 22(4):378-87.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Immediate restoration/loading of immediately placed single implants: is it an effective bimodal approach?
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PERIODONTOLOGY,RESTORATIVE DENTISTRY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: There is an added risk for immediately restored/loaded oral implants placed into extraction sockets (the bimodal approach) in the aesthetic zone as compared with those placed in healed sites. However, it demonstrated that a bimodal approach may offer an advantage with respect to the favourable changes in marginal bone levels. Further long-term, well-conducted, randomized controlled studies are needed to confirm the validity of the bimodal protocol as a treatment option.

Methods: A systematic review and meta-analysis of ten controlled clinical trials to compare the survival and radiographic marginal bone level changes of two immediate implant protocols in the aesthetic region; immediate single implant restoration/loading in extraction sockets (the bimodal approach) compared with the same in healed sites. Database search from inception to 1 August 2008.

Quality of review: A well-conducted and clearly reported systematic review and meta-analysis.  A range of bibliographic databases were searched to identify evidence. There is a risk that the restricted search strategy may have resulted in relevant papers being missed, but this risk was minimised by supplementary hand-searching of key journals and reference list checking. Studies in any language were included, and it also appears the authors attempted to identify unpublished research. The authors checked for publication bias which did not appear to be significant. 

Two independent reviewers selected, data extracted and critically appraised the included studies in duplicate, thereby minimising the risk of bias and error. There was no significant clinical heterogeneity which made it appropriate to combine the study results.

Results: Immediate single implant restoration/loading in extraction sockets in the aesthetic zone was associated with significantly higher risk of implant failure (risk ratio of 3.62, 95% confidence interval 1.15–11.45, P¼0.03). However, the bimodal approach showed favourable marginal bone changes after 1 year.

Citation: Atieh MA, Payne AG, Duncan WJ, Cullinan MP. Immediate restoration/loading of immediately placed single implants: is it an effective bimodal approach? Clinical Oral Implants Research 2009; 20(7):645-59.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Immediate skeletal and dentoalveolar effects of the crown- or banded type Herbst appliance on Class II division 1 malocclusion
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORTHODONTICS]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Dental changes have more impact than skeletal changes in the correction of Class II division 1 malocclusions with the crown or banded Herbst appliance.

Methods: A systematic review of three randomised controlled trials to evaluate the relative skeletal and dental changes produced by the crown- or banded-type Herbst appliance in growing Class II division 1 malocclusion cases. Literature search to March 2007.

Quality of review: Whilst a wide range of databases was searched, the search terms used were not comprehensive and relevant papers may have missed. Unpublished research was not sought which may have introduced publication bias. Sound methods were used to select included papers. However, no method was reported for assessing the validity of included studies; although the inclusion criteria applied some quality limits and further issues were examined in the discussion.

Results: Proclination and anterior movement of the lower incisors, overjet reduction, and improvement of first molar relationship thorough mesial movement of the first molars, reduction of ANB angle, and an increase in the mandibular plane angle were reported. There were mixed findings as to mandibular sagittal length and position and increases in lower face height, both anteriorly and posteriorly. No statistically significant changes were noted in the sagittal length or position of the skeletal maxilla

Citation: Barnett GA, Higgins DW, Major PW, Flores-Mir C. Immediate skeletal and dentoalveolar effects of the crown- or banded type Herbst appliance on Class II division 1 malocclusion. Angle Orthodontist 2008; 78(2): 361-9.

Access: full text freely available

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Impact of a retained instrument on treatment outcome: a systematic review and meta-analysis
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ENDODONTICS,ORAL SURGERY]]>
document.body:
This is a provisional record for information. The review has been identified as potentially meeting our quality criteria. It will be critically appraised and a quality statement provided as soon as possible.
_____________________________________________________

 

Introduction: Fracture of root canal instruments is one of the most troublesome incidents in endodontic therapy. This systematic review and meta-analysis aim to determine the outcome difference between retained fractured instrument cases and matched conventional treated cases.

Methods: The MEDLINE database, EMBASE, Web of Science, and the Cochrane Database were searched. Reference lists were scanned. A forward search was undertaken on identified articles. Papers citing these articles were identified through Science Citation Index to identify potentially relevant subsequent primary research. A systematic data extraction sheet was constructed. Data in these studies were independently extracted. Risk differences of included studies were combined by using the generic inverse variance data and fixed effects method. A 2-stage analysis was conducted. The first was limited to case-control studies, and the second included case series in which data were available for teeth with and without periradicular lesions.

Results: Two case-control studies were identified and included, covering 199 cases. Weighted mean healing for teeth with a retained instrument fragment was 91%. The 2 studies were homogeneous. Risk difference of the combined data was 0.01, indicating that a retained fragment did not significantly influence healing. Overall, 80.7% of lesions healed when a periapical lesion was present, compared with 92.4% remaining healthy when no lesion was present initially (P < .02).

Conclusions: On the basis of the current best available evidence, the prognosis for endodontic treatment when a fractured instrument fragment is left within a root canal is not significantly reduced 

Citation: Panitvisai P, Parunnit P, Sathorn C, Messer HH. Impact of a retained instrument on treatment outcome: a systematic review and meta-analysis. Journal of Endodontics 2010; 36(5):775-780

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Impact of local adjuncts to scaling and root planing in periodontal disease therapy: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,PERIODONTOLOGY,TREATMENT & MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Whether such improvements, even if statistically signi- ficant, are clinically meaningful remains a question. A substantial agenda of future research to address this and other issues (e.g., costs, patientoriented outcomes) is suggested.

Methods: A systematic review of 50 randomised controlled trials to examine whether scaling and root planing (SRP) accompanied by a local adjunctive therapeutic agent improves outcomes over time compared to SRP alone. Literature search 1966-2002.

Quality of review: A reasonable attempt was made to locate all the relevant literature.  However, unpublished research was not sought and non-English language papers were excluded, which may have introduced publication and language bias.  The validity of included trials was assessed by two independent reviewers using predefined criteria. The quality of the trials is not discussed in any detail, although the authors state that the information is presented in the full report.

Results: Among the locally administered adjunctive antimicrobials, the most positive results occurred for tetracycline, minocycline, metronidazole, and chlorhexidine. Adjunctive local therapy generally reduced probing depth (PD) levels. Differences between treatment and SRP-only groups in the baseline-to-follow-up period typically favored treatment groups but usually only modestly (e.g., from about 0.1 mm to nearly 0.5 mm) even when the differences were statistically significant. Effects for clinical attachment level (CAL) gains were smaller and statistical significance less common. The marginal improvements in PD and CAL were a fraction of the improvement from SRP alone.

Citation: Bonito AJ, Lux L, Lohr KN. Impact of local adjuncts to scaling and root planing in periodontal disease therapy: a systematic review. Journal of Periodontology 2005; 76(8): 1227-1236

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Impact of supportive periodontal therapy and implant surface roughness on implant outcome in patients with a history of periodontitis
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,PERIODONTOLOGY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: These results seem to indicate that periodontally compromised patients can be successfully treated with minimally/moderately rough implants, in the presence of supportive periodontal therapy (SPT).

Methods: A systematic review of 16 studies (11 prospective and 5 retrospective) to examine the relationship between periodontitis and the incidence of implant loss and/or peri-implantitis. Literature search to June 2006.

Quality of review: The authors limited bias by selecting, data extracting and quality appraising included studies in duplicate using two independent reviewers. However it is possible that the search strategy missed key papers. Although Medline was searched, and reference lists and key journals handsearched, additional papers may have been identified by searching more databases and contacting experts. It is not reported whether non-English language or unpublished research was sought.

Results: The impact of a history of periodontitis on early implant loss was negligible. Only five papers reported sub-data for patients with different degrees of periodontitis. Four out of five papers indicate a higher incidence of late implant loss and/or marginal bone loss in patients with a history of periodontitis. The difference was most obvious for very rough implants (three papers), and/or when SPT was not organized (one paper). Other confounding factors were often neglected. Another 10 papers only reported the outcome of implants in patients with a history of periodontitis. In case of SPT and when avoiding roughened surfaces, late implant loss remained below 3%, and marginal bone loss remained low.

Citation: Quirynen M, Abarca M, Van Assche N, Nevins M, van Steenberghe D. Impact of supportive periodontal therapy and implant surface roughness on implant outcome in patients with a history of periodontitis. Journal of Clinical Periodontology 2007; 34(9): 805-15.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance.  You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Implant site development by orthodontics extrusion: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,ORTHODONTICS,PERIODONTOLOGY,RESTORATIVE DENTISTRY,TREATMENT & MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Based on the available literature, orthodontic extrusion of nonrestorable teeth prior to implant placement appears to be a viable alternative to conventional surgical augmentative procedures in implant site development. Since no direct comparison to any other method was found, no conclusion can be made about its relative efficacy compared with other methods.

Methods: A narrative systematic review of 15 case reports and 2 case series to determine the effectiveness of orthodontic extrusion of non-restorable teeth prior to implant placement for improving the alveolar bone and gingival characteristics of implant recipient sites. Database search to July 2007.

Quality of review: The results should be viewed with caution as the review is based on case reports and case series. As the authors state, it is not likely to be an accurate reflection of success rates and further research is needed.

The authors searched a wide range of databases and supplemented the search with reference list checking. However, it is possible that relevant papers were missed as the search terms used were quite specific and only published studies in the English language were included with a consequent risk of introducing bias. Appropriate procedures were used to minimise error and bias in study selection, but quality assessment and data extraction processes are not reported. Although the authors stated that they excluded “any articles in which a clear source of bias or other major methodological errors could be identified”, no papers were excluded and no information is provided on the validity of the included papers.

Results: Clinically significant gains in alveolar bone and gingival tissue were reported in all cases, resulting in significant quantitative and qualitative improvements in the implant sites.

Citation: Korayem M, Flores-Mir C, Nassar U, Olfert K. Implant site development by orthodontics extrusion: a systematic review. Angle Orthodontist, 2008; 78 (4): 752-760

Access: Available to the general public

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Implant vs screw loading protocols in orthodontics
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,ORAL SURGERY,PERIODONTOLOGY,RESTORATIVE DENTISTRY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Loading protocols for implants involve a minimum waiting period of 2 months before applying orthodontic forces while loading protocols for screws involve immediate loading or a waiting period of 2 weeks to apply forces. Success rates for implants were on average higher than for screws.   Conclusions should be considered with caution because only a secondary level of evidence was found.

Methods: A systematic review considering the loading protocols applied when using implants and/or screws in orthodontic treatments.  Studies were assessed and found to be of poor methodological quality.

Quality of review: A reasonable attempt was made to find the relevant literature.  A search was conducted across a wide range of databases without language restrictions and reference lists were reviewed.  However, it appears that unpublished research was not sought and this may have introduced publication bias. A quality appraisal was undertaken of the included studies based on a scoring system developed by one of the authors.  Various aspects of study methodology were reviewed including design, measurements and statistical analysis.  All the studies received a low score.  None were randomised or blinded or included any information on loss to follow up.  In general study numbers were very low.  Not surprisingly, the authors indicate that the review conclusions should be treated with caution.

Results: Eleven articles fulfilled the selection criteria established. Five studies involved the use of implants while six involved the use of screws for orthodontic purposes.

Citation: Ohashi E, Pecho OE, Moron M, Lagravere MO. Implant vs screw loading protocols in orthodontics. Angle Orthodontist 2006; 76 (4): 721-7

Access: Full-text online access is freely available.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Improving the oral health of older people in long-term residential care: a review of the literature
document.publisher: International Journal of Older People Nursing
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,DENTAL CARIES,RESTORATIVE DENTISTRY,TREATMENT & MANAGEMENT,SPECIAL CARE DENTISTRY,OLDER PEOPLE]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors’ conclusions:  Multiple barriers were found to negatively impact on daily oral healthcare provision, including lack of carer provider education, oral health values, availability of resources, implementation of supportive policies, documentation and oral health assessment tools.

Relevance to clinical practice: A multi-faceted approach is required to address barriers that impact negatively on oral health outcomes, including development and implementation of oral health education programmes, assessment screening tools, care plans, documentation, supply of oral hygiene aids and the appointment of oral care ‘champions’.

Methods: A narrative systematic review examining barriers that prevent care providers giving good oral care in long term residential care facilities for older people. The review combines qualitative and quantitative data from 30 studies of varied design. Database search dates: from 2000 (end date not specified but review includes studies to 2007).

Quality of review: The authors made a good attempt to identify available qualitative and quantitative studies. They searched a range of electronic sources (CINAHL, Cochrane Library, Medline, plus Proquest, Science Direct, Journals@Ovid, Joanna Briggs Institute and the National Research Register). In addition, relevant publications were hand searched and reference lists of included papers were checked. The review includes unpublished research but it is unclear whether there were any language restrictions.  

The processes used to select, data extract and quality assess included studies are not stated and the introduction of error and bias cannot be excluded.  The authors used a range of tools to assess included studies and consider potential limitations in some detail.

Citation: Miegel K, Wachtel T. Improving the oral health of older people in long-term residential care: a review of the literature. International Journal of Older People Nursing 2009; 4(2): 97-113.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Indications for immediate loading of implants and implant success.
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,ORAL SURGERY,PERIODONTOLOGY,RESTORATIVE DENTISTRY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: More high-level evidence-based studies are needed to demonstrate the relative merits of immediate loading compared with conventional loading in all potential applications.

Methods: A systematic review of 38 studies to compare implant survival and success rates for immediately loaded and conventionally loaded oral implants.  The included papers were a mixture of randomised controlled trials, controlled trials and prospective cohort studies.

Quality of review: It seems likely that the search strategy did not identify all relevant papers.  Whilst several databases were searched, the search terms appeared very narrow.  Hand searching of a wide range of journals was undertaken, but there was no review of reference lists.  It is not clear whether unpublished materials or non-English language papers were sought and this may have introduced publication and language biases. The authors do not report a formal method of quality assessment, although they do mention quality issues:  the inclusion criteria require a minimum of 12 months follow-up and the sample size of the included studies is discussed.  Study numbers of virtually all the studies is very small and the authors rightly acknowledge that the evidence generated is insufficient to draw evidence-based conclusions.

Results: For immediate loading of oral implants in the edentulous and partially dentate, mandible and maxillla the studies identified were based on limited patient numbers.  Therefore definitive conclusions could not be drawn.  The compilation of the current literature shows that prospective controlled studies as well as prospective studies without controls using several different approaches to immediate loading have demonstrated high implant survival and success rates.

Citation: Nkenke E, Fenner M. Indications for immediate loading of implants and implant success. Clinical Oral Implants Research 2006; 17 (s2), 19–34.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Inhalation sedation with nitrous oxide as an alternative to dental general anaesthesia for children
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORAL MEDICINE,ORAL SURGERY,PAEDIATRIC DENTISTRY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Low quality evidence is suggestive that inhalation sedation (IHS) can prevent the need for dental general anaesthesia (DGA) in many older children who would have otherwise required it.

Methods: Systematic review to examine the use of inhalation sedation (IHS) instead of dental general anaesthesia (DGA) for dental treatment. 7  case series  (5 UK, 2 Scandinavian) with a total of 300 patients with DGA and 1595 with IHS were included. Literature search date 1975 to August 2002.

Quality of Study: A good attempt was made to identify studies.  Several databases were searched, selected journals hand-searched, reference lists of included studies were checked and experts were contacted to identify published and unpublished literature.  However, non-English language papers were excluded which may have introduced language bias.  A formal method of assessing the validity of included studies was not reported, although the inclusion criteria addressed soe methodological aspects of studies.  Of the seven included studies five were conducted in university dental hospitals and one in a community centre (location was not stated for one study).  This may limit generalisability to general dental practice.

Results: This is an area of healthcare lacking high-quality clinical evidence (i.e. derived from randomized controlled trials). However, evidence from seven case series studies of variable quality and design is examined. 

Those studies suggest that IHS is effective for a large proportion (83–97%) of selected subgroups of children who would have otherwise required DGA. This may represent 45–64% of all children who are referred for DGA. There is a remarkable degree of consistency between all studies in the reported treatment effectiveness of IHS, despite differences in design and populations treated.

IHS is particularly suitable for orthodontic treatment, for older children, and for children requiring no more than four extractions. Morbidity associated with IHS is minor and infrequent, and user satisfaction is high, or higher compared with DGA. Comparing with DGA, IHS requires significantly longer time per episode and more treatment sessions per patient. In teaching dental hospitals, staffing costs for IHS are estimated to be cheaper by about a third compared with outpatient DGA.

Citation: Lyratzopoulos (Liratsopulos) G, Blain KM. Inhalation sedation with nitrous oxide as an alternative to dental general anaesthesia for children. Journal of Public Health Medicine. 2003 25 (4) 303-312.

Access: Full-text access to this paper is freely available. 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Interventions for treating traumatized necrotic immature permanent anterior teeth: inducing a calcific barrier and root strengthening
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ENDODONTICS,ORAL SURGERY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Based on two included studies, there is weak, unreliable evidence supporting the use of either calcium hydroxide or tricalcium phosphate for apical barrier formation in necrotic immature anterior teeth employing multi-visit apexification techniques. The evidence is insufficient to provide guidelines for practice. There was no reliable evidence on adverse events or long-term effects after the use of calcium hydroxide or tricalcium phosphate justifying caution in their use in apical barrier formation techniques.

Methods:  narrative systematic review of two RCTs to evaluate the relative effectiveness of apexification and apical plug techniques as well as root strengthening procedures for treating traumatized necrotic immature permanent anterior teeth. Reported immediate and/or long-term adverse events and effects of the materials and techniques were also evaluated. Database search dates: 1966-October 2006.

Quality of review: A well conducted systematic review. As the authors conclude, the results are limited by the quality of the available evidence. A good attempt was made to find the available evidence, searching multiple databases without language or publication restrictions and supplemented by  reference list checking, handsearching and contacts with experts and manufacturers. Appropriate methods were used to minimise error and bias in selecting, data extracting and quality assessing included papers. Both included studies were deemed to be at high risk of bias.

Note: the authors published a Cochrane review protocol on this topic in Jan 2009.

Results: Included studies investigated multi-visit apexification techniques using calcium hydroxide and tricalcium phosphate. There were no eligible studies investigating root strengthening procedures or any other intervention for apical barrier formation in necrotic immature anterior teeth. No reliable information was available on long-term adverse effects of the reported interventions or cost implications.

Citation: Al Ansary MA, Day PF, Duggal MS, Brunton PA. Interventions for treating traumatized necrotic immature permanent anterior teeth: inducing a calcific barrier and root strengthening. Dental Traumatology 2009; 25(4):367-79.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Investigation of relationship between change in locoregional control and change in overall survival in randomised controlled trials of modified radiotherapy in head-and-neck cancer
document.publisher: International Journal of Radiation Oncology Biology Physics
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORAL CANCER,ORAL RADIOLOGY,ENT AND AUDIOLOGY,NOSE & SINUS DISORDERS,LARYNX & PHARYNX DISORDERS,SALIVARY GLAND DISORDERS,NEOPLASMS,MALIGNANT,NEOPLASMS,MALIGNANT,NEOPLASMS,MALIGNANT,CONDITIONS,TREATMENT & MANAGEMENT,RADIOTHERAPY,THERAPEUTIC INTERVENTIONS,NON-DRUG TREATMENTS,RADIOTHERAPY,HEAD & NECK CANCER]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: A relationship was demonstrated between a change in locoregional control (LRC) and a change in overall survival (OS) in randomised trials of modified radiotherapy for head-and-neck cancer. A 10% improvement in the 2-year LRC is predicted to lead to a 6.7% improvement in the 5-year OS. This type of analysis may have applications in other tumour sites.

Methods: A systematic review of 19 randomised controlled trials to establish whether a relationship exists between improvment in LRC and improvement in OS in head-and-neck cancer. Literature search 1990-2004.

Quality of study: Key papers may have been missed as only one database (PubMed) was searched with limited search terms. Reference lists were checked. Unpublished research was not sought and only English language papers were included which may have introduced publication and language biases. A formal method of critically appraising included studies is not reported, although the quality of the studies is briefly discussed.

Results: Fourteen trials reported sufficient data for analysis. Linear regression analysis showed a statistically significant correlation between LRC and OS with a slope of 0.67 (95% confidence interval, 0.38–0.96, p = 0.00017), implying that a 10% improvement in LRC would be expected to lead to a 6.7% iimprovement in )S (95%CI 3.8-9.6%).

Citation: Wadsley JC, Bentzen SM. Investigation of relationship between change in locoregional control and change in overall survival in randomised controlled trials of modified radiotherapy in head-and-neck cancer. International Journal of Radiation Oncology Biology Physics. 2004; 60: 1405-1409

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Is alcohol to blame for the rise in oral cancer incidence
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL CANCER,ORAL DISORDERS,ORAL HEALTH,ALCOHOL,RISK FACTORS]]>
document.body:
111-1Is alcohol to blame for the rise in oral cancer incidence

"Alcohol is largely to blame for an ‘alarming’ rise in the rate of oral cancers among men and women in their forties say experts” according to a BBC online news report of 11 August 2009. The report refers to figures published by Cancer Research UK which show that there has been an increase of 26% in the number of cancers in this age group.

_____________________________________________________________________
 

 

 

Where does the evidence come from?

Cancer Research UK who published the latest UK cancer incidence statistics today. However, the information available on their website only provides age-specific incidence rates for men.

 

What were the findings?

In 2006 5,325 new cases of oral cancer were diagnosed, and 1800 deaths were attributable to the disease in 2007 - the latest years for which information is available.

Whilst the actual numbers are relatively low (oral cancer accounts for 1.81% of all diagnosed cancers), between 1997 and 2006 the incidence of oral cancer increased by 24% in men and 18% in women.

 

 Rates per 100,000 of population

What were the conclusions? 

"Alcohol consumption has doubled since the 1950s and the trend we are now seeing is likely to be linked to Britain's continually rising drinking levels." 

“Oral cancer is largely a preventable disease with tobacco and alcohol use being the main risk factors.

“Cancers caused by smoking often take up to 30 years to develop, so tobacco is less likely to be the main reason behind the increase in oral cancer in people in their 40s compared with older people.  And since smoking rates have gone down and alcohol consumption has gone up, experts believe the increase in oral cancer rates could mainly be down to drinking.

“Other risk factors that could have helped to fuel the rise in this age group include a diet low in fruit and vegetables, and a sexually transmitted infection called the human papillomavirus (HPV).

Oral cancer rates in the UK for men in their 40s have gone up by 28 per cent since the mid 1990s, and rates for women in their 40s have increased by 24 per cent in the same period.

For both men and women of all ages, oral cancer rates have increased by more than 45 per cent since records began in 1975.

 

How reliable are the conclusions?

Alcohol is clearly associated with increased risk of oral cancer.

In NICE guidance: Improving outcomes in head and neck cancers - The Manual published in 2004 a review of risk factors for cancers of the upper aerodigestive tract (mouth, pharynx, and larynx) states:

"Most upper aerodigestive tract cancers are triggered by alcohol and tobacco, which together probably account for three-quarters of cases....

"....Alcohol consumption is a particularly important risk factor for cancers of the mouth...Consuming 100g of alcohol or more per day (about 12 units – six pints of beer or 12 measures of wine or spirits) multiplies the risk of developing oral cancer at least six-fold, after adjustment for tobacco use; the more alcohol consumed, the greater the risk.

The guidance also highlights poor diet and the HPV virus as other risk factors.
 


Systematic reviews

Corrao G, Bagnardi V, Zambon A, Vecchia CL. A meta-analysis of alcohol consumption and the risk of 15 diseases. Preventive Medicine. 2004; 38: 613-619 

 

How accurately did the media report the findings?

The statistics were accurately reported.

 

Links to the relevant, available news articles

Drink blamed for oral cancer rise. BBC News Online 11 August 2009

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Is diagnostic delay related to advanced-stage oral cancer? A meta-analysis
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,ORAL CANCER,DIAGNOSIS & REFERRAL]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: The probability for patients with delayed diagnosis to present an advanced-stage tumour at diagnosis was significantly higher than that of patients with no delay in diagnosis. However, new prospective studies with strict methodology are needed to shed more light on this association.

Methods: A systematic review and meta-analysis of 9 retrospective cross-sectional studies to consider the relationship between total diagnostic delay and advanced disease stages in oropharyngeal cancer. Database search dates: from inception to December 2008.

Quality of review: The results of this review should be viewed with some caution, given the limited quality of the evidence identified. As the authors state, there is a need for well-conducted prospective studies. In addition, it should be noted that, despite high levels of heterogeneity overall, discussion focuses on the results of fixed effects analyses, rather than the more appropriate random effects analyses. The former are statistically significant, where the latter are generally not significant.

The authors searched several databases (Medline, Embase and ISI) without language restrictions, supplemented by reference list checking. Whilst only published studies were included, a test for publication bias was negative. 

Appropriate methods were used to minimise the risk of introducing error and bias in study selection, quality assessment and data extraction. The authors used elements of the MOOSE reporting checklist to consider quality; specifying three criteria: follow-up period; measurement of potential confounders; results stratified by anatomical location.

Results: Note: In the results presented there were varying degrees of heterogeneity – mostly high - and the results of the random effects analyses – as the authors indicate in the paper - may be a more accurate reflection of the likely risk

When compared with the absence of diagnostic delay, the fixed-effects pooled odd ratio (OR) of advanced stage of the disease for patients with diagnostic delay was 1.32 (95% CI: 1.07–1.62), while the random effects pooled OR was 1.25 (95% CI: 0.84–1.85), with substantial heterogeneity (Ri = 0.70). 

Restricting the analysis to oral location, the fixed effects pooled OR was 1.47 (95% CI: 1.09–1.99), while the random-effects pooled OR was 1.55 (95% CI: 0.96–2.51), with statistically non-significant heterogeneity. Stratifying the analysis to an oral location with a delay greater than 1 month, the magnitude of the effect increased (fixed effects OR = 1.69 with 95% CI: 1.26–2.77).

Globally, the fixed-effects estimates showed a significant association between diagnostic delay and oral cancer stage. However, the random-effects estimates did not reach statistical significance, although they showed a clear tendency towards an increased risk among patients in whom diagnosis was delayed (probably because of the small number of studies available and the amount of heterogeneity between the RRs of the individual studies).

Pooled results of low-quality studies failed to find any effect of diagnosis delay, whereas high-quality studies showed a substantial increase in the risk (fixed-effects pooled OR: 1.40, 95% CI: 1.11–1.76). Furthermore, studies with extensive follow-up showed an important risk increase (fixed effects pooled OR = 1.42 with 95% CI: 1.10–1.82 and Ri = 0.8), while those with shorter or unknown follow-up did not show any increase. Studies that adjusted for additional factors, such as tobacco smoking or alcohol, did not show any increase in the risk of advanced cancer occurrence with delayed diagnosis, in contrast to studies that did not adjust for other factors. Finally, studies that presented results by anatomic location of oropharyngeal cancer showed a substantial risk increase, while those studies without any stratification by anatomic site did not (pooled OR: 1.51, 95% CI: 1.19–1.90 vs. pooled OR: 0.85, 95% CI: 0.55–1.31).

Citation: Gómez I, Seoane J, Varela-Centelles P, Diz P, Takkouche B. Is diagnostic delay related to advanced-stage oral cancer? A meta-analysis. European Journal of Oral Sciences 2009; 117(5): 541-6.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Is lingual nerve protection neccessary for lower third molar germectomy? A prospective study of 300 procedures
document.publisher: International Journal of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORAL SURGERY,IMPACTED THIRD MOLARS,LINGUAL NERVE PROTECTION]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Lingual nerve protection is unnecessary for third molar germectomy.

Method: A randomised controlled trial of 300 germectomy procedures in 154 patients (mean age 14.9 years) performed over a 5 year period. Patients were allocated to procedures with or without lingual nerve protection and re-examined after 15 days (overall drop out rate 15.6%). Patients and outcome assessors were blind. 

Quality of study: It is unclear whether groups were similar at the start of the trial as patients baseline characteristics are not reported. There is also no information on whether an intention to treat analysis was used.

Results: No lingual nerve injury was observed after third molar germectomy regardless of whether or not lingual nerve protection was used.

Citation: Chossegros C, Guyot L, Cheynet F, Belloni D, Blanc JL. Is lingual nerve protection necessary for lower third molar germectomy? A prospective study of 300 procedures. International Journal of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery 2002; 31(6): 620-4

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Is periodontitis associated with an increased risk of coronary heart disease and preterm and/or low birth weight births?
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,PERIODONTOLOGY,ASSOCIATED CONDITIONS]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusion: The evidence linking periodontitis with an increased risk for coronary heart disease (CHD) and preterm and/or low birth weight deliveries (PLBW) is limited.

There is a clear need for new, well designed observational and intervention studies to confirm the thus far observed associations, explore the validity of the associations in diverse populations, establish whether they are causal in nature and determine potential benefits of periodontal intervention in reducing the risk for these conditions.

Methods: A systematic review evaluating the periodontitis-CHD association in 8 cohort, 4 case-control and 4 cross sectional studies and the periodontitis-low birth weight (PLBW) in 1 cohort and 2 case-control studies. Literature search to October 2001.

Quality of review: Only English language papers were included, and it is unclear if unpublished studies were sought.

Results: Meta-analysis was not performed due to extensive heterogeniety of the studies. Percentage-wise, 50% of the cohort studies (4/8), 75% of the case-control studies (3/4) and 50% of the cross-sectional studies (2/4) reported a significant association between clinical measures of periodontitis and CHD (excess risk ranged from 0 to 3.3-fold). One cohort study as well as one of the two case-control studies reported a significant association between periodontitis and PLBW (odds ratios 4.4–7.9). From two additional case-control studies microbiological data could be extracted. Bacteroides forsythus was found to be associated with PLBW in both studies.

Citation: Madianos PN, Bobetis GA, Kinane DF. Is periodontisis associated with an increased risk of coronary heart disease and preterm and/or low birth weight births? Journal of Clinical Periodontology 2002; 29 (Suppl. 3): 22-36.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page. 

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Is there a superiority of multimodal as opposed to simple therapy in patients with temporomandibular disorders? A qualitative systematic review of the literature
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,DENTO-FACIAL ANOMALIES,ORO-FACIAL PAIN]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Current research suggests that individuals without major psychological symptoms do not require more than simple therapy. In contrast, patients with major psychological involvement need multimodal, interdisciplinary therapeutic strategies. The clinician's acceptance of the importance of psychological factors in TMD pain forms the platform for convincingly educating patients about the need for multimodal management.

Methods: A narrative systematic review of 9 randomised controlled trials of patients with temporomandibular disorders to determine whether multimodal management strategies (at least two different modalities) are superior to simple therapy (dental care with no use of technical dental interventions). Literature search to 2006.

Quality of review: Whilst three databases were searched (Medline, Cochane and SCI) and reference lists checked for studies in any language, additional databases, website searching, handsearching journals and contacting experts may have identified further papers. Unpublished literature was not sought which may have included publication bias.

No formal method for assessing the quality of included studies is reported, however the limitations of each study has been presented in the table of studies. It is not clear whether study selection, data extraction and quality assessment of included studies was performed in duplicate, which is a method used to help limit potential bias.

Results: 1) In the disc displacement group with pain, multimodal therapy was not superior to explanation and advice. (2) A combination of occlusal appliance and biofeedback-assisted relaxation/stress management was not significantly superior to either of these therapies after 6 months. Furthermore, brief information alone or combined with relaxation training or occlusal appliance, respectively, were equally efficacious at the 6-month follow-up. There was no superiority of multimodal therapy including splints as compared with simple care. A slightly better outcome was reported for a combination of education and home physical therapy regimen than for patient education alone. (3) In temporomandibular pain patients with major psychological disturbances, patients benefited more from a combined therapeutic approach compared with simple care.

Citation: Türp JC, Jokstad A, Motschall E, Schindler HJ, Windecker-Gétaz I, Ettlin DA. Is there a superiority of multimodal as opposed to simple therapy in patients with temporomandibular disorders? A qualitative systematic review of the literature. Clinical Oral Implants Research 2007; 18(s3): 138–150.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Is there evidence that barrier membranes prevent bone resorption in autologous bone grafts during the healing period? A systematic review
document.publisher: International Journal of Oral and Maxillofacial Implants
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORAL SURGERY,RESTORATIVE DENTISTRY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Based on a systematic review of the literature, further evidence is needed to determine whether barrier membranes prevent bone resorption in autologous onlay bone grafts.

Methods: A systematic review to evaluate the available evidence that barrier membranes prevent bone resorption in autologous bone grafts. Two human studies (1 RCT and 1 CCT) plus 12 controlled animal studies were included. Literature search from database inception to October 2005.

Quality of review: Although several databases were searched with no language restrictions, the search terms used were limited and key papers may have been missed. The database searching was supplemented with reference list checking, but handsearching and contacting experts may also have found further studies. Unpublished research was not sought which may have introduced publication bias. Whilst the characteristics of included studies are clearly displayed, the results of individual trials are not.

Results: The articles included human and animal experiments with heterogenous objectives and outcome variables. Although most authors concluded that they had found evidence for the protective effect of barrier membrane on bone resorption in bone grafts, this systematic review reveals that the available evidence is too weak to support this. Most included studies were animal experiments; thus, extrapolation to the human situation is difficult. Most studies also had a small number of test sites, and sample size justification was generally not reported. Furthermore, ambiguity and lack of significance were found in many studies, along with additional limitations such as implantation site, nonsuitable designs, and varying outcome measures.

Citation: Gielkens PF, Bos RR, Raghoebar GM, Stegenga B. Is there evidence that barrier membranes prevent bone resorption in autologous bone grafts during the healing period? A systematic review. International Journal of Oral and Maxillofacial Implants 2007; 22(3): 390-398.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Knowledge of oral cancer, distress and screening intentions: longer term effects of a patient information leaflet
document.topics: <![CDATA[ SCREENING,RISK FACTORS,PREVENTION,OUTCOMES,ORAL HEALTH DISORDERS,PATIENTS,ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,ORAL CANCER,ORAL RADIOLOGY,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PUBLIC HEALTH,MANAGEMENT & INTERVENTIONS,INFORMATION,MANAGEMENT & POLICY,GROUPS,POPULATIONS]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: The introduction of a mouth cancer patient information leaflet (PIL) into dental practice may help to inform patients about oral cancer, moderate distress and encourage acceptance of an oral health screen.

Methods: Randomised controlled trial of 444 patients at 2 dental practices in the Northwest of England. The PIL was given to a randomised intervention group of patients in waiting room, whilst the control group did not receive the leaflet. A single sheet questionnaire was completed by both groups of patients at baseline in waiting room (immediately following leaflet administration in intervention arm of study). Patients were followed up at 8 weeks via a postal questionnaire.

Quality of study: The study was conducted in a large patient group.  However, it does not measure knowledge prior to the leaflet being provided, although there is a control group.  The method of randomisation is unclear and there are more women in the PIL group.

Results: Useable replies were received from 317 patients (60% response rate). All measures showed some benefit of immediate exposure to the leaflet at follow up. Older patients, less initial knowledge, and self-reported smoking positively predicted the re-reading of the leaflet.

Citation: Boundouki G, Humphris G, Field A. Knowledge of oral cancer, distress and screening intentions: longer term effects of a patient information leaflet. Patient Education and Counseling 2004; 53: 71-77

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Laser application in non-surgical periodontal therapy: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,PERIODONTOLOGY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: The Er:YAG laser seems to possess characteristics most suitable for the non-surgical treatment of chronic periodontitis. Research conducted so far has indicated that its safety and effects might be expected to be within the range reported for conventional mechanical debridement. However, the evidence from the evaluated studies is weak.

Methods: A narrative systematic review of  12 papers (11 studies) to determine the clinical effect of laser application compared with mechanical debridement in nonsurgical periodontal therapy in patients with chronic periodontitis? A secondary aim was to survey the relevant literature in relation to safety of laser applications. Database search dates 1990 to 2007 inclusive.

Quality of review: As the authors conclude, this review is limited by the weakness of the evidence.

Whilst the authors supplemented their search of two databases (PubMed and Central) with hand-searching and reference list checking, the limited search terms and the restriction to published studies in English may have resulted in studies being missed and the introduction of  bias. Appropriate procedures were used to minimise error and bias in study selection. However, no information is provided on the process used to data extract and to critically appraise included papers. The authors used a comprehensive checklist to quality assess papers for risk of bias. Only two of the 12 included papers were found to be low risk.

Results:  Er:YAG laser monotherapy resulted in similar clinical outcomes, both in the short and the long term (up to 24 months), compared with mechanical debridement. There is insufficient evidence to support the clinical application of either CO2, Nd:YAG, Nd:YAP, or different diode laser wavelengths.

Citation: Schwarz F, Aoki A, Becker J, et al. Laser application in non-surgical periodontal therapy: a systematic review. Journal of Clinical Periodontology, 2008; 35 (Suppl. 8): 29-44

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance.  You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

_____________________________________________________

See also: Karlsson MR, Lofgren CID, Jansson HM. The Effect of Laser Therapy as an Adjunct to Non-Surgical Periodontal Treatment in Subjects with Chronic Periodontitis: a systematic review. Journal of Periodontology, 2008; 79 (11): 2021-8

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Levels of salivary IgA antibodies to Candida spp. in HIV-infected adult patients: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORAL INFECTIONS,SPECIAL CARE DENTISTRY,IMMUNOCOMPROMISED PATIENTS]]>
document.body:
This is a provisional record for information. The review has been identified as potentially meeting our quality criteria. It will be critically appraised and a quality statement provided as soon as possible.
_____________________________________________________

 

Objective: To perform a systematic review of published data with the aim of evaluating the levels of IgA antibodies to Candida albicans in HIV-infected adult patients.

Methods: The search strategy was based on PubMed, Web of Science, Google Scholar, Cochrane and EMBASE databases. Also, the reference lists of included studies were searched. All abstracts found by electronic searches were independently scrutinized by two reviewers. To be eligible for review, the controlled studies had to present the following characteristics: samples of both HIV-infected adults and noninfected adults; appropriate HIV-diagnostic tests for both patient groups (case and control); IgA-diagnostic test applied to a similar population sample.

Results: Of 144 studies found, only six met the initial eligibility criteria, but three were excluded after a thorough analysis. To assess the methodological quality of the three remaining studies, they were categorized according the risk of bias. The three selected studies revealed that the levels of C. albicans-specific IgA antibody were higher in HIV-infected individuals compared with the control group.

Conclusion: Adequate IgA antibody responses to C. albicans appear to be maintained, since the levels of these antibodies were higher in all studies selected. Although the findings of this systematic review are encouraging, the scientific evidence should be interpreted carefully because there are only a few reports in the literature, mostly because of the lack of important methodological details or the varying methodologies employed 

Citation: Pomarico L, de Souza L, Castro GF, Teles RP, Luiz RR, Maia LC. Levels of salivary IgA antibodies to Candida spp. in HIV-infected adult patients: a systematic review. Journal of Dentistry 2010; 38(1):10-15.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Lingual flap retraction and prevention of lingual nerve damage associated with third molar surgery: a systematic review of the literature
document.publisher: Oral Surgery, Oral Medicine, Oral Pathology, Oral Radiology, and Endodontics
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORAL SURGERY,IMPACTED THIRD MOLARS,LINGUAL NERVE PROTECTION]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: The use of a lingual nerve retractor during third molar surgery was associated with an increased incidence of temporary nerve damage and was neither protective nor detrimental with respect to the incidence of permanent nerve damage.

Method: A systematic review of 1 randomised controlled trial and 7 prospective clinical series. Studies with lingual nerve injury cases and 6 months follow-up were included. Literature search to May 1999.

Quality of the review: This review should be viewed with caution. Publication bias may have been introduced as it is unclear whether unpublished research was sought. No formal method for appraising evidence was stated, however the inclusion criteria addressed aspects of quality of the included studies. The authors stated it was not possible to assess heterogeneity because of the limited number of studies and differences in study design, yet they have still combined the studies.

Results: In the 8 studies, lingual nerve injury occurred in 9.6%, 6.4% and 0.6% of the pooled lingual split technique with lingual flap retraction (LS), buccal approach with lingual flap retraction (BA+) and buccal approach without lingual flap retraction (BA-) procedures respectively.

On the basis of risk ratios comparing combined incidence rates, lingual nerve injury is 8.8 times more likely to occur in BA+ than in BA- procedures (CI = 4.3 - 17.8), 13.3 times more likely to occur in LS than in BA- procedures (CI = 6.6-26.9) and 1.5 times more likely to occur in LS than in BA+ procedures (CI = 1.2-1,8).

Permanent injury occurred in 0.1%, 0.6% and 0.2% of the combined LS, BA+ and BA- procedures, respectively.

Citation: Lingual flap retraction and prevention of lingual nerve damage associated with third molar surgery: a systematic review of the literature. Oral Surgery, Oral Medicine, Oral Pathology, Oral Radiologyand Endodontics 2001;91(4):395-401.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Lingual nerve protection during surgical removal of lower third molars. a prospective randomised study.
document.publisher: International Journal of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORAL SURGERY,IMPACTED THIRD MOLARS,LINGUAL NERVE PROTECTION]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: It is suggested that routine application of a lingual protecting instrument during surgical removal of a third molar is not neccessary in the hands of an experienced surgeon.

Method: Type II evidence - randomised controlled trial of 300 patients requiring surgical removal of the lower third molar (mean age 27.4 years). Patients were allocated to surgical removal of the third molar with protection of the lingual nerve by subperiosteal insertion of a retractor, or surgical removal without protection and re-examined after 7 days.

Quality of study: It is unclear whether all patients completed the study. There is no indication that patients or assessors were blind.

Results: The results indicate 1.33% incidence of temporary lingual nerve dysaesthesia - this being low in comparison with other studies. No permanent disturbances were found. The intergroup percentage difference was not significant.
 
Citation: Gargallo-Abiol J, Buenechea-Imaz R, Gay-Escoda C. Lingual nerve protection during surgical removal of lower third molars. International Journal of Oral & Maxillofacial Surgery 2000; 29(4): 268-71.
