document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Literature review of cancer mortality and incidence among dentists
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,DENTAL PUBLIC HEALTH]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: The evidence for an increased mortality or cancer incidence risk among dentists must be interpreted in light of methodological limitations of published studies. Future studies of dentists would benefit from the assessment of specific occupational exposures rather than relying on job title alone.

Methods: A systematic review of 19 epidemiological studies describing dentist mortality and cancer incidence risks focusing on all cancers combined and cancers of the brain, lung, reproductive organs and skin. Literature search to June 2006.

Quality of review: It is likely that the search may have missed relevant papers. The authors limited their search to two databases (PubMed and NIOSHTIC) using restrictive terms, with the addition of reference list checking. Searching additional databases using wider search terms, handsearching journals, contacting experts and website searching may have identified further studies.  Furthermore only published research in English or German was sought, which may have introduced publication and language bias.

It is not reported whether further methods to limit potential bias were employed, such as selection and data extraction of included studies in duplicate by independent reviewers. Nor was any formal method presented for assessing the quality of included studies; although the methodological limitations of the studies are reported in the results and discussion.

Results: Dentist cancer mortality and incidence generally showed a favourable risk pattern for lung cancer and overall cancer occurrence. Nevertheless, several studies reported an increased risk for certain cancers, such as those of the skin and, to a lesser extent, the brain and female breast. These elevated risks may be related to social status or education level, or may alternatively represent the impact of hazards in the workplace.

Citation: Simning A, van Wijngaarden E. Literature review of cancer mortality and incidence among dentists. Occupational and Environmental Medicine 2007; 64(7): 432-8.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. Full text online access is available to NHS staff in England via ATHENS passwords. To apply for an ATHENS password and access this resource and many others please go to the ATHENS registration page.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Long term dental arch changes after rapid maxillary expansion treatment: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,DENTO-FACIAL ANOMALIES,ORTHODONTICS]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Similar maxillary molar and cuspid expansion could be found in adolescents and young adults. Significantly less indirect mandibular molar and cuspid expansion was attained in young adults compared with adolescents. A significant overall gain in the maxillary and mandibular arch perimeter was found in adolescents. More transverse dental arch changes were found after puberty as compared with before, but the difference may not be clinically significant. No anteroposterior dental changes were found on lateral cephalometric radiographs.

Methods: Systematic review of 4 studies that assessed dental arch changes through measurements on dental casts or cephalometric radiographs. Literature search in databases from inception to March 2004.

Quality of Review: This review employed a good search strategy using a number of bibliographic databases and detailed search terms.  Reference lists of included papers were also checked for further relevant papers.  However, unpublished research does not appear to have been sought which may have introduced publication bias.  No formal methodology was reported for assessing the quality of included studies, however some of the inclusion/exclusion criteria do address this issue.  Only limited information is provided on the types of studies included.  The sample sizes of those included are small and therefore limit the reliability of the results reported.

Results: Forty-one articles met the initial inclusion criteria, but 35 were later rejected because they lacked a control group or only evaluated dental changes or used a semirapid technique. Some of them also lacked a reported measurement error. From the remaining articles, two did not report a long-term evaluation. From the final four articles, two measured changes through dental casts and two assessed changes through radiographs (one through lateral cephalometric radiographs and one through posteroanterior radiographs).

Citation: Lagravere MO, Major PW, Flores-Mir C. Long-term dental arch changes after rapid maxillary expansion treatment: a systematic review. Angle Orthodontist 2005; 75(2): 155-161

Access: Available to the general public.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Longevity of teeth and implants: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,RESTORATIVE DENTISTRY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: In clinically well-maintained patients, the loss rate at teeth was lower than that at implant. Bone level changes appeared to be small at teeth as well as at implants in well-maintained patients. Comparisons of the longevity at teeth and dental implants are difficult due to heterogeneity among the studies.

Methods: A narrative systematic review of 20 prospective longitudinal studies to determine the reported incidence of loss of tooth (11 studies – 3015 subjects) and implant (9 studies – 476 subjects). Database search date: to May 2007.

Quality of review: It is likely that potentially relevant studies were missed. The authors only searched PubMed using restrictive search terms, supplemented by reference list checking. Only published papers in the English language were sought which may have introduced publication and language biases. Searching additional databases without restrictions, using a more comprehensive search strategy, contacting experts, handsearching key journals and checking for grey literature may well have led to more studies being identified. No information is provided on the processes used to select and data extract included papers. Whilst no formal quality assessment process is described, several elements were identified in the inclusion criteria including sample size, length of follow-up and drop out rates.

The studies cover a wide range of populations and it is unlikely that data from some of the included studies is directly applicable to the UK general population (eg tooth loss studies in rural Chinese subjects and institutionalised people with learning difficulties).

Results: The incidence of tooth loss among subjects with a follow-up period of 10–30 years varied from 1.3% to 5% in the majority of studies, while in two epidemiological studies on rural Chinese populations the incidences of tooth loss were 14% and 20%. The percentage of implants reported as lost during the follow-up period varied between 1% and 18%. 

Citation: Tomasi C, Wennström JL, Berglundh T. Longevity of teeth and implants: a systematic review. Journal of Oral Rehabilitation, 2008; 35 (s1): 23-32.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

_____________________________________________________

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Long-term stability after craniofacial distraction osteogenesis
document.publisher: Journal of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,DENTO-FACIAL ANOMALIES,ORAL SURGERY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Although, based on the selected studies, craniofacial bone distraction osteogenesis appeared to show long-term stability; limitations of the studies merit caution in interpreting these findings. Some early relapse occurred in the first 3 years postdistraction, but stability was maintained thereafter. Some methodologically sounder studies are needed to confirm the present findings.

Methods: A narrative systematic review of six studies to review long-term skeletal stability after craniofacial distraction osteogenesis. Literature search from database inception to May 2007.

Quality of review: Although the authors searched a good range of databases along with the reference lists of included studies, it is likely that potentially relevant studies were missed. The search terms used were limited and it does not appear that an attempt was made to identify unpublished studies and grey literature. Appropriate procedures were used to minimise error and bias in data extraction and quality assessment. The authors assessed quality using a checklist and it appears that overall study quality was poor.

Citation: Al-Daghreer S, Flores-Mir C, El-Bialy T. Long-term stability after craniofacial distraction osteogenesis. Journal of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery 2008;66(9): 1812-9.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. Full text online access is available to NHS staff in England via ATHENS passwords. To apply for an ATHENS password and access this resource and many others please go to the ATHENS registration page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Long-term stability of orthodontic treatment and patient satisfaction
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORTHODONTICS]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: The review highlights the difficulties in drawing meaningful evidence-based conclusions because of the inherent problems associated with retrospective and uncontrolled study designs. There is a need for well-designed prospective studies with untreated control groups, sufficient sample sizes and sample selection according to type of malocclusion, age, and growth pattern.

Methods: A narrative systematic review of 38 randomised controlled trials to evaluate morphologic stability and patient satisfaction at least five years after orthodontic treatment. Literature review 1966 - 2005.

Quality of review: It is likely that key studies were not identified by the search strategy used. Only PubMed and the Cochrane Library were searched with reference list checking. There was no hand-searching, contacting of experts and unpublished research was not sought which may have introduced publication bias. Furthermore, only papers written in Swedish, Danish, Norwegian, Finnish and English were included.

Results: The search strategy identified 1004 abstracts or full-text articles, of which 38 met the inclusion criteria. Treatment of crowding resulted in successful dental alignment. However, the mandibular arch length and width gradually decreased, and crowding of the lower anterior teeth reoccurred post-retention. This condition was unpredictable at the individual level (limited evidence). Treatment of Angle Class II division 1 malocclusion with Herbst appliance normalized the occlusion. Relapse occurred but could not be predicted at the individual level (limited evidence). The scientific evidence was insufficient for conclusions on treatment of cross-bite, Angle Class III, open bite, and various other malocclusions as well as on long-term patient satisfaction.

Citation: Bondemark L, Holm A, Hansen K, Axelsson S, Mohlin B, Brattstrom V, Paulin G, Pietilah T. Long-term Stability of Orthodontic Treatment and Patient Satisfaction. A Systematic Review.The Angle Orthodontist 2007; 77(1) 181–191.

Access: Available to the general public.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Management of TMD: evidence from systematic reviews and meta-analyses
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,DENTO-FACIAL ANOMALIES]]>
document.body:
This is a provisional record for information. The review has been identified as potentially meeting our quality criteria. It will be critically appraised and a quality statement provided as soon as possible.

 

Aim: This systematic review (SR) synthesises recent evidence and assesses the methodological quality of published SRs in the management of temporomandibular disorders (TMD).

Methods: A systematic literature search was conducted in the PubMed, Cochrane Library, and Bandolier databases for 1987 to September 2009. Two investigators evaluated the methodological quality of each identified SR using two measurement tools: the assessment of multiple systematic reviews (AMSTAR) and level of research design scoring.

Results: Thirty-eight SRs met inclusion criteria and 30 were analysed: 23 qualitative SRs and seven meta-analyses. Ten SRs were related to occlusal appliances, occlusal adjustment or bruxism; eight to physical therapy; seven to pharmacologic treatment; four to TMJ and maxillofacial surgery; and six to behavioural therapy and multimodal treatment. The median AMSTAR score was 6 (range 2-11). Eighteen of the SRs were based on randomised clinical trials (RCTs), three were based on case-control studies, and nine were a mix of RCTs and case series. Most SRs had pain and clinical measures as primary outcome variables, while few SRs reported psychological status, daily activities, or quality of life.

Conclusions: There is some evidence that the following can be effective in alleviating TMD pain: occlusal appliances, acupuncture, behavioural therapy, jaw exercises, postural training, and some pharmacological treatments. Evidence for the effect of electrophysical modalities and surgery is insufficient, and occlusal adjustment seems to have no effect. One limitation of most of the reviewed SRs was that the considerable variation in methodology between the primary studies made definitive conclusions impossible. 

Citation: List T, Axelsson S. Management of TMD: evidence from systematic reviews and meta-analyses. Journal of Oral Rehabilitation 2010; 37(6):430-51.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Mandibular changes produced by functional appliances in Class II malocclusion: a systematic review.
document.publisher: American Journal of Orthodontics and Dentofacial Orthopedics
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORTHODONTICS]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions:  The amount of supplementary mandibular growth appears to be significantly larger if the functional treatment is performed at the pubertal peak in skeletal maturation. None of the 4 RCTs reported a clinically significant change in mandibular length induced by functional appliances; 3 of the 4 RCTs treated subjects at a prepubertal stage of skeletal maturity. The Herbst appliance showed the highest coefficient of efficiency (0.28 mm per month) followed by the Twin-block (0.23 mm per month).

Methods: A systematic review of four randomized clinical trials and eighteen controlled clinical trials to assess the efficacy of functional appliances in enhancing mandibular growth in Class II subjects. Literature search Jan 1966-Jan 2005.

Quality of review:  It is likely that relevant studies have been missed as there was a limited search strategy.  Only PubMed and the Cochrane Clinical Trials Register were searched using narrow search terms.  The authors do not report any additional searching and excluded non-English language papers suggesting the potential for publication and language bias.  The Jadad Scale was used by two independent reviewers to assess quality of both RCTs and CCTs and quality is discussed in some detail; only 6 of the included studies were above average quality and all had methodological limitations.  No meta-analysis was conducted and limited information was provided on individual study results.

Results: Two-thirds of the samples in the 22 studies reported a clinically significant supplementary elongation in total mandibular length (a change greater than 2.0 mm in the treated group compared with the untreated group) as a result of overall active treatment with functional appliances.

Citation: Cozza P, Baccetti T, Franchi L, De TL, McNamara JA, Jr., Cozza P et al. Mandibular changes produced by functional appliances in Class II malocclusion: a systematic review. American Journal of Orthodontics and Dentofacial Orthopedics 2006; 129 (5): 599-12

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Maternal and child oral health - systematic review and analysis
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,DENTAL CARIES,DENTAL PUBLIC HEALTH,PAEDIATRIC DENTISTRY,CAUSES & PREVENTION]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors’ questions and conclusions:

1.  What is the influence of maternal oral health on gestational and peri natal events?  [Strength of evidence: Moderate]

  • Periodontal disease in pregnancy is associated with higher risk of poor birth outcomes in women from disadvantaged groups.
  • Treatment of periodontal disease in pregnant women to reduce risk of poor birth outcomes is currently not supported by evidence however is likely to be beneficial.
  • Control of plaque for the treatment and prevention of periodontal disease is likely to be beneficial to both mother and child.

2.  What is the impact of maternal health and pre and peri-natal events on the development of developmental defects of enamel? [Strength of evidence: Low to Moderate]

  • Promotion of good prenatal maternal health and nutrition may lower risks of developmental defects of enamel in their child.
  • Children born prematurely or those with history of significant illness in early infancy should be considered high risk for developmental defects of enamel and therefore early childhood caries.

3.  What is the influence of maternal general health on the ECC experience in their offspring? [Strength of Evidence: Low]

  • Parental smoking, particularly by mothers may increase the risk of dental caries in their offspring. In addition to the more general health benefits, smoking cessation strategies targeted towards parents may have beneficial effects on future oral health of their child.

4.  What is the influence of maternal oral health on ECC experience in their offspring? [Strength of Evidence: Moderate] 

  • Although there is no very strong evidence (ie RCTs) regarding the relationship between parental (especially maternal) oral health and that of their offspring, what evidence does exist is consistently supportive.
  • Interventions which aim to improve the oral health of parents are likely to have beneficial effects on the oral health of their offspring.

5.  How effective are interventions involving mothers in reducing ECC in their infants? [Strength of Evidence: Moderate]

  • Primary-primary prevention programs which aim to reduce dental caries in children by improving the oral health of mothers are supported by available evidence.
  •  Programs which provide one on one education and support to mothers are also likely to result in significant benefit particularly where they involve outreach into family homes.

Methods: A narrative systematic review incorporating a range of study types. Database searches from 1997. End date not provided.

Quality of review: Whilst this review was conducted for the New Zealand government and consequently focuses on information relevant to the NZ population, it reviews evidence from around the world.

The authors made a good attempt to identify the relevant literature, searching a range of databases and grey literature sources. Whilst the database search strategies used were restrictive, this is likely to have been counteracted by searching for unpublished studies, contacting experts and checking reference lists. Inclusion was limited to English language studies which may have introduced bias.

Limited information is provided on the inclusion/exclusion criteria for the review and the methodology used to conduct the review is unclear. Consequently the introduction of bias and error cannot be excluded. The authors used CASP checklists to evaluate the quality of included studies. None of the summary findings are supported by high quality evidence.

Citation:  Kilpatrick NM, Gussy MG, Mahoney E. Maternal and child oral health - systematic review and analysis. Murdoch Children’s Research Institute, 2008

Access: Full text is freely available.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Maternal infection and risk of preeclampsia: Systematic review and metaanalysis
document.publisher: American Journal of Obstetrics and Gynecology
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ASSOCIATED CONDITIONS,OUTCOMES,ORAL HEALTH DISORDERS,PREGNANCY & CHILDBIRTH DISORDERS,WOMEN,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,ORAL DISORDERS,ORAL HEALTH,PUBLIC HEALTH,MONTHLY ADDITIONS,POPULATIONS,GROUPS,2009 NOVEMBER]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors’ conclusions: Urinary tract infection and periodontal disease during pregnancy are associated with an increased risk of preeclampsia. More studies are required to verify this as well  as to explore whether or not such relationships are causal and, if so, the mechanisms involved

Methods: Systematic review and meta-analysis of 49 observational studies to examine the relationship between maternal infection and preeclampsia. Database search from inception to June 2007.

Quality of review: The results should be interpreted with caution as the quality of the included studies does not appear to be as high as the authors' quality assessment might suggest.

The authors made a good attempt to identify potentially relevant papers. They searched a range of databases without language restrictions and supplemented this with checking reference lists, contacting experts and reviewing conference abstracts. One author selected studies, assessed methodological quality and extracted data which may have introduced error and bias. The authors used seven criteria to critically appraise the included studies and rated all periodontal studies (7 case control; 2 cohort) as high quality. However, a closer look at the data provided on these studies suggests that this may be an overly generous estimate. 

Results: The risk of preeclampsia was increased in pregnant women with urinary tract infection (pooled odds ratio, 1.57; 95% CI, 1.45-1.70) and periodontal disease (pooled odds ratio,
1.76; 95% CI, 1.43-2.18). There were no associations between preeclampsia and presence of antibodies to Chlamydia pneumoniae, Helicobacter pylori, and cytomegalovirus, treated and nontreated HIV infection, and malaria. Individual studies did not find a relationship between herpes simplex virus type 2, bacterial vaginosis, and Mycoplasma hominis and preeclampsia.

Citation: Conde-Agudelo A, Villar J, Lindheimer M. Maternal infection and risk of preeclampsia: Systematic review and metaanalysis. American Journal of Obstretics and Gynecology, 2008; 198 (1): 7-22.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Maxillary molar distalization with noncompliance intramaxillary appliances in Class II malocclusion. A systematic review.
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORTHODONTICS]]>
document.body:
This is a provisional record for information. The review has been identified as potentially meeting our quality criteria. It will be critically appraised and a quality statement provided as soon as possible.
_____________________________________________________

Authors' conclusions: Noncompliance intramaxillary molar distalization appliances all act by distalizing molars with a concomitant and unavoidable loss of anchorage, as revealed by incisor and premolar mesial movement. Buccal acting and palatal acting appliances demonstrate almost similar results, with palatal acting appliances showing less tipping. Friction-free palatal acting appliances appear to produce better molar distalizing effects, but with a concomitant notable loss of anchorage.

Methods: A systematic review and meta-analysis of thirteen studies to evaluate the dental effects of noncompliance intramaxillary appliances in individuals with Class II malocclusion. Dates of literature search not provided.

Results: The data were grouped and analyzed in terms of molar distalization, tipping and vertical movements, and incisor and premolar mesialization, tipping, and vertical movements.  Maxillary first molars showed distal crown movement and tipping greater than the mesial crown movement and tipping shown by incisors and premolars. Vertical movements of incisors and premolars were in general extrusive, but molars were intrusive or extrusive, depending on the study and the type of appliance used. Appliances that acted palatally seemed to display a smaller distal tipping movement, as well as smaller incisor and premolar mesial tipping movements, when compared with those that acted buccally. Friction-free appliances, namely the pendulum, produced a large amount of mesiodistal movement and tipping, if no therapeutic uprighting activation was applied.

Citation: Antonarakis GS, Kiliaridis S. Maxillary molar distalization with noncompliance intramaxillary appliances in Class II malocclusion. A systematic review. Angle Orthodontist 2008; 78(6):1133-40.

Access: Full text freely available.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Meta-analysis and pooled analysis of GSTM1 and CYP1A1 polymorphisms and oral and pharyngeal cancers: a HuGE-GSEC review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,ORAL CANCER,RISK FACTORS]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Our findings suggest that tobacco use and genetic factors play a significant role in oral and pharyngeal cancer.

Methods: A meta-analysis of 30 case controlled studies to review the association of GSTM1 and CYP1A1 polymorphisms and oral and pharyngeal cancer. Literature search to October 2007.

Quality of review: Whilst a comprehensive search strategy was utilised in the Medline and Embase, searching additional databases may have identified further papers. Unpublished research does not appear to have been sought which may have introduced publication bias. Furthermore, only papers written in English, Spanish, Italian or French were included which may have led to language bias. No formal method of critically appraising studies is reported, however the quality of included studies is described in the discussion.

Results: The GSTM1 deletion was 2-fold more likely to occur in African American and African cases than controls (odds ratio: 1.7, 95% confidence interval: 0.9-3.3), although this was not observed among whites (odds ratio: 1.0, 95% confidence interval: 0.9-1.1). The meta-analysis and pooled analysis showed a significant association between oral and pharyngeal cancer and the CYP1A1 MspI homozygous variant (meta-ORm2/m2: 1.9, 95% confidence interval: 1.4-2.7; Pooled ORm2m2: 2.0, 95% confidence interval: 1.3-3.1; ORm1m2 or [infi]m2m2: 1.3, 95% confidence interval: 1.1-1.6). The association was present for the CYP1A1 (exon 7) polymorphism (ORVal/Val: 2.2, 95% confidence interval: 1.1-4.5) in ever smokers. A joint effect was observed for GSTM1 homozygous deletion and the CYP1A1 m1m2 variant on cancer risk.

Citation: Varela-Lema L, Taioli E, Ruano-Ravina A et al. Meta-analysis and pooled analysis of GSTM1 and CYP1A1 polymorphisms and oral and pharyngeal cancers: a HuGE-GSEC review. Genetics in Medicine 2008; 10(6): 369-84.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Meta-analysis of anterior veneer restorations in clinical studies
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,DENTAL CARIES,RESTORATIVE DENTISTRY,TREATMENT & MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Porcelain veneer restorations (VRs) show acceptable longevity after 3 years, which appears to be better than that of preformed acrylic veneer restorations.

Methods: A systematic review of clinical studies to aggregate an overall survival result for four types of VRs. Literature search 1983 to November 1996. 15 clinical trials were included, with no further information as to whether they were randomised or not.

Quality of review: It is likely key papers may have been missed as only Medline has been searched with no reference list follow-up or handsearching. Only English papers were included and unpublished research was not sought which may have introduced publication bias.

Results: From the nine studies on porcelain veneer restorations (VR), the pooled cumulative proportion of survival after 3 years was 0.92 (s.e. 0.01) and from three studies on preformed acrylic VRs this figure was 0.74 (s.e. 0.03). From both direct and indirect resin composite VRs, data from only one study were available after 2.5 and 2 years, respectively. The evaluative and statistical basis of clinical VR studies may be improved to obtain an effective inference of the results.

Citation: Kreulen CM, Creugers NHJ, Meijering AC. Meta-analysis of anterior veneer restorations in clinical studies. Journal of Dentistry. 1998; 26: 345-353

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Meta-analysis of immediate changes with rapid maxillary expansion treatment
document.publisher: Journal of the American Dental Association
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,DENTO-FACIAL ANOMALIES,ORTHODONTICS]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: The greatest changes were in the maxillary transverse plane in which the width gained was caused more by dental expansion that true skeletal expansion. Few vertical and anteroposterior changes were statistically significant, and none was clinically significant.  It should be noted that all the studies had methodological deficiencies and the evidence should be interpreted carefully.

Methods:  A systematic review and meta-analysis of fourteen retrospective studies to evaluate immediate transverse, anteposterior and vertical dental and skeletal changes produced by rapid maxillary expansion.

Quality of review: The authors conducted a search across a wide range of databases and reference lists of included studies were checked.  It does not appear that there were any language restrictions.  There was no search for unpublished studies which may have contributed to publication bias.   The quality of the included studies was assessed.  All had significant methodological flaws and the authors indicate that results should be viewed with caution.   The size of the included studies is generally small and the numbers included in each sub-analysis is not clear from the presentation of results.

Results: The greatest dental and skeletal changes occurred at the dentition, especially in the transverse dental dimension.  Exerting the expansion force on the teeth produced some undesirable effects such as dental tipping and root resorption.   An average of 6.7 mm of expansion was obtained, measured from the molar crowns, while a 4.5 mm expansion increase was observed on the molar root apex.  Significant skeletal increases for intercondyle (valid only for the mandible) width and maxillary interalveolar width measured from the buccal plates. However, these increases were around 2 to 3 mm, clearly showing that a great portion of the true expansion was dental rather than skeletal.  Nonsignificant anteroposterior skeletal changes.  No statistically significant mandibular expansion with the exception of the intercondyle width.

Citation: Lagravere MO, Heo G, Major PW, Flores-Mir C. Journal of the American Dental Association 2006; 137(1): 44-53.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Meta-analysis of mortality and cancer incidence among workers in the synthetic rubber-producing industry
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,ORAL CANCER,RISK FACTORS,OCCUPATIONAL]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions:  Interpretation of these results is complicated by substantial unexplainable heterogeneity; small excesses in specific mortality outcomes may have been disguised by the healthy worker effect.

Methods:  A systematic review and meta-analysis of cohort studies to identify mortality rates and cancer incidence for workers in the rubber-producing industry.

Quality of Review:  An extensive search was undertaken which incorporated unpublished data (although none was subsequently incorporated into the meta-analysis). However, the search was restricted to the English language. Papers were critically appraised by two independent reviewers using a modified scoring scale for observational studies. The authors discuss the possibility of publication bias, particularly for outcomes where only a small number of studies were available. 12 mortality studies and four incidence studies looked at cancer of the buccal cavity and pharynx. An additional mortality analysis looking specifically at tyre production included two oral studies. None of the results were statistically significant. 

Results: The meta-standardised mortality ratio was 0.86 (95% CI: 0.82, 0.91) for all-cause mortality (28 cohorts) and 0.94 (95% CI: 0.89, 1.01) for all malignant neoplasms (27 cohorts). Heterogeneity was observed for these endpoints and for the majority of disease-specific outcomes.

Citation: Alder N, Fenty J, Sutton AJ, Rushton L, Jones DR, et al. Meta-analysis of mortality and cancer incidence among workers in the synthetic rubber-producing industry. American Journal of Epidemiology 2006; 164 (5): 405-20

Access: The full text of this paper is freely available.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Meta-analysis of periodontal disease and risk of coronary heart disease and stroke
document.publisher: Oral Surgery, Oral Medicine, Oral Pathology, Oral Radiology, and Endodontics
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,PERIODONTOLOGY,ASSOCIATED CONDITIONS]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Periodontal disease appears to be associated with a 19% increase in risk of future cardiovascular disease. This increase in relative risk (RR) is more prominent (44%) in persons aged less than or equal to 65 years. Although the increment of risk of coronary heart disease between subjects with and without periodontal disease in the general population is modest, at around 20% because nearly 40% of population has periodontal disease, this modest increase may have a profound public health impact

Methods: A systematic review of 9 cohort studies to provide a quantitative summary of periodontal disease as a risk factor for cardiovascular disease and to explore the possible causes for differences in reported results. Literature search 1980-2001.

Quality of review: Unpublished literature was not sought, however the test of publication bias was not significant suggesting it is unlikely studies might have been chosen preferentially.  

Results: The summary relative risk was 1.19 (95% CI, 1.08-1.32), indicating a higher risk of future cardiovascular events in individuals with periodontal disease compared with those without. In an analysis stratified to individuals less than or equal to 65 years of age, the RR was 1.44 (95%CI 1.20-1.73).

When the outcome was restricted to stroke only, the RR was 2.85 (95% CI, 1.78 to 4.56). In the metaregression analysis, the effects of residual confounding caused an overestimate of the results by 12.9% and with a proxy for periodontal disease, caused an underestimate of 29.7%.

Citation: Janket SJ, Baird AE, Sung-Kiang Chuang, Jones J. Meta-analysis of periodontal disease and risk of coronary heart disease and stroke. Oral Surgery, Oral Medicine, Oral Pathology, Oral Radiology and Endodontics. 2003; 95 (5): 559-569.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Meta-analysis of the effectiveness of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs in a standardized pain model
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORAL SURGERY,IMPACTED THIRD MOLARS,POSTOPERATIVE PAIN RELIEF]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Author's conclusions: Specific nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) should be considered for the control of postoperative oral surgery pain.

Method: A systematic review of 8 double blind RCTs comparing the efficacy of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) and opioid analgesics for treating moderate to severe surgery pain from third molar extractions. The studies involved 1,163 patients, drawn from more than 300 studies published between 1990 and 2000.

Quality of review: The literature search was limited to English language studies and to two databases, and it is unclear whether unpublished data were sought. The authors did not state who selected articles and extracted data and whether the selected studies were reviewed for quality; although these were limited to double-blind randomised trials with stated outcome measures and minimum follow-up periods.

A random-effects model was used, but there was no formal test for heterogeneity and meta-analysis is not presented graphically; this is important where there were many different treatment regimes and participant study characteristics in the meta-analysis.

Results: Data from the 8 studies were subjected to standardized data transformation and analysis procedures using preselected pain measurement inventories. Of the 8 studies, 5 showed significantly better outcomes (p <0.05) with NSAIDs, while 3 showed no differences in outcomes (p >0.05).

Overall there was a signficiant difference favouring the NSAID in the outcome measures of PPID or TOTPAR when the NSAID regimens (naproxen, ketorolac, fluriborifen, ibuprofen, or diflunisal) and opiod (codeine) regimens were compared.

Adverse reactions were greater in the opiate group (p<0.001). Results of the meta-analysis revealed that NSAIDs were either as effective or more effective than codeine-based analgesics for treating the moderate to severe pain associated with oral surgery. NSAIDs also were associated with fewer complications.

Citation: Biddle C. Meta-analysis of the effectiveness of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs in a standardized pain model. American Association of Nurse Anesthetists Journal. 2002;70(2):111-4.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Meta-analysis of the prognostic significance of perionodal spread in head and neck squamous cell carcinomas (HNSCC) patients
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,ORAL CANCER,ENT AND AUDIOLOGY,NOSE & SINUS DISORDERS,LARYNX & PHARYNX DISORDERS,SALIVARY GLAND DISORDERS,NEOPLASMS,MALIGNANT,NEOPLASMS,MALIGNANT,NEOPLASMS,MALIGNANT,CONDITIONS,DIAGNOSIS & REFERRAL,HEAD & NECK CANCER]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: The results support the conclusion that perinodal spread is a significant adverse risk factor for survival in patients with head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC).

Method: Systematic review and meta-analysis of 9 studies to examine the prognostic significance of perinodal spread in patients suffering from HNSCC.

Quality of review: Results should be viewed cautiously, as it is likely key papers were missed. Only PubMed was searched with limited search terms and it does not appear that reference lists were checked, experts contacted, unpublished research or non-English language studies sought. The possibility of publication and language bias therefore cannot be excluded. The authors did not formally appraise the quality of the included studies, although they did exclude those that had missing data on 5 year survival rates or numbers of patients.

Results: Study methodology allowed the enrollment of only nine studies of 115 published papers. Excluded studies lacked regarding primary tumour location, number and location of lymph node metastases, values on five-year survival, or adequate follow-up data. A summarised odds ratio of 2.7 leads to the conclusion that perinodal spread negatively impacts the five-year survival. The lower confidence limit of more than 2 also supports the concept that perinodal spread significantly reduces (doubled risk) the five-year-survival.

Citation: Dunne AA, Muller HH, Eisele DW, Kebel K, Moll R and Werner JA. Meta-analysis of the prognostic significance of perionodal spread in head and neck squamous cell carcinomas (HNSCC) patients. European Journal of Cancer 2006; 42: 1863-1868.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Meta-analysis of the relation between European and American smokeless tobacco and oral cancer
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL CANCER,ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,RISK FACTORS,TOBACCO]]>
document.body:
This is a provisional record for information. The review has been identified as potentially meeting our quality criteria. It will be critically appraised and a quality statement provided as soon as possible.
_____________________________________________________

Authors' conclusions: Smokeless tobacco, as used in America or Europe, carries at most a minor increased risk of oral cancer. However, elevated risks in specific populations or from specific products cannot definitely be excluded.

Method: A systematic review and meta-analysis of 32 studies (3 cohort and 29 case control) to consider the evidence for smokeless tobacco as a contributor to oral cancer in Western populations. Literature search from inception to March 2005.

Results: Based on 38 heterogeneous study-specific estimates of the odds ratio or relative risk for smokeless tobacco use, the random-effects estimate was 1.87 (95% confidence interval 1.40–2.48). The increase was mainly evident in studies conducted before 1980. No increase was seen in studies in Scandinavia. Restricting attention to the seven estimates adjusted for smoking and alcohol eliminated both heterogeneity and excess risk (1.02; 0.82–1.28). Estimates also varied by sex (higher in females) and by study design (higher in case-control studies with hospital controls) but more clearly in studies where estimates were unadjusted, even for age. The pattern of estimates suggests some publication bias. Based on limited data specific to never smokers, the random-effects estimate was 1.94 (0.88–4.28), the eight individual estimates being heterogeneous and based on few exposed cases.

Citation: Weitkunat R, Sanders E, Lee PN. Meta-analysis of the relation between European and American smokeless tobacco and oral cancer. BMC Public Health 2007 Nov 15;7:334.

Access: this paper is freely available.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Meta-analysis of treatment need for temporomandibular disorders in adult nonpatients
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,DENTO-FACIAL ANOMALIES]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: The treatment need for temporomandibular disorders (TMD) in the general adult population is substantial and varies according to definition, criteria, and age. Findings of this meta-analysis can be used for planning and allocating health-care resources.

Methods: A systematic review and meta-analysis of 17 studies to determine the prevalence of treatment need for temporomandibular disorders in adult populations. Literature search to July 2006.

Quality of review: The authors searched several databases, checked reference lists and hand searched two journals. However, they used a limited range of search terms and restricted inclusion to English language studies which makes it likely that potentially relevant studies were missed. Only published studies were included and the authors used a funnel plot to check for publication bias.They indicate that there “was minimal evidence” of bias. Appropriate procedures were used to minimise error and bias in study selection, data extraction and quality assessment. Only five of the 17 included studies were of high quality and none meet all listed quality criteria. The authors state that the “meta-analytic estimates were not adjusted for the quality score” but don’t explain why, and no sensitivity analysis of the five high quality studies was conducted. The degree of heterogeneity evident in the forest plot summarising the meta-analysis makes it questionable whether the studies should have been combined in this way.

Results: The prevalence of treatment need for TMD in adults (95% confidence interval) was estimated to be 15.6% (10.0, 23.6) for the fixed effect model and 16.2% (11.2, 21.1) for the random-effects model. Criteria of estimating treatment need and place of study strongly influenced summary estimates of treatment need (P < .001). Need estimates derived from clinical TMD signs were higher than estimates based on subject-reported symptoms (P = .010). Estimates for younger subjects (19 to 45 years) were higher than for older subjects (46+ years; P = .013).

Citation: Al-Jundi MA, John MT, Setz JM, Szentpétery A, Kuss O. Meta-analysis of treatment need for temporomandibular disorders in adult nonpatients. Journal of Orofacial Pain 2008;22(2):97-107.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. Full text online access is available to NHS staff in England via ATHENS passwords. To apply for an ATHENS password and access this resource and many others please go to the ATHENS registration page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Meta-analysis on the effectiveness of powered toothbrushes for orthodontic patients
document.publisher: American Journal of Orthodontics and Dentofacial Orthopedics
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORTHODONTICS]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Based on the insufficiency of the available data, any inferences for clinical practice are precluded. Greater standardization of the methodology used would add to the relevance of future trials.

Methods: A systematic review and meta-analysis of five randomised controlled trials to determine the efficacy of powered vs manual toothbrushes in patients with gingival inflammation having fixed orthodontic appliance therapy. Database search dates: inception to April 2007.

Quality of review: Overall a well conducted systematic review, based on a pre-defined protocol. The authors searched multiple databases without language restrictions, supplemented by reference list checking, and searching for grey literature. Whilst the search terms were limited, possibly resulting in relevant studies being missed, this likelihood is reduced by the range of sources searched. Appropriate procedures were used to minimise error and bias in study selection, data extraction and quality assessment. Quality assessment reviewed key elements which reduce bias: adequate randomisation, allocation concealment, blinding of examiners and appropriate management of loss to follow-up.

There is no information provided as to whether some or all of the included studies were manufacturer-sponsored trials; which has been shown to introduce bias.

Results: Only one trial reported a statistically significant benefit regarding gingivitis reduction. However, the results of quality assessment and the short experimental period of the included studies led to the conclusion that their validity is limited.

Citation: Kaklamanos EG, Kalfas S. Meta-analysis on the effectiveness of powered toothbrushes for orthodontic patients. American Journal of Orthodontics and Dentofacial Orthopedics, 2008; 133 (2): 187.e1-e14

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Microbial identification in the management of periodontal diseases. A systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,TREATMENT & MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions:  The published material suggests that microbiological monitoring may be useful in management of selected patients who do not respond to standard therapy. Some practitioners consider microbial identification a valuable adjunct to managing patients with certain forms of periodontitis, although there is a lack of strong evidence to this effect. Additional research is needed to address this issue.

Methods: Systematic review to determine if micorbial identification influences periodontal patient management and whether treatment outcomes are better compared to patients whose treatment plans are developed without this information. 24 studies were included(mostly case reports without controls), representing a total patient population of approximately 835. Literature search 1991-2002.

Quality of review: Although selected journals were handsearched and experts contacted for unpublished research, studies may well have been missed as only Medline was searched.  The restriction to English language papers may have introduced language bias. The studies were graded for quality on a scale of 1-5.  No included studies was graded above 3 and the authors state that most were case reports without controls.

Results: There was a lack of articles with a high evidence rating; most pertinent articles were either case reports or case series without controls. Because reports were heterogeneous regarding study design, patient selection, and data collection, meta-analysis was not feasible and results are summarized in tabular format.

Thirteen studies reported on microbiological identification as an aid in treatment planning. Eleven studies reported a differential clinical response depending on the detection or lack of detection of specific organisms.

Citation: Listgarten MA, Loomer PM. Microbial identification in the management of periodontal diseases. A systematic overview. Annals of Periodontology. 2003; 8(1): 182-192

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Mineral trioxide aggregate as a pulpotomy medicament: a evidence-based assessment
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,DENTAL CARIES,ENDODONTICS,PAEDIATRIC DENTISTRY,TREATMENT & MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors’ conclusions: Currently-available evidence suggests mineral trioxide aggregate (MTA)  compared with formocresol (FC), ferric sulphate (FS) and calcium hydroxide (CH) as a pulpotomy medicament resulted in significantly higher clinical and radiographic successes in all time periods up to exfoliation.

Methods: A systematic review and meta-analysis to determine the effectiveness of mineral trioxide aggregate as a pulpotomy medicament. Database search 1966 to October 2005. Eighteen RCTs and 10 CTs (total 1,260 molars) were identified to compare MTA and FC; fourteen RCTs and 4 CTs (total 959 molars) were identified to compare MTA and FS; nine RCTs and 7 CTs (total 531 molars) were identified to compare MTA and CH.

Quality of review: The authors searched a good selection of databases, supplemented by reference checking and a Google search. However, it is possible that relevant studies were missed as the search terms were very restrictive and only published studies in English were included. This may have introduced bias. The authors do not state the procedure used to select, data extract or quality assess included studies.  Whilst the included studies are not formally rated, the quality of included studies is discussed and the authors consider key elements such as randomisation, allocation concealment, assessor blinding and sample size.

Results:

  • Direct meta-analyses found MTA was significantly more successful clinically (COR=3.11; 95%CI=1.09-8.85) and radiographically (COR=4.50; CI=1.78--11.42) than FC, and clinical and radiographic data confirmed this. 
  • Indirect meta-analyses  found no statistically significant difference in clinical successes, but a statistically significant difference in the radiographic successes of MTA and FS (COR=4.69; CI=1.70--12.95). Clinical and radiographic data showed MTA was significantly more successful than FS.
  • Indirect meta-analyses found statistically significant differences in the clinical (COR=6.48; CI=1.75-24.0) and radiographic (COR=10.47; CI=3.35-32.76) successes of MTA and CH. Clinical and radiographic data confirmed MTA was significantly more successful than CH.

Citation: Ng FK, Messer LB. Mineral trioxide aggregate as a pulpotomy medicament: a evidence-based assessment. European Archives of Paediatric Dentistry, 2008; 9 (2): 58-73

111-1Mobile phones and mouth cancer

Both BBC News1 and the Daily Telegraph2 reported the results of an Israeli study3 suggesting that  heavy mobile phone use may be linked to an increased chance of cancer of the salivary gland.

A full report and analysis of the evidence is available from the NHS Choices Behind the Headlines service

 

_________________________________________________________

1  'Cancer link' to heavy mobile use. BBC News, February 18 2008

2 Heavy mobile phone use a cancer risk. The Daily Telegraph, February 18 2008

3 Sadetzki S, Chetrit A, Jarus-Hakak A, et al. Cellular Phone Use and Risk of Benign and Malignant Parotid Gland Tumors—A Nationwide Case-Control Study. Am J Epidemiol 2008; 167: 457–467.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Models for individual oral health promotion and their effectiveness: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,DENTAL PUBLIC HEALTH]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors’ conclusions: There is a need to develop an effective model for chairside oral health promotion that incorporates evidence and allows oral health professionals to focus more on the underlying social determinants or oral disease during the clinical encounter.

Motivational interviewing, based on the Transtheoretical Model, has been found to be one of the most effective approaches to altering client’s behaviours. This approach has been successfully utilized in a variety of fields, including substance abuse, smoking, HIV risk reduction, diabetes and obesity. There is potential to develop this approach further within the oral health field.

Methods: A  narrative systematic review to assess the effectiveness of behaviour models as a basis for individual oral health promotion. Thirty two studies were identified in the fields of clinical preventions and health education, motivational interviewing (MI), counselling and models based interventions. This article discusses the results of studies judged to be of with moderate or strong quality (n=24). Literature search between 2000 and 2007.

Quality of review: The review is limited by the lack of detail reported. The populations or outcomes of interest are not clearly defined, and methods are not fully reported. The authors searched several databases, supplemented by reference list scanning. However, it is possible that potentially relevant studies were missed. The search strategy appears limited and only English language published studies were sought, which may have introduced bias.

It is unclear what methods were used to quality assess and data extract studies and the introduction of error and bias cannot be excluded. The characteristics and results of each study are only described in the text. Given the broad range of populations and outcomes examined, a table/brief overview of the characteristics and results highlighting what works for whom, would have been helpful.

Results: Clinical prevention and health education approaches alone have been found to be unsuccessful in achieving sustainable improvements in oral health. Motivational interventions were found to be the most effective method for altering health behaviours in a clinical setting. The results from have shown that levels of MI training, MI skill and the optimal duration for MI intervention in health care settings remain unknown as often these data were not reported. There is an urgent need for more rigorous good quality trials and research to assess the effectiveness of MI in domains outside addiction in order for its broader application to be considered.

Citation: Yevlahova D, Satur J. Models for individual oral health promotion and their effectiveness: a systematic review. Australian Dental Journal 2009; 54(3):190-197.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Mucositis incidence, severity and associated outcomes in patients with head and neck cancer receiving radiotherapy with or without chemotherapy: a systematic literature review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,ORAL CANCER,TREATMENT & MANAGEMENT,RADIOTHERAPY,CHEMOTHERAPY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Mucositis is a frequent, severe toxicity in patients treated with radiotherapy (RT) for head and neck cancer. While it appears that mucositis may lead to hospitalization and treatment interruptions, its overall impact on outcomes has not been adequately investigated.

Methods: Systematic review of 33 randomised controlled trials  (n=6181 patients) to examine the frequency of mucositis and associated outcomes in patients receiving radiotherapy for head and neck cancer. Literature search 1996-1999.

Quality of review: The authors searched a range of databases including Medline, Embase, Cochrane Library and supplemented the search with reference list checking and reviewing conference proceedings.  However they excluded unpublished and non-English language studies which may have introduced publication and language biases.  No formal validity assessment is described, however, the review discusses several quality aspects of the included studies such as study power, patient baseline characteristics, intention to treat analysis and follow-up period.

Results: Mucositis was defined using a variety of scoring systems. The mean incidence was 80%. Over one-half of patients (56%) who received altered fractionation RT (RT-AF) experienced severe mucositis (grades 3-4) compared to 34% of patients who received conventional RT.

Rates of hospitalization due to mucositis, reported in three studies (n=700), were 16% overall and 32% for RT-AF patients. Eleven percent of patients had RT regimens interrupted or modified because of mucositis in five studies (n=1267) reporting this outcome. Data insufficiency or heterogeneity prohibited analysis of mucositis severity and other associated outcomes, such as oral pain, dysphagia and opioid use.

Citation: Trotti A, Bellm LA, Epstein JB et al. Mucositis incidence, severity and associated outcomes in patients with head and neck cancer receiving radiotherapy with or without chemotherapy: a systematic literature review. Radiotherapy and Oncology 2003; 66: 253-262

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Neoadjuvant chemotherapy of cisplatin and fluorouracil regimen in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma: a meta-analysis
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,ORAL CANCER,TREATMENT & MANAGEMENT,CHEMOTHERAPY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Neoadjuvant chemotherapy with the cisplatin and fluorouracil (PF) regimen in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC) patients has no effect on locoregional relapse. However, it shows a small but significant benefit in reducing distant metastasis and improving the overall survival. [See Quality of Review below]

Methods: A systematic review and meta-analysis of 8 RCTs to evaluate the role of the neoadjuvant chemotherapy with the cisplatin and fluororacil (PF) regimen in enhancing the overall survival of and decreasing locoregional relapse and distant metastasis in HNSCC patients. Database search dates not provided. The authors conducted sub-group analyses of five studies to examine locoregional relapse and distant metastasis. Survival was measured in all studies.

Quality of review: The authors' conclusions do not appear to be fully supported by the evidence. Whilst the results do indicate a small statistically significant benefit in reducing distant metastasis with the PF regimen, there is no such benefit demonstrated for survival. According to Figures 5 and 6 (Forest plots of survival using fixed and random effects models) there is lower survival in the experimental than in the control group (325 deaths in 626 patients in the PF group vs 294 deaths in 633 patients in the control group). Using a fixed effects model a marginal statistically significant result favoured the control: odds ratio 1.28 (1.01, 1.62; P=0.04). Statistical significance disappeared  in the random effects model.

When reviewing the methodology used, additional caveats concerning reliability were identified. It is likely that potentially relevant studies were missed as the search was limited to one database using highly restrictive search terms and supplemented only by reference list checking. Although data were extracted independently in duplicate, it is unclear whether this process was also used to select and quality assess included studies, so the introduction of error and bias cannot be excluded. The Jadad Scale was used to assess study quality. None of the included studies were deemed to be of high quality - 3 medium and 5 low.   

Results: The odds ratio (OR) for the locoregional relapse was 0.92 (0.70–1.22, 95%CI; P=0.57). The OR for distant metastasis was 0.47 (0.33, 0.68; P <0.05) using a fixed effects model. For overall survival the results favoured the control: OR 1.28 (1.01–1.62; P=0.04) using the fixed effects model and OR 1.26 (0.94, 1.68; P=0.13) using the random effects model.

Citation: Su YX, Zheng JW, Zheng GS, Liao GQ, Zhang ZY. Neoadjuvant chemotherapy of cisplatin and fluorouracil regimen in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma: a meta-analysis. Chinese Medical Journal 2008;121(19):1939-44.

Access: Full text of this review is freely available.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Neurosensory disturbance of the inferior alveolar nerve after bilateral sagittal split osteotomy: a systematic review.
document.publisher: Journal of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORAL SURGERY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Objective methods provide the most sensitive diagnostic tests at early controls-within 3 months of the operation. At later control points the sensitivity increases and the inter-rater reliability is satisfactory.

Methods: A systematic review of seven studies to determine the incidence of inferior alveolar nerve sensory disturbance after bilateral sagittal split osteotomy, and the frequency of recovery of sensory function using objective methods only. Literature search 1990 to 2007.

Quality of review: The results of the review should be viewed cautiously due to a poor search strategy that is likely to have missed key papers and poor reporting of methods and results. The three databases (PubMed, Scirus and Central) were searched using restrictive search terms. Additional databases, more comprehensive search terms, handsearching journals and contacting experts may have identified further papers. Furthermore unpublished research does not appear to have been sought and it is unclear whether the search was restricted to English language studies. These may have introduced publication and language bias.

The authors state that articles were quality assessed, although the criteria used to do so is not reported. Whilst the results of individual studies are presented, the characteristics are not, and the study designs are not reported.

Results: The frequency of nerve impairment evaluated by subjective methods was higher than that indicated by studies adopting objective methods at each time of follow-up considered. In particular at the seventh postoperative day the frequency obtained using the objective methods was 63.3% while that obtained with subjective methods was 83%. At 1 year follow-up a frequency of sensory impairment of 12.8% was obtained using objective methods and a frequency of 18.4% when subjective methods were used. The data were analysed using the index of inter-rater reliability (Cohen's Kappa) with the degree of nerve damage evaluated by objective methods considered the "gold standard." The value of Cohen's Kappa at 1 week follow-up is 0.53; at 1 year follow-up it increased to 0.90.

Citation: Colella G, Cannavale R, Vicidomini A, Lanza A. Neurosensory disturbance of the inferior alveolar nerve after bilateral sagittal split osteotomy: a systematic review. Journal of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery 2007; 65(9): 1707-15.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance.  You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.
