document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Nicotine replacement therapy for long-term smoking cessation: a meta-analysis
document.topics: <![CDATA[ SMOKING CESSATION,POPULATION BASED & PREVENTATIVE SERVICES,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,DENTAL PUBLIC HEALTH,ORAL HEALTH,PUBLIC HEALTH,MANAGEMENT & INTERVENTIONS,SERVICES,MEDICAL TREATMENT,HEALTHCARE & HEALTH SERVICES,METHODS,RESEARCH METHODS,ANALYSIS & RESEARCH]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: The relative efficacy of a single course of nicotine replacement therapy (NRT) remains constant over many years. The majority of relapse after 12 months occurs within the first or second year and is not detectable thereafter, suggesting that NRT has a permanent effect on smoking cessation.

However, initial relapse after one year has the effect of diminishing the number of ex-smokers that can be ultimately attributed to NRT. Results after only 6–12 months of follow-up, as used in existing reviews and treatment guidelines, will overestimate the lifetime benefit and cost-efficacy of NRT by about 30%. Because the long-term benefit of NRT is modest, tobacco dependence treatment might be better viewed as a chronic disorder, requiring repeated episodes of treatment.

Methods: Systematic review and meta-analsysis of 12 randomised controlled trials to assess if the effect of a single treatment episode with NRT enhances smoking cessation over many years. Literature search dates not reported.

Quality of review: Whilst a wide range of databases were searched (Medline, Embase, CENTRAL, Psychmed and PubMed), there is insufficient information to determine how systematic or comprehensive the search was as the search terms used and the number of references generated is not reported. Experts were contacted for studies, but there was no hand-searching or reference list checking. It is unclear whether unpublished or non-English language studies were sought and the funnel plot did detect evidence of publication bias. Although inclusion criteria addressed some aspects of study quality (randomisation, length of follow-up, and adequate control group) no formal method for assessing quality is reported and the reliability of the included studies is not discussed.

Results: The odds ratio (OR) in favour of NRT at final follow-up was 1.99 (95% confidence interval (CI) 1.50 to 2.64). There was no evidence that the effect varied according to length of final follow-up (ß = 0.92, p = 0.28) or duration of initial NRT treatment (ß = 0.99, p > 0.5).

The overall relapse rate between the 12 months and final follow-up was 30.0% (95% CI 23.5% to 37.5%). This rate did not differ between NRT and control groups (OR 1.11, 95% CI 0.78 to 1.59), or length of initial NRT treatment.

There was also no evidence that it varied according to length of final follow up. Due to relapse, the overall efficacy of NRT treatment in terms of additional ex-smokers declined from 10.7% over and above placebo (6.6% to 14.8%) after one year to 7.2% (3.8% to 11.3%) at an average of 4.3 years follow up.

Citation: Etter J & Stapletone JA. Nicotine replacement therapy for long-term smoking cessation: a meta-analysis. Tobacco Control 2006: 15; 280-285.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Nonpharmacologic strategies for managing common chemotherapy adverse effects: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORAL CANCER,TREATMENT & MANAGEMENT,ORAL CARE FOR CANCER PATIENTS,SPECIAL CARE DENTISTRY,CANCER PATIENTS]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Although some strategies seem promising, the quality of the RCTs was generally quite low, making it difficult to draw conclusions about the effectiveness of self-care strategies. Future studies require better design and reporting of methodologic issues to establish evidence-based self-care recommendations for people receiving chemotherapy.

Methods: A narrative systematic review of 77 RCTs to determine the effectiveness of self-care strategies to alleviate adverse events (nausea and vomiting, constipation, diarrhoea, fatigue, hair loss and mucositits) associated with cancer chemotherapy. Database search dates: 1980 to August 2007.

Quality of review: The results of this review should be interpreted with caution. Key data are not provided for all included studies. The authors state that the effectiveness review was based on 60 studies quality assessed as good (13) or fair (43). However, detailed data are only provided for 29 studies (1 good, 28 fair) with statistically significant results; from which a “tentative recommendation for strategy” was made. The authors searched three databases (Medline, Embase and CINAHL), supplemented by reference list checking. It is possible that potentially relevant studies were missed and bias introduced as the search terms used were limited and only published studies in the English language were included. The study selection process is not described but appropriate procedures were used to minimise error and bias in data extraction and quality assessment. The authors used a comprehensive checklist to assess the quality of the included papers.

Results: Findings from RCTs of reasonable quality provide limited support for cognitive distraction, exercise, hypnosis, relaxation, and systematic desensitization to reduce nausea and vomiting, psycho-education for fatigue and scalp cooling to reduce hair loss.

Citation: Lotfi-Jam K, Carey M, Jefford M, et al. Nonpharmacologic strategies for managing common chemotherapy adverse effect: a systematic review. Journal of Clinical Oncology, 2008; 26 (34): 5618-5629

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Nutritional interventions and outcome in patients with cancer or preinvasive lesions: systematic review
document.publisher: Journal of the National Cancer Institute
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,ORAL CANCER,ENT AND AUDIOLOGY,CONDITIONS,TREATMENT & MANAGEMENT,THERAPEUTIC INTERVENTIONS,NON-DRUG TREATMENTS,DIETARY SUPPLEMENTS,ADJUNCTIVE THERAPY,HEAD & NECK CANCER]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: The impact of most nutritional interventions cannot be reliably estimated because of the limited number of trials, many of which were of low quality. There is no evidence that dietary modification by cancer patients improves survival and benefits disease prognosis.

Methods:  A systematic review of 59 randomised controlled trials (RCTs) to examine the effect of nutritional interventions on patients with cancer or preinvasive lesions.  Outcome measures were all-cause and cancer mortality, disease-free survival, cancer recurrence, second primary cancer, recurrence of a preinvasive lesion, or progression to cancer. Literature search to 30 September 2005. 

Quality of review: A reasonable attempt was made to identify relevant papers.  Multiple databases were searched with a good search strategy, reference lists checked and no language restrictions were imposed.  However, no attempt was made to identify unpublished studies which may have introduced bias.  The results are limited by the poor quality of  included studies. Please note that pnly two studies considered mouth cancer and three studied head and neck cancer.

Results: 59 eligible trials were identified, 25 in patients with cancer and 34 in patients with preinvasive lesions, respectively. Trial quality was generally low; only three trials (two of cancer and one of preinvasive lesions) had adequate methods for generating the allocation sequence, allocation concealment, and masking both outcome assessors and participants.

The combined odds ratio (OR) for the effect of a healthy diet-given alone or with dietary supplements, weight loss, or exercise-on all-cause mortality was 0.90 (95% confidence interval [CI] = 0.46 to 1.77). There was no evidence of an association between the use of antioxidant (OR = 1.01, 95% CI = 0.88 to 1.15) or retinol (OR = 0.97, 95% CI = 0.83 to 1.13) supplements and all-cause mortality. Meta-analyses of all other outcomes did not show clear evidence of benefit or harm.

Citation: Davies AA, Davey Smith G, Harbord R, Bekkering GE, Sterne JA, Beynon R, Thomas S. Nutritional interventions and outcome in patients with cancer or preinvasive lesions: systematic review. Journal of the National Cancer Institute 2006;9 8(14):961-73.

Access: Full-text online access of this article is freely available.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Nutritional support for head and neck cancer patients receiving radiotherapy: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,ORAL CANCER,ENT AND AUDIOLOGY,THERAPEUTIC INTERVENTIONS,DRUG TREATMENTS,NON-DRUG TREATMENTS,CHEMOTHERAPY,DIETARY SUPPLEMENTS,TREATMENT & MANAGEMENT,RADIOTHERAPY,CONDITIONS,HEAD & NECK CANCER]]>
document.body:
This is a provisional record for information. The review has been identified as potentially meeting our quality criteria. It will be critically appraised and a quality statement provided as soon as possible.
_____________________________________________________

 

Authors' conclusions: Data from RCTs supporting the use of interventions to optimize nutrition in Head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC) patients receiving radiotherapy are limited in both quantity and quality. Potentially effective interventions have not been tested comparatively or in combination, and few patients receiving chemoradiotherapy were studied. Further research in this area is a priority.

Methods: A systematic review and meta-analysis of 10 randomised trials to consider Which interventions aimed at optimizing nutrition are of benefit to HNSCC patients receiving Radiotherapy? Database search 1966 to December 2007.

Results: All trials randomized less than 50 patients per arm. Five trials studied dietary counseling and/or nutritional supplements, four studied drug interventions, and one studied prophylactic enteral tube feeding. Nutritional status appeared to be maintained or improved with dietary counseling, megestrol acetate, and prophylactic enteral tube feeding.

Citation: Garg S, Yoo J, Winquist E. Nutritional support for head and neck cancer patients receiving radiotherapy: a systematic review. Supportive Care in Cancer 2009 Jul 7. [Epub ahead of print]

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Obesity and dental caries - A systematic review.
document.topics: <![CDATA[ OBESITY,OUTCOMES,BIOLOGICAL COMPOSITION,ORAL HEALTH DISORDERS,ORAL DISORDERS,ORAL HEALTH,DENTAL CARIES,PUBLIC HEALTH,DETERMINANTS,METHODS,RESEARCH METHODS,ANALYSIS & RESEARCH,DENTAL DECAY,DENTAL CARIES,DENTAL HEALTH]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Only one study with high level of evidence showed direct association between obesity and dental caries. In view of the findings, further well-designed randomised studies are needed to demonstrate the relationship between dental caries and obesity.

Methods: A systematic review of seven cross-sectional studies to deterine the relationship between obesity in childhood, adolescence and/or adulthood and the prevelance of dental caries.  Literature search 1984-2004 inclusive.

Quality of review: It is likely that the search strategy did not identify all relevant papers.  Whilst the authors searched a range of databases and reference lists of relevant papers, the search terms used were very narrow.  It is not clear whether unpublished research was sought and the possibility of publication bias cannot be excluded.  The quality of the papers was independently assessed by two reviewers using predefined criteria.   Quality of included studies was variable and results inconclusive.

Results:  Inconclusive with considerable variation between the studies.

Citation: Kantovitz KR, Fernanda MP, Rontani RM, Gavio MB. Obesity and dental caries: A systematic review.  Oral Health Prev Dent 2006; 4: 137-144

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Occupational exposure to rock wool and glass wool and risk of cancers of the lung and the head and neck: a systematic review and meta-analysis
document.publisher: Journal of Occupational and Environmental Medicine
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,ORAL CANCER,ENT AND AUDIOLOGY,CONDITIONS,RISK FACTORS,OCCUPATIONAL,HEAD & NECK CANCER]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Despite a small elevation in relative risk (RR) for lung cancer among man-made vitreous fiber (MMVF) production workers, the lack of excess risk among end users, the absence of any dose-risk relation, the likelihood of detection bias, and the potential for residual confounding by smoking and asbestos exposure argue against a carcinogenic effect of MMVF, rock wool (RW), or glass wool (GW) at this time.

For head and neck (HN) cancer, a statistically significant RR of 1.36 was observed among workers in the cohort studies. The absence of a dose-risk relation and the likelihood of residual confounding and publication bias hamper any inference that can be drawn regarding causation.

Results on pleural mesothelioma risk are inconsistent with a true increase in risk, and data on sinonasal cancers are too scant to allow any conclusions.

Methods: a systematic review and meta-analysis of 27 observational studies to consider the risk of cancer arising from occupational exposure to rock wool and glass wool. Database search dates unclear.

Quality of review: As the authors conclude, problems associated with bias; particularly the failure of most included studies to consider significant confounders means that credible causal links cannot be made.

The review itself is limited by the search strategy and it is likely that relevant studies were missed. Only PubMed was searched using limited search terms, supplemented by reference list checking. There were no language restrictions.

No information is provided on the processes used to select and data extract included studies and the introduction of bias and error during these processes cannot be excluded. Whilst the authors do not describe a formal process of quality assessment, they identify and discuss key issues, including follow-up and confounding.

Results: Sixteen estimates of lung cancer risk yielded a summary RR of 1.21 (95% CI = 1.11 to 1.32, based on 1662 exposed cases). Corresponding RRs were 1.26 (95% CI = 1.10 to 1.44) in studies of production workers (with similar risk for RW and GW workers), 1.06 (95% CI = 0.77 to 1.48) in studies of end users, and 1.18 (95% CI = 0.98 to 1.42) in community-based studies. The summary RR for HN cancer was 1.36 (95% CI = 1.13 to 1.63, 414 exposed cases). With a few exceptions, all studies that assessed the risk of lung or HN cancer according to various indices of MMVF exposure failed to detect a dose-risk relation. There was limited evidence of a confounding effect of tobacco smoking. No clear excess of pleural mesothelioma has been reported in MMVF-exposed workers.

Citation: Lipworth L, La Vecchia C, Bosetti C, McLaughlin JK. Occupational exposure to rock wool and glass wool and risk of cancers of the lung and the head and neck: a systematic review and meta-analysis. Journal of Occupational & Environmental Medicine 2009 Sep;51(9):1075-87.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Opinion of the Scientific Panel on Dietetic Products, Nutrition and Allergies (NDA) on a request from the Commission related to the Tolerable Upper Intake Level of Fluoride
document.topics: <![CDATA[ OUTCOMES,ADULTS,CHILDREN,ORAL HEALTH DISORDERS,INTERNATIONAL ORGANISATIONS,SPECIAL HEALTH AUTHORITIES,DENTAL CARIES,DENTAL PUBLIC HEALTH,CAUSES & PREVENTION,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORAL DISORDERS,ORAL HEALTH,PUBLIC HEALTH,MANAGEMENT & INTERVENTIONS,MANAGEMENT & POLICY,INFORMATION,ORGANISATIONS,GROUPS,POPULATIONS,AGE GROUPS]]>
document.body:
Summary

Fluoride is not essential for human growth and development but is beneficial in the prevention of dental caries (tooth decay) when ingested in amounts of about 0.05 mg/kg body weight per day and when applied topically with dental products such as toothpaste. Dental enamel which contains fluoride is less likely to develop caries, because of greater resistance to ingested acids or to acids generated from ingested sugars by the oral bacteria. In addition, fluoride inhibits sugar metabolism by oral bacteria.

Fluoride content of the body is not under physiological control. Absorbed fluoride is partly retained in bone and partly excreted, predominantly via the kidney. In infants retention in bone can be as high as 90% of the absorbed amount, whereas in adults retention is 50% or less. Fluoride is also incorporated into dental enamel during tooth formation.

Excessive intake of fluoride during enamel maturation before tooth eruption from birth to eight years of age, when enamel formation is complete, can lead to reduced mineral content of enamel and to dental fluorosis of deciduous but predominantly of permanent teeth. The incidence and severity of dental fluorosis is dose-dependent. Mild dental fluorosis is not readily apparent and is associated with increased resistance to caries. The Panel considered moderate dental fluorosis, which is characterised by staining and minute pitting of teeth, to be an adverse effect. On the basis that the prevalence of moderate dental fluorosis of permanent teeth is less than 5% in populations ingesting 0.08-0.12 mg fluoride/kg body weight/day, the Panel considered that the upper level (UL) for fluoride is 0.1 mg fluoride/kg/day in children aged 1-8 years. This is equivalent to 1.5 and 2.5 mg fluoride per day in children aged 1-3 years and 4-8 years, respectively.

Fluoride accretion in bone increases bone density but excessive long term intake reduces bone strength and increases risk of fracture and skeletal fluorosis (stiffness of joints, skeletal deformities). Studies with therapeutic oral administration of fluoride in amounts of 0.6 mg/kg body weight/day in postmenopausal women over several years increased the risk for non-vertebral bone fractures significantly. The Panel applied an uncertainty factor of 5 to derive an UL of 0.12 mg/kg body weight/day. This is equivalent to an UL of 5 mg/day in children aged 9-14 years and 7 mg/day for age 15 years and older, including pregnant and lactating women.

The UL for fluoride applies to intake from water, beverages, foodstuffs, including fluoridated salt, dental health products and fluoride tablets for caries prevention.

Children aged 1-8 years have fluoride intakes from food and water well below the UL provided the fluoride content of their drinking water is not higher than 1.0 mg/L. An increase in the prevalence of mild dental fluorosis observed in some countries has been attributed to the inappropriate use of dental care products, particularly of fluoridated toothpaste.

The Panel did not establish an UL for infants. Breast-fed infants have very low fluoride intakes from human milk (2-40 mg/day) and are not at risk of developing enamel fluorosis even when given fluoride supplements of 0.25 mg/day. The Panel notes that the Scientific Committee on Food has recommended a maximum fluoride level of 0.6-0.7 mg/L in infant formula and follow on formula, equivalent to an intake of about 0.1 mg/kg body weight per day in infants during the first six months of life (body weight 5 kg). For powdered formula, this maximum will be exceeded if water containing more than 0.7 mg/L is used for its preparation.

For children older than eight years and adults the probability of exceeding the UL of 5/7 mg fluoride/day on a normal diet is generally estimated to be low. However, consumption of water with a high fluoride content, e.g. more than 2-3 mg/L, predisposes to exceeding the UL]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Optimum force magnitude for orthodontic tooth movement: a systematic literature review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORTHODONTICS]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Because it is not possible to perform a meta-analysis of the relation between force magnitude and rate of tooth movement from current literature, no evidence based force level could be recommended for the optimal efficiency in clinical orthodontics.

Methods: Systematic review of 17 animal and 12 human studies of orthodontic interventions for tooth movement (bodily or tipping movement). Main outcomes measured were the orthodontic force and rate of subsequent tooth movement. Literature search 1966-2001.

Quality of Study: Key papers may have been missed as the only database searched was Medline. It is unclear if unpublished studies and non-English language papers were sought, which may have introduced publication bias. 

Results: Articles on animal experiments were in the majority. A wide range of animal species such as rat, cat, rabbit, beagle dog, monkey, mouse, and guinea pig were used. Besides variation in species, there was also a wide range of force magnitudes, teeth under study, directions of tooth movement, duration of experimental period, and force reactivation. Furthermore hardly any experiments were reported that provide information on the relation between the velocity of tooth movement and magnitude of the applied force.

Data from human research on the efficiency of orthodontic tooth movement appeared to be very limited. The large variation in data from current literature made it impossible to perform a meta-analysis. Well controlled clinical studies and more standardised animal experiments in the orthodontic field are required.

Citation: Ren Y, Maltha JC, Kuijpers-Japtman AM. Optimum force magnitude for orthodontic tooth movement: a systematic literature review. Angle Orthodontist. 2003; 73(1): 86-92.

Access: Full-text article is freely available

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Oral health of patients with intellectual disabilities: A systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,SPECIAL CARE DENTISTRY,LEARNING DISABILITIES]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Evidence supports the need to develop strategies to increase patient acceptance for routine care, additional training for dentists to provide this care, and the development of more effective preventive strategies to minimize the need for this care.
 
Methods: A narrative systematic review of 27 observational studies to determine whether there is a difference in oral health status between adults with intellectual disabilities (ID) and the general population. Database search dates: 1975 to October 2008.
 
Quality of review: Although several databases were searched, it is likely that potentially relevant studies were missed and bias introduced. No other sources were searched and inclusion was restricted to published papers in the English language. 
 
No information is provided on the process used to select and data extract included studies and the introduction of error and bias into these processes cannot be excluded. The authors used a modified version of the Newcastle-Ottawa scale to assess the quality of included studies. This tool has not been validated. The authors note that consistency of evidence was high but there was a wide variation in study quality and a lack of uniform reporting of findings. The authors note that further research is needed.
 
Results: People with intellectual disabilities have poorer oral hygiene and higher prevalence and greater severity of periodontal disease. Caries rates in people with ID are the same as or lower than the general population. However, the rates of untreated caries are consistently higher in people with ID. Two subgroups at especially high risk for oral health problems are people with Down syndrome and people unable to cooperate for routine dental care.
 
Citation: Anders PL, Davis EL, Anders PL, Davis EL. Oral health of patients with intellectual disabilities: a systematic review. Special Care in Dentistry 2010; 30(3):110-7.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Oral hygiene care for adults with dementia in residential aged care facilities
document.publisher: JBI Reports (now International Journal of Evidence-Based Healthcare)
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,SPECIAL CARE DENTISTRY,MENTAL ILLNESS,OLDER PEOPLE]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Training of staff in the form of a comprehensive, practically oriented program addressing areas such as oral diseases, oral screening assessment and hands-on demonstration of oral hygiene techniques and products is likely to have a positive impact on the management of oral hygiene care within residential aged care facilities. The review also identified that regular brushing with fluoride toothpaste, use of therapeutic fluoride products and application of therapeutic chlorhexidine gluconate products are validated by research as effective for the general population and some populations with special needs.

Methods: A systematic review of 306 studies to identify the best available evidence relating to oral hygiene of adults with dementia in residential care, including

  • prevalence and incidence of oral diseases and conditions
  • use of assessment tools by carers
  • strategies to prevent oral diseases and conditions
  • provision of dental treatment and ongoing management.

Quality of the review: This is a moderately well conducted review which addressed clear objectives. A good attempt was made to identify all relevant literature searching Cinahl, Embase, PsycINFO, Medline and Current Contents. In addition, reference lists of included papers were checked. However contacting experts, searching key websites and journal handsearching may also have identified additional studies. Only English language papers were included and it appears that the search was restricted to published papers. This may have introduced publication and language bias.

The results of the review are mostly described in the text, and may have been more clearly presented if also tabulated. It should also be noted that 247 of the 306 studies were low levels of evidence (ie opinion papers or descriptive studies).


Results: possible risk factors identified included: saliva dysfunction, polypharmacy, comorbid medical conditions, swallowing and dietary problems, increased functional dependence, need for assistance with oral hygiene care, and poor access and utilisation of dental care.

Evidence on the use of assessment tools by carers to evaluate residents' oral health showed that successful assessment of residents with and without dementia by nursing staff requires appropriate staff training by a dental professional. Coupled with appropriate training, an oral assessment screening tool designed for residents with dementia has been successfully used by nursing and care staff to identify residents requiring further review by dental professionals. Expert opinion in the field indicates that oral assessment screenings by a staff member and then by a dentist would ideally be undertaken upon admission to a facility, and regularly thereafter by staff and/or dentists as required.

Clinicians and researchers suggested that oral hygiene care strategies to prevent oral diseases and conditions were found to be effective in preventing oral diseases, and thus are relevant for use in the resident with dementia.

In regards to the provision of dental treatment and ongoing management of oral diseases and conditions, the use of adjunctive and preventive aids were found to be effective when introduced in conjunction with a staff training program:

Expert opinion suggests that behaviour management techniques will increase the potential of performing oral hygiene care interventions.

Citation: Pearson A, Chalmers J. Oral Oral hygiene care for adults with dementia in residential aged care facilities. JBI Reports 2004; 2(3): 65-113.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

A Best Practice information sheet for healthcare professionals has been produced based on the systematic review and is freely available.

 

NOTE: Elements of this systematic review are discussed in two other papers:

Chalmers J, Pearson A. Oral hygiene care for residents with dementia: a literature review. Journal of Advanced Nursing 2005; 52(4): 410-419.

Chalmers J, Pearson A. A systematic review of oral health assessment by nurses and caers for residents with dementia in residential care facilities. Special Care Dentistry; 25(5): 227-232.

]]>

document.title: Oral hygiene care for residents with dementia: a literature review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,SPECIAL CARE DENTISTRY,MENTAL ILLNESS,OLDER PEOPLE]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: These literature review findings supported the use of oral assessment screening tools by staff and efficacious preventive oral hygiene care strategies/products for adults with dementia in residential care facilities. Further research with this population is needed to develop and validate oral assessment tools and staff education programmes, trial preventive oral hygiene care strategies/products and trial dementia-focused behaviour management and communication strategies.

NOTE: For full details and a critical appraisal of this review go to:  Pearson A, Chalmers J. Oral Oral hygiene care for adults with dementia in residential aged care facilities. JBI Reports 2004; 2(3): 65-113

A Best Practice information sheet for healthcare professionals has been produced based on the full systematic review and is freely available.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Oral implants in radiated patients: a systematic review
document.publisher: International Journal of Oral and Maxillofacial Implants
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORAL CANCER,RESTORATIVE DENTISTRY,TREATMENT & MANAGEMENT,RADIOTHERAPY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Notwithstanding the low number of implants evaluated, this review showed similar failure rate for implants placed post-radiation therapy (RT) and those placed pre-RT (3.2% and 5.4%, respectively).

Methods: A systematic review of 19 studies to examine the effects of pre- and postimplantation RT on dental implant failure. Literature search 1990 to 2006.

Quality of review: The results of the review should be viewed cautiously due to poor search strategy that is likely to have missed key papers and poor reporting of methods and results. The three databases (PubMed, Scirus, Central) were searched using restrictive search terms. Additional databases, more comprehensive search terms, handsearching journals and contacting experts may have identified further papers. Furthermore unpublished research does not appear to have been sought and it is unclear if the search was restricted to English language studies. These may have introduced publication and language bias.

The authors state that articles were quality assessed, although the criteria used to do so is not reported. Whilst the results of individual studies are presented, the characteristics are not, and the study designs are not reported. The overall failure rates for pre and post implantation radiation therapy are based on the sum of results in the relevant studies, although the discussion states that the studies were highly heterogeneous.

Results: Similar failure rates were found for implants placed post-RT
compared to those placed pre-RT (3.2% and 5.4%). In preimplantation RT, the implant failure rate was lower for the mandible (4.4%) in comparison to the maxilla (17.5%; OR = 4.63; 95% CI: 2.25 to 9.49). Other results did not reach statistical significance. No failures were observed in association with an RT dose lower than 45 Gy. All implant failures observed occurred within 36 months after RT, and most occurred between 1 and 12 months after placement.

Citation: Colella G, Cannavale R, Pentenero M, Gandolfo S. Oral implants in radiated patients: a systematic review. International Journal of Oral and Maxillofacial Implants 2007; 22(4): 616-22.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance.  You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Orthodontic anchorage
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,DENTO-FACIAL ANOMALIES,ORTHODONTICS]]>
document.body:
Authors conclusions: Because of contradictory results and the vast heterogeneity in study methods, the scientific evidence was too weak to evaluate anchorage efficiency during space closure. Intraoral molar distization leads to anchorage loss in various amounts depending on the choice of distalization unit. Most of the studies had serious problems with small sample size, confounding factors, lack of method analysis, and no blinding in measurements. To obtain reliable scientific evidence, controlled RCT's with sufficient sample sizes are needed to determine which anchorage system is the most effective in the respective anchorage situation. Further studies should also consider patient acceptance and cost analysis as well as implants as anchorage.

Methods: A systematic review of four randomised and ten controlled and comparator trials to evaluate the efficacy of orthodontic anchorage systems.  Literature search 1966-2004 inclusive.

Quality of included study:  Relevant studies may have been missed owing to the limited search strategy.  Only PubMed and the Cochrane Clinical Trial Register were searched using narrow search terms.  It does not appear that reference lists were examined or journals hand searched.   There is no indication of a search for unpublished research and non-English language papers were excluded, which may have resulted in the introduction of publication and language biases. The quality of the included studies was evaluated independently by the two authors.  They emphasise that much of the data was of poor quality and highly heterogeneous making it difficult to draw evidence-based conclusions

Results: The search strategy resulted in 494 articles, of which 14 met the inclusion criteria. Two main anchorage situations were identified: anchorage of molars during space closure after premolar extractions and anchorage loss in the incisor or premolar region (or both) during molar distalization. 

Citation: Feldmann I, Bondemark L. Orthodontic anchorage: a systematic review. Angle Orthodontist 2006; 76(3): 493-501

Access:  This is an open access journal. 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Orthognathic treatment and temporomandibular disorders: a systematic review. Part 1. A new quality-assessment technique and analysis of study characteristics and classifications
document.publisher: American Journal of Orthodontics and Dentofacial Orthopedics
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,DENTO-FACIAL ANOMALIES,ORAL SURGERY,ORTHODONTICS]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors’ conclusions: The diversity of diagnostic criteria and classification methods used in the included studies makes inter-study comparisons difficult. There is a definitive need for well-designed studies with standardized diagnostic criteria and classification methods

Methods: A systematic review and meta-analysis of 53 studies to consider the effects of orthognathic surgery on TMD symptoms. Database search dates not stated.

Quality of review: As the authors note, the results of this review should be considered with caution given the quality of the included papers.

The authors made a fair attempt to locate potentially relevant papers. They searched several sources without publication or language restrictions, including contacting experts and hand searching journals. However, it is possible that additional papers may have been located if the authors had searched more than one electronic database and used less specific search terms. Appropriate methods were used to minimise error and bias in selecting, quality assessing and data extracting included papers. The authors designed a specific quality assessment form for the study. All included studies were deemed to be of high risk of bias. 

Citation: Al-Riyami S, Moles DR, Cunningham SJ. Orthognathic treatment and temporomandibular disorders: a systematic review. Part 1. A new quality-assessment technique and analysis of study characteristics and classifications. American Journal of Orthodontics and Dentofacial Orthopedics 2009 Nov;136(5):624.e1-15

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Orthognathic treatment and temporomandibular disorders: a systematic review. Part 2. Signs and symptoms and meta-analyses
document.publisher: American Journal of Orthodontics and Dentofacial Orthopedics
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,DENTO-FACIAL ANOMALIES,ORAL SURGERY,ORTHODONTICS]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Although orthognathic surgery should not be advocated solely for treating temporomandibular disorders (TMD), patients having orthognathic treatment for correction of their dentofacial deformities and who are also suffering from TMD appear more likely to see improvement in their signs and symptoms than deterioration.

Methods: A systematic review and meta-analysis of 53 studies to consider the effects of orthognathic surgery on TMD symptoms. Database search dates not stated.

Quality of review: As the authors note, the results of this review should be considered with caution given the quality of the included papers.

The authors made a fair attempt to locate potentially relevant papers. They searched several sources without publication or language restrictions, including contacting experts and hand searching journals. However, it is possible that additional papers may have been located if the authors had searched more than one electronic database and used less specific search terms. Appropriate methods were used to minimise error and bias in selecting, quality assessing and data extracting included papers. The authors designed a specific quality assessment form for the study. All included studies were deemed to be of high risk of bias.

Results: Pain decreased after surgery for both self-reported symptoms and clinically diagnosed pain on palpation. However, postsurgical results were more varied for joint sounds. The percentage of patients with clicking had a tendency to decrease postsurgery, but improvements in crepitus were questionable. The results from all meta-analyses in this review were subject to considerable statistical heterogeneity, and it was not possible to draw strong inferences relating to the percentage of orthognathic surgery patients with TMD with any degree of certainty.

Citation: Al-Riyami S, Cunningham SJ, Moles DR. Orthognathic treatment  and temporomandibular disorders: a systematic review. Part 2. Signs and symptoms and meta-analyses. American Journal of Orthodontics and Dentofacial Orthopedics 2009 Nov;136(5):626.e1-16

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

 _____________________________________________________________________________

A new quality-assessment technique and analysis of study characteristics and classifications. American Journal of Orthodontics and Dentofacial Orthopedics 2009 Nov;136(5):624.e1-15.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Orthopedic treatment outcomes in class III malocclusion: A systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,DENTO-FACIAL ANOMALIES,ORTHODONTICS]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: High quality investigations are still needed to perform a definitive assessment of effectiveness of Class III treatment at the skeletal level. An RCT on the effects of different orthopedic treatment modalities with a long-term observation at the end craniofacial growth would be desirable.

Methods: A systematic review of 19 studies (1 RCT and 18 retrospective CCTs) to assess the evidence available for the effectiveness of early orthodontic treatment in Class III subjects. Database search dates: 1966 to 2006 inclusive.

Quality of review: The review is limited by the quality of the included studies and the results should be viewed with caution.

It is likely that potentially relevant papers were missed. Restricted search terms were used to search two databases and only published studies in English were included which may have introduced bias. Searching additional databases without restrictions and with comprehensive search terms, supplemented by reference list checking, hand searching key journals, contacting experts and attempting to identify grey literature may well have produced additional studies. Appropriate procedures were used to minimise error and bias in study selection, data extraction and quality assessment. The authors undertook a quality evaluation to document the methodological soundness of the included studies. However, it is not clear that the evaluation process appropriately identified the potential for bias in each study. 

Results: Data derived from medium/high quality research described over 75% of success of orthopaedic treatment of Class III malocclusion (RME and facial mask therapy) at a follow-up observation 5 years after the end of orthopaedic treatment.

Citation: De Toffol L, Pavoni C, Baccetti T, et al. Orthopedic treatment outcomes in class III malocclusion: A systematic review. Angle Orthodontist, 2008; 78 (3): 561-573.

Access: Full text is freely available to the general public.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Osteoporosis and edentulous jaws
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL DISORDERS,ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,RESTORATIVE DENTISTRY,DENTO-FACIAL ANOMALIES]]>
document.body:
Authors' conclusions: Although no firm conclusions could be drawn regarding the effect of osteoporosis on resorption of edentulous jaws, with or without implants, due to the different parameters applied to the various studies, the use of endosseous implants in osteoporosis patients is not contraindicated.

Methods: A narrative systematic review of 11 studies (2 longitudinal 7 cross-sectional and 2 case control) to consider the influence of osteoporosis on resorption in edentulous jaws and whether osteoporosis enhances implant loss. Database search dates: inception to November 2007.

Quality of review: The results of this review should be viewed with caution. The majority of the studies in the review report data from cross-sectional studies and, whilst there may be some limited evidence for associations between the severity of osteoporosis and the outcomes considered, this cannot be assumed to be a causative link.

The authors searched three databases using adequate search terms and supplemented the search with reference list checking. The review was restricted to published papers in English, French, German and Dutch which may have led to the introduction of bias. No information is provided on the process used to select and data extract papers. The authors used Cochrane Handbook methods to assess the methodological quality of included studies. However, there is little data on key quality outcomes other than that the included studies were “methodologically acceptable”. Despite methodological limitations, it appears that cross-sectional studies were included because of the limited data available. 

Results:  Most studies dealt with the association between the extent of resorption or atrophy of edentulous jaws and the systemic (femoral, lumbar spine, metacarpal) bone mineral content (BMC) or bone mineral density (BMD) status. Four studies reported a significant association between the extent of resorption and the skeletal BMC and/or BMD. Four studies evaluated the effect of endosseous implants on mandibular BMC or BMD changes and the association between systematic BMD statuses and loss of implants. These studies revealed no association between systemic BMD status, mandibular BMD status, bone quality, and implant loss.

Citation: Slagter KW, Raghoebar GB, Vissink A. Osteoporosis and edentulous jaws. International Journal of Prosthodontics 2008; 21 (1): 19-26.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Osteoradionecrosis in cancer patients: the evidence base for treatment-dependent frequency, current management strategies, and future studies
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,DENTO-FACIAL ANOMALIES,ORAL CANCER,ORAL CARE FOR CANCER PATIENTS,OSTEONECROSIS OF THE JAW]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: New cancer treatment modalities such as intensity modulated radiotherapy (IMRT) and concomitant chemoradiotherapy (CRT) have had minimal effect on prevalence of osteoradionecrosis (ORN). No studies to date have systematically addressed impact of ORN on either quality of life or cost of care

Methods: A narrative systematic review of 43 studies (a mix of intervention and observational research (1) to consider the impact of cancer therapies on prevalence of osteoradionecrosis (ORN) in head and neck cancer patients and (2) to evaluate management strategies and their consequences on quality of life and cost of care. Database search dates: 1990 to 2008 inclusive.

Quality of review: Overall a reasonably well-conducted systematic review. The authors searched two electronic databases using a highly sensitive search strategy. However, it is possible that potentially relevant studies were missed as no other sources were searched and inclusion was restricted to published studies in the English language. Appropriate processes were used to minimise error and bias in selecting, data extracting and quality assessing included studies. A range of questions designed to identify potential bias in different study types were incorporated into the data extraction form. Only limited information is provided on the included studies. It is not clear if studies could be combined which gives concern to using an overall prevalence score.

Results: The weighted prevalence for ORN included RT=?7.4%, IMRT=5.1%, CRT=6.8%, and brachytherapy=5.3%. Hyperbaric oxygen may contribute a role in management of ORN. However, no clear guideline recommendations could be established for the prevention or treatment of ORN based on the literature reviewed.

Citation: Peterson DE, Doerr W, Hovan A, Pinto A, Saunders D, Elting LS, et al. Osteoradionecrosis in cancer patients: the evidence base for treatment-dependent frequency, current management strategies, and future studies. Supportive Care in Cancer 2010 Aug;18(8):1089-98

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

 

Note: additional details about the methodology are provided in:

Brennan MT, Elting LS, Spijkervet FK. Systematic reviews of oral complications from cancer therapies, Oral Care Study Group, MASCC/ISOO: methodology and quality of the literature. Supportive Care in Cancer 2010 Aug;18(8):979-84.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Outcome of implant therapy in patients with previous tooth loss due to periodontitis
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,PERIODONTOLOGY,RESTORATIVE DENTISTRY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: The survival of the suprastructures and the implants was not significantly different in individuals with periodontitis-associated and non-periodontitis-associated tooth loss. However, significantly increased incidence of peri-implantitis and significantly increased peri-implant marginal bone loss were revealed in individuals with periodontitis-associated tooth loss. The small sample size and the methodological quality assessment of the two studies suggest that the results should be interpreted with caution. Consequently, further long-term studies focusing particularly on the outcome of implant treatment in young adults with aggressive periodontitis are needed before final conclusions can be drawn about the outcome of implant treatment in patients with a history of periodontitis.

Methods:  A systematic review of one prospective and one retrospective cohort study giving 121 implants in 33 patients with previous tooth loss due to periodontitis (vs control of 183 implants in 70 patients).  The purpose of the review was to assess whether individuals with previous tooth loss due to periodontitis have an increased risk of loss of suprastructures, loss of implants, peri-implantitis, and peri-implant marginal bone loss as compared with individuals with previous tooth loss due to reasons other than periodontitis. Database search dates: 1980 to 2005 inclusive.

Quality of review: The search strategy may not have identified all relevant papers.  A range of journals was hand searched and reference lists scrutinised, but only one database (Medline) was searched.  It does not appear that unpublished research was sought and this may have introduced publication bias. The identified studies were quality appraised by two independent reviewers for completeness of reported data and for methodological elements (outcome assessment blinding and follow-up).  Both papers failed to report key data and were deemed to have a high risk of bias.  The authors indicate that results should be treated with caution both because of quality and of low study numbers.  It is also worth noting that only one of the two studies reported on the incidence of smokers among the study population.  That study reported 48% smokers in the group with periodontitis vs 20% in the control. 

Results: A total of 33 patients with tooth loss due to periodontitis and 70 patients with non-periodontitis-associated tooth loss. There was no significant difference in the survival of the suprastructures after 5 years. Furthermore, there were no significant differences in the survival of the implants after 5 and 10 years. However, there were significantly more patients affected by peri-implantitis in the group with periodontitis-associated tooth loss during the 10-year follow-up period, risk ratio 9 (95% CI 3.94–20.57). Moreover, significantly increased peri-implant marginal bone loss was observed in patients with periodontitis-associated tooth loss after 5 years, mean difference 0.5 mm (95% CI 0.06–0.94).

Citation: Schou S, Holmstrup P, Worthington HV, Esposito M. Outcome of implant therapy in patients with previous tooth loss due to periodontitis.
Clinical Oral Implants Research 2006; 17 (S2): 104–123

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Outcome of root canal obturation by warm gutta-percha versus cold lateral condensation: a meta-analysis
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ENDODONTICS,RESTORATIVE DENTISTRY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: warm GP obturation demonstrated a higher rate of overextension than CLC. Postoperative pain prevalence, long-term outcomes, and obturation quality were similar between the two groups.

Methods: A systematic review of 11 RCTs to evaluate clinical outcome differencesof root canal obturation by warm gutta-percha (GP) or cold lateral condensation (CLC) through a systematic review and meta-analysis. Literature search to April 2006.

Quality of review: A range of databases were searched for relevant literature (Medline, Embase, Cochrane Library, SCIsearch and CNKI – a Chinese national database). However, additional techniques such as contacting experts, handsearching and grey literature sources may have identified additional papers. It is not reported whether there were language restrictions or whether the search was limited to published research only, nor are the number of citations generated by the search reported. Potential bias was reduced by conducting literature searches, data extraction and appraising included studies in duplicate by two independent reviewers.

Results: Postoperative pain, long-term outcomes, obturation quality, and overextension were the characteristics investigated. The results suggest that the two obturation techniques are not significantly different except in overextention. The relative risk (RR) value of warm GP versus CLC and 95% confidence interval (CI) of the first three criteria were 1.10 (0.71, 1.71), 0.78 (0.58, 1.05), and 1.31 (0.98, 1.76), respectively. Overextension was more likely to occur in the warm GP obturation group in comparison with the CLC group. The RR value and 95% CI were 1.98 (1.33, 2.93).

Citation: Peng L, Ye L, Tan H, Zhou X. Outcome of root canal obturation by warm gutta-percha versus cold lateral condensation: a meta-analysis. Journal of Endodontics, 2007; 33(2): 106-109.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Outcomes of root canal treatment and restoration, implant-supported single crowns, fixed partial dentures, and extraction without replacement: A systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ENDODONTICS,RESTORATIVE DENTISTRY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Lack of comparative studies with similar outcomes criteria with comparable time intervals limited comparison of these treatments. Implant-supported single crowns (ISC) and root canal treatments and restorations (RCT) resulted in superior long-term survival, compared to fixed partial dentures (FPDs). Limited data suggested that extraction without replacement resulted in inferior psychosocial outcomes compared to alternatives. Long-term, prospective clinical trials with large sample sizes and clearly defined outcomes criteria are needed.

Methods: A systematic review of 143 studies to compare the outcomes, benefits, and harms of endodontic care and restoration compared to extraction and placement of ISCs, FPDs, or extraction without tooth replacement. Literature search January 1996 to September 2006.

Quality of review: A reasonable attempt was made to identify relevant papers. Three databases were searched (Medline, Cochrane and Embase) with the addition of citation mining, journal hand-searching and contacting experts. The database search was limited to English language studies, which may have introduced a language bias.

Three reviewers independently selected, quality assessed and data extracted the included studies. The authors note that "success criteria differed greatly among treatment types" and the results of the meta-analyses should be viewed cautiously due to the significant heterogeneity identified.

Results: The selected studies varied considerably in design, success definition, assessment methods, operator type, and sample size. Direct comparison of treatment types was extremely rare. Limited psychosocial data revealed the traumatic effect of loss of visible teeth. Economic data were largely absent. Success rates for ISCs were higher than for RCTs and FPDs, respectively; however, success criteria differed greatly among treatment types, rendering direct comparison of success rates futile. Long-term survival rates for ISCs and RCTs were similar and superior to those for FPDs.

Citation: Torabinejad M, Anderson P, Bader J et al. Outcomes of root canal treatment and restoration, implant-supported single crowns, fixed partial dentures, and extraction without replacement: A systematic review. Journal of Prosthetic Dentistry 2007; 98(4): 285 - 311.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance.  You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Pacifier use and early childhood caries: an evidence-based study of the literature
document.publisher: Journal of the Canadian Dental Association
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,DENTAL CARIES,PAEDIATRIC DENTISTRY,CAUSES & PREVENTION]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Overall, the evidence does not suggest a strong or consistent association between pacifier use and early childhood caries.

Methods: A systematic review of 8 studies to investigate the relationship between pacifier use (with and without sweetening and prolonged or short-term) and early childhood caries (ECC). More than one database was searched, and reference lists followed up. Included studies were critically appraised according to "causation checklist" of 13 items. Literature search date was not stated.

Quality of review: The review is limited by low quality studies. Key papers may have been missed as unpublished papers were not sought and non-english papers were excluded. Not enough information was provided to determine the design of the included studies, only two papers were identified as a cross-sectional study and a case control study. Therefore this review has been classified as type IV evidence.

Results: The 8 studies assessed were methodologically inconsistent in terms of definitions of ECC, diagnostic criteria for identifying carious lesions, dental examination procedures, interviewing methods and descriptions of pacifier use.

None of the studies achieved a score greater than 6 and hence none was considered to present strong evidence. Six studies did not control for confounding variables, and the conclusions generated were inconsistent. The evidence from the other 2 studies, which did not control for confounding factors presented slightly stronger evidence, but they indicated no statistical difference in pacifier use between children with and those without ECC; furthermore, the reported odds ratios suggested that pacifier use might have had a mildly protective effect.

Citation: Peressini S. Pacifier use and childhood caries: An evidence based study of the literature. Journal of the Canadian Dental Association 2003; 69(1): 16-19c.

Access: Available to the general public.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Patient's delay in oral cancer: A systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,ORAL CANCER]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Healthcare factors and psychosocial factors may play a role but the research in this area is sparse, atheoretical and of poor quality. Patient delay is a problem in oral cancer and yet at present the reasons for such delays are poorly understood and under-researched. Systematic, high-quality and theory-driven research in this area is urgently required.

Methods: A systematic review of eight studies to investigate factors that contribute to patient delay in seeking medical help after self-discovery of oral cancer symptoms.  Literature search 1975-2005. 

Quality of review: A reasonable attempt was made to find all the relevant papers.  The authors searched a range of databases, supplemented by reference list reviews and contacts with experts.  The search was restricted to English language papers and this may have introduced language bias, although the authors state that the potentially relevant non-English language papers they found “did not appear to have patient delay as the primary focus…”.

The authors do not describe any formal method of quality appraising the included studies, but they highlight some key requirements and mention the poor methodological quality of the eight papers.  Results are inconclusive and the authors highlight the lack of available data in this area.  It is possible that this due in part to the requirement for >90% of patients in included studies to have had a histological diagnosis of squamous cell carcinoma

Results: Most clinical/tumour factors, sociodemographic variables, and patient health-related behaviours were not related to the duration of patient delay.

Citation: Scott SE, Grunfeld EA, McGurk M. Patient's delay in oral cancer: a systematic review. Community Dentistry and Oral Epidemiology 2006; 34(5): 337–343.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Pediatric smoking prevention interventions delivered by care providers
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,DENTAL PUBLIC HEALTH]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: There is very limited available evidence demonstrating efficacy of smoking prevention interventions in adolescents conducted in providers' offices and no evidence for long-term effectiveness of such interventions.

Methods: Systematic review of 4 randomised controlled trials examining the effectiveness of smoking prevention interventions delivered by care providers. Two studies were conducted in primary care, and one each in dental and orthodontic offices.

Quality of review: There was a good attempt to identify all the relevant literature; several databases were sought, reference lists were checked and unpublished literature was sought via the Medical Editors Trial Amnesty.  However, non-English language papers were not included.  A formal method of appraising the validity of the research is not reported, however the quality of the included studies is discussed in detail.  The results were not pooled statistically because of the degree of heterogeneity.

Results: Only one study demonstrated a significant effect on smoking initiation; in that study, 5.1% of the intervention group and 7.8% of the control group reported smoking at 12-month follow-up (odds ratio= 0.63; 95% confidence interval, 0.44-0.91). None of the studies had follow-up times greater than 3 years.

Citation: Christakis DA, Garrison MM, Ebel BE, Wiehe SE, Rivara FP. Pediatric smoking prevention interventions delivered by care providers. American Journal of Preventive Medicine. 2003 25 (4) 358-362.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Periodontal disease and adverse pregnancy outcomes: a systematic review.
document.publisher: British Journal of Obstetrics and Gynaecology
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,PERIODONTOLOGY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Periodontal disease may be associated with an increased risk of adverse pregnancy outcome. However, more methodologically rigorous studies are needed for confirmation.

Methods: A systematic review of twenty five studies (13 case–control, 9 cohort, and 3 controlled trials) that examined periodontal disease as a risk factor for adverse pregnancy outcomes.  Literature search Jan 1966 to March 2005.

Quality of review: A reasonable attempt was made to identify all the relevant papers.  Several databases were searched and reference lists of included papers were reviewed.  It is not clear that non-English language papers or unpublished data were sought and their absence could have introduced language and publication biases. Whilst the authors do not discuss any formal quality appraisal process, they do discuss problems associated with the variation of definitions for periodontal disease and potential confounders.  They indicate that these quality issues, combined with the limited number of randomised controlled trials make it impossible to offer clear conclusions.

Results: Of the included studies, 18 suggested an association between periodontal disease and increased risk of adverse pregnancy outcome (ORs ranging from 1.10 to 20.0) and 7 found no evidence of an association (ORs ranging from 0.78 to 2.54). Three clinical trial studies suggest that oral prophylaxis and periodontal treatment can lead to a 57% reduction in preterm low birthweight (pooled RR 0.43; 95% CI 0.24–0.78) and a 50% reduction in preterm births (RR 0.5; 95% CI 0.20–1.30).

Citation: Xiong X, Buekens P, Fraser WD, Beck J, Offenbacher S. Periodontal disease and adverse pregnancy outcomes: a systematic review. British Journal of Obstetrics and Gynaecology 2006; 113 (2): 135–143.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Periodontal disease and coronary heart disease incidence: A systematic review and meta-analysis
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,ASSOCIATED CONDITIONS]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Periodontal disease is an independent, though relatively weak, risk factor or marker for coronary heart disease (CHD) that is independent of traditional CHD risk factors, including socioeconomic status. Further research in this important area of public health is warranted.

Methods: A systematic review and meta-analysis of seven prospective cohort studies to determine whether periodontal disease is a risk factor for CHD. Database search date: 1966-March 2008.

Quality of review: Little information is provided about the search strategy which appears very limited – Medline database, reference list and text book checking. Only published studies in the English language were included. Given the large number of prospective cohort studies that have been/are being conducted, it is possible that potentially relevant studies were missed. Two reviewers assessed studies for inclusion and data extraction was completed by one author and checked by another. Quality assessment of included studies was conducted independently by two reviewers using the US Preventive Services Taskforce checklist. Three of the included studies were rated as good and four as fair.

The choice of study design was appropriate for determining potential causative links. However, as the authors rightly point out, there was significant heterogeneity between the studies. They also identified a lack of consistency in the definition/diagnosis of CHD and in the measurement of periodontal disease, plus the small number of included studies (albeit with a large overall population).

Results: Several studies found periodontal disease to be independently associated with increased risk of CHD. Summary relative risk estimates for different categories of periodontal disease (including periodontitis, tooth loss, gingivitis, and bone loss) ranged from 1.24 (95% CI 1.01-1.51) to 1.34 (95% CI 1.10-1.63). Risk estimates were similar in subgroup analyses by gender, outcome, study quality, and method of periodontal disease assessment.

Citation: Humphrey LL, Fu R, Buckley DI, Freeman M, Helfand M. Periodontal disease and coronary heart disease incidence: A systematic review and meta-analysis. Journal of General Internal Medicine, 2008; 23 (12): 2079-86.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

 

____________________________________________________________________

See also:

Chronic periodontitis associated with increased incidence of coronary heart disease. ADA Critical Summary Rethman MP.

Chronic periodontitis associated with increased incidence of coronary heart disease
ADA Critical Summary Rethman MP.Janket SJ, Baird AE, Sung-Kiang Chuang, Jones J. Meta-analysis of periodontal disease and risk of coronary heart disease and stroke. Oral Surgery, Oral Medicine, Oral Pathology, Oral Radiology and Endodontics. 2003; 95 (5): 559-569

Khader YS, Albashaireh ZSM, Alomari MA. Periodontal diseases and the risk of coronary heart and cerebrovascular diseases: a meta-analysis. Journal of Periodontology. 2004; 75(8): 1046-1053.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Periodontal disease and pre-eclampsia: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,PERIODONTOLOGY,ASSOCIATED CONDITIONS]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: None of the RTCs reported reductions in pre-eclamptic rate after periodontal therapy during pregnancy. Therefore it is questionable whether periodontal disease plays a causal role in the pathogenesis of pre-eclampsia. The observed association in eight observational studies might be the result of induction of periodontal disease due to the pre-eclamptic state or it may be an epiphenomenon of an exaggerated inflammatory response to pregnancy. Larger RCTs with pre-eclampsia as the primary outcome and pathophysiological studies are required to explore causality and to dissect biological mechanisms involved.

Methods: A systematic review of 15 studies (3 RCTs, 9 case control, 2 cohort and 1 cross-sectional) with sub-group meta-analysis of RCTs to evaluate a possible relationship between periodontal disease and pre-ecclampsia. Database search dates to August 2010.

Quality of review: The authors searched three databases (Medline, Embase and CINAHL) using appropriate search terms and supplemented by reference list checking. The search was restricted to peer-reviewed published papers in one of five European languages. Appropriate methods were used to minimise error and bias in selecting, quality assessing and data extracting included studies. Quality was assessed using study-specific checklists and studies that did not meet a quality threshold were excluded.

Results: Eight observational studies reported a positive association, while four studies found no association. None of the RTCs reported reductions in pre-eclamptic rate after periodontal therapy during pregnancy

Citation: Kunnen A, Van Doormaal JJ, Abbas F, Aarnoudse JG, Van Pampus MG, Faas MM. Periodontal disease and pre-eclampsia: a systematic review. Journal of Clinical Periodontology 2010;37(12):1075-87.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.
