document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Periodontal disease and pregnancy outcomes: state-of-the-science
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,PERIODONTOLOGY,ASSOCIATED CONDITIONS]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors’ conclusions: There is evidence of an association between periodontal disease and increased risk of preterm birth and low birth weight, especially in economically disadvantaged populations, but potential biases and the limited number of randomised controlled trials prevents us offering a clear conclusion. More methodologically rigorous studies are needed in this field. Currently, there is insufficient evidence to support the provision of periodontal treatment during pregnancy for the purpose of reducing adverse pregnancy outcomes.

Methods: A systematic review and meta-analysis of 44 studies (26 case control, 13 cohort, 4 RCTs and 1 CCT) to examine the existing evidence on the relationship between periodontal disease and adverse pregnancy outcomes. The studies were conducted in 23 countries and focused on preterm low birth weight, low birth weight, preterm birth, birth weight by gestational age, miscarriage or pregnancy loss, preeclampsia, and gestational diabetes mellitus. Database search dates: 1966 to 2006 inclusive.

Quality of review: As the authors indicate, quality issues, combined with the limited number of randomised controlled trials make it impossible to offer clear conclusions. A reasonable attempt was made to identify all relevant papers. Several databases were searched and reference lists of included papers were reviewed. It is not clear whether non-English language papers sought which could have introduced bias. The authors do not provide information on the processes they used for study selection and data extraction, and here again the risk of error and bias having been introduced cannot be excluded. Whilst the authors do not describe a formal quality appraise al process, they discuss a number of quality issues at some length: the variation of definitions for periodontal disease, potential confounders and sample size.

Results: Of the included studies, 29 suggested an association between periodontal disease and increased risk of adverse pregnancy outcome (odds ratios [ORs] ranging from 1.10 to 20.0) and 15 found no evidence of an association (ORs ranging from 0.78 to 2.54). A meta-analysis of clinical trials suggested that oral prophylaxis and periodontal treatment may reduce the rate of preterm low birth weight (pooled risk ratio (RR): 0.53, 95% confidence interval [CI]: 0.30-0.95, P < 0.05), but did not significantly reduce the rates of preterm birth (pooled RR: 0.79, 95% CI: 0.55-1.11, P > 0.05) or low birth weight (pooled RR: 0.86, 95% CI: 0.58%1.29, P > 0.05).

Citation: Xiong X, Buekens P, Vastardis S, Yu SM. Periodontal disease and pregnancy outcomes: state-of-the-science. Obstetrical and Gynecological Survey 2007; 62(9):605-15.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Periodontal disease as a risk factor for adverse pregnancy outcomes. A systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,PERIODONTOLOGY,ASSOCIATED CONDITIONS]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Periodontal disease may be a risk factor for preterm and/or low birth weight (PT/LBW). Additional longitudinal, epidemiologic, and interventional studies are needed to validate this association and to determine whether it is causal. It is not yet clear whether periodontal diseases play a causal role in adverse pregnancy outcomes.

Preliminary evidence to date suggests that periodontal intervention may reduce adverse pregnancy outcomes.

Methods: Systematic review of 12 studies (1 randomised controlled trial, 2 interventional, 6 case-control, and 3 cross-sectional). Literature search to October 2002.

Quality of review: Key papers may have been missed and bias introduced as it is unclear whether unpublished research was sought and only English language papers were included. Two reviewers independently selected studies for inclusion according to agreed criteria and extracted data. Although all included studies were graded, it is unclear whether  validity was assessed for all studies or only for the randomised controlled trial.

Results: While several studies implicated periodontal disease as a risk factor for preterm and/or low birth weight (PT/LBW), few assessed the impact of the prevention and treatment of periodontal disease on outcomes.

Several epidemiologic studies did not support periodontal disease as a risk factor for PT/LBW.

Citation: Scannapieco FA, Bush RB, Paju S. Periodontol disease as a risk factor for adverse pregnancy outcomes. A systematic review. Annals of Perodontology. 2003; 8(1): 70-78.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Periodontal diseases and cardiovascular events: meta-analysis of observational studies
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,PERIODONTOLOGY,ASSOCIATED CONDITIONS,SPECIAL CARE DENTISTRY,CARDIOVASCULAR CONDITIONS]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors’ conclusions: It seems from observational studies that subjects with periodontal diseases have higher odds and higher risks of developing cardiovascular diseases but the reduction in the risk of cardiovascular events associated with the treatment of periodontitis remains to be investigated.

Methods: A systematic review and meta-analysis of 32 studies (7 cohort, 11 cross-sectional and 14 case control studies). Database search dates: 1989 to 2007 inclusive. Two separate meta-analyses were conducted, the first for cohort studies, the second for cross-sectional and case control studies.

Quality of review: The results of the review are limited by the quality of the included studies. There is a high degree of clinical heterogeneity in exposure and outcome measures. In addition, none of the included studies appear to have adjusted for a full list of potential confounders; indeed three studies provide no information on confounders and two fail to adjust for smoking.

Overall the review is well conducted. The authors searched a wide range of sources without language or publication restrictions. Appropriate processes were used to minimise error and bias in the selection, quality assessment and data extraction of included studies.  The authors used three checklists to assess the quality of included studies. However, only limited information is provided on the outcomes of the assessment and it is unclear how accurately the risk of bias has assessed.

Results: Because of significant statistical heterogeneity, a sensitivity analysis was conducted and two case control studies and one cross-sectional study were excluded from the second meta-analysis. The pooled odds ratio calculated from the 22 case-control and cross-sectional studies was 2.35 (95% CI [1.87; 2.96], p < 0.0001). The risk of developing cardiovascular disease was found to be significantly (34%) higher in subjects with periodontal disease compared to those without periodontal disease (pooled relative risk from the 7 cohort studies was 1.34 (95% CI [1.27; 1.42], p < 0.0001).

Citation: Blaizot A, Vergnes JN, Nuwwareh S, Amar J, Sixou M. Periodontal diseases and cardiovascular events: meta-analysis of observational studies. International Dental Journal 2009
Aug;59(4):197-209.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Periodontal diseases and the risk of coronary heart and cerebrovascular diseases: a meta-analysis
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,PERIODONTOLOGY,ASSOCIATED CONDITIONS]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Findings indicated that periodontal infection increases the risk of coronary heart diseases (CHD) and cerebrovascular diseases (CVD). However, this meta-analysis provided no evidence for the existence of strong associations between periodontitis and CHD and CVD. Larger and better-controlled studies involving socially homogeneous populations and measuring specific periodontal pathogens are required to identify a definite association between periodontal disease and the risk of coronary heart disease and cerebrovascular disease.

Methods: Systematic review of 31 studies (case-controls, cross-sectional and longitudinal). Literature search 1966 to June 2002.

Quality of Review: It is likely that the search strategy did not identify all relevant papers.  Only one database was searched and the search was limited to published English language papers with the consequent potential for both publication and language bias.  While the inclusion criteria and data extraction addressed some methodological issues, a formal method for assessing the validity of included studies is not reported.

Results: Subjects with periodontitis had an overall adjusted risk of coronary heart diseases (CHD) that was 1.15 times (95% CI 1.06 to 1.25; p = 0.001) the risk for healthy subjects. There was no heterogeneity among the studies in the overall relative risk estimate (p = 0.472). As compared to healthy subjects, those with periodontitis had an overall adjusted relative risk of cerebrovascular diseases of 1.13 (95% CI 1.01 to 1.27; p = 0.032).

Citation: Khader YS, Albashaireh ZSM, Alomari MA. Periodontal diseases and the risk of coronary heart and cerebrovascular diseases: a meta-analysis. Journal of Periodontology. 2004; 75(8): 1046-1053. 

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Periodontal diseases and the risk of preterm birth and low birth weight: a meta-analysis
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: The findings indicate that periodontal diseases in the pregnant mother significantly increase the risk of subsequent preterm birth/low birth weight. Although it remains important to promote good oral hygiene during routine prenatal visits, there is no convincing evidence, on the basis of existing case–control and prospective studies, that treatment of periodontal disease will reduce the risk of PTB. Consequently, large, randomised, placebo-controlled, masked clinical trials are required.

Methods: A literature search was conducted using Medline.  Only full length original journal articles published in English were considered.  A manual search was performed.  Information was independently abstracted by two investigators using a standard protocol.

Quality of Review: It is likely that key papers were missed in this review.  The search terms were limited and only Medline and reference lists were searched. Whilst the authors did not detect publication bias in their analysis, the restriction to published papers in the English language may have introduced biases.   Quality was assessed independently by the two reviewers but was used during sensitivity analyses rather than for weighting.  The authors indicate the need for high quality research in this area.

Results: Five studies (three cohort and two case–control) were included. Pregnant women with periodontal disease had an overall adjusted risk of PTB that was 4.28-fold (95% CI, 2.62–6.99; P<0.005) the risk for subjects who did not have periodontal disease. The overall adjusted OR of PLBW was 5.28 (95% CI, 2.21–12.62; P<0.005), whereas the overall adjusted OR of a delivery of either PTB or PLBW was 2.30 (95% CI, 1.21–4.38; P<0.005).

Citation: Khader YS, Ta'ani Q, Periodontal diseases and the risk of preterm birth and low birth weight: a meta-analysis, Journal of Periodontology,2005; 76(2): 161-5

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. 

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Periodontal infection and adverse pregnancy outcomes: a systematic review of epidemiological studies.
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,PERIODONTOLOGY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: The methodological limitations of most studies did not allow conclusions concerning the effects of periodontal disease on adverse pregnancy outcomes. Larger, methodlogically rigorous analytical studies using reliable outcomes and exposure measures are recommended.

Methods:  A systematic review of 36 studies (27 case control studies, 6 cohort studies and 3 clinical trials) to evaluate periodontal disease as a potential risk factor for adverse pregnancy outcomes.  A literature search to Deceber 2005.

Quality of review:   The authors made a reasonable attempt to identify all the relevant literature.  They searched several databases and supplemented that search with a review of reference lists.  They restricted the search to English and Portuguese papers and it does not appear that they searched for unpublished data; this may have introduced language and publication biases. Although they do not report a formal quality appraisal process, it is clear that the authors looked at a range of quality issues in the included papers.  They conclude that virtually every study had serious methodological flaws which raise serious questions about the validity of reported results.

Results:  There was a clear heterogeneity between studies concerning measurement of periodontal disease and selection of type of adverse pregnancy outcome.  Most studies did not control for confounders, thus raising serious doubts about their conclusions.

Citation: Vettore MV, Lamarca GA, Leao AT, Thomaz FB, Sheilham A, Leal MC et al. Periodontal infection and adverse pregnancy outcomes: a systematic review of epidemiological studies. Cad saude Publica 2006; 22(10): 2041-53

Access: Full-text access available online.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Periodontal status of diabetics compared with nondiabetics: a meta-analysis
document.publisher: Journal of Diabetes and its Complications
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Diabetics had a significantly higher severity but the same extent of periodontal disease than nondiabetics.

Methods: A literature search was performed using MEDLINE database for published studies from January 1970 through October 2003 with manual search for references in relevant studies. This meta-analysis was based on 18 comparative cross-sectional studies, three prospective cohort studies and baseline data of two clinical trials that compared oral hygiene, gingival and periodontal status between diabetics and nondiabetics. Heterogeneity was obvious among included studies; therefore, the analysis using random-effects model was conducted.

Quality of review: It is likely that the search strategy did not identify all relevant papers. Only one database (Medline) was searched using narrow search terms and the reference lists of included papers examined.The authors indicte that they restricted the search to published papers in the English language which may have introduced language and publication biases. There is limited information on the quality of included studies.

Results: This study demonstrated that diabetics had significantly worse oral hygiene as measured by the average of plaque index (P1I), higher severity of gingival disease as measured by the average of gingival index (GI) and higher severity of periodontal disease as measured by the average of probing pocket depth (PPD) and clinical attachment loss (CAL). However, diabetics had similar extent of oral hygiene, gingival and periodontal disease as measured by percentages of surfaces or sites with specific scores of P1I, GI, bleeding on probing (BOP), PPD and CAL.

Citation: Khader YS, Daoud AS, El-Qaderi SS, Alkafajei A, Batayha WQ. Periodontal status of diabetics compared with nondiabetics: a meta-analysis. Journal of Diabetes and its Complications 2006; 20(1): 59-68

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Periodontitis as a potential risk factor for peri-implantitis
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,PERIODONTOLOGY,ASSOCIATED CONDITIONS]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors’ conclusions: Based on three studies with a limited number of patients and considerable variations in study design, different definitions of periodontitis, and confounding variables like smoking that have not been accounted for, this systematic review indicates that subjects with a history of periodontitis may be at greater risk for peri-implant infections. It should, however, be stressed that the data to support this conclusion are not very robust.

Methods: A narrative systematic review of three observational studies (2 prospective and 1 retrospective) to consider a possible association between a previous history of periodontitis and peri-implantitis.

Quality of review: As the authors conclude, the review is limited by the quality of the included evidence. It is possible that potentially relevant studies were missed as the search was limited to PubMed using restrictive search terms, supplemented by reference list checking. Limiting inclusion to published papers in the English language may also have introduced bias.

Appropriate methods were used to minimise error and bias in selecting included papers. No information is provided on the process used to extract data. No formal process was used to quality assess included papers, although the authors comment on quality issues.

Citation: Renvert S, Persson GR. Periodontitis as a potential risk factor for peri-implantitis. Journal of Clinical Periodontology 2009 Jul;36 Suppl 10:9-14.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.  

See also: Schou, S., Holmstrup, P., Worthington, H. V. & Esposito, M.  Outcome of implant therapy in patients with previous tooth loss due to periodontitis. Clinical Oral Implants Research 2006; 17 (Suppl. 2), 104–123.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Perioperative management of patients receiving oral anticoagulants: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORAL SURGERY,SPECIAL CARE DENTISTRY,BLEEDING DISORDERS,CARDIOVASCULAR CONDITIONS,ANTICOAGULATION]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Most patients can undergo dental procedures, arthrocentesis, cataract surgery, and diagnositic endoscopy without alteration of their regimen. For other invasive procedures, oral anticoagulation needs to be witheld, and the decision whether to pursue an aggressive strategy of perioperative administration of intravenous heparin or subcutaneous low-molecular-weight heparin should be individualised. The current literature is substantially limited in its ability to help choose an optimal strategy

Methods: A systematic review of 22 studies of perioperatic management of patients receiving oral anticoagulant therapy (OAC) (including 1 systematic review of 26 case reports regarding dental procedures). Several types of surgical and invasive procedures were analysed. Publications from January 1966 to June 2001 were sought.

Quality of study: Unpublished research was not sought and only English language papers were included. The authors themselves call for caution in interpreting the conclusions due to the lack of rigorous methodology of most of the reports of perioperative management.

Results: Overall, 29 thromboembolic events occured among 1868 patients (1.6%, 95% CI 0%-0.7%). Thromboembolic event rates by management strategy were 0.4% (1 of 237) for continuation of OAC, 0.6% (6 of 996) for discontinuation of OAC therapy without administration of intravenous heparin, 0% (0 of 166) for discontinuation of OAC therapy with administration of intravenous heparin, 0.6% (1 of 180) for discontinuation of OAC therapy with administration of low-weight-molecular heparin, and 8.0% (21 of 264) for unspecified or unclear strategies.

Major bleeding while receiving therapeutic OAC was rare for dental procedures (0.2% [4 of 2014]), arthrocentesis (0% [0 of 32]), cataract surgery (0% [0 of 203) and upper endoscopy or colonoscopy with or without biopsy (0% [0 of 111]).

Citation: Dunn AS, Turpie AG.  Perioperative management of patients receiving oral anticoagulants: a systematic review. Archives of Internal Medicine 2003; 163: 901-908.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. Full text online access is available to NHS staff in England via ATHENS passwords. To apply for an ATHENS password and access this resource and many others please go to the ATHENS registration page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Personal use of hair dyes and risk of cancer
document.publisher: Journal of the American Medical Association
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,ORAL CANCER,RISK FACTORS,HAIR DYE]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: The review did not find strong evidence of a marked increase in the risk of cancer among personal hair dye users. Some aspects related to hematopoietic cancer and other cancers that have shown evidence of increased risk in 1 or 2 studies should be investigated further.

Methods: Systematic review of 77 studies (70 case-control and 7 cohort) to examine the association between personal use of hair dyes and relative risk of cancer. One large cohort study investigated hair dye use and cancer of the oral cavity, and one small case-control study investigated cancer of the salivary gland. Literature search 1966-2005.

Quality of Review:  Generally a well-conducted review.  A reasonable attempt was made to locate all relevant research in this area.  Several databases were searched, key journals were hand-searched and reference lists of included papers were checked for further eligible studies.  Unpublished research was not sought, but the authors did not detect evidence of publication bias in their analyses.  The quality of the included studies was independently assessed by two reviewers.  The authors rightly conclude that the evidence was not strong.  The large majority (91%) of studies were case controlled which could introduce recall bias and which cannot prove a causal relationship.

Results: The pooled relative risk for ever users of hair dyes was 1.06 (95% CI, 0.95-1.18) for breast cancer (14 studies), 1.01 (95% CI, 0.89-1.14) for bladder cancer (10 studies), and 1.15 (95% CI, 1.05-1.27) for hematopoietic cancers (40 studies). Other cancers were examined by only 1 or 2 studies, of which the pooled or single relative risk was elevated for brain cancer, ovarian cancer, and cancer of the salivary glands.

Relative risk for cancer of oral cavity (1 study) was 0.61 (95%CI 0.32-1.14) and for salivary gland (1 study) 3.01 (95% CI 1.18-7.69).

No effect was observed for use of permanent dyes or for extensive use.

Citation: Takkouche B. Personal use of hair dyes and risk of cancer. A meta-analysis. Journal of the American Medical Association. 2005; 293(20): 2516-2524

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. Full text online access is available to NHS staff in England via ATHENS passwords. To apply for an ATHENS password and access this resource and many others please go to the ATHENS registration page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Pharmacologic interventions in the treatment of temporomandibular disorders, atypical facial pain, and burning mouth syndrome. A qualitative systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORO-FACIAL PAIN,ORAL MEDICINE]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors conclusions: The common use of analgesics in temporomandibular disorders (TMD) , atypical facial pain (AFP), and burning mouth syndrome (BMS) is not supported by scientific evidence. More large RCTs are needed to determine which pharmacologic interventions are effective in TMD, AFP, and BMS.

Methods: Systematic review of 11 randomised controlled trials of adult patients (n=368) to investigate the pain-relieving effect and safety of pharmacologic interventions in the treatment of TMD, BMS and AFP.

Quality of review: Generally a well conducted systematic review.  Several databases were searched without language restrictions and reference lists of included papers were checked.  However, unpublished research was not sought and this may have introduced publication bias.  Data extraction and validity assessment of the included studies was performed independently by three reviewers and disagreements were resolved by consensus. The authors aknowledge that the review is limited by the low sample sizes of available trials.

Results: Four trials were on TMD patients, 2 on AFP, 1 on BMS, 1 on RA of the TMJ, and 3 on mixed groups of patients with TMD and AFP. Of the latter, amitriptyline was effective in 1 study and benzodiazepine in 2 studies; the effect in 1 of the benzodiazepine studies was improved when ibuprofen was also given. One study showed that intra-articular injection with glucocorticoid relieved the pain of RA of the TMJ. In 1 study, a combination of paracetamol, codeine, and doxylamine was effective in reducing TMD pain. No effective pharmacologic treatment was found for BMS. Only minor adverse effects were reported in the studies.

Citation: List T, Axelsson S, Leijon G. Pharmacologic interventions in the treatment of temporomandibular disorders, atypical face pain, and burning mouth syndrome. A qualitative systematic review. Journal of Orofacial Pain. 2003 17 (4) 301-310.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Pit and fissure sealants in the prevention of dental caries in children and adolescents: a systematic review
document.publisher: Journal of the Canadian Dental Association
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,DENTAL CARIES,CAUSES & PREVENTION]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors conclusions: The following recommendations are based on the evidence gathered in this review: 1. Sealants should be placed on all permanent teeth without cavitation (ie, teeth that are free of caries, teeth that have deep pit and fissure morphology, teeth with "sticky" fissures or teeth with stained grooves) as soon after eruption as isolation can be achieved. 2. Sealants should not be placed on partially erupted teeth or teeth with cavitation or caries of the dentin. 3. Sealants should be placed on the primary molars of children who are susceptible to caries (ie, those with a history of caries). 4. Sealants should be placed on first and second molars within 4 years after eruption. 5. Resin-based sealants should be preferred, until such time as glass ionomer cements with better retention capacity are developed. 6. Sealants should be placed as part of an overall prevention strategy based on assessment of caries risk.

Methods: A systematic review of 25 studies to investigate the evidence for sealants as a means of preventing dental caries in children and adolescents. Database search: 2000 to 2007.

Quality of review: It is likely that the search methodology missed potentially relevant papers. Whilst the authors searched a wide range of sources, the search strategy used was limited and only English language papers were selected. Using a wider range of terms without language restrictions, hand-searching journals and contacting experts may have identified additional papers. This review is designed to provide more up-to-date evidence than that made available in two Cochrane reviews published in 2004¹ and 2006² and the authors of this review might usefully have taken advantage of the more sensitive search strategy used in the Cochrane reviews. The 2004 review was updated and published in late 2008 and the recommendations of this review should be read alongside those of the two Cochrane reviews. The authors quality scored the included papers using a checklist. Thirteen papers were excluded on this basis.

Citation: Azarpazhooh A, Main PA. Pit and fissure sealants in the prevention of dental caries in children and adolescents: a systematic review. Journal of the Canadian Dental Association 2008; 74(2): 171-7.

Access: Full text freely available.

 __________________________________________________________

¹Ahovuo-Saloranta A, Hiiri A, Nordblad A, Worthington H, Mäkelä M. Pit and fissure sealants for preventing dental decay in the permanent teeth of children and adolescents. Cochrane Database Syst Rev 2004; (3):CD001830. Updated in 2008: CD001830. DOI: 10.1002/14651858.CD001830.pub3.

²Hiiri A, Ahovuo-Saloranta A, Nordblad A, Makela M. Pit and fissure sealants versus fluoride varnishes for preventing dental decay in children and adolescents. Cochrane Database Syst Rev 2006; (4):CD003067.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Postoperative chemoradiotherapy for advanced squamous cell carcinoma of the head and neck: a systematic review of the evidence
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,ORAL CANCER,ENT AND AUDIOLOGY,NOSE & SINUS DISORDERS,LARYNX & PHARYNX DISORDERS,NEOPLASMS,MALIGNANT,NEOPLASMS,MALIGNANT,CONDITIONS,TREATMENT & MANAGEMENT,CHEMOTHERAPY,THERAPEUTIC INTERVENTIONS,DRUG TREATMENTS,NON-DRUG TREATMENTS,CHEMOTHERAPY,RADIOTHERAPY,HEAD & NECK CANCER]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Postoperative adjuvant chemoradiotherapy is superior to radiotherapy alone. Because chemoradiotherapy is associated with significantly increased toxicity, further investigations to identify patients most likely to benefit or toxicity reduction strategies are warranted.

Methods: A systematic review of 4 randomised controlled trials evaluating the use of postoperative chemoradiotherapy for patients with advanced (stage III or IV) squamous cell carcinoma of the head and neck at a high risk of recurrence.

Quality of review: The authors searched a range of databases including Medline, Embase, Cochrane Library and supplemented the search with reference list checking and reviewing conference proceedings.  However, they excluded unpublished and non-English language studies and this may have introduced publication and language biases.  No formal validity assessment is described, however, the review discusses several quality aspects of the included studies such as study power, patient baseline characteristics, intention to treat analysis and follow-up period.

Results: Of 4 RCTs identified, 3 reported improvements in locoregional control, 3 reported improved disease-free or progression-free survival, and 3 reported improved overall survival with chemoradiotherapy compared with radiotherapy alone.

Pooling trials confirmed the benefit for chemoradiotherapy in locoregional recurrence (relative risk [RR] = 0.59; 95% confidence interval [CI] = 0.47-0.75; p<0.00001) and overall survival (RR = 0.80; 95% CI = 0.71-0.90; p = 0.0002). More frequent and severe acute mucosal toxicity was reported with combined treatment.

Citation: Winquist E, Oliver T and Gilbert R. Postoperative chemoradiotherapy for advanced squamous cell carcinoma of the head and neck: a systematic review of the evidence. Head & Neck 2007; 29: 38-46

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Posturography as a diagnostic aid in dentistry: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,DENTO-FACIAL ANOMALIES]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors’ conclusions: With limitations because of the poor methodological quality of the present published studies, conclusions are that a correlation between the stomatognathic system and whole-body posture can be detected, at least under experimental conditions; although posturography has little relevance in the monitoring of body posture responses to changes in the stomatognathic system (including temporomandibular disorders). While more investigations with improved levels of scientific evidence are needed, the current evidence does not support the usefulness of posturography as a diagnostic aid in dentistry.


Methods:  A narrative systematic review assessing the scientific evidence for detectable correlations between the stomatognathic system and whole-body posture and the relevance of posturography as a diagnostic aid in dentistry. Twenty-one studies were included. Literature search to May 2009.


Quality of review:  Further relevant studies may have been identified by searching additional bibliographic databases, contacting experts, and handsearching journals and websites. It also appears that the authors have not looked for unpublished research, which may have introduced publication bias. It is unclear whether non-English language papers were considered eligible.

Whether eligible papers were selected and extracted in duplicate, is not reported. However quality assessment of studies was conducted by two independent reviewers, using predefined checklists.

As the authors acknowledge, the review is limited by the quality of the included studies.

Results: After selection, 21 articles qualified for the final analysis. Only one study was judged to be of medium/high quality, with all of the rest classified as of low quality design. Only two studies included follow-up of 28 days and 1 year. Overall, 14 of the studies reported detectable correlations between the stomatognathic system and body posture in at least one of the parameters used, although in four of these studies the authors suggested caution in the interpretation of their data. After a reappraisal of the data provided in 13 of the studies, a weak correlation that reaches biological, but not clinical, relevance is apparent.

Citation: Perinetti G, Contardo L. Posturography as a diagnostic aid in dentistry: a systematic review. Journal of Oral Rehabilitation. 2009; 26: 922-936

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Predictive value of tumor thickness for cervical lymph-node involvement in squamous cell carcinoma of the oral cavity: a meta-analysis of reported studies
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,ORAL CANCER,TREATMENT & MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors’ conclusions: An association between tumor thickness (TT) and cervical lymph-node involvement is confirmed in this study. The optimal cutoff point for TT is 4 mm. For oral cavity tumors thicker than 4 mm, prophylactic neck management is generally recommended. Standardization of the measuring method of TT is required for using TT as valid predictor in planning neck treatment. A less invasive method of assessment is needed if this parameter is to be incorporated into clinical TNM staging system.

Methods: A systematic review and meta-analysis of sixteen studies (study types unclear) to (i) confirm whether TT is a strong predictor for cervical lymph-node involvement in squamous cell carcinoma of the oral cavity and (ii) determine a precise clinically optimal TT cutoff point. Database search dates to January 2007.

Quality of review: The authors searched two databases (Medline and Embase) supplemented by reference list checking. However, the limited search terms and the restriction to published studies in the English language, makes it likely that potentially relevant studies were missed and bias introduced.

Appropriate procedures were used to minimise error and bias in study selection, data extraction and quality assessment. However, whilst the authors state that they assessed methodological quality they do not provide information on the outcome of this assessment.

Considerable variation on the strength of association between tumor thickness and cervical lymph-node involvement is noted. This is attributed to study heterogeneity, imprecise definitions of tumor thickness and limited sample sizes.

Results: Data were examined for the following TT cutoff points: 3 mm (4 studies, 387 patients), 4 mm (9 studies, 778 patients), 5 mm (6 studies, 367 patients), and 6 mm (4 studies, 488 patients). The OR (95% CI) was 7.3 (5.3-10.1) for the overall group. The proportion of FN-PLND was 5.3% (95% CI, 2.0-11.2), 4.5% (2.6-7.2), 16.6% (11.5-22.8), and 13.0% (9.7-16.9) for TT<3, <4, <5, and <6 mm, respectively. There was a statistically significant difference between the 4-mm and 5-mm TT cutoff points (P = .007).

Citation: Huang SH, Hwang D, Lockwood G, Goldstein DP, O'Sullivan B. Predictive value of tumor thickness for cervical lymph-node involvement in squamous cell carcinoma of the oral cavity: a meta-analysis of reported studies. Cancer 2009;115(7):1489-97.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Preferences and utilities of health outcomes and treatments associated with head and neck cancer: A systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORAL CANCER,ORAL SURGERY,ENT AND AUDIOLOGY,NOSE & SINUS DISORDERS,LARYNX & PHARYNX DISORDERS,SALIVARY GLAND DISORDERS,NEOPLASMS,NEOPLASMS,MALIGNANT,NEOPLASMS,MALIGNANT,CONDITIONS,TREATMENT & MANAGEMENT,HEAD & NECK CANCER]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors’ conclusions: Limited data on utilities in head and neck cancer (HNC) highlight the need for further high quality examinations in larger groups of patients. In addition, the limited range of studies re-emphasizes that different treatment options bear different perceptions and outcomes in varying subsites of HNC. While researchers continue to explore the relationship between specific treatments and quality of life outcomes, it is important that the care team invite personal discussion with the patient during the treatment planning phase.

Methods: Systematic review to understand the preferences associated with HNC and its treatments. Included studies had to elicit preferences or utilities (i.e. a measure of desirability/preference) for health states and treatment outcomes associated with HNC. Literature search from 1980 to May 2005.

Quality of review: The limited search strategy and the narrow search terms used make it unlikely that all relevant studies were identified.   The authors do not state whether they sought unpublished studies or non-English language papers and the potential for publication and language biases having been introduced cannot be excluded.  No formal quality appraisal process was undertaken but the authors do comment on several quality aspects including sample sizes and study design.  Whilst the authors take some conclusions from the available evidence, they note that the variation between studies makes it difficult to make general recommendations.

Results: Fifty-six studies were analyzed. Eight of these studies provided quantitative data on utilities elicited by rating scale, time trade-off, or standard gamble methods. Patients reported lower preferences and utilities than physicians and non-patients for outcomes associated with surgery, including radical neck dissection.

Citation: Komatsuzaki Y, Gramegna P, Stephens JM, Botteman MF, Pashos CL, Redaelli A. Preferences and utilities of health outcomes and treatments associated with head and neck cancer: A systematic review. American Journal of Cancer, 2006; 5: 27-34.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Pregabalin in patients with postoperative dental pain
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORAL SURGERY,IMPACTED THIRD MOLARS,POSTOPERATIVE PAIN RELIEF]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Pregabalin appears to have significant analgesic properties in the third molar extraction model. Further research is needed to confirm these findings.

Method: A randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled, parallel-group trial comparing pregabalin (50 and 300 mg) to placebo and 400 mg of ibuprofen in 198 patients who had undergone elective surgery to remove one or two third molars. The study was conducted in the UK at a single centre. Primary efficacy parameters included pain relief (PR), pain intensity difference (PID), pain relief intensity difference (PRID), time to onset of analgesia, and duration of analgesia.

Quality of study: Although an intention-to-treat analyses was carried out and the trial was randomised and double blind, primary and secondary outcome data are reported in graphs rather than in tables and measures of precision (CIs) are not presented. This would be desirable given the higher frequency of adverse events in the pregabalin 300-mg group.

Results: Results showed that there were statistically significant differences in PR, PID, and PRID between the 300-mg pregabalin group and placebo. In addition, the 300-mg pregabalin group had a significantly longer duration of analgesia than the ibuprofen group and had the highest score on the patient global impression of study medication. Adverse events were reported more frequently in the pregabalin 300-mg group.

Citation: Hill CM, Balkenohl M, Thomas DW, Walker R, Mathe H, Murray G. Pregabalin in patients with postoperative dental pain. European Journal of Pain 2001; 5(2): 119-24.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Preterm low birth weight and maternal periodontal status: a meta-analysis
document.publisher: American Journal of Obstetrics and Gynecology
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,PERIODONTOLOGY,ASSOCIATED CONDITIONS]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: The findings indicate a likely association between maternal periodontal disease on preterm delivery and/or birth of low-weight infants, but it needs to be confirmed by large, well designed, multicenter trials.

Methods: Systematic review and meta-analysis to assess the effect of maternal periodontal disease on preterm delivery and/or birth of low-weight infants. 17 observational studies were included (11 case-controls, 4 cohorts and 2 cross-sectionals). Literature search from database inception to September 2005.

Quality of review: The review methodology is very good. It addresses a clearly focused question and a good attempt was amde to locate all relevant literature. The authors searched for both published and unpublished studies in any language using several databases (Medline, Embase, Lilacs, Biosis and Pascal), checked reference lists and contacted experts. Two reviewers independently selected, data extracted and quality assessed the included studies.

However, the decision to conduct a meta-analysis of the included studies is problematic as they are clinically and statistically heterogeneous. The authors considered the statistical heterogeneity and stated that “there was some evidence” to suggest the source of heterogeneity was “the quality of studies”. This is highly likely given that the evidence from the five highest quality studies does not show a statistically significance association between maternal periodontal status and low birth weight - OR 1.66 (95%CI 0.91-3.04, P< .1). This lack of significance suggests significant bias and confounding in the poorer quality studies.

Results: Seven thousand one hundred fifty-one women participated in the studies, 1056 of whom delivered a preterm and/or low birthweight infant.

The overall odds ratio was 2.83 (95% CI: 1.95-4.10, p<0.0001). This pooled value needed to be interpreted cautiously because there appeared to be a clear trend for the better quality studies to be of lower association strength.

Citation: Vergnes JN, Sixou M. Preterm low birth weight and maternal periodontal status: a meta-analysis. American Journal of Obstetrics & Gynecology 2007; 196: 135e1-135e7.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Prevalence of nickel hypersensitivity in orthodontic patients: a meta-analysis
document.publisher: American Journal of Orthodontics and Dentofacial Orthopedics
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORTHODONTICS]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors’ conclusions: Orthodontic treatment is not associated with an increase in the prevalence of nickel hypersensitivity unless subjects have a history of cutaneous piercing. High-validity, longitudinal studies with appropriate controls are needed to produce strong evidence to further support the results of this meta-analysis

Methods: A systematic review and meta-analysis of eight studies (design unclear) to investigate the effect of orthodontic therapy on the prevalence of nickel hypersensitivity and compare it with the prevalence in the general population. Database search: inception to November 2007.

Quality of review: Overall a well conducted systematic review, based on a pre-defined protocol. The authors searched multiple databases without language restrictions, supplemented by reference list checking, and searching for grey literature. Whilst the search terms were limited, possibly resulting in relevant studies being missed, this likelihood is reduced by the range of sources searched. Appropriate procedures were used to minimise error and bias in study selection, data extraction and quality assessment. Quality assessment reviewed key elements which reduce bias: population selection; whether studies are prospective or retrospective, assessor blinding, and examination of loss to follow up.

Results: From the studies retrieved no statistically significant difference between the odds for a positive patch-test result before orthodontic treatment and after the placement of the appliances was observed. Orthodontic patients with no cutaneous piercing or with skin pierced have no statistically significant differences of nickel hypersensitivity after treatment compared with the general population.

Citation: Kolokitha OE, Kaklamanos EG, Papadopoulos MA. Prevalence of nickel hypersensitivity in orthodontic patients: a meta-analysis. American Journal of Orthodontics and Dentofacial Orthopedics, 2008; 134; 6: 722.e1-e12

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Prevalence of pain in patients with cancer: a systematic review of the past 40 years
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,ORAL CANCER,ENT AND AUDIOLOGY,CONDITIONS,TREATMENT & MANAGEMENT,HEAD & NECK CANCER]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Despite clear World Health Organisation recommendations, cancer pain still is a major problem.

Methods: A meta-analysis of 52 studies, including three in head and neck cancer, to investigate the prevalance of pain in cancer patients according to different disease stages and types of cancer. Literature search 1966 to September 2005.

Quality of review: A reasonable attempt was made to locate all the relevant literature with searches in several databases (Medline, PubMed, Embase and the Cochrane Library), supplemented by a review of reference lists.  However, unpublished research was not sought and the search was restricted to English language papers.  Consequently, the review may have been subject to publication and language bias. The validity of the included studies was assessed independently by two reviewers using clearly defined quality criteria.  Studies that did not score at least 14 out of 19 points were excluded. The main quality issues were the representativeness of the study sample and data collection methods.

Results: Pooled prevalence rates of pain were calculated for four subgroups: (i) studies including patients after curative treatment, 33% [95% confidence interval (CI) 21% to 46%]; (ii) studies including patients under anticancer treatment: 59% (CI 44% to 73%); (iii) studies including patients characterised as advanced/metastatic/terminal disease, 64% (CI 58% to 69%) and (iii) studies including patients at all disease stages, 53% (CI 43% to 63%). Of the patients with pain more than one-third graded their pain as moderate or severe. Pooled prevalence of pain was >50% in all cancer types with the highest prevalence in head/neck cancer patients (70%; 95% CI 51% to 88%).

Citation: van den Beuken-van Everdingen MHJ, de Rijke JM, Kessels AG, Schouten HC, van Kleef M, Patijn J. Prevalence of pain in patients with cancer: a systematic review of the past 40 years. Annals of Oncology 2007; 18(9): 1437-49.

Access: Full-text online access to this paper is freely available.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Prevalence of tooth wear in adults
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,RESTORATIVE DENTISTRY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors’ conclusions: The predicted percentage of adults presenting with severe tooth wear increases from 3% at the age of 20 years to 17% at the age of 70 years. Therefore there is a tendency to develop more wear with age. It is not possible to state within the limited number of study analyzed whether this increase reflects greater severity of wear on the same tooth or greater number of teeth involved. To date there are no longitudinal studies in adults or children that have measured wear progression on the same tooth.

Methods:  A systematic review of 13 studies to investigate the prevalence of tooth wear in adults and assess possible correlations. Database search dates: 1980 to Jul 2007

Quality of review: The review is limited by the scarcity of relevant data. It is likely that potentially relevant studies were missed as only two databases (PubMed and Cochrane Library) were searched using very limited search terms. Although the electronic search was supplemented by reference list checking, limiting the search to published studies in English may have introduced bias. Appropriate methods were used to minimise error and bias in study selection and data extraction. The authors did not formally assess the included papers; however they do consider some quality elements.  Included studies were highly heterogeneous limiting the data available for regression analyses.

Citation: Van't Spijker A, Rodriguez JM, Kreulen CM, Bronkhorst EM, Bartlett DW, Creugers NH. Prevalence of tooth wear in adults. International Journal of Prosthodontics 2009; 22(1):35-42.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Prevention of early childhood caries: a review of literature published 1998-2007
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,DENTAL CARIES,PAEDIATRIC DENTISTRY,CAUSES & PREVENTION]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Author's conclusions: Although there is a body of evidence for the use of fluoride in preventing ECC, further high-quality studies are needed to further establish the best way to maintain oral health in infants.

Methods: A narrative systematic review of 22 studies (14 RCTs, 4 CCTs, 4 cohort studies, 1 case series) to consider recent evidence for the effectiveness of methods used for the prevention of early childhood caries.

Quality of review: The review is limited by the quality of the included studies.

It is likely that the author did not identify all potentially relevant studies. The search was limited to English only studies identified from a single database (PubMed) using highly restrictive search terms; this search supplemented by reference list checking. Searching additional databases using a comprehensive search strategy along with attempts to find unpublished research and grey literature may well have identified additional papers. No information is provided on the processes used to select, quality appraise and data extract included papers. Overall study quality was poor with over half rated as low quality and no studies rated as being of high quality.

Results: The results reinforced the role of fluoride toothpaste as the most cost-effective home-care measure and semi-annual fluoride varnish applications as the best professional method for infants at risk. The evidence concerning the preventive effect of antibacterial agents, primary-primary prevention and dental health education were inconclusive but the included studies supported the importance of early start, outreach activities and motivational interviewing as key factors to overcome cultural and socioeconomic barriers.

Citation: Twetman S. Prevention of early childhood caries: a review of literature published 1998-2007. European Archives of Pediatric Dentistry, 2008; 9 (1): 12-18.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance.  You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Preventive intervention possibilities in radiotherapy- and chemotherapy-induced oral mucositis: results of meta-analyses
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORAL CANCER,ORAL INFECTIONS,ORAL MEDICINE,ORAL PATHOLOGY,ORAL RADIOLOGY,ORAL CARE FOR CANCER PATIENTS]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: To date, no single intervention completely prevents oral mucositis, so combined preventive therapy strategies seem to be required to ensure more successful outcomes.

Methods: Systematic review of 45 randomised controlled trials examining  interventions to prevent mucositis in cancer patients undergoing head and neck radiation, chemotherapy, or chemoradiation. Literature search from 1966 to 2004.

Quality of review: A reasonable attempt was made to locate all the relevant literature with searches in several databases (Medline, Embase and CINAHL), supplemented by a review of reference lists. Publication and language bias may have been introduced though as only English language papers were included and it is  not clear whether unpublished research was sought.  No formal methods for critically appraising studies is reported, however the discussion includes some review of study quality.  The authors comment that most studies had small sample sizes and lacked double-blinding or placebo control. They note that only one of the 14 included studies was a large, multi-centre, double-blind randomised trial and point to the need for further research with well-designed studies.

Results: The meta-analyses included 45 studies fulfilling the inclusion criteria, in which 8 different interventions were evaluated: i.e., local application of chlorhexidine; iseganan; PTA (polymyxin E, tobramycine, and amphotericin B); granulocyte macrophage-colony-stimulating factor/granulocyte colony-stimulating factor (GM-CSF/G-CSF); oral cooling; sucralfate and glutamine; and systemic administration of amifostine and GM-CSF/G-CSF.

Four interventions showed a significant preventive effect on the development or severity of oral mucositis: PTA with an odds ratio (OR) = 0.61 (95% confidence interval [CI], 0.39–0.96); GM-CSF, OR = 0.53 (CI: 0.33–0.87); oral cooling, OR = 0.3 (CI: 0.16–0.56); and amifostine, OR = 0.37 (CI: 0.15–0.89).

Citation: Stokman MA, Spijkervet FKL, Boezen HM, Schouten JP, Roodenburg JLN, de Vries EGE. Preventive intervention possibilities in radiotherapy- and chemotherapy-induced oral mucositis: results of meta-analyses. Journal of Dental Research 2006; 85(8) 690-700

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. Full text online access is available to NHS staff in England via ATHENS passwords. To apply for an ATHENS password and access this resource and many others please go to the ATHENS registration page. 

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Principles of patient consent
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,INTRODUCTION TO PPI,PPI IN PRACTICE,TECHNIQUES,SERVICE DELIVERY,POLICY,COLLECTIVE INVOLVEMENT,SERVICE ORGANISATION AND DELIVERY OF CARE]]>
document.body:
This guidance explains the following principles in getting consent.

  1. Informed consent - the patient has enough information to make a decision.
  2. Voluntary decision-making - the patient has made the decision.
  3. Ability - the patient has the ability to make an informed decision.

If you are the member of the dental team providing the treatment, it is your responsibility to discuss it with the patient and get their consent, as you will have a thorough understanding of the procedure or treatment, how it is carried out and any risks attached to it. If it is not practical for you to get consent, you may ask someone else to do this for you, but you must make sure that they: are suitably trained and qualified; know enough about the planned treatment; understand the risks involved; and follow the principles explained in this booklet.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Probing pressure, a highly undervalued unit of measure in periodontal probing: a systematic review on its effect on probing pocket depth
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,PERIODONTOLOGY,TREATMENT & MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: The results of the present review show that with increasing probing pressure, the probing pocket depth (PPD) increases. The dimensions of the increase are dependent on the periodontal tissue conditions. PPD showed a mean increase of 0.004 mm per increase of 1 N/cm2 at diseased sites and 0.002 mm at healthy/treated sites. Both can be used as a correction factor for the comparison of outcomes of studies that have used different probing pressures.

Methods: A systematic review of five studies (2 RCTs, 3 CCTs) to determine the effect of different probing pressures on the recorded PPD. Database search to June 2008.

Quality of review: It is possible that potentially relevant studies were missed as the authors searched only two databases supplemented by reference list checking. The search was restricted to published studies in the English language which may have introduced bias. Appropriate methods were used to minimise error and bias in selecting studies for inclusion. The processes used to data extract and quality assess included studies is unclear. The authors assessed studies for risk of bias but did not score them. 

Results: In all instances, a higher probing pressure resulted in an increase in PPD.

Citation: Larsen C, Barendregt DS, Slot DE, Van der Velden U, Van der Weijden F. Probing pressure, a highly undervalued unit of measure in periodontal probing: a systematic review on its effect on probing pocket depth. Journal of Clinical Periodontology 2009 Apr;36(4):315-22.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Prognostic significance of vascular endothelial growth factor immunohistochemical expression in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma: a meta-analysis.
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,ORAL CANCER,PROGNOSIS]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: This meta-analysis showed that VEGF protein overexpression, as detected with immunohistochemistry, is associated with worse overall survival in patients with HNSCC. All studies, with one exception, had results in the same direction; a prognostic effect on mortality was seen also in the three largest studies; and VEGF expression had also a significant prognostic effect on HNSCC-specific mortality. However, results should be interpreted very cautiously. VEGF might be a potential prognostic marker in HNSCC, but associations with traditional prognostic factors such as clinical stage or differentiation may explain some of its prognostic effect. Moreover, the strength of the association was significantly smaller in larger studies. This may signify publication bias against the dissemination of ‘‘negative’’ results.

Methods: A systematic review and meta-analysis of 17 retrospective observational studies (1,287 patients). Database searches to July 2004.

Quality of review: As the authors state, the results of this review should be interpreted very cautiously. The results are based on retrospective studies and the strength of the association varies inversely with sample size.

The authors searched several databases without language restrictions, supplemented by reference list checking, hand searching and contacting experts. The search terms used were restrictive and it is possible that a wider range of terms might have identified additional studies. Whilst data extraction methods minimised the introduction of error and bias, no information is provided on how studies were selected, nor was there any formal process used to assess the quality of included studies. The possibility of error and bias having been introduced cannot be excluded. The authors do consider some quality issues, including sample size and adjustments for confounders.

Results: The estimated risk of death in 2 years was 1.88-fold higher in the VEGF-positive patients [95% confidence interval, 1.43-2.45; P < 0.001 random effect calculations]. Between-study heterogeneity was nonsignificant (P = 0.15) but larger studies tended to provide more conservative estimates (P = 0.097). VEGF overexpression was not significantly associated with the presence of lymph node metastasis (risk ratio, 1.20; 95% confidence interval, 0.97-1.49; P = 0.087) and there was significant between-study heterogeneity (P = 0.08).

Citation: Kyzas PA, Cunha IW, Ioannidis JPA. Prognostic significance of vascular endothelial growth factor immunohistochemical expression in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma: a meta-analysis. Clinical Cancer Research 2005;11:1434-40.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Promoting oral health: interventions for preventing dental caries, oral and pharyngeal cancers, and sports-related craniofacial injuries
document.publisher: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,DENTAL CARIES,DENTAL INJURIES,ORAL CANCER,DENTAL PUBLIC HEALTH,ENT AND AUDIOLOGY,CONDITIONS,PREVENTION,SCREENING,HEAD & NECK CANCER]]>
document.body:
Aims: To formulate recommendations for selected population-based interventions to prevent and control dental caries, oral (mouth) and pharyngeal (throat) cancers, and sports related craniofacial injuries

Recommendations: The Task Force on Community Preventive Services (the Task Force) strongly recommends community water fluoridation and school based or school linked pit and fissure sealant delivery programs for prevention and control of dental caries.

Using the rules of evidence it has established, the Task Force found insufficient evidence of effectiveness or ineffectiveness of the remaining interventions reviewed. Therefore, the Task Force makes no recommendation for or against use of statewide or communitywide sealant promotion programs, population based interventions for early detection of precancers and cancers, or population based interventions to encourage use of helmets, facemasks, and mouthguards to reduce oral-facial trauma in contact sports.

The Task Force's finding of insufficient evidence indicates the need for more research on intervention effectiveness. Until the results of such research become available, readers are encouraged to judge the usefulness of these interventions by other criteria.

Intended audience: Decision makers in state and local health departments, managed care organizations, purchasers of health care, persons responsible for funding public health programs, and others who have interest in or responsibility for improving oral and related general health in all segments of the population.

Methodology and Development Process: Evidence based guideline using a systematic review and appraisal of the evidence. Levels of evidence and the strength of the recommendations were graded. Development was carried out by a multidisciplinary, nationally representative team.

Publication history information: This guideline was published in November 2001. Available to the general public.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Prophylactic gastrostomy tubes in head and neck cancer patients - a time out project
document.publisher: Journal of Human Nutrition and Dietetics
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,ORAL CANCER,TREATMENT & MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Author's conclusions: The evidence suggests that prophylactic gastrostomy prior to cancer therapy offers some benefits; however, this evidence is based on retrospective studies with small sample sizes and flaws in study design. The studies reviewed do, however, tend to suggest that gastrostomy placement is a safe and effective method of delivering enteral nutrition, so, could be useful in patients at high risk of malnutrition. In order to minimize risks associated with gastrostomy placement, patients should be assessed adequately and skilled staff should perform the insertion procedure.

Methods: A narrative literature review of the use of feeding tubes in head and neck cancer patients undergoing cancer therapy. Database search dates: 1966 to February 2003.

Quality of review: The results of this review should be viewed with caution; as the author notes, there is a lack of high quality evidence. The review is presented in short form and methodological information is limited. It is likely that potentially relevant studies were missed as the search was limited to Medline and the Cochrane Database of Systematic reviews and further restricted English Language studies. The author does not indicate the process used to select, appraise and data extract included studies and the introduction of error and bias during these processes cannot be excluded. The author comments that the evidence is based on small scale retrospective studies.

Results: Studies showed that prophylactic gastrostomy
tubes in HNC patients undergoing cancer treatment can offer the following advantages: (i) a significantly reduced incidence of weight loss, (ii) significantly fewer nutritionrelated hospital admissions when compared to controls and (iii) potentially fewer treatment interruptions. No randomized trial has conclusively demonstrated improved local control or survival as a result of nutritional intervention before or during radiotherapy. Most studies reviewed concluded that gastrostomy placement in HNC patients was a safe and effective way to maintain nutritional status but acknowledged that there were some complications associated with placement.

Citation: Huston J. Prophylactic gastrostomy tubes in head and neck cancer patients - a time out project. Journal of Human Nutrition and Dietetics 2004 17(6) 577-578

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Randomised trial of the psychological effect of information about oral cancer in primary care settings
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,DENTAL PUBLIC HEALTH]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: The influence of an information leaflet appeared to have a positive effect on anxiety level and intentions to agree to receive an oral cancer screen.

Methods: Randomised controlled trial to determine the influence of a patient information leaflet (PIL) on the intention to have a screen for oral cancer, and associated anxiety, in primary care settings. 800 patients from 14 general practices (8 dental and 6 medical) in the North West of England were allocated to either the experimental group (PIL provided) or control (no leaflet). All participants completed a questionaire assessing knowledge of oral cancer, intention to screen and anxiety.

Quality of study: This is a multicentre study conducted in a large patient sample.  However, it only measures short-term effects.  It does not measure knowledge prior to the leaflet being provided, although there is a control group.  The method of randomisation is unclear and there are more women in the PIL group.

Results: Patients who had read the oral cancer PIL demonstrated an increase in their intention to have a screen (p<0.001) and reduced anxiety (p<0.05). Subjective risk was not elevated by the extra information. Intention to have a screen was predicted by knowledge level and anxiety (odds ratios: 1.10 and 0.70 respectively, both p's<0.001).

Citation: Humphris GM, Ireland RS, Field EA. Randomised trial of the psychological effect of information about oral cancer in primary care settings. Oral Oncology 2001; 7: 548-552  

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled comparison of the analgesic efficacy of oxycodone 10 mg/acetaminophen 325 mg versus controlled-release oxycodone 20 mg in postsurgical pain.
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORAL SURGERY,IMPACTED THIRD MOLARS,POSTOPERATIVE PAIN RELIEF]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: This new formulation offers the combination of two analgesic drugs with complementary mechanisms of action, which results in enhanced analgesia, an "opioid-sparing" effect, and an improved side effect and safety profile.

Method: A double-blind randomised controlled trial of 150 patients (age 16 to 60 years) with moderate to severe persistant acute pain following oral (molar) surgery. Patients were allocated to receive oxycodone 10mg/acetaminophen 325mg, CR oxycodone 20mg, and placebo.

Quality of study: The follow-up period was of 6 hours may not have been long enough to observe all of the outcomes, but is standard for the dental pain model. 

Results: Combination agent and CR oxycodone were significantly superior to placebo for all efficacy measures. Combination agent was statistically superior to CR oxycodone in four of five outcome measures of pain intensity and pain relief. It also provided a faster onset (>6:00 [h:min], 95%CI 1:45 to >6:00; p<0.05) and 24% reduction in the number of patients reporting treatment-related adverse events compared with twice the dose of opioid alone.

Citation: Gammaitoni AR, Galer BS, Bulloch S et al. Randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled comparison of the analgesic efficacy of oxycodone 10mg/acetaminophen 325 mg versus controlled-release oxycodone 20 mg in postsurgical pain. Journal of Clinical Pharmacology 2003; 43(3): 296-304.
