document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Rapid palatal expansion effects on nasal airway dimensions as measured by acoustic rhinometry . A systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORTHODONTICS]]>
document.body:
This is a provisional record for information. The review has been identified as potentially meeting our quality criteria. It will be critically appraised and a quality statement provided as soon as possible.

Objective: To evaluate available information on the effects of rapid maxillary expansion on nasal airway minimal cross-sectional area and volume, as measured by acoustic rhinometry.

Materials and Methods: An electronic database search was conducted. Based on abstracts/titles, articles were initially selected; then full articles were retrieved and were further sorted according to secondary, more stringent criteria. References from selected articles were hand-searched for potential missed publications. Clinical trials using acoustic rhinometry on subjects undergoing rapid maxillary expansion therapy were included. Syndromic or medically compromised patients and absence of an untreated control group were reasons for exclusion. Selected studies thereafter were evaluated methodologically.

Results: Only four articles reached final selection, and their overall methodology scores were low, limiting the applicability of results. After rapid maxillary expansion, three of four studies found statistically significant increases in minimal cross-sectional area, and two of three studies reported statistically significant increases in nasal cavity volume as compared with control groups. It appears that any increase is less stable if a traditional technique is used on patients who have passed their peak growth spurt.

Conclusions: Although some increases in nasal dimensions have been reported, the changes in nasal volume were small and should not be presented to patients as a clinically significant indication for therapeutic maxillary expansion.

Citation: Gordon GM, Rosenblatt M, Witmans M, Carey JP, Heo G, Major PW, Flores-Mir C. Rapid palatal expansion effects on nasal airway dimensions as measured by acoustic rhinometry . A systematic review.  Angle Orthodontist 2009; 79:1000-1007.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Rapid palatal expansion effects on nasal airway dimensions as measured by acoustic rhinometry. A systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORTHODONTICS]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors’ conclusions: Although some increases in nasal dimensions have been reported, the changes in nasal volume are small and should not be presented to patients as a clinically significant indication for therapeutic maxillary expansion. 

  • Rapid maxillary expansion (RME) should not be encouraged as a treatment option for individuals with reduced minimum cross-sectional area (MCA) without an orthodontic indication. In cases with an orthodontic treatment need, nasal cavity changes are expected; however their clinical significance is questionable.
  • Variability has been noted; therefore, for a given individual patient, the change may be significant.
  • Given the current limited quality of evidence, it is encouraged that future studies overcome the identified limitations in an effort to support related conclusions with stronger methodologic quality.

Methods: A narrative systematic review of four non-randomised controlled trials of the effects of RME on nasal airway minimal cross-sectional area and volume. Literature search to August 2008.

Quality of review: As acknowledged by the authors, the quality of the included studies, limits the reliability and applicability of the results.

A reasonable attempt was made to identify relevant published evidence, including a search of several databases, reference list checking and the inclusion of non English language papers. Unpublished research was not sought, which may have introduced publication bias. The authors were unable to obtain the full text of three potentially relevant papers, so these studies were not included.

Results: Only four articles were eligible and their overall methodology scores were low, limiting the applicability of results.  After RME, three of four studies found statistically significant increases in minimal cross-sectional area, and two of three studies reported statistically significant increases in nasal cavity volume as compared with control groups. It appears that any increase is less stable if a traditional technique is used on patients who have passed their peak growth spurt.

Citation: Gordon JM, Rosenblatt M, Witmans M et al. Rapid palatal expansion effects on nasal airway dimensions as measured by acoustic rhinometry. A systematic review. Angle Orthodontist 2009; 79:1000-1007.

Access: The full text of this paper is freely available.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Recommendations for using fluoride to prevent and control dental caries in the United States
document.publisher: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
document.topics: <![CDATA[ OUTCOMES,ORAL HEALTH DISORDERS,POPULATION BASED & PREVENTATIVE SERVICES,HEALTH PROTECTION,ORAL DISORDERS,ORAL HEALTH,DENTAL CARIES,DENTAL PUBLIC HEALTH,CAUSES & PREVENTION,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PUBLIC HEALTH,MANAGEMENT & INTERVENTIONS,SERVICES,INTERNATIONAL ISSUES,GEOGRAPHY,SETTINGS,DENTAL HEALTH,DENTAL DECAY,DENTAL CARIES]]>
document.body:
Aims: To make recommendations to guide dental and other health-care providers, public health officials, policy makers, and the public in the use of fluoride to achieve maximum protection against dental caries while using resources efficiently and reducing the likelihood of enamel fluorosis.

Recommendations: Before promoting a fluoride modality or combination of modalities, the dental-care or other health-care provider must consider a person's or group's risk for dental caries, current use of other fluoride sources, and potential for enamel fluorosis. Although these recommendations are based on assessments of caries risk as low or high, the health-care provider might also differentiate among patients at high risk and provide more intensive interventions as needed. Also, a risk category can change over time; the type and frequency of preventive interventions should be adjusted accordingly.

Please view the full guideline for the complete list of recommendations, including information on:

  • Fluoridation of community drinking water
  • Counselling parents and caregivers regarding use of fluoride toothpaste by young children
  • Mouth-rinsing to persons at high risk
  • Fluoride supplements
  • High concentration products to persons at high risk
  • Supervised use of fluoride toothpaste among young children

Intended Audience: Advanced practice nurses. allied health personnel, dentists, nurses, patients, physician assistants, physicians, public health departments. Although the recommendations were developed specifically for the United States, aspects of this report could be relevant to other countries.

Methodology and Development Process: Evidence based guideline adapting U.S. Preventive Services Task Force criteria to grade the quality of scientific evidence and strength of the recommendations. Development was carried out by a multidisciplinary, nationally representative group. 

Publication history information: The guideline was published in 2001.

Access: Available to the general public

 

 

 

 

 

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Recurrence related to treatment modalities of unicystic ameloblastoma: a systematic review
document.publisher: International Journal of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORAL SURGERY,ORAL CYSTS]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: there is weak evidence showing that resection resulted in the lowest recurrence rate, followed by enucleation with application of Carnoy's solution. Enucleation alone resulted in the highest recurrence rate, and treatment by marsupialization could not be sufficiently evaluated since most cases were followed by a second stage surgery of some kind.

Methods: A review of six retrospective studies to determine which treatment for unicystic meloblastoma results in the lowest recurrence rate?.  Literature search date not reported. 

Quality of review: A reasonable attempt was made to identify published and unpublished literature. Several databases were searched, journals hand searched and experts contacted, without any language restrictions. Two independent reviewers selected and assessed papers for inclusion.

However, there are some concerns over the statistical methods used. The six studies had a total of 132 cases of unicystic ameloblastoma. The authors report that whenever possible, cases where patients were lost to follow-up, or when the individual follow-up period was less than 5 years without a recurrence, were deleted. This left a total of 100 patients for whom data was retrievable. However there is no rationale provided for the deletions. Furthermore the review is limited by the low levels of evidence available.

Results: Four treatment modalities for unicystic ameloblastomas were identified. The recurrence rates were 3.6% for resection, 30.5% for enucleation alone, 16% for enucleation followed by application of Carnoy's solution and 18% for marsupialization with/without other treatment in a second phase.

Citation: Lau SL, Samman N. Recurrence related to treatment modalities of unicystic ameloblastoma: a systematic review. International Journal of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery 2006; 35(8):681-90.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Relationship between bruxism and temporomandibular disorders: a systematic review of literature from 1998 to 2008
document.publisher: Oral Surgery, Oral Medicine, Oral Pathology, Oral Radiology, and Endodontics
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,DENTO-FACIAL ANOMALIES]]>
document.body:
This is a provisional record for information. The review has been identified as potentially meeting our quality criteria. It will be critically appraised and a quality statement provided as soon as possible.
_____________________________________________________

Objectives: The present paper aims to systematically review the literature on the temporomandibular disorders (TMD)-bruxism relationship published from 1998 to 2008.

Study design: A systematic search in the National Library of Medicine's PubMed database was performed to identify all studies on humans assessing the relationship between TMD symptoms and bruxism diagnosed with any different approach. The selected articles were assessed independently by the 2 authors according to a structured reading of articles format (PICO).

Results: A total of 46 articles were included for discussion in the review and grouped into questionnaire/self-report (n = 21), clinical assessment (n = 7), experimental (n = 7), tooth wear (n = 5), polysomnographic (n = 4), or electromyographic (n = 2) studies. In several studies, the level of evidence was negatively influenced by a low level of specificity for the assessment of the bruxism-TMD relationship, because of the low prevalence of severe TMD patients in the studied samples and because of the use of self-report diagnosis of bruxism with some potential diagnostic bias.

Conclusions: Investigations based on self-report or clinical bruxism diagnosis showed a positive association with TMD pain, but they are characterized by some potential bias and confounders at the diagnostic level (eg, pain as a criterion for bruxism diagnosis). Studies based on more quantitative and specific methods to diagnose bruxism showed much lower association with TMD symptoms. Anterior tooth wear was not found to be a major risk factor for TMD. Experimental sustained jaw clenching may provoke acute muscle tenderness, but it is not analogous to myogenous TMD pain, so such studies may not help clarify the clinical relationship between bruxism and TMD 

Citation: Manfredini D, Lobbezoo F. Relationship between bruxism and temporomandibular disorders: a systematic review of literature from 1998 to 2008. Oral Surgery, Oral Medicine, Oral Pathology, Oral Radiology, and Endodontics 2010; 109(6):e26-e50 

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Relationship between clinical and magnetic resonance imaging diagnoses and findings in degenerative and inflammatory temporomandibular joint diseases: a systematic literature review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,DENTO-FACIAL ANOMALIES]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors’ conclusions: The studies included in this review give no clear evidence of a relationship between a clinical diagnosis and an MRI diagnosis. And consistency concerning the relationship between clinical findings and MRI findings was limited. Some studies reported a relationship between pain and internal derangement, but odds ratios (ORs) were generally low. This review reveals a need for studies with improved quality in reporting of samples, examination techniques, findings, and definitions and rationales for cutoffs, categories, and diagnoses. We recommend that standardized protocols such as the Research Diagnostic Criteria for temporomandibular disorders (RDC/TMD) and the Standards for Reporting of Diagnostic Accuracy (STARD) statement be implemented in future studies.

Methods: A narrative systematic review of 23 studies (study types unclear) to consider how a diagnosis derived from patient history and clinical examination compares to a diagnosis derived from MRI in patients with TMJ disc displacement or (osteo)arthrosis? Database search dates 1988-2007 inclusive.

Quality of review:  As the authors note, there are insufficient data on which to base firm conclusions. It is likely that potentially relevant studies were missed as the authors searched only PubMed with limited search terms, supplemented by reference list checking.  The potential for bias was further increased by restricting inclusion to English language published studies. Appropriate methods were used to minimise error and bias in study selection and data extraction. The authors used a modified version of the QUADAS tool. Unfortunately, some key questions that address bias were omitted (interpretation of results, study withdrawals).

Results: Several studies reported a relationship between clinical pain and internal derangements diagnosed with MRI, but the calculated odds ratio (OR) for this relationship was generally low (1.54-2.04). ORs for the relationship between pain and disc displacement without reduction (4.82) or between crepitation and disc displacement without reduction (3.71) were higher.

Citation: Koh KJ, List T, Petersson A, Rohlin M. Relationship between clinical and magnetic resonance imaging diagnoses and findings in degenerative and inflammatory temporomandibular joint diseases: a systematic literature review. Journal of Orofacial Pain 2009 Spring;23(2):123-39.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Relationship between sponsorship and failure rate of dental implants: a systematic approach
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,RESTORATIVE DENTISTRY]]>
document.body:
This is a provisional record for information. The review has been identified as potentially meeting our quality criteria. It will be critically appraised and a quality statement provided as soon as possible.
_____________________________________________________

Background: The number of dental implant treatments increases annually. Dental implants are manufactured by competing companies. Systematic reviews and meta-analysis have shown a clear association between pharmaceutical industry funding of clinical trials and pro-industry results. So far, the impact of industry sponsorship on the outcomes and conclusions of dental implant clinical trials has never been explored. The aim of the present study was to examine financial sponsorship of dental implant trials, and to evaluate whether research funding sources may affect the annual failure rate.

Methods: A systematic approach was used to identify systematic reviews published between January 1993 and December 2008 that specifically deal with the length of survival of dental implants. Primary articles were extracted from these reviews. The failure rate of the dental implants included in the trials was calculated. Data on publication year, Impact Factor, prosthetic design, periodontal status reporting, number of dental implants included in the trials, methodological quality of the studies, presence of a statistical advisor, and financial sponsorship were extracted by two independent reviewers (kappa = 0.90; CI(95%) [0.77-1.00]). Univariate quasi-Poisson regression models and multivariate analysis were used to identify variables that were significantly associated with failure rates.

Results: Five systematic reviews were identified from which 41 analyzable trials were extracted. The mean annual failure rate estimate was 1.09%.(CI(95%) [0.84-1.42]). The funding source was not reported in 63% of the trials (26/41). Sixty-six percent of the trials were considered as having a risk of bias (27/41). Given study age, both industry associated (OR = 0.21; CI(95%) [0.12-0.38]) and unknown funding source trials (OR = 0.33; (CI(95%) [0.21-0.51]) had a lower annual failure rates compared with non-industry associated trials. A conflict of interest statement was disclosed in 2 trials.

Conclusions: When controlling for other factors, the probability of annual failure for industry associated trials is significantly lower compared with non-industry associated trials. This bias may have significant implications on tooth extraction decision making, research on tooth preservation, and governmental health care policies 

Citation: Popelut A, Valet F, Fromentin O, Thomas A, Bouchard P, Popelut A et al. Relationship between sponsorship and failure rate of dental implants: a systematic approach. PLoS ONE 2010; 5(4):e10274

Access: Full-text online access of this paper is freely available.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Reliability of physical examination for diagnosis of myofascial trigger points: a systematic review of the literature
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORO-FACIAL PAIN,ORAL MEDICINE]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

_____________________________________________________

 

Authors' conclusions: No study to date has reported the reliability of trigger point diagnosis according to the currently proposed criteria. On the basis of the limited number of studies available, and significant problems with their design, reporting, statistical integrity, and clinical applicability, physical examination cannot currently be recommended as a reliable test for the diagnosis of trigger points. The reliability of trigger point diagnosis needs to be further investigated with studies of high quality that use current diagnostic criteria in clinically relevant patients

Methods: A systematic review summarize evidence on the reliability of physical examination for the diagnosis of painful trigger points (TPs). Database search dates: inception to March 2008.

Quality of review: Generally a well-conducted and well reported review. A good attempt was made to identify relevant research via a broad range of databases, citation tracking, handsearching textbooks and journals, and contacting experts. It is possible that using broader or plural versions of search terms may have identified further studies. Included studies were selected, data extracted and critically appraised in duplicate to minimise bias and inaccuracy. It is unclear whether unpublished or non-English language papers were eligible for inclusion in the review.

Results: Nine studies were eligible for inclusion. None satisfied all quality and applicability criteria. No study specifically reported reliability for the identification of the location of active trigger points in the muscles of symptomatic participants. Reliability estimates varied widely for each diagnostic sign, for each muscle, and across each study. Reliability estimates were generally higher for subjective signs such as tenderness ([kappa] range, 0.22-1.0) and pain reproduction ([kappa] range, 0.57-1.00), and lower for objective signs such as the taut band ([kappa] range, -0.08-0.75) and local twitch response ([kappa] range, -0.05-0.57).

Citation: Lucas N, Macaskill P, Irwig L, Moran R, Bogduk N. Reliability of physical examination for diagnosis of myofascial trigger points: a systematic review of the literature. Clinical Journal of Pain. 2009 Jan;25(1):80-9.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Restoration of class II cavities in primary molar teeth with conventional and resin modified glass ionomer cements: a systematic review of the literature
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,DENTAL CARIES,PAEDIATRIC DENTISTRY,RESTORATIVE DENTISTRY,TREATMENT & MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Glass ionomer cement (GIC) cannot be recommended for class II cavities in primary molars. There is evidence that resin modified glass ionomer cement (RMGIC) can perform successfully in small to moderate sized class II restorations.

Methods: A systematic review of 22 studies concerning the restoration of primary teeth with GIC or RMGIC used in conventional class II cavities.  Literature search 1966 - 2006.

Quality of review: While sound methods were used to select and assess the quality of included papers, the search strategy may have missed key studies. Only Medline and Embase were searched and reference lists of included studies checked. Extra databases, handsearching, grey literature sources and contacting experts may have located additional key studies. Furthermore, unpublished and non-English language papers were not included which may have introduced publication and language bias.
Heterogeneity between studies or whether it is possible to combine study results is not addressed by the authors.

Results: The search identified 411 papers, from which an application of the inclusion criteria yielded 20 studies. Of these, 2 were rated B1 and 18 B2. Failure rates varied from 6.6% to 60% for GIC, and from 2% to 24% for RMGIC.

Citation: Chadwick BL, Evans DJP. Restoration of class II cavities in primary molar teeth with conventional and resin modified glass ionomer cements: a systematic review of the literature. European Archives of Paediatric Dentistry 2007; 8(1): 14-21.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance.  You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Retention of resin-based pit and fissure sealants: A systematic review.
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,DENTAL CARIES,CAUSES & PREVENTION]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: The scarcity of well-conducted studies made judgement difficult, except for the isolation stage. If using a rubber dam did not affect retention of auto-polymerized resin-based sealants (RBSs), it did for fluoride-containing light-cured RBSs (RR = 2.03, 95% CI: 1.51–2.73).

Methods: A systematic review of 31 studies to identify the retention of of resin-based sealants according to the materials and clinical procedure used.  Studies comprised 3 RCTs, 4 CCTs, 21 split mouth RCTs and 4 split mouth CCTs.   

Quality of review:  A good attempt was made to identify all relevant research, using multiple databases, combined with manual searching, reference list checking and contacting authors of unpublished studies.  There were no language restrictions. Study assessment and quality appraisal were both independently assessed by two reviewers.  Included studies were assessed for quality using criteria identified in the Cochrane handbook. There was considerable overall heterogeneity, with the result that the authors conducted a number of sub-group analyses. Overall study quality was moderate to low and the authors stress that the results should be viewed with caution.

Results: The retention rate of auto-polymerized and light cured RBSs did not differ significantly. Light-cured RBSs had a significantly higher retention rate than fluoride-containing light-cured RBSs at 48 months (RR = 0.80, 95% CI: 0.72-0.89) and more.  

Citation: Muller-Bolla M, Lupi-Pegurier L, Tardieu C, Velly AM, Antomarchi C. Retention of resin-based pit and fissure sealants: A systematic review. Community Dentistry And Oral Epidemiology 2006; 34(5): 321-36

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Reviews of evidence on interventions to prevent dental caries, oral and pharyngeal cancers, and sports-related craniofacial injuries
document.topics: <![CDATA[ BENIGN,MALIGNANT,LARYNX & PHARYNX DISORDERS,NEOPLASMS,ENT AND AUDIOLOGY,CONDITIONS,SCREENING,PREVENTION,OUTCOMES,ORAL CANCER,CANCER,ORAL HEALTH DISORDERS,INJURIES,SPORTS INJURIES,POPULATION BASED & PREVENTATIVE SERVICES,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,DENTAL CARIES,DENTAL PUBLIC HEALTH,DENTAL INJURIES,ORAL CANCER,ORAL MEDICINE,ORAL SURGERY,ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,PUBLIC HEALTH,MANAGEMENT & INTERVENTIONS,SERVICES,RESEARCH METHODS,METHODS,ANALYSIS & RESEARCH,DENTAL HEALTH,DENTAL CARIES,DENTAL DECAY,HEAD & NECK CANCER]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: This collection of reviews forms the basis for extensive recommendations by the US Task Force on Community Preventive Services about the use of selected interventions intended to prevent or control dental caries, oral and pharyngeal cancers, and sports-related craniofacial injuries.

Methods: a report of systematic reviews of effectiveness, applicability, other positive and negative effects, economic evaluations, and barriers to use of five selected population-based interventions:

  • Community water fluoridation (CWF);
  • School-based sealant delivery programmes; 
  • Community-wide sealant promotion programmes;
  • Cancer awareness and screening programmes, and
  • Promoting the use of dental and craniofacial protectors in contact sports.

Included study designs ranged from cross-sectional surveys to randomised trials and diagnostic test accuracy studies. Papers were sought up to 2000.

Quality of reviews: Only English language articles were included. Authors’ conclusion stating there was strong evidence that water fluoridation was effective in reducing dental caries within communities should be viewed with caution since the included studies varied by design (none of which were RCTs), levels of analysis, measures of dental caries occurrence, differences in the fluoride concentrations being compared, and the direction of change in exposure to water fluoridation over time. Heterogeneity was not assessed formally.

Results: The results of individual studies on each intervention were displayed in tabular format and as figures, and the median and range of the effect measures were reported. The strength of the body of evidence was summarised on the basis of the numbers of available studies, the strength of their design and execution, and the size and consistency of the reported effects.  

Citation: Truman BI, Gooch BF, Sulemana I, Gift HC, Horowitz AM, Evans CA, Griffin SO, Carande-Kulis VG; Task Force on Community Preventive Services. Reviews of evidence on interventions to prevent dental caries, oral and pharyngeal cancers, and sports-related craniofacial injuries. American Journal of Preventive Medicine. 2002;23(1 Suppl):21-54. 

Access: Full-text online access of this article is freely available via the link above.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Risk factors for dental caries in young children: a systematic review of the literature
document.topics: <![CDATA[ OUTCOMES,ENVIRONMENTAL,RISK FACTORS,ORAL HEALTH DISORDERS,CHILDREN,ORAL DISORDERS,ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,DENTAL CARIES,PAEDIATRIC DENTISTRY,DENTAL PUBLIC HEALTH,CAUSES & PREVENTION,PUBLIC HEALTH,DETERMINANTS,METHODS,RESEARCH METHODS,ANALYSIS & RESEARCH,POPULATIONS,GROUPS,AGE GROUPS,DENTAL HEALTH]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors conclusions: There is a shortage of high quality studies using the optimum study design - a longitudinal study. The evidence suggests that children are most likely to develop caries if Streptococcus Muttans is acquired at an early age, although this may be partly compensated by other factors such as good oral hygiene and a non-cariogenic diet. Diet and oral hygiene may interact so that if there is a balance of 'good' habits by way of maintaining good plaque control and 'bad' habits by way of having a cariogenic diet, the development of caries may be controlled.

Methods: Systematic review of 73 studies (41 cross-sectional, 19 cohort, 6 case control and 7 interventional) investigating risk factors for dental caries in deciduous teeth of children aged six years and under.

Quality of review: The limited search strategy may have failed to identify relevant studies. Although there were no language restrictions, only PubMed was searched using limited search terms. There was no reference list checking or handsearching and a failure to seek unpublished research may have resulted in publication bias. The authors used predefined criteria to assess the validity of the included studies.

Results: 106 risk factors were significantly related to the prevalence or incidence of caries.

Citation: Harris R, Nicoll AD, Adair PM, Pine CM. Risk factors for dental caries in young children: a systematic review of the literature. Community Dental Health 2004; 21 (supplement): 71-85.

Access: Full-text online access of this article is available.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Risk perception of oral cancer in smokers attending primary care: a randomised controlled trial
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORAL CANCER,DENTAL PUBLIC HEALTH,PREVENTION,RISK FACTORS]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: The study found a clear benefit of the patient information leaflet (PIL) on patients' oral cancer knowledge, particularly in smokers and those with a history of smoking. The findings demonstrate that public awareness of smokers can be raised with written information although health beliefs such as risk perceptions require more intensive intervention.

Methods: A multi-centred randomised controlled clinical trial involving 967 patients attending 20 general dental practices in Northern Ireland.

Experimental participants were given a patient information leaflet (PIL), and then completed a self-report questionnaire following the return of the leaflet. The PIL outlined symptoms and risks of oral cancer, prevalence and mortality rates, and behaviours to reduce risk and promote early detection. Control participants only completed the questionnaire and did not receive the PIL.

Measures included a 36 item oral cancer knowledge scale and two items to assess risk perception.

Quality of study: A large study in which patients were randomised by session. Allocation was concealed via computer generated numbers.  The response rate was 97% and the data was analysed on an intention to treat basis.

Results: Risk perceptions of oral cancer were minimally effected by the PIL (p=0.023). This effect was demonstrable in smokers. Smokers were 16 (95% CI 8–30) times more likely to believe that they were at greater risk of oral cancer than non-smokers.

Citation: Humphris GM, Freeman R, Clarke HMM. Risk perception of oral cancer in smokers attending primary care: a randomised controlled trial. Oral Oncology 2004; 40: 916-924

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Risks and benefits of deliberate hypotension in anaesthesia: a systematic review
document.publisher: International Journal of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORAL SURGERY,ORTHODONTICS]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Hypotensive anaesthesia is most valuable in a lengthy operation where a large amount of blood loss and consequent blood transfusion are to be expected. Bimaxillary osteotomies, especially when more complicated procedures are involved, are a good indication for deliberate hypotension and possible avoidance of blood transfusion. Although there are certain risks associated with hypotensive anaesthesia, most orthognathic patients are young and fit and complications are rare. Thorough preoperative assessment and appropriate continuous monitoring are mandatory.

Methods: A narrative systematic review of 20 randomised controlled trials to determine whether deliberate hypotension should be used routinely during orthognathic surgery. Database search from 1966 to June 2007.

Quality of review: It is likely that the search missed potentially relevant studies as it was restricted to two databases using limited search terms, supplemented by reference list checking. Searching more databases, hand searching journals and consulting experts may have identified additional studies. In addition, restricting the search to published papers in the English language may have introduced publication and language biases. The authors do not describe the process used to select studies, assess their validity and extract data from included studies, although information is provided on the criteria used to assess bias as high, medium or low risk. Eight of the twenty studies were deemed to be of low risk (met at least 9/10 criteria). Where information was not available from low risk studies, the authors included data from studies at medium risk of bias which met at least 8/10 criteria.

Results: There is some evidence for a reduction in blood loss under hypotensive anaesthesia, but the magnitude of the effect is difficult to confirm from current evidence. Five studies showed reduction in blood loss, although two failed to show statistical significance. Data on transfusion rates under hypotensive anaesthesia versus normotensive anaesthesia were scarce. The criteria for transfusion often varied between different centres. Only two trials compared the transfusion rate between groups; both found a decrease in transfusion rate in patients receiving hypotensive anaesthesia. There was insufficient information to to make any conclusion about impact on the length of hospital stay. There is some evidence for an improved operative field. Two studies presented data about the quality of the surgical field during hypotensive anaesthesia based on an evaluation by surgeons blinded to treatment allocation. Both studies showed an improvement in the surgical field during induced hypotension. Most studies showed no decrease in cerebral blood flow, and even if there were a statistically significant reduction there was no evidence of a long-term adverse outcome clinically. One study showed no significant difference in cognitive test scores between patients receiving normotensive and hypotensive anaesthesia. Based on the best current evidence, deliberate hypotension seems to cause no additional adverse effect on the cardiovascular system. Renal effects: urine flow was shown to decrease during induced hypotension, and but returned to normal after anaesthesia based on the best current available evidence. Two studies with the lowest risk of bias failed to demonstrate any change in standard liver enzyme markers in the hypotensive group. Since many authors only investigated the effect  on normal healthy patients, there is insufficient evidence showing the safety of of induced hypotension in patients with pre-existing impaired function of major organs.

Citation: Choi WS, Samman N. Risks and benefits of deliberate hypotension in anaesthesia: a systematic review. International Journal of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery, 2008; 37 (8): 687-703

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Role of different imaging modalities in assessment of temporomandibular joint erosions and osteophytes: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,DENTO-FACIAL ANOMALIES]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors’ conclusions: Axially corrected sagittal tomography is currently the imaging modality of choice for diagnosing erosions and osteophytes in the temporomandibular joint (TMJ). CT does not seem to add any significant information to what is obtained from axially corrected sagittal tomography. High-resolution ultrasound and cone beam CT (CBCT) might prove to be a cost- and radiation dose-effective alternative to axially corrected sagittal tomography. Combining different radiographic techniques is likely to be more accurate in diagnosing erosions and osteophytes in the TMJ than using a single imaging modality. Diagnostic studies that simultaneously evaluate all of the available TMJ imaging technologies are needed.

Methods: A narrative systematic review of nine diagnostic studies to determine the ability of different imaging techniques to diagnose the presence of erosions and osteophytes in the temporomandibular joint. Database search from inception to November 2006. Note: the abstract states that the Lilacs database was searched, but this is not evident from the full text of the paper.

Quality of review: A range of databases were searched without language restrictions, supplemented by reference list checking. It is possible potentially relevant papers were missed as the search terms used were limited and only published studies were included. Appropriate procedures were used to minimise error and bias in study selection, data extraction and quality assessment. The authors used the QUADAS tool to determine the quality of the included studies; all of which shared a similarly high score of ~ 80 percent. All the included studies used autopsy specimens, which the authors state “precludes information regarding clinical signs and symptoms of TMD and generalizability of the results.”

Citation: Hussain AM, Packota G, Major PW, Flores-Mir C. Role of different imaging modalities in assessment of temporomandibular joint erosions and osteophytes: a systematic review. Dentomaxillofacial Radiology, 2008; 37: 63-71

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. 

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Root resorption associated with orthodontic tooth movement: a systematic review
document.publisher: American Journal of Orthodontics and Dentofacial Orthopedics
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORTHODONTICS]]>
document.body:
This is a provisional record for information. The review has been identified as potentially meeting our quality criteria. It will be critically appraised and a quality statement provided as soon as possible.
_____________________________________________________

Introduction: This systematic review evaluated root resorption as an outcome for patients who had orthodontic tooth movement. The results could provide the best available evidence for clinical decisions to minimize the risks and severity of root resorption.

Methods: Electronic databases were searched, nonelectronic journals were hand searched, and experts in the field were consulted with no language restrictions. Study selection criteria included randomized clinical trials involving human subjects for orthodontic tooth movement, with fixed appliances, and root resorption recorded during or after treatment. Two authors independently reviewed and extracted data from the selected studies on a standardized form.

Results: The searches retrieved 921 unique citations. Titles and abstracts identified 144 full articles from which 13 remained after the inclusion criteria were applied. Differences in the methodologic approaches and reporting results made quantitative statistical comparisons impossible. Evidence suggests that comprehensive orthodontic treatment causes increased incidence and severity of root resorption, and heavy forces might be particularly harmful. Orthodontically induced inflammatory root resorption is unaffected by archwire sequencing, bracket prescription, and self-ligation. Previous trauma and tooth morphology are unlikely causative factors. There is some evidence that a 2 to 3 month pause in treatment decreases total root resorption.

Conclusions: The results were inconclusive in the clinical management of root resorption, but there is evidence to support the use of light forces, especially with incisor intrusion 

Citation: Weltman B, Vig KW, Fields HW, Shanker S, Kaizar EE. Root resorption associated with orthodontic tooth movement: a systematic review. American Journal of Orthodontics & Dentofacial Orthopedics 2010; 137(4):462-476

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Saliva substitutes for the treatment of radiation-induced xerostomia - a review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORAL CANCER,TREATMENT & MANAGEMENT,SPECIAL CARE DENTISTRY,CANCER PATIENTS]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Note:extracted data refer only to results of clinical use in patients with radiation-induced xerostomia

Authors' conclusions: The findings suggest that there are significant differences in the performance of various saliva substitutes.  Further studies are necessary.

Methods: A narrative systematic review of 16 clinical studies (excluding data from 36 in vitro studies) to consider the clinical acceptance and performance in patients with radiation-induced xerostomia and hyposalivation.

Quality of review: The results and conclusions of this review should be viewed with caution.  The overall quality of the 16 included clinical studies was poor.

It is likely that potentially relevant studies were missed as only PubMed was searched with highly restrictive search terms, supplemented by reference list checking. The search was limited to published papers in the English language which may have introduced additional bias. The methods used to select and data extract studies are unclear and the introduction of error and bias in these processes cannot be excluded. The Jadad Scale was used to assess quality which was poor. Only one study appears to have been of low risk of bias. 

Citation: Hahnel S, Behr M, Handel G, Bürgers R. Saliva substitutes for the treatment of radiation-induced xerostomia--a review. Supportive Care in Cancer 2009 Nov;17(11):1331-43

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Self-ligating brackets in orthodontics
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORTHODONTICS]]>
document.body:
This is a provisional record for information. The review has been identified as potentially meeting our quality criteria. It will be critically appraised and a quality statement provided as soon as possible.
_____________________________________________________

 

Authors' conclusions: At this stage there is insufficient high-quality evidence to support the use of self-ligating fixed orthodontic appliances over conventional appliance systems or vice versa.

Methods: A systematic review of 27 studies (6 RCTs and 11 CCTs) to evaluate the clinical differences in relation to the use of self-ligating brackets in orthodontics.

Results: Meta-analysis of the influence of bracket type on subjective pain experience failed to demonstrate a significant advantage for either type of appliance. Statistical analysis of other outcomes was unfeasible because of inadequate methodological design and heterogenous designs.

Citation: Fleming PS, Johal A. Self-ligating brackets in orthodontics. Angle Orthodontist 2010 May;80(3):575-84.

Access: Full text of this paper is freely available.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Sentinel node biopsy in squamous cell cancer of the oral cavity and oral pharynx: a diagnostic meta-analysis
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,ORAL CANCER,ENT AND AUDIOLOGY,LARYNX & PHARYNX DISORDERS,NEOPLASMS,MALIGNANT,CONDITIONS,DIAGNOSIS & REFERRAL,HEAD & NECK CANCER]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: The sentinel node biopsy procedure has shown high sensitivity rates in pilot studies for oral and oropharyngeal squamous cell cancer across the globe and is reliable and reproducible. This study provides a firm evidence base for forthcoming trials on the role of sentinel node biopsy in head and neck cancer.

Methods: Systematic review of 19 studies including 301 patients with oral cavity primary tumours and 46 patients with oropharyngeal primary tumours. Literature search to December 2003.

Quality of review: A good attempt was made to find all relevant research, using several databases, manual searching, reference list checking and contacting experts in the field.  No evidence of publication bias was found in the funnel plot and eligible papers were critically appraised by two reviewers independently.  The reporting of the individual study design and of the results of the included studies is limited.

Results: The pooled sensitivity result using the random effects model was 0.926 (95% confidence interval, 0.852-0.964). The cumulative payoff for the sentinel node biopsy arm was lower than that for the elective node dissection arm by about 1%. The payoffs were assigned for the recurrence and mortality rates only and did not take into account the morbidity caused by the procedures.

Citation: Paleri V, Rees G, Arullendran P, Shoaib T, Krishman S. Sentinel node biopsy in squamous cell cancer of the oral cavity and oral pharynx: A diagnostic meta-analysis. Head & Neck 2005; 27(9): 739-747

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Short-term anteroposterior treatment effects of functional appliances and extraoral traction on Class II malocclusion
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,DENTO-FACIAL ANOMALIES,ORTHODONTICS]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Intermaxillary changes being present in all appliance groups, anteroposterior treatment response following the use of functional appliances and/or extraoral traction in growing class II malocclusion patients is most evident in one of the two jaws (mandible for activators and combination appliances and maxilla for extraoral traction) except for the twin block group, which shows changes on both jaws.

Methods: A systematic review of 9 randomised controlled trials to evaluate the anteroposterior short-term skeletal and dental effects on Class II malocclusion in growing patients following treatment with functional appliances (activators or twin block), extraoral traction, or combination appliances (appliances with both functional and extraoral traction components). Literature search dates not provided.

Quality of review: A reasonable attempt was made to locate all relevant studies although some of the methods used are unclear due to poor reporting (eg authors state that OVID was searched – but not the databases they actually searched via this platform). The studies were heterogeneous which the authors tried to address in the combining the results with a random effects model for groups of interventions.

Results: All appliance groups showed an improvement in sagittal intermaxillary relationships (decrease in ANB) when compared to untreated subjects. Activators and twin block appliances accomplish this mainly by acting on the mandible (increases in SNB) while twin block appliances also seem to act on the maxilla (decrease in SNA). Extraoral traction appliances achieve this by acting on the maxilla (decreases in SNA). Combination appliances mainly act on the mandible (increase in SNB). Activators, twin block, and combination appliances also reveal a decrease in overjet, which is not the case in the singular use of extraoral traction.

Citation: Antonarakis GS and Kiliaridis S. Short-term anteroposterior treatment effects of functional appliances and extraoral traction on Class II malocclusion. Angle Orthodontist 2007; 77(5): 907-914.

Access: Available to the general public 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Single-dose vicoprofen compared with acetaminophen (paracetamol) with codeine and placebo in patients with acute postoperative pain after third molar extractions
document.publisher: Journal of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORAL SURGERY,IMPACTED THIRD MOLARS,POSTOPERATIVE PAIN RELIEF]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Vicoprofen was found to be an effective postoperative analgesic medication in the management of acute postoperative dental pain. Its total analgesic effect, duration of analgesia, and global evaluation were superior to acetaminophen (paracetamol) with codeine and placebo in this study model.

Method: A randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial of 125 patients (60% female, aged 16 to 40 years old), with moderate to severe postoperative dental pain after surgical extraction of at least one impacted mandibular third molar. Patients were allocated to receive a single dose of Vicoprofen (ibuprofen 200 mg/hydrocodone 7.5 mg), acetaminophen with codeine phosphate (acetaminophen 300 mg/codeine 30 mg), or placebo. Pain intensity and pain relief scores were recorded using standard verbal descriptors up to 8 hours after dosing.

Quality of study: Although an intention-to-treat analysis was carried out and the trial was randomised and double-blind, primary and secondary outcome data are reported in graphs rather than in tables and measures of precision (eg confidence intervals) are not presented.

Results: Both active treatments were superior to placebo for all analgesic measures. Pain relief scores were significantly better for Vicoprofen than placebo throughout the study and significantly better than for acetaminophen with codeine from 2 through 8 hours after dosing. The duration of analgesia (time to remedication) was significantly longer for Vicoprofen (median, 5.50 hours) compared with acetaminophen with codeine (median, 3.03 hours) and placebo (median, 1.00 hours). Mean global evaluation for Vicoprofen was significantly better than for placebo and acetaminophen with codeine. Overall, there were no significant differences in the adverse event profile among the 3 treatment groups.

Reference: Ziccardi VB, Desjardins PJ, Daly-DeJoy E, Seng GF. Single-dose vicoprofen compared with acetaminophen with codeine and placebo in patients with acute postoperative pain after third molar extractions. Journal of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery. 2000; 58(6): 622-8.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Single-tooth replacement in the Anterior Maxilla by means of immediate implantation and provisionalization: A review
document.publisher: International Journal of Oral and Maxillofacial Implants
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,AESTHETICS,RESTORATIVE DENTISTRY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Implant survival and even management of papilla levels seem predictable following immediate implantation and provisionalization. However, maintaining the midfacial gingival margin may be more problematic, since post-extraction bone remodeling and therefore marginal gingival changes will occur irrespective of the timing of the placement of an implant. Currently available information is scarce and more long-term prospective controlled clinical studies are needed.

Methods: A narrative systematic review of 11 studies to assess outcomes of immediate implantation and provisionalization for replacing single maxillary teeth in the aesthetic zone. Database search from1977 to October 2006.

Quality of review: This review is limited by the quality of the included studies. Several databases were searched, reference lists checked and two journals hand-searched. However, the highly restrictive search terms used make it likely that the authors did not identify all relevant studies In addition limiting the search to published studies in the English language may have introduced publication and language biases. No information is provided on the methodologies used to select, data extract and assess the quality of included studies. It does not appear that a formal quality appraisal tool was used, although minimal quality elements are discussed (length of follow-up, sample size and whether consecutive cases were reported). Some of the included studies had very short follow-up periods and the authors highlight the dearth of well-conducted prospective longitudinal studies.

Citation: De Rouck T, Collys K, Cosyn J. Single-tooth replacement in the Anterior Maxilla by means of immediate implantation and provisionalization: A review. The International Journal of Oral and Maxillofacial Implants, 2008; 23 (5): 897-904.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance.  You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

_____________________________________________________________

See also: den Hartog L, Huddleston Slater JJR, Vissink A, Meijer HJA, Raghoebar GM. Treatment outcome of immediate, early and conventional single-tooth implants in the aesthetic zone: a systematic review to survival, bone level, soft tissue, aesthetics and patient satisfaction. Journal of Clinical Periodontology, 2008; 35; 1073-1086.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Sinus floor elevation using osteotomes: A systematic review and meta-analysis
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Short-term clinical success/survival (= 3 years) of implants placed with an osteotome sinus floor elevation (OSFE) technique seems to be similar to that of implants conventionally placed in the partially edentulous maxilla. Controlled prospective clinical studies are needed to evaluate the long-term outcome and various surgical modifications of OSFE.

Methods: A systematic review of eight studies investigating the survival or success rate of OSFEs. Literature search to 2003.

Quality of review: a reasonable number of databases were searched to identify relevant research and journals hand searched for papers in any language. However is unclear whether unpublished research was sought and the risk of publication bias cannot be excluded. No formal method is reported for quality assessing included papers, although the inclusion criteria incorporate some quality elements (sample size and minimum follow-up period). The design of the included studies is not clearly stated by the authors other than a statement that they did not identify randomised controlled or controlled clinical trials.

Results: Eight out of 44 articles dealing with osteotome sinus floor elevation met the inclusion criteria. Five of the studies met established success criteria. The survival and success rates were 95.7% and 96.0% after 24 months and 36 months, respectively. The median and mean follow-up periods were 24 and 18.73 months for the survival rate and 24 and 19.7 months for the success rate. Regarding different surgical elements, i.e., osteotome techniques, implant types, and augmentation materials, the database was multivariate. Thus, no statistical analysis could be performed on these parameters.

Citation: Emmerich D, Att W, Stappert C. Sinus floor elevation using osteotomes: a systematic review and meta-analysis. Journal of Periodontology 2005; 76(8): 1237-1251

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires a subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. 

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Skeletal and dental changes in Class II division 1 malocclusions treated with splint-type Herbst appliances
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORTHODONTICS]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Dental changes are as important as skeletal changes to attaining the final occlusal results. Long-term, prospective, double-blinded, randomized clinical trials are needed to support these conclusions.

Methods: A systematic review of three controlled studies to evaluate skeletal and dental changes in growing individuals through lateral cephalograms obtained after the sole use of the splint-type Herbst appliances in Class II division 1 malocclusions. Literature search to January 2006.

Quality of review: The review is limited by the lack of available high quality studies in this area. However, whilst a number of databases were searched, further papers could potentially have been identified using a wider range of search terms, handsearching journals, contacting experts, and seeking unpublished research through grey literature sources.

Results: The selected studies all showed statistically significant changes in the anteroposterior length of the mandible, vertical height of the ramus, lower facial height, mandibular incisor proclination, mesial movement of the lower molars, and distal movement of the upper molars. Posttreatment relapse in overjet and molar relationship was also observed.

Citation: Flores-Mir C, Ayeh A, Goswani A, Charkhande S. Skeletal and dental changes in Class II division 1 malocclusions treated with splint-type Herbst appliances. Angle Orthodontist 2007; 77(2) 376–381.

Access: Full text available to the general public.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Skeletal and dental changes with fixed slow maxillary expansion treatment: a systematic review
document.publisher: Journal of the American Dental Association
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,DENTO-FACIAL ANOMALIES,ORTHODONTICS]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Only a lower level of evidence was found therefore the authors could make no strong conclusions on dental or skeletal changes that occurred after SME treatment. Clinicians need to rely on their clinical experience, experts' opinions and the presented limited evidence concerning SME treatments.

Methods: Systematic review of 8 clinical trials that assessed skeletal and dental arch changes through measurements on dental casts or cephalometric radiographs. Literature search to July 2004.

Quality of review:  Several databases were searched and reference lists of papers scanned for additional relevant papers. However unpublished research does not appear to have been sought, which may have introduced publication bias. Although a formal method for assessing the validity of included studies has not been reported, the quality of the trials has been discussed in detail, and the authors have appropriately concluded that the evidence is too poor to draw any conclusions on the effectiveness of SME. 

Results: Eight articles met the initial inclusion criteria. The authors found that a significant deficiency in the studies was the lack of a control group to factor out changes in the dental arch and skeletal structures associated with normal growth.

Citation: Lagravere MO, Major PW, Flores-Mir C. Skeletal and dental changes with fixed slow maxillary expansion treatment: A systematic review. Journal of the American Dental Association 2005; 136(2): 194-199

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Socioeconomic inequalities and oral cancer risk: A systematic review and meta-analysis of case-control studies
document.topics: <![CDATA[ RISK FACTORS,OUTCOMES,ORAL HEALTH DISORDERS,CANCER,ORAL CANCER,MONTHLY ADDITIONS,ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,ORAL CANCER,DETERMINANTS,PUBLIC HEALTH,SOCIAL DETERMINANTS,SOCIOECONOMIC FACTORS,2009 NOVEMBER]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Oral cancer risk associated with low SES is significant and comparable to lifestyle risk factors. Our results provide evidence to steer health policy which focus on lifestyles factors toward an integrated approach incorporating measures designed to tackle the root causes of disadvantage.

Methods: A systematic review of 41 case controlled studies to assess the association between socioeconomic status and oral cancer incidence risk. Database searches to September 2006.

Quality of review: A good quality systematic review. The authors conducted an extensive search, using a wide range of electronic databases without language restrictions. In addition, references were checked and authors were contacted to identify unpublished studies, resulting in the inclusion of data from an additional 13 studies. The quality of the included studies was independently assessed in duplicate.

Results:  Compared with individuals who were in high SES strata, the pooled ORs for the risk of developing oral cancer were 1.85 (95%CI 1.60, 2.15; n = 37 studies) for those with low educational attainment; 1.84 (1.47, 2.31; n = 14) for those with low occupational social class; and 2.41 (1.59, 3.65; n = 5) for those with low income. Subgroup analyses showed that low SES was significantly associated with increased oral cancer risk in high and lower income-countries, across the world, and remained when adjusting for potential behavioural confounders. Inequalities persist but are perhaps reducing over recent decades.

Citation: Conway DI, Petticrew M, Marlborough H, Berthiller J, Hashibe M, Macpherson LM.Socioeconomic inequalities and oral cancer risk: a systematic review and meta-analysis of case-control studies. International Journal of Cancer. 2008; 122(12): 2811-9.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Soft tissue changes following the extraction of premolars in nongrowing patients with bimaxillary protrusion
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORTHODONTICS]]>
document.body:
This is a provisional record for information. The review has been identified as potentially meeting our quality criteria. It will be critically appraised and a quality statement provided as soon as possible.
_____________________________________________________

Objective: To quantify the amount of perioral tissue changes following the extraction of four premolars in patients with bimaxillary protrusion who had nearly completed active growth.

Materials and Methods: A literature search was conducted to identify clinical trials that assessed cephalometric perioral soft tissue changes in patients affected by biprotrusion and treated with extractions. Electronic databases (PubMed, ISI WoS Science Citation Index Expanded, and HubMed) were searched. Abstracts that appeared to fulfill the initial selection criteria were selected, and the full-text original articles were retrieved and analyzed. Only articles that fulfilled the final selection criteria were finally considered. Their references were also hand-searched for possible missing articles from the database searches.

Results: Nine abstracts met the initial inclusion criteria and these articles were retrieved. From these, five were later rejected mostly because the sample dealt with growing subjects. Four articles remained and they showed that the upper and lower lips retracted and the nasolabial angle increased following premolar extraction. Upper lip retraction ranged from 2 mm to 3.2 mm, lower lip retraction ranged from 2 mm to 4.5 mm.

Conclusions: The lip procumbency improves following the extraction of four premolars and this improvement is predictable. However, the changes are small and do not dramatically modify the profile. A "dished in" profile is not to be expected. Individual variation in response is large.  

Citation: Leonardi R, Annunziata A, Licciardello V, Barbato E. Soft tissue changes following the extraction of premolars in nongrowing patients with bimaxillary protrusion. A systematic review. Angle Orthodontist 2010; 80(1):211-216. 

Access: Full-text online access is freely available.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Soft tissue changes with fixed functional appliances in Class II division 1
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,DENTO-FACIAL ANOMALIES,ORTHODONTICS]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: The conclusions from this systematic review should be considered with caution because only a secondary level of evidence was found. Long-term double-blinded prospective randomized clinical trials are needed. Three-dimensional quantification of the soft tissue changes is required to overcome current limitations in our understanding of the soft tissue changes obtained with the use of fixed functional appliances.

Methods: A systematic review of four retrospective and one prospective clinical trials. The review's objective was to evaluate facial soft tissue changes after the use of fixed functional appliances in Class II division 1 malocclusion cases. Literature search from database inception to August 2005.

Quality of study: The authors searched a wide range of databases and supplemented their search with a review of reference lists from all retrieved articles.  There were no language restrictions.  Unpublished research does not appear to have been sought and this may have introduced publication bias. A methodological scoring process was developed by the authors and used it as the basis to evaluate the five papers for quality.  They caution against uncritical acceptance of the results because only a secondary level of evidence was available.

Results: Although fixed functional appliances produce some significant statistical changes in the soft tissue profile, the magnitude of the changes may not be perceived as clinically significant. 

Citation: Flores-Mir C, Major MP, Major PW.  Soft tissue changes with fixed functional appliances in Class II division 1. Angle Orthodontist 2006;76(4): 712-720.

Access: Full-text online access of this article is freely available.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Soft tissue profile changes after bilateral sagittal split osteotomy for mandibular advancement: A systematic review
document.publisher: Journal of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORAL SURGERY,ORTHODONTICS]]>
document.body:
This is a provisional record for information. The review has been identified as potentially meeting our quality criteria. It will be critically appraised and a quality statement provided as soon as possible.
_____________________________________________________

Purpose: The purpose of the present systematic review was to evaluate the soft tissue/hard tissue ratio in bilateral sagittal split advancement osteotomy (BSSO) with rigid internal fixation (RIF) or wire fixation (WF).

Materials and Methods: The databases PubMed, Medline, CINAHL, Web of Science, Cochrane Library, and Google Scholar Beta were searched. From the original 711 articles identified, 12 were finally included. Only 3 studies were prospective and 9 were retrospective. The postoperative follow-up ranged from 3 months to 12.7 years for RIF and 6 months to 5 years for WF.

Results: The short- and long-term ratios for the lower lip to lower incisor for BSSO with RIF or WF were 50%. No difference between the short- and long-term ratios for the mentolabial-fold to point B and soft tissue pogonion to pogonion could be observed. It was a 1:1 ratio. One exception was seen for the long-term results of the soft tissue pogonion to pogonion in BSSO with RIF; they tended to be greater than a 1:1 ratio. The upper lip mainly showed retrusion but with high variability.

Conclusions: Despite a large number of studies on the short- and long-term effects of mandibular advancement by BSSO, the results of the present systematic review have shown that evidence-based conclusions on soft tissue changes are still unknown. This is mostly because of the inherent problems of retrospective studies, inferior study designs, and the lack of standardized outcome measures. Well-designed prospective studies with sufficient sample sizes that have excluded patients undergoing additional surgery (ie, genioplasty or maxillary surgery) are needed.

Citation: Joss CU, Joss-Vassalli IM, Kiliaridis S, Kuijpers-Jagtman AM. Soft tissue profile changes after bilateral sagittal split osteotomy for mandibular advancement: A systematic Review. Journal of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery 2010; 68(6):1260-1269. 

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.
