document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Splinting duration and periodontal outcomes for replanted avulsed teeth: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,DENTAL INJURIES,ENDODONTICS]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: The evidence for an association between short-term splinting (14 days or less) and an increased likelihood of functional periodontal healing, acceptable healing, or decreased development of replacement resorption, appears inconclusive. The review found no evidence to contraindicate the current guidelines and suggests that the likelihood of successful periodontal healing after replantation is unaffected by splinting duration. Pending future research to the contrary, it is recommended that dentists continue to use the currently-recommended splinting periods when replanting avulsed permanent teeth.

Methods: A narrative systematic review of four studies (two retrospective and two prospective) pooling 138 replanted avulsed teeth. Database search dates not stated.

Quality of review: As the authors themselves admit, it is possible that potentially relevant papers were missed. Although they searched several electronic databases, the search terms were restrictive, no additional sources were searched and only English language papers were included. No information is provided on the methods used to select, quality assess and data extract included papers and the introduction of error and bias in these processes cannot be excluded. The authors developed their own quality appraisal checklist based on several others. Overall study quality was limited.

Results: Included papers indicate that the likelihood of successful periodontal healing after replantation is unaffected by splinting duration.

Citation: Hinckfuss SE, Messer LB. Splinting duration and periodontal outcomes for replanted avulsed teeth: a systematic review. Dental Traumatology 2009 Apr;25(2):150-7.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Stability after bilateral sagittal split osteotomy setback surgery with rigid internal fixation: a systematic review
document.publisher: Journal of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORAL SURGERY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions:

  • Bilateral sagittal split advancement osteotomy (BSSO) for mandibular advancement is a good treatment option for skeletal Class II, but seems less stable than BSSO setback in the short and long terms.
  • Bicortical screws of titanium, stainless steel, or bioresorbable material show little difference regarding skeletal stability compared with miniplates in the short term. A greater number of studies with larger skeletal long-term relapse rates were evident in patients treated with bicortical screws instead of miniplates.
  • The etiology of relapse is multifactorial, involving the proper seating of the condyles, the amount of advancement, the soft tissue and muscles, the mandibular plane angle, the remaining growth and remodeling, the skill of the surgeon, and preoperative age. 
  • Patients with a low mandibular plane angle have increased vertical relapse, whereas patients with a high mandibular plane angle have more horizontal relapse. 
  • Advancements in the range of 6 to 7 mm or more predispose to horizontal relapse.
  • To obtain reliable scientific evidence, further short-term and long-term research into BSSO advancement with rigid internal fixation should exclude additional surgery, ie, genioplasty or maxillary surgery, and include a prospective study or randomized clinical trial design with correlation statistics.

Methods: A narrative systematic review of 24 papers (Six prospective and 18 retrospective) to evaluate horizontal relapse and its causes in bilateral sagittal split advancement osteotomy (BSSO) with rigid internal fixation of different types. Database search dates not stated.

Quality of review: The review is limited by the poor quality of the included studies. It is likely that potentially relevant studies were missed. The search was restricted to electronic sources (Medline, Google Scholar, Cochrane Library) using limited search terms. Additional sources such as reference list checking, hand-searching key journals and contacting experts may have identified additional papers.

The process used to select, quality assess and data extract studies is unclear and the introduction of error and bias cannot be excluded. Quality was assessed using a checklist developed by the authors.

Results: The short-term relapse for bicortical screws was between 1.5% and 32.7%, for miniplates between 1.5% and 18.0%, and for bioresorbable bicortical screws between 10.4% and 17.4%, at point B. The long-term relapse for bicortical screws was between 2.0% and 50.3%, and for miniplates between 1.5% and 8.9%, at point B.

Citation: Joss CU, Vassalli IM. Stability after bilateral sagittal split osteotomy setback surgery with rigid internal fixation: a systematic review. Journal of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery, 2009; 66: 1634-1643

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Stability factors after double-jaw surgery in Class III malocclusion: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,DENTO-FACIAL ANOMALIES,ORAL SURGERY,ORTHODONTICS]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions:

  • Surgical correction of skeletal Class III malocclusion after combined maxillary and mandibular procedures appears to be a fairly stable procedure independent of the type of fixation used to stabilize the mandible, for maxillary advancements up to 5–6 mm (especially with superior repositioning) and for the correction of pre-surgical sagittal intermaxillary discrepancies smaller than 7 mm. This result highlights the role of orthopedic treatment of Class III malocclusion in growing subjects aimed to reduce the amount of sagittal disharmony before the completion of active growth.
  • A limited degree of intra-operative clockwise rotation of the mandibular proximal segment along with a limited ‘‘stretching’’ of the muscles are additional factors of postsurgical stability.

Methods: A narrative systematic review of 15 studies (study type unclear) to determine whether bimaxillary surgery of skeletal Class III malocclusion is effective and whether there any stability/relapse factors associated with this surgery. Database search 1959 to October 2007.

Quality of review: The review is limited by the quality of the included papers and the results should be viewed with caution.

It is likely that potentially relevant papers were missed. Limited search terms were used to search two databases and only published studies in English were included which may have introduced bias. Searching additional databases without restrictions and with comprehensive search terms, supplemented by reference list checking, hand searching key journals, contacting experts and attempting to identify grey literature may well have produced additional studies. Whilst the process used to select included studies is unclear, appropriate procedures were used to minimise error and bias in data extraction and quality assessment. The authors undertook a quality evaluation to document the methodological soundness of the included studies. However, it is not clear that the evaluation process would have identified the potential for bias in each study. Note: follow-up periods vary between the studies from 6 weeks to about 7 years.

Citation: Mucedero M, Coviello A, Baccetti T. Stability factors after double-jaw surgery in Class III malocclusion: a systematic review. Angle Orthodontist, 2008; 78 (6): 1141-1152

Access: Full text freely available. 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Standard and novel cytotoxic and molecular-targeted therapies for HNSCC: an evidence-based review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,ORAL CANCER,TREATMENT & MANAGEMENT,CHEMOTHERAPY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions and results: Concurrent or alternate chemoradiotherapy, with a schedule based on cisplatin, with or without 5-fluorouracil, has an established place in the management of locally advanced nonmetastatic HNSCC.

In locoregionally advanced disease, cetuximab plus radiotherapy significantly prolongs survival, relative to radiotherapy alone, without increasing toxicity. Cetuximab plus platinum-based therapy appears to be effective and generally well tolerated in patients with refractory metastatic and/or recurrent HNSCC, although large-scale RCTs are required to corroborate this. While chemoradioprotective agents such as amifostine and erythropoietin may reduce chemoradiotherapy-related toxicity (eg, dysphagia, mucositis, xerostomia) and blood-transfusion requirements, large-scale RCTs would again be useful to more clearly define the places in therapy of these agents.

Methods: A systematic review of evidence for the efficacy and tolerability of therapeutic and supportive approaches in head and neck squamous cell carcinoa (HNSCC).

Quality of review: A reasonable attempt was made to find relevant papers through multiple electronic database searching.  However, it is not clear whether reference lists were checked, experts contacted or relevant journals hand-searched.  In addition, the search was restricted to English language published papers which may have introduced publication and language biases.  There was no formal critical appraisal of included papers, although the selection criteria for randomised controlled trials looked at some elements of validity. Please note that the published meta-analyses reviewed in this paper are not included in this specialist collection as two did not meet systematic review criteria and one was published prior to 2000.

Citation: Murdoch D. Standard and novel cytotoxic and molecular-targeted therapies for HNSCC: an evidence-based review. Current Opinions in Oncology 2007; 19: 216-221.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Supportive therapy and the longevity of dental implants: a systematic review of the literature
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,DENTO-FACIAL ANOMALIES,PERIODONTOLOGY,RESTORATIVE DENTISTRY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: There are, to date, few available studies evaluating the long-term effect of supportive programs for implant patients. Based on the nine studies included, no evidence is available to suggest the frequency of recall intervals or to propose specific hygiene treatments. There is an urgent need for such studies to be initiated.

Methods: Systematic review including nine studies (2 case series, 6 prospective cohorts and one retrospective cohort). The review evaluates whether supportive implant treatment during a follow-up of at least 10 years after functional loading is effective in prevention of biological complications and fixture loss. 749 fixtures were included and followed for more than 10 years of functional load. Literature search from 1965 to April 2006.

Quality of review: It is likely that key papers were missed. Whilst bibliographic database searching was supplemented with reference listed checking and handsearching of selected journals, only Medline was searched. Additional databases, grey literature sources and contacting experts may have identified further studies. The search was restricted to published papers in the English language which may have introduced publication and language bias. Although the inclusion criteria and data extraction did address some aspects of study quality, no formal method for assessing quality is reported and the reliability of the included studies is not discussed.

The review provides details of the implant system, but not surface. Clinical value is limited by the lack of detail on maintenance programmes which does not appear to have been documented in the majority of included studies.

Results: Five of the included studies gave no detailed information of the assessments or the treatment at follow-up visits during the 10 years. Only in two of the included cohorts were patients enrolled in an individualized supportive program on a 3–6-month recall interval.

Citation: Hultin M, Komiyama A, Klinge B. Supportive therapy and the longevity of dental implants: a systematic review of the literature. Clinical Oral Implants Research 2007; 18(s3): 50-62

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Surgical therapies for the treatment of gingival recession. A systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,ORAL SURGERY,PERIODONTOLOGY,TREATMENT & MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Soft tissue augmentation procedures are effective means of obtaining root coverage. Connective grafting techniques appear to have an advantage over guided tissue regeneration (GTR). There is a need for further efficacy studies and for investigation of these procedures relative to patient-oriented outcomes such as esthetics, root sensitivity, and postoperative morbidities.

Methods: Systematic review of 32 randomised controlled trials (total study population 687).  11 (population 286) related to various autogenous soft tissue augmentation procedures; 18 (population 360) to the GTR; and 3 (population 41) to allogenic soft tissue augmentation. Literature search to April 2002.

Quality of study: Key papers may have been missed and publication bias introduced as the search was restricted to an electronic search of two databases and only English language studies were included. Two reviewers independently selected studies for inclusion according to agreed criteria and assessed the quality of those studies.

Results: Meta-analysis identified greater gains in both root coverage and keratinized tissue width for connective tissue graft procedures compared to GTR. No other data were compatible with meta-analysis.

Citation: Oates TW, Robinson M, Gunsolley JC. Surgical therapies for the treatment of gingival recession. A systematic review. Annals of Periodontology. 2003; 8(1): 303-320

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Survival and complications of computer aided-designing and computer-aided manufacturing vs. conventionally fabricated implant-supported reconstructions: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,RESTORATIVE DENTISTRY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors’ conclusions: Only a small number of clinical studies reporting on implant-supported CAD–CAM fabricated restorations exists of which only one study was designed to explore differences in the outcome of CAD–CAM vs. conventional fabrication technique. The lack of data makes a scientifically valid comparison between CAD–CAM fabricated and conventionally fabricated restorations for the broader range of applications impossible.

Methods:  A systematic review four studies: 1 RCT, 2 prospective and 1 retrospective cohort study. The aim was to assess the internationally published survival and complication rates of implant-supported computer-aided designing (CAD) and computer-aided manufacturing (CAM)-fabricated restorations and to compare them with those of conventionally fabricated implant-supported restorations. Database search dates not stated.

Quality of review:  The results of this review should be viewed with caution. It is likely the authors missed potentially relevant studies. Whilst PubMed and the Cochrane Library were searched without language restrictions, the search terms were highly specific. No other sources were searched and the introduction of bias cannot be excluded. Appropriate methods were used to minimise error and bias in study selection and data extraction. The authors did not formally assess the quality of the included studies, although they do consider certain quality-related elements.  Rather than identifying studies that compare computer-aided with conventionally fabricated implants, the authors took the unusual step of using three systematic reviews of conventionally fabricated implants. It is not clear how they were identified and no attempt is made to consider their methodological quality.

Results:  The cumulative 5-year survival rate of implants supporting full-arch-fixed dental prostheses (FDPs) ranged from 81.4% to 95.6%. Reported survival rates of implants supporting all-ceramic single crowns (SCs) were 100% [95% confidence interval (CI): 92.4–100]. The cumulative 5-year survival rate for full-arch FDPs ranged from 72.2% to 100%. Reported cumulative 5-year survival rates for all-ceramic SCs were 100% (95% CI: 92.4–100%). Technical complications were reported in two of the four selected studies and the estimated annual failure rate for chipping/fracture of the veneering material was 0.43 (95% CI: 0.06–3.06) for implant-supported all-ceramic SCs and 3.61 (95% CI: 2.05–6.36) for implant-supported FDPs.

Citation: Survival and complications of compute aided-designing and computer-aided manufacturing vs. conventionally fabricated implant-supported reconstructions: a systematic review. Clinical Oral Implants Research 2009; 20 Suppl 4:48-54.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Survival of hydroxyapatite-coated implants: A meta-analytic review
document.publisher: Journal of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORAL SURGERY,PERIODONTOLOGY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Detailed analysis of the clinical trials meeting the inclusion criteria for the review did not show that hydroxyapatite (HA) -coating compromises the long-term survival of dental implants. 

Methods: A systematic review of 11 clinical trials to examine survival rates of hydroxyapatite (HA) coated implants. Literature search from 1990 to 1999.

Quality of review: It is not clear whether the studies were sufficiently similar to be combined statistically.

Results: One group of 5 studies reported implant survival using overall percentage, and another group of 6 studies reported survival using life-table analysis. The overall percentage survival rates ranged from 93.2% to 98.5%, with 4 to 8 years of follow-up. The cumulative survival rates for studies that used life-table analysis ranged from 79.2% to 98.5%, with 5 to 8 years of follow-up. The yearly interval survival rates reported for the studies using life-tables were variable but remained above 90% and did not show a progressive or precipitous decrease with increasing years of follow-up.

The survival rates reported for hydroxyapatite (HA) -coated implants were similar to the survival rates reported for uncoated titanium implants. If resorption of the HA coating causes late failure of implants, the yearly interval survival rates should have decreased with increased years of follow-up. This decrease was not observed in the longitudinal human clinical trials that met the selection criteria for this study.

Citation: Lee JJ, Rouhfar L, Beirne OR. Survival of hydroxyapatite-coated implants: A meta-analytic review. Journal of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery 2000; 58(12): 1372-1379.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Swallowing outcomes after radiotherapy for head and neck cancer: systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORAL CANCER,ORAL PATHOLOGY,ORAL RADIOLOGY,ENT AND AUDIOLOGY,NOSE & SINUS DISORDERS,LARYNX & PHARYNX DISORDERS,NEOPLASMS,MALIGNANT,NEOPLASMS,MALIGNANT,CONDITIONS,TREATMENT & MANAGEMENT,RADIOTHERAPY,THERAPEUTIC INTERVENTIONS,NON-DRUG TREATMENTS,OTHER,DEGLUTITION DISORDERS,RADIOTHERAPY,HEAD & NECK CANCER]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors’ conclusions: There are limited data on swallowing outcomes after radiotherapy or chemoradiotherapy for head and neck cancer. Further work is needed to ascertain which aspects of swallowing should be measured, and then to use such measures in well-designed clinical trials and prospective cohort studies of this under-researched population.

Methods: A systematic review of the current data on swallowing function after radiotherapy or chemoradiotherapy was performed.  Electronic databases were searched for 1966-2005. Papers were categorised according to level of evidence, methodological quality, and the specific domain of swallowing being measured.

Quality of review: A good attempt was made to identify studies using multiple electronic databases and reference lists of included studies.  It appears that included studies were restricted to those which had been published in English and this may have introduced publication and language biases.  The authors independently assessed the quality of the included studies.  All studies were of a low quality and measures used to assess swallowing were diverse or inconsistently used.  

Results: Of 109 papers retrieved, 33 were identified and reviewed. Evidence was primarily classified as either level III.2 (cohort studies) or level IV (case series). Methodological quality was found to be compromised in most studies. Although many researchers had investigated swallowing impairment, a wide variety of measurement tools were employed.

Citation: Frowen JJ and Perry AR. Swallowing outcomes after radiotherapy for head and neck cancer: systematic review. Head and Neck 2006; 28(10): 932-944

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Systematic literature review of oral hygiene practices for intensive care patients receiving mechanical ventilation
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,DENTAL PUBLIC HEALTH]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Despite the importance of providing oral hygiene to intensive care patients receiving mechanical ventilation, high-level evidence from rigorous randomized controlled trials or high-quality systematic reviews that could inform clinical practice is scarce.

Apart from the possible use of chlorhexidine mouth rinse in cardiothoracic intensive care patients, high-level evidence that could inform clinical practice regarding oral hygiene in ICUs is limited. Meta-analysis is hindered by the absence of standardized processes such as use of solutions and oral hygiene tools and by the lack of outcome measures such as validated oral assessment scales relative to ICUs.

Only a few small studies addressed nurses’ perceptions of the importance of oral hygiene practices and the barriers that prevent or strategies that facilitate adherence to evidence-based practice guidelines.

Because oral care may contribute to improved clinical outcomes, further research is warranted for establishing best-practice guidelines.

Methods: A narrative systematic review of 55 papers (11 prospective controlled trials, 20 observational studies, and 24 descriptive reports) to determine the best available evidence for providing oral care to intensive care patients receiving mechanical ventilation and to document a research agenda for this important activity in optimising patients’ outcomes. Literature search 1985 to 2006.

Quality of review: This narrative systematic review had a clearly focused research question and used reliable methods for selecting eligible studies. Only published research in the English language was sought for this review, which as the authors acknowledge, may have introduced language and publication bias. Studies evidence levels were graded using the SIGN system which considers study type and quality. However, it is not reported how the validity of these studies was assessed by the authors.

Results:  Although chlorhexidine reduces respiratory infections in cardiac surgery patients, its effect on ventilator-associated pneumonia in the broader ICU population is unknown. No significant evidence supports the use of sodium bicarbonate or hydrogen peroxide–impregnated sticks for use with the critically ill. Without evidence-based guidelines to direct best practice, critical care nurses often perform oral hygiene according to their individual preferences and historical patterns. Limited high-level evidence exists to inform clinical practice regarding oral hygiene in the intensive care setting.

Citation: Berry AM, Davidson PM, Masters J, Rolls K. Systematic Literature Review of Oral Hygiene Practices for Intensive Care Patients Receiving Mechanical Ventilation. American Journal of Critical Care 2007; 16(6): 552-562.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Systematic review and meta-analysis of antibiotic therapy for bone and joint infections
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORAL INFECTIONS,ORAL MEDICINE]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: There exists little high-quality evidence on antibiotic therapy for osteomyelitis and septic arthritis. The observed heterogeneity among patient populations and medical and surgical treatment concepts preclude reliable inferences from the available data. 

Methods: A systematic review of  19  randomised and 3 quasi randomised trials containing 927 patients eligible for final analysis. Literature search from 1966 to 2000.

Quality of review: This is a generally well-conducted review which used bibliographic databases, handsearching and contacting experts to locate published and unpublished literature in any language. Quality of included papers was assessed by two independent reviewers.

Results: Methodological quality was poor among most studies, and interpretability of results was further limited by small sample sizes, missing descriptions of patient populations and disease characteristics, and the frequent application of concomitant antibiotics.

A trend towards improved, long-lasting infection control was observed in favour of a rifampicin-ciprofloxacin combination versus ciprofloxacin monotherapy for the treatment of staphylococcal infections related to orthopaedic devices (absolute risk difference [ARD] 28-9%; 95% CI -0.7 to 54.4%). Obviously unbalanced comparative studies showed some benefit of ticarcillin for bone infections caused by Pseudomonas species. No significant differences in therapeutic efficacy were found among trials comparing oral fluoroquinolones with intravenous beta-lactam drugs for both end-of-treatment (OR 0.8; 0.5 to 1.4) and long-term results (OR 1.3; 0.8 to 2.1). A variety of drugs was used as controls, thereby leading to inconsistent findings of drug-related side effects.

Only one randomised trial was suitable to investigate the impact of polymethylmethacrylate gentamicin bead chains compared with parenteral antibiotics for skeletal infections, although this study was biased by patients receiving both combined local and systemic antibiotic therapy. Whereas intention-to-treat evaluation suggested a therapeutic advantage of systemic over local therapy, this trend diminished in the per-protocol analysis (1-year follow-up ARD -2.3;-17.5 to 10.8%). 

Citation: Stengel D, Bauwens K, Sehouli J, Ekkernkamp A, Porzsolt F. Systematic review and meta-analysis of antibiotic therapy for bone and joint infections. Lancet Infectious Diseases. 2001;1(3):175-88. Erratum in: Lancet Infectious Diseases 2002; 2(2):125. 

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Systematic review and meta-analysis of diagnostic accuracy of 18F-FDG PET in suspected recurrent head and neck cancer
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,ORAL CANCER,DIAGNOSIS & REFERRAL]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: 18F-FDG PET was useful in patients with suspected recurrence of head and neck cancer, showing a high sensitivity and intermediate-high specificity.

Methods: A systematic review and meta-analysis of 19 studies (study type unclear) to evaluate the diagnostic accuracy of F-FDG PET in suspected recurrent head and neck cancer.

Quality of review: The authors searched two databases without language restrictions. Expanding the search terms used and the databases searched may have led to additional papers being identified. The database search was supplemented by handsearching journals and an attempt to find unpublished studies. Appropriate methods were used to select and quality assess included studies. However the authors do not state the method used to data extract and the introduction of error and bias in this process cannot be excluded. Study quality was assessed independently using a checklist adapted by the authors.

Results: A diagnostic odds ratio was calculated as a diagnostic test performance measurement tool. A global value of 51.68 (95% CI, 30.34-88.05) was obtained. The positive likelihood ratio (LR) was 4.25 (95% CI, 3.17-5.72) and shows that a positive 18F-FDG PET result leads to small changes in the pre-test probability. However, the negative LR was 0.11 (95% CI, 0.07-0.16) and shows that when the 18F-FDG PET was negative it lead to moderate changes in the pre-test probability. The summary ROC curve shows a good link between the sensitivity and the specificity.

Citation: Pasamontes Pingarron JA, Cabrera Martin MN, Delgado Bolton RC, Fernandez Perez C, Carreras Delgado JL, Scola Yurrita B. Systematic review and meta-analysis of diagnostic accuracy of 18F-FDG PET in suspected recurrent head and neck cancer. Acta Otorrinolaringologica Espanola 2008;59(4):190-7.

Availability: Full text of this review is freely available.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Systematic review of studies comparing the anti-caries efficacy of children's toothpaste containing 600ppm of fluoride or less with high fluoride toothpastes of 1,000 ppm or above.
document.topics: <![CDATA[ INDIVIDUAL BEHAVIOUR,OUTCOMES,CHILDREN,ORAL HEALTH DISORDERS,ORAL DISORDERS,ORAL HEALTH,DENTAL CARIES,DENTAL PUBLIC HEALTH,PAEDIATRIC DENTISTRY,CAUSES & PREVENTION,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,DETERMINANTS,PUBLIC HEALTH,HYGIENE,RESEARCH METHODS,METHODS,GROUPS,AGE GROUPS,ANALYSIS & RESEARCH,POPULATIONS,DENTAL HEALTH,DENTAL DECAY,DENTAL CARIES]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: 250 ppm fluoride dentifrice was not as effective in caries prevention in the permanent dentition as dentifrice containing 1,000 ppm fluoride (F) or more. More studies are needed to test the anticaries efficacy of 500 ppm against 1,000 ppm F and above. 

Methods: A systematic review of 7 randomised controlled trials in children to compare the effectiveness of low fluoride toothpastes (250 and 500 ppm) with toothpaste containing 1,000 ppm or more fluoride in preventing dental caries. Databases were searched from 1966 to January 2001.

Quality of review: Although the literature search was comprehensive, it was restricted to English language articles, and there were no attempts to identify unpublished research. Meta-analysis results were not fully reported, and although heterogeneity was assessed statistically and a funnel plot was presented, few studies were included to detect any heterogeneity or publication bias

Results: The quality assessment of the included papers showed that randomisation methods and other key data were seldom reported.

Results of the meta-analysis of 5 studies were statistically significant in favour of the control group (1,000 ppm): DFS increments in the 250-ppm group were 0.6-0.7 greater than the 1,000-ppm group. No meta-analysis could be carried out for the 500 ppm F comparison.  

Citation: Ammari AB, Bloch-Zupan A, Ashley PF. Systematic review of studies comparing the anti-caries efficacy of children's toothpaste containing 600 ppm of fluoride or less with high fluoride toothpastes of 1,000 ppm or above. Caries Research 2003; 37(2): 85-92.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page. 

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Systematic review of survival rates for implants placed in the grafted maxillary sinus
document.publisher: International Journal of Periodontics and Restorative Dentistry
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORAL SURGERY,RESTORATIVE DENTISTRY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: When implants are placed in grafted maxillary sinuses, the performance of rough implants is superior to that of smooth implants. Bone-substitute materials are as effective as autogenous bone when used alone or in combination with autogenous bone. Studies using a split-mouth design with one variable are needed to further validate the findings.  

Methods: Systematic review of 39 studies (3 rcts, 7 ccts, 10 case series and 19 retrospective) to determine the survival rate of root-form dental implants placed in the grafted maxillary sinus. Literature search 1986 to 2002.

Quality of study: A good attempt was made to find the relevant literature: multiple databases, hand searching, reference lists and the inclusion of non-English language papers. However, unpublished research was not sought and may have resulted in the introduction of publication bias. There did not appear to be a formal quality appraisal process, although the inclusion criteria incorporated some quality elements (study size, minimum follow-up period and low loss to follow-up).  The authors state that results did not vary with level of evidence.

Results: The overall implant survival rate for the 39 included studies was 91.49%. The database included 6,913 implants placed in 2,046 subjects with loaded follow-up time ranging from 12 to 75 months.

Implant survival was 87.70% with grafts of 100% autogenous bone, 94.88% when combining autogenous bone with various bone substitutes, and 95.98% with bone grafts consisting of bone substitutes alone.

The survival rate for implants having smooth and rough surfaces was 85.64% and 95.98%, respectively. Simultaneous and delayed procedures displayed similar survival rates of 92.17% and 92.93%, respectively.

Citation: Del Fabbro M, Testori T, Francetti L, Weinstein R. Systematic review of survival rates for implants placed in the grafted maxillary sinus. International Journal of Periodontics & Restorative Dentistry. 2004; 24 (6): 565-577. 

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Systematic review of the effect of smoking on nonsurgical periodontal therapy
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,PERIODONTOLOGY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Following nonsurgical periodontal therapy, people who smoke will experience less reduction in probing depth than nonsmokers. There is no evidence of a difference in gain in clinical attachment between smokers and nonsmokers or a reduction of bleeding on probing between smokers and nonsmokers. Differences in study design and lack of data precluded an adequate and complete pooling of data for a more comprehensive analysis. In short-term studies, it is unclear whether people who quit smoking will respond as favorably to nonsurgical therapy to those who have always been nonsmokers. Progress in understanding the effects of smoking on periodontal therapy will require the evaluation of objective measures of smoking exposure such as cotinine and exhaled carbon monoxide in place of sole reliance on patient reported information.

Methods: A systematic review of 13 controlled clinical trials to answer the question: "In patients with chronic periodontitis, what is the effect of smoking and smoking cessation on the response to nonsurgical periodontal therapy in terms of clinical and patient centred outcomes. Search to March 2003.

Quality of review: It is possible that key papers may have been misssed as non-English language studies were not included and it is unclear whether unpublished research was sought. Data was extracted and quality assessed independently by two reviewers and heterogeneity was tested in the meta-analyses.

Results: Smoking can have a negative effect on mechanical nonsurgical periodontal therapy as indicated by less probing depth reduction in smokers than in nonsmokers. Whereas the analysis for sites with an initial probing depth of at least 5 mm indicated statistical heterogeneity, six out of the eight studies had outcomes that statistically significantly favored nonsmokers and the other two studies had outcomes showing no statistically significant difference between smokers and nonsmokers. Therefore, although the degree of heterogeneity is troubling, the most likely conclusion is that smoking decreases the effect of probing depth reduction.

Data were only available to explore the heterogeneity in terms of differences in baseline disease severity between smokers and nonsmokers and the number of sessions of treatment that patients received. Neither of these factors significantly influenced the outcome of the studies. Nevertheless, this should not be taken to mean that the impact of smoking is unclear. Instead, we would interpret this finding as indicating that smoking very likely affects the treatment response, but that the size of the effect remains uncertain.

It is not possible to reject the null hypothesis of no difference between smokers and nonsmokers for all outcomes. There were no statistically significant differences in the change in clinical attachment level between smokers and nonsmokers either when studies considered full mouth sites or when they considered only initially deeper sites.

Citation: Labriola A, Needleman I, Moles DR. Systematic Review of the effect of smoking on nonsurgical periodontal therapy. Periodontology 2000. 2005; 37: 124-137. 

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. 

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Systematic review of the effectiveness of botulinum toxin or radiotherapy for sialorrhea in patients with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis
document.publisher: Journal of Pain and Symptom Management
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ENT AND AUDIOLOGY,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORAL HEALTH,SALIVARY GLAND DISORDERS,OTHER,NON-DRUG TREATMENTS,THERAPEUTIC INTERVENTIONS,SPECIAL CARE DENTISTRY,CONDITIONS,SIALORRHOEA]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.
_____________________________________________________

 

Authors' conclusions: There is some evidence indicating that both botulinum and radiotherapy are well tolerated, effective treatments for persistent sialorrhea in patients with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) and that the duration of action is up to three months with botulinum and six months with radiotherapy.

Methods: A systematic review of five studies (28 patients) to assess the evidence for the effectiveness and toxicity of botulinum and of radiotherapy for sialorrhea in patients with ALS. Database search to April 2006.

Quality of review: As the authors note, the review’s conclusions are limited by the quality of the included papers. Several electronic databases were searched, supplemented by reference list checking and hand searching.  However, the restrictive database search strategy, coupled with language restrictions may not have identified all relevant papers and consequently introduced bias.  The authors used reasonable methods to minimise error and bias in study selection, quality assessment and data extraction.

Results: Of the four studies using an intraglandular method of injection, no adverse effects occurred. Two of these had positive findings of the effect of botulinum in salivary secretion rate and quality of life. In contrast, significant adverse effects were experienced by two patients in a study of retrograde injections into the salivary ducts. Two studies were included in the analysis of radiotherapy (27 patients). Both demonstrated a positive effect of radiotherapy on salivary secretion rate. Some patients experienced mild acute side effects. Because of the small numbers of studies, small sample sizes, and poor quality of reporting, it is not possible to draw firm conclusions.

Citation: Stone CA, O'Leary N. Systematic review of the effectiveness of botulinum toxin or radiotherapy for sialorrhea in patients with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis. Journal of Pain and Symptom Management 2009 Feb;37(2):246-58.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Systematic review of the relation between smokeless tobacco and cancer in Europe and North America
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,ORAL CANCER,RISK FACTORS,TOBACCO]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors’ conclusions: Meta-analyses based on smoking-adjusted estimates for a relatively wide range of cancers show no indication of an increased risk of cancer for snuff, as used in Scandinavia. The overall data for oropharyngeal cancer shows a significant increase in risk associated with smokeless tobacco (ST) use, but this is not evident for estimates adjusted for smoking and alcohol, or for studies published since 1990. Any effect of ST may relate mainly to products used in the past in the USA. A weak but significant association with prostate cancer, based on limited data from US studies, requires more confirmatory evidence. Reports of significant associations with pancreatic and esophageal cancer in an earlier review are not confirmed, and reasons for this will be discussed in a later publication. Risk from ST products as used in North America and Europe is clearly very much less than that from smoking, and is not evident at all in Scandinavia.

Methods: A systematic review and meta-analysis of 104 papers (9 cohort, 80 case control studies) to look at the effects of smokeless tobacco use on the incidence of a range of cancers. Database search to May 2008.

Quality of review: The results of this review should be viewed with caution. As the authors highlight, “the available data relating to smokeless tobacco use have a number of weaknesses, including inadequate control for smoking in many, and limited data for never smokers. In addition, they declare competing interests in the form of consultancy work for “a number of tobacco, pharmaceutical and chemical companies”. The review was funded by the European Smokeless Tobacco Council and previous related work by Philip Morris International.

In addition, it is possible that potentially relevant studies were missed as only one database (Medline) was searched using restrictive search terms and reference lists checked. Included studies were all from Scandinavia or the USA, (studies in Asian and African populations were excluded). It is unclear whether non-English language studies were included.

No information is provided on the methods used to select, quality assess and data extract included studies and the introduction of error and bias cannot be excluded. The authors discuss a range of methodological issues and highlight weaknesses.  

Results: Eighty-nine studies were identified; 62 US and 18 Scandinavian. Forty-six (52%) controlled for smoking. Random-effects meta-analysis estimates for most sites showed little association. Smoking-adjusted estimates were only significant for oropharyngeal cancer (1.36, CI 1.04–1.77, n = 19) and prostate cancer (1.29, 1.07–1.55, n = 4). The oropharyngeal association disappeared for estimates published since 1990 (1.00, 0.83–1.20, n = 14), for Scandinavia (0.97, 0.68–1.37, n = 7), and for alcohol-adjusted estimates (1.07, 0.84–1.37, n = 10). Any effect of current US products or Scandinavian snuff seems very limited. The prostate cancer data are inadequate for a clear conclusion.

Citation: Lee PN, Hamling J. Systematic review of the relation between smokeless tobacco and cancer in Europe and North America. BMC Medicine 2009;7:36.

Access: Full text is freely available.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: systematic review of trismus induced by cancer therapies in head and neck cancer patients
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,ORAL CANCER,ORAL CARE FOR CANCER PATIENTS]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Newer radiation modalities may decrease the prevalence of trismus compared to conventional radiotherapy. Few studies have addressed the quality of life impact of trismus, and no studies were identified to assess the economic impact of trismus. The few preventive and management trials identified in the literature showed some promise, although larger, well designed studies are required to appropriately assess these therapies before recommendations can be provided.

Methods: A narrative systematic review of 22 studies (5 intervention and 17 observational studies) to determine the impact of cancer therapies on the prevalence, quality of life and economic impact, and management strategies for cancer-therapy-induced trismus.  Database search dates: 1990 to 2008 inclusive.

Quality of review: Overall a reasonably well-conducted systematic review. The authors searched two electronic databases using a highly sensitive search strategy. However, it is possible that potentially relevant studies were missed as no other sources were searched and inclusion was restricted to published studies in the English language. Appropriate processes were used to minimise error and bias in selecting, data extracting and quality assessing included studies. A range of questions designed to identify potential bias in different study types were incorporated into the data extraction form. Only limited information is provided on the included studies. It is not clear if studies could be combined which gives concern to using an overall prevalence score.

Results: Most studies assessed the prevalence of trisus, and few focused on management. The weighted prevalence for trismus was 25.4% in patients who received conventional radiotherapy and 5% for the few intensity-modulated radiation therapy studies. No clear guideline recommendations could be made for the prevention or management of trismus.

Citation: Bensadoun RJ, Riesenbeck D, Lockhart PB, Elting LS, Spijkervet FK, Brennan MT; Trismus Section, Oral Care Study Group, Multinational Association for Supportive  Care in Cancer (MASCC)/International Society of Oral Oncology (ISOO). A systematic review of trismus induced by cancer therapies in head and neck cancer patients. Supportive Care in Cancer 2010 Aug;18(8):1033-8.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

 


Note: additional details about the methodology are provided in:

Brennan MT, Elting LS, Spijkervet FK. Systematic reviews of oral complications from cancer therapies, Oral Care Study Group, MASCC/ISOO: methodology and quality of the literature. Supportive Care in Cancer 2010 Aug;18(8):979-84.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Systematic review on the effect of rinsing with povidone-iodine during nonsurgical periodontal therapy
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,PERIODONTOLOGY,TREATMENT & MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body:
This is a provisional record for information. The review has been identified as potentially meeting our quality criteria. It will be critically appraised and a quality statement provided as soon as possible.
_____________________________________________________

 

Authors' conclusions: The adjunctive use of povine (PVP)-iodine during scaling and root planing may increase the clinical pocket depth reduction, although the clinical significance is small to moderate.

Methods: A systematic review of 31 RCTs to assess the additional effect of PVP-iodine as an adjunct to scaling and root planing compared with water, saline or no rinse in the treatment of chronic periodontitis. Database search inception to August 2009.

Results: A small, but statistically significant additional beneficial effect of the adjunctive use of PVP-iodine with enhanced probing pocket depth reductions of 0.28 mm (95% confidence interval: 0.08 to 0.48, p = 0.007) was found. There was no significant heterogeneity between studies (I(2) = 0%). However, most of the studies included in the meta-analysis were of low quality, and the treatment modalities showed various differences such as the use of PVP-iodine at different concentrations and application modalities. Nevertheless, single-rooted teeth, in particular, showed an additional benefit after scaling and root planing with PVP-iodine, particularly when the treatment was repeated during the healing stage.

Citation:  Sahrmann P, Puhan MA, Attin T, Schmidlin PR. Systematic review on the effect of rinsing with povidone-iodine during nonsurgical periodontal therapy. Journal of Periodontal Research 2009 Nov 9. [Epub ahead of print]

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Systemic anti-infective periodontal therapy. A systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,PERIODONTOLOGY,TREATMENT & MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: The use of systemically administered adjunctive antibiotics with and without scaling and root planing (SRP) and/or surgery appeared to provide a greater clinical improvement in attachment level  than therapies not employing these agents.

The data supported similar effect sizes for the majority of the antibiotics; therefore, the selection for an individual patient has to be made based on other factors. Due to a lack of sufficient sample size for many of the antibiotics tested, it is difficult to provide guidance as to the more effective ones.

Methods: Systematic review of 29 studies (26 randomsied controlled trials and 3 quasi-experimental). 22 studies (27 comparisons) were used in the meta-analysis, evaluating if the antibiotics provided a consistent benefit in mean attatchment level  change for different patient populations, for different therapies, and for different antibiotics. Literature search 1966 to May 2002.

Quality of Review: Key papers may have been missed as only the PubMed database was searched and non-English language papers were excluded. There was no report that unpublished research was sought and consequently publication bias may have been introduced. The quality of the studies was assessed independently in duplicate.

Results: For the majority of the comparisons, systemically administered antibiotics exhibited a more positive attachment level change than the control group in the study. The combined results were statistically significant (p<0.001).

The systemic antibiotics were uniformly beneficial in providing an improvement in attatchment level when used as adjuncts to scaling and root planing (SRP) and were consistently beneficial, although of borderline significance, when used as adjuncts to SRP plus surgery or as a stand alone therapy.

When examining the effects of individual or combinations of antibiotics, it was found that there were statistically significant improvements in attachment level for tetracycline, metronidazole, and an effect of borderline statistical significance for the combination of amoxicillin plus metronidazole.

Improvements in mean attatchment level were consistent for both chronic and aggressive periodontitis subjects, although the aggressive periodontitis patients benefited more from the antibiotics.

Citation: Haffajee AD, Socransky SS, Gunsolley JC. Systemic anti-infective periodontal therapy. A systematic review. Annals of Periodontology 2003; 8(1): 115-177.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: The adjunctive use of platelet-rich plasma in the therapy of periodontal intraosseous defects: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,PERIODONTOLOGY,TREATMENT & MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body:
This is a provisional record for information. The review has been identified as potentially meeting our quality criteria. It will be critically appraised and a quality statement provided as soon as possible.
_____________________________________________________

 

Authors' conclusions: Diverse outcomes (positive and negative) have been reported for the efficacy of PRP combined with various therapeutic bioactive agents/procedures, reflecting the limited and heterogeneous data available and possibly suggesting that the specific selection of agents/procedures combined with PRP could be important. Additional research on the efficacy of each specific combination of PRP is necessary.

Methods: Systematic review of 10 RCTs to address the focused question, 'What is the efficacy, with respect to clinical, radiographical and patient-centred outcomes, of combinations of PRP with other therapeutic bioactive agents/procedures, compared with the efficacy of the same agents/procedures without the adjunctive use of PRP in the therapy of periodontal intraosseous defects in patients with chronic periodontitis and without systemic diseases that could potentially influence the outcome of periodontal therapy?' Database search to September 2008

Citation: Citation: Kotsovilis S, Markou N, Pepelassi E, Nikolidakis D. The adjunctive use of platelet-rich plasma in the therapy of periodontal intraosseous defects: a systematic review. Journal of Periodontal Research 2009 Nov 9. [Epub ahead of print]

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: The application of ozone in dentistry: a systematic review of literature
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,DENTAL CARIES,TREATMENT & MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: While laboratory studies suggest a promising potential of ozone in dentistry, the clinical evidence for application of ozone in dentistry is not extensive. There is still a need for the highest level of evidence, ie, well designed, double-blind randomised clinical trials with adequate sample size, limited or no loss to follow up, and carefully standardised methods of measurement and analysis in order to justify the routine use of ozone as a treatment modality in dentistry. 

Methods: A systematic review of 20 randomised and quasi-randomised studies (5 in vivo and 15 in vitro) with the aim of determing 1) the clinical application and remineralization potentials of ozone in dentistry; (2) summarising the available in vitro applications of ozone in dentistry.

Quality of review: It is likely that the search methodology missed potentially relevant papers. Whilst the authors searched a wide range of sources, the search strategy used was limited and only English language papers were selected. Using a wider range of terms without language restrictions, hand-searching journals and contacting experts may have identified additional papers. As the authors note, a Cochrane systematic review was published in 2004¹ followed in 2006 by another systematic review as part of the Health Technology Assessment programme². Both reviews were conducted using sensitive search strategies and the authors of this review could usefully have used one of those strategies. The authors discuss the quality of the included papers but do not provide information on the appraisal methods used.

Results:

In vitro:

  • Good evidence of ozone biocompatibility with human oral epithelial cells, gingival fibroblast, and periodontal cells;
  • Conflicting evidence of antimicrobial efficacy of ozone but some evidence that ozone is effective in removing the microorganisms from dental unit water lines, the oral cavity, and dentures;
  • Conflicting evidence for the application of ozone in endodontics;
  • Insufficient evidence for the application of ozone in oral surgery and implantology; 
  • Good evidence of the prophylactic application of ozone in restorative dentistry prior to etching and the placement of dental sealants and restorations.

In vivo: Despite the promising in vitro evidence, the clinical application of ozone in dentistry (so far in management of dental and root caries) has not achieved a strong level of efficacy and cost-effectiveness.

Citation: Azarpazhooh A, Limeback H. The application of ozone in dentistry: a systematic review of literature. Journal of Dentistry 2008; 36(2): 104-16.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

___________________________________________________________________ 

1 Rickard GD, Richardson RJ, Johnson TM, McColl DC, Hooper L. Ozone therapy for the treatment of dental caries. Cochrane Database of systematic Reviews 2004, Issue 3. Art. No.: CD004153. DOI: 10.1002/14651858.CD004153.pub2

2 Brazzelli M, McKenzie L, Fielding S, Fraser C, Clarkson J, Kilonzo M, Waugh N. Systematic review of the effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of HealOzone (R) for the treatment of occlusal pit/fissure caries and root caries. Health Technology Assessment, 2006: 96

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: The Arg194Trp polymorphism in the X-ray repair cross-complementing group 1 gene as a potential risk factor of oral cancer: a meta-analysis
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,ORAL CANCER,RISK FACTORS]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors’ conclusions: We suggest that the Arg194Trp polymorphism in the XRCC1 gene may be a biomarker of oral cancer susceptibility among Asian population.

Methods: A systematic review and meta-analysis of eight case control studies (1326 cases and 3,130 controls) to consider the effect of XRCC1 polymorphisms on the risk of oral cancer. Database search dates unclear (to June 2008 in abstract; to September 2008 in full text).

Quality of review: As the authors indicate, the review is limited by the quality of the included studies.

It is likely that potentially relevant studies were missed. Although there were no language restrictions, only one database (PubMed) was searched using limited search terms, supplemented by reference list checking. Whilst unpublished studies were not sought, a check did not reveal publication bias. The review was limited to case control studies, although no reason is given for this. Selection criteria for other reviews identified in this area also include cohort studies.

Appropriate methods were used to minimise error and bias in study selection and data extraction. The authors do not report conducting quality assessment of the included studies although they identify several methodological flaws that may have introduced bias, including the use of hospital-based controls, a lack of information on potential confounders and small sample sizes.

Results: The odds ratio (OR) of various comparisons showed that the oral cancer risk was not associated with the selected three XRCC1 polymorphisms (P > 0.05). However, after stratification, significant association was found between the XRCC1 Arg194Trp polymorphism and oral cancer risk among Asians, showing an OR of 1.347 (95% confidence interval (CI): 1.000, 1.814) for allele comparison, 1.378 (95% CI: 1.070, 1.775) for TT homozygotes versus CC homozygotes, and 1.420 (95% CI: 1.041, 1.936) for comparison under the dominant model. Publication bias was not shown around the studies; however, ORs among these three polymorphisms all yielded significant between-study heterogeneity (P < 0.05) and a part of the heterogeneity was from ethnic differences.

Citation: Zhou C, Zhou Y, Li J, Zhang Y, Jiang L, Zeng X, et al. The Arg194Trp polymorphism in the X-ray repair cross-complementing group 1 gene as a potential risk factor of oral cancer: a meta-analysis. Tohoku Journal of Experimental Medicine 2009;219(1):43-51.

Access: Full text is freely available.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: The association between generalized joint hypermobility and temporomandibular joint disorders: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,DENTO-FACIAL ANOMALIES,ORO-FACIAL PAIN]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: It is not clear whether generalised joint hypermobility (GJH) is associated with temporomandibular joint disorder (TMD) and more rigorous studies are needed. 

Methods: A systematic review of 14 observational studies. Literature search dates not reported.

Quality of review: The review was limited by the variable quality of the included studies (generally poor), the possible inherent heterogeneity, and the lack of relevant data.

Results: The methodological quality of the 14 included papers was assessed according to 14 criteria. Four studies fulfilled the criteria for further review, and data from 3 studies (113 cases and 95 controls) were available for analysis. Twenty-six cases and five controls were hypermobile (OR=5.4; 95% CI 2 to 14.6). In a sensitivity analysis, the odds ratio changed from significant to non significant in 2 of 5 scenarios.

Citation: Dijkstra PU, Kropmans TJ, Stegenga B. The association between generalised joint hypermobility and temporomandibular joint disorder: a systematic review. Journal of Dental Research. 2002; 81(3): 158-163.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. Full text online access is available to NHS staff in England via ATHENS passwords. To apply for an ATHENS password and access this resource and many others please go to the ATHENS registration page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: The association between head and cervical posture and temporomandibular disorders: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,DENTO-FACIAL ANOMALIES]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions:  Since most of the studies included in this systematic review were of poor methodological quality, the findings of the studies should be interpreted with caution. The association between intra-articular and muscular temporomandibular disorders (TMD) and head and cervical posture is still unclear, and better controlled studies with comprehensive TMD diagnoses, greater sample sizes, and objective posture evaluation are necessary.

Methods:  A systematic review of twelve studies (11 cross-sectional studies and 1 case series) to assess the evidence concerning the association between head and cervical posture and temporomandibular disorders. Literature search 1965-Nov 2004.

Quality of review: The authors searched a wide range of electronic databases for papers in all languages and supplemented the search with a review of reference lists. However, it is likely that the search strategy did not identify all relevant research.  The search terms used were narrow and the search itself was limited to published papers. This limit may have introduced publication bias. The validity of the 12 included studies was assessed by a tool adapted by one of the authors. As the authors indicate, most studies were of poor quality and, consequently results should be viewed with caution.

Results:  Nine articles that analysed the association between head posture and TMD included patients with mixed TMD diagnosis; one article differentiated among muscular, articular, and mixed symptomatology; three articles analysed information from patients with only articular problems; two studies evaluated the association between head posture and TMD in patients with muscular TMD. Several methodological defects were noted in the 12 studies.

Citation:  Armijo Olivo S, Bravo J, Magee DJ, Thie NMR, Major PW, Flores-Mir C. The association between head and cervical posture and temporomandibular disorders: A systematic review. Journal of Orofacial Pain 2006; 20:9-23

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: The association between the cervical spine, the stomatognathic system, and craniofacial pain: a critical review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,DENTO-FACIAL ANOMALIES,ORO-FACIAL PAIN]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: The information provided by this review suggests an association between the cervical spine, stomatognathic system, and craniofacial pain, but most of this information is not conclusive and was derived from poor-quality studies (levels 3b, 4 and 5 based on Sackett's classification). Better designed studies are needed in order to clarify the real influence that the cervical spine has in relation to the stomatognathic system and craniofacial pain.

Methods: A narrative systematic review of 63 studies (number obtained from counting studies listed in tables). Literature search to 2006.

Quality of review:  The review suffers from inadequate reporting of methods. The objectives and inclusion criteria are poorly defined and the method for appraising the quality of included studies (and hence the levels of evidence assigned) is not reported. A wide range of databases were searched and reference lists checked but the total number of citations and included studies is not presented. As unpublished research was not sought and only papers in English or Spanish were included, publication and language biases may have been introduced.

Results: The results identified must be treated with caution because of a lack of scientific rigour. However they do point out a tendency toward a link between the cervical spine, neck structures and craniofacial pain. search provided information referring to the biomechanical, 

Citation: Armijo Olivo S, Magee DJ, Parfitt M, Major P, Thie NM. The association between the cervical spine, the stomatognathic system, and craniofacial pain: a critical review. Journal of Orofacial Pain 2006; 20(4) 271-287.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: The association of psycho-social factors and survival in head and neck cancer
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,ORAL CANCER,ENT AND AUDIOLOGY,NOSE & SINUS DISORDERS,LARYNX & PHARYNX DISORDERS,SALIVARY GLAND DISORDERS,NEOPLASMS,NEOPLASMS,MALIGNANT,NEOPLASMS,MALIGNANT,CONDITIONS,PROGNOSIS,HEAD & NECK CANCER]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: There appears to be some association between selected psycho-social factors and long-term survival from head and neck cancer. However this relationship is currently neither strong nor proven, requiring examination by multi centred trials with standardisation of research definitions and methodologies, and examination of post-treatment psycho-social factors.

Methods: A systematic review of 7 studies (4 prospective, 2 retrospective and 1 case control). Literature search: 1 January 1995 to 1 June 2007.

Quality of review: It is possible that the search did not identify all possible papers. Whilst three databases were searched (Cochrane, PsycINFO and Embase) and reference lists checked, a Medline search was not conducted nor was there was any journal hand searching or an attempt to identify grey literature. It appears that the review was restricted to published papers which could have introduced publication bias. Also, it is unclear whether studies in all languages were included. The authors considered the quality of the included studies using tools developed by SIGN. They rightly point out the methodological failings in most of the included studies and the results of the review should be interpreted with caution.

Results: At baseline, expression of intense psycho-social complaints, higher self-perceived physical ability and self-reported high physical functioning were significantly associated with increased survival. Uncertainty about the diagnosis and treatment was found to be a negative prognostic indicator, as was being single, poor cognitive function, baseline fatigue and alcoholism. Overall quality of life and head and neck pain 12 months after date of diagnosis were found to be significantly associated with survival in one study. However, overall quality of life and depression at the time of diagnosis were not.

Citation: Mehanna HM, De Boer MF, Morton RP. The association of psycho-social factors and survival in head and neck cancer. Clinical Otolaryngology 2008; 33(2): 83-9.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: The association of the composite IL-1 genotype with periodontitis progression and/or treatment outcomes: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,PERIODONTOLOGY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Based on these findings, (i) there is insufficient evidence to establish if a positive interleukin-1 (IL-1) genotype status contributes to progression of periodontitis and/or treatment outcomes. Therefore, (ii) results obtained with commercially available tests should be interpreted with caution.

Methods: A systematic review of 11 longitudinal studies to compare progression of periodontitis and/or treatment outcomes in IL-1 genotype-positive (carrying allele 2) and IL-1 genotype-negative (not carrying allele 2) subjects. Literature search 1997 to 2005 inclusive.

Quality of review: Whilst sound methods were used to select, data extract and quality appraise included papers, the limited search strategy employed may have missed key papers. Only one database (Medline) was searched; supplemented by reference list checking and hand-searching. Experts were not contacted and unpublished research was not sought which may have introduced publication bias. Only including English, French, German and Italian language research may also have biased the review.

Results: The heterogeneity of the data prevented the performance of a meta-analysis. While findings from some publications rejected a possible role of IL-1 composite genotype on progression of periodontitis after various therapies, other reported a prognostic value for disease progression of the positive IL-1 genotype status. When assessed on a multivariate risk assessment model, several publications concluded that the assessment of the IL-1 composite genotype in conjunction with other covariates (e.g. smoking and presence of specific bacteria) may provide additional information on disease progression. The small sample size of the available publications, however, requires caution in the interpretation of the results.

Citation: Huynh-Ba G, Lang NP, Tonetti MS, Salvi GE. The association of the composite IL-1 genotype with periodontitis progression and/or treatment outcomes: a systematic review. Journal of Clinical Periodontology 2007; 34(4): 305–317.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.
