document.title: The caries-preventive effect of chlorhexidine varnish in children and adolescents: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,DENTAL CARIES,PAEDIATRIC DENTISTRY,CAUSES & PREVENTION]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Evidence regarding the effectiveness of chlorhexidine varnish for preventing caries is inconclusive. Further well-conducted randomised trials are required before chlorhexidine varnish can be recommended for caries prevention.

Methods: A narrative systematic review of 12 randomised controlled trials to determine the caries-preventive effect of chlorhexidine varnish in children and adolescents aged 18 and under. Database search dates inception to December 2009 (Embase) or March 2010 (Medline and Central)

Quality of review: Although three databases were searched, supplemented by reference list checking, it is possible that potentially relevant studies were missed. The search terms used appear limited and inclusion was restricted to published studies in English. Appropriate methods were used to limit the introduction of error and bias in selecting data extracting and appraising the quality of included studies. The authors assessed risk of bias using Cochrane methodology. Only four of the included studies were deemed to be at low risk of bias (two parallel design and 2 split-mouth design).

Results: Six parallel group trials reported no statistically significant difference in caries increment in permanent teeth with the application of chlorhexidine varnish compared to placebo or no treatment. The results of 4 split-mouth trials were conflicting: 2 trials found no significant difference in caries increment and 2 reported statistically significant results in favour of chlorhexidine varnish. One trial of the effect of chlorhexidine varnish in primary teeth demonstrated a statistically significant reduction in caries increment. The results of 1 trial comparing chlorhexidine varnish with fluoride varnish for preventing caries in adolescents were equivocal.

Citation: James P, Parnell C, Whelton H. The caries-preventive effect of chlorhexidine varnish in children and adolescents: a systematic review. Caries Research 2010;44(4):333-40.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: The clinical effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of routine dental checks: a systematic review and economic evaluation
document.topics: <![CDATA[ OUTCOMES,ECONOMICS,ECONOMICS,ORAL HEALTH DISORDERS,POPULATION BASED & PREVENTATIVE SERVICES,SCREENING,COST EFFECTIVENESS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,DENTAL PUBLIC HEALTH,DENTAL CARIES,CAUSES & PREVENTION,ORAL DISORDERS,ORAL HEALTH,PUBLIC HEALTH,DETERMINANTS,MANAGEMENT & INTERVENTIONS,RESEARCH METHODS,IMPACT ASSESSMENT,METHODS,SERVICES,ANALYSIS & RESEARCH,DENTAL HEALTH]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: There is little existing evidence to support or refute the practice of encouraging 6-monthly dental checks in adults and children.

Methods: A systematic review addressing the effectiveness of routine dental checks on the oral health of encompassing children and adults and the cost effectiveness. 25 articles reporting the results of 29 studies were included in the review of the effectiveness of dental checks on oral health. 24 investigated the effect of dental checks on caries, 9 concerned periodontal disease, 2 oral cancer and 1 quality of life.

A separate literature search resulted in 6 studies that met the inclusion criteria for the economic evaluation of the quality of life and cost-effectiveness of dental checks.

Quality of review: The review is is limited by the quality of the included studies and their relevance to the UK. Studies included in the effectiveness review were poorly reported, limiting internal comparison (between studies) and also external comparison with the current UK situation. Heterogeneity across studies with regard to the intervention under study further limits external comparison with the current UK situation. Only three studies addressing caries in permanent or deciduous teeth included 6/12 months as a comparison frequency and thus addressed the review from a UK perspective.

Results: Decision analysis modeling using current UK data to investigate further the cost-effectiveness of different dental check recall frequencies on the experience of dental decay in deciduous and permanent dentition suggests that moving to longer (more than 6 monthly) dental check frequencies would be cost effective. However the model demonstrates that cost-effectiveness varies across risk groups and therefore consideration should be given to whether a population recall policy or a recall policy based on individual risk would be more appropriate.

Given the limitations of existing UK epidemiological data, it was not possible to undertake a modeling exercise to investigate the cost-effectiveness of different frequencies of dental checks on the experience of periodontal disease or on the morbidity and mortality associated with oral cancer. There is a need for further primary research addressing the role of the dental check and its effectiveness in different oral diseases.

Citation: Davenport C, Elley K,Salas C, et al. The clinical effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of routine dental checks: a systematic review and economic evaluation. Health Technology Assessment 2003; 7(7).

Access: Available to the general public

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: The cost-effectiveness of supportive periodontal care of patients with chronic periodontitis
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,PERIODONTOLOGY,TREATMENT & MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Supportive periodontal care (SPC) delivered in specialist as compared with general practice will result in greater stability of clinical attachment but this will be achieved at relatively greater cost.

Methods: A narrative systematic review of 14 studies (13 cohorts and 1 RCT) to evaluate the effectiveness of supportive periodontal care provided in specialist care and general practice for patients with chronic periodontitis; to construct a model for its cost effectiveness.

Quality of review: The authors made a reasonable attempt to identify potentially relevant papers. They searched multiple databases – albeit with rather limited search terms, supplemented by hand-searching and attempts to identify unpublished and in press studies. Appropriate methodology was used for study selection, data extraction and quality assessment, which the authors conducted independently in duplicate. The included papers were quality assessed for risk of bias.

Note: The authors identified 14 studies as meeting their criteria and report the results of three more identified in the search that did not, but which they felt added value. However the main results appear to have been extracted from the three included papers that specifically answered the authors’ focused question.

Results: Three papers looked at patients undergoing "specialist" SPC. Changes in CAL were 0.1mm (2 years), 0.2mm (6 years) and -0.01mm (3 years) respectively. In generalist care changes in CAL during SPC were -2.2, -1.8 and -2.8 mm. Differences between specialist and generalist SPC were an extra 20.59 tooth years and 3.95mm attachment loss for generalist SPC. Incremental cost-effectiveness ratios were an extra €E288 for one tooth year or an extra €1503/1mm reduction in loss of attachment for SPC delivered in specialist care.

Citation: Gaunt F, Devine M, Pennington M, Gwynnett E, Steen N, Heasman P. The cost-effectiveness of supportive periodontal care of patients with chronic periodontitis. Journal of Clinical Periodontology, 2008; 35 (Suppl. 8): 67-82

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance.  You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: The craniofacial morphology of the parents of children with orofacial clefting: A systematic review of cephalometric studies
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,DENTO-FACIAL ANOMALIES,ORTHODONTICS,PAEDIATRIC DENTISTRY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: The parental craniofacial complex of children with orofacial clefting (OFC) is distinctive in comparison to the non-cleft population.

Methods: A systematic review of 15 retrospective case/control studies investigating the craniofacial morphology of the parents of children with orofacial clefting. The included studies investigated populations from a variety of countries: USA, UK, Japan, Czechoslovakia, and Saudi Arabia.

Quality of review: Due to the widely differing study methods, methodological quality, measurements and variables used in the study no meta-analysis could be performed. Many of the studies had methodological shortcomings, highlighting the need for better quality research in this area.

Results: At present there is insufficient consistency in study design and results to accurately localize the features that characterize the parents of children with OFC. Although there is evidence that the craniofacial morphology of the parents of children with cleft clip and palate differs to the morphology of the parents of children with cleft lip, there is insufficient information to be able to accurately localize these differences.

Citation: McIntrye GT, Mossey PA. The Craniofacial morphology of the parents of children with orofacial clefting: A systematic review of cephalometric studies. Journal of Orthodontics 2002; 29: 23-29.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: The effect of a pulsed Nd:YAG laser in non-surgical periodontal therapy
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,PERIODONTOLOGY,TREATMENT & MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: The majority of studies analyzed showed no beneficial effect of a pulsed Nd:YAG laser compared to conventional therapy (ultrasonics and/or hand instrumentation) in the initial treatment of patients with periodontitis. The pulsed Nd:YAG laser was assessed as monotherapy and as an adjunct to non-surgical periodontal treatment; efficacy was determined by the extent of plaque removal and the reduction of periodontal inflammation. This literature review suggests that there is no evidence to support the superiority of the Nd:YAG laser over traditional modalities of periodontal therapy.

Methods: A systematic review of 8 RCTs (including 4 split mouth design) to determine the efficacy of a pulsed Nd:YAG laser in the initial treatment of patients with periodontitis, either as monotherapy or as an adjunct to non-surgical periodontal treatment. Database search to May 2008.

Quality of review: The review is limited by the poor quality of the included studies: 7 were considered high and 1 moderate risk of bias. 

It is possible that not all potentially relevant papers were found as the authors limited their search to published English language papers indexed in two databases (PubMed and Cochrane Central). Appropriate methods were used to minimise error and bias in study selection and data extraction. The authors used a variety of methods to assess the risk of bias of included studies.

Citation: Slot DE, Kranendonk AA, Paraskevas S, Van der Weijden F. The effect of a pulsed Nd:YAG laser in non-surgical periodontal therapy. Journal of Periodontology 2009; 80(7):1041-56.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.  

See also:

Karlsson MR, Lofgren CID, Jansson HM. The Effect of Laser Therapy as an Adjunct to Non-Surgical Periodontal Treatment in Subjects with Chronic Periodontitis: a systematic review. Journal of Periodontology, 2008; 79 (11): 2021-8.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: The effect of cetylpyridinium chloride-containing mouth rinses as adjuncts to toothbrushing on plaque and parameters of gingival inflammation: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,PREVENTION,TREATMENT & MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: When used as an adjunct to either supervised or unsupervised oral hygiene, cetylpyridinium chloride-containing (CPC) mouth rinses provide a small but significant additional benefit when compared with toothbrushing only or toothbrushing followed by a placebo rinse in that they reduce plaque and gingival inflammation.  

Improvement in gingival health is more apparent if a high level of inflammation is present at the baseline (GI < 1 represents a relatively healthy state). The baseline GI of the investigated populations mostly varied between 0.7 and 2.02. Furthermore, four trials involved a baseline prophylaxis, a variable for which the magnitude cannot be assessed in the outcome of plaque and gingivitis studies. The conclusions drawn in this systematic review are applicable only to subjects in good general health and with good to moderate gingival health. As a result, more research is needed to establish whether CPC-containing mouth rinses have additional efficacy in patients already suffering from periodontitis.

Methods: A systematic review of eight randomised controlled trials with a meta-analysis of some included studies. The aim of the review is to determine the effectiveness of CPC-containing mouthwashes as adjuncts to toothbrushing in preventing plaque build up and gingival inflammation. Database search dates: inception to January 2008.

Quality of review: The review is limited by the quality of the included studies. The authors identified a number of issues and consequently the results should be viewed with caution. Mouth rinses used in the studies contained different formulations and concentrations of CPC (between 0.05% and 0.10%). Four studies were conducted by industry employees and a further two stated they were funded by industry grants. A range of indices were used to measure several different clinical outcomes and four trials involved baseline prophylaxis.

Two databases were searched using reasonably comprehensive search terms and reference lists of included studies were checked for published studies in the English language. However it is possible that potentially relevant studies were missed. Searching additional databases and using additional techniques such as hand searching key journals, contacting experts and product manufacturers may have yielded additional papers.
Appropriate procedures were used to minimise error and bias in study selection, data extraction and quality assessment. Quality assessment considered randomisation, allocation concealment, examiner blinding and completeness of follow-up.

Citation: Haps S, Slot DE, Berchier CE, Van der Weijden GA. The effect of cetylpyridinium chloride-containing mouth rinses as adjuncts to toothbrushing on plaque and parameters of gingival inflammation: a systematic review. International Journal of Dental Hygiene, 2008; 6 (4): 290-303

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. Full text online access is available to NHS staff in England via ATHENS passwords. To apply for an ATHENS password and access this resource and many others please go to the ATHENS registration page. 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: The effect of cranio-maxillofacial osteotomies and distraction osteogenesis on speech and velopharyngeal status: A critical review.
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,DENTO-FACIAL ANOMALIES,ORAL SURGERY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions:  None of the included studies compared conventional osteotomy and distraction by including both groups in a single study.  RCTs with adequate numbers of subjects and follow-up duration are required.

Methods:  A systematic review of 39 studies of varied design to identify the the effects of maxillary advancement on speech.

Quality of review: The limited search strategy (Pubmed and Science Direct) using narrow search terms makes it unlikely that all relevant studies were identified. It does not appear that non-published studies were sought and non-English language papers were excluded; this may have introduced both publication and language bias. The authors comment on the variation and the poor methodological quality of the included studies.   The results were varied and the main conclusion is the need for methodologically appropriate RCTs to be conducted.

Results: Findings varied. Many studies found that surgery had no impact on speech and velopharyngeal status. Some reported worsening only in patients with preexisting velopharyngeal impairment or those with borderline velopharyngeal function before surgery. There was no clear difference in outcome between distraction and conventional osteotomy, although there have been few systematic comparisons. There was great variation among reviewed studies in the number of subjects, speech sample, number and type of listeners, speech outcome measures, and timing of postoperative assessment. Few studies employed reliability measures.

Citation:  Chanchareonsook N, Samman N, Whitehill TL. The effect of cranio-maxillofacial osteotomies and distraction osteogenesis on speech and velopharyngeal status: A critical review. Cleft Palate-Craniofacial Journal 2006; 43(4): 477-87.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: The effect of laser therapy as an adjunct to non-surgical periodontal treatment in subjects with chronic periodontitis: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,PERIODONTOLOGY,TREATMENT & MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors’ conclusions: A limited number of studies have evaluated the clinical effect of laser as an adjunct to scaling and root planning (SRP. Results from new methods, such as laser as an adjunct to SRP or laser replacing SRP as the first treatment option for chronic periodontitis, should be interpreted with caution until there are several independent randomised controlled trials with sufficient statistical power.

Methods: A narrative systematic review of four randomised controlled trials to determine the  effectiveness of laser therapy as an adjunct to non-surgical periodontal treatment in adults with chronic periodontitis. Database search dates: 1966 to February 2008.

Quality of review: The review is limited by the quality of the included studies. It is possible that relevant papers were missed. The authors searched only two databases using what appear to have been limited search terms and supplemented by reference list checking. Additionally, only published studies in the English language were included which may have introduced bias. Searching additional databases with a sensitive search strategy and without language restrictions, hand searching journals and searching grey literature sources may have identified additional studies. Appropriate procedures were used to minimise error and bias in study selection, data extraction and quality assessment. A quality assessment checklist was used to review key elements which reduce bias including randomisation, allocation concealment, examiner blinding and loss to follow-up. The quality of the included studies was poor.

Results: Four different laser methods were identified. All studies included a limited number of subjects. No significant conclusions could be reached.

Citation: Karlsson MR, Lofgren CID, Jansson HM. The Effect of Laser Therapy as an Adjunct to Non-Surgical Periodontal Treatment in Subjects with Chronic Periodontitis: a systematic review. Journal of Periodontology, 2008; 79 (11): 2021-8

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form. _____________________________________________________

See also, Schwarz F, Aoki A, Becker J, et al. Laser application in non-surgical periodontal therapy: a systematic review. Journal of Clinical Periodontology, 2008; 35 (Suppl. 8): 29-44

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: The effect of periodontal therapy on the survival rate and incidence of complications of multirooted teeth with furcation involvement after an observation period of at least 5 years: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,ORAL SURGERY,PERIODONTOLOGY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Good long-term survival rates (up to 100%) were found following therapy of furcation-involved multirooted teeth. Endodontic failures, root fractures and caries development in the furcation area represented the most frequent complications leading to tooth loss. No RCTs were available comparing the long-term (5 years or more) outcomes of different treatment modalities of molars with comparable degree of furcation involvement.

Methods: A narrative systematic review of 22 studies (4 prospective and 18 retrospective cohort studies) the survival rate and incidence of complications of furcation-involved multirooted teeth following periodontal therapy after at least 5 years.

Quality of review: As the authors note in the discussion, the results of this review are limited by the quality of the included studies. It is possible that potentially relevant papers were missed as only one electronic database (Medline) was searched with limited search terms, supplemented by reference list checking and handsearching of four periodontal journals. Restricting inclusion to published studies in English may have introduced bias. Appropriate methods were used to minimise error and bias in the selection, quality assessment and data extraction of included studies.

Results: The survival rate of molars treated non-surgically was >90% after 5–9 years. The corresponding values for the different surgical procedures were:
• Surgical therapy: 43.1% to 96%, observation period: 5–53 years.
• Tunnelling procedures: 42.9% to 92.9%, observation period: 5–8 years.
• Surgical resective procedures including amputation(s) and hemisections: 62% to 100%, observation period: 5–13 years.
• Guided tissue regeneration (GTR): 83.3% to 100%, observation period: 5–12 years.

Citation: Huynh-Ba G, Kuonen P, Hofer D, Schmid J, Lang NP, Salvi GE. The effect of periodontal therapy on the survival rate and incidence of complications of multirooted teeth with furcation involvement after an observation period of at least 5 years: a systematic review. Journal of Clinical Periodontology 2009 Feb;36(2):164-76.

 Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: The effect of photodynamic therapy for periodontitis: a systematic review and meta-analysis
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,PERIODONTOLOGY,TREATMENT & MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body:
This is a provisional record for information. The review has been identified as potentially meeting our quality criteria. It will be critically appraised and a quality statement provided as soon as possible.
_____________________________________________________

 

Background: The purpose of this review was to evaluate the effectiveness of photodynamic therapy (PDT) for periodontitis in adults as a primary mode of treatment or as an adjunct to non-surgical treatment of scaling and root planing (SRP) compared to a conventional non-surgical SRP treatment.

Methods: MEDLINE, EMBASE, CINAHL, other relevant databases, and the International Pharmaceutical Abstracts were searched from their inception until May 2009 for randomized controlled trials of PDT compared to a placebo, no intervention, or non-surgical treatment in an adult population. Data on changes in clinical attachment level (CAL), probing depth, gingival recession, and full-mouth plaque or bleeding scores were extracted and meta-analyzed, and the pooled mean difference (MD) was reported.

Results: Five studies were included in this review. These studies had a small sample size for some of the performed analysis with a moderate to high risk of biases. There were clinical heterogeneities among included studies. PDT as an independent treatment or as an adjunct to SRP versus a control group of SRP did not demonstrate statistically or clinically significant advantages. Combined therapy of PDT + SRP indicated a probable efficacy in CAL gain (MD: 0.34; 95% confidence interval [CI]: 0.05 to 0.63) or probing depth reduction (MD: 0.25 mm; 95% CI: 0.04 to 0.45 mm).

Conclusions: PDT as an independent treatment or as an adjunct to SRP was not superior to control treatment of SRP. Therefore, the routine use of PDT for clinical management of periodontitis cannot be recommended. Well-designed clinical trials are needed for proper evaluation of this therapy 

Citation: Azarpazhooh A, Shah PS, Tenenbaum HC, Goldberg MB. The effect of photodynamic therapy for periodontitis: a systematic review and meta-analysis. Journal of Periodontology 2010; 81(1):4-14

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: The effect of topical fluorides on decalcification in patients with fixed orthodontic appliances
document.publisher: American Journal of Orthodontics and Dentofacial Orthopedics
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,DENTAL CARIES,DENTO-FACIAL ANOMALIES,ORTHODONTICS,CAUSES & PREVENTION]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Different preparations and formats appear to decrease decalcification, but there was no evidence that any one method was superior. There was some evidence that the potency of fluoride preparations might be important.

Methods: Systematic review of 7 reports (of 6 studies) examining the effectiveness of topical fluoride preparations in preventing decalcification during fixed orthodontic treatment.

Quality of review: Good search strategy to identify all the relevant research with stringent inclusion criteria.  Design of included studies is unclear and does not appear to include randomised controlled trials.  No formal method of quality appraisal was reported, however inclusion criteria did address the quality of papers.  The authors were limited by the lack of research in this area; and because much of what had been done was non-standardised.

Results: Differences in the methodologies and reporting made statistical analysis impossible. However, the use of topical fluorides in addition to fluoride toothpaste reduced the incidence of decalcification in populations with both fluoridated and non-fluoridated water supplies.

Citation: Chadwick BL, Roy J, Knox J, Treasure ET. The effect of topical fluorides on decalcification in patients with fixed orthodontic appliances: A systematic review. American Journal of Orthodontics and Dentofacial Orthopedics 2005; 128: 601-6.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: The effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of prophylactic removal of wisdom teeth
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORAL SURGERY,IMPACTED THIRD MOLARS,PROPHYLACTIC REMOVAL]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions:  There is no reliable research evidence to support the prophylactic removal of disease-free impacted third molars. Available evidence suggests that retention may be more effective and cost-effective than prophylactic removal, at least in the short to medium term.

Method: A systematic review of 2 randomised controlled trials, 34 literature reviews and 4 decision analysis studies. Study participants had unerupted or impacted third molars, or were undergoing surgical removal of third molars either as prophylaxis or due to associated pathological changes. Literature search from 1984 to 1999.

Quality of review: This is a well conducted systematic review which searched for published and unpublished literature and included non-English language papers. Relevance and quality of papers were assessed by two independent reviewers. Data extraction was checked by a second reviewer.

Results:  One UK RCT focused on the effects of retained third molars on incisor crowding in patients who had previously undergone orthodontic treatment. The results suggested that the removal of third molars to prevent late incisor crowding cannot be justified. Another on-going RCT in Denmark compares the effects and costs of prophylactic removal of third molars with removal according to morbidity. Preliminary results indicate that watchful waiting may be a promising strategy. However, more data and longer follow-up of patients are needed to conclude which treatment strategy is the most cost-effective.

The methodological quality of the literature reviews was generally poor, and none of the reviews was systematic:

  • Nine reviews on anterior crowding suggested that there was only a weak association between retention of third molars and crowding.
  • Six out of 21 reviews with a more general scope also concluded that the prophylactic removal of third molars was unjustified.
  • Twelve general reviews did not conclude with a clear message about the management of third molars.
  • Three reviews suggested that prophylactic removal of third molars is appropriate, but these reviews were of poorer methodological quality than the majority of other reviews.
  • Three out of four papers focusing on surgical management expressed uncertain conclusions relating to the prophylactic extraction of third molars.

Although there were important differences in the structure and methods for estimating input values, the findings of the decision analyses (by two groups of researchers) consistently suggested that retention of third molars was cost-saving and more cost-effective compared with prophylactic removal of impacted third molars.

Implications for Research: There is a need for well-designed RCTs to compare prophylactic removal with management by deliberate retention, using long-term follow-up. There is also a need for decision analysis models that could be used to compate long-term outcomes of prophylactic removal with retention of impacted third molars.

Citation: Song F, O'Meara S, Wilson P, Golder S, Kleijen J. The effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of prophylactic removal of wisdom teeth. Health Technology Assessment. 2000; 4(15).

Access: Full text available to the general public (pdf file). 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: The effectiveness of a toothpaste containing triclosan and polyvinyl-methyl ether maleic acid copolymer in improving plaque control and gingival health
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,DENTAL PUBLIC HEALTH,PREVENTION]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: This systematic review indicates that a dentrigice containing triclosan/copolymer provides a more effective level of plaque control and periodontal health than a conventional fluoride dentrifice.

Methods: Systematic review of 16 randomised controlled trials comparing the effectiveness of triclosan/copolymer and fluoride dentrifices in improving plaque control and gingival health.

Quality of review: A well conducted review with a comprehensive search. Several databases were searched and non-English language papers were included, although a search for unpublished research is not reported.  The authors used a funnel plot to examine the potential for publication bias; it indicated the presence of bias in one of the four outcomes (gingivitis severity). Two independent reviewers conducted quality assessment and data extraction of the included studies. There was significant heterogeneity in the meta-analyses that the authors were unable to explain and consequently a randome effects model was used to calculate treatment effects.

Results: The triclosan/copolymer dentifrice significantly improved plaque control compared with a fluoride dentifrice, with a weighted mean difference (WMD) of -0.48 (95% CI -0.64 to -0.32) for the Quigley–Hein index and WMD of -0.15 (95% CI -0.20 to -0.09) for the plaque severity index. When compared with a fluoride dentifrice, the triclosan/copolymer dentifrice significantly reduced gingivitis with WMDs -0.26 (95% CI -0.34 to -0.18) and -0.12 (95% CI -0.17 to -0.08) for the Loe and Silness index and gingivitis severity index, respectively.

Citation: Davies RM, Ellwood RP, Davies GM. The effectiveness of a toothpaste containing triclosan and polyvinyl-methyl ether maleic acid copolymer in improving plaque control and gingival health. Journal of Clinical Periodontology. 2004; 31(12): 1029-1033.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: The effectiveness of commonly used mouthwashes for the prevention of chemotherapy-induced oral mucositis: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORAL CANCER,ORAL CARE FOR CANCER PATIENTS,SPECIAL CARE DENTISTRY,CANCER PATIENTS]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: The use of chlorhexidine as well as other mouthwash for preventing oral mucositis in patients undergoing chemotherapy cannot be recommended. The use of an iodine solution could be promising, but should be investigated further.

Methods: A systematic review of 7 randomised controlled trials examining the effect of mouthwashes for the prevention and amelioration of oral mucositis in adult patients undergoing chemotherapy. Literature search from 1992 to Autumn 2004.

Quality of review: It is possible that relevant papers were missed as only Medline and Cinahl databases were searched with limited search terms. It is unclear whether reference lists were checked, experts contacted, unpublished research or non-English language studies sought and the possibility of bias having been introduced cannot be excluded. The quality of included studies was assessed for randomisation, blinding and intention to treat analysis.

Results: Based on study quality, three out of five randomized controlled trials investigating chlorhexidine were included in a meta-analysis. The results failed to detect any beneficial effects of chlorhexidine as compared with sterile water, or NaCl 0.9%. Patients complained about negative side-effects of chlorhexidine, including teeth discoloration and alteration of taste in two of the five studies on chlorhexidine. The severity of oral mucositis was shown to be reduced by 30% using a povidone-iodine mouthwash as compared with sterile water in a single randomized controlled trial.

Citation: Uitterhoeve R, Scholte op Reimer W, Van Achterberg T. The effectiveness of commonly used mouthwashes for the prevention of chemotherapy-induced oral mucositis: a systematic review. European Journal of Cancer Care 2006; 15(5): 431–439.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: The effectiveness of computer-aided learning in teaching orthodontics: a review of the literature
document.publisher: American Journal of Orthodontics and Dentofacial Orthopedics
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORTHODONTICS]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: The controlled trials of computer-aided learning (CAL) in orthodontics that met our quality assessment checklist (QAC) cutoff score of 8 were split, with two showing that CAL enjoyed a significant advantage over conventional teaching, one showing no difference, and one showing that the conventional tutorial method was better. More high-quality trials evaluating the effectiveness of CAL in orthodontics are needed. CAL programs in orthodontics elicit mostly positive responses and attitudes from students toward learning.

Methods: Level I evidence. A systematic review of 12 randomised controlled trials to examine the effectiveness of computer-aided self-instructional programs in dental education. Literature search 1966 - June 2002.

Quality of review: A thorough attempt was made to identify relevant research; searching a wide range of databases. However, it is unclear  whether the authors searched for unpublished or non-English language studies. Selection and quality appraisal of included studies were performed independently by two reviewers.

Results: Four randomized controlled trials comparing CAL with conventional teaching fulfilled the inclusion criteria and met the cutoff QAC score of = 8. Each study was assessed for quality by 2 independent reviewers. The validity and strength of the selected studies were assessed by using a QAC for an educational intervention.

Citation: Rosenberg H, Sander M, Posluns J. The effectiveness of computer-aided learning in teaching orthodontics: A review of the literature. American Journal of Orthodontics and Dentofacial Orthopedics 2005; 127(5): 599-605

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: The effectiveness of periodontal disease treatment during pregnancy in reducing the risk of experiencing preterm birth and low birth weight: A meta-analysis
document.publisher: Journal of the American Dental Association
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,PERIODONTOLOGY,ASSOCIATED CONDITIONS]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: The results of our meta-analysis indicate that periodontal treatment during pregnancy does not reduce the risks of pregnant women experiencing of preterm birth (PTB) and low birth weight (LBW). Pooled results from the high-quality RCTs with low bias do not support the continued treatment of periodontal disease in pregnancy to prevent PTB, LBW or both. Further studies are needed to understand this subject better. We also suggest that stricter criteria for diagnosing periodontitis and guidelines for documenting the effectiveness of treatment should be developed to ensure uniformity in future studies.

Methods: A systematic review and meta-analysis of ten randomised controlled trials to determine the effectiveness of periodontal disease treatment during pregnancy in reducing the risk of preterm birth and low birth weight. Database search dates: inception until March-June 2010.

Quality of review: Whilst the authors searched multiple databases, many were at best marginally relevant and the limited search terms used may not have identified all relevant research. Database searching was supplemented by reference list checking, but no attempt appears to have been made to find unpublished research. It is unclear whether there were any language restrictions.

The authors appear to have used appropriate methods to minimise the introduction of error and bias in selecting and quality assessing included studies. The process used to extract data is unclear. Authors assessed risk of bias in included RCTs. As the authors note, Whilst overall statistically significant results favoured treatment, this significance disappeared when only high quality (low risk of bias) studies were considered.

Results: Ten RCTs met the inclusion criteria for PTB, and eight RCTs met the inclusion criteria for LBW. The odds ratio of PTB in the treatment group was 0.589 (95 percent confidence interval [CI] = 0.396-0.875) and of LBW was 0.717 (95 percent CI = 0.440-1.169). Level of bias was the only significant predictor (P < .001) in subgroup analysis. High-quality studies (studies with low bias), which included 71.2 percent of participants, yielded the pooled estimates of 1.082 (95 percent CI = 0.891-1.314) for PTB and 1.181 (95 percent CI = 0.960-1.452) for LBW.

Citation: Uppal A, Uppal S, Pinto A, Dutta M, Shrivatsa S, Dandolu V, et al. The effectiveness of periodontal disease treatment during pregnancy in reducing the risk of experiencing preterm birth and low birth weight: A meta-analysis. Journal of the American Dental Association 2010 Dec 1;141(12):1423-34.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal for 12 months after publication. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: The effectiveness of sealants in managing caries lesions
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,DENTAL CARIES,PAEDIATRIC DENTISTRY,TREATMENT & MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: The evidence supports the placement of sealants over non-cavitated caries lesions in the pits and fissures of permanent teeth in children, adolescents, and young adults. Despite variations in study design and conduct, subgroup and sensitivity analyses found the effect to be consistent in size and direction: sealing non-cavitated caries in permanent teeth is effective in reducing caries progression.

Methods: A systematic review and meta-analysis of six studies (4 RCTs 1 prospective and 1 retrospective cohort) to examine the effectiveness of dental sealants in preventing the progression of caries lesions in the pits and fissures of permanent teeth.

Quality of review:  Overall a reasonably well conducted review. It is possible that potentially relevant studies were missed. Whilst the authors searched several databases using comprehensive search terms, the search appears to have been restricted to published papers in English. A search without language restrictions, supplemented by a range of snowballing techniques (such as reference list checking, hand searching journals, grey literature searching and contacting experts) may have yielded additional papers. Initial study selection was conducted by one reviewer. Appropriate procedures were used to minimise error and bias in final study selection, data extraction and quality assessment. The authors used quality criteria developed by the US Preventive Services Task force and study quality was assessed as fair for all included studies.

Results: The median annual percentage of non-cavitated lesions progressing was 2.6% for sealed and 12.6% for unsealed carious teeth. The summary prevented fraction for RCT was 71.3% (95%CI: 52.8%–82.5, no heterogeneity) up to 5 years after placement.

Citation: Griffin SO, Oong E, Kohn W, et al. The effectiveness of sealants in managing caries lesions. Journal of Dental Research, 2008; 87(2): 169-174.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: The effects of orthodontic therapy on periodontal health: a systematic review of controlled evidence
document.publisher: Journal of the American Dental Association
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,ORTHODONTICS,PERIODONTOLOGY,TREATMENT & MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: There is an absence of reliable evidence on the positive effects of orthodontic therapy on periodontal status. Epidemiologic studies with adequate comparison groups and follow-up time are lacking, as are studies that focus on adult populations or specific techniques such as current orthodontic expansion methods. The evidence that does exist suggests a small mean worsening of periodontal status after orthodontic therapy. Claims that orthodontic therapy results in overall improved periodontal health cannot be supported with the existing controlled evidence.

Methods: A narrative systematic review systematic review of 12 studies (1 RCT, 3 prospective cohort studies and 8 cross-sectional studies) to compare contemporary orthodontic treatment with no intervention, by means of evaluating periodontal outcomes measured after end of treatment. Database search dates: 1980 to June 2006.

Quality of review: A good quality systematic review. Several databases were searched, supplemented by reviewing reference lists, hand-searching journals and contacting experts. There were no language restrictions and attempts were made to identify unpublished studies. The quality of the included studies was assessed independently by two reviewers.

Results: RCT: Subjects in the orthodontically treated group had, on average, a pocket depth 0.3mm deeper than subjects in the untreated groups. Teeth that had been orthodontically treated had a similar number of bleeding sites as did teeth that had not been orthodontically treated (20 of 96 sites versus 18 of 96 sites).

Cohort and cross-sectional studies: Mean alveolar bone loss in three studies was 0.13 mm (CI, 0.07–0.20) greater among the groups that had been orthodontically treated than among the groups that had not. In two studies periodontal pocket depth in the orthodontically treated group was, on average, 0.23 mm (CI, 0.15–0.30) deeper than those of the untreated groups. In three studies gingival recession in the orthodontically treated group was 0.03 mm (CI, 0.01–0.04) greater than did the untreated group. Attachment loss in those who had undergone orthodontic treatment was 0.11 mm (CI, 0.07–0.15) greater attachment loss in one study and 0.05 mm (CI, –0.11–0.01) and 0.06 (CI, –0.12–0.00) lower attachment loss in the other studies, compared with those who had not received treatment. The gingival index was 0.15 points (CI, 0.07–0.23) and 0.05 points (CI, –0.13–0.26) higher in the group that had received orthodontic treatment in two studies. The mean percentages of sites with bleeding on probing were six points (CI, –10.7- -1.3) and 23.8 points lower in the orthodontically treated group than in the group that had not received orthodontic treatment in two other studies

Citation: Bollen AM, Cunha-Cruz J, Bakko DW, Huang GJ, Hujoel PP. The effects of orthodontic therapy on periodontal health: a systematic review of controlled evidence. Journal of the American Dental Association. 2008; 139 (4): 413-422

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance.  You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: The effects of orthognathic surgery on speech: a review
document.publisher: Journal of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,DENTO-FACIAL ANOMALIES,ORAL SURGERY,ORTHODONTICS]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: There is no clear evidence directly relating malocclusions to speech discrepancies. Furthermore, it is difficult to draw any firm conclusions with respect to the effect of orthognathic surgery on speech. Further investigation is required.

Methods: A systematic review of 18 longitudinal studies (4 controlled and 14 uncontrolled) to asssess the effects of orthnagthic surgery on speech in non-cleft individuals.

Quality of review: This appears to be a moderate quality narrative systematic review. The report lacks details on some aspects of the methodology. For example neither the total number of citations resulting from the search, nor the number of papers excluded has been reported. No formal method of assessing the validity of included studies is presented, although the quality of the papers is discussed. Whilst two databases and handsearching were employed with no language restrictions, unpublished research was not sought; potentially introducing publication bias.

Results: 13 papers reported preoperative articulation errors. In 8 of the trials, speech articulation either improved or was corrected for the majority of individuals assessed. In the studies assessed, the type of surgery or degree of movement did not appear to affect speech.

Citation: Hassan T, Naini FB,  Gill DS. The effects of orthognathic surgery on speech: a review. Journal of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery 2007; 65 (12): 2536-2543

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: The efficacy and safety of articaine versus lignocaine in dental treatments: a meta-analysis
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORAL SURGERY]]>
document.body:
This is a provisional record for information. The review has been identified as potentially meeting our quality criteria. It will be critically appraised and a quality statement provided as soon as possible.
_____________________________________________________

 

Authors' conclusions: The results of this systematic review provide support for the argument that articaine is more effective than lignocaine in providing anaesthetic success in the first molar region for routine dental procedures. In addition, both drugs appear to have similar adverse effect profiles. The clinical impact of articaine's higher post-injection pain scores than lignocaine is negligible. Hence, articaine is a superior anaesthetic to lignocaine for use in routine dental procedures. Use in children under 4 years of age is not recommended, since no data exists to support such usage.

Methods: A systematic review and meta-analysis to compare the efficacy and safety of articaine with lignocaine in maxillary and mandibular infiltrations and block anaesthesia in patients presenting for routine dental treatments. 

Results: Articaine is more likely than lignocaine to achieve an anaesthetic success in the posterior first molar area with a relative risk for success at 1.31 (95% CI 1.12-1.54, P=0.0009). There is no difference in post-injection adverse events between articaine and lignocaine with a relative risk of 1.05 (95% CI 0.66-1.65, P=0.85). However, articaine injection results in a higher pain score as measured by Visual Analogue Scale, than lignocaine at the injection site after anaesthetic reversal with a weighted mean difference of 6.49 (95% CI 0.02-12.96, P=0.05) decreasing to 1.10 (95% CI 0.18-2.02, P=0.02) on the third day after injection.

Citation: Katyal V. The efficacy and safety of articaine versus lignocaine in dental treatments: a meta-analysis. Journal of Dentistry. 2010 Apr;38(4):307-17. Epub 2009 Dec 16.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: The efficacy of bone replacement grafts in the treatment of periodontal osseous defects. A systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,PERIODONTOLOGY,TREATMENT & MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: The results of this systematic review indicate that bone replacement grafts provide demonstrable clinical improvements in periodontal osseous defects compared to surgical debridement alone.

Methods: Systematic review of 49 randomised controlled trials providing clinical outcome data on BRG materials in the treatment of intrabony defects and 17 studies providing clinical outcome data on BRG materials for the treatment of furcation defects.

Quality of review: Although several databases were searched and selected journals handsearched, the restriction of included studies to those published and available in English, studies may have been missed and bias introduced.  Inclusion and study methodology were reviewed by three investigators.

Results: With respect to the treatment of intrabony defects, the results of meta-analysis supported the following conclusions:

  1. Bone grafts increase bone level, reduce crestal bone loss, increase clinical attachment level, and reduce probing depth compared to open flap debridement (OFD) procedures;
  2. No differences in clinical outcome measures emerge between particulate bone allograft and calcium phosphate (hydroxyapatite) ceramic grafts;
  3. bone grafts in combination with barrier membranes increase clinical attachment level and reduce probing depth compared to graft alone.

With respect to the treatment of furcation defects, 15 controlled studies provided data on clinical outcomes. Insufficient studies of comparable design were available to submit data to meta-analysis. Nonetheless, outcome data from these studies generally indicated positive clinical benefits with the use of grafts in the treatment of Class II furcations.

With respect to histological outcome parameters, 2 randomised controlled studies provide evidence that demineralized freeze-dried bone allograft (DFDBA) supports the formation of a new attachment apparatus in intrabony defects, whereas OFD results in periodontal repair characterized primarily by the formation of a long junctional epithelial attachment. Multiple observational studies provide consistent histological evidence that autogenous and demineralized allogeneic bone grafts support the formation of new attachment.

Limited data also suggest that xenogenic bone grafts can support the formation of a new attachment apparatus. In contrast, essentially all available data indicate that alloplastic grafts support periodontal repair rather than regeneration.

Citation: Reynolds MA, Aichelmann-Reidy MA, Branch-Mays GL, Gunsolley JC. The efficacy of bone replacement grafts in the treatment of periodontal osseous defects. A systematic review. Annals of Periodontology. 2003; 8(1): 227-259.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page. 

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: The efficacy of dental floss in addition to a toothbrush on plaque and parameters of gingival inflammation: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,PREVENTION,TREATMENT & MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: the dental professional should determine, on an individual patient basis, whether high-quality flossing is an achievable goal. In light of the results of this review it appears that a routine instruction to use floss is not supported by scientific evidence.

Methods: a systematic review of 11 randomised controlled trials (four cross-over and seven parallel designs) to assess the adjunctive effect of flossing and brushing versus brushing alone. Database search dates: inception to December 2007.

Quality of review: The review is limited by the quality of the included studies. The authors identify a number of issues and consequently the results should be viewed with caution. Ten of the eleven included studies received industry funding. A range of indices were used to measure several different clinical outcomes. In four of the studies, the participants had received complete oral prophylaxis prior to the study. In addition, none of the included papers appear to have considered the smoking status of their study population.

It is likely that potentially relevant studies were missed. Whilst the authors searched two databases using a reasonably comprehensive search strategy, checking reference lists, hand-searching journals, consulting experts and product manufacturers may have yielded additional results. Restricting inclusion to published studies in the English language may have introduced bias. A clear attempt was made to avoid selection bias with reviewers independently considering papers for inclusion in duplicate. Key elements of study validity were examined, although the methods used are not stated.

Results: most studies did not show a benefit for floss on plaque and clinical parameters of gingivitis. Sub-group meta-analyses were performed for the plaque index and gingival index; neither showed a significant treatment effect.

Citation: Berchier CE, Slot DE, Haps S, Van der Weijden GA. The efficacy of dental floss in addition to a toothbrush on plaque and parameters of gingival inflammation: a systematic review. International Journal of Dental Hygiene 2008; 6(4):265-79.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. Full text online access is available to NHS staff in England via ATHENS passwords. To apply for an ATHENS password and access this resource and many others please go to the ATHENS registration page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: The efficacy of interdental brushes on plaque and parameters of periodontal inflammation: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,PREVENTION,TREATMENT & MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: As an adjunct to brushing, the interdental brush (IDB) removes more dental plaque than brushing alone. Studies showed a positive significant difference using IDB with respect to the plaque scores, bleeding scores and probing pocket depth. The majority of the studies presented a positive significant difference in the plaque index when using the IDB compared with floss.

Methods: A systematic review of nine randomised controlled trials with a meta-analysis of some included studies. The aim of the review is to determine the effectiveness of interdental brushes as an adjunct to toothbrushing alone or other interdental oral hygiene devices on plaque and the clinical parameters of periodontal iinflammation. Database search date: 1965 to November 2007.

Quality of review: The review is limited by the quality of the included studies. The authors identify a number of issues and consequently the results should be viewed with caution. Although only two studies excluded smokers, none of the included papers analysed the effect of smoking on study outcome variables. Six of the nine included studies received industry funding and the authors comment that “no such information was presented” for the other three studies. A range of indices were used to measure several different clinical outcomes.

Review authors searched two databases using reasonably comprehensive search terms and reference lists of included studies were checked for published studies in the English language. However it is possible that potentially relevant studies were missed. Searching additional databases and using additional techniques such as hand searching key journals, contacting experts and product manufacturers may have yielded additional papers. Appropriate procedures were used to minimise error and bias in study selection, data extraction and quality assessment. Quality assessment considered randomisation, allocation concealment, examiner blinding and completeness of follow-up.

Results: A significant improvement in plaque scores was observed for the groups using IDB in all but one study. In those studies that assessed bleeding scores and probing pocket depth, a significant improvement was also observed. Of studies that assessed gingival health according to the Loe and Silness Gingival Index, two out of three showed a significant reduction, while one study showed no change.

Citation: Slot DE, Dorfer CE, Van der Weijden GA. The efficacy of interdental brushes on plaque and parameters of periodontal inflammation: a systematic review. International Journal of Dental Hygiene, 2008; 6: 253-264.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. Full text online access is available to NHS staff in England via ATHENS passwords. To apply for an ATHENS password and access this resource and many others please go to the ATHENS registration page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: The efficacy of magnetic resonance imaging in the diagnosis of degenerative and inflammatory temporomandibular joint disorders: a systematic literature review
document.publisher: Oral Surgery, Oral Medicine, Oral Pathology, Oral Radiology, and Endodontics
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,DENTO-FACIAL ANOMALIES]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors’ conclusions: The evidence for diagnostic efficiency expressed as sensitivity, specificity and likelihood ratio is insufficient. The results of this review emphasise the need for high-quality studies on the diagnostic efficacy of magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), incorporating accepted methodological criteria.

Methods: A review of 12 studies to evaluate the evidence for the efficacy of MRI in the diagnosis of disk position and configuration, configuration, disk perforation, joint effusion, and osseous and bone marrow changes in the temporomandibular joint. Literature search 1988 to July 2005.

Quality of review: It is likely that search did not identify all key papers. The only database searched was PubMed using very narrow search terms. Although reference lists were checked and some journals handsearched, additional databases employing exhaustive search terms, website searching, and contacting experts may have identified additional papers. Furthermore, limiting the search to published research in the English language may have introduced publication and language biases.  The validity of the included studies was assessed by two reviewers.

Results: The evidence grade for diagnostic efficacy expressed as sensitivity, specificity, and predictive values was insufficient.

Citation: Limchaichana N, Petersson A, Rohlin M. The efficacy of magnetic resonance imaging in the diagnosis of degenerative and inflammatory temporomandibular joint disorders: a systematic literature review. Oral Surgery Oral Medicine Oral Pathology Oral Radiology and Endodontics. 2006; 102(4): 521-36.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: The efficacy of oral irrigation in addition to a toothbrush on plaque and the clinical parameters of periodontal inflammation: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,PREVENTION,TREATMENT & MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: As an adjunct to brushing, the oral irrigator does not have a beneficial effect in reducing visible plaque. However, there is a positive trend in favour of oral irrigation improving gingivial health over regular oral hygiene (the habitual use of oral hygiene products) or toothbrushing only.

Methods: A narrative systematic review of nine studies (4 RCTs, 3 CCTs) to determine the effect of oral irrigation as an adjunct to toothbrushing on plaque and the clinical parameters of periodontal inflammation. Database search date: 1965 to January 2008.

Quality of review:  The review is limited by the quality of the included studies. The authors identify a number of issues and consequently the results should be viewed with caution. None of the included papers appear to have considered the smoking status of their study population. Six of the seven included studies received industry funding. A range of indices were used to measure several different clinical outcomes.

Review authors searched two databases using reasonably comprehensive search terms and reference lists of included studies were checked for published studies in the English language. However it is possible that potentially relevant studies were missed. Searching additional databases and using additional techniques such as hand searching key journals, contacting experts and product manufacturers may have yielded additional papers. Appropriate procedures were used to minimise error and bias in study selection, data extraction and quality assessment. Quality assessment considered randomisation, allocation concealment, examiner blinding and completeness of follow-up. Given the considerable heterogeneity of the included studies, the authors appropriately decided against data synthesis.

Results: None of the selected studies showed a significant difference between the toothbrush plus OI and the toothbrush only group. There are some significant differences in favour of the OI compared with regular oral hygiene (ROH) on plaque and the clinical parameters of periodontitis. With respect to plaque, no significant differences were observed. Three studies showed significant reductions in bleeding for the OI group as compared with the ROH group. When observing visual signs of gingival inflammation, three studies found a significant additional effect of OI as adjunct to ROH. Two of the four studies, showed a significant reduction of the probing depth as a result of OI as an adjunct to toothbrushing.

Citation: Husseini A, Slot DE, Van der Weijden. The efficacy of oral irrigation in addition to a toothbrush on plaque and the clinical parameters of periodontal inflammation: a systematic review. International Journal of Dental Hygiene, 2008; 6: 304-314

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. Full text online access is available to NHS staff in England via ATHENS passwords. To apply for an ATHENS password and access this resource and many others please go to the ATHENS registration page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: The efficacy of woodsticks on plaque and gingival inflammation: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,TREATMENT & MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Woodsticks do not have an additional effect on visible interdental plaque or gingival index, but do, however, provide an improvement in interdental gingival inflammation by reducing the bleeding tendency.

Methods: A narrative systematic review of eight studies (6 RCTs, 2 CCTs) to determine whether a hand-held triangular woodstick, as compared with no adjunct or another interdental cleaning device can improve the clinical parameters of gingival inflammation. Database search dates: inception to February 2008.

Quality of review: The review is limited by the quality of the included studies. The authors identify a number of issues and consequently the results should be viewed with caution. None of the included papers appear to have considered the smoking status of their study population. A range of indices were used to measure several different clinical outcomes. None of the included studies provided data on participant smoking status. Length of follow up short was short: 3 weeks to 3½ months. There was significant heterogeneity between studies in terms of age, oral health status and comparator treatments.

The authors searched two databases using adequate search terms and checked references of included papers. It is possible that relevant papers were missed as the search was restricted to published literature in the English language, which may have introduced bias. Study selection was conducted independently in duplicate. Similar information is not provided for quality assessment and data extraction. The quality of the included studies was assessed in terms of randomisation (including allocation concealment), blinding of examiners and completeness of follow-up.

Results: Any effect size appears to be limited. Five studies measured plaque index with only one showing a statistically significant reduction (p<0.05).Three studies measured mean bleeding scores with two showing statistically significant reductions. 

Citation: Hoenderdos NL, Slot DE, Paraskevas S, Van der Weijden GA. The efficacy of woodsticks on plaque and gingival inflammation: a systematic review. International Journal of Dental Hygiene, 2008; 6 (4); 280-289.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. Full text online access is available to NHS staff in England via ATHENS passwords. To apply for an ATHENS password and access this resource and many others please go to the ATHENS registration page. 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: The feasibility of smoking reduction: an update
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: These results indicate that reduction is feasible when aided by treatment. Whether reduction should be promoted will depend on the effect of reduction on health outcomes and future cessation.

Methods: Qualitative systematic review.

Quality of review: A thorough search was conducted for published and unpublished research using several databases, abstracts of annual meetings and contacting relevant pharmaceutical companies.  No formal method was reported for assessing the quality of included studies, however, the authors did look at whether trial results were reported as statistically significant and whether analysis was based in intention to treat. The authors appropriately reported that heterogeneity of the included studies precluded a meta-analysis. 

Results: Few daily smokers spontaneously reduce. Among those who try to stop smoking and relapse, some return to reduced smoking but whether they maintain this reduction is unclear. Nicotine replacement (and perhaps behavior therapies) can induce smokers not interested in quitting to make significant reductions in their smoking and maintain these over time. Some compensatory smoking occurs with reduction but significant declines in smoke exposure still occur.

Citation: Hughes JR, Carpenter MJ, The feasibility of smoking reduction: an update, Addiction 2005; 100 (8): 1074-1089 

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. Full text online access is available to NHS staff in England via ATHENS passwords. To apply for an ATHENS password and to access this resource and many others please go to the ATHENS registration page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: The impact of malocclusion/orthodontic treatment need on the quality of life
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,DENTO-FACIAL ANOMALIES,ORTHODONTICS]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

_____________________________________________________________________________

 

Authors' conclusions: Findings of this review suggest that there is an association (albeit modest) between malocclusion/orthodontic treatment need and quality of life. There is a need for further studies of their relationship, particularly studies that employ standardized assessment methods so that outcomes are uniform and thus amenable to meta-analysis.

Methods: A narrative systematic review of 23 studies (19 cross sectional and 4 longitudinal) to assess the current evidence of the relationship between malocclusion/orthodontic treatment need and quality of life.

Quality of review:  A good attempt was made to identify relevant studies published in a range of languages, by searching several databases and using comprehensive search terms. These searches were also supplemented with journal handsearching and reference list checking. Unpublished/grey literature was not sought, which could potentially have introduced publication bias.

The quality of the included studies was assessed using predefined criteria, and the authors conclusions appear appropriate given the type of research identified.

Results: Eighteen articles described findings in child/adolescent study populations and five described findings in adult populations. An observed association between HRQoL and malocclusion/orthodontic treatment need was generally detected irrespective of how they were assessed. However the strength of the association could be described as modest at best.

Citation: Liu Z, McGrath C, Hägg U. The impact of alocclusion/orthodontic treatment need on the quality of life. Angle Orthodontist 2009; 79(3): 585-91.

Access: The full text of this paper is freely available

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: The impact of polyol-containing chewing gums on dental caries: A systematic review of original randomized controlled trials and observational studies
document.publisher: Journal of the American Dental Association
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,DENTAL CARIES,CAUSES & PREVENTION]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Although research gaps exist, particularly on optimal dosing and relative polyol efficacy, research evidence supports using polyol-containing chewing gum as part of normal oral hygiene to prevent dental caries.

Methods: A systematic review of 14 studies [19 papers – 1 RCT, 4 cluster RCTs, 8 CCTs and 4 cohorts] designed to assess the impact of polyol-containing chewing gum on dental caries compared with the effect with no chewing gum. Database search dates: inception to May 2008. Sub-group meta-analyses were conducted using combinations of the 5 RCTs and 8 CCTs.

Quality of review: It is likely that the authors did not identify all potentially relevant studies. Searching a wider range of electronic sources with more comprehensive search terms and without language restrictions, reference list checking, hand-searching key journals, contacting experts and manufacturers may have identified additional studies. Appropriate procedures were used to minimise error and bias in study selection, data extraction and quality assessment. Validity was assessed using the Jadad Scale for RCTs and the US Preventive Services Taskforce criteria.for the remaining studies.

Results: Provided as prevented fractions (PF) – the proportional reduction in dental caries between the intervention group and the control. The use of xylitol, xylitol-sorbitol blend and sorbitol were associated with mean prevented PF of 58.66%  (95% CI: 35.42-81.90), 52.82% (CI: 39.64-66.00) and 20.01% (12.74-27.27), respectively. For the sorbitol-mannitol blend, it was 10.71% percent (-20.50-41.93), which was not statistically significant. Sensitivity analyses confirmed the robustness of the findings.

Citation: Deshpande A, Jadad AR. The impact of polyol-containing chewing gums on dental caries: A systematic review of original randomized controlled trials and observational studies. Journal of the American Dental Association, 2008; 139;1602-1614.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance.  You can find your local library via the My Library home page.
