document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: The influence of malocclusion on masticatory performance
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORTHODONTICS]]>
document.body:
This is a provisional record for information. The review has been identified as potentially meeting our quality criteria. It will be critically appraised and a quality statement provided as soon as possible.
_____________________________________________________

 

Objective: To systematically review the relationship between malocclusions and masticatory performance. In addition, we will perform a qualitative analysis of the methodological soundness of the studies.

Materials and Methods: A literature survey was done by applying the Medline database in the period from January 1965 to June 2009, using the “Medical Subject Headings” term malocclusion crossed with various combinations of the following terms: masticatory performance, masticatory efficiency, and chewing efficiency. The articles were separated into two main topics: (1) the influence of malocclusion treatment (orthognathic surgery) and (2) the influence of malocclusion type and severity.

Results: The search strategy used identified 78 articles. After selection according to the inclusion/exclusion criteria, 12 articles qualified for the final analysis. The research quality and methodological soundness were high in one study, medium in 10 studies, and low in one study. The most serious shortcomings comprised the clinical trials and controlled clinical trials designs with small sample sizes and inadequate description of selection criteria. Lack of method error analysis and the absence of blinding in measurements were other examples of shortcomings.

Conclusions: Malocclusions cause decreased masticatory performance, especially as it relates to reduced occlusal contacts area. The influence of malocclusion treatment (orthognathic surgery) on masticatory performance is only measurable 5 years after treatment.

Citation: Magalhaes IB, Pereira LJ, Marques LS, Gameiro GH. The influence of malocclusion on masticatory performance. The Angle Orthodontist 2010; 80(5):981-7

Access: Full-text of this paper is freely available

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: The longevity of dental restorations: A systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,DENTAL CARIES,TREATMENT & MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Overall, the review found that in permanent teeth, amalgam is the most durable material followed by inlays, composite and glass ionomer cements. The order in primary teeth is the same with the exception of inlays which are rarely prescribed.

Methods: A systematic review of 195 studies including randomised controlled trials, other clinical trials, prospective and retrospective studies with concurrent controls.

Quality of review: The review was limited by the quality of included studies. There were few long term studies available, and results often reported after relatively short periods of time (12 or 24 months). There was also a lack of practice based studies making the results of the review difficult to generalise to the primary care setting.

Results: The best results occurred with amalgam where in permanent teeth the survival function at nine years was 93% (CI 92.1% to 93.0%). In primary teeth a restoration survival function of 90.8% of up to five years was found (CI 88.5% to 93.1%).

With composite restoration in permanent teeth a survival function of 90% (CI 89.3% to 90.7%) was found for the first three years but declined to 59% at eight years (CI 56.0% to 61.9%).

Both ceramic inlays and gold inlays had a survival function of over 90% for the first four years, but declined after that point to yield a survival function of 68% at 7 years.

Glass ionomers in permanent teeth had a survival function of 90.3% (CI 88.9% to 91.7%) , declining steadily to 64.9% by five years. (CI 59.7% to 70.1%)

Therefore Dental amalgam is the material of choice as it lasts longest and is the cheapest. Unless there is a contradiction (which is usually aesthetics or pregnancy) it is recommended for routine use wherever possible.

For each restoration material, the data for cavity types was pooled. Class II restorations are not in general as durable as class I and V therefore results may over estimate survival of class II restorations and underestimate survival for other restoration classes.

Citation: Chadwick B, Dummer P, Dunstan F, et al. The Longevity of Dental Restorations: A Systematic Review. NHS Centre for Reviews and Dissemination. Report 19

Access: Available to the general public

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: The long-term effect of a mouthrinse containing essential oils on dental plaque and gingivitis: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CAUSES & PREVENTION,PERIODONTOLOGY,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,DENTAL CARIES,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORAL DISORDERS,ORAL HEALTH,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CONDITIONS D-E,DENTAL CONDITIONS,CONDITIONS A-Z,HERBAL MEDICINE,DECEMBER 2009]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: When used as an adjunct to unsupervised oral hygiene, a mouthrinse containing essential oils (EO) provides an additional benefit with regard to plaque and gingivitis reduction as compared to a placebo or control.

Methods: A systematic review and meta-analysis of 11 randomised controlled trials looking at the long term effect of EO on dental plaque and gingivitis. Literature search to December 2006.

Quality of review: There was no thorough attempt to identify all relevant studies. Only two databases were searched (Medline and Central) plus reference list checking. Additional databases, handsearching journals, contacting experts and website searching may have identified additional papers. Furthermore, the search was restricted to published paper written in English which may have introduced publication and language bias. There may also be potential bias given that eight of the eleven studies included in the review were funded or associated with the company that manufactures a well known and widely available essential oil-containing mouthrinse.

The results of the meta-analyses should be viewed cautiously due to the significant heterogeneity between the studies which varied greatly in the interventions and comparisons used and sample sizes. The clinical significance of the mouthwash effects should also be carefully considered due to the small WMDs observed.

Results: In all studies, EO was used as an adjunct to regular daily toothbrushing. A statistically significant reduction in overall gingivitis was noted compared to the control (weighted mean difference [WMD]: -0.32, 95% confidence interval [CI]: -0.46 to -0.19, p<0.00001). For interproximal sites the use of the test mouthrinse resulted in significantly more gingivitis reduction compared to control mouthrinse (WMD: -0.29, 95% CI: -0.48 to -0.11, p = 0.002), whereas no differences were observed compared to dental floss. With respect to plaque scores, EO produced significant overall reductions in plaque (WMD: -0.83, 95% CI: -1.13 to -0.53, p<0.00001). Separate analysis for interproximal areas revealed that EO resulted in more pronounced plaque drops compared to the control mouthrinse (WMD: -1.02, 95% CI: -1.44 to -0.60, p<0.00001) or the use of floss (WMD: -0.75, 95% CI: -1.15 to -0.363, p<0.0002). Most studies agreed that EO did not produce more staining than the control products.

Citation: Stoeken JE, Paraskevas S, van der Weijden GA.The long-term effect of a mouthrinse containing essential oils on dental plaque and gingivitis: a systematic review.Journal of Periodontology 2007; 78(7): 1218-28.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance.  You can find your local library via the My Library home page. 

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: The management of otitis media with early routine insertion of grommets in children with cleft palate - a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,DENTO-FACIAL ANOMALIES,ENT AND AUDIOLOGY,EAR & AUDITORY SYSTEM DISORDERS,MIDDLE EAR,OTITIS MEDIA,OTITIS MEDIA WITH EFFUSION,CONDITIONS,THERAPEUTIC INTERVENTIONS,SURGICAL PROCEDURES,OTOLOGIC SURGICAL PROCEDURES,MIDDLE EAR VENTILATION]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors’ conclusions: There is currently insufficient evidence on which to base the clinical practice of early routine grommet placement in children with cleft palate.

Methods: a systematic review of 18 studies (eight case series, six historical cohort studies, three prospective cohort studies, and one randomized trial) to determine whether early routine grommet insertion in children with cleft palate has a beneficial effect on hearing and speech and language development compared with conservative management.

Quality of review: The results of this review are limited by the poor quality of the included studies. The authors made a reasonable attempt to identify relevant papers, searching a range of databases without language restrictions and supplemented by reference list checking. It does not appear that an attempt was made to identify unpublished studies which may have introduced bias.

Appropriate procedures were used to minimise error and bias in study selection and data extraction the quality assessment process is unclear.

Results: Most studies were either small or of poor quality or both. The results of the studies were contradictory, with some studies suggesting early placement of grommets was beneficial and others reporting there was no benefit.

Citation: Ponduri S, Bradley R, Ellis PE, Brookes ST, Sandy JR, Ness AR. The management of otitis media with early routine insertion of grommets in children with cleft palate -- a systematic review. Cleft Palate and Craniofacial Journal 2009; 46(1):30-8.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: The parental dentocraniofacial phenotype-an orofacial clefting microform
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,DENTO-FACIAL ANOMALIES]]>
document.body:
This is a provisional record for information. The review has been identified as potentially meeting our quality criteria. It will be critically appraised and a quality statement provided as soon as possible.
_____________________________________________________

 

Objective: Using the systematic review method, (1) to identify the investigations of the parental dentocraniofacial phenotype in orofacial clefting, (2) synthesize the data to derive a model of the phenotypic features that will assist in the identification of cleft morphogenes, and (3) make recommendations for the future global strategy for researching the parental craniofacial phenotype in orofacial clefting.

Search strategy: The Cochrane, Medline (via PubMed and OVID platforms [1966 to December 2006]), Embase, CINAHL, and ASKSAM Orthodontic Reference Database (1950-1997) databases were searched using a combination of the following keywords: microform, parent, craniofacial, dental, and cleft. All published articles were reviewed. There were no exclusions of non-English reports. Of the 36 studies identified using this strategy, 26 met the inclusion criteria.

Data abstraction/Synthesis: The statistically significant data were abstracted using a pro forma, and the methodological quality of the selected studies was evaluated using a checklist. There was considerable heterogeneity among the studies, and therefore it was not possible to synthesize the data. We were, however, able to collate the data.

Results/Conclusions: (1) The craniofacial phenotype possessed by parents of children with orofacial clefting is distinctive when compared with that of the noncleft population. (2) There is insufficient evidence to produce a model of the phenotypic features to assist in the search for orofacial clefting morphogenes. (3) The pattern of expression of the phenotypic features identified to date supports the contention that there are differences in the inheritance of cleft lip with or without cleft palate and isolated cleft palate. Progress in this field is affected by extreme heterogeneity in etiology of cleft lip with or without cleft palate, as well as heterogeneity in study design. (4) Subphenotyping using features such as microforms should be employed to reduce the heterogeneity and to improve the power of future genetic investigations and will also assist in clinical management and genetic counseling for families 

Citation: Mossey PA, Batra P, McIntyre GT. The parental dentocraniofacial phenotype-an orofacial clefting microform. Cleft Palate-Craniofacial Journal 2010; 47(1):22-34 

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: The prevalence and incidence of coronary heart disease is significantly increased in periodontitis: a meta-analysis
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,PERIODONTOLOGY,ASSOCIATED CONDITIONS]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: This meta-analysis indicates that both the prevalence and incidence of coronary heart disease (CHD) are significantly increased in periodontitis (PD). Therefore, PD may be a risk factor for CHD. Prospective studies are required to prove this assumption and evaluate risk reduction with the treatment of PD.

Methods: Previous studies have shown conflicting results as to whether periodontitis (PD) is associated with increased risk of coronary heart disease (CHD). The aim of the current study was to evaluate whether such an association exists. A systematic review of 5 prospective cohort studies (follow-up >6 years), 5 case-control studies, and 5 cross-sectional studies. Literature search to 2006.

Quality of review: A moderate quality systematic review. Selection of included studies, data extraction and quality appraisal was conducted by two independent reviewers. However, it is possible that the search strategy missed key papers as unpublished research was not sought and search terms appear basic. It is unclear whether non-English language papers were eligible for inclusion. The possibility of language and publication bias cannot be excluded. 

Results: Meta-analysis of the 5 prospective cohort studies (86092 patients) indicated that individuals with PD had a 1.14 times higher risk of developing CHD than the controls (relative risk 1.14, 95% CI 1.074-1.213, P < .001). The case-control studies (1423 patients) showed an even greater risk of developing CHD (OR 2.22, 95% CI 1.59-3.117, P < .001). The prevalence of CHD in the cross-sectional studies (17724 patients) was significantly greater among individuals with PD than in those without PD (OR 1.59, 95% CI 1.329-1.907, P < .001). When the relationship between number of teeth and incidence of CHD was analyzed, cohort studies showed 1.24 times increased risk (95% CI 1.14-1.36, P < .0001) of development of CHD in patients with <10 teeth.

Citation: Bahekar AA, Singh S, Saha S, Molnar A, Arora R. The prevalence and incidence of coronary heart disease is significantly increased in periodontitis: A meta-analysis. American Heart Journal 2007; 154(5): 830-837

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: The psychosocial impact of orthognathic surgery: A systematic review
document.publisher: American Journal of Orthodontics and Dentofacial Orthopedics
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,DENTO-FACIAL ANOMALIES,ORAL SURGERY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: The included studies indicate that orthognathic surgery can have psychosocial benefits but due to the variations in the study designs it is difficult to quantify the extent and duration of the benefits.

Methods: Narrative systematic review of 29 studies (1 cohort, 16 prospective, 10 retrospective and 2 cross-sectional studies. Literature published from 1984 to December was sought. 

Quality of review: The literature search appears comprehensive, with no language restrictions, although there was no apparent attempt to locate unpublished studies. No formal method for assessing the validity of included studies as reported, although the quality of studies were discussed with the results. Studies were also ordered into a  hierarchy of evidence according to study design.

Results: The results of the review indicated that orthognathic patients experience psychosocial benefits as a result of orthognathic surgery, including improved self-confidence, body and facial image, and social adjustment. However, there were wide variations in the study designs and a lack of uniformity in measuring the psychosocial constructs. This made it difficult to quantify the extent and the duration of the psychosocial benefits.

Citation: Hunt OT, Johnston CD, Hepper PG, Burden DJ. The psychosocial impact of orthognathic surgery: a systematic review. American Journal of Orthodontics and Dentofacial Orthopedics. 2001; 120(5): 490-7.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: The relationship between diabetes mellitus and destructive periodontal disease: a meta-analysis
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,PERIODONTOLOGY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Type 2 diabetes melitus (DM) can be considered a risk factor for periodontitis. More studies are needed to confirm the harmful effects of type 1 DM on periodontal disease.

Methods: A systematic review and meta-analysis of 57 studies (49 cross-sectional, 8 longitudinal) to determine whether there is an association between diabetes melitus and destructive periodontal disease. Sub-group meta-analyses were conducted using 15 cross-sectional studies. Database search dates: January 1980 to  June 2007.

Quality of review: As the authors note, the results of the review are limited by the poor quality of the included studies. Most notably, none adjusted adequately for potential confounders. For example, only 15 of the 49 cross-sectional studies and 2 of the 8 longitudinal studies adjusted for smoking. The authors conducted several sub-group meta-analyses to explore associations. The results for type 2 DM (using between 3 and 5 cross-sectional studies) showed at best limited significance and it is questionable whether the authors’ conclusions are fully supported by the evidence.

The authors made a reasonable attempt to identify relevant studies, searching four databases, supplemented by reference list checking. The search was limited to published studies in the English language which could have introduced bias. Tests did not identify any evidence of publication bias.

Appropriate methods were used to minimise error and bias in selecting and data extracting studies. The authors quality-assessed the included studies using eight criteria. As noted above, quality was poor.

Results: Twenty-seven of the cross-sectional studies detected more periodontal disease in diabetic subjects compared with non-diabetic subjects. The greater risk of periodontal disease progression was associated with type 2 DM, and one study associated DM with response to periodontal therapy. Methodological flaws of most of the studies included inadequate control for confounders, insufficient statistical analysis and lack of information about sampling design. Random effect model showed a significant association with clinical attachment level (mean difference = 1.00 [CI 95% = 0.15 to 1.84; p=0.021]) and periodontal pocket depth (mean difference = 0.46 [CI 95% = 0.01 to 0.91; p=0.046]) between type 2 diabetics and non-diabetics. 

Citation: Chávarry NG, Vettore MV, Sansone C, Sheiham A. The relationship between diabetes mellitus and destructive periodontal disease: a meta-analysis. Oral Health and Preventive Dentistry 2009;7(2):107-27.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: The relationship between waiting time for radiotherapy and clinical outcomes: A systematic review of the literature
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,ORAL CANCER,TREATMENT & MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: The risk of local recurrence increases with increasing waiting times (WTs) for radiotherapy (RT). The increase in local recurrence rate may translate into decreased survival in some clinical situations. WTs for RT should be as short as reasonably achievable.

Methods: A systematic review of observational studies to determine the clinical evidence relating waiting times for radiotherapy to its outcomes. Literature search 1975 to July 2005. 

Quality of review: The authors searched a range of databases (PubMed HealthSTAR, Cancerlit and the Cochrane Library) without language restrictions, albeit with restrictive search terms. They also checked conference abstracts and reference lists of included papers. Four authors independently assessed the quality of the included studies using stated criteria. However, the results of this review should be treated with some caution. Whilst the authors identified heterogeneity between the included studies, they conducted a meta-analysis using a fixed effects rather than a random effects model. It is notable that the results of higher weight studies were either non- or marginally significant.

Results: Meta-analysis demonstrated a significant increase in the risk of local failure with increasing waiting time. For post operative radiotherapy for head and neck cancer, the relative risk (RR) of local recurrence per month was 1.28 (CI: 1.08-1.52) and for definitive radiotherapy the RR was 1.15 (CI: 1.02-1.29). There was a marginally significant decrease in survival in four studies of head and neck cancer: RR of death per month was 1.16 (CI:1.02-1.32)

Citation: Chen Z, King W, Pearcey R, Kerba M, Mackillop WJ.The relationship between waiting time for radiotherapy and clinical outcomes. Radiotherapy and Oncology 2008; 87(1): 3-16

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: The relationship of alcohol dependence and alcohol consumption with periodontitis: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,PERIODONTOLOGY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Alcohol consumption can be considered a risk indicator for periodontitis. Longitudinal studies on the association of alcohol dependence and alcohol consumption with periodontitis are needed to confirm the association or not.

Methods: A narrative systematic review of 16 studies (11 cross-sectional and 5 prospective longitudional) to examine the relationship of alcohol dependence and alcohol consumption with periodontitis. Database search dates: January 1965 to July 2008.

Quality of review: The results of this review should be viewed with caution. Much of the evidence identified comes from cross-sectional studies, which is not an appropriate study type to confirm a causal relationship. Two of the four prospective longitudinal studies included failed to detect an association with alcohol consumption and, as the authors state, additional prospective longitudinal studies are required to confirm whether or not there is a direct association.

A fair attempt was made to identify relevant studies. Four electronic databases were searched and reference lists of included studies checked. However, it is possible that potentially relevant studies were missed. The search terms were restrictive and only published studies in English were sought. Appropriate procedures were used to minimise error and bias in study selection, however it is unclear whether similar procedures were used to quality assess and data extract included studies. There was considerable inter-study heterogeneity and the authors appropriately decided not to conduct a meta-analysis.

Results: Seven of the 12 studies on alcohol consumption and 4 of the 4 studies on alcohol dependence reported positive associations between alcohol intake and periodontitis.

Citation: Amaral Cda S, Vettore MV, Leão A. Journal of Dentistry 2009; 37(9):643-51. Epub 2009 May 23. The relationship of alcohol dependence and alcohol consumption with periodontitis: a systematic review.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: The role of parental presence in the context of children's medical procedures: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PAEDIATRIC DENTISTRY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Although parental presence may not have a clear, direct influence on child distress and behavioural outcomes, there are potential advantages for parents. It seems appropriate that clinicians provide parents with the opportunity to be present during their child's painful procedure. 

Methods: Systematic review of 28 studies (including 9 randomised controlled trials) to assess the effects of parental presence in the paediatric treatment room on child, parent and health professional outcomes. Studies included a total of 1256 children with a parent present and 1025 children without a parent present. One pseudo-randomised controlled trial investigated dental treatments (with 16 parents present and 16 absent).

Quality of Review: Generally a well conducted systematic review.  The search covered published and unpublished research.  Several databases were searched, reference lists of included studies were checked, experts were contacted and there were no year or language restrictions. Included studies were coded by one reviewer for study design, sample size, levels of evidence, outcomes used and study quality and a secind reviewer conducted reliability checks.

Results: There were mixed findings regarding the effect of parental presence on measures of child distress and affect, however, studies of lower levels of evidence were more likely to report significant results. Parents who were present during their child's medical intervention were either better off or no different from parents who were absent with regard to their levels of distress and satisfaction.

There was no evidence of increased technical complications nor elevated staff anxiety for health professionals attending to children with a parent present as compared to attending to children without their parents.

Citation: Piira T, Sugiura T, Champion GD, Donnelly N, Cole ASJ. The role of parental presence in the context of children's medical procedures: a systematic review. Child: Care, Health & Development. 2005; 31(2): 233-243.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Therapy of peri-implantitis: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,PERIODONTOLOGY,RESTORATIVE DENTISTRY]]>
document.body:
Authors' conclusions: The selected studies are too limited in number and exhibit small sample sizes and short follow-up periods.Therefore, there is a definite need for more well-designed, preferably longitudinal, randomized controlled clinical trials. Within the limitations of the selected studies, mechanical debridement combined with antiseptic/antibiotic therapy, the Er:YAG laser or regenerative techniques may be used for treating peri-implantitis, but the indications for each of these techniques have not been delineated clearly.

Methods: A systematic review of five randomised controlled trials to consider the efficacy of treatments for peri-implantitis. Literature search from inception to July 2007.

Quality of review: As the authors indicate, the review is limited by the small number and poor quality of included studies.

It is possible that potentially relevant papers were missed. Only two databases were searched (PubMed and Central) using very limited search terms. The addition of reference list checking and hand searching an extensive range of key journals may have gone some way to compensate for this. However, restricting inclusion to published studies in English could have introduced bias. Appropriate procedures were used to minimise error and bias in study selection, data extraction and quality assessment. 

Results: Certain data tend to indicate:

  • Sub-mucosal debridement alone may not be adequate for the removal of bacterial load from the surfaces of implants with peri-implant pockets =5 mm.
  • The use of the Er:YAG laser can improve peri-implant clinical parameters within 6 months, but it remains unclear whether these effects can be maintained over time.
  • The combination of minocycline and mechanical debridement appears to provide an improved treatment outcome, although to a limited extent, compared with the combination of chlorhexidine and mechanical debridement, at least during a short-term period of 12 months.
  • Guided bone regeneration or the application of a bone substitute (nanocrystalline hydroxyapatite) can be efficacious for the treatment of peri-implantitis lesions.

Citation: Kotsovilis S, Karoussis IK, Trianti M, Fourmousis I. Therapy of peri-implantitis: a systematic review. Journal of Clinical Periodontology 2008; 35(7): 621-9.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: TMD in relation to malocclusion and orthodontic treatment: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,DENTO-FACIAL ANOMALIES,ORTHODONTICS]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors’ conclusions: Associations between specific types of malocclusions and development of significant signs and symptoms of temporomandibular disorder (TMD) could not be verified. There is still a need for longitudinal studies.

Methods: A systematic review of 30 studies to evaluate associations between different malocclusions, orthodontic treatment, and signs and symptoms of TMD. Literature search 1966 to May 2003. A later update was made in January 2005.

Quality of review: Study selection and quality appraisal of included papers was performed independently in duplicate using predefined criteria. However, as the authors acknowledge, the restrictions in the number of databases and languages may have yielded fewer articles than a more comprehensive search. Only Medline and Cochrane databases were searched, without reference list checking, handsearching journals or contacting experts. Papers were restricted to English or Scandinavian languages and unpublished research was not sought – this may have introduced publication and language bias.  The results of the 9 studies judged to be of moderate evidence are clearly displayed, whereas the results of the 21 papers of limited evidence are not fully presented.

Results: Associations between certain malocclusions and TMD were found in some studies, whereas the majority of the reviewed articles failed to identify significant and clinically important associations. TMD could not be correlated to any specific type of malocclusion, and there was no support for the belief that orthodontic treatment may cause TMD. Obvious individual variations in signs and symptoms of TMD over time according to some longitudinal studies further emphasized the difficulty in establishing malocclusion as a significant risk factor for TMD. A considerable reduction in signs and symptoms of TMD between the teenage period and young adulthood has been shown in some recent longitudinal studies.

Citation: Mohlin B, Axelsson S, Paulin G, Pietilä T, Bondemark L, Brattström V et al. TMD in relation to malocclusion and orthodontic treatment: A Systematic Review. The Angle Orthodontist 2007; 77(3): 542–548.

Access: Full text of the paper is freely available to the general public.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Tooth survival following non-surgical root canal treatment: a systematic review of the literature
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ENDODONTICS]]>
document.body:
This is a provisional record for information. The review has been identified as potentially meeting our quality criteria. It will be critically appraised and a quality statement provided as soon as possible.
_____________________________________________________

Aims: To investigate (i) the effect of study characteristics on reported tooth survival after root canal treatment (RCTx) and (ii) the effect of clinical factors on the proportion of root filled teeth surviving after RCTx.

Methodology: Longitudinal human clinical studies investigating tooth survival after RCTx which were published up to the end of 2007 were identified electronically (MEDLINE and Cochrane database 1966-2007 December, week 4). In addition, four journals (Dental Traumatology, International Endodontic Journal, Journal of Endodontics, Oral Surgery Oral Medicine Oral Pathology Oral Radiology & Endodontics), bibliographies of all relevant articles and review articles were hand searched. Two reviewers (Y-LN, KG) assessed and selected the studies based on specified inclusion criteria and extracted the data onto a pre-designed proforma, independently. The criteria were as follows: (i) clinical study on RCTx; (ii) stratified analysis of primary and secondary RCTx available; (iii) sample size given and larger than 10; (iv) at least 6-month postoperative review; (v) success based on survival of tooth; and (vi) proportion of teeth surviving after treatment given or could be calculated from the raw data. Three strands of evidence or analyses were used to triangulate a consensus view. The reported findings from individual studies, including those excluded for quantitative analysis, were utilized for the intuitive synthesis, which constituted the first strand of evidence. Secondly, the pooled weighted proportion of teeth surviving and thirdly the combined effects of potential prognostic factors were estimated using the fixed and random effects meta-analyses on studies fulfilling all the inclusion criteria.

Results: Of the 31 articles identified, 14 studies published between 1993 and 2007 were included. The majority of studies were retrospective (n = 10) and only four prospective. The pooled percentages of reported tooth survival over 2-3, 4-5 and 8-10 years following RCTx were 86% (95% CI: 75%, 98%), 93% (95% CI: 92%, 94%) and 87% (95% CI: 82%, 92%), respectively. Substantial differences in study characteristics were found to hinder effective direct comparison of findings. Evidence for the effect of prognostic factors on tooth survival was weak. Based on the data available for meta-analyses, four conditions were found to significantly improve tooth survival. In descending order of influence, the conditions increasing observed proportion of survival were as follows: (i) a crown restoration after RCTx; (ii) tooth having both mesial and distal proximal contacts; (iii) tooth not functioning as an abutment for removable or fixed prosthesis; and (iv) tooth type or specifically non-molar teeth. Statistical heterogeneity was substantial in some cases but its source could not be investigated because of insufficient available information.

Conclusions: The pooled proportion of teeth surviving over 2-10 years following RCTx ranged between 86% and 93%. Four factors (listed above) were identified as significant prognostic factors with concurrence between all three strands of evidence 

Citation: Ng YL, Mann V, Gulabivala K. Tooth survival following non-surgical root canal treatment: a systematic review of the literature. International Endodontic Journal 2010; 43(3):171-189 

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Treatment and follow-up of oral dysplasia - A systematic review and meta-analysis
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,ORAL CANCER,RISK FACTORS]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Oral dysplasia appears to carry a significant transformation rate to oral cancer, which occurs over a period of years, even when treated by surgical excision. This would suggest that patients should be kept under surveillance after diagnosis for anything up to 20 years. It may be feasible to tailor the duration of the surveillance period, and possibly its frequency, according to several clinical factors, including grade of dysplasia, and clinical management (lesions which are not excised). However, the limited data available for this review can neither confirm nor reject the hypothesis that higher grade dysplastic lesions would transform earlier.

Methods: A systematic review and meta-analysis of 14 observational studies (6 prospective, 8 retrospective) with 992 patients to inform the management and surveillance of oral dysplasia. Database searches to June 2008.

Quality of review: As the authors state, the review is limited by the paucity of high quality follow-up studies.  Few of the included studies had adequate follow-up rates and none blinded outcome assessment. Although management of confounders was considered as part of the quality evaluation, no information on this is provided in the review.

It is possible that potentially relevant papers were missed. Whilst the authors searched several databases and supplemented the search by reference list checking, the search terms used were limited and inclusion limited to published papers. It is unclear whether there were any language restrictions.

Appropriate methods were used to minimise error and bias in study selection, data extraction and quality assessment processes. There was considerable clinical and statistical heterogeneity between studies. The authors used a random effects model in their calculations, but the degree of heterogeneity suggests that it may not have been appropriate to conduct a meta-analysis.

Results: There was considerable heterogeneity between studies: mean overall MTR = 12.1% (confidence interval: 8.1%, 17.9%) and mean TMT = 4.3 years. Histologic grade significantly affected mean MTR (p < .008). Lesions that were not excised demonstrated considerably higher MTR than those that were excised (p = .003).

Citation: Mehanna HM, Rattay T, Smith J, McConkey CC. Treatment and follow-up of oral dysplasia - A systematic review and meta-analysis. Head & Neck 2009; 31(12):1600-9.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Treatment of gingival recession with coronally advanced flap procedures: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,PERIODONTOLOGY,RESTORATIVE DENTISTRY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors’ conclusions: connective tissue graft or enamel matrix derivative in conjunction with coronally advanced flap (CAF) enhances the probability of obtaining complete root coverage (CRC) in Miller Class I and II single gingival recessions.

Methods: A systematic review and meta-analysis of 25 randomised controlled trials to consider the efficacy of coronally advanced flap alone or in combination with tissue grafts, barrier membranes, enamel matrix derivative (EMD) or other material for treating gingival recession. Database search: January 2000 to August 2007.

Quality of review: A systematic review using a high quality methodology. It is possible that studies were missed as the authors did not use comprehensive search terms. However, the range of snowballing techniques used – reference list checking, hand searching journals, contacting experts - may have counteracted this. Appropriate procedures were used to minimise error and bias in study selection and quality assessment. The authors used Cochrane methods to assess validity (adequate allocation concealment; outcome assessors blinded to treatment outcome and completeness of follow-up).

Results: The results of meta-analyses showed that only two combinations: (CAF + CTG and CAF + EMD) provided better results than CAF alone. CAF + CTG resulted in better clinical outcomes for both complete root coverage (OR52.49) and recession reduction at follow-up visit (10.49 mm) compared with CAF, and no other therapy provided better results than CAF + CT.

Citation: Cairo F, Pagliaro U, Nieri M. Treatment of gingival recession with coronally advanced flap procedures: a systematic review. Journal of Clinical Periodontology, 2008; 35: 136-162.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Treatment outcome of immediate, early and conventional single-tooth implants in the aesthetic zone: a systematic review to survival, bone level, soft tissue, aesthetics and patient satisfaction.
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,RESTORATIVE DENTISTRY]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: The included literature suggests that promising short-term results could be achieved for immediate, early and conventional single-implants in the aesthetic zone. However, important parameters such as aesthetic outcome, soft-tissue aspects, and patient satisfaction were clearly underexposed. The question whether immediate and early single-implant therapies would result in better treatment outcomes remained inconclusive due to lack of well-designed controlled clinical studies.

Methods: A systematic review and meta-analysis of 19 prospective longitudinal studies (15 included in meta-analysis) to determine the outcome of single-implant restorations in the aesthetic zone with natural adjacent teeth using immediate, early and conventional implant approaches. Database search from inception to June 2008.

Quality of review: The authors searched a reasonable range of databases along with the reference lists of included studies for papers in a number of languages. However, it is likely that potentially relevant studies were missed. The combination of search terms will have limited the results and it does not appear that an attempt was made to identify unpublished studies and grey literature. Appropriate procedures were used to minimise error and bias in study selection, data extraction and quality assessment. Seven studies were excluded on grounds of quality.

Results: A meta-analysis of 15 studies showed an overall survival rate of 95.5% [95% CI: 93.0–97.1] after 1 year. All lost implants failed within 6 months of installation. A stratified meta-analysis revealed no differences in survival between immediate, early and conventional implant strategies. Little marginal peri-implant bone resorption was found together with low incidence of biological and technical complications. No significant differences in outcome measures were reported in clinical trials comparing immediate, early or conventional implant strategies.

Citation: den Hartog L, Huddleston Slater JJR, Vissink A, Meijer HJA, Raghoebar GM. Treatment outcome of immediate, early and conventional single-tooth implants in the aesthetic zone: a systematic review to survival, bone level, soft tissue, aesthetics and patient satisfaction. Journal of Clinical Periodontology, 2008; 35; 1073-1086.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance.  You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

_____________________________________________________________

See also: De Rouck T, Collys K, Cosyn J. Single-tooth replacement in the Anterior Maxilla by means of immediate implantation and provisionalization: A review. The International Journal of Oral and Maxillofacial Implants, 2008; 23 (5): 897-904.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Trismus in head and neck oncology: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,ORAL CANCER,ENT AND AUDIOLOGY,LARYNX & PHARYNX DISORDERS,NEOPLASMS,BENIGN,MALIGNANT,CONDITIONS,TREATMENT & MANAGEMENT,ORAL CARE FOR CANCER PATIENTS,RADIOTHERAPY,HEAD & NECK CANCER]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: The knowledge about trismus remains scarce and effects of therapeutic interventions are rarely investigated. Research into criteria for trismus, functional consequences of trismus, risk factors for trismus and interventions studies are needed.

Methods: Systematic review of 1 randomised controlled trial and 3 cohort studies to identify criteria for trismus in head and neck cancer, the evidence for risk factors for trismus and the interventions to treat trismus. Literature search 1966 to June 2003.

Quality of review: Two independent reviewers applied stringent criteria to only include higher quality studies, but the results are limited by the low quality of research available. It is possible that key papers may have been missed during the literature search. Despite searching three databases for evidence, publication and language bias may have been introduced as unpublished research was not sought and only English, German and Dutch papers were included.

Results: Radiotherapy (follow-up: 6–12 months) involving the structures of the temporomandibular joint and or pterygoid muscles reduces mouth opening with 18% (SD 17%).

Exercises using a therabite device or tongue blades increase mouth opening significantly (no follow-up), effect sizes (ES) 2.6 and 1.5 respectively.

Microcurrent electrotherapy (follow-up 3 months) and pentoxifylline (no follow-up) increases mouth opening significantly (ES for both: 0.3).

Citation: Dijkstra PU, Kalk WWI, Roodenburg JLN. Trismus in head and neck oncology: a systematic review. Oral Oncology 2004; 40: 897-889.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: True incisor intrusion attained during orthodontic treatment: A systematic review and meta-analysis
document.publisher: American Journal of Orthodontics and Dentofacial Orthopedics
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,ORTHODONTICS]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: True incisor intrusion is achievable in both arches, but the clinical significance of the magnitude of true intrusion as the sole treatment option is questionable for patients with severe deepbite. In nongrowing patients, the segmented arch technique can produce 1.5 mm of incisor intrusion in the maxillary arch and 1.9 mm in the mandibular arch.

Methods: Electronic databases were searched to identify clinical trials that assessed true incisor intrusion through cephalometric analysis and factored out craniofacial growth when required. Literature search 1966 - February 2004.

Quality of review: A good attempt was made to identify all relevant research in a large number of databases.  However, unpublished research does not appear to have been sought which may have introduced publication bias.  There was only limited information reported regarding the inclusion criteria and the design of the studies looked for or identified.  No formal method of assessing the quality of included studies, however studies that did not state error of measurements or evaluate 'true' intrusion were not included.

Results: Twenty-eight articles met the initial inclusion criteria, but 24 were rejected because they did not quantify true incisor intrusion or factor out normal growth impact when required. The remaining 4 articles showed that true incisor intrusion is attainable (0.26 to 1.88 mm for the maxillary incisors and -0.19 to 2.84 mm for the mandibular incisors) but with large variability depending on the appliance used. A meta-analysis with results from the 2 articles that used the segmental technique was completed. The combined mean estimates of intrusion and 95% CI were 1.46 mm (1.05–1.86 mm) for the maxillary incisors and 1.90 mm (1.22–2.57 mm) for the mandibular incisors.

Citation: Ng J, Major PW, Heo G, Flores-Mir C. True incisor intrusion attained during orthodontic treatment: a systematic review and meta-analysis. American Journal of Orthodontics and Dentofacial Orthopedics 2005; 128(2): 212-219.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Validation of self-reported periodontal disease: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PERIODONTAL DISEASE,PERIODONTOLOGY,DIAGNOSIS]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Based on the literature synthesized, self-report shows good potential for the assessment of periodontal disease

Methods: A systematic review of 16 studies that assessed the validity of self-reported periodontal and gingivitis measures against clinical gold standards. Literature published between 1966 to June 2004 was sought.

Quality of Review:  Key papers may have been missed owing to the limited nature of the search strategy - only one database (Medline) and reference list checking.  Unpublished research was not sought and this could have introduced publication bias.  It is unclear whether non-English language papers were included.

The authors do not report a formal method of assessing the validity of the included papers.  However, they do provide an overview of study quality in the discussion.

Results: The review indicates that some measures showed promise, but results varied across populations and self-reported measures.

One example of a good measure is, "Has any dentist/hygienist told you that you have deep pockets?", which had a sensitivity of 55%, a specificity of 90%, positive predictive value of 77%, and negative predictive value of 75% against clinical pocket depth.

Higher validity could be potentially obtained by the use of combinations of several self-reported questions and other predictors of periodontal disease.

Full Citation: Blicher B, Joshipura K, Eke P. Validation of self-reported periodontal disease: a systematic review. Journal of Dental Research 2005; 84 (10): 881-890

Access: Full text online access is available to NHS staff in England via ATHENS passwords. To apply for an ATHENS password and access this resource and many others please go to the ATHENS registration page .

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Water Fluoridation and health
document.topics: <![CDATA[ OUTCOMES,DETERMINANTS,ENVIRONMENTAL,ENVIRONMENT,ORAL HEALTH DISORDERS,ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,DENTAL PUBLIC HEALTH,CAUSES & PREVENTION,DENTAL CARIES,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,PUBLIC HEALTH,RESEARCH METHODS,METHODS,ANALYSIS & RESEARCH]]>
document.body:
LAY SUMMARY

The practice of adding fluoride to drinking water to improve dental health has been endorsed by numerous national and international health institutions, including the World Health Organization. It has been argued that in communities with piped water supplies it is the most cost-effective method of reaching the whole population, particularly children with a high risk of tooth decay.

Much of the evidence that links water fluoridation to improved dental health comes from research conducted several decades ago. The Department of Health therefore commissioned the NHS Centre for Reviews and Dissemination at the University of York to produce an up to date review of the topic, looking at relevant studies.

The York review, published in September 2000 - Fluoridation of Drinking Water: a Systematic Review of its Efficacy and Safety  - confirmed the beneficial effects of water fluoridation on dental caries (cavities), but also highlighted the increased prevalence of dental fluorosis (a defect of the enamel ranging from mild speckling to more gross effects) associated with fluoridation. The review concluded that little high quality research had been carried out on the broader question of fluoride and health, and that the available evidence did not allow confident estimates to be made of other possible risks to health or of the benefits of water fluoridation in reducing dental health inequalities.

In light of these findings the Medical Research Council, at the request of the Department of Health, set up the present Working Group to consider what further research is required to improve knowledge about fluoridation and health. This report aims to identify areas of uncertainty regarding the balance of benefits and risks of water fluoridation, and to make appropriate recommendations for research to address these uncertainties. 

With regard to public knowledge and understanding of the fluoridation issue, this report identifies additional information needed by the public to make informed decisions. For example, better information is needed on the prevalence of different forms of dental fluorosis (and their visual/aesthetic impact) and on similar looking tooth defects that are not associated with fluoridation.

Because of the wide use of toothpastes and other dental health care products containing fluoride, and the potential for fluoride exposure from a number of other sources, it is especially important to understand better the total exposure that individuals are experiencing. This knowledge should then be used in any future studies on the impact of water fluoridation. It is also important to gain a better understanding of any differences there might be in the uptake of fluoride from artificially fluoridated as opposed to naturally fluoridated water; and to determine the impact, if any, of the level of water hardness.  Trends in fluoride exposure, especially in children, need to be tracked.

Research recommendations on caries include the need to study the impact of water fluoridation on caries reduction in children against a background of widespread use of fluoride toothpaste, and to extend knowledge on how the effects of water fluoridation vary with social class. There is also a need to understand better the economic impacts and the effects of fluoridation on health and well-being beyond the usual measures of decayed, missing or filled teeth. Further work is warranted on the effects of fluoridation on dental health in adults.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: What impact do systemically administrated bisphosphonates have on oral implant therapy? A systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,SPECIALIST DENTISTRY,DENTO-FACIAL ANOMALIES,ORAL SURGERY,SPECIAL CARE DENTISTRY,CANCER PATIENTS,OLDER PEOPLE,OSTEONECROSIS OF THE JAW]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: From analysis of the included studies (217 patients), the placement of an implant may be considered a safe procedure in patients taking oral bisphosphonates (BPs) for <5 years with regard to the occurrence of bisphosphonate-related osteonecrosis of the jaw (BRONJ) since in these studies no BRONJ has been reported. Moreover, the intake of oral-BPs did not influence short-term (1-4 years) implant survival rates.

Methods: A narrative systematic review of four studies (one CCT, two case control studies and one case series). Review aim was to evaluate whether: i) patients on intravenous (IV) or oral BPs can receive oral implant therapy and what could be the risk of developing BRONJ;  ii) osseointegrated implants could be affected by BP therapy. Database search: to December 2008.

Quality of review: The results of this review should be viewed with caution given the limited data available and the poor quality of the included studies.

The authors appear to have made a reasonable attempt to identify relevant studies, searching four databases (Medline, Embase, Central and CDSR), supplemented by reference list checking. No search terms are provided. The search was restricted to published studies in the English language which may have introduced bias. No information is provided on the methods used to select, data extract and quality appraise included studies and the introduction of error and bias in these processes cannot be excluded. The quality of the four included studies was assessed and found to be poor with small sample sizes and short follow-up times.

Results: The prospective controlled clinical study followed patients with and without BP medication up to 36 months after implant therapy. The patients in the experimental group had been on oral BPs before implant therapy for periods ranging between 1 and 4 years. None of the patients developed BRONJ and implant outcome was not affected by the BP medication. The three retrospective studies yielded very similar results. All have followed patients on oral BPs after implant therapy, with follow-up ranging between 2 and 4 years.BRONJ was never reported and implant survival rates ranged between 95% and 100%. Among the guidelines, there is a consensus on contraindicating implants in cancer patients under IV BPs and not contraindicating dental implants in patients under oral BPs for osteoporosis.

Citation: Madrid C, Sanz M. What impact do systemically administrated bisphosphonates have on oral implant therapy? A systematic review. Clinical Oral Implants Research 2009; 20 Suppl 4: 87-95.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

BDA members can request a copy of this paper by submitting a BDA Library photocopy request form.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: Will targeted therapy hold its promise? An evidence-based review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,ORAL CANCER,TREATMENT & MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: Despite targeted therapy that has clearly benefited and even cured certain patients (eg, imatinib, trastuzumab), the ultimate goal of curing cancer, and the more immediate goal of replacing non-targeted chemotherapies with less toxic, targeted agents has yet to be achieved for most cancer patients. In head and neck squamous-cell carcinoma (HNSCC) cetuximab plus radiotherapy (versus radiotherapy alone) significantly improves locoregional control and survival (hazard ratio 0.68; p = 0.005) without worsening radiotherapy-related toxicity. [Note: results from one RCT]

Methods: A systematic review of randomised controlled trials to consider the evidence for the efficacy and tolerability of biologic agents and molecularly targeted therapies in the management of various cancers. [Note: data provided relates only to head and neck cancer.] Literature search to July 2007.

Quality of review: It is likely that key studies were missed as the literature search appears to have been restricted to electronic databases (Medline, Embase, Cochrane Library and a publisher’s proprietary database) using limited search terms. Hand searching, reference list checking, contacting experts and searching the grey literature may well have identified additional studies. Only published studies in the English language were included which may have introduced publication and language biases. The authors did not formally assess the quality of the included papers but did consider some quality elements (sample size, length of follow-up).

Results: [Note: the results extracted reflect data from a single RCT.] The median duration of locoregional disease control was 24.4 vs 14.9 months (HR 0.65; p=0.005) after a median follow-up of 54 months, median overall survival was 49.0 vs 29.3 months (HR 0.74; p=0.03).

Citation: Murdoch D, Sager J.Will targeted therapy hold its promise? An evidence-based review. Current Opinions in Oncology. 2008; 20(1): 104-11.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Oral Health]]>
document.title: XRCC1 polymorphisms and cancer risk: a meta-analysis of 38 case- control studies
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,ORAL DISORDERS,ORAL CANCER,RISK FACTORS]]>
document.body:
This record is a critical summary produced by NHS Evidence - oral health. For further details see our Quality Policy.

 

Authors' conclusions: In conclusion, our current study support that XRCC1 Arg194Trp polymorphism may contribute to individual susceptibility of cancers. To further evaluate gene-to-gene and gene-to-environment interactions on XRCC1 polymorphisms and cancer risk, a single larger study with thousands of subjects and tissue-specific biochemical and biological characterizations are required.

Methods: A systematic review and meta-analysis of 38 case control studies to determine the cancer risk associated with XRCC1 polymorphisms.

Quality of review: It is likely that potentially relevant studies were missed. Only Medline was searched using highly restrictive search terms, supplemented by reference list checking. Only published studies were included and the authors note that publication bias may have influenced the results.  The authors provide only limited methodological information and the introduction of error and bias cannot be excluded. Whilst there is no formal quality assessment of the included studies, the authors comment on a number of quality-related issues. These include sample size (the largest effects were seen in the smaller studies), selection bias and lack of adjustment for demographic confounders.

Results: There was no overall effect either in recessive or dominant modeling for the Arg399Gln polymorphism, and compared with the wild Arg/Arg genotype, variant Gln/Gln homozygote was not associated with overall cancer risk. For the Arg194Trp, the variant genotypes (Trp/Trp + Arg/Trp), compared with the wild-type homozygote (Arg/Arg), were associated with a significantly decreased cancer risk (OR, 0.89; 95% CI, 0.81-0.98) for all tumor types without between-study heterogeneity. Similarly, we observed a fixed overall 19% increased risk of cancer for the variant genotypes (His/His + Arg/His) of the Arg280His polymorphism, compared with the wild homozygote (OR, 1.19; 95% CI, 1.00-1.42).

Citation: Hu Z, Ma H, Chen F, Wei Q, Shen H. Xrcc1 polymorphisms and cancer risk: a meta-analysis of 38 case- control studies. Cancer Epidemiology Biomarkers and Prevention 2005; 7(14):1810-18.

Access: Full-text online access of this article requires subscription to the journal. NHS staff please contact your local NHS library for further assistance. You can find your local library via the My Library home page.
